They are desperate, Your Majesty. And desperation makes men both grateful and suspicious. They remember 1204. They remember that the last time Latin armies came to 'help' Constantinople, those armies sacked the city and established a Latin emperor on the Byzantine throne. Whatever you offer them, they will wonder what you want in return.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Papal supremacy. Your Majesty, you say you have come to argue for this, but you must understand—you stand in a Council that has already declared itself superior to the Pope. They invoke the decrees of Constance. They claim that a general council, representing the universal Church, holds authority over any individual, including the Bishop of Rome. The French delegation would cheer if Eugenius were deposed tomorrow. If you stand before this assembly and proclaim papal supremacy, you will not convince them. You will confirm their suspicion that you are the Pope's creature, sent to undermine their legitimate reforms. You will lose whatever influence Castile has built.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: The Hussites. Yes, you have been warned of their military power, and wisely so. But there is more. The moderate Hussites here at Basel—the Utraquists, they call themselves—are not the radicals. The radicals remain in Bohemia, suspicious of any negotiation. The moderates want peace. They want their reforms recognized. They are willing to compromise on some matters. But the Church property question is not theological for them—it is political. Bohemian nobles seized those lands. Those nobles now hold power in Bohemia. Any settlement that demands property return means those nobles lose power, which means civil war in Bohemia, which means the moderates here cannot deliver what they promise. You speak of ending heresy and preventing theft. Noble goals. But ending heresy requires Bohemian cooperation, and preventing theft requires Bohemian nobles to surrender their gains. These goals may be mutually exclusive.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And finally—you say the Pope has given you authority to speak on his behalf. Your Majesty, forgive an old man's bluntness, but has he? I have seen no letter to the Council. No formal announcement. No papal bull declaring Juan of Castile as legate or representative. You have his blessing, yes. His trust, certainly. But when you stand before Cardinal Cesarini and the assembled fathers and claim to speak for Rome, they will ask: by what authority? A private conversation in the Vatican is not the same as formal appointment. If you overstate your mandate, you will be seen as presumptuous. If you understate it, you will be seen as powerless. Which role do you intend to play?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: I do not say these things to discourage you, Your Majesty. Your presence here matters. Granada's completion matters. But you have weeks, not months. You cannot solve what this Council has failed to solve in over a year. So I ask again, more precisely: of these four goals, which matters most? And what would success look like for you, knowing the constraints you face?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I show him the papal decree and section four specifically. I am not an official papal legate, but I do speak with his blessing and support. This is all put in writing. I will meet with the Utraquists and see if I can settle them the matter theologically. If I can get them to back down, returning church property becomes a matter between the individual nobles and the church. They have just seized lands unjustly. Could this work do you think? Has the council of Constance actually established consular supremacy? I am confused. I thought that this matter was not established. Tell me. I will listen to the Byzantines first before saying anything. I want to hear their position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott took the decree carefully, his aged eyes squinting at the Latin script in the fading light. He read Article Four slowly, lips moving slightly as he absorbed each phrase. When he finished, he set the document down with visible respect.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: This is more than I expected. His Holiness speaks of 'complete confidence' and 'apostolic blessing.' He declares your witness is testimony the Council fathers 'must hear.' This is not formal legation, no—but it is substantial. It gives you ground to stand upon.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Show this to Cardinal Cesarini when you address the Council. Let him see the Fisherman's Ring seal with his own eyes. It will not make you the Pope's legate, but it will prove you are not merely some foreign king meddling in Church affairs. You speak with Rome's encouragement, if not Rome's formal authority. That distinction matters, and the Cardinal will appreciate it.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your logic is sound in principle, Your Majesty. Separate the theology from the theft. Grant communion in both kinds—which Scripture supports—while refusing to legitimize seizure of Church lands. The Utraquists here might accept such terms. They are moderates. They want reconciliation.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But consider: the Utraquist delegation does not speak for Bohemia. They speak to Bohemia. Behind them stand the nobles who hold actual power—men who seized abbeys and monasteries and now draw rents from those properties. These nobles sent the Utraquists to Basel not because they desire theological peace, but because they want their theft sanctified by Church agreement. If the Utraquists return to Prague with terms that say 'you have your communion, but you must return the lands,' those nobles will reject the settlement entirely. The moderates will be discredited. The radicals—the Taborites, who believe all Church property is an abomination—will gain strength.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And there is another complication. The Hussites justify the seizures theologically. They cite evangelical poverty—Christ and His apostles owned nothing, therefore the Church should own nothing, therefore seizing Church wealth is restoring proper Christian practice. When you say 'this is theft,' they say 'this is reform.' You are not merely arguing property law. You are arguing ecclesiology. What is the Church? What should it own? What is its proper relationship to worldly wealth?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Can your approach work? Perhaps. If you can convince the Utraquists that evangelical poverty as a principle is compatible with respecting existing Church property—that reform means future simplicity, not retroactive seizure—you might thread the needle. But you would need to be extraordinarily persuasive. And even then, the Bohemian nobles must be compelled to return what they've taken. By whom? With what force? Emperor Sigismund has tried for fifteen years and failed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's expression shifted when you asked about Constance. He sat back, his voice taking on the tone of a teacher addressing a crucial misunderstanding.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Ah. Now we come to the heart of it. You ask if Constance established conciliar supremacy. The answer is: they claimed to, and that claim is precisely what this entire crisis is about.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: In 1415, with three rival popes each claiming legitimacy and Christendom torn apart, the Council of Constance issued a decree called Haec Sancta—'This Holy Council.' It declared, in language that could not be clearer, that the Council holds its authority directly from Christ. That everyone—everyone, including the Pope—is bound to obey the Council in matters of faith, ending schism, and Church reform. They used this decree to depose all three rival popes and elect Martin V, ending the Great Schism.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Then they issued Frequens, requiring that general councils meet regularly—first after five years, then seven, then every ten years perpetually. Pope Martin V accepted his election by the Council. He acknowledged Frequens and convened this Council of Basel according to its requirements.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But here is where ambiguity becomes crisis. Martin V never explicitly endorsed Haec Sancta as permanent constitutional law. He accepted it as an emergency measure to end schism—not as a permanent subordination of papal authority to conciliar vote. When he died and Eugenius succeeded him, Eugenius took the same view: Constance solved a crisis, it did not rewrite the Church's constitution. The Pope remains supreme in his proper sphere.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: The Council fathers here invoke Haec Sancta as settled law. They say: Constance established our supremacy, the Pope must obey. Eugenius says: Constance was emergency measure, I am not bound by it. When he tried to dissolve this Council, they declared his dissolution invalid because Haec Sancta means they answer to no pope. When he summoned them to meet in Italy instead, they refused because Frequens says Basel was properly convened. They have even summoned him to appear before them—citing Constance's authority.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: This is not settled law, Your Majesty. This is open constitutional war. Both sides cite Constance, both interpret it differently, and neither will yield. If you argue for papal supremacy, you argue against Haec Sancta. If you argue for conciliar authority, you argue against the Pope who just blessed your crusade. There is no neutral ground. There is only choosing which interpretation of Constance you support—and living with the enemies that choice creates.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Listening first is wise. Wiser than most Western lords manage. The Greeks have been lectured to for eight months about Latin theological superiority. They have been told their Filioque rejection is error, their liturgical practices are deficient, their entire Eastern tradition is somehow lesser. They are proud men representing an ancient empire, and they have been treated as supplicants come to beg correction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose slowly from his chair, his joints protesting.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Hear their fears before you offer solutions. Learn what they actually need—not what we assume they need. They may surprise you. They may also test you. Bessarion is brilliant, a scholar who thinks in systems. Isidore is more practical, more political. Both are desperate enough to make deals but proud enough to reject condescension.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott moved toward the door, then paused.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: One more thing, Your Majesty. When you meet them, remember: they did not come to Basel to become Latin. They came hoping to remain Orthodox while receiving Latin swords. Every word you speak, they will weigh for signs of forced conversion, of theological imperialism, of another Fourth Crusade. If you can convince them you want to save Constantinople, not Latinize it, you may find them more receptive than you expect.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bowed stiffly.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Shall I send word to Metropolitan Bessarion that you will receive them tomorrow? And would you prefer I attend, or would you meet them alone?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets talk about the powers of the pope versus that of the council. There is no clear legal or even moral argument that is much better than the other in this matter. What will happen do you think if I say nothing about this and just let the council decide for itself? Can this council elect a new pope? The last council clearly did and could this council not do so again? What do you think will happen?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott had been reaching for the door handle. Your question stopped him mid-motion. He turned back, and something in his expression shifted—a sharpening of focus, as if you had finally asked the question he had been waiting for. He returned to his chair, lowering himself with renewed purpose.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Now you are thinking like a king who understands what is truly at stake.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Can this Council elect a new pope? Legally, canonically, by precedent—yes. Constance did so. They deposed three rival popes and elected Martin. If Basel declares Eugenius deposed for contumacy—for refusing to submit to conciliar authority—and elects a new pope, they have Constance as their precedent. They would say they are not innovating. They are following established procedure.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty, there are fathers here who want exactly that. The French delegation would celebrate. Cardinal Louis Aleman—who presides when Cesarini is absent—is a fierce conciliarist who believes Eugenius is a tyrant. Some Germans support deposition as the only way to force reform. Even some Italians who despise Eugenius personally would accept a new pope if it meant ending this paralysis.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But consider what happens if they do. Eugenius will not accept deposition. He will remain in Rome, claiming he is the true pope. He has loyal cardinals—twenty-three signed your decree, yes? Those cardinals will not recognize Basel's pope. You will have two popes again. Not three as in the Great Schism, but two. And this time, one will be elected by a Council that claims supreme authority, the other will be the sitting pontiff who claims councils cannot depose him. Christendom will split. Every kingdom, every diocese, every monastery will have to choose: Basel's pope or Rome's pope. Another schism, Your Majesty. Perhaps worse than the last.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's hands gripped the chair arms.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: You ask what happens if you say nothing and let the Council decide. I will tell you what happens. Your silence will be interpreted. The French will say: 'Castile does not oppose us, therefore Castile accepts conciliar supremacy.' The papal loyalists will say: 'Castile received the Pope's blessing and now abandons him—they are cowards or traitors.' Cardinal Cesarini will wonder why the king who returned the crusade treasury and received perpetual grants from Eugenius suddenly has no opinion on whether Eugenius should remain pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stood again, too agitated now to remain seated.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And there is more. You carry that decree. Article Five declares an alliance between Rome and Castile founded in shared faith. If this Council deposes Eugenius and you have said nothing to defend him, what is that alliance worth? What does your word mean? You accepted his grants—the Military Orders in perpetuity, his support for Alfonso's Naples claim, his letters of blessing. You took everything he offered. And when his enemies moved to destroy him, you stood silent?

encounters.recap: Abbott Rodrigo González briefs Juan II on the complex political and theological dynamics at the Council of Basel. He explains the procedural complexity that makes decision-making slow, the factions involved (French conciliarists, divided Germans and Italians), and the key issues: papal supremacy versus conciliar authority, the Hussite property question, and Byzantine pleas for military aid. The Abbott warns that neutrality is impossible—remaining silent on papal authority would be interpreted as abandonment of Eugenius IV, potentially leading to another papal schism if the Council elects a rival pope.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty, there are fathers here who want exactly that. The French delegation would celebrate. Cardinal Louis Aleman—who presides when Cesarini is absent—is a fierce conciliarist who believes Eugenius is a tyrant. Some Germans support deposition as the only way to force reform. Even some Italians who despise Eugenius personally would accept a new pope if it meant ending this paralysis.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaned forward, his aged eyes burning with intensity.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But consider what happens if they do. Eugenius will not accept deposition. He will remain in Rome, claiming he is the true pope. He has loyal cardinals—twenty-three signed your decree, yes? Those cardinals will not recognize Basel's pope. You will have two popes again. Not three as in the Great Schism, but two. And this time, one will be elected by a Council that claims supreme authority, the other will be the sitting pontiff who claims councils cannot depose him. Christendom will split. Every kingdom, every diocese, every monastery will have to choose: Basel's pope or Rome's pope. Another schism, Your Majesty. Perhaps worse than the last.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's hands gripped the chair arms.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: You ask what happens if you say nothing and let the Council decide. I will tell you what happens. Your silence will be interpreted. The French will say: 'Castile does not oppose us, therefore Castile accepts conciliar supremacy.' The papal loyalists will say: 'Castile received the Pope's blessing and now abandons him—they are cowards or traitors.' Cardinal Cesarini will wonder why the king who returned the crusade treasury and received perpetual grants from Eugenius suddenly has no opinion on whether Eugenius should remain pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stood again, too agitated now to remain seated.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: And there is more. You carry that decree. Article Five declares an alliance between Rome and Castile founded in shared faith. If this Council deposes Eugenius and you have said nothing to defend him, what is that alliance worth? What does your word mean? You accepted his grants—the Military Orders in perpetuity, his support for Alfonso's Naples claim, his letters of blessing. You took everything he offered. And when his enemies moved to destroy him, you stood silent?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's voice softened, but his words remained sharp.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I understand the appeal of neutrality. You wish to avoid making enemies. You wish to focus on Hussites and Byzantines, matters where you see clear moral ground. But this Council's central question—who rules the Church, Pope or Council—is not a side issue you can avoid. It is the issue. Everything else flows from it. If the Council is supreme, they can negotiate with Hussites however they wish, regardless of papal objection. If the Pope is supreme, Basel's decrees mean nothing without his approval. Your other goals cannot be separated from this constitutional crisis.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved to the window, staring out at the cathedral spire.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: I do not tell you that you must argue for absolute papal supremacy. That would indeed make enemies here. But silence is not neutrality—it is abandonment of the man who just gave you everything you asked for. There are positions between 'the Pope is absolute monarch' and 'the Council can depose him at will.' Perhaps the path is arguing that both Pope and Council have proper spheres—that reform requires cooperation, not domination. That Basel's legitimate reforms deserve papal approval, and the Pope's legitimate authority deserves conciliar respect. A middle way.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turned back to face you.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But even that middle way requires you to speak. To say clearly: 'I do not support deposing Eugenius. I do not support schism. I support reform through reconciliation, not revolution.' Can you say that much, at least? Or will you truly stand silent while they decide whether to tear the Church in two?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am not a church member, I am a king who seeks to be a good Christian and I am here primarily to see how I as a king can help our brothers in faith in Constantinople. Winning wars is after all not a matter of theology but of warfare. I don't know the former but do know the latter. My faith and grants from the vatican are well-known; they allowed me to finish the reconquuista and God willing I continue my work in service of god fighting the Ottomans. When the church is divided, this becomes very difficult. On matters regarding reform, my delegation is very clear and I hope their arguments have found root. Regarding the important issue of concilliar supremacy, I cannot argue either way on legal grounds. It is not my task or responsibility to do so. I do benefit greatly from a united church and this is my appeal to this council. Reform on it's merits and try to seperate the issue of reform from supremacy. Please find a way to stay united somehow. The church's flock needs a unified church, not another scism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott listened carefully, his expression unreadable as you laid out your proposed position. When you finished, he remained silent for a long moment, his fingers steepled beneath his chin.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: The unity appeal has power, Your Majesty. Genuine power. When you speak of the flock needing a unified Church, when you frame yourself as the warrior who needs a united Christendom to fight the Ottomans—that will resonate. Men here are weary of schism. They remember the chaos of three popes. They do not want to repeat it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved back to his chair, sitting heavily.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: And focusing on Constantinople is strategically sound. It gives you purpose beyond the constitutional debate. No one can accuse you of meddling in theology when you speak of saving Christian brothers from Turkish swords. That part works.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His tone sharpened.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty, you cannot stand before this Council holding that document and claim to be merely a king with no stake in Church matters. You carry the Fisherman's Ring seal. Article Five declares an alliance between Rome and Castile founded in shared faith. Article Four says you come with papal blessing to remind the Council fathers what their debates truly concern. You accepted perpetual grants that bind all future popes. You are entangled in Church matters, by your own choice and the Pope's explicit favor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott leaned forward intently.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: When you say 'I cannot argue either way on legal grounds,' the French will hear: 'He knows we are right but fears to say it.' When you say 'it is not my task to decide,' Cardinal Cesarini will wonder why the Pope trusted you if you refuse to defend him. When you plead for unity without stating what unity means, both sides will claim you for their own or dismiss you as a coward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He softened slightly.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: There is a path here. But it requires you to say something about the supremacy question—not as a theologian, but as a faithful king. You need not declare the Pope absolute monarch over all councils. But you must say clearly: 'I do not support deposing Eugenius. I do not support electing a rival pope. I support reform through cooperation, not through schism.' That much, at least, you owe the man who gave you those grants.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He studied your face.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Can you say that much? That you oppose deposition and schism, even if you claim no competence on the finer legal questions?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Just theoretically abott, what if I support the conciliarists? I have recieved support, yes, but I could say that my judgement based on moral and judicial grounds are seperated from any help I have recieved. What support does the pope have left? If we support the church and the council as supreme, would they start a new election? possibly elect pope Eugenius then, now using council election mechanics?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's face went very still. For a long moment, he said nothing, his eyes fixed on you with an expression that mixed alarm with something approaching disbelief.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, do you hear what you are proposing? You would stand before Christendom and say: 'Three days ago I knelt before Pope Eugenius, kissed his ring, accepted his perpetual grants, formed an alliance sealed with the Fisherman's Ring, and received his complete trust. Now I declare that councils are supreme over popes and by extension support his potential deposition.' And you believe you can separate your judgment from the help you received?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose from his chair with more energy than his aged frame usually permitted.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: No one will believe that separation, Your Majesty, because it is not believable. It is sophistry. You accepted the grants. You carry the decree in your saddlebag. You gave the Pope your word—not explicit perhaps, but implicit in every action. When a man kneels before the Pope and accepts his blessing, he does not then support those who would depose him. Not three days later. Not ever.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He began pacing, his robes swishing against the floor.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: And your question about re-election reveals you do not understand what is happening here. The conciliarists do not wish to depose Eugenius and then re-elect him under their authority. That gains them nothing. They want to break papal resistance to conciliar supremacy. If they depose Eugenius, they will elect someone who accepts that councils are supreme—who will sign whatever they place before him, who will be their creature. Cardinal Louis Aleman perhaps, or another who shares their views.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott stopped pacing and faced you directly.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Eugenius will not accept deposition. He will remain in Rome claiming legitimacy. His loyal cardinals—those twenty-three who signed your decree—will not recognize Basel's pope. You will have schism. Two popes, two obediences, Christendom split in two. And you, King of Castile, will be known as the man who betrayed the Pope who blessed his crusade. The man whose word means nothing. The man who took everything Rome offered and then stabbed Rome in the back.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice softened slightly, but his gaze remained intense.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: What support does Eugenius have left? More than you might think. He has the Papal States, however embattled. He has loyal Italian cardinals. He has the legitimacy of succession from Martin V. He has England's cautious support. He has the Iberian kingdoms—Portugal, Aragon, and until this moment, Castile. If you abandon him, you encourage others to do the same. You weaken him precisely when your alliance was meant to strengthen him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott moved closer, lowering his voice.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I must ask—what is driving this thinking? Three days ago you wept before Eugenius, begging him to protect your faith in the Church's purity. Now you contemplate supporting those who would depose him? Is this strategy, or is this fear of the harder path? Because if you support the conciliarists to avoid conflict, you will create far greater conflict. And you will have destroyed something precious—your reputation as a man whose word can be trusted, whose oaths mean something, whose faith is genuine rather than convenient.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stepped back.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: You asked what I think. I think this path leads to dishonor. I think it leads to schism. I think it makes you an oath-breaker in the eyes of Christendom. And I think, Your Majesty, that you already know this, which is why you framed it as 'theoretical.' Some theories should remain theoretical.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I hope I do understand a bit about the situation here father. I was only asking the question hypothetically to grasp the adges of papal control and support. But what I do not yet understand is this; this council has been adopting measures about many things already. About clergy having only one title at max. Does the pope recognize these measures?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's expression shifted from alarm to something more measured. He nodded slowly, seeming to understand that you were probing the edges of a complex situation rather than truly contemplating betrayal.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Ah. Now that is the question that reveals the full absurdity of where we stand. The answer is: no. And yes. And it depends on who you ask.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He held up a hand before you could respond.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: The Council has passed reform decrees, yes. Measures against pluralism—holding multiple benefices. Regulations on papal taxation of national churches. Procedures requiring future councils to meet regularly. These decrees were voted upon properly, approved by three of four deputations, proclaimed in general congregation. By the Council's own authority—which they claim from Constance's Haec Sancta—these are now binding law of the Church.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice took on a sardonic edge.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But Eugenius has not approved them. He has not signed them. He has not issued papal bulls confirming them. He cannot, because doing so would acknowledge the Council's authority to legislate without his approval. If he signs their decrees, he admits they have power to bind the Church. If he refuses to sign, he can claim the decrees are invalid without papal confirmation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott spread his hands.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: So we have reform decrees that the Council says are law and the Pope says are proposals awaiting his approval. Bishops return to their dioceses uncertain whether they must obey Basel's rules on benefices or whether they can ignore them pending papal confirmation. Abbots wonder if the taxation reforms apply or not. The entire Church exists in legal chaos because no one knows whose authority is valid.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaned forward.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: This is precisely why the supremacy question cannot be separated from reform. Every reform decree Basel passes is only as valid as Basel's authority to pass it. If the Pope is supreme, these decrees mean nothing until he approves them. If the Council is supreme, they are already binding law. The two questions are inseparable, Your Majesty. You cannot support the reforms without implicitly supporting the authority that enacted them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes narrowed thoughtfully.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: There is a path out of this tangle. If Eugenius and the Council reconciled—if he acknowledged the Council as legitimate and they acknowledged his approval was needed for decrees to bind—then both authorities would be preserved. Reform would proceed with proper sanction. But that reconciliation requires someone to bridge the gap. Someone both sides might trust.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So I would advocate for the pope to sign these laws into force and this would be the new procedure? The council debates and accepts laws and the pope signs them into law? But would this not create a stalemate? What if the pope never confirms anything the council proposes?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's weathered face creased into something almost like a smile—the expression of a teacher whose student has finally grasped the difficulty of the problem.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Now you see it, Your Majesty. Now you understand why this Council has raged for over a year with no resolution. Yes, that is precisely the danger. If the Pope must confirm all decrees, he becomes a veto. He can refuse any reform he dislikes, claiming it exceeds proper conciliar authority. The Council passes measures against simony—the Pope refuses to sign because the language threatens papal revenue. The Council limits multiple benefices—the Pope delays indefinitely because it affects curial appointments. Nothing changes. The conciliarists' nightmare.

encounters.recap: Abbott Rodrigo warns Juan that neutrality on papal deposition will be seen as betrayal by both sides. Juan proposes positioning himself as a warrior-king focused on Constantinople, seeking Church unity without taking sides on conciliar supremacy. The Abbott finds merit in this approach but insists Juan must at minimum oppose deposition and schism. When Juan theoretically explores supporting the conciliarists, the Abbott strongly rebukes this as oath-breaking that would create schism. They discuss how existing Council reforms exist in legal limbo without papal confirmation, illustrating why the supremacy question cannot be separated from reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's weathered face creased into something almost like a smile—the expression of a teacher whose student has finally grasped the difficulty of the problem.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Now you see it, Your Majesty. Now you understand why this Council has raged for over a year with no resolution. Yes, that is precisely the danger. If the Pope must confirm all decrees, he becomes a veto. He can refuse any reform he dislikes, claiming it exceeds proper conciliar authority. The Council passes measures against simony—the Pope refuses to sign because the language threatens papal revenue. The Council limits multiple benefices—the Pope delays indefinitely because it affects curial appointments. Nothing changes. The conciliarists' nightmare.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But reverse it. If the Council can legislate without papal approval, the Pope becomes a figurehead. They pass whatever they wish. They strip papal authority piece by piece. They rewrite Church governance to their liking. The Pope's nightmare. And likely schism, because no pope will accept being reduced to a ceremonial bishop who signs whatever Basel demands.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott rose and moved to the window, gazing out at the darkening sky.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: This is why both sides fight so fiercely over supremacy. Neither trusts the other with final authority. And truthfully? Perhaps neither should be trusted with absolute power. Popes have been corrupt—selling offices, living in luxury while preaching poverty, ignoring genuine calls for reform. But councils have been dangerous too—Constance burned Jan Hus despite his safe conduct, and many here would burn more if given the chance. The only path through this impasse is mutual trust, which does not exist. The Pope would need to trust that the Council will reform genuine abuses rather than strip his legitimate authority. The Council would need to trust that the Pope will approve genuine reforms rather than veto everything that threatens his power.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Someone must build that trust, Your Majesty. Someone must convince both sides that cooperation serves them better than conflict. That the Pope approving conciliar reforms strengthens rather than weakens him—because it shows he supports genuine reform and is not the tyrant they claim. That the Council seeking papal approval strengthens rather than weakens them—because it gives their reforms legitimacy that unilateral action cannot.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: This is where your position might actually serve. Not arguing for papal supremacy, not arguing for conciliar supremacy, but arguing for cooperation. You could say: 'I am a king who rules with my Cortes. I propose laws, they debate them, we find agreement. Neither I nor they have absolute power, and this makes Castile stronger, not weaker. Perhaps Pope and Council might find similar accommodation.' But I warn you—this middle path has few friends. The French want clear conciliar victory. Papal loyalists want clear papal victory. Men who preach compromise are often despised by both sides as either cowards or traitors. Are you prepared for that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think I will argue for reform first. Reform under a temporary procedure. I will advocate that the pope signs these new measures if they also bear his approval. Hopefully this creates some space and trust moving forward. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: There is wisdom here, Your Majesty. Real wisdom. You avoid the trap of declaring supremacy while still advocating for papal involvement. 'Temporary procedure' sidesteps the permanent constitutional question. And focusing on reform first gives you common ground—everyone here claims to want reform, whatever their true motives. But the devil, as always, lurks in the details. Let me pose the questions that will be thrown at you immediately.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: First: the Council has already passed reform decrees. On pluralism. On papal taxation. On future council procedures. They consider these valid law, enacted under their Constance authority. Will you ask them to re-submit these decrees for papal approval? They will see that as surrender—admitting their previous actions were invalid without the Pope's signature. The French will refuse outright. Second: what does 'temporary' mean? Six months? A year? Until the supremacy question is resolved? If you cannot define the timeframe, both sides will assume the worst. The Pope will think you're trapping him into permanent subordination. The Council will think you're buying time for papal resistance.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Third: you say the Pope signs measures 'if they also bear his approval.' What happens when he disapproves? The Council passes a decree limiting papal revenue from annates. The Pope refuses to sign. Is the decree dead? Does the Council revise it? Who decides if his objection is legitimate concern or obstruction? You have not solved the stalemate—you have merely delayed it. And fourth: who proposes this procedure to the Pope? You have his trust, yes. But you are here in Basel. He is in Rome. Do you send a letter suggesting he submit to conciliar authority, even temporarily? How will that letter read to a Pope already feeling besieged?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: I do not say your idea is wrong, Your Majesty. I say it is incomplete. If you stand before the Council and propose this, you must have answers to these questions. Otherwise, you will be seen as naive—a well-meaning king who does not understand Church politics. Tell me: when you say the Pope signs measures that 'bear his approval,' do you mean he can reject any decree he dislikes? Or do you mean something else? And what do you propose for the decrees the Council has already passed?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I have answers to these questions, yes. I will ask the pope to sign exactly the same law. This way, neither side is supreme over the other. We all want reform and we should find common cause instead of grounds of division. Temporary for these laws only. Nothing more. Meaning that this does not create precedent or time pressure. Both sides want reform and are worried that the method of enacting it will diminish their power. We must instead focus on the matters at hand. If the pope disapproves we are exactly where we are right now. In the stalemate of differing jurisdictions. I will propose it, using the best measures available to me.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: You have thought on this more carefully than I credited, Your Majesty. The framing is clever—asking the Pope to sign exactly the same laws avoids the humiliation of resubmission. Neither side surrenders. Both claim they enacted reform. That has elegance. And 'temporary for these laws only' sidesteps the precedent question. You are not proposing permanent constitutional settlement. You are proposing practical solution for immediate reforms. That may appeal to moderates weary of theoretical warfare.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty, there are two gaps in your thinking that will be exploited immediately. First: the Council fathers here believe their decrees are already valid law. They were properly debated, properly voted, properly proclaimed. From their view, asking the Pope to sign them is asking him to acknowledge what is already true, not to make them true. You frame it as cooperation. They will frame it as: 'Why should we seek approval for what we have already lawfully enacted?' The French especially will resist anything that implies their previous actions lacked validity.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Second, and more critical: you propose this for current reforms only. But what of future reforms? The Council is not finished. They have months, perhaps years, of work ahead. If your temporary procedure applies only to current decrees, what happens when they pass new measures next month? Do those require papal signature? If yes, you have created permanent procedure despite calling it temporary. If no, you have solved nothing—the supremacy question remains for all future legislation. The Council will ask you directly: 'King of Castile, you propose the Pope sign our current reforms. Do you propose he must sign all future reforms as well?' How do you answer that question?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The whole principle is that the council does not ask for approval at all. If the pope passes exactly the same law, it unites the church without establishing a procedure where the council asks the pope for permission. If anything, it reduces papal authority since they adopt exactly the council law, but I see no way around this, especially if I myself actually support these measures. The reason we are in this mess is because people conflate right procedure to enact reform. The church desperately needs reform. Solve this first and this makes the question of authority much less painful for both sides. We still need to establish good procedure, we do. My argument is that doing so becomes easier once critical reforms have passed.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Now that is a distinction worth making, Your Majesty. The Pope does not approve the Council's law. The Pope passes his own law that happens to be identical. Two authorities enacting the same reform independently. Neither asks permission of the other. Neither claims supremacy. Both claim credit for reform. It is clever. Perhaps too clever—some will see through the fiction immediately. But the fiction may be exactly what both sides need. A way to cooperate without admitting cooperation. A way to retreat from their positions without appearing to retreat.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But you admit it yourself—this reduces papal authority. You are asking Eugenius to enact whatever the Council passes, word for word. Even if he does so 'independently,' everyone will know he is following their lead. He becomes the one who signs what they write. That is a bitter draught for a Pope already feeling besieged. Have you considered how you will convince him to accept this?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: You carry his complete trust. You formed an alliance with him. You wept together about defending the Church. Now you will write to him—or perhaps visit him again?—and say: 'Holy Father, I propose you enact whatever Basel passes, exactly as they write it.' How do you imagine he will receive that counsel?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Your second point about solving reform first to ease procedural conflict—yes, there is logic there. Demonstrate cooperation works before demanding permanent settlement. But Your Majesty, time presses. How long before the Council passes new decrees? How long before the supremacy question forces itself back to the fore? You speak of making things easier. The conciliarists speak of deposing Eugenius now, while their momentum holds. They will not wait for your gradual trust-building.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: If you truly mean to propose this, you must move quickly. Speak to Cardinal Cesarini—he is the moderate who might champion such compromise. Speak to the Byzantine delegation—Constantinople's crisis might unite factions around common cause. And most importantly, you must know whether Eugenius will accept your proposal before you publicly champion it. Otherwise you promise what you cannot deliver. When do you intend to make this proposal? And to whom do you speak first—the Council, or the Pope?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I understand father. But this is just doing honest work. I do not know how to convince the pope of anything. I can only try. And I cannot do it right now for sure. Finally, I must ask if there has been discussions or proposals regarding a new pope by the council. And if so, what procedure did they propose?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's expression grew grave. He moved back to his chair and sat slowly, as if the weight of the question pressed upon him.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: You ask about papal election discussions. Yes, Your Majesty. There have been such discussions, though not yet formal procedures. In February of this year—just three months past—the Council issued a formal summons to Pope Eugenius. They commanded him to appear before them within sixty days to answer charges of contumacy. Contumacy, Your Majesty—willful disobedience to legitimate authority. They treat him as an accused criminal, not as Supreme Pontiff.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: When the sixty days passed and Eugenius did not appear—could not appear, for to do so would acknowledge their authority to summon him—the radicals began pushing for formal proceedings. Cardinal Louis Aleman, the Archbishop of Arles, leads this faction. He argues that if Eugenius refuses to submit to conciliar authority, he proves himself a tyrant and heretic against the decrees of Constance. Such a pope, Aleman claims, must be deposed.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: They have not yet begun formal deposition proceedings. The moderates—Cardinal Cesarini chief among them—have held them back. Cesarini still hopes for reconciliation. He negotiated that compromise with Eugenius last August, where the Pope acknowledged the Council's legitimacy while the Council softened its supremacy claims. A fragile peace.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: But that peace frays daily. Every week the radicals grow bolder. Every week Eugenius's refusal to cooperate feeds their arguments. If they do move to formal deposition, they would follow Constance's precedent: formal charges presented, trial conducted by the Council fathers, vote on removal, and then conclave to elect successor—but a conclave controlled by the Council itself, not the cardinals in Rome.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you arrive at a moment of balance. The radicals lack quite enough support for deposition—yet. The moderates hold the line—barely. Your voice, your presence, your authority from Granada's completion—these things have weight. If you speak for cooperation and reconciliation, you strengthen the moderates. If you remain silent or equivocate, the radicals will claim you fear to oppose them.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Emperor Sigismund arrives in Rome for coronation in three days. After that, he comes here—perhaps by late June or July. He too seeks to prevent schism. If you and he speak with one voice for reconciliation, you may tip the balance. But if you wait too long, the radicals may force the question before you can act.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you father. I know I have asked much of you. Thank you for your insight and knowledge. What time is it now?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott glanced toward the window. The last light of day had faded entirely while you spoke, and the room was now lit only by the guttering candles on the table. The spires of Basel's cathedral had become dark silhouettes against a purple-black sky.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: Past Compline, Your Majesty. Perhaps nine of the clock, or near to it. We have talked for hours. My old bones protest, and you have had a long journey. You have learned more of Basel's complexities in one evening than many delegates grasp in months. That speaks well of your mind, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved toward the door, then paused.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: The Byzantine metropolitans will be anxious for your answer. Brother Guillem's message will have bought you time, but not much. They have waited months for someone to take their plea seriously. If you mean to meet them tomorrow, I would suggest morning—their patience runs thin, and making them wait longer may be taken as insult rather than discretion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott bowed, his joints creaking audibly.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo
exchanges.text: I am lodged at the Augustinian house near the cathedral. Send word if you need me. And Your Majesty—pray on what we have discussed tonight. What does Castile's honor require of you here? Not what is strategically wise, but what is right. God grant you wisdom, and your Queen safe delivery. Good night, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He opened the door, letting in the cool night air of Basel.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a diplomatic compromise to the Council-Pope standoff: rather than seeking papal approval for conciliar reforms, he suggests the Pope independently pass identical laws, allowing both sides to claim authority over reform without subordination. Abbott Rodrigo provides detailed analysis of the proposal's merits and weaknesses, warns of radical factions led by Cardinal Aleman pushing for papal deposition, and emphasizes the urgent need for action before Emperor Sigismund's arrival shifts the political balance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sleep came fitfully. The merchant's bed was comfortable enough—better than many you'd known on campaign—but your mind churned through the Abbott's words long after you closed your eyes. Papal authority, conciliar supremacy, reform procedures, Byzantine desperation, Hussite defiance. Each thread tangled with the others until the whole tapestry seemed impossible to unravel. Somewhere in the small hours, you dreamed of Isabel. She stood in the Toledo Cathedral, one hand resting on her swollen belly, the other reaching toward you. But the distance between you stretched impossibly, and no matter how fast you walked, she remained beyond your grasp. You woke before dawn, throat dry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The streets of Basel lay quiet as you made your way toward the cathedral. Mist rose from the Rhine, threading between buildings like ghostly fingers. Your boots echoed on cobblestones still damp from overnight rain. Captain Robles had offered to accompany you, but you'd refused. This was not a king's business. This was a man's. The cathedral doors stood open even at this hour—Basel had become a city of perpetual theological activity, and some council father was always at prayer or debate. You entered the nave and found it nearly empty. A few monks knelt in distant corners. Candles flickered before the altar, casting dancing shadows across the stone pillars. You chose a spot away from others, knelt on the cold floor, and crossed yourself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your gaze wandered across the nave—the stone pillars rising into shadow, the distant altar with its flickering candles, the hunched forms of monks at their devotions. Nothing spoke to you. The cathedral remained what it was: cold stone shaped by human hands, indifferent to your turmoil. Then movement caught your eye. A figure knelt in a side chapel dedicated to the Virgin, partially obscured by a pillar. The man wore the red of a cardinal, his biretta set carefully on the pew beside him. His hands were clasped so tightly the knuckles had gone white, and his shoulders trembled with suppressed emotion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Giuliano Cesarini. You recognized him from the Abbott's descriptions—the papal legate who presided over this Council, the moderate voice trying desperately to prevent schism. The man who had consulted privately with Fray Hernando three times. The bridge-builder caught between two irreconcilable positions. He was weeping. Not the dignified tears of formal mourning, but the ragged, silent sobs of a man pushed beyond endurance. His lips moved in prayer, but no sound emerged. Before him, a single candle burned beneath a statue of Mary holding the infant Christ. The cardinal's eyes were fixed on that image—mother and child, protection and innocence—as if pleading for guidance he could not find.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rose quietly from your kneeling position, your joints protesting the cold stone. Moving slowly so as not to startle him, you walked toward the side chapel, your boots making soft sounds on the flagstones. When you reached a point perhaps ten paces from the chapel entrance, you stopped. And waited. The cardinal continued his silent prayer, shoulders still trembling. Minutes passed—five, perhaps ten. The dawn light through the cathedral windows grew stronger, shifting from grey to pale gold. Gradually, the trembling subsided. Cesarini drew a deep, shuddering breath. His hands unclenched. He reached up and wiped his face with his sleeve—an oddly human gesture for so elevated a churchman.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightened his back, squared his shoulders. The transformation was remarkable. The broken man reassembled himself piece by piece into the papal legate, the presiding officer of the Council, the diplomat who held Christendom's fragile peace in his hands. He reached for his biretta. That was when he turned slightly and saw you. Cesarini froze for just an instant—long enough for you to see the flash of alarm in his eyes, the realization that his moment of weakness had been witnessed. Then the mask settled fully into place. He rose from his knees with practiced grace, biretta in hand, and faced you.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. You are... abroad early.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Excuse me father, I did not want to intrude upon a person such as yourself or disturb you while at prayer. I came alone to pray this morning because my soul is heavy with worry about what path to take next. Yesterday, I had a long talk with my confessor and he advised me to seek guidance in the church every morning to guard my soul against temptation and sin. I know full well that the image, power and prestige I wield are significant. But what if I am wrong? I try to act out of love and compassion, but even those intentions can be twisted into divine justification for my actions. I was praying father for something. A sign, something to guide me. A light or some cornerstone in faith I can fall back on and reason from there. Align my actions along with it. What is even true in this world? What is from God's kingdom? When I saw you praying there all alone...I hope you can forgive me for approaching you. I was hoping you could pray with me for a moment if you would indulge me father. It would help and honour me greatly.

roll.outcome: Cardinal Cesarini at Prayer - The papal legate himself, alone and kneeling, tears on his face.

encounters.recap: Juan seeks spiritual guidance at dawn prayer in Basel Cathedral, where he discovers Cardinal Cesarini weeping alone. After waiting respectfully, Juan approaches with humility, confessing his doubts about his path and requesting to pray together. The encounter reveals both men struggling with the weight of their impossible burdens.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: You need not ask forgiveness, Your Majesty. A man who seeks guidance in prayer deserves no rebuke. Come. We shall pray together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved back to the kneeling rail before the Virgin's statue, making space for you beside him. As you knelt, he crossed himself and bowed his head. His hands folded with the ease of long habit. His voice took on the measured cadence of liturgical Latin—familiar, formal, safe. He offered prayers for wisdom, for guidance, for protection against pride and error.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks what is true in this world. What is from God's kingdom. The Church teaches that Scripture, Tradition, and the Magisterium together guide us toward truth. When we are uncertain, we submit ourselves to these authorities. You have completed a great work in Granada. God has blessed your arms. But you are right to question whether past blessing guarantees future righteousness. Continue to pray. Continue to seek counsel. Guard yourself against the sin of certainty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Where in this church may one find God father?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: There. In the Blessed Sacrament. Christ's true presence. But also... In the faithful at prayer. In the Word proclaimed from that pulpit. In the sacraments administered at that altar. Some days, Your Majesty, I confess God feels very far from this place. These halls echo with arguments about His Church, but the arguments themselves... Seek Him in the Eucharist. Seek Him in silence. Seek Him in the faces of the poor and suffering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan took the Cardinal and sat him down with him in the benches.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Be with us O lord, not when we gather in plain sight for all to see, but be with us in darkness. I do not know what to do o Lord. Fighting Moors in Granada seems so easy compared to crusades against fellow christians. How can I support such actions? You know my heart o Lord. You know how I long to protect Isabel and my little Catalina. I know that there may come a time when you make me choose between them and the path that leads to your kingdom. I fear I have lost your path o lord. I cannot see your light as I did before. I am not worthy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini had stiffened when you took his arm and guided him to the bench. His eyes widened slightly at the presumption—cardinals were not accustomed to being physically directed by anyone save the Pope himself. But he did not resist, and as your prayer poured forth, he remained seated beside you, listening in silence.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, what you describe is the dark night of the soul. When God seems absent, when His light is hidden, when every path seems wrong. This is not abandonment. This is purification. When we cannot see the path, we walk by faith. When we cannot hear God's voice, we obey His commandments. You speak of protecting your wife and child. This is holy. Continue in prayer, Your Majesty. Examine your conscience daily. Seek the counsel of your confessor. Dominus vobiscum. The Lord be with you. I will pray for your discernment. And for Queen Isabel's safe delivery.

roll.outcome: Uncomfortable Silence - Says nothing, clearly conflicted, offers only brief blessing

encounters.recap: Juan shares his spiritual anguish with Cardinal Cesarini in the cathedral, confessing his fears about crusading against fellow Christians and his struggle to see God's path. The Cardinal offers pastoral counsel about the dark night of the soul but maintains emotional distance, blessing Juan before departing for Council duties.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of Basel rang Terce—the third hour of prayer, mid-morning. You waited in the merchant's study, the window open to let in the spring air. Outside, you could hear the city's sounds: cart wheels on cobblestones, distant voices arguing in German, Latin, French. The Council city never truly fell silent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Shortly after the bells ceased, footsteps sounded on the stairs. Brother Guillem's voice, and two others speaking in accented Latin. A knock at the door.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Metropolitan Bessarion entered first. He was younger than you expected—perhaps forty, with a neatly trimmed dark beard and penetrating eyes that seemed to catalogue everything in the room within seconds. He wore the black robes and distinctive cylindrical hat of the Orthodox clergy, a golden pectoral cross resting against his chest. His bearing was that of a scholar: composed, watchful, precise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind him came Metropolitan Isidore, older by perhaps a decade, his beard longer and streaked with grey. Where Bessarion's gaze was analytical, Isidore's was political—he assessed you not as a puzzle to solve but as a potential ally or threat to weigh. His robes were similar to his companion's, though slightly more worn from travel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Both men stopped at a respectful distance and inclined their heads—not the full bow a Latin bishop might offer a king, but a gesture of courtesy between equals in faith.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. We thank you for receiving us. We have traveled far from Constantinople to seek aid for our people, and we have waited many months in this city of endless debates. You asked yesterday to hear our position. We are here. What would you know of us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Welcome and please take a seat. As you know I have just completed the reconquista and I will place my sword at the disposal of Christian cause and am willing to do so again. I know that my Granada conquest was relatively simple compared to fighting the Ottomans, but I genuinely feel I can offer you real aid should you be willing to accept it. Right now, that is all I have, a willingness to help you as best I can. But I must be real about my own limitations, nor would I want to impose myself on your faith and Empire. Before I move any further, I would like to learn about you. What is your position? How can I help? Do you even want help in the first place? What are your concerns? Maybe after we have taken the time to get to know each other, we can let this cooperation bear fruit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two metropolitans exchanged a glance—brief but unmistakable. Something passed between them, some shared recognition. Bessarion's expression, which had been carefully neutral, hardened almost imperceptibly. Isidore's lips pressed into a thin line. They took the offered seats, but their posture remained stiff. Formal. Distant.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. Your words are... respectful. We thank you for that courtesy. But Your Majesty will forgive us if we have heard such words before. Many times. From many latin lords.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: Eight months, Your Majesty. Eight months we have sat in this city while Western theologians debate whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father alone or from Father and Son together. Eight months while our emperor waits in Constantinople, watching the Ottoman noose tighten. Eight months of 'getting to know each other' and 'taking time' and 'understanding positions.'

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: You ask what our position is? Our position is simple: Constantinople will fall. Not in a generation. Not in a decade. Soon. Perhaps five years. Perhaps three. The Sultan masses troops. He builds new fortresses on our shores. He strangles our trade. And we—we sit here begging Latin princes who speak of 'willingness to help' while offering nothing concrete.

roll.outcome: Bitter Skepticism - See this as more Latin evasion, barely concealed frustration

encounters.recap: Juan meets privately with Byzantine Metropolitans Bessarion and Isidore, offering respectful cooperation and aid for Constantinople. However, his vague promises trigger bitter skepticism from the Byzantines, who have endured eight months of empty Western rhetoric while their empire faces imminent Ottoman conquest.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They took the offered seats, but their posture remained stiff. Formal. Distant.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. Your words are... respectful. We thank you for that courtesy. But Your Majesty will forgive us if we have heard such words before. Many times. From many Latin lords.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_isidore
exchanges.text: Eight months, Your Majesty. Eight months we have sat in this city while Western theologians debate whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father alone or from Father and Son together. Eight months while our emperor waits in Constantinople, watching the Ottoman noose tighten. Eight months of 'getting to know each other' and 'taking time' and 'understanding positions.'

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_bessarion
exchanges.text: You ask what our position is? Our position is simple: Constantinople will fall. Not in a generation. Not in a decade. Soon. Perhaps five years. Perhaps three. The Sultan masses troops. He builds new fortresses on our shores. He strangles our trade. And we— —we sit here begging Latin princes who speak of 'willingness to help' while offering nothing concrete. You say you completed the Reconquista. We congratulate you. You say you will place your sword at the Christian cause. Noble words. But Castile is far from the Bosphorus, Your Majesty. Very far. And words—even sincere words—do not stop Turkish cannons.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_isidore
exchanges.text: You ask if we even want help. What we want is for the West to remember that Constantinople has stood as Christendom's shield against Islam for a thousand years while your ancestors were still learning to read. What we want is for one—just one—Latin prince to offer troops, ships, gold, without first demanding we abandon our faith and submit to Rome. So, Your Majesty of Castile. You wish to help? Then tell us plainly: what will you give, and what will you demand in return? No more 'getting to know each other.' Our people die while we talk.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: 100,000 florins does Castile have in its treasury reserve. I commit it all to the cause of aiding you. I will petition the pope to release the crusade funds that were returned after a successful crusade against Granada. Together with my treasury, it will be about half a million florins. I have 800 crusaders here in Basel and most of them in Rome at the moment. They have been released from their crusader's vow and cannot command them into another crusade or war immediately, but I can ask them if they want to join me into a new war against the Ottomans. In Castile, I command about 5,000 soldiers from three orders who can set sail immediately should this be required. I have entered into an alliance with Aragon who will soon secure Naples. This gives me naval bases and a large fleet. I must confer with them but I have every expectation they will commit. I have founded an academy of Christian military commanders to come up with new tactics to fight the Ottomans. They have already educated officers and can provide doctrine for the army facing the Ottomans in the field. I myself will lead from the front like I did in Granada. I will not ask a man to do something I am not willing to do myself. I have faith that I can rally more kingdoms to come to your aid, especially when there is hope for victory. Hungary and Poland seemed eager to help. A brother in need...you do not ask what he offers you in return when he is about to drown. You just help. I have but one request. My wife is with child and I have made a promise to be by her side during childbirth. A promise I cannot break. You speak plainly, so I will do so as well. I must admit, there are still many unknowns in my plans. But this is what Castile, what I am committing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two metropolitans sat very still as you spoke. With each concrete number—one hundred thousand florins, five hundred thousand total, five thousand knights, eight hundred crusaders—their expressions shifted subtly. Bessarion's analytical eyes narrowed, calculating. Isidore's weathered face lost some of its bitter edge. When you finished, silence hung in the room for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_bessarion
exchanges.text: You... speak numbers. Actual numbers. Not 'the West will aid you' or 'Christendom must unite.' Numbers. Your Majesty, do you understand what you have just done? In eight months of pleading in this city, we have received theological lectures, promises to pray for our situation, and endless debates about whether our church is in error. You are the first—the first—Latin lord to speak of florins and soldiers rather than filioque clauses.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_isidore
exchanges.text: Half a million florins would fund a serious campaign. Five thousand Military Order knights are worth twice that number in regular infantry against the Turks. But— —the Pope must release those crusade funds. What makes you believe he will do so? Eugenius is embattled. His treasury is strained. Will he part with three hundred thousand florins on your request alone?

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_bessarion
exchanges.text: And your Military Orders—Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara. We know of them. Fearsome warriors. But their purpose has been Iberian crusade against the Moors. Will they follow their king across the Mediterranean to fight Ottomans? You say you command them, but do their Masters share your vision? The naval question is critical. Constantinople is accessible only by sea unless you march through Ottoman territory—which you cannot. Naples would provide staging ground, yes. But King Alfonso has his own wars to fight. His own treasury to manage. You say you have 'every expectation' of his commitment. Expectation is not certainty. And timing. You mention your wife's childbirth—we respect that. Family is sacred. But when would this aid arrive? Next year? The year after? The Sultan does not wait, Your Majesty. Each season he grows stronger while we grow weaker.

exchanges.speaker: metropolitan_isidore
exchanges.text: You say you ask nothing in return. No submission to Rome. No abandonment of our faith. We want to believe this. But the Pope who must release those funds—what will he demand? You are allied with him. You carry his blessing. Will he give three hundred thousand florins to save an Orthodox Constantinople that refuses Latin supremacy?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First, you must be willing to accept any aid offered. I want to know if my aid is even wanted. Many of the assets I command require activation or in the case of Naples, require some events to play out. But we can summon the Aragonese ambassador, who is here for just this purpose. And what aid does the Empire require right now? Are you under attack? How can my crusaders and military orders best be deployed? Don't worry about their loyalty, I command them fully and they are as loyal as any commander can be. My advice carries some weight with the pope. While you can understand I cannot speak for him, I have good faith that the treasury will be put at our disposal. Let's wait a moment for the ambassador to arrive.

roll.outcome: Genuine Engagement - Impressed despite themselves, begin discussing practicalities

encounters.recap: The Byzantine metropolitans initially express deep skepticism and frustration after eight months of fruitless negotiations in Basel. When Juan offers concrete military and financial commitments—500,000 florins, 5,000 knights, naval support through Naples—their hostility transforms into cautious but genuine engagement. They begin testing the practicalities of his proposals while Juan summons the Aragonese ambassador to demonstrate his alliance network.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Do we want aid? Your Majesty, we have crossed half of Christendom, left our churches and our people, sat in this city for eight months enduring theological condescension—all to beg for aid. Yes. We want aid. We are drowning. We have been drowning for decades. Constantinople wants to live.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: The question is not whether we want help. The question is whether we can accept help that comes with chains. But you say you attach no chains. So yes—if you offer what you say, we want it. Desperately.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You called for Brother Guillem and instructed him to fetch Don Bernat de Centelles immediately. The monk bowed and departed swiftly.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: You ask what we need immediately. We are not under direct siege—not yet. The Sultan consolidates his position, builds his strength. But the noose tightens. Our immediate needs are thus: First: naval strength. The Ottomans control the seas around us. We need galleys to keep supply lines open and to threaten Turkish coastal positions. Second: professional soldiers. Not peasant levies—trained men who can fight Turkish janissaries. Your Military Order knights would be invaluable. Third: artillery. The Sultan has cannons. Large ones. We need the same, or we need men who know how to counter them. Fourth: gold to hire mercenaries and repair our walls. Our treasury is exhausted.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: And fifth: hope. Our people need to know the West has not abandoned them. That someone remembers we are Christians too.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The door opened and Don Bernat de Centelles entered—a man in his mid-fifties with the weathered look of someone who had spent decades navigating Mediterranean politics. His clothing was fine but practical, his bearing that of a diplomat accustomed to difficult negotiations. He bowed to you first, then noticed the two Orthodox metropolitans in their distinctive black robes and cylindrical hats.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. You summoned me?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You gestured for him to sit and began explaining the situation—the Byzantine delegation's desperate need for military aid, the concrete commitments you had just outlined, and crucially, the papal decree that now explicitly supported King Alfonso's claim to Naples against René of Anjou.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: His Holiness has declared for King Alfonso formally? In writing? With the Fisherman's Ring seal? This changes much, Your Majesty. René of Anjou's claim rested heavily on papal favor. If Eugenius now supports my king openly... But I must be plain, Your Majesty. King Alfonso's primary concern is Naples. His treasury, his fleet, his armies—these are committed to securing that throne. You speak of Constantinople, of Ottoman wars, of crusading eastward. I am not authorized to commit Aragonese forces to campaigns beyond Naples. Such decisions rest with my king alone. What exactly do you propose regarding Aragon's role?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Our problem is that Castille has very few ships on it's own and has no bases nearby to operate from. Support from Aragon and it's new bases in Naples changes this situation doesn't it? My cousin Alfons has promised me aid should I secure papal backing for him in Naples. I understand you do not speak for the king, but this makes our position against the Ottomans better doesn't it?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Strategically? Yes, Your Majesty. Unquestionably. Naples changes everything for any Eastern operation. Without it, Castile must operate from... what? Valencia? The Balearics? Far too distant. Supply lines would stretch impossibly thin. But Naples sits in the heart of the Mediterranean. Sicily even more so. From there, you can reach Greek waters in days rather than weeks. King Alfonso commands one of the finest fleets in Christendom. Aragonese galleys are experienced in Mediterranean warfare. If Naples is secured—and with papal backing, that becomes far more likely—then yes, you would have access to ports, shipyards, and established naval infrastructure. However, Your Majesty, I must remind you—Naples is not yet secured. René of Anjou still presses his claim. Papal backing strengthens our position enormously, but there may yet be fighting. King Alfonso's immediate priority will be consolidating that throne. How quickly he could then turn attention eastward... That I cannot say.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: So the aid Castile offers depends upon Aragon securing Naples, and Aragon turning its attention from Italian wars to Ottoman ones. How long might this take, Ambassador? A year? Two years? Five?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your ability for Castille to lend aid does not solely depend on securing Naples honoured Bessarion. It does help a great deal, but it does not prevent it. We have some bases in Naples and Aragon controls the whole of Sicily, so we are not entirely without means. I will arrange with Aragon to secure Naples as soon as possible. But in the mean time, we must not delay our aid. What are Constantinople's defences? How can we reinforce best?

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
