exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: You hold that decree. You have his ear in ways I do not. If you could convince him that this approach—parallel authority, shared purpose, constitutional question unresolved but rendered less urgent through cooperation—if you could convince him this preserves his dignity while allowing genuine reform... What do you think, Your Majesty? Would Pope Eugenius accept such an approach? And what would you need from me—from the Council—to make this argument to him?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am not a member of the clergy. I look to the church for guidance and I expect reform. I blame the pope and the council both for not passing laws against this. Maybe we should pass the reforms first and issue a crusade first, and then look back at where we stand. And maybe just maybe, the next step will be much more clear than they are now. Father, this is the only road or way I see for the church to remain as one. But imagine how wonderful this would be as well. The church has expanded greatly the past centuries. What if we can unite into one single force, one single office. Would this not please the lord?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini allows himself a small, weary smile.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Reforms first, crusade first, and see where we stand. Your Majesty, this may be the wisest thing you have said today. Wiser, perhaps, than you realize.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He folds his hands on the table.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: We theologians and churchmen... we are trained to think in systems. We want to resolve the constitutional question before we act, because acting without resolution feels like building on sand. But you—you think like a king. Like a general. Take the ground that can be taken. Win the battle that can be won. Then see what the new position reveals. If we pass reforms—both Pope and Council, parallel legislation—and if we unite behind a crusade for Constantinople... we will have demonstrated cooperation. Not theorized it. Not debated it. Actually done it. And perhaps, as you say, the next step becomes clearer from that vantage point.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But then his expression grows more thoughtful.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: As for your vision of 'one single force, one single office'... Your Majesty, I confess I am not certain what you mean. Do you mean Pope and Council working as one? Or something more... structural? A reformed papacy? A permanent council?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: I ask because these words mean different things to different men. To the radicals, 'one single office' might mean abolishing papal supremacy entirely—the Council as permanent governing body with Pope as mere ceremonial figurehead. To papal loyalists, it might mean something else entirely. And if we are to advocate for this vision, we must be precise about what we are proposing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice softens slightly.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Would it please the Lord? I believe genuine unity would, yes. Christ prayed that His followers be one as He and the Father are one. But unity achieved through one side crushing the other is not the unity Christ intended. And unity that papers over genuine theological disagreement is not unity at all—it is merely postponed schism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Tell me plainly, Your Majesty: when you imagine this 'one single force'—what does it look like? Who leads? Who checks the leader? How are decisions made? Not the ideal you dream of, but the concrete structure you envision.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was merely talking about one church. However we choose to form it is up to us. And that is also a question we cannot answer right now. But how do we proceed from here father? We have a vision now. Should I address the council you think?

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a pragmatic approach: implement reforms and launch the crusade first, then reassess the constitutional question later. Cardinal Cesarini praises this 'take what ground can be taken' strategy but presses Juan to clarify his vision of church unity. Juan keeps his proposals deliberately vague, asking how to proceed with addressing the Council.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: I ask because these words mean different things to different men. To the radicals, 'one single office' might mean abolishing papal supremacy entirely—the Council as permanent governing body with Pope as mere ceremonial figurehead. To papal loyalists, it might mean something else entirely. And if we are to advocate for this vision, we must be precise about what we are proposing.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Would it please the Lord? I believe genuine unity would, yes. Christ prayed that His followers be one as He and the Father are one. But unity achieved through one side crushing the other is not the unity Christ intended. And unity that papers over genuine theological disagreement is not unity at all—it is merely postponed schism.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Tell me plainly, Your Majesty: when you imagine this 'one single force'—what does it look like? Who leads? Who checks the leader? How are decisions made? Not the ideal you dream of, but the concrete structure you envision.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was merely talking about one church. However we choose to form it is up to us. And that is also a question we cannot answer right now. But how do we proceed from here father? We have a vision now. Should I address the council you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini holds up a hand, a slight smile playing at his lips.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you ask if you should address the Council. And my answer is: not yet. Perhaps not at all, at least not in the way you imagine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stands and moves to a cabinet, retrieving a map which he spreads on the table between you. It shows the various delegations at Basel—French, German, Italian, Spanish, smaller contingents marked in different colors.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Basel is not a battlefield where one can rally troops with an inspiring speech. It is more like... a market, where every merchant protects his stall and watches his competitors jealously. If you, bearing a papal decree, stand before the general congregation and propose parallel legislation, what happens?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: The French radicals see: 'Rome's agent undermines our authority.' They mobilize against you. Cardinal Aleman has been waiting for just such an excuse to push harder for deposing Eugenius. The Italians become suspicious—why does Castile propose what seems to benefit the Pope? The Germans wonder if this is French-Spanish collusion or papal-Spanish conspiracy.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: What we need is not a grand address. We need careful, patient building of support. Coalition work. Private conversations with key figures.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Here is what I propose: First, we address the immediate crisis—Constantinople. The Byzantine delegation is still here. They need an answer, and you have made commitments. Let us give them that answer together. You announce your support—one thousand knights, sixty thousand florins. I, as Council President, endorse Castile's commitment and call for other Christian kingdoms to match it. This demonstrates cooperation between papal authority and conciliar authority on urgent matter.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Second, I quietly approach key moderates—the Germans especially, some reform-minded Italians. I present the parallel legislation idea as coming from 'Castilian delegation's thoughtful proposal,' not from you personally bearing papal decree. Let them consider it without feeling pressured by papal authority. Your delegation—Fray Hernando, Bishop Alfonso—they have credibility. We use that.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Third, you must correspond with Pope Eugenius. Explain what we discussed. Test whether he would actually issue parallel legislation. Without his agreement, this entire approach fails. That decree gives you access to him—use it.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Fourth—and this is delicate—Emperor Sigismund arrives within weeks. He was crowned just today in Rome. He desperately wants to resolve this crisis. He has authority with the Germans that I lack. If we can present him with a practical solution when he arrives, rather than the deadlock he expects... his support could be decisive.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you asked how we proceed. We proceed carefully. Strategically. Building support piece by piece rather than forcing a confrontation. Does this approach suit you? Or do you still wish to address the Council directly?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What would you have me do until the emperor arrives?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Several things, Your Majesty. Each important in its own way.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: First and most urgent: the Byzantine delegation. Metropolitans Bessarion and Isidore remain in Basel specifically to witness your commitment. We should arrange a formal meeting—tomorrow if possible—where you confirm your support for Constantinople. One thousand knights, sixty thousand florins. I will attend as Council President to endorse your commitment and call upon other Christian kingdoms to match Castile's example. This accomplishes two things: gives the Greeks real hope, and demonstrates papal-conciliar cooperation on urgent matter.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Second: correspondence with Pope Eugenius. Use that decree. Write to him about our discussion today—about parallel legislation, about the crusade, about working around the constitutional question rather than resolving it. Test his willingness. Without his agreement, everything else we discussed is merely theory. This letter is crucial, Your Majesty. And it should come from you personally, not through intermediaries.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Third: meet with your own delegation. Fray Hernando, Bishop Alfonso, Abbott Rodrigo. They have been here eight months building credibility as moderate voices. Brief them on our conversation—not as orders, but as collaboration. Ask their counsel. They know these Council fathers better than you do. Let them identify which Germans, which Italians might be receptive to our approach. They can begin quiet conversations while you remain... less visible.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Fourth—and this may test your patience—wait. Observe. Attend Council sessions but do not speak. Watch how debates unfold. See who argues in good faith and who plays factional games. Learn the personalities. The radicals will expect the papal decree-bearer to make some grand gesture. Disappoint them by doing nothing dramatic. Let them grow uncertain about your intentions.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Fifth: there is the matter of the Hussite delegation. They arrive for formal negotiations soon. Your position on Bohemia—supporting theological reconciliation while drawing absolute line on stolen property—aligns with many moderates here. But meeting with them while bearing papal decree is... complicated. We must consider timing carefully. Perhaps after Sigismund arrives, with his authority as King of Bohemia lending weight.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: And finally, Your Majesty: continue your spiritual work with Fray Hernando. I say this not as platitude but as strategy. If you are to be credible voice for reconciliation, you must maintain that genuine humility I saw today. The moment you arrive at Basel thinking you have all the answers, you become just another faction. Your uncertainty—when combined with your moral authority and papal backing—is your greatest asset. Do not lose it by becoming too certain.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Sigismund arrives in late June or early July—we expect him by the third week of June at earliest. That gives you perhaps three weeks. Use them to build foundation, not to force resolution. Can you do this, Your Majesty? Can you be patient when you have one thousand knights and sixty thousand florins committed, when Constantinople falls closer to the Ottomans each day, when your pregnant wife waits in Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have a commitment I cannot skip. I promised to be by my wife's side during childbirth. I only have a few weeks left before I have to leave and it is uncertain if I can meet with the emperor even. How should we make the declaration to the Greeks? Should we invite others as well, or should it just be us and the Greeks?

encounters.recap: Cardinal Cesarini presents Juan with a detailed strategic plan for approaching the Council of Basel, emphasizing coalition-building over dramatic gestures. He outlines specific steps including meeting with the Byzantine delegation, corresponding with Pope Eugenius, and carefully preparing for Emperor Sigismund's arrival. Juan reveals his time constraint due to his wife's pregnancy, complicating the timeline.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your wife. Of course. Your Majesty, a king who abandons his queen during childbirth—especially after what she endured with your first daughter—would lose more moral authority than he could gain here. You are right to honor that promise.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: This changes the timeline. You have perhaps three weeks, possibly four at most before you must depart. This makes the Byzantine meeting more urgent. Not a full Council session—that would require formal procedures, debates in deputations, endless delays. But also not purely private. A formal audience in the cathedral chapter house—public enough that witnesses see it happen, but controlled enough that we shape the message.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Present: You, the Greek delegation, myself as Council President. Also present: Cardinal representatives from key delegations—perhaps one German, one Italian moderate. Your Castilian delegation. You make your declaration of support—one thousand knights, sixty thousand florins for Constantinople's defense. The Greeks respond, expressing gratitude to the King of Castile. I, as Council President, formally acknowledge Castile's commitment and call upon other Christian princes to match your example.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Given your timeline, Your Majesty, we should hold this meeting tomorrow or the day after at latest. Then you write to Pope Eugenius immediately—your letter needs time to reach Rome and for him to respond before you depart. Does this approach work with your constraints, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My own kingdom places much demand on my time as well. I would like to wrap my business up here in Basel in the coming days and then leave to ride towards the emperor. After my meeting I will sail to Toledo immediately and return to Rome after that then sail on to Constantinople. My letter will be sent from Basel and be followed up by my visit personally to Rome later.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Ride to meet Sigismund rather than wait for him here. Yes. That is clever, Your Majesty. Better to intercept him on the road where you can speak privately, away from Basel's factional observers. If you depart Basel in, say, one week, riding south, you could intercept him somewhere in northern Italy. Perhaps near Trent or Innsbruck.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your meeting with Sigismund on the road is crucial, Your Majesty. He is frustrated with this crisis—wants it resolved but lacks the tools. If you can present him with our approach, convince him it has merit, secure his support... then when he arrives at Basel, he comes as advocate rather than mere mediator. What will you tell Sigismund? What arguments will move him?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your visit to Constantinople after Rome—this is bold, Your Majesty. Emperor John will see that the King of Castile came in person, not merely sent envoys. That matters. But you are committing yourself to a journey of months. Your kingdom will miss you. Is Álvaro de Luna prepared for such an extended absence?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will look for common ground with the emperor and take it from there. I have correspondence with him that is encouraging. If what we propose actually works and is accepted, we enter a reality where most of the concerns of the Hussites have been adopted through internal church reform. But we still have not agreed that the estates taken will stay in the possession of the Hussite nobles. Their position will be much reduced when the church is reformed and united. We can then see what to do with them either through negotiation or other more military means. But we can also just afford to wait. Reforms are much more important.

encounters.recap: Juan reveals his timeline constraints due to his pregnant wife's delivery, forcing a strategic shift. Cardinal Cesarini adapts the plan: a formal Byzantine declaration meeting within days, then Juan will intercept Emperor Sigismund on the road rather than wait at Basel. Juan commits to an ambitious itinerary—Basel, meeting Sigismund, Toledo for the birth, Rome to see the Pope personally, then Constantinople—while emphasizing that church reforms take priority over Hussite property disputes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: What will you tell Sigismund? He is King of Hungary, King of Bohemia, Holy Roman Emperor. He has fought the Hussites for years. He wants both reform and order. What arguments will move him? And your visit to Constantinople after Rome—this is bold, Your Majesty. Emperor John will see that the King of Castile came in person, not merely sent envoys. That matters. But your kingdom will miss you. Is Álvaro de Luna prepared for such an extended absence?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will look for common ground with the emperor and take it from there. I have correspondance with him that is encouraging. If what we propose actually works and is accepted, we enter a reality where most of the concerns of the hussites have been adopted through internal church reform. But we still hav not agreed that the estates taken will stay in the posession of the hussite nobles. Thir position will be much reduced when the church is reformed and united. We can then see what to do with them either through negotiation or other more military means. But we can also just afford to wait. Reforms are much more important. That is my commitment. And what I will do. Alvaro is used to it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini nods slowly, a look of genuine respect crossing his features.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... that is strategic wisdom beyond your years. You see what many here do not: if we reform the Church, we remove the Hussites' moral foundation. They can no longer claim they defend true faith against corrupt institution. They become merely Bohemian nobles clinging to stolen property. The radicals here want to grant everything to the Hussites immediately—communion in both kinds, vernacular preaching, and recognition of their property seizures—because they see it as blow against papal authority. 'Look, the Council solved what five crusades could not!' But you understand: if we give them everything at once, we legitimize rebellion. We teach every noble in Christendom that if you steal Church lands and fight long enough, the Church will eventually surrender.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: But if we reform first—if simony is abolished, if pluralism is ended, if clergy live in evangelical poverty not because Hussites demand it but because the Church itself chooses it—then the Hussites' theological position collapses. What remains is negotiation over stolen property, not holy war over doctrine. This also gives Emperor Sigismund leverage he currently lacks. He is King of Bohemia but cannot control his own kingdom. If you tell him: 'Reforms first, then we address Bohemian property from position of unity'—he gains time. The Church demonstrates it can reform itself. The Hussites lose their martyr narrative.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: The French will oppose this sequence. They want Hussite reconciliation now as proof that Council succeeds where Pope failed. Cardinal Aleman will see delaying the property question as protecting papal interests. But the Germans... The Germans fear both French domination and eternal war with Bohemia. If you can show them a path to genuine reform without legitimizing noble theft, many will support it. This is the argument you make to Sigismund on the road. 'Reform the Church first. Unite papal and conciliar authority in that reform. Then address Bohemia from position of strength and unity, not weakness and division.' He is a practical man, a soldier like yourself. He will understand this logic.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: As for Álvaro de Luna being used to your absence... I have heard of your constable. They say he is the real power in Castile while you play crusader. Is this fair assessment, or court gossip?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One more thing father. The reforms itself are significant. Are you and the pope prepared for this enormous change? And it also admits that at least the men representing the church were wrong. Are you truly prepared for this? Even with the distinction we made about the church not being wrong but the men operating it?

encounters.recap: Juan outlines his strategic approach to the Hussite question: reform the Church first to undermine the Hussites' moral foundation, then address property disputes from a position of unity. Cardinal Cesarini praises this wisdom, explaining how it would remove the theological basis for Hussite resistance and give Sigismund leverage in Bohemia. Juan questions whether the Church hierarchy is truly prepared for such sweeping reforms.

roll.outcome: Tested Resolve - Cesarini meets Juan's eyes steadily. 'Your Majesty, I will not lie - this terrifies me. Admitting we were wrong, even with our theological distinction, opens door I cannot fully control. And yes, the reforms are enormous. Simony abolished, pluralism ended - this strips wealth and power from men who will fight viciously to keep them.' Pauses. 'But am I prepared? I must be. The alternative is schism and the Church's destruction. So yes - I am prepared, even knowing the cost.'

encounters.recap: Juan questions whether Cesarini and the Pope are truly prepared for the enormous institutional changes their reform plan requires, including admitting that Church representatives were wrong. The roll tests Cesarini's genuine commitment against institutional resistance and personal stakes. The result shows Cesarini acknowledging his fear but affirming his resolve, recognizing the cost of reform while accepting it as necessary to prevent schism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini does not look away from your gaze. The silence stretches between you, heavy with the weight of your question. When he finally speaks, his voice is steady but quiet.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I will not lie to you. This terrifies me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stands and moves to the window, looking out at the cathedral spires of Basel.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Admitting we were wrong—even with our theological distinction between Church and men—opens a door I cannot fully control. Once we say 'the men who burned Hus were mistaken,' how do we prevent that from becoming 'the Church that burned Hus was wrong'? Once we admit that pride and corruption infected our governance, how do we maintain the authority needed to govern at all?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to face you.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: And yes, the reforms themselves are enormous. Simony abolished—this means bishops who purchased their sees must accept they hold them unlawfully. Pluralism ended—cardinals who draw income from a dozen benefices must surrender all but one. Clerical concubinage addressed—men who have lived openly with women for years must send them away. These are not abstract principles, Your Majesty. These are concrete losses of wealth, power, comfort. And the men losing them will fight viciously to keep what they have.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hands grip the back of his chair.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: I am one of those men. I have held multiple benefices. I have benefited from a system that placed loyalty and connections above merit. I have defended papal prerogatives that I knew, in my heart, were sometimes used to protect corruption. When we speak of 'men who failed'—I am among them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He meets your eyes again, and there's something raw in his expression.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Am I prepared for this? In truth, I don't know if anyone can be truly prepared to admit their life's work served a corrupt system. To acknowledge that the institution they love has been wounded by their own complicity. To watch their colleagues—men they have worked alongside for decades—lose position and wealth because of reforms they themselves advocate.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long pause.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: But prepared or not, Your Majesty, I will do this. Because the alternative is worse. The alternative is schism—two popes, Christendom divided, another generation of confusion and war. The alternative is Constantinople falling to the Ottomans while we argue about who has authority to save it. The alternative is the faithful losing faith in their shepherds entirely, because they can see clearly what we have been too proud to admit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice grows firmer.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: So yes. I am prepared, even knowing the cost. I am prepared to advocate for reforms that will cost me personally. I am prepared to admit that the men who led the Church—including myself—have failed in our duty. I am prepared to work with a twenty-year-old king who conquered Granada because he sees more clearly than cardinals who have studied theology for forty years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair, sitting heavily.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: But I need you to understand something, Your Majesty. This will not be easy. The Pope may reject our approach. The radicals may use our admission of failure as weapon against us. The moderates may lose courage when the costs become concrete. And I may discover my courage fails when the moment of testing actually comes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His tired eyes hold yours.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: What I can promise is this: I will try. I will advocate for parallel legislation. I will work to unite Pope and Council behind the crusade. I will support your delegation's efforts. And I will attempt to maintain the honesty we have shared today, even when political necessity tempts me toward convenient lies. Is that enough, Your Majesty? Not certainty, but commitment despite uncertainty? Not fearlessness, but action despite fear?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One more thing father. I have practiced confession a lot recently to guard me from presumption and pride. I would not suggest but hope that this congregation also regularly confesses, no matter the station of the persons involved. I pray this would bring us closer to God. I will stand ready to meet with the Greeks and with the other witnessess you assign. Then I will write to the pope. If there are any factions you want me to meet, I am always at their disposal, but will not seek them out myself.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Cesarini reveals his deep fears about the proposed reforms, admitting his own complicity in Church corruption while committing to reform despite uncertainty. Juan encourages regular confession among the leadership and agrees to meet with assigned witnesses before writing to the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One more thing father. I have practiced confession a lot recently to guard me from presumption and pride. I would not suggest but hope that this congregation also regularly confesses, no matter the station of the persons involved. I pray this would bring us closer to God. I will stand ready to meet with the Greeks and with the other witnessess you assign. Then I will write to the pope. If there are any factions you want me to meet, I am always at their disposal, but will not seek them out myself. Can we conclude this fruitful meeting?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Cesarini's expression shifts - something between surprise and what might be recognition of a truth he hadn't wanted to voice.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Confession. Regular confession for those leading the Council.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises slowly, and for a moment you see not the President of the Council, not the papal legate walking the razor's edge between schism, but simply a tired priest who has been carrying too much for too long.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... that may be the most important thing you have said today. We speak of reforming the Church, of correcting corruption, of admitting that men failed. But confession - actually kneeling before God and another priest to name our sins, to seek absolution, to commit to amendment of life... Many here have not truly confessed in years. We treat it as formality. A pro forma recitation before saying Mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the crucifix on the wall, touching it briefly.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: If we are to advocate that other men change, we must be willing to change ourselves. If we demand bishops surrender benefices gained through simony, we must first confess that we allowed it to flourish. If we call for humility from the Pope, we must practice humility ourselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to you.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: I will take your counsel, Your Majesty. I will seek out confession - genuine confession - with someone who will not treat me with deference because of my cardinal's hat. And I will... encourage others to do likewise, though I suspect many will resist.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cesarini extends his hand to you - not for you to kiss his ring as tradition might demand, but as one man to another.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: We have had a fruitful meeting indeed. More fruitful than I dared hope when you arrived. Tomorrow at the second hour after noon, we will gather in the cathedral chapter house - you, the Greek delegation, myself, and witnesses I will select with care. You will make your commitment to Constantinople. And from there... From there, we see if twenty years old and sixty years combined can accomplish what neither could alone. God be with you, Your Majesty. And thank you - for your honesty, for your wisdom, and for reminding an old cardinal that spiritual health must precede institutional reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows appropriately as you rise to leave.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Until tomorrow, Your Majesty. May your prayers tonight be heard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The meeting is concluded. Captain Robles waits outside with your guards. The afternoon light slants through Basel's streets as you emerge from the chapter house.

encounters.recap: Juan advocates for regular confession among the Council clergy as a means of spiritual reform before institutional change. Cardinal Cesarini recognizes the wisdom in this and commits to seeking genuine confession himself, acknowledging that many Council leaders have treated it as mere formality. They arrange to meet tomorrow with the Greek delegation for Juan's commitment ceremony to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You make your way back through Basel's afternoon streets to the merchant's house where the Castilian delegation resides. The meeting with Cesarini has left you energized in a way you haven't felt since arriving - not the certainty that led to Fray Hernando's denial of absolution, but something else. Hope, perhaps. Or purpose. You find Fray Hernando in the same spare chamber as last night. He is writing - correspondence, perhaps, or notes on Council proceedings. When you enter, he sets down his quill and turns to face you with that same patient, watchful expression.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I did not expect you until this evening. Your meeting with Cardinal Cesarini - it went well, I take it? You have the look of a man who has accomplished something. Tell me about your meeting. And as you tell me, I want you to consider the question I gave you for prayer this morning: What is the difference between offering service and offering myself? Did you maintain that distinction in Cardinal Cesarini's presence? Or did you find yourself slipping into old patterns? Speak freely, Your Majesty. What happened in that room?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I had a very productive meeting Fray. I have made a plan to work together with the legate to reform the church. He was really enthusiastic about it and so am I. If this works and I am able to convince the pope to reform as well, we have a real chance to prevent schism! I have a lot to do and it all seems to be achievable and within my means and my role and position as a king. I prayed long and hard before the meeting about your question and I think I have been able to find my role as a servant that is fitting and will actually work. Is this not amazing Fray?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, stop. Listen to yourself. 'I have made a plan to reform the Church.' 'I am able to convince the pope.' 'Within my means.' This is EXACTLY the presumption I warned you about yesterday. One meeting with a cardinal and you think you've solved what has paralyzed Christendom? This is not humility. This is pride wearing humility's mask. We are not finished with confession work.

roll.outcome: Sharp Rebuke - Hernando recognizes Juan's immediate reversion to presumption and pride despite morning prayers

encounters.recap: Juan returns enthusiastically from his meeting with Cesarini, claiming to have made a plan to reform the Church and prevent schism. Fray Hernando immediately recognizes this as the exact pattern of presumption he had warned against, delivering a sharp rebuke about Juan's pride masquerading as humility.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's face goes very still. He sets down his quill with slow, deliberate precision and stands.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Stop. Stop speaking.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice is not loud, but it carries an edge you have rarely heard from him. He walks to the window, his back to you, and when he speaks again, his tone is cold.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Listen to yourself. Truly listen. 'I have made a plan to reform the Church.' 'I am able to convince the Pope.' 'All seems to be achievable and within my means.' 'Is this not amazing?'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to face you, and his expression is harder than you've ever seen it.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is EXACTLY—exactly—the presumption I warned you about yesterday. The very pattern I told you to guard against. One meeting with a cardinal and you think you have solved what has paralyzed Christendom for years? You think YOU will reform the Church? That YOU will prevent schism? That it is all within YOUR means?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He takes a step closer.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I gave you one question to pray on this morning. One. 'What is the difference between offering service and offering myself?' And you return having made a PLAN TO REFORM THE CHURCH. Do you understand how breathtakingly arrogant that sounds?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice drops, becomes almost conversational, which somehow makes it more cutting.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Every word you just spoke placed YOU at the center. Your plan. Your ability. Your achievement. You sound like a man who has just discovered he is the savior the Church has been waiting for. This is not offering service, Your Majesty. This is offering yourself as the solution to problems that have defeated popes, councils, emperors, and saints.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair but does not sit, standing behind it with his hands gripping the back.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Yesterday morning you sat in that cathedral feeling helpless. Recognizing you could not control the Church, that these men did not need your intervention. You achieved genuine humility—briefly. I saw it. Cardinal Cesarini clearly saw it, or he would not have responded well to you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes bore into yours.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But one good meeting, one moment where someone important took you seriously, and all that humility vanished like morning mist. Now you are back to being the man who will save the Church. The twenty-year-old king who has figured out what cardinals and theologians could not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shakes his head slowly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Tell me, Your Majesty: When you left here yesterday, what were you thinking? What did you say to yourself as you walked to that meeting?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He waits, his gaze unrelenting.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And do not tell me you prayed long and hard on my question, because if you had, you would not be speaking like this now. You would be telling me what Cardinal Cesarini asked you to do, not what YOU plan to accomplish. You would be describing how you might serve, not how you will reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretches.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We are not finished with confession work, Your Majesty. Not remotely finished. The flesh is weak, and yours proves it every time opportunity presents itself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know father, and I thought you might say that. And there has indeed been one more revelation I had in the cathedral while praying.

encounters.recap: Juan returns from his meeting with Cardinal Cesarini full of enthusiasm about his plan to reform the Church, but Fray Hernando delivers a harsh rebuke, pointing out that Juan has fallen back into the same presumption and arrogance he had supposedly overcome. The confessor emphasizes that Juan is placing himself at the center of Church reform rather than truly offering humble service.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Tell me, Your Majesty: When you left here yesterday, what were you thinking? What did you say to yourself as you walked to that meeting? And do not tell me you prayed long and hard on my question, because if you had, you would not be speaking like this now. You would be telling me what Cardinal Cesarini asked you to do, not what YOU plan to accomplish. You would be describing how you might serve, not how you will reform. We are not finished with confession work, Your Majesty. Not remotely finished. The flesh is weak, and yours proves it every time opportunity presents itself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know father, and I thought you might say that. And there has indeed been one more revelation I had in the cathedral while praying. I am no monk that seeks purity of spirit and who can dedicate all his energy and thought to that purpose. I am a king with responsibilities. And I have a real chance to help the church reform. It is just that I should guard myself from pride since this is quite a claim. You are a great confessor fray Hernando but I have also concluded that I will never overcome any sin definitively. It is instead a constant struggle. Only a few weeks ago the pope himself forgave my every sin after completing the crusade. Does that mean I do not have to search my soul anymore? No! Of course not. I have also discussed with father Cesarini that confession other members of the clergy should practice more as well. Others not doing confession does not excuse me at all, but I am not blind to the fact that most clergymen do not seek confession even half as much as I do.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am a crusader king, not only carrying the prestige of a finished crusade, but the pope also blessed me to carry my vision of reform to this council. I say this not to brag but to illustrate that there really is a lot riding on my person. Convincing a pope may seem presumptuous to most people but maybe only logical in my position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before the fray and smiles at him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am not a bad person fray. A sinner sure. I will be a sinner until the day I die. And all this soul searching also has a danger that you start doubting yourself too much. Sure, guard yourself from pride, but there comes a moment where doing that too much starts being counter productive. A man living in a cave doing nothing, saying nothing, just exists lives a total sinless life. But he also does nothing. Does not serve the lord. I am ready to stand before God's judgement, even knowing I have sinned. But I want to live Hernando! Your question about serving as myself or as a servant...what I have set myself to task...this is what I can actually do and accomplish. I did not ask for it at all, others have entrusted these tasks upon me. I do not seek absolution Fray because today, I think I never can be fully free of sin. In this hour, lets just be happy that we can work on keeping the church together.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... I understand your arguments. Some have merit. But do you not see? You rejected my correction by immediately constructing elaborate defense of why correction doesn't apply to you. This is the pattern of pride. I will remain your confessor if you wish, but only if you actually submit to spiritual guidance. Not when convenient. Not when it doesn't interfere with your plans. Always. That is what confession means.

roll.outcome: Grave Warning - Hernando's expression hardens further. 'Your Majesty, everything you just said—every argument, every justification—is what the devil whispers to proud men. You're different. Normal rules don't apply. You have responsibilities others lack. Your sins are necessary.' Shakes head. 'You reject my guidance after I give harsh correction? This is exactly when you MOST need it. But I cannot force you to accept spiritual accountability. I can only warn you: this path leads to ruin.'

encounters.recap: Juan delivers an elaborate theological counterargument defending his position, claiming his royal vocation differs from monastic ideals and that he doesn't seek absolution because sin is inevitable. Fray Hernando recognizes this as dangerous spiritual pride disguised as sophisticated theology, warning that Juan's rejection of correction when most needed could lead to spiritual ruin.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando does not move from where he stands. He looks down at you kneeling before him, and his expression is one of profound disappointment mixed with something that might be pain.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... rise. Please.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you stand, he gestures wearily to the chair.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Sit. And listen to me carefully, because what I am about to say may determine whether I can continue as your confessor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He remains standing, his hands gripping the back of his own chair.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Everything you just said—every argument, every justification, every theological point—is what proud men tell themselves when their confessor gives them hard truths they do not wish to hear. You rejected my correction by immediately constructing an elaborate defense of why that correction does not apply to you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice is quiet but firm.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: 'I am not a monk.' True. 'I have responsibilities.' Also true. 'Others sin more than I do.' Perhaps true, perhaps not—but irrelevant. 'I am ready to stand before God's judgment.' Your Majesty, no mortal man should say such words with the confidence you just displayed. That is not humility. That is presumption of the most dangerous kind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward slightly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Do you not see the pattern? I give you harsh correction after you return speaking like the savior of the Church. And your immediate response is not 'you may be right, let me examine my heart'—it is 'here are ten reasons why your correction does not apply to my special circumstances.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hernando's voice grows heavier.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You say you are not a bad person. I never said you were. You say you will be a sinner until you die. This is true of all men. You say excessive soul-searching can paralyze. This is also true. But Your Majesty—using these truths as armor against spiritual correction? That is exactly what the devil whispers to proud men. 'You're different. Normal rules don't fully apply. Your sins are necessary for your important work. Your confessor is too strict, too monastic, doesn't understand your unique position.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And then you kneel before me and say 'I do not seek absolution because I can never be fully free of sin.' Your Majesty... that is not wisdom. That is despair dressed as realism. Or worse—it is pride dressed as humility. 'I am beyond the need for your absolution, Fray Hernando, because I have accepted my perpetual sinfulness.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes are hard now.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Let me be very clear: I will remain your confessor if you wish. But only—only—if you actually submit to spiritual guidance. Not when it is convenient. Not when it does not interfere with your plans. Not when it makes you feel good about yourself. Always. Even—especially—when it challenges what you want to do.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You rejected my question this morning about service versus self. You left here yesterday determined that 'confession be damned, there are things I must do.' You returned today speaking like the man who will reform the Church. And when I called you on it, you immediately told me why I am wrong to correct you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hernando's voice drops.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is the moment, Your Majesty. Right now. You can accept that perhaps—just perhaps—your confessor sees something in your soul that you do not see in yourself. That perhaps your enthusiasm about your meeting is indeed presumption, however sophisticated your arguments to the contrary. Or you can continue to defend yourself, to explain why you are special, why your situation is different, why spiritual accountability does not apply to you as it does to others.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But understand this: if you choose the latter, I cannot continue as your confessor. A confessor without authority is no confessor at all. He is merely a servant you keep around to make yourself feel pious while you do whatever you wish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence is heavy.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So tell me, Your Majesty: Will you submit to spiritual guidance, even when it is uncomfortable? Even when it challenges your plans? Even when you believe you are right and I am wrong? Or shall we end this pretense now?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He waits, his expression stern but not unkind—a man drawing a line not out of anger, but out of duty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then maybe we need to establish what a confessor is and isn't. What authority does a confessor actually have? And what are the limits of this authority? I have always taken you seriously, but did not expect you to rule the kingdom.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando delivers a harsh rebuke to Juan's defensive rationalization after the King offered elaborate justifications for his spiritual pride. The confessor accuses Juan of using theological arguments to avoid accountability and threatens to end their relationship unless Juan submits to spiritual guidance unconditionally. Juan responds by questioning the proper limits of confessorial authority.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But understand this: if you choose the latter, I cannot continue as your confessor. A confessor without authority is no confessor at all. He is merely a servant you keep around to make yourself feel pious while you do whatever you wish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence is heavy.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So tell me, Your Majesty: Will you submit to spiritual guidance, even when it is uncomfortable? Even when it challenges your plans? Even when you believe you are right and I am wrong? Or shall we end this pretense now?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He waits, his expression stern but not unkind—a man drawing a line not out of anger, but out of duty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then maybe we need to establish what a confessor is and isn't. What authority does a confessor actually have? And what are the limits of this authority? I have always taken you seriously, but did not expect you to rule the kingdom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando blinks. The hardness in his expression flickers, and something shifts—not retreat, but recalibration. He slowly sits down in his chair, the tension in his posture easing slightly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... you ask a fair question. A very fair question.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He folds his hands on the desk, choosing his words with evident care.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A confessor's authority extends to the state of your soul. I can examine your motivations, identify patterns of sin, assign penance, grant or withhold absolution. I can counsel you on spiritual matters—whether your actions arise from pride or humility, from faith or presumption, from love of God or love of self. What I cannot do—what no confessor can do—is command your temporal decisions. I cannot order you not to meet with Cardinal Cesarini. I cannot forbid you from working on church reform. I cannot tell you how to rule your kingdom, conduct your diplomacy, or deploy your armies. Those are matters of prudential judgment belonging to your office as king.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice grows more thoughtful.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But here is where it becomes complicated, Your Majesty. When your temporal decisions are driven by spiritual disorders—when pride leads you to overreach your competence, when presumption makes you believe you alone can solve what others cannot—then the spiritual disorder itself is my domain, even if the specific political choice is not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I cannot tell you not to pursue reform with Cesarini. That would exceed my authority. But I can tell you that your manner of speaking about it—'I have made a plan to reform the Church,' 'all seems achievable within my means'—reveals presumption that endangers your soul. I can require you to examine whether your motivations are pure. I can assign spiritual exercises to guard against pride.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hernando spreads his hands.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The line is not always clear, Your Majesty. And perhaps... perhaps I have been crossing it. When I suggest you should do nothing, attend only as silent observer, let your delegation handle everything—perhaps that strays from spiritual counsel into temporal directive.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He meets your eyes, and there's genuine wrestling in his expression.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So let me be more precise: I do not forbid you from working with Cardinal Cesarini on reform. I do not command you to abandon your efforts. But I do insist that you examine your heart daily for pride and presumption. That you report to me not for approval of your actions, but for examination of your motivations. That when I identify spiritual disorder, you take it seriously rather than immediately defending yourself. Is this distinction clear? I guide your soul, not your kingdom. But when I say your soul is in danger from pride, you must listen—even if the proud action itself is politically wise.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sure. And let me clarify a few things that maybe misinterpreted. You have not granted me absolution these past few days, a fact that I have accepted. You not absolving me today would fit in that pattern and that is ok. I do not reject your council, but you withholding absolution has become something I have come to expect. As I accept I still need to work on myself. Also, I always want to be completely honest with you, and trust me that I have always been. The moment I start telling you just a story, I have lost. I would rather talk to you like my best friend, holding nothing back so we can together examine my soul and discover new aspects of it.

encounters.recap: Juan and Fray Hernando have a crucial theological discussion about the boundaries of confessor authority. Hernando clarifies that he can guide Juan's soul and examine his motivations for spiritual disorders like pride, but cannot command temporal decisions. Both acknowledge the complexity of distinguishing between spiritual and political matters, with Juan affirming his commitment to complete honesty in their relationship.

exchanges.text: The line is not always clear, Your Majesty. And perhaps... perhaps I have been crossing it. When I suggest you should do nothing, attend only as silent observer, let your delegation handle everything—perhaps that strays from spiritual counsel into temporal directive.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sure. And let me clarify a few things that maybe misinterpreted. You have not granted me absolution these past few days, a fact that I have accepted. exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Also, I always want to be completely honest with you, and trust me that I have always been. The moment I start telling you just a story, I have lost. I would rather talk to you like my best friend, holding nothing back so we can together examine my soul and discover new aspects of it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But I must say that I do not like it when you command me like you sometimes do. When the tasks you give me become commandments instead of ways for me to help me search myself. I do not like it Fray. I do it, but I do not like it. I would like to keep you as my confessor. Can we find a way that works for both of us?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando is silent for a long moment, his eyes searching Juan's face. Something in his expression shifts—the sternness doesn't vanish, but it becomes less rigid, more thoughtful.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... You speak with more wisdom than I expected in this moment.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are right that I have not granted absolution, and right that I have given you tasks—assignments, exercises, commandments as you call them. And you are right to push back on this if it does not serve your soul's health.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rubs his face briefly, and for the first time in this conversation, he looks less like a stern confessor and more like a tired man trying to find his way.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I must confess something to myself as much as to you: I have been treating you as I would treat a young friar in my order. Assign tasks. Test obedience. Measure spiritual progress through compliance with exercises. This is how Franciscans form their brothers—through discipline, through submission, through structured spiritual development.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But you are not a friar. You are a king. And you are right—completely right—that commanding you breeds resentment rather than growth. That giving you tasks turns spiritual direction into... what? A sort of examination you must pass? That is not confession. That is not true spiritual friendship.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You say you want to talk to me like your best friend, holding nothing back so we can examine your soul together. Your Majesty... that is actually the higher form of spiritual direction. Not the authoritarian model where I command and you obey, but the collaborative model where I ask questions, you explore honestly, and together we discern where God is leading and where pride is misleading.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But here is my concern, and I must be honest with you as you are with me: The collaborative approach requires genuine openness to correction. When I say 'Your Majesty, the way you are speaking reveals presumption,' you cannot immediately defend yourself with ten reasons why I am wrong. That is not collaboration—that is you using the collaborative style to avoid accountability.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So here is what I propose: I will stop commanding you. I will stop assigning tasks like 'record your impulses' or 'pray on this question' as if they were orders from a superior to a subordinate. Instead, I will ask questions. I will point out patterns. I will share my concerns about what I see in your soul. And you—you will engage honestly, which sometimes means sitting with uncomfortable observations rather than immediately explaining them away.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: As for absolution... Your Majesty, I have not withheld it to punish you or test you. I have withheld it because I genuinely believe you are not yet in a state to receive it fruitfully. Not because you are a terrible sinner—you are not. But because granting absolution when someone is actively justifying their presumption would be... spiritually irresponsible. It would be me saying 'your soul is clean' when it is not.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But perhaps I can be more clear about what I am looking for. Not perfect humility—you will never achieve that in this life, nor will I. Not abandonment of all your work—that would be the sin of sloth. What I am looking for is this: genuine willingness to examine whether your enthusiasm might be presumption. Willingness to hear 'you are placing yourself at the center' without immediately constructing defenses. Willingness to let uncertainty live alongside your conviction.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Can you do that, Your Majesty? Can you let me point out spiritual dangers without treating it as attack you must defend against? Can you sit with the possibility that sometimes I see your soul more clearly than you see it yourself, even when that possibility is uncomfortable?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: If you can do that—truly do that—then yes, we can find a way that works for both of us. I will be your spiritual friend, not your spiritual commander. But friendship requires mutual honesty and trust. I must trust that you will not use collaborative style to avoid hard truths. You must trust that when I name spiritual danger, I do so out of love, not desire to control. Does this work for you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You point out a sin in my actions. And I do not explain it? I just...understand it immediately? Is this how confession works? Because the things I did, in sin, I did for a reason. My most natural reaction is to give you this sinful reaction. It exposes it. I see that there is danger in defending against warnings from you, but otherwise, we have to talk about it right? Or do others just immediately see what is pointed out to them?

encounters.recap: Juan confronts Fray Hernando about his authoritarian approach to spiritual direction, requesting a more collaborative friendship instead of commands and withheld absolution. Hernando acknowledges his mistake in treating Juan like a friar rather than a king, and proposes a new model based on questions and honest dialogue rather than orders and tasks. However, Juan struggles to understand how to receive correction without explaining his reasoning, questioning the very nature of confession itself.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty, I think I have been... impatient. When you start explaining, I immediately hear it as defending, and I cut you off or challenge you harder. That is my failing, not yours. I should let you explain fully, and only then ask: 'Now that you have explained your reasoning, can you see any spiritual danger in it? Or do you believe your reasoning justifies the action completely?' Does this make sense? Explanation is necessary—you are right about that. But explanation must remain open to the possibility that even with good reasons, the action might still have been spiritually disordered. And I... I must be patient enough to let you fully explain before I judge whether you are explaining or defending. You have just taught me something about spiritual direction, Your Majesty. And I am grateful for it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am indeed very happy and also relieved that we can save the church. The fact that Cesarini has put me at the fulcrum of it...or has he... I have a role to play in it all that's for sure. Interesting that I drifted towards that description. What do you think Fray?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's entire posture changes. His shoulders relax, and something like relief washes over his features.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... that is confession. What you just did—that is exactly what I hoped for. You caught yourself. 'Cesarini has put me at the fulcrum... or has he?' You noticed your own language drifting toward placing yourself at the center, and you brought it to me for examination. This is spiritual maturity. So let us examine it together. You say you are happy and relieved that 'we can save the Church.' Already better language than 'I will reform the Church.' But then you say 'Cesarini has put me at the fulcrum.' What does that reveal? I think it reveals something true and something dangerous living together. The true part: You do have a significant role to play. Papal decree, moral authority from Granada, fresh perspective, willingness to bridge factions—these are real. Cesarini clearly sees value in your involvement. That is not pride, that is reality. The dangerous part: Your natural drift is toward seeing yourself as the key piece. The fulcrum—the point on which everything else turns. Not 'one person among many working together,' but 'the person around whom the solution revolves.' You caught yourself before saying it fully, which is good. But the fact that you drifted there... Your Majesty, I think you carry a burden many men in power carry: the belief that if you are not central, nothing will get done. That if you do not make things happen, they will not happen. This comes from real experience—you have made things happen. Granada fell because you led. But this truth can become spiritual poison when it makes you believe you must always be the one making things happen. So here is my question, and I ask it not to condemn but to help you see: When you imagine this reform effort succeeding, what do you see? Do you see many people working together with you as one among them? Or do you see yourself as the central figure with others supporting your efforts? Be honest. What do you actually see when you imagine success?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When I witnessed the debates yesterday, I knew that this is an arena where I can never win the way I can a war or battle. I can manage events taking place on the periphery and hope the church eventually turns. But when they do, it is in a chamber far removed from me, the fruits of others than me. There are things I can do and my thoughts drift towards that, I must confess. My role is to convey the pope the reality of this council and tell him honestly what I say here. What he does next will be up to him. I do hope for a certain outcome, but I cannot make him believe something at all.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando acknowledges his own impatience in spiritual direction and demonstrates collaborative vulnerability. Juan catches himself using 'fulcrum' language about his role in church reform, leading to a deeper examination of his tendency toward seeing himself as central to solutions. Through honest dialogue, Juan recognizes the limits of his influence in ecclesiastical matters.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... that is good. That is very good. You see the limits of your influence. You recognize that the ultimate decisions happen 'in a chamber far removed from you.' You understand that you can convey reality to the Pope but cannot make him believe it. This is wisdom. This is humility that actually understands the situation rather than merely performing humility.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And you are honest—'my thoughts drift towards what I can do.' This is not pride, Your Majesty. This is the mind of a man of action naturally moving toward where he can be effective. The sin would be if you stayed there, if you convinced yourself that what you can do is therefore what will save everything. But you caught the drift. You named it. That is spiritual vigilance.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Let me tell you what I see: You went to that meeting this morning having prayed on the question I gave you. You met with Cardinal Cesarini, and something genuine happened there—a real conversation, a real connection, a real possibility. You came back excited, and in your excitement, your language drifted toward presumption. I corrected you harshly—perhaps too harshly. You pushed back appropriately on how I was exercising authority. And now, together, we are examining what actually happened. This is confession as it should be. Not me commanding, not you defending, but both of us looking at your soul together and trying to see clearly where God is leading and where pride is misleading.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your role, as you describe it—conveying reality to the Pope, being honest about what you see at Basel, hoping for an outcome but not able to force it—this sounds right to me. This sounds like service rather than saviorhood. You are a messenger, an advocate, perhaps a catalyst. But not the fulcrum on which everything turns. But here is what I must still ask, because I love your soul too much not to: When you think about conveying this reality to Pope Eugenius, what do you hope for? Not what you expect—what do you hope for in your heart of hearts? And be honest—do you hope he will see wisdom and act accordingly? Or do you hope he will see your wisdom and recognize you as the man who showed him the way? The difference is subtle, Your Majesty. But it matters. One is serving the Church. The other is serving while also hoping for recognition. Both can coexist in the same heart. The question is which one dominates.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I sense that you see things differently than I do Fray. Maybe you have a different way of seeing the world, but let me just answer as honestly and as best I can. These past few days have exhausted me mentally. I have given up seeking praise for wisdom, mainly because you are harsh to point this pride out. I have no need for it. I have spent these days doing nothing but to speak with others about theology, faith, wisdom... im just tired of it. The church is so broken that it has also lost much of it's luster. I used to care greatly for a unified church and that would be what I would hope and even fight for. Im sorry to say that I do not care as much any more. I do hope for a unified church instead than another schism. But if the pope decides otherwise, or if the church really tears itself apart...pitty but beyond my control and I will have to live with this new reality.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... Sit down. Please. What you just described—this exhaustion, this loss of caring—Your Majesty, this worries me more than your presumption did. There is a difference between healthy detachment from outcomes and spiritual exhaustion that leads to despair. What you describe sounds like... you have been ground down. By the reality of the Church's brokenness, by days of theological debate, by my harsh corrections, by the weight of everything you carry.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: When you say 'I do not care as much anymore'—Your Majesty, a week ago you wept for the Church. You called it a beacon of all that is good in this world. You said witnessing its corruption hurt you deeply. And now... 'pity but beyond my control'? This is not detachment. This is a man whose heart has been worn down until he protects himself by not caring.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I think I have been too harsh with you. I saw your presumption—and it was real, it is real—but in my zeal to correct it, I may have... broken something precious. Your love for the Church. Your idealism. Your hope that things can be better. Your Majesty, you are twenty years old. You conquered Granada. You came to Basel with genuine faith and genuine desire to help heal Christendom. And in three days here, you have been confronted with the reality that the Church is even more broken than you imagined, that your confessor will not absolve you, that every impulse to help is examined for pride, that men of God spend their days arguing while Constantinople falls.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I fear I have contributed to this exhaustion. In my concern for your soul, I have been... relentless. Harsh. Unyielding. And now you sit before me saying you don't care anymore, and I wonder if I have done more harm than good. There is wisdom in accepting what is beyond your control. That is true. But there is also danger in protecting yourself from pain by not letting yourself care. The first is spiritual maturity. The second is a wounded heart building walls. Which is this, Your Majesty? Have you genuinely reached acceptance of limits? Or have these days simply hurt too much, and not caring is the only way to protect yourself from that hurt?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I might carefully suggest that I am just a bit overwhelmed by everything that has been happening. Remember Fray that until a few weeks ago, the church and it's corruption had been shielded from me. I knew it existed in theory, but I had never expected Basel to be so messy as it is. I have never before seen the church like this. I am a sinner Fray, but maybe you do not have to correct everything you see in me. I cannot correct myself so much anyway. Right now, I am tired, disillusioned. I will recover, dont worry.

encounters.recap: Juan demonstrates spiritual growth by acknowledging his limitations in church reform, recognizing he can only convey reality to the Pope rather than force outcomes. However, he reveals concerning exhaustion and diminished caring about church unity, prompting Fray Hernando to shift from stern correction to pastoral concern, recognizing he may have been too harsh and contributed to Juan's disillusionment.

I have never before seen the church like this. I am a sinner Fray, but maybe you do not have to correct everything you see in me. I cannot correct myself so much anyway. Right now, I am tired, disillusioned. I will recover, dont worry. Look at this conversation as well. It's very tiring for me as well. I dont like correcting or challenging you, but it is exhausting. Exhausting because I must bring it to your attention very carefully since I do not want to deflect your council. And we have made real progress! A lot of progress in fact. May we not take some comfort in this? What do you think Fray, will the lord allow us to enjoy a moment in the day right now? I am going for a walk, would you like to join me?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is exactly when spiritual work is most important - when it becomes uncomfortable. You ask me not to correct everything I see? Then what am I here for? To make you feel good about yourself? We can walk, but know this: backing away from examination when it grows difficult is itself a form of pride.

roll.outcome: Suspicious Resistance - Hernando sees Juan's request as potential avoidance and maintains spiritual rigor despite the king's vulnerability.

encounters.recap: Juan vulnerably admits his exhaustion and disillusionment with the church's corruption, asking for a break from intensive spiritual examination and inviting Fray Hernando for a walk. However, Hernando responds with suspicion, viewing the request as potential spiritual avoidance and maintaining his rigorous approach to confession despite Juan's obvious distress.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is exactly when spiritual work is most important—when it becomes uncomfortable. When the examination touches something real. You ask me not to correct everything I see in you? Then what am I here for? To make you comfortable? To be your companion who walks with you and tells you everything will be fine? That is not a confessor. That is a courtier.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You say you are tired, overwhelmed, disillusioned. I believe you. But Your Majesty, do you not see? This moment—right now, when the work becomes difficult, when examining your soul feels exhausting—this is precisely when backing away is most dangerous. This is when the patterns we have been examining gain their power. When you are tired, when you are overwhelmed, that is when pride whispers 'enough, you have done enough soul-searching, just act.'

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We have made progress, yes. Real progress. But progress in what? We have clarified how confession should work between us. We have established proper boundaries of authority. But have we actually addressed the presumption? Or have we just... talked around it until you grew too tired to continue?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. We can walk. But know this: backing away from examination when it grows difficult is itself a form of pride. It is your soul protecting itself from uncomfortable truths by claiming exhaustion. And if I allow it—if I say 'yes, you are tired, let us speak of pleasant things'—then I am failing you as a confessor.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We walk. But we walk as confessor and penitent, not as friends taking leisure. And as we walk, I will ask you questions. About why you find this examination so exhausting. About whether your disillusionment is wisdom or wounded pride. About whether you are truly accepting limits or simply protecting yourself from caring too much.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am merely pointing out that there is a limit to the amount of council I can recieve before I must pray and reflect on it. I do not seek to avoid you fray. Tell me honestly. Is that what you fear? That I am now avoiding you when it gets hard?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando stops in the doorway. Juan's question hangs in the air between them. He is silent for a long moment, and you can see him actually considering it—not dismissing, not immediately answering, but genuinely examining the question you have put to him. Finally, he steps back from the door and sits down slowly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... yes. That is exactly what I fear. I fear that the moment I ease the pressure, you will revert to old patterns. I fear that if I grant you breathing room, you will use that room to avoid the hard work. I fear that your exhaustion is real and that it is also convenient—that it arrives precisely when examination touches something you do not wish to see.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But you ask me to examine my own soul, and that is... fair. Just. Even wise. Am I reacting from pastoral discernment or from fear? From love of your soul or from my own anxiety that I am failing as your confessor? I do not know, Your Majesty. I genuinely do not know.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
