exchanges.text: You ask if you can have time to pray and reflect before receiving more counsel. That is not only reasonable—it is necessary. Spiritual direction is not meant to be an interrogation that continues until the soul breaks. It is meant to plant seeds that need time to grow.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So perhaps... perhaps you are right. Perhaps we do need to walk simply as two men who serve God. Not to avoid the work, but to give you time to integrate what we have discussed. And perhaps I need to examine whether my fear is making me a harsh taskmaster rather than a wise guide.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Come, Your Majesty. We walk. Not as pleasant leisure, but not as unceasing examination either. Perhaps as... two men who are both trying to discern God's will and both finding it difficult. You with your presumption. Me with my harshness. And if either of us figures out how to be perfect, perhaps we can share the secret with the other.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like that very much Fray. And can I confess something? It is something I have feared sharing even with you. Maybe it played an even greater role than I imagined

encounters.recap: Juan asks for respite from spiritual examination, leading Fray Hernando to initially resist, fearing avoidance of difficult truths. When Juan challenges him directly about this fear, Hernando admits his anxiety and harshness, recognizing Juan's legitimate need for time to integrate spiritual counsel. They agree to walk together as fellow servants of God, with Juan preparing to share a deeply held confession.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We walk. But we walk as confessor and penitent, not as friends taking leisure. And as we walk, I will ask you questions. About why you find this examination so exhausting. About whether your disillusionment is wisdom or wounded pride. About whether you are truly accepting limits or simply protecting yourself from caring too much.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: If you wish a companion for pleasant conversation, Your Majesty, Captain Robles or Abbott Rodrigo would serve better. I am your confessor. And right now, your soul needs examination more than it needs comfort.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am merely pointing out that there is a limit to the amount of council I can receive before I must pray and reflect on it. I do not seek to avoid you fray. Tell me honestly. Is that what you fear? That I am now avoiding you when it gets hard?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando stops in the doorway. Juan's question hangs in the air between them. He is silent for a long moment, and you can see him actually considering it—not dismissing, not immediately answering, but genuinely examining the question you have put to him. Finally, he steps back from the door and sits down slowly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... yes. That is exactly what I fear. I fear that the moment I ease the pressure, you will revert to old patterns. I fear that if I grant you breathing room, you will use that room to avoid the hard work. I fear that your exhaustion is real and that it is also convenient—that it arrives precisely when examination touches something you do not wish to see.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But you ask me to examine my own soul, and that is... fair. Just. Even wise. Am I reacting from pastoral discernment or from fear? From love of your soul or from my own anxiety that I am failing as your confessor?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I do not know, Your Majesty. I genuinely do not know. You have patterns—the presumption is real, the tendency to place yourself at the center is real. But I also have patterns. I have been at Basel for eight months watching learned men avoid hard truths through endless sophisticated arguments. I have grown... suspicious. Harsh. Perhaps too quick to see avoidance even when someone is genuinely overwhelmed.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You ask if you can have time to pray and reflect before receiving more counsel. That is not only reasonable—it is necessary. Spiritual direction is not meant to be an interrogation that continues until the soul breaks. It is meant to plant seeds that need time to grow.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So perhaps... perhaps you are right. Perhaps we do need to walk simply as two men who serve God. Not to avoid the work, but to give you time to integrate what we have discussed. And perhaps I need to examine whether my fear is making me a harsh taskmaster rather than a wise guide.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Come, Your Majesty. We walk. Not as pleasant leisure, but not as unceasing examination either. Perhaps as... two men who are both trying to discern God's will and both finding it difficult. You with your presumption. Me with my harshness. And if either of us figures out how to be perfect, perhaps we can share the secret with the other.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like that very much Fray. And can I confess something? It is something I have feared sharing even with you. Maybe it played an even greater role than I imagined

encounters.recap: Juan challenges Fray Hernando's harsh approach to spiritual direction, asking if the confessor fears Juan is avoiding difficult spiritual work. Hernando admits this fear and acknowledges he may have grown too suspicious and harsh from his experiences at Basel. Both men agree to a more balanced approach to their spiritual relationship.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So perhaps... perhaps you are right. Perhaps we do need to walk simply as two men who serve God. Not to avoid the work, but to give you time to integrate what we have discussed. And perhaps I need to examine whether my fear is making me a harsh taskmaster rather than a wise guide.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Come, Your Majesty. We walk. Not as pleasant leisure, but not as unceasing examination either. Perhaps as... two men who are both trying to discern God's will and both finding it difficult. You with your presumption. Me with my harshness. And if either of us figures out how to be perfect, perhaps we can share the secret with the other.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like that very much Fray. And can I confess something? It is something I have feared sharing even with you. Maybe it played an even greater role than I imagined

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando stops and turns to face you fully. The sternness is gone now, replaced by something gentler—a priest recognizing the moment when a soul is about to open a door it has kept closed.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... If you have been carrying something you feared to share even with me, then yes. Please. Tell me. Let us sit. A confession given while standing in doorways is not truly given. Come.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Whatever it is, Your Majesty, know this: I am your confessor. Not your judge. My role is to help you see your soul clearly, not to condemn what I find there. And if you have been afraid to share this with me... that fear itself tells me it is something important. Something that has been weighing on you. Speak freely. Whatever it is—I am here to listen, not to attack.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The pope has granted me and all crusaders absolution in Rome after we concluded the crusade. What we are doing right now, I believe this to be true confession and searching for absolution. I think or I fear that the absolution I received for completing the crusade is not the same. In fact it feels wrong. Far removed from God's grace. It made me doubt the church as well I think.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando goes very still. His eyes widen slightly, and for a long moment he simply stares at you. When he speaks, his voice is barely above a whisper.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... how long have you been carrying this? Tell me. Tell me exactly what happened in Rome. What the absolution felt like. Why it felt wrong.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I marched my crusaders through the ancient city. The pope was not safe in his own city. We had to keep our weapons at the ready as we carried 300,000 florins, the banner through the city. I delivered everything to the pope who was very happy to see me. I had expected...something different. Something more profound. Eugenius held up his hands high and spoke a sentence. My crusaders felt deeply moved, but I felt nothing. I thought I would feel God's grace, but I did not.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe this has been weighing on me more than I thought. We set off towards Basel immediately afterwards. I knew you were here and that I would seek you out for confession the moment we would meet again. I think I knew the absolution from the pope was not real. Or thought it was at least. Am I making sense Fray?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's face changes completely. His eyes widen with dawning comprehension, and he slowly sinks into the chair across from you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... You have been seeking true absolution since Rome. Everything I have seen in you these past days—all of it—you have been acting from spiritual hunger. The Pope's absolution was valid, Your Majesty. Theologically, sacramentally—it was valid. When he raised his hands and spoke those words, your sins were forgiven before God. That is how the sacrament works. It does not depend on your feelings or mine.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But absolution without true confession, without examination of sin, without the work of conscience that prepares the soul to receive grace... it can feel hollow. Not because grace was absent—grace was there. But because you had not done the work that makes the soul ready to receive that grace. Your soul knew something was wrong. Not that the absolution was invalid—but that it was incomplete.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You came to Basel seeking me. You knew you needed true confession. And I—I saw your presumption, your certainty, your grand plans. I corrected them, assigned tasks, denied you absolution. But I never asked the simple question: Why are you so desperate? What are you seeking? You have been spiritually starving, Your Majesty. And I have been critiquing your table manners while refusing to feed you.

roll.outcome: Pastoral Understanding - Fray Hernando recognizes Juan's spiritual hunger beneath his presumptuous behavior, understanding that the Pope's valid absolution felt hollow without true confession

encounters.recap: Juan confesses his deepest fear to Fray Hernando: that the papal absolution he received in Rome felt spiritually hollow and distant from God's grace. This revelation transforms Hernando's understanding, as he realizes Juan has been acting from spiritual hunger rather than mere presumption, seeking true confession and meaningful absolution rather than the formulaic ritual he experienced with the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's face changes completely. His eyes widen with dawning comprehension, and he slowly sinks into the chair across from you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... You have been seeking true absolution since Rome. Everything I have seen in you these past days—all of it—you have been acting from spiritual hunger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward, his expression no longer that of a stern examiner but of a priest finally understanding the wound he's been treating.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Pope's absolution was valid, Your Majesty. Theologically, sacramentally—it was valid. When he raised his hands and spoke those words, your sins were forgiven before God. That is how the sacrament works. It does not depend on your feelings or mine.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But absolution without true confession, without examination of sin, without the work of conscience that prepares the soul to receive grace... it can feel hollow. Not because grace was absent—grace was there. But because you had not done the work that makes the soul ready to receive that grace. Do you understand the difference?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hernando runs his hand over his face.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You marched into Rome carrying the crusade treasury and sacred relics. You delivered them to a Pope besieged in his own city. He was grateful, overwhelmed, moved. And he granted you and your crusaders absolution—a plenary indulgence for completing your service. This is his right and authority. But there was no confession first. No examination of your particular sins. No naming of what you personally had done wrong. Just... a formula spoken over hundreds of men.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your soul knew something was wrong. Not that the absolution was invalid—but that it was incomplete. Like receiving medicine for a wound that has not been cleaned. The medicine works, but the wound still festers because the poison was never drawn out.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans back, and there's something like sadness in his expression.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is what is wrong with the Church, Your Majesty. Not just simony and pluralism and concubinage—though those are real. But this. Absolution granted by formula without confession. Grace dispensed like... like coins from a purse, without the relationship, without the examination, without the genuine spiritual work that makes grace meaningful.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You came to Basel seeking me. You knew you needed true confession. And I—I saw your presumption, your certainty, your grand plans. I corrected them, assigned tasks, denied you absolution. But I never asked the simple question: Why are you so desperate? What are you seeking?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You have been spiritually starving, Your Majesty. And I have been critiquing your table manners while refusing to feed you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long pause.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The presumption is still real. The pattern of placing yourself at the center—that is still something we must address. But now I understand it differently. You have been acting from a soul that felt unforgiven, trying to earn through works what should come through grace. Trying to prove your worthiness through grand accomplishments because you never felt truly absolved in Rome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His expression is gentle now, almost tender.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Tell me, Your Majesty: What sins have you been carrying? What specific things weigh on your conscience that you never confessed to the Pope because there was no opportunity for true confession? What has your soul been trying to tell you needs to be named, examined, and genuinely absolved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He waits, no longer the harsh examiner but the compassionate priest Juan came to Basel to find.

roll.outcome: Excavated spiritual crisis beneath surface behavior patterns

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando finally understands Juan's true spiritual condition—that he has been seeking genuine confession and absolution since Rome. The Pope's absolution was valid but felt hollow because it lacked proper confession and examination of conscience. Hernando realizes he has been treating Juan's symptoms of spiritual hunger rather than addressing the underlying wound, and offers to provide the true confession Juan has been desperately seeking.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Can you do that, Your Majesty? Can you let me point out spiritual dangers without treating it as attack you must defend against? Can you sit with the possibility that sometimes I see your soul more clearly than you see it yourself, even when that possibility is uncomfortable? If you can do that—truly do that—then yes, we can find a way that works for both of us. I will be your spiritual friend, not your spiritual commander. But friendship requires mutual honesty and trust. I must trust that you will not use collaborative style to avoid hard truths. You must trust that when I name spiritual danger, I do so out of love, not desire to control. Does this work for you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You point out a sin in my actions. And I do not explain it? I just...understand it immediately? Is this how confession works? Because the things I did, in sin, I did for a reason. My most natural reaction is to give you this (sinful) reaction. It exposes it. I see that there is danger in defending against warnings from you, but otherwise, we have to talk about it right? Or do others just immediately see what is pointed out to them?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando stops. He actually stops, his mouth opening slightly as if to respond, then closing again. He sits back in his chair, and something like surprise crosses his features.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... that is an excellent question. Genuinely excellent. You are right. You are absolutely right. Of course you must explain your reasoning. Of course you must tell me why you did what you did, what you were thinking, what motivated you. How else can I—or you—examine whether those motivations were pure or corrupted? How else does confession work? I think... I think I have been confusing two different things. Let me try to articulate this clearly, because you have identified something I was doing wrong.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Explaining your reasoning—'I spoke that way because I felt enthusiasm,' 'I used those words because Cardinal Cesarini responded well'—this is necessary. This is good. This is how we examine conscience together. You must tell me what you were thinking and feeling. Otherwise I am just judging external actions without understanding interior motivations. But there is a difference between explaining and defending. Between 'here is why I did this, help me see if it was sinful' and 'here is why I did this, therefore it was not sinful.' Do you see the distinction? When you explain, you are opening your soul for examination. You are saying 'this is what happened inside me—help me understand it.' When you defend, you are closing your soul to examination. You are saying 'this is what happened inside me—and here is why it was actually fine.'

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Let me give you an example. You return from your meeting saying 'I have made a plan to reform the Church.' I point out this sounds presumptuous. Now there are two ways you might respond: First way—explaining: 'I can see why it sounds that way. In my excitement, I put myself at the center of the language. What actually happened was Cardinal Cesarini and I discussed an approach together, and I am one part of it. But yes, the way I spoke just now—"I have made a plan"—that does reveal pride. Help me understand why I defaulted to that language.' Second way—defending: 'I know it sounds presumptuous, but actually I am in a unique position with papal decree and crusader authority, and convincing the Pope is logical given my circumstances, and most clergy don't practice confession as much as I do, and I am ready to stand before God's judgment, so really my presumption is justified by my special situation.' Do you see? The first opens to examination. The second closes it. The first invites me to help you see more clearly. The second explains why my correction doesn't apply.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty, I think I have been... impatient. When you start explaining, I immediately hear it as defending, and I cut you off or challenge you harder. That is my failing, not yours. I should let you explain fully, and only then ask: 'Now that you have explained your reasoning, can you see any spiritual danger in it? Or do you believe your reasoning justifies the action completely?' Does this make sense? Explanation is necessary—you are right about that. But explanation must remain open to the possibility that even with good reasons, the action might still have been spiritually disordered. And I must be patient enough to let you fully explain before I judge whether you are explaining or defending. You have just taught me something about spiritual direction, Your Majesty. And I am grateful for it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I clearly see the distinction. And lets immediately continue with your example. I am indeed very happy and also relieved that we can save the church. The fact that Cesarini has put me at the fulcrum of it...or has he... I have a role to play in it all that's for sure. Interesting that I drifted towards that description. What do you think Fray?

encounters.recap: Juan questions Fray Hernando about confession methodology, pointing out the tension between explaining one's actions and being defensive. Fray Hernando recognizes the validity of Juan's concern and clarifies the distinction between explaining (opening oneself to examination) and defending (closing oneself to correction). Both men reach a deeper understanding of how spiritual direction should work, with Hernando acknowledging his own impatience and Juan immediately applying the new framework to examine his feelings about his role in church reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The merchant's house study felt smaller than it had moments before. Shadows pooled in the corners as afternoon light slanted through the narrow window. Fray Hernando sat motionless, his weathered hands folded in his lap, eyes steady on Juan's face. The question hung in the air between them like something physical. Not accusing. Not impatient. Simply there. Waiting.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask what sins I carry, Fray. The sins I carry are not those of adultery, lying, stealing. Mine are more in terms of pride, presumption, other sins that can hide in good intentions. I know I am a sinner and I always like how we can examine these things together. I have been missing that most of all. Since we met again, I have searched to the best of my ability for the sins on my soul.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have made many choices that determined the lives of many men. Many have died. Or got wounded. I did it all in the name of our Lord and maybe I took some comfort in the knowledge that I would be forgiven, or that also the cause was just. Probably both. The weight of running the kingdom as a whole, dealing with rebels. I guess I always knew that all these choices were good, or at least any sins coming from them would be forgiven.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do I make sense, Fray? I always try to act in accordance with Christian virtue. Have I been hiding behind the crusade banner to hide my sin?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Yes. Yes. This is what I have been waiting to hear.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hernando stood and moved to the window where Juan had stood moments before, looking out at the divided city. When he spoke again, his voice carried not accusation but understanding.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Not elegant self-analysis, Your Majesty. Not philosophical questions about whether you've been hiding. But honest recognition: 'I took comfort in knowing I'd be forgiven.' That comfort - that certainty of absolution before acting - that is the spiritual disease.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The crusade banner didn't just inspire holiness. It excused examination. Every death, every hard choice, every moment when you might have paused to ask 'Is this right?' - the banner answered before you could question. Of course it's right. God blessed this cause. The Pope blessed this cause. Any sins will be forgiven because the cause is just.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: That comfort is poison, Your Majesty. Not because the cause was unjust - the Reconquista was just. But because that certainty made you God's instrument in your own mind before you ever asked God if He wanted you to be His instrument. It made examination feel unnecessary. Wasteful. Perhaps even faithless.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You ask me if you've been hiding behind the crusade banner. I think you already know the answer. You wouldn't ask the question if some part of you didn't recognize the truth of it. But knowing the mechanism is not the same as confessing the acts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando sat now, deliberately, slowly. Not the harsh interrogator of recent days but something gentler. A physician who has finally found the wound.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So now - now we can do real work. Not abstract examinations of pride and presumption, but concrete acts. What did that comfort permit you to do? Which specific decisions did you make more easily because you knew they would be forgiven? Which deaths sit on your soul not because they were wrong, but because you didn't grieve them properly - because the banner made grief feel unnecessary?

roll.outcome: Encouraged Breakthrough - Hernando recognizes Juan's honest admission about taking comfort in pre-absolution as the spiritual disease he has been waiting for Juan to identify. He presses for specific acts that this comfort permitted.

encounters.recap: Continuing the confession begun in Chapter 2.5, Juan moves beyond abstract sins of pride to confess the mechanism of his spiritual disease: taking comfort in the certainty of forgiveness before acting, using the crusade banner as a shield against examination. Fray Hernando, rolling a 71, responds with encouraged recognition rather than harsh interrogation, identifying this honest admission as the breakthrough he has been waiting for. He urges Juan to name the specific acts that this comfort of pre-absolution permitted him to commit without proper grief or examination.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fray... there are so many actually. I feel a bit stupid not sharing this earlier. I did not think it affected me at all.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So many spring to mind. The ambush me and my company had to fight through. I gave the order to push through in close formation. We could not stop to collect our wounded. Those men gave their lives for me. And I do not even know their names.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dream about the young soldier at Loja. I had ordered the assault on the fort and it was brutal, the garrison fought like devils. Made us bleed for every foot. I visited the wounded afterwards. He looked up at me with the innocence of youth and said 'We did it, we have taken the fort!' He was dying, Fray. I thanked him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And the hundreds killed and wounded I never even met. Reports that told about a setback, a few hundred wounded or killed, in the grand scheme of things one soldier's life is not much, but behind every number is a soul. And I ordered them all into a grand design. Their deaths and suffering must not have been for nothing, right Fray?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando sat very still for a long moment. The afternoon light slanting through the window had shifted, casting longer shadows across the study floor. When he finally spoke, his voice carried something that hadn't been there in days - not harshness, not examination, but relief.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This. This is what I have been waiting for.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes searched Juan's face.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Not philosophy about pride. Not elegant questions about whether you've been hiding. But grief. Real men. Real deaths. Real weight.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the wounded you left in the ambush whose names you never learned - that is not an abstraction. The boy at Loja who thought he'd won while dying - that is not a concept to be examined. The hundreds reduced to numbers in reports - those are souls, as you said. And you have carried them. Carried them without proper confession, without proper absolution, trying to bear the weight alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando made the sign of the cross, his hand steady and deliberate.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Ego te absolvo in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti. For the sins you have confessed - for taking comfort in certain forgiveness rather than examining each moment as it came. For allowing the righteousness of the crusade to become a shield against proper grief. For the spiritual disease of pre-absolution that made examining your conscience feel unnecessary. You are forgiven.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He placed his hand on Juan's shoulder - a gesture he hadn't made since their reunion.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You have shown true contrition, Your Majesty. You have named what you carry. That is confession. And I... I have been harsh with you these past days. Critiquing your presumption while you were spiritually starving. That was not the guidance you needed.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: That question you asked at the end - 'must not have been for nothing, right Fray?' - I hear it differently now. Not as manipulation or seeking validation, but as the cry of a soul that has carried unforgiven weight too long. The desperate need for their suffering to mean something.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We will work on that together. On helping you carry this weight as a king must - honestly, without false comfort of certainty, but also without the crushing burden of carrying it alone and unforgiven. But for now... you are absolved. Truly absolved. Not the hollow formula you received in Rome, but genuine forgiveness after genuine confession. You have been carrying this since you knelt naked before the Holy Father, and you should not have had to carry it this long.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room felt different now. Quieter. The weight that had hung in the air between them for days had shifted - not disappeared, but transformed into something more bearable.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: How do you feel, Your Majesty?

roll.outcome: Warm Recognition and Absolution - Hernando's face softens with clear relief. He recognizes grief, real men, real deaths, real weight. He grants absolution with the sign of the cross, forgiving Juan for taking comfort in certain forgiveness and allowing the crusade banner to shield against proper grief.

encounters.recap: Juan names the specific acts that haunt him: the wounded left behind in an ambush whose names he never learned, the dying boy at Loja who thought he had won, and the hundreds reduced to numbers in reports. Hernando, rolling a 53 on the revised table, responds with warm recognition and grants genuine absolution - the first true absolution Juan has received since the hollow ceremony in Rome. Hernando admits he was too harsh in previous days and reframes Juan's final plea ('must not have been for nothing') not as validation-seeking but as the cry of a soul carrying unforgiven weight too long.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The absolution hits Juan like a hammer. His shoulders start to shake.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Father... the absolution... I do not deserve it. And I had even given up hope I would ever receive it at all. But I now feel God's grace again. I can see it. A light. A path.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think I know what I can do. And I will. And I will stumble and fail, Fray. I will succumb to presumption and pride. And maybe other sins I have not yet come to know.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But I must try, Fray. Try and stay on the path of our Lord. Would you be my confessor, Fray? Now that you know what task is being asked of you? I know I test your patience many times and I can find another confessor should you feel a different calling. We can part ways honourably should you choose this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando looked at Juan for a long moment - at the shaking shoulders, the raw vulnerability of a king who had just received grace he didn't think he deserved. Something in the confessor's face shifted, the harsh lines softening.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you offer me an honorable way out, and I respect that deeply. But I do not seek one.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You will stumble. You will succumb to presumption - probably tomorrow, possibly within the hour. And yes, you will test my patience. I am harsh, Your Majesty. I am suspicious. I am perhaps too quick to see pride where there is only human weakness trying to do its best in impossible circumstances.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But that is what spiritual direction is. Not a perfect confessor guiding a perfect penitent toward certain holiness. It is two imperfect men trying to discern God's will while wrestling with their own failures. You with your presumption. I with my harshness. Both of us stumbling.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will be your confessor, Your Majesty. Not because I have the patience of a saint - God knows I do not. Not because this work is easy - it is perhaps the most difficult calling I have ever received. But because this is the work God has given me.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And you... you are learning. Slowly. Painfully. With many steps backward for each step forward. But you are learning. That confession you just made? The grief you just showed? Six months ago in Rome, you could not have done that. You would have given me philosophy and elegant self-analysis. Today you gave me men's names. Men's faces. Real weight.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So yes. I will walk this path with you. I will correct you when correction is needed - and I will probably do it too harshly sometimes. I will deny you absolution when you are not ready - and I may sometimes deny it when I should grant it. I will test your patience as you test mine.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But we will stumble toward God together. And that, Your Majesty, is all any confessor and penitent can do. We are both imperfect instruments trying to discern the voice of a perfect God. We will fail. We will frustrate each other. But we will try.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light had deepened now, casting amber across the study walls. Somewhere in the city below, bells rang for Vespers.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is my calling. Until God releases me from it, I am your confessor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan takes his hand.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then let us build God's kingdom together, Fray. Come.

roll.outcome: Committed Partnership - Hernando softens, respects the honorable exit offered but declines it. Accepts the role as confessor with honest acknowledgment that both men are imperfect, committing to stumble toward God together.

encounters.recap: Overwhelmed by the absolution, Juan's shoulders shake as he feels God's grace for the first time since Rome. He humbly asks Fray Hernando to continue as his confessor, offering him an honorable exit if he prefers. Rolling a 59, Hernando commits to the partnership with warmth and honesty, acknowledging his own harshness as a flaw alongside Juan's presumption. He frames their relationship as two imperfect men stumbling toward God together, and formally accepts the calling as Juan's confessor. This marks a fundamental shift in the Juan-Hernando dynamic from adversarial examination to committed spiritual partnership.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks out of the study and commands 'Assemble everyone outside!' He goes inside and starts getting into his crusade armor with the white cloth - not because he needs protection, but because it is familiar attire that makes him feel at ease.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando followed Juan out of the study, his expression shifting from pastoral warmth to something more cautious - watching. Within minutes, the courtyard of the merchant's house began to fill.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernan Alonso de Robles emerged first from the guardroom, hand instinctively on sword hilt. Behind him came the fifty crusaders in white surcoats marked with red crosses. Abbott Rodrigo Gonzalez hurried from the upper chambers. Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena appeared moments later, still holding a quill. The courtyard fell silent as Juan emerged in full crusade armor - the white surcoat brilliant in the golden light, the red cross stark across his chest.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Crusaders, Father Abbott and the others of my delegation, the Lord asks us to fight once more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: These last few days have hurt me greatly. I have seen with my own eyes how the holy Church is tearing itself apart. And the worst part is that changing this is not up to us, not up to me. We are affected by it. We are helpless children as the Church thunders on. And I have not been willing to accept this reality.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But it is what it is. Some things are not in our hands and resisting this natural order of things leads to chaos. Sin. And death.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What can we do? What can I do? When the problems are beyond our control to mend, and we cannot turn the minds of others? We must do what we can do. We must fight!

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I did not don my armor for a physical fight. I myself must instead fight against my own sins of presumption. I see that now. And I also see that I must always fight this. Fight for what is right, just and virtuous. As should we all. Turning the hearts of others is the domain of the Almighty alone. But if we can just win our own fight - the fight for our own soul, fighting our own sin - are we not also fighting for God's kingdom?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan takes his sword from his hip, keeping it in its scabbard, and holds it up high.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This fight is a spiritual one. And I have just found out that confession has helped me greatly. We have all been forgiven by the Pope in Rome, but this fight is not one that is won decisively, allowing us to rest on our laurels. No. It is a constant battle. We can win victories, yes, but as mortal men can never totally defeat it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I invite you all to join me in this fight. We are in a great struggle at the moment and I encourage everyone to do what he can. Seek out confession, point out sins of pride or greed. Search your own soul. And together, together, if we truly seek out God's grace, only then are we worthy of His victory.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan draws his sword and holds it up high.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We have much to do. We cannot reform the Church, but we can do what we do best. Tomorrow I will formally commit to aiding Constantinople. I ask if some of you accompany them back east. The rest of us will travel home soon for some well deserved rest. But until then -

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan looks up at the sword.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Remember. Non nobis Domine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: 'Non nobis Domine!' The response thundered from the crusaders' throats. Fifty swords flashed from scabbards, raised high. The white surcoats seemed to glow in the golden light. Captain Robles's voice led them, and the courtyard rang with their unified cry: 'NON NOBIS DOMINE!'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But beyond the ranks of enthusiastic warriors, Abbott Rodrigo Gonzalez stood very still. His aged eyes met Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena's across the courtyard. The Bishop's hand, which had begun to rise in blessing, paused. A look passed between them - concern, recognition, something almost like grief. Both had seen Juan just hours ago. Exhausted. Disillusioned.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando had not moved. He stood to the side, his weathered face carefully neutral. But his posture - arms crossed, weight slightly back - spoke volumes. He was not joining the enthusiasm. He was watching. And the clergy noticed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As the cheering began to fade, Abbott Rodrigo moved slowly through the crowd, approaching Juan with deep respect but also a grandfather's gentle concern.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, those were beautiful words. Truly beautiful. The crusaders are moved, and rightly so.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty... just hours ago, you were exhausted. Overwhelmed. And now... this is the pattern, is it not? A spiritual breakthrough, and then immediately - immediately - a grand gesture. A declaration. An assembly.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Perhaps what you need now is rest? To let the grace you received settle into your bones before channeling it into action? The transformation is real, Your Majesty. I can see it in your eyes. But transformation needs time to take root.

roll.outcome: Crusaders enthusiastic, clergy deeply concerned - Crusaders respond with 'Non nobis Domine!' but Abbott exchanges worried glance with Bishop. Fray Hernando's watchful stance is noticed. Enthusiasm is genuine but clergy see the pattern: spiritual breakthrough immediately becomes grand gesture.

encounters.recap: Immediately after receiving absolution, Juan dons his crusade armor and assembles the entire delegation in the courtyard for a rousing speech about spiritual warfare, confession, and commitment to Constantinople. The crusaders respond thunderously with 'Non nobis Domine!' and drawn swords. However, rolling a 37, the clergy react with deep concern: Abbott Rodrigo and Bishop Cartagena exchange worried glances, recognizing the familiar pattern of spiritual breakthrough immediately channeled into grand public gesture. Fray Hernando stands apart, arms crossed, watching - and the clergy notice his caution. Abbott Rodrigo gently confronts Juan about the pattern, urging rest rather than immediate action.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You call it the pattern. It is also who I am. A great burden has been lifted from me and I felt the urge to share it with you and the crusaders. What is wrong with that? I am not a monk, I am a king and things are expected of me. If I am constantly guarding against presumption and sin, I would get nowhere.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You say it is the pattern. Sure. But let me ask you this. Where is the actual sin? Tell me that and I promise you I will examine it carefully.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... the sin is... it is not... I cannot say there is a specific sin in what you just did.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_de_cartagena
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you are right. Sharing joy with your men after receiving grace - that is not sin. Leading them - that is your office. Being decisive - that is kingship. Perhaps we are being overly cautious.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you ask where the sin is. That is a fair question. There may be no sin in the act itself. Sharing grace with your men. Leading them. These are good things.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But the timing. You received absolution perhaps what, half an hour ago? Less? And already you are in armor, making declarations, committing to Constantinople tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Is the sin in acting? No. But perhaps the question is whether the grace has time to transform you before you use it as fuel for action. You said yourself moments ago: 'I will stumble and fail. I will succumb to presumption.' And I said I would help you carry that weight.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty, we have not even left the room where you received absolution, and already you are doing. Not resting in what you received. Not letting it settle. But immediately channeling it into grand gesture.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You ask where the sin is. Perhaps there is none. Perhaps we are being overly cautious, as the Bishop says. Or perhaps the sin is not in the doing, but in the inability to not do. To simply receive grace and rest in it, even for an evening.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is right that you are a king, not a monk. Things are expected. But even kings need time for grace to take root before bearing fruit. That is not monastic withdrawal. That is wisdom.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You ask us to identify the sin so you can examine it. That is good. Honest. But Your Majesty, do you see that you are doing it again? Turning even this conversation into action? 'Tell me the sin so I can examine it' - already looking forward to the next task, the next thing to accomplish. Rather than simply being still with what you just received.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And being still about what we receive is a great guard against sin. That may be wisdom, but I am glad you agree that there is in this case no sin to examine. What happened here was just that I felt inspired and relieved. I acted in the grand gestures and speeches that are normal to me. It felt right somehow. I wanted to share a moment with the men who have received absolution with me from the Pope and share my own breakthrough with them. Maybe some struggle the same way I did with the papal absolution. I also wanted to not keep what I had discussed with Fray in private to just myself. Sharing it out in the open somehow feels more sincere.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Look at me, discussing theology like a priest. I am going for a walk through the city. Let's have dinner together tonight, alright? We can discuss further and I am glad to receive any further insight any of you have.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando closed his eyes briefly. When he opened them, his expression carried something that looked like grief mixed with exhaustion.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. You are doing it right now. Right now, in front of us.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: We raised a concern. You asked us to identify the sin. We gave you a nuanced answer - perhaps no sin in the act, but a pattern in the inability to be still. And you took that nuance as vindication. 'You agree there is no sin to examine.' Then you dismissed our actual concern by joking about 'discussing theology like a priest.' And now you are leaving.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is the pattern, Your Majesty. Challenge arrives. You engage it just enough to deflect it. Then you move on to the next thing. The walk through the city. The dinner discussion. Always moving. Always doing. Never simply receiving what has been given and sitting with it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Abbott Rodrigo's aged face showed something like sorrow. He nodded slowly but said nothing. What could he say? Juan was the king. If the king wished to leave, he would leave. Bishop Cartagena bowed respectfully, but his eyes reflected the same resignation.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Go on your walk, Your Majesty. We will speak at dinner.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: There was no anger in his voice. No judgment. Just tiredness. And perhaps a touch of sadness - not at Juan's failure, but at the recognition of how hard this transformation would actually be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crusaders still stood at attention, uncertain. The courtyard had grown uncomfortable - no longer filled with inspiring rhetoric but with the awkward silence that follows when authority figures disagree in public.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: We will be here when you return, Your Majesty. Enjoy your walk.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words were kind. But underneath them lay an unspoken understanding: they could not stop this pattern. They could only walk beside it, point it out when they saw it, and pray that eventually - perhaps over years rather than hours - transformation would take deeper root.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, shall I accompany you?

roll.outcome: Frustrated Recognition - Fray Hernando closes his eyes briefly. Abbott and Bishop exchange looks of resignation. Hernando names the pattern happening in real time: concern raised, specifics demanded, nuance taken as vindication, then dismissal and departure. They let their king leave but the concern remains unaddressed.

encounters.recap: Juan pushes back against the clergy's concern about his pattern, challenging them to name the specific sin rather than criticize his nature as a decisive king. The clergy struggle to identify a concrete sin, and Bishop Cartagena even concedes Juan may be right. Fray Hernando offers the most nuanced response - perhaps the sin is not in the doing but in the inability to simply be still with grace received. Juan takes their inability to name a specific sin as vindication, dismisses the theological discussion, and announces he is going for a walk. Rolling a 37, Hernando responds with frustrated recognition, naming in real time exactly what is happening: Juan engaged the challenge just enough to deflect it, took their nuanced answer as vindication, and is now leaving. The courtyard is left divided - crusaders uncertain, clergy resigned, the pattern fully demonstrated before their eyes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words echoed off the ancient stones of the merchant house courtyard. Fifty throats answered: 'Non Nobis Domine! Non Nobis Domine!' The chant continued, building in intensity despite the smaller number. Marco Tornesi had tears streaming down his weathered face. Andrea Vescovi -- the gangly Florentine farmer's son who had been the first to take the oath three years ago -- stood with fist raised, voice hoarse. Brother Guillem led the monastery-trained voices in harmony, turning the Latin into something almost liturgical.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chanting gradually faded. The crusaders remained in the courtyard, breaking into smaller groups. Their voices carried excitement, energy -- discussions of Constantinople, the Greeks, what fighting the Ottomans would mean. Some spoke of seeing their families in Granada first, settling affairs before such a journey. Others debated whether Turkish janissaries were truly as fearsome as rumored.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernan Alonso de Robles stood near the courtyard entrance, observing. He had positioned guards at the gate during the speech. Now he watched the dispersing crowd with the practiced eye of a man responsible for security. The late afternoon sun cast long shadows across the cobblestones.

encounters.recap: Following Juan's rallying speech to his fifty crusaders in Basel, the men respond with the chant 'Non Nobis Domine' with great intensity. The crusaders break into animated groups discussing Constantinople, the Ottomans, and logistics for the journey ahead. The energy from the speech lingers as the courtyard slowly empties.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captain, we will meet with the Greeks soon. I hope some brothers feel the call to accompany the Greeks to their city. I will follow after my visit to Granada and Toledo. I like some brothers already there in Constantinople. For the emperor there to talk to and for me to get a better understanding of the situation once I get there. Do you think some will want to go? I cannot command them to, but would hope some would do this for me.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I think you'll have volunteers. These men are still crusaders at heart, even if the oaths are fulfilled. They didn't fight three years just to return to farms and workshops.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Marco Tornesi, for one. He'll go -- I'd wager my sword on it. The man's been seeking redemption since he left mercenary service. Constantinople is exactly the kind of desperate cause that calls to him. Brother Guillem will volunteer. He's a monk-warrior -- this is precisely his vocation. And Andrea Vescovi... the boy who was first to take your oath? He won't let others go without him. That'd be against his nature.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Giovanni Rossi might stay -- he's older, been talking about seeing his sister in Pisa now that the crusade's done. But Alonso Fernandez will go. Several of the Italians who joined in Barcelona. Maybe ten, perhaps fifteen men total who'll see this as continuing God's work rather than starting something new.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Greeks are desperate, the cause holy, and you've just reminded them why they took the cross. Give me until tomorrow morning. I'll speak with them quietly, see who feels the call. No pressure, as you said -- but I think you'll have your volunteers. Shall I begin asking tonight, Your Majesty? Or would you prefer to address them again tomorrow before the meeting with the Byzantines?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, begin asking immediately. I would like to present the group to the Greeks soon after my meeting with them. Ask them today and give them the night to sleep on it.

roll.outcome: Strong Positive Response: Captain Robles expects ten to fifteen volunteers. Names Marco Tornesi, Brother Guillem, Andrea Vescovi, and Alonso Fernandez as likely. Giovanni Rossi may stay. Robles is confident the speech has rekindled crusading spirit.

encounters.recap: Juan asks Captain Robles whether any of the fifty crusaders would volunteer to travel ahead to Constantinople with the Byzantine delegation as an advance party. A d100 roll of 73 yields a strong positive response: Robles expects ten to fifteen volunteers and names several likely candidates including Marco Tornesi, Brother Guillem, and Andrea Vescovi. Juan orders Robles to begin asking immediately and let the men sleep on it overnight.

encounters.location: Basel, City Streets and Fountain Square

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks through Basel's narrow streets as evening approaches. The city shows signs of strain from hosting the Council for nearly two years -- foreign clerics everywhere, theological arguments spilling from taverns, the local economy both enriched and exhausted by the constant presence of churchmen. Moving away from the cathedral district, he finds quieter neighborhoods where Basel's ordinary residents live. A small square with a fountain, children playing, the smell of bread from a nearby bakery.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: An elderly man sits on a bench near the fountain, feeding pigeons from a cloth bag. He is perhaps seventy-five or eighty, his hands gnarled with age, his face deeply lined. He wears simple but well-maintained clothes -- a prosperous craftsman or merchant, retired.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: You have the look of someone escaping all that madness near the cathedral. Foreign, yes? Come for the Council? Ah. Not just a clerk or theologian. Something more, I think. In my years, I've learned to recognize when great lords walk among us trying to be simple men.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: I was forty years old when they held the Council of Constance. Twenty-five years ago now. This square was full of foreign princes then too. Three popes, they said -- three men all claiming Peter's throne. They argued for four years. Four years! The inns were full, the markets thrived, and we Basel folk watched churchmen debate while Christendom tore itself apart.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: But they ended it. Deposed all three popes, elected Martin. The bells rang for three days. I wept -- grown man, father of four, and I wept because the madness finally stopped.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Now they're at it again. Different words, same madness. Pope versus Council, Council versus Pope. My grandchildren ask me: Will the Church tear itself apart again, grandfather? Will there be three popes once more?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Why is it you think, that us lords try to walk among the simple folk?

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Several reasons, I think. First -- the simple one -- even great lords need air that doesn't smell of intrigue. Up there by the cathedral? Everyone wants something from you. Everyone watches, measures, calculates. Down here, you're just another man feeding pigeons.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Second reason -- less flattering perhaps -- you want to see what we really think. Not what your advisors tell you we think. Not what petitions and formal audiences show you. You want to hear an old man on a bench say what he truly believes, without fear or favor.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: And third -- the reason I think is truest, though lords rarely admit it -- you want someone to see you. Not your title, not your power, not what you represent. Just... you. A man confused by the world, same as any of us.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: In Constance, twenty-five years ago, I met a German prince one evening. Much like this -- he walked away from all the madness, found me in this very square. We spoke for perhaps an hour. He never told me his name, and I never asked. But I saw in his eyes what I see in yours now. Fear. Not of enemies or death -- that's easy fear, soldier's fear. No, the fear that everything you're trying to do might be wrong. That the weight on your shoulders might crush something precious. That perhaps you're not the man everyone needs you to be. Was I right, my lord?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! I think so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan sits down with the old man and talks about family. He tells him about Catalina and that his wife is pregnant again. He asks about fatherhood.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Catalina, you said? That's a good name. Strong. Just learning to stand, then? Grabbing everything, putting everything in her mouth? My eldest daughter -- God rest her, she died of fever twelve years ago -- she was like that. Fearless. Would climb anything if we looked away for a moment.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: I had four children. Lost two -- one in infancy, one as I said to fever. The other two are grown now. My son runs a textile workshop here in Basel. My youngest daughter married a vintner in Freiburg. Seven grandchildren between them.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Fatherhood... I'll tell you what no one tells young fathers. You think it's about protecting them, yes? Keeping them safe, making sure they have what they need. And that's true -- but it's not the heart of it. The heart of it is this: they will become who they become, and you cannot control it. Your daughter -- she'll be her own person. Different from you, different from what you imagine. And your task isn't to shape her into what you think she should be. It's to love whoever she actually is.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: With my son, I wanted him to be a scholar. He had a good mind. But he loved working with his hands, loved the feel of fabric, the patterns. I fought him on it for years. Years! Finally my wife -- God rest her too -- she said to me: 'Hans, you're trying to have the son you imagined instead of the son you have.' Changed everything.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: And about your wife being with child again -- you're afraid?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How can I not be! But I will be by her side. I pray all goes well.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: That you'll be by her side -- that's what matters. My wife, when she bore our fourth child, there were complications. I sat outside the door for twelve hours, praying every prayer I knew. She lived, thank God, though the child did not. You pray, you stay close, and you trust. That's all any man can do, lord or beggar.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They sit together in companionable silence as the evening deepens. The children playing in the square are called home by their mothers. Lamps begin to glow in windows. The old man eventually stands, joints creaking, and tips his hat.

exchanges.speaker: hans_the_elder
exchanges.text: Go with God, my lord. And when that little Catalina is older, tell her a Basel grandfather she never met wished her well.

roll.outcome: Meet elderly Basel resident who remembers Council of Constance (1414-1418), wants to share memories and concerns.

encounters.recap: Juan takes an evening walk through Basel's streets to escape the pressures of statecraft. A d100 roll of 63 leads him to a quiet fountain square where he meets an elderly retired craftsman named Hans who remembers the Council of Constance twenty-five years prior. The old man offers sharp observations about why lords seek out common folk, and the two share an intimate conversation about fatherhood, fear, and family. Juan tells him about his daughter Catalina and his wife's pregnancy. Hans shares wisdom about letting children become who they are meant to be, and wishes Catalina well as they part.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan returns to the merchant house as full darkness settles over the city. The courtyard is quiet now, the crusaders dispersed. A lamp burns in the window of Captain Robles's chamber -- he is likely still speaking with men about Constantinople. In Juan's quarters on the second floor, Fray Hernando has left the leather document case containing the drafted letters to Alvaro de Luna and Emperor John Palaiologos, awaiting review and signature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan reviews both letters, makes minor adjustments to the wording, and signs them with his seal. They will be dispatched in the morning -- orders to Alvaro de Luna for the deployment of 1,000 Military Order knights with 60,000 florins, and the personal letter to Emperor John VIII Palaiologos expressing his desire to visit Constantinople and discuss strategic options.

encounters.recap: Juan reviews and signs two critical letters drafted by Fray Hernando de Talavera: one to Alvaro de Luna ordering the deployment of 1,000 Military Order knights and 60,000 florins for Constantinople, and a personal letter to Emperor John VIII Palaiologos expressing Juan's desire to visit Constantinople and discuss strategic cooperation against the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan wakes to the sound of the city coming alive. The meeting with the Byzantine delegation is arranged for mid-morning at the cathedral chapter house -- Cardinal Cesarini's suggestion for a formal but not overly public setting.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Seventeen volunteers, Your Majesty. More than I expected. Marco Tornesi, as I predicted. Brother Guillem. Andrea Vescovi wouldn't let others go without him. Alonso Fernandez. Giovanni Rossi changed his mind -- said his sister can wait, Constantinople cannot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He lists the others -- mostly men from Barcelona and Florence, several who fought in the hardest campaigns. Good men who understand this isn't another Granada -- it's something harder. The Greeks will have experienced crusaders who know what real war looks like.

encounters.recap: Captain Robles reports to Juan on the morning of June 1 that seventeen crusaders have volunteered to travel ahead to Constantinople with the Byzantine delegation -- more than expected. The volunteers include Marco Tornesi, Brother Guillem, Andrea Vescovi, Alonso Fernandez, and Giovanni Rossi (who changed his mind about visiting his sister in Pisa). The men are mostly veterans from Barcelona and Florence who fought in the hardest Granada campaigns.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is modest by Council standards -- a long table, high windows letting in morning light, walls lined with ecclesiastical documents. Cardinal Cesarini sits at the head of the table. Metropolitan Bessarion and Metropolitan Isidore sit to his right, their dark Eastern vestments contrasting with Cesarini's scarlet. Several other figures are present: two cardinals from the German delegation, Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena representing Castile, and a secretary to record the proceedings.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. Their Eminences, the Metropolitans of Nicaea and Kiev. Shall we begin?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks around the table, shaking the hand of each person present. Cardinal Cesarini's handshake is firm, his eyes grateful. The two German cardinals -- older men, cautious -- accept with diplomatic politeness. Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena bows slightly, clearly pleased. Metropolitan Bessarion's grip is scholar's hands -- ink-stained fingers, but strong. Metropolitan Isidore's handshake is brief but not unfriendly, the wariness from their first encounter somewhat diminished.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty requested this meeting to address the matter of Constantinople's defense. Their Eminences the Metropolitans have traveled from the East to plead their case before this Council. For eight months they have waited while we debate theology. King Juan of Castile has asked to speak directly to this matter. I thought it appropriate that witnesses be present -- that what is said here not be mere private conversation, but carry the weight of public commitment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, dear delegates. I do have to share my intentions about what to do about the Ottoman situation. It is not a secret anymore that I plan to help, but maybe it's better if the Greek delegates explain their situation and what they have come here to ask.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: For eight months we have attended this Council. We came seeking two things: theological reconciliation with Rome, and military aid against the Ottoman Sultan Murad II. On the first matter, we have debated endlessly. The Filioque -- whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father alone, or from the Father and the Son. Centuries of division over this question.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: On the second matter -- the military threat -- we have received sympathy, prayers, and theological debate. The Sultan's armies gather. Our walls need repair. We need soldiers, ships, gold, and we need them now, not after years of discussion about whether councils are supreme over popes.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Constantinople has stood for a thousand years as the shield of Christendom. The wall repairs alone require 50-60,000 florins. Our garrison needs reinforcement. Our naval strength has diminished. Without aid, the question becomes not if Constantinople falls, but when. King Juan has asked what we need. We have told him. The question before this assembly is: will the West answer, or will we watch alone as the New Rome falls?

encounters.recap: A formal meeting convenes at the Cathedral Chapter House with Cardinal Cesarini presiding. The Byzantine Metropolitans Bessarion and Isidore present their case for military aid to Constantinople, detailing eight months of fruitless waiting at Basel while the Ottoman threat grows. They outline their needs: 50-60,000 florins for wall repairs, garrison reinforcement, and naval support. Juan invites them to present their situation formally before the assembled witnesses including German cardinals and Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have committed what I can towards aid for the Greeks. I have commanded already for Castile to gather 1,000 experienced crusaders to sail for Constantinople and have the means to repair the walls with them including 60,000 florins. I have also indicated that I must be realistic about what I can do for Constantinople. I alone cannot turn the tide. I will do what I can and expect nor require anything in return. If we are to drive the Ottoman from the European continent, we all as Christians need to be unified. And when I look around at this council and how we are fighting each other instead of fighting the problem, I have doubts we can.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room responds with immediate, passionate force.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Eight months. Eight months we have sat in this city, explaining to theologians why our walls matter while they debate the Filioque. One Castilian king -- three days in Basel -- orders a thousand knights and sixty thousand florins before we finish explaining our situation. Your Majesty, you have given Constantinople something we had almost lost. Not just soldiers and gold -- though God knows we need them desperately. You have given us hope. Real hope. Hope that the West remembers we exist.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Emperor John will hear of this. Our people will hear of this. When I write to Constantinople, I will tell them: there is at least one Christian king who understands that walls falling is not a theological problem to be debated, but a disaster to be prevented.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The German cardinals are leaning forward in their seats.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal speaks: 'His Majesty shames us. He is correct -- we fight each other while Constantinople falls. While we debate whether councils are supreme over popes, the shield of Christendom crumbles.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The second German cardinal stands: 'The German deputation will propose immediate crusade authorization. We will match Castilian commitment -- how many men can Bavaria and the Rhineland raise? Five hundred? A thousand? We will push this through all four deputations. If a foreign king can act decisively in three days, what excuse does this Council have after two years?'

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, for two years I have tried to hold this Council together. To prevent schism. To find common ground between Pope and Council. And every day it becomes harder, because we argue about power while the world burns. They have sat here for eight months. Good men, faithful men, watching us debate abstractions while their city faces destruction. And you... you have given me what I have prayed for. An example that cannot be ignored. A king who simply acts because it is right to act.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Council and Pope will both issue crusade call for Constantinople. Parallel authority, common cause -- exactly what we discussed yesterday. German deputation will propose it. Castilian delegation will second it. And I will use every bit of authority I possess to push it through.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The secretary has stopped writing, staring at the scene before him. Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena sits very still, clearly moved but also aware of what comes next. The Abbott's warning echoes: French delegation will oppose this. Cardinal Aleman's faction sees any papal cooperation as surrender.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal looks directly at Juan: 'Your Majesty, you criticized this Council for fighting each other instead of the problem. You were right. We have been wrong. Starting today, that changes.'

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: On behalf of Emperor John VIII Palaiologos and the people of Constantinople, I thank His Majesty of Castile. Your aid will be recorded in our chronicles. When the wall repairs are complete, when your knights stand on our battlements, Constantinople will remember who acted when action was needed.

roll.outcome: Passionate Response: Room erupts. Metropolitans overcome with emotion. Isidore nearly weeping. German cardinals commit to pushing crusade authorization through all deputations. Cesarini declares parallel legislation path forward. Byzantines express profound gratitude. French radicals absent but will oppose.

encounters.recap: Juan formally announces his commitment of 1,000 crusaders and 60,000 florins to Constantinople's defense and criticizes the Council for internal fighting while Christendom's shield crumbles. A d100 roll of 89 produces a passionate response: Metropolitan Isidore is nearly moved to tears, Bessarion vows to write Emperor John, the German cardinals commit to pushing crusade authorization through all four deputations, and Cardinal Cesarini declares the parallel legislation strategy as the path forward. The moment is a genuine diplomatic breakthrough, though the absent French radical faction under Cardinal Aleman remains a looming threat.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have prayed and sought confession a lot these past few days. And I have come to the conclusion that I cannot save the church. The church can only save itself. All I can do is fight. Fight for what is right. Fight for the weak, the poor and the just. And I will fight together with all those souls willing to fight alongside me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Metropolitan Isidore and Bessarion, I have a request. I arrived here with 50 crusaders. Some of them would like to accompany you to Constantinople to start their work and to prepare for the arrival of the rest. These men are true Christians and have fought hard in the crusade. They can help Constantinople prepare for more of their number to arrive.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we accept this offer. Gratefully. But we must be honest with you about what this means.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Seventeen experienced soldiers traveling with us to Constantinople -- this is generous and practical. They can assess our defenses, prepare for the larger force, help us understand what we truly need. But...

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Emperor John has not yet approved Western soldiers entering the city. We will write ahead immediately, strongly recommending he accept them. Given your commitment of gold and knights, I believe he will agree. But we cannot promise this until we receive his response.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: And there are practical matters. These men report to whom? To Constantine Palaiologos -- the Emperor's brother who commands our military forces? To your officers when the larger force arrives? This must be clear before they depart. They speak no Greek. Our people speak no Spanish or Latin beyond clergy. How do they communicate their assessments?

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, our people remember 1204. The Fourth Crusade. Western soldiers entered Constantinople as 'allies' and sacked the city. Destroyed more than the Turks ever have. Seventeen men is small number, but the symbol... it is large.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Not all will welcome them immediately. Some will be suspicious. We can manage this -- we will explain these are crusaders committed to our defense, not mercenaries seeking plunder. But you should understand the... complications.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: What we're saying, Your Majesty, is this: We accept. We are grateful. Truly. But we want you to understand what you're offering, and we want to be honest about difficulties so there are no surprises when your men arrive in our city.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: If you still wish to send these seventeen men with us, knowing these complications, we will write to Emperor John tonight. We leave Basel within the week. Your men should prepare for a sea journey -- perhaps two months, perhaps three depending on winds and arrangements through Venice or Genoa.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But my dear friends... this is exactly why I will send these men in advance of the main force. If you have problems with a handful of crusaders, what will happen with hundreds? And you did ask for help. I understand that what happened before has made you suspicious, but looking from our side, it looks weird if we make all of the journey with our chisels and a treasury to repair the walls, only to be treated like criminals. We will need to respect your customs as well and you will need to get accustomed to our presence as well. Use this time to get ready. Ask these men questions. They are men of character and faith. They answer to me. First we need to get Constantinople secured. Then I can have a good long talk with the emperor about how we can structure support in the long term.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is absolutely correct. We ask for help, then immediately explain why help might be difficult. This is... exactly the paralysis you criticized about this Council.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: You make excellent point. If seventeen crusaders cause problems, what happens when thousand arrive? Better to discover difficulties now, when numbers small and solutions possible.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: And you are right -- from your perspective, this must seem absurd. You commit gold, knights, engineers to repair our walls, and we say 'but our people might be suspicious.' This is not how allies behave.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal speaks up: 'His Majesty demonstrates wisdom beyond his years. Test the arrangement with small force first. Identify problems when they can be solved, not when thousand men stand at Constantinople's gates wondering why they're not welcome.'

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
