Now I'm negotiating with Basel to grant communion in both kinds to the Bohemians. The Compactata being drafted right now—this very month—will concede exactly what five crusades failed to prevent.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Is it theologically sound? I don't know. I'm not a theologian. The Council of Constance said Christ is entirely present in the bread alone—concomitance, they call it. So denying the cup doesn't deny Christ's blood. That's the official position. But here's what I do know. The moderate Hussites—the Utraquists—are sincere Catholics who want reconciliation with Rome. If we grant them the cup, they'll accept papal authority on everything else. They'll help us crush the Taborite radicals. They'll bring Bohemia back into the fold. So yes, I support it—not as theology, but as policy. If communion in both kinds ends thirty-five years of war, it's a small price. The question is whether Rome will accept it as a local exception for Bohemia, or whether they'll see it as surrender to heresy.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Third—annates. When a bishop or abbot receives his office from Rome, he pays a fee—roughly half the first year's revenue. For major benefices, this goes to the papal treasury and the cardinals split it. These are called servitia communia. For minor benefices appointed by the Pope, the full payment goes to the Apostolic Camera. There are also smaller fees—servitia minuta—paid to various Curia officials. The amounts are enormous. A wealthy bishopric might owe thousands of florins. The new bishop often has to borrow—from Italian bankers, usually—and spend years paying off the debt. Meanwhile, Rome keeps careful records. The Apostolic Camera knows exactly what every benefice in Christendom is worth.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Council of Constance set a minimum threshold. Benefices worth less than twenty-four gold florins annually are exempt from annates.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: But anything above that threshold pays. And here's the problem: Rome sets the valuations. They can assess a benefice at whatever they claim it's worth. Disputes are endless. The German princes have been screaming about annates for decades. It's one of the few issues where I have genuine support across factions. Your Castilian document says 'reduce and standardize.' I want specific caps. Perhaps: annates cannot exceed one-quarter of the first year's revenue, assessed by the local bishop rather than Rome. Something concrete that actually limits papal extraction. Give me that language, and I can tell my princes I won something real. 'Reduce and standardize' sounds like Rome will keep doing whatever it wants.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: So. Three issues. Imperial privileges in episcopal elections—can we find language that preserves reform while acknowledging traditional rights? Communion in both kinds—are you willing to support it as a path to Bohemian reconciliation? And annates—can we strengthen the language to give it actual teeth? If we can agree on these, we draft tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Explain to me how the new proposed electoral system would work and how you would lose influence. It seems like you have no influence in actual elections but that candidates with a strong relationship with you are at an advantage. Regarding communion in both kinds. A strong choice to now support it if it brings Bohemia back into the church. I understand that this is not easy, but it shows character. Regarding the annates, I would support one-quarter as max for titles. But I doubt letting the local bishop set the worth might swing corruption in the other direction. Should we support also a reform of the apostolic camera and let them assess correctly. I am training assessors in my own kingdom and we should support the camera to not abuse their office to levy overly grand proportions. Would this be acceptable?

encounters.recap: Sigismund insists on collaborative drafting of their alliance proposal. He explains the complex mechanics of imperial influence in ecclesiastical elections, his pragmatic support for communion in both kinds to resolve the Hussite crisis, and detailed problems with the annates system. Juan proposes reforms to the Apostolic Camera's assessment process rather than local bishop control over valuations.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: So. Three issues. Imperial privileges in episcopal elections—can we find language that preserves reform while acknowledging traditional rights? Communion in both kinds—are you willing to support it as a path to Bohemian reconciliation? And annates—can we strengthen the language to give it actual teeth? If we can agree on these, we draft tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Explain to me how the new proposed electoral system would work and how you would lose influence. Regarding communion in both kinds, a strong choice to now support it if it brings Bohemia back into the church. Regarding the annates, I would support one-quarter as max for titles. But I doubt letting the local bishop set the worth might swing corruption in the other direction. Should we support also a reform of the apostolic camera and let them assess correctly?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund pauses, considering your question about electoral reform carefully. He stands, pacing as he thinks.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: You're right to press me on this. Let me be more precise. Currently, cathedral chapters technically elect their bishops. But over the past century, Rome has increasingly used 'papal provisions' and 'reservations'—claiming the right to directly appoint bishops, bypassing chapters entirely. This decree ends that practice. Chapters regain genuine electoral power. My concern is not the substance of the reform. It's the language. If the decree says something like 'no secular prince shall interfere in episcopal elections,' that formally excludes me from even informal influence. What I want is silence on secular rulers—neither endorsing nor forbidding our traditional relationships.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Session Twelve decree focuses primarily on ending papal provisions and restoring chapter elections. It does not explicitly address secular princes' traditional influence, though some interpretations—

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Some interpretations could read it either way. That's the problem. I want language that cannot be interpreted against imperial custom. A reference to 'respecting privileges confirmed at Constance' would accomplish that.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund's expression softens slightly at your words about character and communion in both kinds.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Character. Perhaps. Or perhaps just exhaustion. Thirty-five years of watching men die over whether laymen drink from the cup. But thank you. If Castile supports this position, it strengthens my hand at Basel. The French will oppose it—they want the Hussites crushed, not reconciled. Having a king who actually won a crusade speak for compromise... That carries weight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund listens to your counter-proposal on annates, his expression shifting from skepticism to grudging interest.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Reform the Apostolic Camera itself. You're right that local bishops assessing their own benefices invites a different corruption—undervaluation to curry favor, or overvaluation to harm rivals. But reforming the Camera... that's asking Rome to police itself.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Council has already passed provisions on Camera reform. Session Twelve addresses abuses in the collection of papal revenues. The machinery exists—the question is enforcement.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Alright. One-quarter maximum—that's concrete, that's enforceable. On assessment, we don't shift authority to local bishops, but we demand transparency from the Camera. Published valuations. Right of appeal to a neutral body—perhaps the Council itself, or a standing commission. If we frame it as reforming the Camera rather than circumventing it, Rome might actually accept it. So: one-quarter cap, Camera retains assessment authority but with mandatory transparency, published valuations, and right of appeal. Does that satisfy your concern?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In regards to the elections; I think it is only natural that the election process takes into account the prominent and special relationship these bishops have with Germany and the Holy Roman Empire. Regarding reform of the camera, we encounter the same problem we have everywhere. Who controls or polices the church itself? I think we should establish the habit or precedent that if the men that make up an institution such as the apostolic camera are not performing the tasks correctly or without corruption, the council should dismiss every member of the organization. And yes, this principle would apply to everyone, including popes. What do you think about this?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund nods slowly at your first point, genuine approval in his expression.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: On the electoral language—Yes. That's well-framed. The prince-elector archbishops are not ordinary bishops. They're imperial officers. If we state that candidates for these positions should demonstrate qualifications for both their spiritual and their imperial responsibilities, we acknowledge reality without creating new powers. Good. We can draft that tonight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund listens carefully to your proposal about institutional oversight. His expression shifts—first interest, then something more cautious. He sets down his quill and moves to the window.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Juan. An hour ago, you said we should stay away from Haec Sancta. Sidestep the question of papal versus conciliar authority. Now you're proposing that the Council should have power to dismiss any Church institution—including popes. That's not sidestepping the authority question. That is the authority question. If the Council can dismiss the Pope, the Council is superior to the Pope. That's precisely what Haec Sancta claims.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund returns to his seat, his tone serious but not hostile.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: I understand the logic. Who watches the watchmen? But think about what you're actually proposing. First: You want the Pope to adopt Council reforms through parallel legislation. That requires him to believe the Council respects papal authority. Second: You want to include language saying the Council can dismiss any institution, including popes. The moment Eugenius reads that, he sees a trap. Third: The French will love this language—which should concern you. So here's my question: Do you actually want to take a position on Haec Sancta? Or do you want institutional accountability without explicitly establishing conciliar supremacy over the papacy?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are right, I had just said that I want to keep neutral on Haec Sancta and this proposal would indeed indirectly come down to the same. The pope has already acknowledged Frequens, maybe after a successful council in Basel, maybe in the next, he will acknowledge Haec Sancta as well. For this council, this is not realistic. We should focus on reforms. We should establish the system; a reform of the apostolic camera with reinforcement mechanisms against corruption. For this council, that should be enough.

encounters.recap: Juan and Sigismund negotiate three key reform issues: episcopal elections (agreeing to language acknowledging imperial bishops' dual responsibilities), communion in both kinds for Bohemian reconciliation (Juan's support), and annates reform (one-quarter cap with Camera transparency measures). Juan initially proposes radical conciliar oversight powers but retreats to modest Camera reforms when Sigismund points out this contradicts their neutral stance on papal authority.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: —between saying 'the Council may investigate and recommend reforms to correct institutional failures' and saying 'the Council may dismiss any institution including the Pope.' The first is oversight. The second is supremacy. So here's my question: Do you actually want to take a position on Haec Sancta? Because if you do, I need to understand that before I sign anything. My strategy has been to keep both Pope and Council functioning—not to hand either one victory over the other. Or do you want institutional accountability without explicitly establishing conciliar supremacy over the papacy? Because that's a different document—harder to write, but possible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are right, I had just said that I want to keep neutral on Haec Sancta and this proposal would indeed indirectly come down to the same. The pope has already acknowledged Frequens, maybe after a successful council in Basel, maybe in the next, he will acknowledge haec Sancta as well. For this council, this is not realistic. We should focus on reforms. One of those reforms are making sure the church polices itself. In that vein, we should support an initiative for internal checks in the church. If it is a church institution, it will not have the power to depose a pope. We should establish the system; a reform of the apostolic camera with reinforcement mechanisms against corruption. For this council, that should be enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund's tension eases visibly. He nods, something like respect in his expression.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Good. You can adjust when you've overreached. That's rarer than you'd think in kings. So. Internal mechanisms. The Church policing itself—but with actual teeth. The Camera answers to the Pope. If we create an oversight body that also answers to the Pope, we've accomplished nothing. The fox guarding the henhouse.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: There is precedent for mixed bodies. The Council of Constance established commissions with representatives from multiple nations and factions. They investigated specific abuses, reported findings, recommended actions. They had no power to compel—but their findings carried moral weight.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: So we propose a standing commission—appointed jointly by Pope and Council during sessions, continuing between sessions. They audit the Camera. Investigate complaints. Publish findings. No power to dismiss the Pope. No power to overrule papal decisions. But if they find corruption, they publish it. They name names. They document abuses for all Christendom to see. Sunlight as enforcement. Corrupt officials can't be removed by the commission, but they can be exposed. Let public shame do what legal authority cannot—at least until the Church is ready for stronger medicine. For this Council, that's achievable. It establishes the principle of accountability without claiming supremacy. Future councils can strengthen the mechanism once the precedent exists.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund begins writing notes.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: So—our framework. Electoral reform with language acknowledging imperial functions. Support for communion in both kinds for Bohemian reconciliation. Annates capped at one-quarter with Camera transparency and appeal rights. And a standing oversight commission for institutional accountability. Can we draft tonight? I have two more days in Como. If we leave with letters ready—one to Eugenius, one to our allies at Basel—we've accomplished something real.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fray? Can you draft this document tonight? Emperor? Should we include anything more about what we should do together to give this position some teeth? Should we include something that both of us are committed to work together to ensure church unity through these reforms?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I can have a working draft by morning, Your Majesty. The substance is clear—it's a matter of finding precise language that accomplishes our goals without triggering the concerns we've discussed. If His Imperial Majesty permits, I would work from those notes alongside our delegation's documents. The Emperor's concerns about electoral language and annates specificity are well-taken—better to address them in the initial draft than negotiate amendments later.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund slides the notes across.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Take them. I'll have my secretary available if you need clarification on German precedents. Teeth. What does that actually mean between two rulers separated by a thousand miles? Here is Castile. Here is the Empire. Between us—France, Burgundy, the Italian states. We share no border. Our armies cannot support each other directly. If Eugenius refuses our reforms, I cannot march on Rome, and neither can you. So what can we do together? First: diplomatic coordination. We speak with one voice. Letters delivered simultaneously. Ambassadors instructed to reinforce each other's positions. If the Pope hears the same message from Vienna and Toledo on the same day, he knows this isn't one king's hobby—it's a coalition. Second: economic pressure. The Church depends on revenue from our lands. If we instruct our clergy to delay annate payments pending reform... that's leverage. Not refusal—delay. 'We support the Holy Father, but our bishops require clarity on the new assessment procedures before they can calculate what they owe.' Bureaucratic obstruction in service of reform. Third: the implicit threat. We don't need to say it directly, but Eugenius knows: if Pope and Council split into open schism, secular rulers choose which pope to recognize. If we signal that our support for him depends on reform, he understands the alternative. We don't threaten—we simply remind him that unity requires compromise from everyone. Fourth: Basel itself. Your delegation remains there. I'll return there within weeks. If we coordinate with the German moderates, Cardinal Cesarini, whatever reasonable Italians remain—we build a reform faction that neither French radicals nor papal hardliners can ignore. Weight of numbers. Should we include language about commitment? Yes—but carefully. Something like: 'We pledge to coordinate our efforts in support of these reforms, to encourage their adoption by all Christian princes, and to work toward Church unity through genuine reform rather than factional victory.' What we don't say publicly is the harder question. Are we willing to recognize a Council-elected pope if Eugenius refuses reform entirely and Basel deposes him? Are we willing to withhold recognition from Eugenius if he tries to dissolve Basel again? Those are the real teeth, Juan. The ultimate leverage. I'm not asking you to answer tonight—but you should think about where your limits are. How far are you willing to go if the Pope chooses confrontation over compromise?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And while we don't share borders directly, My alliance stretches from Iberia to Naples in Italy. With the Imperial states to his north and My alliance to the south, the pope is right in between us. He would do well to have a good relationship with us. Fray: Start drafting our position in a statement we both can sign. We will then write separate letters to our delegations and allies and to the pope. But the statement as a separate document signed by both of us will be a powerful statement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund's expression shifts. He looks at you with new appreciation.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Castile, Aragon, Naples. The western Mediterranean. And if Alfonso secures Naples with your support and papal recognition... The Papal States. Here. To the north—my imperial territories, the German princes, Austria. To the south—your alliance. Naples controls the approaches from the south. Aragon holds Sicily, Sardinia, the Balearics. Castile commands the Atlantic and the western Mediterranean. Eugenius sits in Rome with the Colonna threatening him from within, Milan's condottieri raiding his borders, and now two of Christendom's most powerful rulers coordinating reform demands from north and south. You're right. He would do very well to maintain good relationships with us. And if we frame our letter correctly—supportive, cooperative, emphasizing our desire to help him lead reform rather than have it imposed on him—he may see partnership as his best option. Then we're agreed. A joint declaration. Both signatures. Let it be known that Emperor and King stand together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund extends his hand to you. Fray Hernando has been listening carefully. He gathers the notes and documents, his expression focused.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. I understand the task. A formal declaration—a statement of shared principles—signed by both of you. Then separate letters: to our delegations at Basel, to allied cardinals and princes, and to His Holiness Pope Eugenius. For the declaration itself, I have a question of tone. Do we frame this as a petition to the Holy Father—humble subjects requesting reform? Or as a statement of position—two rulers announcing what they support and expect? The first is softer, more traditionally deferential. The second is stronger, makes clear this is a coordinated stance that will not easily bend. The Pope will read the tone as carefully as the substance.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Your friar asks the right question. How do we wish to present ourselves?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Statement of position. We cannot afford another schism. Either we reform or we will be fighting crusades against Christians for the rest of our lives. I think we should signal that we are serious. That there is too much at stake otherwise. And I think our alliance has the political power is strong enough for a statement of position to be taken seriously. Do you agree?

encounters.recap: Juan and Sigismund finalize their joint reform proposal, creating a sophisticated framework for Church accountability that avoids directly challenging papal supremacy. They design a standing oversight commission with moral rather than legal authority, coordinate diplomatic and economic pressure tactics, and recognize their combined territorial control effectively surrounds the Papal States. The meeting concludes with both rulers committing to a formal joint declaration asserting their shared reform position rather than a deferential petition.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: For the declaration itself, I have a question of tone. Do we frame this as a petition to the Holy Father—humble subjects requesting reform? Or as a statement of position—two rulers announcing what they support and expect? The first is softer, more traditionally deferential. The second is stronger, makes clear this is a coordinated stance that will not easily bend. The Pope will read the tone as carefully as the substance.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Your friar asks the right question. How do we wish to present ourselves?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Statement of position. We cannot afford another schism. Either we reform or we will be fighting crusades against Christians for the rest of our lives. I think we should signal that we are serious. That there is too much at stake otherwise. And I think our alliance has the political power strong enough for a statement to be taken seriously. Do you agree?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund is quiet for a moment. The candles flicker. Outside, Como sleeps. Then he nods slowly.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: You're right. A petition from Emperor and King—from men who command between us half of Christendom's military strength—would look like uncertainty. Like we're asking permission rather than stating necessity.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stands, moving to the window one final time. When he speaks, his voice is heavier.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: I've spent two years trying to mediate. Gentle letters. Careful diplomacy. 'Holy Father, perhaps you might consider...' 'Venerable Council fathers, if it please you to examine...' And what has it accomplished? Nothing. They're still at each other's throats. Still more concerned with winning than with the Church surviving. You completed a crusade while I wrote letters. Perhaps it's time I remembered that emperors are supposed to lead, not beg.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund returns to the table and sits heavily.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Statement of position. We support these reforms. We expect the Church to adopt them. We commit to working together to see them implemented. And we make clear—without explicit threat, but unmistakably—that Christian unity depends on genuine reform, not factional victory.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Frame it as duty, not demand. We speak not as adversaries of the Holy Father, but as Christian rulers who cannot watch the Church tear itself apart. Our position is firm because the alternative is unthinkable—not because we seek to diminish papal authority.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Firm in substance, respectful in form. The strength comes from the signatures and the coordination, not from aggressive language.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Exactly. We stand together because we must, not because we wish to threaten. Let Eugenius understand that this is not politics—this is survival. His and ours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand across the table.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Then we are agreed, Juan of Castile. Draft tonight. Review tomorrow. Sign before you leave Como. I have waited a long time to find a king who understands what's actually at stake. Who acts instead of talks. Who listens when he's wrong and adjusts. Perhaps God has not abandoned the cause of Christian unity entirely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases your hand and gestures to Fray Hernando.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Go. Write. We'll reconvene at first light.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. This declaration—if it works—may be remembered for generations. If it fails... I will write carefully.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He departs. The chamber falls quiet. Sigismund pours two cups of wine and slides one to you.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Now. While your friar writes, tell me about Constantinople. You've committed a thousand knights and sixty thousand florins. I received Emperor John's appeals years ago—sent what I could spare, which wasn't much. What's your actual plan? Defend the walls until the Ottomans lose interest? Buy time for a broader crusade? Or something more ambitious?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Even if I consolidate my alliance and unite them in the defence of Constantinople, it still will not be enough. The florins and the men buys them some time. Time to think about what to do next. Actually beating the Ottomans requires a massive effort. And it is really up to Constantinople if they will want to make that effort. I have also offered them sanctuary and the right to settle lands in Castille. But it would mean leaving Constantinople. I dont know what they will say when I visit them later this year.

encounters.recap: Juan and Sigismund finalize their approach to the joint declaration on church reform, choosing a firm statement of position rather than humble petition. They agree to draft the document overnight, emphasizing their shared commitment to Christian unity and reform while maintaining respectful language toward papal authority. The alliance is sealed with mutual respect and discussion of Constantinople's defense.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando gathers the documents and bows to both of you. At the door, he pauses.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. This declaration—if it works—may be remembered for generations. If it fails... I will write carefully.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He departs. The chamber falls quiet. Sigismund pours two cups of wine and slides one to you.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Now. While your friar writes, tell me about Constantinople. You've committed a thousand knights and sixty thousand florins. I received Emperor John's appeals years ago—sent what I could spare, which wasn't much. What's your actual plan? Defend the walls until the Ottomans lose interest? Buy time for a broader crusade? Or something more ambitious?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Even if I consolidate my alliance and unite them in the defence of Constantinople, it still will not be enough. The florins and the men buys them some time. Time to think about what to do next. Actually beating the Ottomans requires a massive effort. And it is really up to Constantinople if they will want to make that effort. I have also offered them sanctuary and the right to settle lands in Castille. But it would mean leaving Constantinople. I dont know what they will say when I visit them later this year.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund drinks slowly, considering your words. The late hour and the wine have softened something in him—this is no longer negotiation, but two tired rulers talking honestly.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Sanctuary in Castile. That's... not what I expected. Most kings who talk about Constantinople imagine themselves riding through the Golden Gate as liberators. You're offering them an escape route. It's realistic. I'll grant you that. More realistic than anything I've heard from Rome or Basel. But you're right—they won't take it. Not yet. Perhaps not ever.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund stares into his wine.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: I've dealt with the Palaiologoi for decades. Proud beyond reason. They still call themselves Basileus Rhomaion—Emperor of the Romans. They believe Constantinople is the center of the world, the Second Rome, the city God himself protects. Their empire has been dying for two hundred years, and still they believe God will save them at the last moment. They'll fight. They'll die on those walls rather than abandon them. It's who they are. The only way they leave Constantinople is if Constantinople ceases to exist—and by then, there won't be many left to resettle anywhere.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A heavy silence.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: As for actually defeating the Ottomans... I have one commander who understands how to fight them. János Hunyadi. Transylvanian. Brilliant tactician. He's won victories no one thought possible—small ones, but real. He knows their methods, their weaknesses. Hunyadi tells me the same thing you just said. It requires a massive effort. Unified command. Thirty-five, forty thousand professional soldiers—not feudal levies who go home after one season. Supply lines through Hungary. Years of sustained campaign, not one glorious charge.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund laughs bitterly.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Do you know what I told him? 'János, I can't get the German princes to agree on anything for more than six months. I can't get the Pope and Council to stop fighting each other long enough to declare a crusade. Where am I supposed to find forty thousand men and the gold to feed them for years?' So. Your thousand knights buy time. Your florins repair walls. And then? The Sultan masses his forces. The walls hold for a year, maybe two, maybe five if God is merciful. And then one day they don't hold. And Constantinople falls. And the Ottomans stand at Hungary's doorstep with nothing between them and Vienna.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He refills both cups.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: That's the future I see, Juan. Unless something changes. Unless someone actually unites Christendom—not in words, but in action. Pope and Council. Emperor and kings. Hungary and Poland and Venice and Genoa and Castile and Aragon and whoever else can be dragged into it. You've done something I couldn't do. You united Castile, finished the Reconquista, built an alliance stretching to Naples. You made the impossible happen once. Can you do it again? Can anyone?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will try. But I cannot change the hearts of others. If they are too proud and stubborn to see reason, I will not fight for them. I will not bleed my men for those who will not save themselves. A lost cause. If they are indeed too proud and want to die on their walls, then I cannot turn them. But I am ready. I can command my navy to go toe to toe with theirs, and my armies do not fear them. I do not fear them. If they are truly ready for the fight for their culture, their city and their empire, then so will I be ready to come to their aid and I will speak with you again. We will need to unite as christians and drive Islam from the eastern side of the european continent. I have done it already in the west, now we should do the same in the east. But I will first have to speak with them. I will keep you updated sir. This concerns us both.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund is silent for a long moment. The candles have burned low. Somewhere in the palace, a clock chimes the late hour. When he speaks, his voice is quieter than before.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: 'I will not bleed my men for those who will not save themselves.' That's... that's what I should have said thirty-five years ago. About Bohemia. About a dozen other hopeless causes I threw men into because honor demanded it, or pride, or stubbornness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at you with something new in his expression. Not warmth exactly—Sigismund is too old and too scarred for easy warmth—but recognition. The look of a man who has finally found someone who speaks his language.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: You've already done it in the west. Sixty years of my life, Juan—sixty years—and I've never seen a Christian king actually finish what he started. They talk about crusades. They raise armies. They march out with banners flying. And then... winter comes, or the treasury empties, or they quarrel with their allies, or they simply lose interest. The crusade dissolves. Nothing changes. You didn't just talk. You conquered Granada. You ended the Reconquista. Eight hundred years of war, and you finished it. And now you sit here telling me you'll do the same in the East—if Constantinople wants to be saved.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund moves to the door, then pauses, his hand on the frame.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Keep me informed. When you've spoken with Emperor John, when you know whether they'll fight or merely die with dignity—write to me. If there's a real chance, if Constantinople chooses to live rather than simply to fall gloriously... Then you'll have Hungary at your side. What's left of my strength, whatever years I have remaining. Hunyadi and his tactics. The weight of the imperial title, for whatever that's worth anymore.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ghost of a smile crosses his weathered face.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: I'm sixty-five years old, Juan. I've failed at almost everything I've attempted. Bohemia. The Church. Holding the Empire together. But perhaps... Perhaps God has kept me alive this long to see one thing through. To find one ally who actually means what he says.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens, some of the imperial dignity returning.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: We sign tomorrow. Then you ride to your wife, and I ride to Basel. And after that—Constantinople, Rome, whatever comes next. Sleep if you can. Fray Hernando will have the draft by morning. And Juan— Thank you. For riding three days through the Alps to meet an old man on the road. For listening. For being honest about what you can and cannot do. I think perhaps we understand each other.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He departs, his footsteps fading down the corridor. The chamber falls silent. Through the window, the first hint of gray touches the eastern sky over the lake. Somewhere below, you can hear Fray Hernando's voice, quietly dictating to a scribe.

encounters.recap: Juan and Sigismund discuss the dire situation in Constantinople over wine in the late hours. Juan reveals his pragmatic approach: offering sanctuary in Castile if the city cannot be saved, and refusing to bleed his men for those unwilling to save themselves. Sigismund recognizes a kindred spirit in Juan's realistic assessment and pledges Hungary's support if Constantinople chooses to truly fight. The two aging rulers form a bond of mutual respect based on their shared understanding of the massive effort required to defeat the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: I think perhaps we understand each other.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He departs, his footsteps fading down the corridor. The chamber falls silent. Through the window, the first hint of gray touches the eastern sky over the lake. Somewhere below, you can hear Fray Hernando's voice, quietly dictating to a scribe.

encounters.recap: The Declaration of Como is formally drafted as a joint statement between Juan II and Emperor Sigismund, establishing coordinated church reform positions including pluralism reform, episcopal elections, annates limitations, and Bohemian reconciliation. Accompanying letters are prepared for Pope Eugenius IV and the Castilian delegation at Basel, completing the diplomatic framework of their alliance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light filtering through the Archbishop's palace windows carried the particular clarity of early summer in the Alpine foothills—clean and bright, the sky above Como a crystalline blue after yesterday's scattered clouds. You rise from a bed that, despite its borrowed luxury, provided only fitful rest. Your mind turned through the night, replaying fragments of the long conversation with Sigismund.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Emperor is awake, Your Majesty. His secretary reports he took breakfast an hour ago. Fray Hernando is already in the audience chamber, reviewing the final copies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The audience chamber of the Archbishop's palace is modest by royal standards—a comfortable receiving room rather than a throne hall, with windows overlooking Como's famous lake. When you enter, Fray Hernando stands at a writing desk near the windows, three stacks of documents arranged before him. He looks exhausted but alert, dark circles under his eyes testament to his labors.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Emperor Sigismund sits in a high-backed chair near the cold fireplace, a cup of wine in hand despite the early hour. At sixty-five, he looks every year of his age this morning—the stooped shoulders more pronounced, the lined face showing the weight of thirty-five years fighting a war he cannot win. But his eyes remain sharp, watching you enter with the measuring gaze of a man who has survived more betrayals than most rulers face in a lifetime.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Ah, the young crusader rises. Come. Your Franciscan has been explaining his work. I confess I'm impressed—he captured our discussion with remarkable precision.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I have prepared three copies of each document. The Declaration itself, the letter to His Holiness, and the instructions for our delegation at Basel. All require both signatures and seals.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I would ask that you review the final text before signing. I have tried to capture what was agreed, but words on parchment never quite match the living conversation from which they spring.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The documents lie waiting—thick parchment, elegant script, the blank spaces below where Sigismundus Rex Romanorum and Ioannes Rex Castellae will soon appear. The Archbishop's secretary and a representative of the imperial chancery stand nearby as witnesses.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: In Nomine Domini. Amen. We, Sigismund and Juan, servants of Christ and guardians of Christian peoples... Well. Shall we see what we have wrought?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I read the statement and agree that this is indeed the spirit of both our wishes. Is the emperor also ready to sign?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund sets down the Declaration and picks up the letter to Eugenius IV, scanning it with the practiced eye of a man who has read ten thousand diplomatic documents. His expression remains neutral—not the neutrality of displeasure, but the careful blankness of a ruler who learned long ago not to show his hand until the ink is dry.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Your Franciscan writes well. The tone is correct. Respectful without groveling. Firm without threatening.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: You served at Constance, Brother?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I did not have that honor, Imperial Majesty. But I have studied the records extensively.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: It shows. Well then.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: No ceremony. No flourish. The Emperor of the West takes up a quill, dips it carefully, and signs his name in the space prepared: Sigismundus Rex Romanorum. The script is precise, unhurried—the signature of a man who has written his name on treaties, proclamations, and death warrants for thirty-five years. He moves to the second copy. Signs again. The third. Then the letters to Eugenius and to the Castilian delegation. Six signatures in all, each identical, each executed with the mechanical precision of long practice.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Your turn, King of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light falls across the parchment, illuminating the Emperor's fresh signatures, the blank spaces waiting below them.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: We have made our position known. Now we see how the world responds.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: May this be the start of a fruitful cooperation emperor. If there is nothing else, I will depart immediately for Toledo.

roll.outcome: Measured Partnership. Sigismund signs with professional dignity. A firm nod, perhaps a brief acknowledgment: 'Well then. We have made our position known.' Neither cold nor warm—the seasoned caution of an old ruler who has learned not to invest too much hope in any single document.

encounters.recap: Juan II and Emperor Sigismund formally sign the Declaration of Como and supporting documents in the Archbishop's palace. The ceremony is conducted with measured dignity rather than fanfare, establishing their partnership against the Council of Basel with professional commitment tempered by Sigismund's long experience of diplomatic disappointment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sigismund sets down his wine cup and rises, moving to stand beside the desk. He picks up the Declaration, scanning the opening lines.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: In Nomine Domini. Amen. We, Sigismund and Juan, servants of Christ and guardians of Christian peoples... Well. Shall we see what we have wrought?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I read the statement and agree that this is indeed the spirit of both our wishes. Is the emperor also ready to sign?

roll.outcome: Measured Partnership. Sigismund signs with professional dignity. A firm nod, perhaps a brief acknowledgment: 'Well then. We have made our position known.' Neither cold nor warm—the seasoned caution of an old ruler who has learned not to invest too much hope in any single document.

encounters.recap: After a night of negotiations, Emperor Sigismund reviews the final Declaration and prepares to sign. A roll determines his demeanor at this historic moment—he proceeds with measured professional dignity, neither cold nor warm, showing the seasoned caution of an experienced ruler.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Your turn, King of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando moves the documents to make room. The witnesses—the Archbishop's canon, the imperial secretary—step forward to observe. Captain Robles, standing near the door, watches with the professional alertness of a man who has learned that even signing ceremonies can turn dangerous. The morning light falls across the parchment, illuminating the Emperor's fresh signatures, the blank spaces waiting below them.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: We have made our position known. Now we see how the world responds.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: May this be the start of a fruitful cooperation emperor. If there is nothing else, I will depart immediately for Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The quill feels light in your hand. You sign beneath each of Sigismund's signatures—Ioannes Rex Castellae—the familiar flourish of your name that has appeared on tax rolls and execution warrants, marriage contracts and military orders, and now on a document that may reshape the politics of Christendom. Six signatures. The ink glistens wet in the morning light, then begins to dry. You extend your hand. Sigismund takes it—a firm grip, the calloused palm of a man who still rides to war despite his years. His eyes meet yours, and for a moment the diplomatic mask slips just slightly.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Fruitful cooperation. Yes. We shall see. I ride for Basel within the week. Your delegation will have instructions before I arrive. When you return from Toledo—after your queen's safe delivery, God willing—come to Rome as you promised. Let Eugenius see the man behind the signature.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: You have a talent for surprising people, King of Castile. The Pope will expect a young conqueror drunk on victory. Show him what you showed me—a man who can hear hard truths and adjust his position. That will serve you better than any army.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando has already begun gathering the copies designated for Castile. The imperial secretary does the same for Sigismund's archives. The witnesses sign their attestations. Sealing wax is heated, the great seals pressed into crimson pools—the double-headed eagle of the Empire beside the castles and lions of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Go to your wife. Hold your daughter. Be a father for a few weeks before you try to save Constantinople. The Turks will still be there when you return. They are patient, those Ottomans. We must learn to be patient too.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, your small party is mounted and riding south through Como's streets toward the road that will take you over the Alps and eventually home to Toledo. Thirty-three crusaders, Fray Hernando, Captain Robles, and the sealed documents that represent weeks of negotiation compressed into parchment and ink.

encounters.recap: Juan II signs the Declaration of Como alongside Emperor Sigismund, formally sealing their alliance. After a handshake and final words of counsel from the Emperor, Juan departs Como with his small party, carrying the sealed documents that represent their diplomatic agreement as they begin the journey back to Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, your small party is mounted and riding south through Como's streets toward the road that will take you over the Alps and eventually home to Toledo. Thirty-three crusaders, Fray Hernando, Captain Robles, and the sealed documents that represent weeks of negotiation compressed into parchment and ink. Behind you, the Emperor's banners still fly from the Archbishop's palace. Ahead lies a journey of perhaps four weeks—over the mountains, through Lombardy and Provence, across the Pyrenees, and finally to the wife and daughter waiting in Castile.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Two main options, Your Majesty. Overland through France. We ride to Turin, cross into Savoy, then through the Rhône valley to Montpellier. Over the Pyrenees at Perpignan, down through Aragón to Toledo. Four weeks, perhaps a bit less if we push hard and the mountain passes cooperate. Reliable. We control our own pace. No waiting on winds or ships.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Or we ride hard to Genoa—three, four days through the Ligurian hills. Find a ship bound for Barcelona or Valencia. If the winds favor us, we're in Iberia within a week of leaving Genoa. Then overland to Toledo. Could cut ten days off the journey. Could also leave us sitting in Genoa harbor for a week waiting for favorable winds, or blown off course to Marseille, or becalmed in sight of the Spanish coast.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The sea is faster when it's faster, Your Majesty. But it doesn't answer to kings. The road is slower but honest—it tells you exactly what it costs.

exchanges.speaker: father_hernando
exchanges.text: The Queen's time draws near. Late July, the physicians said. Perhaps August.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I cannot risk not being with Isabel when she delivers. We ride hard through land. Fray has been working through the night. If we need to drop off slow travellers and horses in order to maintain good speed we will do so.

encounters.recap: At Como's northern gate, Juan consults with Captain Robles about the fastest route to Toledo. Weighing maritime versus overland options, Juan chooses the reliable overland route through France to ensure he reaches Queen Isabel before her expected delivery in late July or August.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Queen's time draws near. Late July, the physicians said. Perhaps August.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It is June 7th. You have perhaps seven or eight weeks before Isabel's expected delivery.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I cannot risk not being with Isabel when she delivers. We ride hard through land. Fray has been working through the night. If we need to drop off slow travellers and horses in order to maintain good speed we will do so.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Understood, Your Majesty. We'll ride hard. I'll arrange fresh horses at every major town—Turin, Avignon, Montpellier, Perpignan, Zaragoza. We travel light, sleep short, and anyone who can't keep pace stays behind with coin for their own journey home.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The friar will need to ride in a cart if he's to make it, at least for the first days. We can find one in Turin.

roll.outcome: Exceptional Speed. Fortune favors the journey in ways beyond planning—a Savoyard duke provides his own swift horses and guides through the Alpine passes, the Aragonese roads prove dry and fast, every town has fresh mounts ready. Under three weeks. Juan arrives in Toledo before June 25th.

encounters.recap: Juan decides to ride hard from Como to Toledo to reach Queen Isabel before her delivery. Captain Robles arranges the swift journey, and fortune smiles upon them with exceptional speed, arriving in under three weeks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fortune favors you. The first stroke of luck comes in Turin, where the Duke of Savoy's steward recognizes your banners and—having heard rumors of the Como meeting—offers the Duke's own relay horses through the Alpine passes. "His Grace would consider it an honor," the steward says, and you suspect the Duke is hedging his bets, currying favor with the king who just signed a joint declaration with the Emperor. You accept without hesitation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The passes are clear. June in the Alps can be treacherous—late snows, sudden storms—but the weather holds crystalline and warm. Your party crosses into Savoy in two days rather than four, the Duke's mountain-bred horses sure-footed on paths that would have slowed lesser mounts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando, gray and hollow-eyed for the first three days, rides in a cart commandeered in Turin. By the time you reach Avignon, he's recovered enough to mount a horse again, though he remains quieter than usual—the exhaustion of the all-night drafting session compounded by the relentless pace. He prays the offices silently as he rides, lips moving with the familiar Latin.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In Avignon, more fortune: a Castilian merchant bound for Barcelona offers his string of pack-horses, fresh and strong, in exchange for the honor of saying he aided his king's journey. "Your Majesty's conquest of Granada has made Castilian merchants welcome throughout Christendom," he says. "It is a small repayment."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Rhône valley roads are dry and fast. The summer sun bakes the dirt hard. You push through Montpellier, Narbonne, Perpignan—each town a blur of fresh horses, brief sleep, and dawn departures. The Pyrenees prove gentler than the Alps. The passes here are lower, the roads better maintained by Aragonese merchants who profit from Iberian trade. You cross into Aragón on June 18th, barely eleven days out of Como.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Word of your passage spreads ahead of you. In Zaragoza, the local bishop offers his own escort for the final leg to Toledo—partly honor, partly curiosity about the king who met with the Emperor and rides home as if demons pursued him. You decline the escort but accept the fresh horses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fifteen days. Fifteen days from Como to Toledo—a journey that should have taken four weeks. You ride through Toledo's gates in the golden light of late afternoon, dust-covered and saddle-sore but triumphant. The city rises around you in familiar terraces of stone and tile, the Tagus glinting below, the cathedral towers catching the setting sun.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles sends a rider ahead. By the time you reach the Alcázar, word has spread: the King has returned. And there, in the courtyard where you have arrived so many times before—from Rome, from Barcelona, from Granada—Isabel waits. She is visibly pregnant now, her belly round beneath a simple summer gown. Beside her stands Doña Beatriz, and in the Portuguese lady's arms, a child who has grown considerably since you last saw her: Catalina, now sixteen months old, watching the arriving horses with wide curious eyes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel's face holds the particular expression you have come to know—relief and joy and something beneath both, the fear that never quite leaves her when you are away. She does not run to you. She is too dignified for that, too conscious of the watching servants and guards. But her hands tremble slightly as she clasps them before her.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: You're early. The letters said July. We thought—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She stops. Her eyes are bright.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Isabel, my queen, my love. The lord has granted me blessed journey.

roll.outcome: Exceptional Speed. Fortune favors the journey in ways beyond planning—a Savoyard duke provides his own swift horses and guides through the Alpine passes, the Aragonese roads prove dry and fast, every town has fresh mounts ready. Under three weeks.

encounters.recap: Juan's return journey from Como to Toledo becomes exceptionally swift due to extraordinary good fortune. The Duke of Savoy provides mountain horses, Castilian merchants offer fresh mounts, and perfect weather holds throughout. What should have been a four-week journey takes only fifteen days, bringing Juan home to Toledo on June 22nd to reunite with pregnant Isabel and young Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And there, in the courtyard where you have arrived so many times before—from Rome, from Barcelona, from Granada—Isabel waits. She is visibly pregnant now, her belly round beneath a simple summer gown. Beside her stands Doña Beatriz, and in the Portuguese lady's arms, a child who has grown considerably since you last saw her: Catalina, now sixteen months old, watching the arriving horses with wide curious eyes. Isabel's face holds the particular expression you have come to know—relief and joy and something beneath both, the fear that never quite leaves her when you are away. She does not run to you. She is too dignified for that, too conscious of the watching servants and guards. But her hands tremble slightly as she clasps them before her.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: You're early. The letters said July. We thought—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Isabel, my queen, my love. The lord has granted me blessed journey. I will not leave your side again during the pregnancy Isabel. How have you been?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel has learned to protect herself from hope. She squeezes his hand, manages a smile, but something is held back.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: I am glad you're home.

roll.outcome: Guarded Relief. Isabel has learned to protect herself from hope. She squeezes his hand, manages a smile, but something is held back. The words are right but the walls are up—weeks of anxiety don't dissolve instantly. She'll need time before she truly believes he's staying.

encounters.recap: Juan returns early to Toledo and reunites with his pregnant queen Isabel in the alcázar courtyard. Despite her joy at his return and his promise to stay through the pregnancy, Isabel's reaction is emotionally guarded—weeks of anxiety about his safety and her dangerous pregnancy have taught her to protect herself from hope, requiring time before she fully believes in his presence and promise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel watches you kneel, watches you rise, feels your lips brush her knuckles. Her hand is cool in yours despite the June warmth.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I am glad you're home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words are correct. The smile is correct. But something in her voice is too measured, too careful—the tone of a woman who has rehearsed this moment in her mind so many times that the reality of it cannot quite penetrate. She squeezes your hand once, then releases it. A small step back, almost imperceptible, creating distance where there should be none.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: The journey was blessed indeed. Fifteen days from Lombardy—the servants will scarcely believe it. You must be exhausted. I'll have baths prepared, and food. You'll want to rest before—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She's managing. You recognize it now—the same careful control she maintained during the worst days after Catalina's birth, when the physicians weren't certain she would survive. The walls she builds when the alternative is feeling too much. Catalina fusses in Doña Beatriz's arms, reaching toward the horses. Isabel glances at her daughter, and something flickers across her face—there and gone.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: How have I been? Well enough. The physicians visit daily. The pregnancy progresses normally, they say. They say many things.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The courtyard is full of watching eyes—servants, guards, grooms tending to your exhausted horses. Isabel is acutely aware of them. Whatever she's holding back, she won't release it here.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Come inside. Please. You must be tired.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have missed you Isabel. Now we are together again. Tell me, how are you really? I love you and am here for you.

roll.outcome: Weary Gratitude. The pregnancy has been hard. Isabel looks tired—dark circles under her eyes, movements careful and slow. Her smile is genuine but exhausted.

encounters.recap: Juan returns from his Italian journey to find Isabel emotionally guarded and exhausted from her difficult pregnancy. Despite her genuine relief at his return, she maintains careful composure in the public courtyard, suggesting deeper struggles that she's not ready to share in front of watching servants and courtiers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She's managing. You recognize it now—the same careful control she maintained during the worst days after Catalina's birth, when the physicians weren't certain she would survive. The walls she builds when the alternative is feeling too much. Catalina fusses in Doña Beatriz's arms, reaching toward the horses. Isabel glances at her daughter, and something flickers across her face—there and gone.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: How have I been? Well enough. The physicians visit daily. The pregnancy progresses normally, they say. They say many things.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The courtyard is full of watching eyes—servants, guards, grooms tending to your exhausted horses. Isabel is acutely aware of them. Whatever she's holding back, she won't release it here.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Come inside. Please. You must be tired.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corridor is cool and dim after the sunlit courtyard. Servants melt away at a gesture from Doña Beatriz, who withdraws with Catalina, understanding without being told that the King and Queen need privacy. You pull Isabel into your arms. For a moment she is stiff, holding herself apart even within the embrace—the last defense of a woman who has spent weeks being strong. You feel the swell of her belly pressed between you, the new life growing there, and you hold her tighter.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have missed you, Isabel. Now we are together again. Tell me, how are you really? I love you and am here for you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A shudder runs through her. Then another.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: The physicians say the baby is positioned wrong. Like Catalina was. They say—they say it may need to be turned, or— I almost died, Juan. I almost died bringing Catalina into the world, and I could feel it happening—I could feel myself slipping away, and all I could think was that you were in Granada and you wouldn't know, you'd come home to a dead wife and a motherless daughter, and— And now it's happening again. The same signs. The same warnings. And everyone keeps telling me to rest, to pray, to trust God, and I do trust God, I do, but I'm so frightened, Juan. I'm so frightened and I couldn't tell anyone because I'm the Queen and I have to be strong and—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She's crying now, the sobs coming in ragged gasps, weeks of suppressed terror finally finding release. She pulls back just enough to look at you, her face wet, her composure utterly shattered.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Promise me you'll stay. Promise me that if I—if something happens—promise me you'll be here. That I won't die alone. Promise me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course Isabel. And I understand what you feel. The baby is positioned wrong again? That is disturbing news. But we will face it together. I promise to be by your side the whole time Isabel. Don't worry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel leans into you, her forehead resting against your chest. The sobs subside slowly, replaced by the shaky breathing of someone who has finally set down a burden too heavy to carry alone. For a long moment she simply stands there, letting yourself be held. You feel the tension draining from her shoulders, the rigid control softening into something more human. Your hand rests on the curve of her back, and you're aware of how thin she feels beneath the gown—she hasn't been eating well, you suspect. Finally she pulls back, wiping her eyes with the heel of her hand. A watery almost-laugh escapes her.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Look at me. The Queen of Castile, weeping like a child. Doña Beatriz has been wonderful. And my mother writes every week—she says she'll come again when the time is near, as she did for Catalina. The Portuguese physicians who saved me before, she's already sent word to them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches up to touch your face, her fingers tracing the lines of road-weariness.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: The physicians here say the baby may yet turn on its own. There's time still—six weeks, perhaps seven. They've seen it happen. And I'm stronger now than I was with Catalina. I know what to expect. I know the signs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She takes your hand and places it on her belly. Beneath your palm, you feel movement—a flutter, then a stronger kick.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: He's active. Always moving. The midwives say that's a good sign. Tell me about the Emperor. Tell me something good, Juan. I want to hear about something other than babies and blood and fear.

encounters.recap: Juan reunites privately with Isabel after his return from the Holy Roman Empire. Isabel finally confesses her terror about her pregnancy complications—the baby is positioned wrong like Catalina was, threatening a difficult birth. She breaks down emotionally after weeks of maintaining royal composure, revealing her fears of dying in childbirth while Juan was away. Juan promises to stay by her side throughout the birth, providing the emotional support she desperately needed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The small dining chamber off the royal apartments is warm with afternoon light. Servants bring simple fare—bread, cheese, cold meats, fruit from the Toledo gardens—and withdraw at Isabel's nod. This is not a state dinner but a family meal, intimate and unannounced. Doña Beatriz brings Catalina, then curtsies and leaves you alone—the three of you, soon to be four.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your daughter has grown since you saw her last. At seventeen months, she walks now—unsteady, determined steps that carry her from furniture to furniture with fierce concentration. Her hair has darkened from the wispy near-white of infancy to a soft brown, and her eyes—Isabel's eyes—watch everything with sharp curiosity. She regards you with the wariness of a child who recognizes a face but cannot quite place it. You've been gone more than half her short life. The portrait Isabel mentioned, the one Catalina points to—that's been more present than you have.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But when you lift her into your lap, she doesn't cry. She studies your face with grave intensity, one small hand reaching up to touch your beard. Her fingers close around a strand and tug experimentally.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: Papa. That's Papa, Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina repeats, or something like it. The sound is half-formed, more vowel than consonant. She tugs your beard again, harder this time, then laughs—a bright, startling sound—when you wince. Isabel watches from across the small table, and for the first time since your arrival, her smile reaches her eyes.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: She's been saying a few words. 'Mama.' 'No'—that one she knows very well. 'Bird.' She loves the birds in the garden. She'll warm to you quickly. She's fearless, this one. Nothing frightens her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina has discovered a piece of cheese on the table and is attempting to stuff the entire thing into her mouth at once.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina shrieks with delight as she rises into the air, cheese forgotten, her small hands grabbing at nothing. For a moment she hangs there above you, legs kicking, eyes wide with surprise—and then the laughter comes, that pure infant joy that knows nothing of politics or war or the weight of crowns. The word isn't quite there, but the meaning is unmistakable. She squirms in your grip, bouncing, demanding.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You lift her again. Another shriek. She throws her head back, mouth open in a gummy grin, utterly fearless as Isabel said. No hesitation, no anxiety about the stranger holding her—just the simple trust of a child who has never been dropped.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: Careful. She'll expect this every time now. You'll have created a monster.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The third lift earns you a cascade of giggles and a small hand that smacks against your nose with surprising force. Catalina finds this hilarious. She grabs your face with both hands, squishing your cheeks together, and studies the result with deep satisfaction. She announces definitively, as if confirming something to herself. Then she twists in your arms, pointing imperiously at the plate of fruit.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: She has your temperament. She sees what she wants and reaches for it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You settle Catalina back into your lap with a piece of soft pear. She gnaws at it contentedly, leaning against your chest as if she's always belonged there, sticky fingers leaving trails on your traveling clothes. Isabel watches you both, one hand resting on her belly. The fear hasn't left her eyes entirely—perhaps it never will, not until the birth is safely past—but something else is there now too.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: I'd forgotten. What it looks like. You with her.

encounters.recap: Juan reunites with his seventeen-month-old daughter Catalina during an intimate family lunch. The toddler, initially wary, quickly warms to her father through playful interactions, while Isabel watches with hope and remembrance of their family bond.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pa. Want.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: She has your temperament. She sees what she wants and reaches for it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You settle Catalina back into your lap with a piece of soft pear. She gnaws at it contentedly, leaning against your chest as if she's always belonged there, sticky fingers leaving trails on your traveling clothes. Isabel watches you both, one hand resting on her belly. The fear hasn't left her eyes entirely—perhaps it never will, not until the birth is safely past—but something else is there now too.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: I'd forgotten. What it looks like. You with her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina squeals as you sweep her up and "leap" across the room—your legs doing the real work while she kicks wildly in the air, convinced she's flying. Her shrieks echo off the stone walls, pure breathless joy.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Jump! Jump!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You carry her in a great arc to the far wall, then spin and launch back toward Isabel. Catalina sees her mother approaching and reaches out with grabby hands— You deposit her gently atop Isabel's head, and for one perfect moment your daughter sits there like a very small, very confused queen, hands tangled in her mother's hair. Isabel freezes, eyes wide, mouth twitching.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: Juan, what—

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: MAMA!

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: Ow—Juan—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rescue Isabel by swooping Catalina away in another great leap, and your daughter cackles like a tiny madwoman as she soars back across the room to land on the table before the bread. She stands there on unsteady legs, surveying her domain. The bread looms before her. The cheese beckons. A bowl of figs presents itself as a worthy challenge. She looks back at you, then at Isabel, then at the bread. The decision takes approximately half a second. She sits down heavily, grabs the entire small loaf with both hands, and bites directly into the crust with her few teeth. Crumbs explode everywhere. She chews with fierce determination, watching you both as if daring anyone to stop her. Isabel laughs—a real laugh, surprised out of her.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: She's a barbarian. An absolute barbarian. Look at her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pa. Want.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon dissolves into a blur of small joys. Catalina quickly grasps the rules of the game: fly to Mama, kiss, fly away, return. Each circuit earns fresh giggles. By the fourth pass, she's leaning forward in your arms, puckering her lips in anticipation as Isabel's face approaches.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mwah!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She's learned the sound if not the technique, planting wet open-mouthed kisses somewhere in the vicinity of Isabel's cheek, nose, eye—wherever she happens to land. Isabel stops flinching after the first few. By the seventh or eighth circuit, she's laughing so hard she has to brace herself against the table.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: Enough, enough—my face is covered in drool and bread crumbs—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But she doesn't mean it, and you don't stop. The light shifts as the hours pass. Catalina's energy flags, the wild shrieks softening to tired giggles, then to drowsy contentment. She falls asleep against your chest mid-flight, head lolling, one sticky hand still clutching a fragment of bread like a treasure. You sit with her for a while, this small warm weight, feeling her breath rise and fall. Isabel watches from her chair, feet tucked beneath her, the fear in her eyes finally quiet.

exchanges.speaker: isabel
exchanges.text: She'll sleep for hours now. You've exhausted her completely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz appears to carry Catalina to the nursery. Your daughter doesn't stir, dead to the world, dreaming whatever dreams seventeen-month-old conquerors dream. The shadows are lengthening toward evening when Álvaro de Luna is admitted to the royal study. He looks well—older perhaps than when you left for Rome, gray threading more heavily through his dark hair, but still sharp-eyed and straight-backed. He bows precisely, then studies your face with the frank assessment of a man who has known you since childhood.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Toledo rejoices at your return. Fifteen days from Como. The stablehands are still talking about the state of your horses.

encounters.recap: Juan II spends a joyful afternoon playing with his seventeen-month-old daughter Catalina in the dining chamber, carrying her around the room in mock flight, kissing Isabel, and watching Catalina devour bread with barbaric enthusiasm. The playful family time exhausts Catalina into sleep and brings laughter to Isabel, easing her pregnancy fears. The day concludes with Álvaro de Luna arriving for matters of state.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The shadows are lengthening toward evening when Álvaro de Luna is admitted to the royal study. He looks well—older perhaps than when you left for Rome, gray threading more heavily through his dark hair, but still sharp-eyed and straight-backed. He bows precisely, then studies your face with the frank assessment of a man who has known you since childhood.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Toledo rejoices at your return. Fifteen days from Como. The stablehands are still talking about the state of your horses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He settles into the chair you indicate, producing a leather folio from beneath his arm.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I have reports. The kingdom has been... manageable, in your absence. But there are matters requiring your attention. Where would you like to begin?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I carry with me the grant of the pope granting me complete control over the military orders. I want to reform them completely into a new structure. I want to discuss this. Also, I want to further develop our plans to invade Africa. Is there news from our informants that we have sent out into Morocco? Are there subjects loyal to the crown that are converted muslims or muslims themselves who can be entrusted to be vassals of cities we take in Morocco? Also, I want to develop a theological structure allowing muslims to serve as vassals or servants to christians with possibilities for conversion. Genuine conversion. Also, I want to discuss what my claims are to the throne of Aragon and Naples. Has Aragon been able to secure Naples now that we have papal support? What other matters of state are pressing?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The realm is well, Your Majesty. I'll address your questions in order. Diego de Daza's reforms have continued at pace. Tax collection stands at approximately thirty-five percent implementation—up from thirty when you departed. The Council of Great Houses met twice in your absence. A dispute arose between the Mendoza and Guzmán families over assessment methods, but Don Íñigo resolved it internally without requiring crown intervention. They've collected another twelve thousand maravedís in voluntary underpayments. Revenues are meeting projections. No shortfalls, no windfalls. The treasury is stable.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Masters know you petitioned Rome. They do not yet know the full scope of what was granted—only what rumors have filtered back from Italy. I have kept the decree's exact language to myself, awaiting your return. Your Majesty speaks of reforming them completely. I must counsel caution in how this is approached. These Orders have existed for three centuries. Their traditions, their lands, their sense of identity—these cannot be unmade by decree alone, even papal decree.
