The Masters served faithfully in the Reconquista. They will expect consultation, not imposition. What manner of reform does Your Majesty envision? Consolidation? New command structures? Redeployment for overseas crusading? The approach will determine how much resistance we face.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: No word yet from Commander Martín's delegation. Nor should we expect any—they departed barely eleven weeks ago, and the mission parameters anticipated reports in autumn. October at the earliest. No news is neither good nor bad. It simply means the work continues.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This is beyond my competence, Your Majesty. The mudéjar tradition exists—Muslims living under Christian rule, paying special taxes, practicing their faith in designated areas. Granada's surrender terms permit this for the present generation. But a theological framework for Muslim vassals with structured paths to conversion—that requires scholars, not administrators. Fray Hernando would be the natural advisor, or Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena when he returns from Basel. The Archbishop of Toledo might also have views. Strong views, most likely. What specifically does Your Majesty envision? Vassals in conquered Moroccan territories? A formalized status for converted lords who retain their lands? This determines which theologians to consult and what questions to ask them.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's claims to Aragon are... indirect. You have no direct claim while Alfonso V lives. Your sister María is his queen, but she has borne no children in—what is it now, twelve years of marriage? Alfonso is forty, focused entirely on Naples, and shows no sign of producing an heir. Should Alfonso die childless, succession becomes complex. The Infantes Juan and Enrique are dead. Young Carlos of Viana is dead. The next legitimate claimants would trace through collateral lines—or through María herself, depending on how Aragonese lawyers interpret their succession laws. But this is speculation about events that may never occur. Alfonso is healthy and consumed with Naples.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: As for Naples itself—the latest reports say Alfonso's position has strengthened since the papal endorsement. Queen Giovanna's death last year left René of Anjou as his primary rival, but René is occupied in France. Alfonso controls much of the kingdom in practice. Full recognition may come within the year. Don Bernat de Centelles returned to Naples after accompanying you to Rome, I assume? He would have the freshest intelligence.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Nothing urgent demands immediate attention. The usual accumulation of petitions, land disputes, appointment requests—these can wait for Your Majesty's convenience. The realm is quiet, Your Majesty. Perhaps too quiet—men are watching to see what the King who met with Pope and Emperor intends to do next. The Declaration of Como has reached us by courier. Bold words. Now they wait to see if bold words become bold actions. What are your intentions regarding the Military Orders? That, I suspect, will set the tone for everything else.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see that the military orders have a combined income of 180.000 florins annually. I will add it to the treasury. Then, I want to make a professional core of my army based on the existing order infrastructure. But united in one organization. For tradition's sake and for their honour, they will be able to maintain their battle colours but they will be reformed into fighting units according to the reforms from the academy. Uniform units that can operate independantly on campain and on the battlefield. I do not seek to replace the current leadership but they will be given new structure. Essentially, the old structure and order will cease to exist. But I will also found a new order. One dedicated to eternal crusade and the 1000 crusaders sent to Constantinople are the start of this. We will find a new frontier and expand the military order's strongholds there. What do you think?

roll.outcome: Quiet Progress. Things have gone well. Diego's reforms have advanced slightly, the Council of Great Houses resolved a minor dispute among members without crown intervention, tax revenues are meeting projections. The realm is healthy and stable.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Álvaro de Luna to discuss the state of the realm during his absence and his ambitious plans. The kingdom has remained stable with continued progress on reforms. Juan reveals his papal grant for the Military Orders and proposes radical restructuring: consolidating their 180,000 florin income into the treasury, transforming them into professional military units while preserving their honors, and founding a new crusading order for eternal expansion.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Nothing urgent demands immediate attention. The usual accumulation of petitions, land disputes, appointment requests—these can wait for Your Majesty's convenience.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The realm is quiet, Your Majesty. Perhaps too quiet—men are watching to see what the King who met with Pope and Emperor intends to do next. The Declaration of Como has reached us by courier. Bold words. Now they wait to see if bold words become bold actions. What are your intentions regarding the Military Orders? That, I suspect, will set the tone for everything else.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see that the military orders have a combined income of 180.000 florins annually. I will add it to the treasury. Then, I want to make a professional core of my army based on the existing order infrastructure. But united in one organization. For tradition's sake and for their honour, they will be able to maintain their battle colours but they will be reformed into fighting units according to the reforms from the academy. Uniform units that can operate independently on campaign and on the battlefield. I do not seek to replace the current leadership but they will be given new structure. Essentially, the old structure and order will cease to exist. But I will also found a new order. One dedicated to eternal crusade and the 1000 crusaders sent to Constantinople are the start of this. We will find a new frontier and expand the military order's strongholds there. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro is silent for a long moment. His fingers tap once, twice against the armrest of his chair. When he speaks, his voice is measured—the tone of a counselor who has learned when to choose his words with particular care.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has the authority. The papal decree is clear. The Orders are yours to command. But authority and implementation are different beasts. Let me speak frankly, as you have always permitted me to do.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, moving to the window that overlooks the Tagus far below. His back is to you—a liberty he permits himself only in private.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: You propose to dissolve three institutions that have existed for three hundred years. The Order of Calatrava was founded in 1158. Santiago in 1171. Alcántara in 1154. They predate the union of Castile and León. They predate your dynasty. Knights have lived and died under those banners for ten generations. These are not mercenary companies to be reorganized at will. They are religious orders. The knights take vows—poverty, chastity, obedience. They answer to God as well as to king. Their identity is not merely professional. It is spiritual.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: One hundred eighty thousand florins is... optimistic. The Orders' revenues are substantial, yes, but they also bear substantial costs—maintaining fortresses, supporting chapter houses, funding hospitals and charitable works required by their rules. The net income available for military purposes is perhaps half that figure, possibly less. And those revenues derive from estates spread across the realm. Absorbing them into the treasury means absorbing their administration—thousands of tenants, hundreds of properties, legal obligations stretching back centuries.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: You say the Masters will retain leadership but under new structure. I must ask plainly: what does that mean? Don Luis de Guzmán is Master of Santiago. Under your proposal, is he a general commanding royal troops? A pensioned nobleman? A religious prior without military authority? These men are not fools. They will understand immediately that 'retaining leadership' within a dissolved Order means retaining nothing. They will see this as—forgive me—punishment for faithful service.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: A new Order dedicated to eternal crusade—this has merit. The knights in Constantinople, a perpetual frontier, expansion of Christendom. This vision could inspire men in ways that bureaucratic reorganization cannot. But founding a new Order does not require destroying the old ones. Let the new Order draw volunteers—young knights seeking glory, veterans hungry for purpose beyond garrison duty. Let it grow alongside the existing Orders rather than from their ashes.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's goals are sound. Professional training. Unified command in wartime. Crown authority over deployment. Modern organization. All of this can be achieved. But consider a different path. Rather than dissolution, transformation. Announce that the Orders will be reorganized for the eternal crusade. Establish the Royal Military Academy as the training ground for all Military Order officers. Create unified command structures for overseas deployment while preserving the Orders' domestic identity.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good suggestions. But I do think I should put the orders under direct crown supervision. I want to control their revenue income and expenses. We can maintain the orders mainly as they are, but I want to be able to review and where needed change it. Many expenses such as border patrol and forts are no longer needed. Tell me, do the three orders differ in any way from each other? Apart from their geographical location? Do they have different traditions or vows?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The three Orders share common purpose but differ in important particulars, Your Majesty. The Order of Santiago is the largest and wealthiest—more possessions than the other two combined. Their rule follows the Augustinian tradition rather than the Cistercian. Most importantly, Santiago permits married knights. They take vows, yes, but not the strict monastic celibacy of the other Orders. Their emblem is the red cross shaped like a sword—la cruz espada. Their spiritual focus is the protection of pilgrims on the Way of Saint James.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Calatrava is the strictest. Cistercian rule, modeled on lay brothers of the monasteries. Full monastic vows—poverty, chastity, obedience. Rules of silence in the refectory, dormitory, and oratory. Abstinence four days each week. Their emblem is the red cross fleur-de-lysée on white. Spiritually, they answer not just to Rome but to the Abbot of Morimond in France. The most militarily disciplined of the three, but also the most resistant to change—they see themselves as monk-warriors, not merely soldiers with religious decoration.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Alcántara is the smallest and poorest of the three—but proud of their Leonese heritage. Their rule resembles Calatrava's—they were affiliated with Calatrava in their early years and follow similar Cistercian customs. Full monastic vows, though enforcement has varied with the strength of individual Masters. Their emblem is the green cross flordelisada. They've always been somewhat overshadowed by their larger brethren, but fiercely independent.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's proposal to supervise revenues and redirect expenses—this is achievable. But the how matters enormously. Approach Santiago differently than Calatrava. Acknowledge Alcántara's distinct heritage. And whatever you do, do not let any Master feel he is being treated worse than his peers. These men have spent their lives in rivalry with each other. United resentment would be far more dangerous than divided grumbling.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see now that we cannot merge these orders together. And I also see that there are different functions for these orders in my new army. The fanaticism of Calatrava will serve us well if properly tempered with the discipline of the new tactics from the academy. We might even expand or support their order even more. I also like how Santiago offers nobles the chance to marry and still serve. This might be a good tool for nobles to be granted lands in new conquered lands. But it all starts with their realization that they are now fully under crown command and that I will review and maybe restructure them without destroying them.

encounters.recap: Juan II discusses reforming the Military Orders with Álvaro de Luna. Initially proposing dissolution and merger, the King learns of the Orders' distinct traditions and decides instead to place them under direct crown supervision while preserving their separate identities, seeing different strategic uses for each Order's unique characteristics.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: So you see the complications. Santiago's knights are often married nobles with families and inheritances—they will resist anything that threatens their dynastic arrangements. Calatrava's knights see themselves as monks first, soldiers second—they may view crown supervision as secular interference in religious vows. Alcántara's knights carry old Leonese pride—they will suspect any reform originating from Castilian Toledo. The Orders also have different relationships with Rome. Santiago is more autonomous. Calatrava technically answers to Morimond, though that's largely nominal now. Any reform touching their religious character will require careful navigation with the Vatican—even with your papal grant.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's proposal to supervise revenues and redirect expenses—this is achievable. But the how matters enormously. Approach Santiago differently than Calatrava. Acknowledge Alcántara's distinct heritage. And whatever you do, do not let any Master feel he is being treated worse than his peers. These men have spent their lives in rivalry with each other. United resentment would be far more dangerous than divided grumbling.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see now that we cannot merge these orders together. And I also see that there are different functions for there orders in my new army. The fanaticism of Calatrava will serve us well if properly tempered with the discipline of the new tactics from the academy. We might even expand or support their order even more. I also like how Santiago offers nobles the chance to marry and still serve. This might be a good tool for nobles to be granted lands in new conquered lands. But it all starts with their realization that they are now fully under crown command and that I will review and maybe restructure them without destroying them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's expression shifts—the careful neutrality of a counselor hearing a problematic proposal replaced by something closer to genuine approval. He rises, moving to a side table where a servant has left wine. He pours two cups without asking—a familiarity born of years of private counsel—and hands one to you before settling back into his chair.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Now Your Majesty speaks with wisdom. Different tools for different purposes. Yes. The Orders need not be identical to serve the crown effectively. Let me think aloud on what Your Majesty proposes. The monk-warriors. Fanatics, as you say—but fanaticism is a blade that cuts both ways. Properly directed, they could become the finest heavy infantry in Christendom. Men who genuinely believe they fight for God do not break when lesser men would flee. The Academy's tactics—disciplined formations, coordinated maneuver, integration with artillery—these require soldiers who obey without question. Calatrava's monastic discipline already instills this. They are accustomed to rules, to hierarchy, to sublimating individual will to collective purpose. I would suggest: make Calatrava the model for your professional core. Send their officers to the Academy first. Let Sir Thomas Beaumont work with their existing discipline rather than against it. If Calatrava embraces the new methods and demonstrates their effectiveness, Santiago and Alcántara will follow rather than be seen as inferior.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The married knights. Yes—this is a tool for colonization that Your Majesty grasps correctly. A Santiago knight granted lands in Morocco can build a family there. His sons will be born on that soil, will consider it home. His grandsons will be Castilians who happen to live in Africa, not Castilians occupying foreign territory. The Orders of the Reconquista repopulated the lands they conquered. They granted fueros—charters—to villages, attracted settlers, built churches and mills and markets. Santiago did this better than anyone. They know how to turn conquered territory into productive Christian land. When Morocco comes—and I see now that it will come—Santiago should be your instrument of settlement. Grant them commanderies on African soil. Let their married knights put down roots. In two generations, those lands will be as Castilian as Extremadura.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The proud Leonese. Smaller, poorer, but with something to prove. Men who feel overlooked often fight hardest when given the chance. Perhaps... a specialized role? Frontier garrisons, where independence and initiative matter more than numbers? Or naval operations, working alongside the Aragonese fleet? Something that lets them distinguish themselves rather than forever standing in Santiago's shadow? I confess I have less clarity here. But the principle holds: find what they do well, and make that their purpose.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro sets down his wine cup and leans forward, his voice dropping.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This is the crux. Everything else flows from this. If the Masters accept crown supervision willingly—or at least without open resistance—reform becomes possible. If they resist, you spend years fighting your own Orders instead of conquering new lands. Your Majesty holds the papal decree. That is the hammer. But a wise carpenter does not begin with the hammer—he measures first, marks the wood, ensures the cut will be true. The hammer comes last, when precision work is done.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: First: summon the three Masters to Toledo. Not to announce reforms, but to consult. Ask their counsel on how the Orders might best serve the eternal crusade now that the Reconquista is complete. Let them speak. Let them feel heard. Second: show them the papal decree privately, one by one. Let each understand that crown authority is not a proposal to be debated but a fact to be accommodated. But frame it as protection—you now stand between them and any future Pope who might wish to meddle in Spanish affairs. The French connection that Calatrava resented? Gone forever. No Abbot of Morimond will ever again claim oversight of Castilian knights.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Third: present your vision for their distinct roles. Not dissolution, but elevation. Calatrava becomes the elite core of a professional army. Santiago becomes the instrument of Christian expansion. Alcántara receives a special mission worthy of their pride. Each Order gains purpose rather than losing identity. Fourth: address revenues openly. Explain that border fortresses against Granada are no longer needed—those funds must be redirected to the eternal crusade. Offer them a voice in how the redirected funds are spent. Let them see their wealth building fleets and training soldiers, not simply vanishing into the royal treasury.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Only then, when the ground is prepared, do you formalize the new arrangements. By that point, the Masters have been consulted, reassured, given roles they can embrace with honor. The decree is signed not as an imposition but as a confirmation of what has already been agreed. This takes time, Your Majesty. Months, perhaps a year, to do properly. But the alternative—announcing reforms by decree and daring the Masters to resist—risks turning three loyal institutions into resentful obstacles.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro sits back and meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The crusade treasury sits in Rome, awaiting release for eastern campaigns. The Morocco mission gathers intelligence that will not bear fruit until autumn. Isabel's child will not come for weeks yet. You have time—time to build consensus rather than impose dictates. Shall I draft letters summoning the Masters to Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, summon the masters to Toledo. Now, I want to put the qadi and Fray Hernando in the same room and to draft a system for muslim vassals to serve Castille.

encounters.recap: Juan and Álvaro finalize their strategy for military orders reform, deciding to preserve each order's distinct identity while bringing them under crown authority. Calatrava will become elite professional infantry, Santiago will handle colonization, and Alcántara will receive specialized frontier roles. Álvaro outlines a careful diplomatic approach: consult the Masters first, then gradually introduce reforms through consensus rather than decree. Juan approves summoning the Masters to Toledo and shifts focus to developing a system for Muslim vassalage.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This takes time, Your Majesty. Months, perhaps a year, to do properly. But the alternative—announcing reforms by decree and daring the Masters to resist—risks turning three loyal institutions into resentful obstacles. The crusade treasury sits in Rome, awaiting release for eastern campaigns. The Morocco mission gathers intelligence that will not bear fruit until autumn. Isabel's child will not come for weeks yet. You have time—time to build consensus rather than impose dictates. Shall I draft letters summoning the Masters to Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, summon the masters to Toledo. Now, I want to put the qadi and Fray Hernando in the same room and to draft a system for muslim vassals to serve Castille. Now, Is it realistic for both myself and the king of Aragon to name each other heir? I am already more or less his heir, but would naming me not make it more official and clear for everyone?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... Fernando is not available. He departed with Commander Martín's delegation to Morocco in April. He is somewhere on the North African coast as we speak—if all has gone well. Fray Hernando is here, of course. And there are other learned men who might contribute—Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena when he returns from Basel has studied both Islamic and Christian law. The Archbishop of Toledo has views, as I mentioned. But the particular combination you envision—the converted qadi who understands Islam from within, paired with your confessor who understands your soul—that cannot happen until autumn at the earliest, when the Morocco delegation returns.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro sets down his wine cup and steeples his fingers—the gesture he makes when navigating delicate political ground.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks whether mutual naming would make the succession 'more official and clear.' The answer is... complicated. First, the facts as they stand. Alfonso is forty years old, married to your sister María for twelve years, childless. His brothers—the Infantes Juan and Enrique—are dead. Young Carlos of Viana is dead. The direct male line of Alfonso's father, Ferdinand of Antequera, is effectively extinct save for Alfonso himself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, pacing slowly.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Consider the advantages of formal mutual naming. It signals to all of Christendom that Castile and Aragon stand united. It removes uncertainty that might invite foreign meddling—France has always had designs on Aragon's Pyrenean territories. It gives both kingdoms stability: if Alfonso dies, Aragon knows who inherits. If—God forbid—something happens to Your Majesty and Isabel bears no son, Castile knows who inherits. The three-kingdom alliance you discussed with Alfonso—Castile, Aragon, Naples united for eternal crusade—becomes more credible when the thrones themselves may soon be joined.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro stops pacing, turning to face you.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: But now consider the dangers. Aragon is not Castile. They have their own Cortes, their own laws, their own fierce pride in their independence. The Aragonese remember that Ferdinand of Antequera was a Castilian prince who claimed their throne through the Compromise of Caspe—and that compromise was bitterly contested. Many Aragonese nobles felt a Catalan candidate had the stronger claim. If Alfonso formally names you as heir, he must secure the approval of the Aragonese Cortes. They will demand concessions. They will insist that Aragon remain a separate kingdom with separate laws, not absorbed into Castile.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: My counsel: do not rush this. The informal understanding you reached at Granada—mutual support, succession discussions to follow—is sufficient for now. Let Alfonso secure Naples. Let Your Majesty consolidate the Military Orders and establish crown authority firmly. Let Isabel deliver safely and, God willing, provide an heir. Then, perhaps next year or the year after, when positions are stronger and circumstances clearer, formalize the arrangement. Do it with the approval of both Cortes. Do it with papal blessing. Do it in a way that cannot be challenged by rival claimants or foreign powers. Patience, Your Majesty. The crowns will come to you—or to your children—in time. Grasping too quickly may shatter what patient work will secure.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No Alvaro, just want to make sure all the pieces on the board are at the right place. I do think we should establish good relations with the Aragonese Cortes. And the fact that my sister is there being queen is actually a gift from god in this regard. Can we signal something to the Catalan court? A letter? A gift? I dont want it to be inappropriate. Maybe something for my sister? What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's expression warms slightly. This is the kind of subtle political work he excels at—building relationships through gesture and implication rather than blunt negotiation.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty thinks wisely. María is indeed a gift in this regard—a Castilian princess who has been Aragon's queen for twelve years. She knows the Aragonese court, understands their sensibilities, has cultivated her own relationships with the great families. And she is your sister. Fraternal affection requires no justification. Consider this: a formal gift to Queen María in recognition of her role in facilitating the alliance between Castile and Aragon. Something that acknowledges her as a political figure, not merely as your sister or Alfonso's wife.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The gift itself should be significant but not ostentatious. Something with meaning rather than mere value. Perhaps something from Granada? A piece of Moorish craftsmanship—the Nasrid artisans produced extraordinary work in silk, metalwork, ceramics. Such a gift says: This is from the Reconquista that we completed together. Aragon's support made this possible. We share this triumph.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think we should send Maria something nice made of silk from Grenada. I do love my sister so I will send a letter personally. The offer for Catalan noble sons to train at the academy is also a good idea. We should offer that as well. Can we signal that we value Catalan customs and identity? That seems to be their major concern. If they know I value their identity, it may adress their most pressing concerns. Also, send invitations to the universities. I want to talk about how they operate and how the crown can support and expand them. Especially the university of Salamanca seems very nice.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This requires delicacy, Your Majesty. The Catalans are proud—fiercely so. They have their own language, their own laws, their own Cortes separate from Aragon proper. They remember when Barcelona was the heart of a Mediterranean empire, when Catalan merchants dominated trade from Valencia to Athens. They do not wish to be tolerated. They wish to be respected as equals. Better to demonstrate respect through actions that cost you something. The Academy invitation is one such action—you spend Castilian coin training their sons. But consider also: when you write to María, write a portion of the letter in Catalan.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's eyebrows rise slightly—a flicker of genuine interest breaking through his usual composure.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Salamanca. Yes. The oldest university in Castile, one of the oldest in Christendom. Founded two centuries ago, rivaling Paris and Bologna in reputation. Also a nest of competing factions, jealous privileges, and scholars who would rather debate than decide. But yes—nice is one word for it. Your Majesty's interest in the universities is... unexpected. Welcome, but unexpected. Most kings view universities as sources of lawyers and clerks, not as institutions worthy of royal attention in themselves.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How does one actually found a new university? Is it a monastic order? Or do we just hire new scolars and build them a roof over their head?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Neither monastic order nor mere hiring of scholars, Your Majesty. A university is something in between—a corporation of masters and students, recognized by higher authority and granted specific privileges. To found a true university—one whose degrees carry weight throughout Christendom—you need three things. First: authority to grant the privilege. A royal charter suffices for a studium generale within your own realm. But for universal recognition—the licentia ubique docendi, the right for graduates to teach anywhere without further examination—you need papal confirmation. Second: endowed chairs. Professors must be paid, and paid reliably. Third: governance and constitutions.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty wished to found a university—in Granada, say, or expand what exists in Toledo—the steps would be these: First, secure a royal charter establishing the studium generale with specific privileges. Second, petition Rome for papal confirmation. Third, endow chairs with reliable revenues. Fourth, recruit masters of reputation. Fifth—and this is often forgotten—build. Not grand halls at first, but adequate spaces. The true cost is not the founding but the maintaining—chairs must be funded in perpetuity, or the institution withers when royal attention turns elsewhere.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets hear from the masters of the two universities that we have for now. Then we will look further. Also invite the master of the War academy as well. It may not be a university in the strict sense of the word, but they do train students. I would like to see if Grenada can have a University. Also, I want to see if there can be a university to research fundamentally about how the world works. Gunpowder for example but beyond military application. Why does gunpowder burn like it does? Are there other ways as well to use it? What else do we not understand about this world? I once read that Greeks measured that the world is a globe and they used the shade from the sun to measure how big it is. Things like that.

encounters.recap: Juan discusses succession arrangements with Aragon and diplomatic outreach to Catalonia with Álvaro. They plan gifts for Queen María, invitations for Catalan nobles to train at the academy, and meetings with university masters to explore founding new institutions including a research university in Granada focused on natural philosophy and experimental knowledge.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Salamanca operates on revenues from royal and papal concessions—lands, tithes, fees from students. A new foundation would require... perhaps five to ten thousand florins annually to sustain a modest beginning. More as it grows. The true cost is not the founding but the maintaining—chairs must be funded in perpetuity, or the institution withers when royal attention turns elsewhere.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It is a worthy ambition, Your Majesty. A university in Granada—Christian scholars teaching where Muslim scholars once taught—would be a statement heard throughout Christendom. But it is also a commitment of decades, not years. The students who enter your new university as boys will be old men before it rivals Salamanca.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Is this what Your Majesty envisions? A new foundation? Or rather the strengthening of what already exists?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets hear from the masters of the two universities that we have for now. Then we will look further. Also invite the master of the War academy as well. It may not be a university in the strict sense of the word, but they do train students. I would like to see if Grenada can have a University. Also, I want to see if there can be a university to research fundamentally about how the world works. Gunpowder for example but beyond military application. Why does gunpowder burn like it does? Are there other ways as well to use it? What else do we not understand about this world? I once read that Greeks measured that the world is a globe and they used the shade from the sun to measure how big it is. Things like that.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I will send summons to the Rector of Salamanca and Valladolid both. The journey from Salamanca is perhaps four or five days; Valladolid somewhat closer. They can be here within a fortnight, assuming they are not away on ecclesiastical business. Sir Thomas Beaumont is already in Toledo, overseeing the Academy's summer training. He can attend at Your Majesty's convenience—tomorrow, if you wish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But at your second line of thought, Álvaro's expression shifts. Not confusion exactly, but the careful blankness of a man hearing something outside his expertise.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of... researching how the world works. Gunpowder. The shape of the earth. The why of things, not merely the how.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I am an administrator, Your Majesty. I can tell you how many florins flow through the treasury, which nobles are reliable, how to structure a tax reform. But this... This is the domain of scholars. Natural philosophy, they call it—the study of nature's workings. It is taught at universities, yes, but as preparation for theology, not as an end in itself.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: What Your Majesty describes—dedicated investigation of why gunpowder burns, what else might burn similarly, how the Greeks measured the earth—this is not how universities typically operate. They teach what is already known. Aristotle. Galen. The Church Fathers. Students learn the received wisdom of the ancients and the commentaries upon it.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And yet... the Moors did something like what you describe. In Córdoba, in Toledo before the Reconquest, in Granada itself—Muslim scholars gathered to study mathematics, astronomy, medicine, alchemy. They translated Greek texts, yes, but they also added to them. New observations. New calculations. New methods.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: There was a man—al-Zarqali, they called him. Lived in Toledo four centuries ago, before it was Christian. He built instruments to measure the stars, created tables predicting their movements more accurate than anything the ancients produced. The Christians who took Toledo preserved his work, translated it. Our own astronomers still use his tables.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I tell you this not because I understand such work, but because Your Majesty's question reminds me of it. The Moors had places where scholars gathered not merely to teach but to discover. Perhaps... perhaps such a thing could exist again. Under Christian auspices this time.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: But I am the wrong man to design such an institution. This is a question for the university masters themselves—and perhaps for scholars who work at the boundaries of knowledge rather than teaching its established core.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: There is a man Your Majesty might wish to meet. A Florentine—Paolo dal Pozzo Toscanelli. I have heard his name mentioned by merchants who trade in Italy. They say he studies mathematics, astronomy, geography. They say he has calculated distances across the Ocean Sea, speculated about what lies beyond. He corresponds with scholars throughout Christendom.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I do not know if he would come to Castile, or what it would take to lure him. But if Your Majesty seeks men who ask why rather than merely what, such men exist. They are rare, and they are often considered... eccentric. But they exist.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: For now, let me summon the university masters and arrange Sir Thomas for tomorrow or the day after. When the scholars arrive, Your Majesty can put these questions to men better equipped to answer them. Ask them: what would it take to create an institution dedicated not to teaching the known, but to discovering the unknown? They may look at you strangely—or they may have ideas that surprise us both.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: As for Granada... A university there makes sense regardless of this other matter. Christian scholars where Muslim scholars once taught, as I said. But perhaps Granada could be both—a traditional university teaching law and theology, and also something new. A place where the Moorish tradition of inquiry continues under Christian rule.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It would be a statement, Your Majesty. That Castile does not merely conquer—it learns. That we are heirs to all the knowledge that came before us, Christian and classical and yes, even Muslim. That the completion of the Reconquista is not an ending but a beginning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A slight smile crosses his weathered face.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The scholars will think you mad, of course. Kings are supposed to want glory and gold, not to ask why gunpowder burns. But perhaps that is precisely why they will come.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, summon them. Question; how is the construction of the ships we ordered going? And is my flagship ready yet?

encounters.recap: Juan discusses founding a university in Granada and creating an institution for natural philosophy research with Álvaro. Álvaro explains the costs and challenges, draws parallels to Moorish scholarly traditions, and suggests consulting Paolo dal Pozzo Toscanelli. They agree to summon university masters and Thomas Beaumont for further discussions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Question; how is the construction of the ships we ordered going? And is my flagship ready yet?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The shipyards at Sevilla and Santander have been active since Your Majesty gave the order in January. Let me give you the current state.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The five war galleys are under construction at Sevilla—the Guadalquivir shipyards have experience with Mediterranean vessels. Five months into an eighteen to twenty-four month timeline. The keels are laid, the ribs are rising. Master shipwright reports good progress, though he warns that finding enough seasoned timber for the oars has been... challenging.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: At current pace, we expect the first galley launched by late autumn. The full squadron should be operational by spring or summer of 1434. Cost remains on budget—fifty-two thousand five hundred florins from the crusade treasury allocation.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The four carracks are being built at Santander—the Basque shipwrights know Atlantic construction better than anyone in Christendom. These are heavier vessels, designed for cannon mounting. The Basques are... particular about their work. They will not be rushed.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your flagship—she has been given priority. The master shipwright claims she will be ready for sea trials by late summer, perhaps September. The other three carracks will follow over the winter and into next year. Total cost of fifty-eight thousand florins from crown treasury, as budgeted.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: She is being built to Your Majesty's specifications—larger than a standard carrack, with reinforced gunwales for cannon mounting. The Basques are experimenting with techniques learned from Genoese shipwrights for securing the guns against recoil. They say she will carry twelve guns when complete—more than any other vessel in Castilian service.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: She does not yet have a name, Your Majesty. The shipwrights have been calling her simply La Grande for her size, but they await your pleasure. A royal flagship should bear a name chosen by her king.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I cannot leave Isabel. But we should send them our regards. I plan to travel to Constantinople using my flagship. When will it be available for me to use from Seville?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The flagship is being built at Santander, Your Majesty—not Sevilla. Santander is on the northern coast, facing the Bay of Biscay. The war galleys are at Sevilla; the carracks are Basque work.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: If sea trials proceed as expected in September, and assuming no significant problems are discovered... the ship would need to sail from Santander, around the coast of Portugal, through the Strait of Gibraltar, and into the Mediterranean. That voyage alone—Santander to Sevilla, or directly to a Mediterranean port—takes perhaps three to four weeks depending on weather and winds.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of sailing to Constantinople. That is a voyage of... considerable distance. From Sevilla or Málaga through the Mediterranean, past the Balearics, past Sardinia and Sicily, through the waters between Greece and the Italian boot, into the Aegean, and finally to the Bosphorus. Two months at minimum, perhaps three depending on winds and how many ports you wish to visit along the way.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty insists on using the flagship for this voyage, the earliest realistic departure would be spring of 1434. The ship would be fully tested by then, the crew experienced with her handling, and the sailing season favorable.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, have the thousand knights been dispatched with the treasury? I hope you recieved my order correctly?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's order was received, yes. The letter arrived in Toledo in early June, carried by royal courier from Basel.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I must speak frankly. When I received the order, the Military Orders were still operating under their traditional authority. The Masters had served faithfully in the Reconquista, yes, but they had not yet been informed of the papal decree granting Your Majesty permanent control over their Orders.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: To demand one thousand knights for a foreign campaign—a third of their combined strength—without first establishing crown authority over the Orders... I judged this would provoke resistance. The Masters might comply, or they might demand to see the papal grant, or they might delay while seeking clarification from Rome.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I have assembled the sixty thousand florins. That was straightforward—treasury matters are within my authority. The coin sits in the royal vaults, ready for transport.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: For the knights, I have sent preliminary inquiries to the three Masters, asking how many knights each Order could make available for 'overseas crusading operations' and on what timeline. I framed it as consultation rather than command, to gauge their willingness before Your Majesty's return allowed us to establish proper authority.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The responses have been... mixed. Santiago, with its married knights and family obligations, expressed willingness to provide perhaps three hundred men within two months. Calatrava, with its stricter monastic discipline, offered four hundred but requested six months to arrange garrison replacements. Alcántara offered two hundred but complained of being asked to contribute equally despite being the smallest Order.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: In total: nine hundred knights potentially available, but spread across different timelines and with various conditions attached.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You judged the situation correctly Alvaro. We will discuss this with the masters when they arrive here. I might as well accompany them personally when I leave for Constantinople. This gives us time to properly prepare. Lets await the meeting with the masters first, then send a message to the Greeks with a realistic timeline.

encounters.recap: Juan reviews naval construction progress with Álvaro. The flagship will be ready for sea trials by September 1433, with full deployment to Constantinople planned for spring 1434. Discussion reveals that the thousand knights ordered for Constantinople deployment were delayed pending establishment of royal authority over the Military Orders, with treasury funds ready but knight commitments still being negotiated through preliminary consultations.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: But I will not pretend the knights are already sailing for Constantinople. They are not. The delay is my responsibility. If Your Majesty wishes to rebuke me for it, I will accept that judgment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You judged the situation correctly Alvaro. We will discuss this with the masters when they arrive here. I might as well accompany them personally when I leave for Constantinople. This gives us time to properly prepare. Lets await the meeting with the masters first, then send a message to the Greeks with a realistic timeline.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's shoulders ease almost imperceptibly—the tension of a man who feared rebuke draining away.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Thank you, Your Majesty. I am relieved my judgment aligns with yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reaches for his wine cup, takes a measured sip, and sets it down again.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty intends to accompany the knights personally... that changes the nature of the expedition considerably. A thousand knights sailing to reinforce Constantinople is a military deployment. The King of Castile sailing to Constantinople at the head of a thousand knights is... a statement. A declaration to all of Christendom about Castile's intentions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins counting considerations on his fingers.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: First, the regency. Your Majesty cannot leave the realm without formal arrangements. The regency council structure from the Rome journey would serve again—myself, the Archbishop of Toledo, and others Your Majesty trusts, with unanimous decision required for major matters. But this voyage will be longer than Rome. Months, perhaps half a year or more depending on what Your Majesty intends to do once you arrive.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Second, Isabel. She will have delivered by spring—God willing, safely. But leaving her with an infant, possibly two young children, while you sail into Ottoman-threatened waters... She will understand. She understood when you rode to Granada. But understanding does not mean the fear will be any less.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Third, the political implications. Every court in Europe will learn that the King of Castile personally sails east with a crusading force. The Pope will see it as vindication of your alliance. The Council of Basel will wonder what it means for the negotiations. Emperor Sigismund will watch carefully. The Venetians and Genoese will calculate how your presence affects their commercial interests. And the Ottoman Sultan...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Murad II will learn that the king who conquered Granada—the first Christian monarch to complete a successful crusade in generations—now sails toward his conquests. He may see it as a threat. He may see it as an opportunity, if he thinks he can capture or kill a Christian king far from home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans back.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: None of this is reason to abandon the plan. But it is reason to prepare carefully. The Masters' meeting is the first step. Once we know what forces we command and on what timeline, we can plan properly.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I will draft a letter to the Byzantine metropolitans—or to Cardinal Cesarini at Basel, who can relay it to the Greeks—explaining that Castile's commitment stands firm, that preparations are underway, and that a realistic timeline will follow once Your Majesty has consulted with the Military Order leadership.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses, a thought occurring to him.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The seventeen crusaders who departed with the Byzantine delegation in June—they should arrive in Constantinople before autumn, if their journey goes well. They will serve as proof that Castile's promises are not empty words. The Greeks will know that more follows.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Is there anything else Your Majesty wishes to address tonight? The hour grows late, and Isabel will be wondering where you are.

encounters.recap: Juan decides to personally accompany the Constantinople expedition, transforming it from a military deployment into a royal crusade. Álvaro outlines the complex implications: regency arrangements, Isabel's concerns with a newborn, and the major political statement this would make across Europe and to the Ottoman Sultan. They agree to await the Military Order Masters' meeting before finalizing plans and communicating realistic timelines to the Greeks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The meeting with Álvaro concluded as the last light faded from the study windows. Toledo's summer heat had softened into evening warmth, the thick stone walls of the Alcázar finally releasing the day's accumulated weight. Servants moved quietly through corridors, lighting candles and opening casements to admit what breeze might stir from the river below. The walk to the royal chambers took only moments—the route memorized from years of habit—yet felt unfamiliar after so many months abroad. Different tapestries hung in the corridor. A bust he didn't recognize. Some functionary had been making improvements in his absence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The guard at Isabel's door—a grizzled veteran who'd served Juan's father—offered a respectful nod and opened the heavy oak without announcement. There was no need. The Queen expected him. The chamber was lit by candles clustered on the window ledge, their flames dancing in the faint breeze. Isabel sat at her dressing table, Doña Beatriz having just finished braiding her hair for the night. The Portuguese lady-in-waiting looked up as Juan entered, curtsied smoothly, and withdrew without a word—closing the door softly behind her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel watched him in the polished silver mirror as he approached. She wore a simple linen shift, white against her olive skin, her pregnant belly visible now without the formal gowns of the day. Seventeen months since Catalina. Seven months along, perhaps a little more. The physicians' warnings hung in the air like smoke from the candles.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: She finally fell asleep. She was asking for Pa until her eyes closed. I think she's decided you're allowed to stay.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turned on the little stool to face him. In the candlelight, the terror that had consumed her earlier—the raw confession of mortality and fear—had given way to something quieter. Exhaustion, perhaps. The relief of having finally spoken the unspeakable. Or simply the bone-deep weariness of a pregnant woman who had spent months pretending she wasn't afraid. Her eyes found his.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I rehearsed this moment a hundred times while you were gone. What I would say. How I would look. Whether I would cry or be brave. All those rehearsals, and when you actually arrived, I couldn't say anything at all. I just... managed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She extended her hand toward him—a simple gesture, palm upward, fingers slightly curled.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I don't want to manage anymore tonight. Not with you. Just... come here.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel's face softens with something like wonder—as if this simple request, this desire to watch their daughter sleep, confirms something she needed to believe about him. The nursery adjoins the royal chambers through a small antechamber. Isabel opens the door slowly, silently, with the practiced care of a mother who has done this a hundred times without waking the child within. The room is dim, lit only by a single candle in a glass housing on the far table.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And there, in a small carved bed with low rails to keep her from rolling, lies Catalina. She sleeps on her back, arms thrown wide in that peculiar abandon only small children possess—complete surrender to unconsciousness. Her dark hair, Isabel's hair, curls damply at her temples. Her lips are slightly parted, and in the candlelight Juan can see the tiny rise and fall of her chest beneath the light blanket. Seventeen months old. Walking now. Speaking a few words. Pa. She is so small. So impossibly small.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to the royal chambers after his meeting with Álvaro to find Isabel waiting for him. In the candlelit intimacy of their bedroom, she opens her heart about the fear and loneliness she experienced during his absence. They share a tender moment watching their sleeping daughter Catalina in the nursery, reconnecting as husband, wife, and parents after months of separation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan wakes to summer light filtering through the casements and the distant sound of the city stirring below. Isabel still sleeps beside him, her breathing deep and even, one hand resting on the swell of her belly. He lies still for a moment, unwilling to disturb her. Then, from somewhere in the Alcázar, he hears the familiar sounds of a palace coming to life—servants in corridors, the clatter of the kitchens, a door opening and closing. And voices. Hushed but urgent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A soft knock comes at the outer door of the antechamber. Doña Beatriz's voice, carefully modulated: "Your Majesty? Forgive the intrusion. Don Álvaro sends word—there are matters requiring attention when you are ready. Nothing urgent, he says, but... accumulated correspondence. And the Masters of Santiago and Calatrava have sent riders ahead. They will arrive sooner than expected. Perhaps within the week."

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell Don Álvaro I will meet with him after midday. The matters have waited this long. They can wait a few hours more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan dresses quietly—simple clothes, nothing formal—and slips through the antechamber to the nursery. The wet-nurse is awake now, seated by the window with morning light streaming in, but Catalina's bed is empty. For a moment his heart lurches—then he hears the giggling. His daughter is on the floor near the foot of the bed, engaged in serious negotiations with a wooden horse that has seen better days. She holds it by one leg and appears to be explaining something to it with great conviction in a language composed entirely of sounds that are not quite words. She looks up when the door opens. Her face transforms—eyes widening, mouth opening into a perfect circle of surprise and delight. She drops the horse immediately and begins the laborious process of getting to her feet, arms windmilling for balance.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pa!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She toddles toward him with the determined, slightly drunken gait of a child who has only recently mastered walking—arms outstretched, grinning with all six of her teeth. The wet-nurse rises and curtsies, but Juan waves her back to her seat without looking away from his daughter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina shrieks with delight as Juan sweeps her up and holds her high above his head. Her small hands grab at the air, at his face, at anything within reach. Juan carries his daughter through the antechamber, banking her around corners like a ship in full sail. She extends her arms, a tiny figurehead cutting through imaginary waves. Down she goes—up she goes—a brief stop to inspect a tapestry ("Bird!" she announces, pointing at what is clearly a lion)—and then onward to the royal chamber.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One great swooping arc around the room—Catalina's feet nearly brushing the canopy—and then Juan brings her in low over the bed, descending toward Isabel's face like a very small, very giggly falcon.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mama!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel's startled expression melts into something soft and unguarded—the face of a woman woken not by fear or duty but by her daughter's kiss and her husband's smile. She reaches up, still half-asleep, and touches Juan's cheek as he leans down to kiss her properly.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Good morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan settles onto the edge of the bed, releasing his daughter into the landscape of linen and down. Catalina immediately sets about conquering this new territory with the seriousness of a general surveying a battlefield. She crawls across the sheets, investigates a pillow by pressing her face into it, emerges with her hair wild, and then discovers that blankets can be pulled.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: She's been doing this every morning. The pillows are enemy fortresses, I think. Yesterday she spent ten minutes trying to defeat that one. She'll do this for an hour if you let her. The same game, over and over. Doña Beatriz says it's maddening. I think it's wonderful. That she can find such joy in something so simple.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina squeals with delight as Juan gathers her into the linen, transforming the sheet into a billowing cloud. He lifts her high and carries her through the room in great sweeping arcs—around the bedpost, past the dressing table, toward the window where morning light pours in. She clutches the fabric with both hands, eyes wide, mouth open in perpetual astonishment at this new form of flight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Princess Catalina. For the flagship. I think it suits her.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: You would name the ship that carries you to Constantinople after her? The ship that takes you away from us?

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: The Princess Catalina. She'll be insufferable when she's old enough to understand, you know. A warship named after her before her second birthday.

encounters.recap: Juan spends a tender morning with his family, playing with young Catalina and sharing intimate moments with Isabel. He announces his intention to name his flagship after their daughter, strengthening family bonds before his departure for the crusade.

roll.outcome: Exceptional — Physicians genuinely surprised; everything progressing better than anyone dared hope

encounters.recap: Against all medical expectations, Isabel's high-risk second pregnancy progresses exceptionally well. The baby turns to proper head-down position, her health improves dramatically, and the fear that had plagued both royal parents transforms into genuine hope as delivery approaches in early August.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The riders arrived two days before their masters—outriders bearing the banners of three Orders that had fought for Christendom in Iberia for three centuries. Black crosses of Santiago. Red crosses of Calatrava. Green crosses of Alcántara. By the third of July, all three Masters had reached Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Luis de Guzmán, Master of Santiago, arrived first. He had aged visibly since the crusade began, gray now dominating his beard, but his bearing remained that of a soldier at ease with authority. Juan received him privately, producing the papal decree bearing the Fisherman's Ring and twenty-three cardinal signatures.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I came as quickly as the summons allowed. Your letter mentioned matters of great consequence for the Orders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Luis read in silence. When he reached Article Two about perpetual crown control over the Military Orders, he stopped and read it again. And again.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: I see. And has Your Majesty already determined who shall be appointed as Master of Santiago?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Master of Calatrava was a different man entirely. Where Don Luis cultivated inscrutability, Don Pedro wore his heart closer to the surface. His weathered hands trembled slightly as he held the parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Perpetual. Irrevocable. No pope may revoke. Your Majesty, I have served Calatrava for twenty-three years. The Order was my purpose. To fight the Moor. To defend Christendom's frontier. And now the frontier is gone. Granada is Christian. The Reconquista is complete. What is Calatrava for now?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Juan de Sotomayor, the youngest Master, received the news with controlled stillness. He read the decree twice, asked to examine the seals, studied the cardinal signatures.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The Pope has granted this freely? There was no... coercion? No threat to the Holy Father? What assurances can Your Majesty offer that Alcántara will not simply be... absorbed? Dissolved? Our lands distributed to reward loyal nobles?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three Masters sat on one side of the long table in the Royal Council Chamber. Álvaro de Luna sat at Juan's right hand, his dark eyes moving between the Masters with patient attention. The mood was not hostile, but neither was it comfortable.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We have each read the Pope's decree. We acknowledge its authority. The Holy Father has spoken, and we are faithful sons of the Church. But we have questions. Concerns. We would hear from Your Majesty's own lips what you intend for our Orders.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: What are we for now? The Moor is defeated. The frontier is gone.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And what happens to our knights? Our commanderies? Our traditions?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you all for coming. We have won a great victory and now is the time to set our sights on new glories. The orders were founded to drive the moors from Iberia. Now that this has been achieved, we must find a new purpose and make sure the military orders are in a good position to fulfill that purpose. The Moors are no more. The border forts in our kingdom may not be needed anymore. But this does not diminish the need for the orders at all. In fact, if christianity calls again, I might need the orders more than ever before.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The pope has granted me full authority over the orders, meaning that the men in this room can determine together how best to reshape the orders while preserving their traditions and identity. You all have served me and the crusade greatly so I seek no change in leadership.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In regards to what out next goals are: I see two major objectives. The first is eternal crusade against Morocco. I have already sent out informants to Morocco to look and see what cities are ripe for conquest. I see no problems in taking cities, but holding them is where the orders come in. Secondly, I will leave for constantinople next spring to see if we can drive the Ottomans from europe in the east as well. I have promised the Greeks 1000 knights from the orders to temporarily support the Greeks. Depending on what the actual situation is, we might commit to also fight in the east against the Ottomans. This will require the sustained campain, forts and commanderies the orders specialize in.

encounters.recap: Juan presents the papal decree granting him perpetual control over the Military Orders to each Master individually, then convenes them together. Despite their concerns about purpose and autonomy after the Reconquista's completion, Juan proposes new crusades against Morocco and potential campaigns supporting Byzantium against the Ottomans, offering the Orders continued relevance while maintaining current leadership.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We have each read the Pope's decree. We acknowledge its authority. The Holy Father has spoken, and we are faithful sons of the Church. But we have questions. Concerns. We would hear from Your Majesty's own lips what you intend for our Orders.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And what happens to our knights? Our commanderies? Our traditions?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro remained silent, watching Juan. This was the King's moment—the Constable would not speak unless called upon. The three Masters waited.

Now that this has been achieved, we must find a new purpose and make sure the military orders are in a good position to fulfill that purpose. The Moors are no more. The border forts in our kingdom may not be needed anymore. But this does not diminish the need for the orders at all. In fact, if christianity calls again, I might need the orders more than ever before.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In regards to what our next goals are: I see two major objectives. The first is eternal crusade against Morocco. I have already sent out informants to Morocco to look and see what cities are ripe for conquest. I see no problems in taking cities, but holding them is where the orders come in. Secondly, I will leave for Constantinople next spring to see if we can drive the Ottomans from europe in the east as well. I have promised the Greeks 1000 knights from the orders to temporarily support the Greeks. Depending on what the actual situation is, we might commit to also fight in the east against the Ottomans. This will require the sustained campaign, forts and commanderies the orders specialize in.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Either way, we should make use of our new developed tactics and I hope the orders will send their officers to the War academy to learn these new tactics that are needed to fight the ottomans and the Moroccans. In short, we must reform the orders so they can best face the new challenges. Challenges that are different from fighting Granada so that naturally requires some different organization. But I have every intention to again let the orders take a pivotal role in our new campaigns. Castile and its success and glory is because of the military orders who have contributed greatly to the reconquista and I will never forget that.

roll.outcome: Cautious Acceptance, Significant Concerns — Masters acknowledge the new reality but press hard for specifics. Don Luis wants detailed written protections for Order properties and revenues. Don Juan de Sotomayor demands explicit guarantees about Alcántara's continued existence. Don Pedro asks difficult questions about the War Academy—are their current knights inadequate? The 1,000-knight commitment made without consultation is raised as a concern. Productive meeting, but trust must be built gradually.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the three Military Order Masters about their future under papal decree granting him authority over the Orders. He promises continued leadership, new crusading missions in Morocco and Constantinople, and preservation of their traditions. The Masters respond with cautious acceptance but demand specific protections and guarantees, particularly regarding their autonomy and the King's prior commitment of 1,000 knights without consultation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence that follows Juan's speech stretches longer than comfort allows. Don Luis de Guzmán is the first to move—a slight shift in his chair, his fingers steepling before him in the manner of a man organizing his thoughts. His face remains carefully neutral, but his eyes have sharpened.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of reform. Of reshaping the Orders while preserving traditions and identity. These are fine words. But words are not policy. Santiago commands eighty-three commanderies. Vast lands in Extremadura, Murcia, Andalucía. Revenues that fund two thousand knights and their households. When Your Majesty speaks of reform—what precisely does this mean for our properties? Our revenues? The rights we have held for three centuries?

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentioned the War Academy. That our officers should learn 'new tactics needed to fight the Ottomans and Moroccans.' Calatrava has fought the Moor for two hundred and seventy years. My knights broke the Granadan cavalry at Alcalá. We held the siege lines at Málaga through three weeks of sorties. We bled for the crusade Your Majesty led to victory. Are we now to be told our methods are... inadequate? That we must sit as students while others teach us war?

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty said you seek no change in leadership. That you intend to preserve our traditions and identity. Yet I notice Your Majesty did not address my specific concern from yesterday. Alcántara is the smallest of the three Orders. We hold fifty commanderies. Fewer knights than my brothers command. When resources are scarce and priorities must be set, the smallest is always first to be... rationalized. Absorbed. Dissolved for the greater good. I would have written guarantees, Your Majesty. Explicit commitments that Alcántara will not simply disappear into Santiago or Calatrava when administrative convenience suggests it.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentioned one thousand knights already committed to Constantinople. Committed to the Greeks. This commitment was made, I understand, while Your Majesty was at Basel. Before this meeting. Before any consultation with the Orders whose knights are being committed. We do not dispute the Pope's decree. The Holy Father has spoken. Crown authority over the Orders is now... reality. But if this authority is to be exercised wisely—if the Orders are to serve Castile as effectively as Your Majesty desires—then perhaps future commitments might benefit from... consultation. Before they are made.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You knights are not inferior. I am only inviting them to make use of the most modern tactics if we are to fight the Ottomans. I did not order you to do so, but please make use of the academy. As for the 1000 soldiers, I promised as Castille that we would support them with that amount. I specifically have asked you to come here so we way discuss together how to achieve this. Understand that I could not say to the Greeks: 'Let me first discuss with the masters of my order if and how we can send any help.' I gave the Greeks my word as king. If the orders cannot fulfill this request, then I will send my own men. I will keep my word. But understand that I had to balance committing to aid to the Greeks and discussing the operation with you, which we are doing now. You ask what reform looks like. We should first make sure we understand what your new purpose is exactly. Only then can we determine in what way the orders should be reformed. So I can't tell you exactly what this would look like now. We must first focus on the purpose first. Until then, things will stay the same. I have no problem drafting a new order charter stating that the honourable order of Alcantara will maintain it's identity and will not be absorbed into another order.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The atmosphere in the chamber shifts—subtly, but perceptibly. Don Juan de Sotomayor sits back in his chair, and something in his posture eases. The offer of a written charter—specific, concrete, addressing his exact concern—has landed precisely where it needed to.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: A charter. Your Majesty, that is... that is what I asked for. If Alcántara's identity and continued existence can be guaranteed in writing, then Alcántara will serve the crown faithfully in whatever capacity is required.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: An invitation. Then I... may have spoken too sharply, Your Majesty. Calatrava has always sought to improve. If new tactics exist that will help us fight the enemies of Christ more effectively... I will send officers to observe. To learn what may be useful.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's position regarding Constantinople is... understandable. A king must be able to make commitments. And you are correct—we are discussing the operation now, which is consultation of a sort. But I would note, for future reference, that the Orders' value lies not merely in our knights' swords but in our knowledge. Our experience. Our understanding of logistics, of garrison warfare, of holding territory far from home. If Castile is to campaign in Morocco, in Constantinople, in lands none of us have seen—that experience may prove valuable. Before commitments are made. Not merely after.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says we must first understand our new purpose before we can discuss reform. This is logical. So let us discuss purpose. You have mentioned two objectives: Morocco and Constantinople. These are very different campaigns. Different terrain. Different enemies. Different distances from Castile.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Morocco is across the strait. Close. Reinforcement and supply are possible. Constantinople is... Months away by sea. Fighting there means fighting far from home, far from support.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And the Ottomans are not the Moors of Granada. Everything we hear suggests they are more numerous, better organized, better equipped. The Greeks have been losing to them for decades.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: These are precisely the questions His Majesty hoped to discuss with you. What would be required? What is realistic? What role can the Orders play—and what role should they play?

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Very well, Your Majesty. Let us discuss purpose. You have our attention—and, provisionally, our cooperation. What would you have us consider?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Keep in mind, our goal in Constantinople is not to defeat them. We must learn about the situation. If Constantinople can even be saved in the first place. And your king has promised immediate aid to save them from immediate danger. That aid is 60.000 florins, paid by the crown and 1000 knights to temporarily reinforce the city. Master Juan de Sotomayor, how would you go about this situation? What would you propose?

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the Military Orders' Masters' concerns about reform, offering specific guarantees including a written charter preserving Alcántara's independence. The Masters shift from resistance to cautious cooperation, agreeing to discuss the Orders' new purpose in supporting crusading missions to Constantinople and Morocco. Juan clarifies the Constantinople mission as reconnaissance and temporary aid rather than conquest.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Juan de Sotomayor is silent for a long moment after Juan's question. The other Masters watch him—Don Luis with polite skepticism, Don Pedro with neutral curiosity.
