The smallest Order. The youngest Master. Asked to advise the King on a campaign none of them have ever contemplated. Then something shifts in Sotomayor's bearing. He sits straighter. When he speaks, his voice carries a clarity that was not there before.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty honors me by asking. I know little of Constantinople. I have never seen the Bosphorus or faced Ottoman sipahis. But I know something of holding ground far from home with fewer men than the task demands. That is what Alcántara has done for two centuries.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises from his chair—not asking permission, simply needing to move as his mind works. The other Masters exchange glances but say nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has promised immediate aid. One thousand knights, sixty thousand florins. This promise must be kept—honor demands it, and Castile's word must mean something if we are to be taken seriously in the East. But how we keep that promise matters as much as that we keep it. I would propose a phased approach. Three stages.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to pace, hands clasped behind his back.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: First: The Vanguard. Send three hundred knights immediately. Not the full thousand—not yet. These three hundred should include your best captains, men capable of honest assessment. Their task is twofold: reinforce the walls, yes, but also see. See the defenses. See the Greek troops. See whether Constantinople can truly be held or whether we are pouring water into sand. Include men who will tell you the truth even if the truth is ugly. Not courtiers seeking glory. Soldiers who understand that an honest report of failure is worth more than a flattering report of false hope.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Second: The Assessment. Give these three hundred knights ninety days. At the end of ninety days, they send a report—not to the Greeks, not to the Pope, but to you, Your Majesty. This report answers three questions. One: Can Constantinople hold for five years with the forces available, including our support? Two: What would be required to make it hold for twenty years? Three: If it cannot hold—if the situation is truly desperate—how do we extract our knights before the walls fall?

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: You speak of... retreat? Before we have even arrived?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I speak of reality, Don Luis. Alcántara has held posts that could not be held. I have buried knights who died not because they failed, but because no one planned for what to do when success became impossible. I will not send Alcántara brothers to die in a city that is already lost without at least considering how to bring them home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long pause. Don Luis inclines his head slightly—not agreement, perhaps, but acknowledgment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Third: Calibrated Commitment. Based on the assessment, Your Majesty decides. If Constantinople can hold—if our knights can make a difference—then send the remaining seven hundred. Rotate them on twelve-month deployments so no man is trapped indefinitely. Establish supply through Venetian or Genoese merchants; we cannot rely on Greek logistics alone. But if the assessment says Constantinople is lost—if the Ottomans will take it regardless of what we do—then Your Majesty must decide whether to die gloriously for a doomed city or preserve Castilian strength for battles we can actually win. Morocco, for instance. Close to home. Achievable. Sustainable. A victory there builds strength for future campaigns. A catastrophe at Constantinople might break us for a generation.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: You have thought about this.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I have thought about holding impossible positions. Constantinople is the most impossible position in Christendom. That does not mean we should abandon it. It means we should approach it with open eyes.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: The Master of Alcántara speaks wisdom. A phased approach. Assessment before full commitment. Extraction planning. These are not the words of a man seeking glory. They are the words of a man who has learned that glory without survival is merely a pretty death.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro de Luna permits himself a small smile. He catches Juan's eye briefly. Sotomayor returns to his seat, his piece said. But he sits differently now—no longer the junior Master hoping not to be absorbed, but a counselor who has proven his worth. The dynamic in the room has shifted.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You make a fine point. And how should these 300 be assembled? From all three orders? Or would you include some crown soldiers as well? And who do you propose will lead this force?

roll.outcome: Exceptional Performance — Sotomayor seizes the opportunity brilliantly. He provides a coherent framework: immediate aid as promised (honor demands it), built-in assessment mechanism, clear criteria for escalation or withdrawal, rotation system to prevent knights being trapped indefinitely. He addresses both military and political dimensions. When finished, even Don Luis acknowledges: 'The Master of Alcántara speaks wisdom.' Juan's decision to consult him specifically is validated. Sotomayor has established himself as a valuable voice in future councils.

encounters.recap: Juan asks Sotomayor for his assessment of the Constantinople situation. Despite having no direct experience with the Ottomans, Sotomayor delivers an exceptional strategic proposal: a three-phase approach involving an initial 300-knight vanguard for assessment, followed by calibrated commitment based on realistic evaluation. His thoughtful analysis impresses the other Masters and establishes him as a valuable counselor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Luis de Guzmán studies the younger Master with an expression that has shifted from skepticism to something approaching respect.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: The Master of Alcántara speaks wisdom. A phased approach. Assessment before full commitment. Extraction planning. These are not the words of a man seeking glory. They are the words of a man who has learned that glory without survival is merely a pretty death.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro de Luna permits himself a small smile. He catches Juan's eye briefly. Sotomayor returns to his seat, his piece said. But he sits differently now—no longer the junior Master hoping not to be absorbed, but a counselor who has proven his worth. The dynamic in the room has shifted.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You make a fine point. And how should these 300 be assembled? From all three orders? Or would you include some crown soldiers as well? And who do you propose will lead this force?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sotomayor does not answer immediately. He takes a breath, and when he speaks, there is a deliberateness to his words that suggests he understands exactly what ground he is walking on.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Composition first. That is the easier question. The vanguard should draw from all three Orders. Not equally—that would be foolish, given our different strengths—but visibly. When these knights ride through Constantinople's gates, the Greeks should see Santiago's black cross, Calatrava's red, Alcántara's green. They should see that Castile's entire crusading tradition stands with them, not merely one Order's ambition.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I would propose: one hundred fifty from Santiago, one hundred from Calatrava, fifty from Alcántara. This reflects our relative strength. Santiago has more knights to spare; Alcántara fewer. But all three Orders share the burden and the honor.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: And crown soldiers?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Yes. Your Majesty should include fifty men from the crown forces. Soldiers who answer to you directly, not to any Master. They serve two purposes: first, they demonstrate that this is Castile's mission, not merely the Orders' adventure. Second—they provide Your Majesty with eyes that owe no loyalty except to you. If a Master's report is... colored by pride or ambition, crown soldiers can provide a different perspective.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A slight tension enters the room. Sotomayor has just suggested—politely, diplomatically—that the Orders' reports might not be entirely trustworthy. But he has included himself in that implicit criticism, which disarms it. Don Luis's eyes narrow, but he does not object. The logic is sound, even if it stings.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And leadership. This is the harder question. And I will not pretend I do not have personal interest in the answer. Alcántara is the smallest Order. We have always had to do more with less. That has taught us... economy. Careful judgment. The habit of asking 'what can we actually achieve' rather than 'what glory can we win.' It has also taught us humility, because we cannot afford pride we cannot pay for.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I believe Alcántara would serve well in leading this vanguard. Not because we are greater than Santiago or Calatrava—we are not—but because the nature of this mission suits our experience. Assessment. Careful judgment. Holding ground with limited resources. Knowing when to fight and when to preserve strength for another day. But I am not the only choice. And I am not so foolish as to think I see all factors Your Majesty must weigh.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Don Luis. Santiago is the greatest of our Orders. If you believe Santiago should lead this vanguard, I will not contest it. I will send Alcántara's fifty knights under your command, and I will support that command loyally. The mission matters more than who leads it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Luis is silent for a long moment. His expression is unreadable. Then, slowly, the corner of his mouth twitches. Not quite a smile—Don Luis does not smile easily—but something approaching respect.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: The Master of Alcántara plays this game better than I expected. He makes himself the obvious choice while appearing to defer. He addresses his own ambition openly, which makes it seem like honesty rather than grasping. And he offers to serve under me, knowing I cannot accept such an offer without appearing to have stolen command from a man who clearly deserves it. Well played, Don Juan. Well played indeed.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I learned politics from watching Santiago, Don Luis. You have been an excellent teacher, even if you did not intend to be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Something that might be a genuine smile flickers across Don Luis's face.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Apparently so.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: I thought we were discussing Constantinople. It seems we are also watching a masterwork of positioning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tension in the room has transformed. What could have been rivalry or resentment has become something closer to professional admiration. Sotomayor has made his case without alienating his peers—indeed, by being so transparent about his maneuvering, he has turned it into a shared joke rather than a threat.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asked for counsel. Here is mine: the Master of Alcántara has proposed a sound structure and has demonstrated exactly the kind of careful thinking this mission requires. I will not pretend I would not have welcomed command myself. But Don Juan has made his case well, and I believe he may be the right choice for this particular task.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: Calatrava concurs. If Your Majesty wishes to appoint the Master of Alcántara to lead the vanguard, he will have our support.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I understand that the orders together propose the force to Constantinople will be led by the master of Alcantara, as well as a force make-up as a mix of the three orders and fifty crown soldiers as well. I have already seventeen men in Constantinople right now. Another thirty would complement them nicely. I will be sending you on your way with 60,000 florins commander. Will you be able to repair the walls with these funds? And does this fit your goal of assessing if the city can be saved?

encounters.recap: Juan de Sotomayor masterfully navigates the political complexities of proposing himself as commander of the Constantinople vanguard. Through careful diplomatic maneuvering, he gains the support of both Santiago and Calatrava Masters while outlining a balanced force composition of 300 knights from all three Orders plus crown soldiers. Juan approves the plan and commits 60,000 florins to the mission.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tension in the room has transformed. What could have been rivalry or resentment has become something closer to professional admiration. Sotomayor has made his case without alienating his peers—indeed, by being so transparent about his maneuvering, he has turned it into a shared joke rather than a threat.

exchanges.speaker: luis_gonzalez_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asked for counsel. Here is mine: the Master of Alcántara has proposed a sound structure and has demonstrated exactly the kind of careful thinking this mission requires. I will not pretend I would not have welcomed command myself. But Don Juan has made his case well, and I believe he may be the right choice for this particular task.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: Calatrava concurs. If Your Majesty wishes to appoint the Master of Alcántara to lead the vanguard, he will have our support.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will be sending you on your way with 60.000 florins commander. Will you be able to repair the walls with these funds? And does this fit your goal of assessing if the city can be saved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sotomayor absorbs the appointment with a single nod—no effusive gratitude, no false modesty. He has argued for this command; now he must prove worthy of it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I will answer honestly: I do not know if sixty thousand florins can repair Constantinople's walls. I have never seen them. What I know of them comes from pilgrim tales and old chronicles. They say the Theodosian walls are the greatest fortifications in Christendom—triple walls, towers every fifty meters, a moat that can be flooded. They have stood for a thousand years.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: If those walls are intact and merely need garrison—sixty thousand florins is a fortune. We could supply defenders for years. But if the walls are crumbling, if centuries of neglect have left breaches and weak points... Then sixty thousand florins might patch one section while three others fall. I cannot promise what I do not know.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: With Your Majesty's permission, I would propose this: I will not spend the sixty thousand florins on walls until I have seen Constantinople myself. The money travels with us, secured. When I arrive, I meet with Your Majesty's men already there. I inspect the defenses. I speak with the Greeks—their engineers, their commanders, their Emperor if he will receive me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Then I determine: What does Constantinople actually need? Is it walls? Is it men? Is it food, weapons, ships? Perhaps the walls are stronger than we fear and the money is better spent on supplies for a siege. Perhaps one critical section needs immediate repair while the rest can hold. Perhaps the situation is already beyond what sixty thousand florins can remedy, and we must tell Your Majesty the hard truth.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will grant you a decree placing you in command of all forces in Constantinople, including those men already there. Use your initiative to see where the money can best be spent, but know that the Greeks themselves estimate that it will cost 55.000 florins for essential repairs of the walls and I have given them my word that I will gift them these funds to be used on their walls repair. Also, know that I will travel to the city myself in spring 1434, possibly with the other 700 knights.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I understand, Your Majesty. The funds are committed—a promise already given. I will honor that promise unless circumstances make it genuinely impossible to do so. May I ask what would constitute such an extreme situation in Your Majesty's view? If the walls are beyond repair entirely? If the Greeks have already fallen before we arrive?

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty intends to travel to Constantinople personally. In spring of 1434. With the remaining seven hundred knights. This changes the nature of my mission considerably. I am no longer merely assessing whether Constantinople can be saved. I am preparing the ground for my king's arrival.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I will need to send regular reports. Not merely a final assessment after ninety days, but ongoing communication—monthly at minimum, more frequently if circumstances warrant. Your Majesty must know what awaits before you sail, not after you arrive.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There is something you should all know about me by now. I do not fear God's calling. I do not fear travel, danger or a fight. If I die, my cousin, king of Aragon will inherit, uniting our kingdoms. If My queen births a son, then he is my heir. This is still a secret, but it is already agreed between myself and my cousin king Alfonso.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now, lets finalize our plan. You leave with 300 and the treasury to use on the walls. Only if the city has already fallen will this money not be used on the walls. Keep in communication while we prepare for the other 700 to come as well. When can you leave and how fast can we assemble the 300 men?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three Masters exchange glances at the revelation of the succession arrangement. Don Luis's eyes widen almost imperceptibly—this is significant political intelligence. Sotomayor simply nods, filing it away. But Juan has made clear the discussion of risk is closed. They are moving to logistics now.

exchanges.speaker: luis_gonzalez_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Santiago's knights are spread across eighty-three commanderies. If I send riders today with summons bearing the royal seal... three weeks to gather one hundred fifty quality men with horses and equipment. Perhaps four if we want them properly supplied.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: Calatrava is more concentrated. I can have one hundred knights assembled in two weeks. Perhaps eighteen days to be certain they have everything they need.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Alcántara is smallest and most compact. Fifty knights in two weeks. I will select men personally—those with experience in garrison command, assessment, the kind of careful judgment this mission requires.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The crown soldiers—a week. Perhaps less. We have capable men in Toledo who could depart within days if needed.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The constraint is Santiago—the largest contingent from the most dispersed Order. If Don Luis sends riders tomorrow, we could have all three hundred assembled by the first week of August. Assembly point should be a port. I would suggest Valencia or Cartagena—both have harbors capable of handling a force this size.

exchanges.speaker: luis_gonzalez_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Valencia. Better shipwrights, more Genoese and Venetian traders who know the eastern routes. We can contract passage there more easily than Cartagena.

exchanges.speaker: juan_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Ships for three hundred knights, horses, equipment, and sixty thousand florins in treasury. That requires planning. Has Your Majesty already arranged transport, or must we contract vessels? The treasury especially—we need secure vessels, trustworthy captains. Sixty thousand florins is a tempting prize for pirates or unscrupulous merchants.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will put the crown treasury at your disposal to find ships to travel to Constantinople. Use Cartagena to depart from. Send us a message early 1434 so we can leave in the spring with the rest. Unless the city is under immediate threat to fall, I will leave in spring 1434. Well, master Don Sotomayor. It is your operation now. Do you have everything you need in order to fulfill your purpose?

encounters.recap: Juan formally appoints Sotomayor as commander of the Constantinople expedition with backing from the other Military Orders. Sotomayor demonstrates exceptional strategic analysis, outlining assessment protocols and logistical requirements. Juan reveals his secret succession arrangement with Aragon and his plan to personally travel to Constantinople in 1434. The Masters coordinate assembly of 300 knights by August, with departure from Cartagena using crown treasury funds for transport.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He is thinking through every element now—the commander's mind fully engaged.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: If ships must be contracted, we should send word to Valencia immediately. Arranging transport for this force could take as long as assembling it. The treasury especially—we need secure vessels, trustworthy captains. Sixty thousand florins is a tempting prize for pirates or unscrupulous merchants.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will put the crown treasury at your disposal to find ships to travel to Constantinople. Use Cartagena to depart from. Send us a message early 1434 so we can leave in the spring with the rest. Unless the city is under immediate threat to fall, I will leave in spring 1434. Well, master Don Sotomayor. It is your operation now. Do you have everything you need in order to fulfill your purpose?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sotomayor rises from his chair. The movement is deliberate—a soldier accepting command.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has given me authority, funds, and clear purpose. That is more than most commanders receive. Three matters remain. First: the decree placing me in command of all Castilian forces in Constantinople, including the seventeen men already present. I will need this in writing, with the royal seal, before I depart. The men there do not know me. They must see Your Majesty's authority, not merely hear my claim to it. Second: communication. Messages from Constantinople to Castile will travel slowly—weeks at best, months if weather or war disrupts the routes. I propose establishing a relay through Venice or Genoa. Merchants travel those routes regularly. A letter entrusted to the right trading house can move faster than any courier we send alone. With Your Majesty's permission, I will arrange this and send word of which merchant houses to trust with return correspondence. Third: diplomatic authority. When I stand before the Greek Emperor, what may I promise on Your Majesty's behalf? I understand the sixty thousand florins and the three hundred knights are committed. But if Emperor John asks for more—more men, more gold, a formal alliance—what am I permitted to say? I do not wish to overpromise and shame Castile. Nor do I wish to seem cold and lose Greek confidence. Clear boundaries will help me navigate whatever I find there. Answer these three questions, and I will have everything I need. Alcántara will not fail you, Your Majesty. Nor will Santiago or Calatrava. We go as one force. Three crosses, one purpose.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Alvaro; draft the decree for Don Juan today. Good, set up this communication system. I have made promises and you can be clear to the emperor that I will keep my word. Your task is to help repair the walls and to help man it as well. I will travel to the city myself, so leave any further promises and diplomacy to me. You will be on your own for a while so I want you to act on your own initiative, you know what our position is. Now, if that is everything, we can move on to the other goal: morocco and the continuation of the reconquista. Taking and keeping the coastal cities are a difficult goal, but hopefully achievable. What are your thoughts?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sotomayor inclines his head. The atmosphere shifts as the topic changes. Constantinople is distant, abstract—a city none of them have seen, an enemy they know only by reputation. Morocco is different. Morocco is visible from Castilian shores. The Moors they would fight there are cousins to the Moors they have fought for centuries. This is familiar ground. Don Luis de Guzmán straightens in his chair, and there is a subtle change in his bearing. Constantinople was Sotomayor's moment. Morocco is Santiago's domain.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty raises the question that has occupied my thoughts since Granada fell. What now? The Reconquista is complete in Iberia. But across the strait, the Moor still holds cities that were once Christian. Ceuta. Tangier. The coast that faces our own shores. Santiago has studied this question for decades. My predecessors wrote memoranda on it. We have always known that finishing the work meant crossing the water. But crossing the water changes everything. In Granada, we fought with our backs to Castile. Supply lines measured in days. Reinforcement always possible. In Morocco... In Morocco, we fight with our backs to the sea. Every sack of grain, every replacement horse, every fresh soldier must come by ship. If the sea is closed to us—by weather, by enemy galleys, by simple misfortune—our garrisons starve.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: I have held sieges. I know what hunger does to men. A fortress can hold against assault for months. Against starvation? Weeks. Perhaps less.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: The Portuguese have learned this. They took Ceuta eighteen years ago—Your Majesty's father-in-law led that assault himself, when he was younger. They still hold it. But holding it has cost them dearly. Constant supply runs. Garrison rotations. The Moors pressing always, always, waiting for weakness. Taking a coastal city is not the difficulty, Your Majesty. With enough ships and enough men, we can take any port on that coast. Holding it—holding it for years, for decades, for centuries—that is the challenge. That is where the Orders become essential. What does Your Majesty envision? A single port, as the Portuguese hold Ceuta? Multiple cities along the coast? A true conquest, pushing inland toward Fez and Marrakesh?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can we take a coastal city, install a muslim as vassal in that city and establish outposts nearby to help them defend it against raids and attacks from the rest of morocco?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long silence follows Juan's question. The three Masters exchange glances—not the subtle political calculations of earlier, but genuine surprise. This is not what they expected.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: A Muslim vassal? Your Majesty would take a city and then... give it to a Moor?

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty proposes something... unconventional. Let me be certain I understand. We take a coastal city—Tangier, let us say, or Asilah. Rather than garrison it with Castilian troops and Christian settlers, we install a local ruler—a Muslim—who governs as Your Majesty's vassal. He administers the city, handles the population, maintains order. And we... We establish outposts nearby. Fortified positions. Not to rule, but to protect. To ensure that when the Sultan of Fez or some tribal confederation comes to punish this vassal for his submission to a Christian king, he finds Castilian steel between him and his target. It is clever. I will grant that. It addresses the core problem—administration and supply. A Muslim vassal rules Muslims. He knows the language, the customs, the politics. He can extract taxes, maintain order, negotiate with neighbors in ways no Castilian governor ever could. And our burden becomes purely military. Outposts. Patrols. Relief forces when needed.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: But the Orders exist to fight the Moor. To drive out the infidel. To plant the cross where the crescent stood. How do we explain to our knights that they are now... protecting a Muslim city? Guarding a Muslim lord?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: We protected Muslim lords during the Reconquista. Vassal taifas paid parias to Christian kings for generations. The Orders served kings who took that money. This is not so different. The goal is not to convert every soul in Morocco tomorrow. The goal is to establish Castilian power on that coast. If a Muslim vassal serves that purpose better than direct rule...

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: The strategy has merit. But it rests on a foundation that may be sand. Where do we find this vassal? A Muslim lord willing to submit to a Christian king makes himself a traitor to his faith, his people, his culture. The Sultan of Fez will declare him apostate. Other lords will compete to destroy him and claim the glory. His own people may murder him in his bed rather than live under a 'collaborator.' Your Majesty has seen this in Granada. Commander Martín converted and served faithfully—but he converted. He became Christian. His men followed him into baptism. A Muslim vassal who remains Muslim... He is neither one thing nor the other. Too Christian for Morocco. Too Muslim for Castile. Who is this man? Where do we find him? And why would he accept a position that makes him a target for everyone?

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: And even if we find such a man—can we trust him? What prevents him from accepting our aid, establishing himself, and then betraying us the moment he feels strong enough? We would have handed him a city and then watched him close the gates against us.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentioned informants already sent to Morocco. Commander Martín's mission. Is this why? To find such a man? To identify someone who might accept this arrangement?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The alternative is to appoint a Christian lord, but I fear that the populace will find it very hard to be ruled by him. Although...if the christian ruler is very well informed by muslim customs, maybe a converted moor? Maybe that would not be as bad. We can use the system the order of Santiago has used to settle lands and make them Christian. Either way, we must know very carefully what we are getting into.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Luis de Guzmán leans forward, and there is a new energy in his bearing. Juan has invoked Santiago's settlement system—the Order's proudest achievement beyond mere military victory.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Now Your Majesty speaks of something I know well. Santiago has settled more frontier land than any other Order. We did not merely conquer—we transformed. Muslim villages became Christian towns. Mosques became churches. But not overnight. Never overnight. The system works thus: when we take territory, we do not immediately expel every Muslim. That would be foolish—we would inherit empty fields, silent workshops, dead markets. Instead, we establish authority. Christian lords, Christian law, Christian churches. But the Muslim population remains, at first. They work. They pay taxes. They see that Christian rule is not the catastrophe their imams promised. Then, gradually, we settle Christians among them. Farmers from Castile and León, seeking land. Merchants looking for opportunity. Priests building parishes. Over years—sometimes decades—the balance shifts. Muslims convert, or emigrate, or simply... fade. Their children grow up surrounded by Christians. Their grandchildren attend Mass.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: I have seen this in Calatrava's territories. It is slow. But it works.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: It works because it is patient. And because the frontier was connected to Castile. Settlers could walk to their new homes. Priests could visit their bishops. If trouble arose, reinforcement was days away, not weeks. Morocco is different. Settlers cannot walk across the strait. Every Christian farmer, every merchant, every priest must come by ship. The numbers will be smaller. The process slower. The isolation greater. A converted Moor as governor... yes. This has merit. He knows the people, the customs, the language. He can administer in ways a Castilian knight never could. And if he is genuinely converted—not merely performing for advantage—he has reason to want Christian success. His salvation depends on it.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: Commander Martín. He is exactly this—a converted Moor of high rank, proven in battle, trusted by Your Majesty. Is he not already in Morocco on the intelligence mission?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And Fernando—the former qadi. A scholar who converted genuinely, examined by cardinals in Rome. He understands the theological dimensions. How to present Christian rule to Muslim populations without provoking immediate holy war.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: These are the men who could make such a system work. Converted Moors who believe in what they are doing, not merely opportunists seeking advantage. But they are few. Two men cannot govern a coast. We would need more—and finding Muslims of quality who will genuinely convert, not merely mouth words for profit, is... Rare. It happened at Granada because Your Majesty's victory was so total, so clearly divine judgment. That broke something in men like Commander Martín. They did not convert for advantage—they converted because their world had ended and they needed to understand why. Can we replicate that in Morocco? Without conquering the entire sultanate? I do not know. Perhaps Commander Martín's mission will tell us. Perhaps he will find men whose faith is already shaken, who are ready to hear a different truth.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_giron
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is right that we must know carefully what we are getting into. What do we know now? Commander Martín departed—when? April? We will not hear from him until autumn at earliest. Should we wait for his report before planning further? Or begin preparations now?

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: And what preparations? Ships? Knights? Settlers? The Order of Santiago can begin identifying families willing to emigrate—we have done this before. But we should not promise them land we have not yet taken, in cities we have not yet chosen.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we go on, we need to know why we are going into Morocco. Firstly, it's trade. We can channel trade from Africa into our markets. Also, taking the port cities prevents pirates from operating easily. Secondly, we can convert more to christianity and further drive back our ancient enemy, Islam.

encounters.recap: Juan finalizes Constantinople expedition command under Sotomayor, then discusses Morocco strategy with military Orders. They explore using converted Muslim vassals to govern conquered cities, with Santiago's settlement system as model for gradual Christianization while awaiting intelligence from Commander Martín's mission.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Rare. It happened at Granada because Your Majesty's victory was so total, so clearly divine judgment. That broke something in men like Commander Martín. They did not convert for advantage—they converted because their world had ended and they needed to understand why. Can we replicate that in Morocco? Without conquering the entire sultanate? I do not know. Perhaps Commander Martín's mission will tell us. Perhaps he will find men whose faith is already shaken, who are ready to hear a different truth.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is right that we must know carefully what we are getting into. What do we know now? Commander Martín departed—when? April? We will not hear from him until autumn at earliest. Should we wait for his report before planning further? Or begin preparations now?

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: And what preparations? Ships? Knights? Settlers? The Order of Santiago can begin identifying families willing to emigrate—we have done this before. But we should not promise them land we have not yet taken, in cities we have not yet chosen.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we go on, we need to know why we are going into Morocco. Firstly, it's trade. We can channel trade from Africa into our markets. Also, taking the port cities prevents pirates from operating easily. Secondly, we can convert more to christianity and further drive back our ancient enemy, Islam. Now, there is much we do not know yet. But I do know one thing: We cant just go in, take a port city and garisson it. That will fail. We need to know exactly how we are going to hold the city, what the population thinks, who to put in power. I think that for now, we just need to await the return of the informants and reconvene again when they have returned. Only then can we to really start to plan. Target what ports to take if any, know what role every order shall have. Do you agree?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three Masters nod almost in unison.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty shows wisdom that many kings lack—the patience to wait for knowledge before committing men to die. Trade and faith. These are sound reasons for Morocco. Not mere glory-seeking or restless ambition. The pirates of the Barbary coast have plagued our shipping for generations—Castilian merchants would pay handsomely to see those nests cleared. And extending Christendom... that is what the Orders exist to do.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: I have seen too many campaigns launched on assumption and hope. Íllora taught me what happens when we do not know what we face. Waiting for Commander Martín's report is not weakness. It is sense.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The timing may work well, Your Majesty. I depart for the East within weeks. Commander Martín's mission reports in autumn—October, November perhaps. By the time Your Majesty has digested that intelligence and reconvened this council, I will have sent my own reports from Constantinople. You will know whether the East demands more resources, or whether Castile's strength can be turned toward Morocco. If Constantinople is holding, if the walls are repaired and the Greeks can sustain themselves with the aid we provide—then perhaps Morocco becomes the priority for 1435. But if Constantinople is falling, if the Ottomans are massing for final assault... Then Your Majesty faces a different choice entirely.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Two fronts, thousands of miles apart. Castile is strong, but not infinite. We cannot save Constantinople and conquer Morocco simultaneously. Not without breaking ourselves. So yes, Your Majesty. We agree. Wait for intelligence. Reconvene when we know more. In the meantime, Santiago will begin quiet preparations. Identifying potential settlers. Reviewing our records on North African ports—we have archives, maps, reports from merchants and spies accumulated over decades. When the time comes to plan, we will not start from ignorance.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava will do the same. Our fortress-builders have experience that may translate to holding coastal fortifications. I will have them study what we know of Moroccan defenses—how they build, how they assault, what works against them.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Alcántara will be... otherwise occupied. But if I learn anything in Constantinople that bears on Morocco—Ottoman naval tactics, methods of holding distant outposts—I will include it in my reports.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The meeting has reached its natural conclusion. The Masters appear satisfied—genuinely so, not merely compliant. They have been heard, consulted, included in genuine strategic discussion. The transition from autonomous Orders to crown authority has been handled with respect for their expertise and their dignity. Don Luis rises, and the others follow.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. This has been... not what I expected when I rode to Toledo. I expected to be informed of decisions already made. Instead, I have been asked to counsel. To contribute. The Orders will serve the crown faithfully. You have my word—and I believe I speak for my brothers as well. Is there anything else Your Majesty requires of us before we depart to our duties?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan draws his sword and kisses the blade.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The pope has released his authority, granting us together the power to set out on a new path, a new destiny. There is power in this room when we together set our minds to a single purpose. Let this be the beginning of a new partnership between crown and the orders where we will fight for God's glory in new lands. Deus Vult!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Something shifts in the room. The steel whispers from its scabbard as Juan raises the blade, kisses it, speaks the words that have echoed across seven centuries of holy war. The invocation catches fire. All three Masters respond with immediate, full-throated conviction. Don Luis's carefully maintained dignity falls away—he is not the Master of Santiago calculating advantage but a knight of Christ answering the ancient call. Sotomayor's eyes shine. Don Pedro weeps again, unashamed. The 'DEUS VULT!' that fills the chamber could shake walls. This is not ceremony—this is covenant.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a patient, intelligence-based approach to Morocco expansion focused on trade and Christianity. The Masters initially skeptical but warm to his strategic wisdom. The meeting concludes with Juan invoking 'Deus Vult' in a transcendent moment that transforms the three Masters from cautious subordinates into fervent brothers-in-arms, cementing a new partnership between crown and military orders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The steel whispers from its scabbard. Juan raises the blade, kisses it, speaks the words that have echoed across seven centuries of holy war.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Deus Vult!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: For a heartbeat, silence. Then Don Pedro González de Padilla moves. Not hesitantly, not with the measured caution of a subordinate responding to his king. He draws his sword in a single fluid motion—the instinct of a man who has drawn that blade a thousand times—and his voice breaks as he answers.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: DEUS VULT!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tears stream down his weathered cheeks. He does not wipe them. He does not care. This is what Calatrava was made for. This is what he has yearned for since Granada fell and left him purposeless. A king who understands. A mission that matters. A reason to raise his sword again. Sotomayor is next. The youngest Master draws his blade and steps forward, his eyes shining with something that looks like wonder.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: DEUS VULT!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice cracks on the words—not from weakness, but from the weight of meaning they carry. And then Don Luis de Guzmán. The Master of Santiago has maintained his composure through everything. But something breaks in him now. Perhaps it is the sight of Don Pedro weeping without shame. Perhaps it is simply the accumulation of everything—the completed Reconquista, the king who returned the crusade treasury instead of keeping it, the genuine consultation where he expected mere command. Don Luis de Guzmán draws his sword. The blade rises. His arm does not tremble. But his voice—his careful, measured, political voice—breaks.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: DEUS VULT!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words tear out of him with a force that surprises even himself. Four swords rise together. Four voices thunder as one. The sound fills the chamber. It echoes off stone walls that have witnessed centuries of royal councils, but nothing quite like this. Not politics. Not negotiation. Covenant. Don Luis steps forward. He reaches out with his free hand and grasps Juan's sword-arm, just above the wrist. It is a gesture of brotherhood. Of equality. The kind of touch that passes between men who have bled together.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: I have served three kings. Your grandfather, who was weak. Your father, who was distracted. And you. I did not expect to find a king worthy of the Orders. I had stopped hoping for one. I came here today prepared to manage a transition, to preserve what could be preserved, to ensure Santiago survived the loss of its independence. I was wrong. You are not ending the Orders' purpose. You are restoring it. You are giving us back what we were supposed to be, before we forgot. For Santiago. For Calatrava. For Alcántara. For Castile.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: For Christ!

exchanges.speaker: alonso_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: For Constantinople!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And all of them together, one final time, swords still raised. The moment holds. Stretches. Becomes something that each man present will carry with him until he dies. Then, slowly, the swords lower. Don Pedro wipes his face with the back of his hand, looking slightly embarrassed but not apologetic. Álvaro de Luna, who has watched the entire scene from his seat, catches Juan's eye. The Constable's expression is unreadable to anyone who doesn't know him well. But Juan knows him well. Álvaro is impressed. More than that: Álvaro is moved. The three Masters stand before Juan—no longer reluctant subordinates accepting papal decree, but brothers-in-arms bound by something older and deeper than politics.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We know what to do. I will send for you again brothers when the informants have returned. Until then, walk with God.

roll.outcome: Transcendent moment. Complete transformation of the Masters from reluctant subordinates to devoted brothers-in-arms. Legendary brotherhood forged.

encounters.recap: In a transcendent ceremony, Juan draws his sword and declares 'Deus Vult!' The three Military Order Masters respond with overwhelming emotion, drawing their own swords. Don Pedro weeps openly, Sotomayor transforms from cautious junior to devoted commander, and Don Luis abandons political calculation for genuine brotherhood. The ceremony creates an unbreakable covenant between the crown and the Orders, with all Masters now willing servants rather than reluctant subordinates.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: More than that: Álvaro is moved. And Álvaro de Luna is not a man who moves easily. The three Masters stand before Juan—no longer reluctant subordinates accepting papal decree, but brothers-in-arms bound by something older and deeper than politics. The Military Orders belong to the crown now. But more importantly: they want to.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We know what to to. I will send for you again brothers when the informants have returned. Until then, walk with God.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three Masters bow—not the formal obeisance of subjects to sovereign, but the deeper acknowledgment of men who have recognized something true in one another.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Until then, Your Majesty. We will prepare. Santiago will be ready when you call.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_girón
exchanges.text: As will Calatrava.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I will send word from Valencia before we sail. And from Constantinople as soon as I am able to assess what we face. Thank you, Your Majesty. For the charter. For the command. For—for seeing what Alcántara could be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then they are gone. The sound of their boots echoes down the corridor, fading into the general murmur of the Alcázar. Álvaro de Luna rises slowly from his seat. He moves to the window, looking out over Toledo's rooftops, his hands clasped behind his back.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: That was well done. Better than well done. I have watched you negotiate with popes and emperors. I have seen you command armies and accept the surrender of sultans. But what you did in this room today... You took three proud men who came here afraid and resentful, and you sent them away as believers. The Orders will follow you now. Not because the Pope commands it. Not because they must. Because they want to. Your father never managed that. Your grandfather certainly didn't. You have accomplished something in a single morning that the crown has failed to achieve for a century. I will have Sotomayor's decree drafted within the hour. The charter guaranteeing Alcántara's independence by nightfall. Is there anything else Your Majesty requires before I attend to these matters?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When are the University delegates arriving?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Rectors of Salamanca and Valladolid were summoned alongside the Masters. They travel slower—scholars are not accustomed to hard riding, and they bring books and documents they consider essential. The Rector of Salamanca, Don Diego de Anaya, sent word that he would arrive by the seventh. Valladolid's Rector—Don Lope de Barrientos—perhaps a day or two later. Both should be in Toledo within the week. Sir Thomas Beaumont has been in Toledo throughout, working on the Military Academy curriculum. He can be summoned at Your Majesty's convenience. You mentioned to me before—questions about gunpowder, about why things work, about universities that study the nature of things rather than merely theology and law. This is an unusual direction for a king's attention. Most monarchs concern themselves with revenues and armies, not with why fire burns or stones fall. May I ask what Your Majesty envisions? It would help me prepare the Rectors for what you intend to discuss with them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Islam has not only retained knowledge, but has expanded on it as well. How cannons have transformed our military, this innovation could never happen here unless we explore, challenge and discover. If we want to defeat Islam, we must also look beyond our horizon. Go beyond Archimedes and discover new ways of arithmetics. Christian science and knowledge. We must move forward. And the universities will help us do this.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Moors preserved Aristotle when we had forgotten him. Their physicians surpass ours. Their mathematicians calculate what our scholars cannot. Their astronomers map the heavens with precision we lack. I have seen what their knowledge built in Granada. The Alhambra's engineering. The irrigation systems that made the Vega bloom. We conquered it—but we do not fully understand how it was made. Gunpowder came from the East. The cannon that broke Granada's walls—we did not invent it. We learned it. Adopted it. Improved it, perhaps. But the original discovery... Not ours. What Your Majesty proposes is not merely a university. Salamanca teaches law. Valladolid teaches theology. They preserve and transmit what is already known. They do not—discover. They do not ask 'why does gunpowder burn' and then seek the answer through experiment. This would be something new. A place where scholars are charged not with memorizing Aristotle but with surpassing him. Where asking dangerous questions is not heresy but duty. The Church may have concerns. Rome has not always welcomed those who look beyond accepted doctrine. Galileo's predecessors have faced... difficulties. I do not say this to dissuade Your Majesty. I say it so we may prepare for the obstacles. If we are to build a place of Christian discovery, we must do so carefully. Frame it correctly. Ensure Rome sees it as strengthening the faith, not threatening it. You have just returned from Basel with papal favor. You have the Pope's ear. If anyone can persuade Rome that Christian science serves God's glory... Perhaps it is the king who completed the Reconquista. What would you have me tell the Rectors? That Your Majesty wishes to discuss more than curriculum and funding? That you envision something beyond the traditional university?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You dont have to tell them anything. I will start with just listening as I always do and we will see what happens next. Thank you Alvaro, that is all for today. I go to Isabel and Catalina.

encounters.recap: Following the successful meeting with the Military Orders, Álvaro praises Juan's diplomatic mastery, noting that he transformed three reluctant subordinates into devoted allies—something previous kings never achieved. Juan reveals his vision for advancing Christian science and knowledge to compete with Islamic learning, discussing the need for universities that discover rather than merely preserve. Their relationship deepens as advisor and king discuss ambitious plans for educational reform before Juan departs to see his family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He finds them in the small garden courtyard adjacent to Isabel's chambers. The afternoon heat has softened, and someone has set up a canopy for shade. Isabel sits on a cushioned bench, her hand resting on her belly, watching. Catalina is engaged in serious business. She has discovered a beetle.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: The conquering hero returns. How were the Masters? Did they kneel? Did they weep? Did they swear eternal loyalty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It went well. We drew our swords and shouted 'Deus Vult!'. You know...the things knights do. What have you two been doing today?

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Oh, is that what knights do? Draw swords and shout Latin at each other? We have had a very demanding day. This morning, Catalina discovered that spoons can be dropped from her chair. Repeatedly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina shrieks with delight as she rises into the air, her small hands grabbing at nothing, at everything, at the sky itself. Then he brings her down to his lap, and she settles there with the satisfied air of a conqueror claiming her throne.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Bug. BUG. Pa! Up up up.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I am glad you are home. I am glad you will be here when this one arrives. I am glad for... all of it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I plan to travel to Constantinople in the spring 1434. I will be sailing with my flagship that I have had specially designed for you to travel on as well. I hope you are well enough to come with me. You know, when the time comes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel has gone very still beside Juan. For a long moment she says nothing. Her hand remains on her belly, and he can see her processing—the flicker of emotions crossing her face too quickly to catalog.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Constantinople. You want me to come with you. To Constantinople. Across the sea. To a city that may be besieged by the Turks. Are you truly asking me to come with you? Not leaving me behind to wait and wonder, but... You designed a ship for me?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. And we will be travelling with a large escort. It will be as safe as it can be. And the flagship 'Princess Catalina' has quarters for you and your ladies. You dont have to say anything for now, just think about it.

encounters.recap: In the garden courtyard, Juan proposes to Isabel that she accompany him on his planned voyage to Constantinople in spring 1434. He reveals he has designed a flagship called 'Princess Catalina' with special quarters for her and their children. Isabel is stunned by the proposal, torn between fear and hope at the prospect of traveling together rather than being left behind to wait and worry.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Juan. I have spent two years watching you ride away. Waiting. Praying. Imagining the worst. When you left for Granada, I thought I would die of the fear before you ever returned. Are you... are you truly asking me to come with you? Not leaving me behind to wait and wonder, but... You designed a ship for me?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. And we will be travelling with a large escort. It will be as safe as it can be. And the flagship Princess Catalina has quarters for you and your ladies. It is still going to be a sea journey that will take months, but at least we will be together. You dont have to say anything for now, just think about it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Isabel is quiet for a long moment. Her eyes have gone bright—not quite tears, but the shimmer of emotion held carefully in check. She watches Catalina, who has discarded the pebble and discovered a flower growing between the flagstones, now engaged in delicate negotiations with its petals.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: You named the ship after her. You designed quarters for me. For my ladies. You were in Rome. In Basel. Negotiating with popes and emperors. And you were thinking about... about how to bring me with you.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I have never— When I married you, I understood what it meant to be a queen. I would manage the household. Bear children. Wait. Pray. That is what queens do. What queens have always done. My mother waited for my father. Her mother waited for hers. No one has ever asked me to come.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns to face him, and now the tears do fall—silent, unashamed. She releases his hand only to bring both of hers to his face, cupping his cheeks, holding him there so she can look at him properly.

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: I will think about it. I will think about the children, the dangers, the journey. I will be practical and wise and consider everything carefully. But Juan—yes. Whatever thinking I do, however many fears I must wrestle with—the answer is yes. I would rather face the Turks at your side than face another year of waiting in Toledo, wondering if you are alive or dead. Ask me again when the baby is born. I will say yes then too.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She kisses him—soft, quick, fierce. The afternoon stretches long and golden. Isabel settles against him, her head finding the hollow of his shoulder, her body relaxing in a way it rarely does when others are watching. Catalina has abandoned the flower and discovered something even more fascinating: her own shadow. She stands in a patch of sunlight, waving her arms, watching the dark shape on the flagstones mimic her movements.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Me. Me?

exchanges.speaker: isabel_of_portugal
exchanges.text: She asked me yesterday if the moon was a ball. She wanted to know if she could catch it. I told her it was too far away. She said she would climb.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina grows bored with her shadow and returns to her parents, climbing onto the bench beside Isabel and leaning against her mother's other side. For a moment she is still—an unusual state for her—content simply to be held between them.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mama. Pa.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then, satisfied that both are accounted for, she closes her eyes. Isabel's hand finds Juan's across the curve of her belly. Their fingers intertwine. No words are needed. The sun continues its slow descent toward evening. The bees drone among the roses. A princess sleeps between her parents, dreaming whatever dreams seventeen-month-old children dream. And for this one afternoon, the world asks nothing of its king.

encounters.recap: Isabel emotionally accepts Juan's invitation to join the voyage to Constantinople. Overwhelmed by the fact that he considered bringing her instead of leaving her to wait, she declares her willingness to face danger at his side rather than endure another year of uncertainty in Toledo. The family shares a tender afternoon moment in the garden courtyard with young Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Rectors arrive on the ninth of July, within hours of each other—Don Diego de Anaya of Salamanca in the morning, Don Lope de Barrientos of Valladolid by mid-afternoon. They are a study in contrasts. Don Diego de Anaya is ancient—nearly eighty years old, a man who has outlived three kings and two popes. He moves slowly, supported by a carved walking stick, but his eyes remain sharp and his mind sharper. Don Lope de Barrientos is younger—perhaps fifty—and carries himself with the energy of a man still building his legacy. They eye each other with the careful courtesy of professional rivals.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan receives them without ceremony—no throne, no formal court. Just the study where he works, with chairs arranged to facilitate conversation rather than emphasize hierarchy. Álvaro sits nearby, ready to contribute but content to observe. Sir Thomas Beaumont has been summoned as well, standing near the window in his English soldier's practicality. The Rectors have settled into their seats, wine poured, courtesies exchanged.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: Your Majesty honors us with this summons. Salamanca stands ready to serve the crown, as it has for two centuries. Though I confess, I am curious. Kings summon soldiers and bishops, treasurers and diplomats. It is... unusual... to summon scholars.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: We received Your Majesty's letter but little explanation of its purpose. We have brought documents on our universities' finances, student enrollments, faculty appointments—whatever Your Majesty might wish to review.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First of all, welcome. I wanted us to meet personally because I understand how important education is for a realm. As you may know, I have started a new program for tax assessors and I require many educated nobles for these and future roles as well. I wanted to make sure you have everything you need to succeed. Secondly, I plan to expand the field of education we currently offer. But I value your input and would like to learn how you feel about the field of natural sciences, algebra, astrology and arithmetics. Finally, I would like to start a new University in Granada to take advantage of the knowledge already there. We have learned from Muslim scholars before and maybe we should do so again. We are getting ready to fight the Ottomans and if we are, we should meet them in every field. Right now, they are just more advanced than we are. I seek to amend this. So, now you know why you are here. And now is the time for me to listen to what you have to say.

roll.outcome: Thoughtful Reception — The Rectors respond with more enthusiasm than expected. Don Diego surprises by recounting Salamanca's own history of learning from translated Arabic texts. Don Lope suggests frameworks for theological oversight that could satisfy Church concerns.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with university rectors Don Diego de Anaya of Salamanca and Don Lope de Barrientos of Valladolid to propose educational reforms including expanding into natural sciences and establishing a new university in Granada that would learn from Muslim scholarship. The rectors respond more positively than expected, showing genuine interest in the ambitious vision.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A silence follows Juan's words—but it is not the uncomfortable silence of men searching for polite objections. It is the silence of scholars processing something unexpected.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: Your Majesty uses the word 'astrology.' I assume you mean astronomia—the study of celestial movements, their mathematics, their patterns. Not astrologia judiciaria—the casting of horoscopes and reading of fates, which the Church rightly condemns.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: When I was a young man—younger than Your Majesty is now—I studied the texts that came to us from Toledo's translation schools. Euclid. Ptolemy. Aristotle. All preserved by Islamic scholars when we had lost them. Salamanca was built on recovered knowledge.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: The theological concerns are real. Not because Islamic knowledge is inherently corrupt—Aquinas himself used Averroes and Avicenna—but because it must be received carefully. A university in Granada, learning from texts and scholars already present there... this could be framed as recovery. The reconquest of knowledge to match the reconquest of territory.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: Framing matters. A university that studies Islamic texts sounds dangerous. A university that recovers ancient knowledge from infidel occupation sounds heroic.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: If Granada produced men who understood these calculations—who could tell a commander exactly how much powder, at what angle, to breach a wall of specific thickness—that would be worth more than a hundred knights.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Forgive me my mistake. I of course mean astronomy. Can we both see what the Granada university still has in terms of knowledge, to see if it is of use for our Universities? And also restore the learning institution and focus on natural sciences. I want to stay away from theology in Granada, this is complicated. But if we focus on purely mathematics and natural science, I think it would work.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Avoiding theology entirely is wise. Very wise. Mathematics is numbers. Natural science is observation of God's creation. Neither requires doctrinal interpretation. Neither invites accusations of heresy.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: An assessment of what remains in Granada... yes. This should be done quickly, before more is lost. Your Majesty, do you know what survived? The madrasas, the libraries, the private collections of learned men?

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Then this is the first task. Send scholars to Granada—men who can read Arabic, who know what to look for. Let them assess what remains before we plan what to build.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: I have three who might serve. Old students of mine who learned Arabic to read Averroes in the original. If Your Majesty will provide safe passage and accommodation, I will send them within the month.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: I have spent my life preserving knowledge, Your Majesty. But preservation is not enough. You speak of going beyond Aristotle. Of discovery. Of creating knowledge rather than merely guarding it. I am too old to see this completed. But I am not too old to help it begin. What would Your Majesty have us do?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do you require a decree from me to search the Granada universities? Or anything else?

encounters.recap: Juan meets with university rectors Diego de Anaya (Salamanca) and Lope de Barrientos (Valladolid) to discuss educational reform. After initial correction about astronomy versus astrology, both rectors show surprising enthusiasm for creating a new university in Granada focused on natural sciences and mathematics while avoiding theology. They agree to send Arabic-reading scholars to assess surviving Islamic texts and knowledge in Granada, framing the initiative as intellectual reconquest rather than adoption of Muslim learning.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: And coordination with Salamanca and Valladolid, so we strengthen each other rather than compete. Granada trains mathematicians and natural philosophers. We train lawyers and theologians. The kingdom benefits from all. This could take years to build properly, Your Majesty. Perhaps decades. I will not live to see it completed. But I would very much like to help it begin.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: As would I. Valladolid will contribute what it can.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do you require a decree from me to search the Granada universities? Or anything else?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Diego and Don Lope exchange a glance—the practiced communication of men accustomed to navigating institutional requirements.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: A royal letter would smooth many paths, Your Majesty. Granada is newly conquered territory under military governance. Scholars wandering through madrasas and private houses, asking questions, examining documents... Without clear royal authority, the Governor might view us as complications. Or worse, as spies.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: A letter to Don García López de Padilla—he is still Governor, yes?—instructing him to provide our scholars with access, accommodation, and cooperation. Protection too, if needed. Granada is pacified but not yet peaceful. Resentments linger. We need three things. First, the letter of authority Your Majesty mentions. Second, funds for travel and lodging—modest, but necessary. My scholars are not wealthy men. Scholarship does not enrich.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Third, access to those who might know where knowledge is hidden. The converted scholars. The former qadi—Fernando. Even Muslim merchants or craftsmen who might know of private collections. Books are valuable. When a city falls, valuable things disappear. Some may have been hidden, waiting for safer times. Some may have been... acquired... by soldiers who recognized their worth without understanding their contents.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: A proclamation might help. Offering fair payment for texts brought forward, amnesty for those who took them during the conquest. Better to buy back what was looted than lose it forever.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: The army kept reasonable discipline, but no army is perfect. If manuscripts were taken as plunder, some soldiers may still have them—or may have sold them.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: A proclamation offering purchase rather than punishment would yield more than threats. Soldiers respond to coin.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: So. A letter of authority for the scholars. A letter to the Governor requiring cooperation. Funds for the expedition. And a proclamation offering to purchase recovered texts. If Your Majesty can provide these, we can begin within the month. One more thing, if Your Majesty permits. A name. Someone in Granada who can serve as guide and liaison. The former qadi Fernando would be ideal—he knows Islamic scholarly traditions, he knows what to look for, and his conversion is beyond question. Is he available?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Alvaro, draft both the proclamation and the royal letter for these scholars. And allocate funds from the treasury for this task as well. Next, draft an official decree founding the Granada university with the stated research goals. The pope will understand that we need to develop better if we are to fight the Ottomans. And we will of course respect any theological fields in the new University.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It will be done, Your Majesty. The proclamation and letter of authority can be ready by tomorrow morning. I will consult with Don Diego and Don Lope on precise language before finalizing—to ensure it serves their scholars' needs. Funds I can allocate from the household treasury immediately. A modest sum for travel and initial assessment. Larger allocations can follow once we know the scope of what remains in Granada. The founding decree for the university itself... this is a larger matter, Your Majesty. It will require careful drafting. The stated purposes must be precise—natural philosophy, mathematics, astronomy, practical sciences. Explicitly not theology, as Your Majesty wisely noted. I would welcome the learned doctors' review before it is finalized. Their knowledge of university charters far exceeds mine.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: Your Majesty moves swiftly. This is... not unwelcome, but perhaps we should discuss sequence. A founding decree is a permanent document. It establishes the institution in law. Once issued, it shapes everything that follows.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Might it be wiser to issue the decree after the assessment? Once we know what knowledge survives in Granada, we can craft the university's charter to match reality. If we find great riches in mathematics and astronomy, we emphasize those. If we find more in medicine or optics, we adjust accordingly. A delay of two months, perhaps three. The scholars travel to Granada, assess what remains, report their findings. Then Your Majesty issues the founding decree with full knowledge of what we are building upon.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of Rome. A founding decree issued before papal approval risks... complications. If Eugenius grants his charter, all is well. If he hesitates or demands changes, we would need to revise a decree already issued. Better to move in parallel—seek papal approval while conducting the assessment, then issue the founding decree when both are complete.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Perhaps, Your Majesty, a declaration of intent rather than a founding decree? A royal proclamation announcing that Castile will establish a university of natural sciences in Granada, with details to follow. This signals Your Majesty's commitment, begins the process with Rome, but preserves flexibility until the assessment is complete.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: This would serve. The scholars travel with clear purpose—they are not merely investigating, they are preparing the ground for a royal institution. The Pope receives word that Castile intends great things and is invited to participate. But the precise charter awaits full knowledge. And Fernando, Your Majesty? The former qadi? Would he be available to guide our scholars? His knowledge would be invaluable.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Fernando departed with Commander Martín's delegation to Morocco in April. He is not expected to return until October or November at the earliest.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: A loss. But not insurmountable. There must be other converted scholars in Granada who might serve.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: The Governor would know. Educated Muslims who converted during or after the conquest. Perhaps not of Fernando's caliber, but capable of identifying what our scholars should seek.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good. We assess first, then we draft a charter. I plan to visit Rome next spring, and I will take the university grant with me. I'm confident I can get papal support. But indeed, yes. First the assessment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Both Rectors visibly relax. The King has listened. The King has adjusted. This is not a common experience for scholars summoned before power.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: Your Majesty shows wisdom beyond your years. Assessment, then charter, then Rome. This is how scholars work. It is gratifying to find a king who understands the value of knowing before acting.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: Spring gives us time. My scholars can depart within the month, spend August through October in Granada, return with their findings by November. That allows the winter to draft the charter properly, with full knowledge of what we are building upon. If Salamanca's scholars work alongside Valladolid's, we can divide the labor. Some focus on mathematical texts. Others on natural philosophy. Others on practical sciences—engineering, optics, medicine.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: A joint expedition. Salamanca and Valladolid working together. That alone may be Your Majesty's greatest miracle. We have spent decades competing. Perhaps it is time we remembered we serve the same kingdom.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I will have the letters of authority and the proclamation regarding recovered texts ready for Your Majesty's seal tomorrow. Funds will be allocated by week's end. If the learned doctors will provide me with the names of their scholars and any specific requirements, I will ensure everything is prepared for their departure.

exchanges.speaker: lope_de_barrientos
exchanges.text: You will have the names within two days, Don Álvaro.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: As will you from Salamanca.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, if I may—the Military Academy would benefit greatly from whatever mathematical knowledge Granada yields. Gunnery, fortification, logistics... these are all mathematics in practice. Perhaps the Academy could send an observer with the scholars? Someone to identify texts of military application?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_anaya
exchanges.text: A soldier who values books. You are an unusual man, Sir Thomas.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: I am a man who has seen what cannons do to walls built by men who did not understand mathematics. I would prefer to be on the side that calculates correctly.
