exchanges.text: It shall be done, Your Majesty. I will begin working with the mare immediately—accustoming her to sudden movements, high voices, the unpredictability of small children. For the pony, I will send inquiries to the breeders in Córdoba and Jerez. What we want is a Castilian pony, twelve hands or less—sturdy, calm, forgiving of mistakes. They are not rare, but a good one, one worthy of a princess... That takes time to find. I will have candidates for Your Majesty's inspection by spring, well before the princess turns three.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: If I may speak plainly, Your Majesty? The princess has a gift. Some children freeze on horseback—their bodies fight the animal's movement. Others relax too much and flop about like sacks of grain. But she... She listens to the horse. Feels him. It cannot be taught, only encouraged. Her mother was the same way, Your Majesty. Queen Isabel rode like she was born to it. God rest her soul.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Catalina. This is Pedro. He looks after the horses. When you are older, you will have a horse of your own to ride on. Would you like that?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina studies Pedro Carrillo with the intense scrutiny she reserves for new people—taking in his grey beard, his weathered hands, the smell of horses and leather that clings to him. After a moment, she apparently finds him acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Hello Pedro. A horse? My own horse? Like Hidalgo? But Hidalgo is very big, Papá. I am small. How will I get up?

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: Not a horse like Hidalgo, Your Highness. A pony. A small horse, just the right size for a princess. She will grow as you grow, and when you are bigger, you will have a bigger horse. But first— A little one. Just for you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: What is her name? What color is she? Can I see her now?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! No not yet Catalina. It will be many many more nights before you will have your horse. You can ride with papa on Hidalgo or with Lucia on her horse until then.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But Papá... I want to see her now. Lucia's horse? The black one? Tormenta? Can I ride with Lucia today? Where is she? Can we go find her? I will be very good, Papá. I will hold on tight. I won't pull Tormenta's hair. Maybe just a little pull. To say hello.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We can go and have a ride, sure. Why don't you go to Lucia and ask her if you can ride with her on her horse? I think she is inside in her chambers.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I will ask her. I will say please.

encounters.recap: Juan takes Catalina for her regular horsemanship training with Hidalgo. He consults stable master Pedro Carrillo about appropriate ages for children to learn riding. Pedro recommends starting with a pony at age three and offers to prepare a gentle mare for Catalina. Catalina shows natural talent and enthusiasm for riding, and eagerly anticipates riding with Lucia on her horse Tormenta.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Can I ride with Lucia today? Where is she? Can we go find her?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I will be very good, Papá. I will hold on tight. I won't pull Tormenta's hair. Maybe just a little pull. To say hello.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We can go and have a ride, sure. Why don't you go to Lucia and ask her if you can ride with her on her horse? I think she is inside in her chambers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina's face transforms with delight. You set her down, and she stands for a moment, vibrating with barely contained energy—a small princess with a mission.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I will ask her. I will say please.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns and toddles toward the Alcázar with surprising determination, her small legs pumping. Then she stops abruptly and looks back at you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá? Where is Lucia's chambers?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She has been there before, of course, but the geography of the Alcázar is vast and confusing for a nineteen-month-old whose previous navigation has always involved being carried. A groom nearby suppresses a smile. Pedro Carrillo develops a sudden cough that sounds suspiciously like laughter. Catalina stands in the courtyard, halfway between you and the fortress, her face scrunched with the realization that her grand independent mission has encountered an immediate logistical obstacle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Maybe maybe Papá can show me. Just this time. And then I will remember.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think it is this way...what door shall we explore now Catalina? You can point me in the direction and we will go there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina takes to this new game with enthusiasm, her earlier impatience transformed into the thrill of exploration. She peers down the corridors from her vantage point in your arms, her small face screwed up in concentration.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You oblige, walking toward it. A servant passing by flattens himself against the wall, bowing deeply and looking faintly alarmed at the sight of the King of Castile taking navigational directions from a toddler. The door leads to a storage room. Catalina peers inside at stacked linens and folded tapestries.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No. Not this one. That one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You try another door—a small chapel, empty and quiet. Catalina shakes her head.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia is not praying. She is... she is doing lady things.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The third door opens onto a servant's staircase. Catalina frowns at the narrow steps disappearing upward.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Too small. Lucia is tall.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A guard at the end of the corridor watches this procession with a carefully blank expression, though his mustache twitches suspiciously. Finally, after two more incorrect guesses—a disused antechamber and what appears to be someone's private office—Catalina spots a door flanked by two men in Ferrarese livery.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: There! The men with the funny clothes! That's Lucia's door!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Ferrarese guards exchange glances, uncertain whether 'funny clothes' constitutes an insult requiring response. They settle for bowing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina lands on her feet and straightens her dress with a gesture she has clearly observed from adult women—a small, unconscious imitation that tugs at something in your chest. She looks up at the Ferrarese guards. They are tall, armored, utterly foreign to her experience. For a moment she hesitates, her natural boldness warring with the sheer bigness of these strangers blocking her path. Then she draws herself up to her full height—which brings her roughly to their knees—and announces with tremendous dignity:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I am Princess Catalina. I am here to see Lucia. Please.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One guard—younger, with a kind face beneath his helmet—smothers a smile and bows deeply to her. He cracks the door open and murmurs something in Italian. There is a flutter of female voices within, and then Lucia's voice cuts through, sharp with curiosity:

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Catalina? By herself?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The door swings wide. Lucia stands in the entrance, dressed simply for an afternoon indoors, her dark hair loose around her shoulders. Behind her, the Italian ladies peer out with expressions of delighted surprise.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Princess Catalina. To what do I owe this honor?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina clasps her hands in front of her, takes a deep breath, and delivers her petition:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia. Will you please come riding with me? On Tormenta? I will hold on very tight and I will not pull her hair. Maybe only a little pull. To say hello. Papá said I could ask you.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well...It seems the princess has delivered a petition. O how shall the lady respond?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: A royal petition! Delivered in person by the Princess of Asturias herself! I see the King of Castile has sent his most formidable ambassador.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She drops to one knee, bringing herself to Catalina's level—a gesture that makes the Italian ladies behind her exchange knowing glances.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Your Highness, I am deeply honored by your invitation. However, I must ask certain questions before I can render my decision. This is how diplomacy works, you understand. First: Will there be fast riding, or slow riding? Tormenta prefers to go fast, but I am told princesses must be careful.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Slow. Maybe... a little fast? Just once?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Second: If Tormenta's mane is very soft and beautiful, am I to understand that you will only pull it gently, to say hello, and not yank it like a bell-rope?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Gentle. Very gentle. Like... like petting a gato.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: A cat. Acceptable. And third, most important: After our ride, will the princess share a crostata with me? Diplomacy requires the sharing of sweets. It is an ancient tradition.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Yes! I will share! I promise!

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Then the lady accepts the petition. Let me change into my riding clothes, and we shall away to the stables. With your permission, Your Majesty? I believe I have been summoned by a higher authority.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And should the princess change into riding clothes as well? I think she should. Come, lets get changed.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But Papá, this dress is fine. It is not even very dirty.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: Perhaps the princess might consider that Tormenta is a very elegant horse. And elegant horses prefer riders who wear their riding clothes. It is a matter of respect.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You are not wearing riding clothes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_ferrarese
exchanges.text: No. Which is why I must also change. We shall both change into our riding clothes, and then we shall both be elegant enough for Tormenta. Do you see? It is only fair.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Oh. Oh. Yes. We will both change. Because of Tormenta. Come, Papá. We must be quick. Lucia is waiting.

encounters.recap: Princess Catalina embarks on an independent mission to find Lucia and invite her riding. After navigating the Alcázar corridors with Juan's help, she formally presents her petition to Lucia, who accepts with diplomatic ceremony. The encounter showcases Catalina's growing independence and the warm relationship developing between her and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The nursery transformation is swift—Doña Beatriz, summoned by a servant, produces a smaller, sturdier dress of brown wool that she calls Catalina's "adventure dress." Catalina submits to the change with unusual patience, motivated entirely by the promise of riding with Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Quickly, Doña Beatriz. Tormenta is waiting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the time you reach the stables, Lucia is already there, transformed back into her green riding habit. Tormenta stamps and tosses her head, sensing activity, her black coat gleaming in the afternoon light. You lift Catalina up first. She is lighter than a sack of grain, and you settle her onto the saddle in front of where Lucia will sit.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hold tight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I know, Papá.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia mounts behind her with practiced grace, her arms coming around Catalina to take the reins, creating the same protective cage you form when riding with her on Hidalgo. Catalina leans back against Lucia's chest, looking up at her with absolute trust.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I am ready.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Where shall we ride, Your Majesty? The princess and I await your command.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You lead the small procession through Toledo's winding streets, Hidalgo's hooves ringing on the cobblestones. Citizens bow and step aside as you pass—their king, the Italian lady who will soon be queen, and the small princess perched before her like a figurehead on a ship's prow.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Look, Lucia, a dog! And that man has bread! So much bread! Why does he have so much bread?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Once through the gates and across the bridge, the road opens before you. The November afternoon is crisp and clear, the olive groves giving way to open fields where farmers have finished the autumn harvest. You turn Hidalgo off the main road onto a cart track that runs between fallow fields. The ground here is firm and level—good footing for horses, safe enough for a faster pace.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ready?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Fast now, Papá? Can we go fast?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Ready.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hidalgo surges forward, his powerful stride eating up the ground. You hold him to a collected canter—faster than the sedate walk of the city streets, slow enough for control. Beside you, Lucia gives Tormenta her head. The black mare leaps forward eagerly, matching Hidalgo's pace with evident joy. And between Lucia's arms, Catalina shrieks. Not with fear—with pure, unbridled delight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: FAST! We're going FAST, Papá!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She's a natural! Feel how she moves with the horse!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: More! Faster, Lucia! Faster!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You look across at Lucia. Her arms are locked firmly around Catalina, the child pressed securely against her chest. Lucia meets your gaze and gives a single sharp nod—she's safe, I have her. You lean forward in the saddle and touch your spurs to Hidalgo's flanks. The destrier explodes beneath you. Behind you, Lucia gives Tormenta her head. The black mare surges forward, her competitive spirit ignited by Hidalgo's challenge.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: PAPÁÁÁÁÁ!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tormenta pulls alongside Hidalgo, and for a moment you ride neck and neck, grey and black, king and future queen, with a nineteen-month-old princess laughing between you like the world has never contained anything so wonderful as this single moment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How was that Catalina? Did you go fast?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: So fast. So fast, Papá. We were... we were like birds.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia. Tormenta is the best horse.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Better than Hidalgo?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: They are both best. Hidalgo is best for Papá. Tormenta is best for me and Lucia. Can we do it again?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Without waiting for an answer, you give Hidalgo the spurs and sprint back the way you came. You hear Catalina's outraged shriek behind you—"PAPÁ! WAIT!"—and then the thunder of Tormenta's hooves as Lucia gives chase.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: FASTER, Tormenta! We have to catch Papá! FASTER!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: We're CATCHING you!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The King of Castile, fleeing before a toddler and an Italian! What would the chronicles say?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rein Hidalgo in, letting the grey destrier slow to a canter, then a trot, then a walk. Tormenta thunders past you, and Lucia has to circle the black mare twice before bringing her to a stop.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: We won! We won, Papá! Tormenta is the FASTEST!

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So it would seem.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You let us win.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I wanted to be careful with Catalina. This is her first fast ride. Besides...I would gladly lose against you Lucia. How is she doing?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is remarkable, Juan. Most children her age would be terrified. Or at least crying for their nurse by now. But she wanted more. When you sprinted ahead, she did not scream with fear. She urged Tormenta to chase you. She competed. Her seat is natural. She moves with the horse without being taught. And her courage... That is not something that can be trained into a child. That comes from somewhere deeper.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia, is Tormenta tired? She is breathing very loud.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is tired, little one. We ran very fast. She needs to rest.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good girl, Tormenta. You are very brave. You can rest now.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She will not remember Isabel. Not truly. She is too young. But Isabel is in her, Juan. I can see it. The warmth. The fearlessness. The way she loves without reservation.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me about your mother Lucia. Have you inherited your mother's beauty?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: My mother was considered the beauty of Ferrara in her youth. Dark hair, like mine. Grey eyes—though hers were softer, I think. Less sharp. She had a way of looking at people that made them feel seen. Valued.

encounters.recap: Juan takes Catalina and Lucia on a riding expedition to the countryside outside Toledo. Catalina shows remarkable courage and natural horsemanship during her first fast ride, delighting in the speed and competition. The outing strengthens the bond between Lucia and Catalina, with Lucia noting how the child has inherited Isabel's fearlessness and capacity for love. The event ends with intimate conversation about family and heritage.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Royal War Academy has taken residence in a former monastery on Toledo's eastern slope, its cloisters converted to training yards, its cells to barracks, its refectory to a great hall where officers gather for instruction. The monks were relocated—generously compensated—and the building now rings with the clash of steel rather than the chanting of psalms. You arrive without fanfare, accompanied only by two guards. Sir Thomas Beaumont meets you at the gate, his weathered English face creasing with surprise and pleasure.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I did not expect— You honor us.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I wished to observe. Show me what you have built.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sir Thomas leads you through the grounds, explaining as you walk. The academy currently houses forty-seven students—young men drawn from noble families across Castile, Aragon, and even a handful from Portugal. They range from seventeen to twenty-five years of age, some already blooded in the Granada campaign, others fresh from their fathers' estates with nothing but ambition and family names.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: We teach them in three streams. Horsemanship and cavalry tactics. Infantry command and siege craft. And the new arts. Gunpowder. Artillery. The weapons that will define the wars to come.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You watch the drill in silence. The students move with varying degrees of competence—some crisp and confident, others still fumbling through the formations.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How do they fare?

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: The Castilians are proud. Sometimes too proud to learn. The Aragonese are clever but clannish—they stick together and resist mixing with the others. The Portuguese... There are only three, but they work hard. The greatest challenge, Your Majesty, is teaching them to think. Any fool can swing a sword. But reading a battlefield, anticipating an enemy's movements, knowing when to press and when to withdraw—that requires a different kind of training.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will soon be departing with 700 additional soldiers to Constantinople, preferably led by cadets of the academy. They will be facing the Ottomans. You think some are ready to be put to the test?

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: The Ottomans. Your Majesty, I have never faced them myself, but I have spoken with men who have. Hungarians. Venetians. Knights of Rhodes who passed through England in my youth. They are not like the Moors of Granada. The Granadan army was brave, but fractured—tribal loyalties, factional disputes, commanders who would not coordinate. The Ottomans... They are professional. Disciplined. Their janissaries train from childhood. Their cavalry can feign retreat and draw you into ambush with terrifying precision. Their commanders study war as scholars study scripture.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: To answer your question, Your Majesty: yes, some of my cadets are ready to fight. Perhaps a dozen have the skill and temperament to lead men in battle. But ready to face the Ottomans? That is a harder question. See the tall one there, with the red sash? Don Álvaro de Zúñiga's second son. Excellent horseman, quick mind, men follow him naturally. He commanded a company at Málaga—acquitted himself well. He could lead a hundred lances and not disgrace himself. The stocky one beside him—Rodrigo Manrique. Slower to learn, but steady. He does not panic. In a siege, holding a wall, you want men like him. I could give you eight, perhaps ten, who are ready for real command. Another fifteen who could serve as junior officers under experienced captains. But Your Majesty... Constantinople is not a training ground. If you send boys to learn war against the Ottomans, many of them will learn only how to die.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me put it differently Thomas. I am sending 700 knights from the orders to Constantinople next spring. How best can the war academy be involved?

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: Ah. That is a different matter entirely. The Military Order knights are experienced soldiers—they know how to fight, how to hold discipline, how to follow commands. What they lack is knowledge of Ottoman warfare specifically. Their experience is against the Moors, who fight differently. First: I could assign my best cadets as observers, not commanders. Attach them to the Order captains, let them watch, learn, record. They study Ottoman tactics firsthand and bring that knowledge back to the academy. We build a library of experience for future campaigns. Second: Before the expedition departs, I could conduct intensive instruction for the Order officers themselves—a week, perhaps two, on what we know of Ottoman methods. The feigned retreats. The horse archery. The janissary formations. János Hunyadi's letters have been... invaluable. The man knows his enemy. I have been translating his observations into training exercises. Third: When the expedition returns—God willing, when, not if—we debrief every officer extensively. What worked. What failed. What surprised them. That knowledge becomes the foundation for training the next generation. The academy should not try to lead this expedition, Your Majesty. The Order masters would rightly resent boys commanding veterans. But we can learn from it. We can prepare those who go. And we can ensure that the blood spent in Constantinople purchases wisdom for Castile. There is one more thing. If Your Majesty permits.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: When I trained knights in England, and later when I served with the French, I saw the same pattern repeat itself. Experienced soldiers return from campaign, and their knowledge... scatters. They go back to their estates, their garrisons, their families. What they learned dies with them, or survives only in tavern stories. The Ottomans do not make this mistake. Their janissaries train together, fight together, teach together. Knowledge passes from veteran to recruit in an unbroken chain. It is one of the reasons they are so formidable. When your seven hundred return from Constantinople, I would ask Your Majesty's permission to keep some of them. Not permanently—perhaps six months, a year. The best of them, the ones who learned the most. Let them teach at the academy. Let them drill the cadets in what they saw, what they faced, what they survived. Knights do not like to teach. They think it beneath them. But if it came as a royal command—a mark of honor, to be selected as an instructor at the King's own academy... Pride can be redirected, if you know how to push it. In five years, Your Majesty, I could give you officers who have never seen an Ottoman but know how to fight them. In ten years, I could give you an army that does not need to learn on the battlefield—because the lessons have already been paid for in other men's blood.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good idea. I will send for the orders to assemble their command at Toledo well before departure so their commanders may be involved with the academy before departure. We will attach the cadets as observers. And I will seek to reform the orders to adopt a system to preserve knowledge. I return to Alvaro and tell him to write to the orders. Include an invitation for the order masters to come to me and to start preparing the 700 soldiers in anticipation of our decision to send them to Constantinople, but make clear that we still have to decide this together. There has been intelligence from Morocco and Constantinople so we can now develop our strategy together.

encounters.recap: Juan inspects the War Academy and discusses the planned Constantinople expedition with Sir Thomas Beaumont. They develop a strategy to involve academy cadets as observers rather than commanders, conduct pre-departure training for Order knights on Ottoman tactics, and establish a system for preserving battlefield knowledge through veteran instructors at the academy.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good idea. I will send for the orders to assemble their command at Toledo well before departure so their commanders may be involved with the academy before departure. We will attach the cadets as observers. And I will seek to reform the orders to adopt a system to preserve knowledge. I return to Alvaro and tell him to write to the orders. Include an invitation for the order masters to come to me and to start preparing the 700 soldiers in anticipation of our decision to send them to Constantinople, but make clear that we still have to decide this together. There has been intelligence from Morocco and Constantinople so we can now develop our strategy together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro receives your instructions in his study, making careful notes as you speak. The afternoon light slants through the windows, illuminating the ever-present stacks of correspondence on his desk.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It shall be done, Your Majesty. I will write to Don Luis de Guzmán of Santiago, Don Pedro González de Padilla of Calatrava, and Don Juan de Sotomayor of Alcántara. The letters will go out today.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: To summarize: an invitation to Toledo, framed as consultation rather than command. We inform them that intelligence has arrived from Morocco and Constantinople—though we do not detail the contents in writing. We request they begin preparing their knights for potential deployment, while emphasizing that the final decision will be made jointly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He taps the quill against the paper thoughtfully.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The timing is fortunate, Your Majesty. With your wedding on December 3rd, the Masters may arrive for the ceremony and remain for the strategic discussions afterward. It gives them reason to come without appearing to be summoned like servants.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Shall I mention Sir Thomas's proposal regarding the academy—the intensive instruction before departure, the attachment of cadets as observers? Or do you wish to present that yourself when they arrive?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets down the quill and folds his hands.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Also, Your Majesty should know: a letter arrived this morning from Fray Hernando. He requests an audience at your convenience. He did not specify the subject, but... He mentioned it concerned a spiritual matter he wished to discuss before the wedding.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Leave out Thomas for now, we will discuss in time with them. I will go to Hernando myself now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro nods, making a final note.

encounters.recap: Juan instructs Álvaro to write to the military order masters, inviting them to Toledo for strategic discussions about the potential Constantinople deployment. The letters will frame this as consultation rather than command, mentioning new intelligence from Morocco and Constantinople. Álvaro suggests timing the meeting around Juan's wedding on December 3rd, and mentions that Fray Hernando has requested an audience about a spiritual matter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Fray Hernando in the small chapel adjacent to the royal apartments—the same chapel where you have confessed to him countless times over the years, where he has guided you through crises of faith and conscience, where he refused you absolution in Basel when your soul needed correction more than comfort. He kneels before the altar, his Franciscan robes pooling on the cold stone floor. The chapel is dim, lit only by candles and the fading afternoon light filtering through narrow windows. The air smells of incense and beeswax.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, thank you for coming. I wished to speak with you before the wedding. Not as your confessor—unless you wish to confess—but as... As a friend, perhaps. If a friar may presume to call a king his friend. I have been watching you with the Lady Lucia. With Catalina. With the court. I have observations. And I have concerns. Will you hear them?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course friend, let us sit together. I have always valued your company and yes, you are my friend. What is on your mind?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will speak plainly, as I always have with you. And I ask that you hear me fully before you respond. When I first became your confessor, you were a young man trapped in your own palace—a king in name only, surrounded by those who used you for their own ends. I watched you break free of that cage through courage, cunning, and genuine faith. You have grown into a remarkable king, Juan. Perhaps a great one. But I must ask you something, and I ask it as a friend who has walked with you through darkness and light. It has been mere days since you met this woman. Days. And already you speak of her as though she were your partner in all things. So I ask you, not as your confessor but as your friend: Do you love this woman? Or do you love what she represents?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Isabel's shadow hangs over me still fray. And I have addressed this immediately with Lucia as well. I arranged to re-marry soon for two reasons. First; succession. I need another son and so does the realm. And secondly, Catalina has taken the loss of her mama very well, but I wanted to give her someone who could love her like a mother soon. Right after Isabel's death, I was so very angry Fray. Angry at God as well. Going on rides with Catalina and Lucia not replaces Isabel, but we are making new memories and gives us a space to be happy. Catalina needs taking care of, needs to be educated and needs to explore the world. I have found that when I just focus on that task, everything falls into place naturally.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I remember your anger. After Isabel died. You raged at God in this very chapel. I stood outside the door and listened, and I did not intervene. Because it was honest. That is when I knew your faith was real, Juan. And now I see something different. Not anger. Not performance. But healing. Quiet healing. You speak of focusing on Catalina, on the task before you, and letting everything else fall into place. This is wisdom, Juan. Have you spoken to Lucia about Isabel? Truly spoken—not merely acknowledged that she existed, but shared who she was?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No, not really. She has expressed that Isabel must have been an incredible woman. She was. I found it difficult Fray to make Lucia feel welcome and not compare her to my late wife. She is her own person, very different from Isabel. Comparing her with or talking a lot about Isabel felt unfair to her. But you are right. Maybe the time is ripe for us to have this conversation now.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You show wisdom in this, Juan. And kindness—to recognize that Lucia deserves to be seen for herself, not measured against a ghost. But consider this: by not speaking of Isabel, you may inadvertently make her shadow loom larger, not smaller. If you do not fill those spaces with truth, Lucia will fill them with imagination. Isabel would want this, Juan. She loved you enough to want you happy. And happiness, true happiness, requires wholeness—not the careful partitioning of your heart into rooms that your new wife may not enter.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will Fray, thank you. Shall we pray together? The Constantinople campaign is on my mind a lot. Help me face this challenge with the same honesty and humility that has brought me success in the past.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises from the bench and moves to kneel before the altar. You join him, the cold stone pressing through the fabric of your clothing, the familiar discomfort of supplication. The candles flicker, casting dancing shadows across the simple wooden cross that hangs above.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Heavenly Father, we come before You as we are—not as kings or priests, but as men. Flawed, uncertain, reaching toward Your light through the darkness of our own limitations. Your servant Juan faces a task that stretches beyond the borders of his realm, beyond the familiar fields of his victories. Constantinople calls—an ancient city, a wounded church, a people crying out for deliverance. Grant him wisdom to know when to act and when to wait. Grant him humility to listen to counsel, even when it contradicts his own vision. Grant him courage to face what must be faced, and grace to accept what cannot be changed. And Lord, guard his heart against the seductions of glory. Let him remember always that he is Your instrument, not Your equal. Juan. Speak to Him. In your own words. He is listening.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando counsels Juan before his wedding to Lucia, expressing concerns about the speed of their courtship while affirming Juan's spiritual growth. They discuss Juan's grief over Isabel and the importance of sharing memories with his new bride. The session concludes with prayer for the upcoming Constantinople campaign, focusing on humility and divine guidance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great cathedral is transformed. Thousands of candles blaze from every surface, their light catching the gold leaf of the altarpiece, the jeweled vestments of the clergy, the silks and velvets of the assembled nobility. The air is thick with incense and the scent of winter flowers—roses brought at tremendous expense from somewhere that still grows them, white lilies, branches of evergreen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The doors open. Lucia enters on the arm of Don Íñigo, who once again has been granted the honor of escorting her. She wears a gown of white silk embroidered with silver stars, the colors of the Virgin, of purity, of Ferrara's night sky. A veil of delicate lace covers her dark hair, held in place by a circlet of pearls. She carries no flowers—only the sapphire ring on her finger, catching the candlelight with each step.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Dearly beloved, we are gathered in the sight of God and this congregation to join this man and this woman in holy matrimony...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I, Juan, take thee, Lucia, to be my wedded wife. To have and to hold, from this day forward, for better for worse, for richer for poorer, in sickness and in health, to love and to cherish, till death us do part, according to God's holy ordinance; and thereto I plight thee my troth.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I, Lucia, take thee, Juan, to be my wedded husband. To have and to hold, from this day forward, for better for worse, for richer for poorer, in sickness and in health, to love, cherish, and obey, till death us do part, according to God's holy ordinance; and thereto I give thee my troth.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Those whom God hath joined together, let no man put asunder. I pronounce that they be man and wife together, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost. Amen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral erupts. 'VIVAT REX JUAN! VIVAT REGINA LUCIA!' And then Lucia is in your arms, her veil pushed back, her lips meeting yours as the bells of Toledo ring out across the city, across the kingdom, carrying the news to every corner of Castile: The King has taken a Queen.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá, Lucia is pretty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, she is.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: She is ours now?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, little one. She is ours now.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good. I like her.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Grace. The hour grows late. The bridal chamber has been prepared.

encounters.recap: King Juan II marries Lucia of Ferrara in Toledo's cathedral before the assembled nobility of Castile. After exchanging vows blessed by Archbishop Alonso, they celebrate with a great feast where young Catalina expresses her approval of her new stepmother. The royal couple then retires to consummate their marriage.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bridal chamber glows with candlelight, the great bed draped in silks, rose petals scattered across the floor. Someone has left wine and sweetmeats on a small table, though neither of you reaches for them. Lucia stands before you, her veil already removed, her dark hair loose around her shoulders. The sharp wit, the political calculation, the careful armor she has worn since arriving in Castile—all of it falls away as the door closes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Husband

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Wife

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: What follows is private—a sacrament between two souls now joined before God, a conversation without words, a knowing and being known that belongs to the marriage bed alone. Afterward. The candles have burned low. Through the window, the first grey light of dawn touches the sky over Toledo. The celebrations in the city have finally quieted, the revelers gone home or collapsed where they fell. Lucia lies beside you, her head resting on your chest, her fingers tracing idle patterns on your skin.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I was afraid. Not of you. Of... this. Of being known so completely. In Ferrara, I learned to hide everything. To show only what I wished to be seen. I do not wish to hide from you, Juan. Not anymore. Tell me something. Something true. Something you have never told anyone.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have never known my parents. I know them from the stories. Stories about them and other kings. I want to be a good king. A strong king. Like those in the stories about the great kings of old. Somehow I never seem to match up to them. But I will eventually.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You speak of the kings in stories. But have you considered, Juan, that those stories were written after? That the men who lived them were just as uncertain, just as flawed, just as afraid of falling short as you are now? The chroniclers polish away the doubt. They remove the nights when a king lay awake wondering if he had made the right choice. I have known you for less than a month, Juan. And in that time, I have seen you race across a field with your daughter laughing in your arms. I have seen you kneel on a nursery floor to build block towers. The great kings of the stories—did any of them conquer Granada before their thirtieth year? Did any of them win the love of their nobles by carrying a child among them at a feast? You do not need to match the stories, husband. Someday, they will write stories about you. And some young king, centuries hence, will lie awake at night wondering how he could ever hope to be as great as Juan II of Castile. But I will know the truth. I will know that he was a man who worried he was not enough. And I will love him for it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You know something else? I just realized that you are older than me. That means you should be wiser as well. I must be careful that an older woman will not impress me too much and wrap me around her finger.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Older? I am twenty-three, you impossible man. You are—what—twenty-eight? Twenty-nine? Wait. How old are you? I confess I never thought to ask. In Ferrara, they told me the King of Castile was young and brilliant and possibly mad. They did not mention he was a child who would tease his wife about her advanced years on their wedding night. I should warn you, husband—I have six Italian ladies who are entirely loyal to me, and Donna Francesca knows seventeen different ways to make a man regret his words.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am twenty one, turning twenty two next year. I was eighteen when I went on crusade.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Twenty-one? You were eighteen when you knelt before the Pope? Eighteen when you conquered Granada? Dio mio. I have married a boy. The courts of Italy will never let me live this down. Lucia d'Este, the great beauty of Ferrara, ensnared by a child-king barely old enough to grow a proper beard. What were you like, Juan? At eighteen? Before all of this?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Like I told you in the garden. I had no power or independance at all. I knew I had to do something. But there was something else as well. I sometimes just know I have to do something. 'It must be done', I tell myself. I feel that pull whenever I am about to do something important. I know that eventually, I will drive out the Ottomans from europe and take control of an empire. They will become part of my kingdom and you Lucia will help me do it. You will be my queen and hold my court when I am away. Me on the battlefield, you on the throne in the court. And together we will lift it all closer to God.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: When you say these things... when you speak of empires and driving out the Ottomans and lifting the world closer to God... Do you hear yourself, Juan? Any other man, I would think him mad. But you... you mean it. Every word. And the terrifying thing is that I believe you. What if it is real, Juan? What if God truly has marked you for something beyond what any king has achieved in a thousand years? Promise me something. Promise me that if this pull, this certainty, ever leads you toward something monstrous—something that would damn your soul or destroy everything you love—you will stop. Promise me you will remain the man who knelt in a garden and whispered his dreams to a woman he barely knew.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, I did not choose you to be a decoration on the wall. I am telling you because I want us to share this dream together. I will make you a queen Lucia. You have no idea yet of what you are capable of. Your sharp mind will serve you well. You will learn to command. I will enjoy seeing you develop into this role. Now that you are my wife, your old life is over.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You see me. You actually see me. All my life, men have looked at me and seen... a prize. A beauty to be won. But you look at me and see someone I have not yet become. Someone I did not know I could be. You want to make me a queen. Not a decoration—a queen. Someone who commands, who rules, who stands beside you as an equal in all but name. Then teach me, husband. My old life is over, you say? Good. Let it burn. I am Lucia of Castile now. Your wife. Your queen. Your partner in an empire that does not yet exist. Show me what I can become.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: From now on, you will attend every meeting with me. You will know exactly what is going on so you can decide the course of the kingdom when I am away. Tomorrow, we will meet with Alvaro and the masters of Calatrava, Alcantrara, and santiago. We will discuss the coming campain to Constantinople. We need to convince the pope to reform, our first real test. Then we travel on to the eternal city by ship.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Every meeting. Good. I will need to understand not just the decisions, but the men who make them. Complementary colors. Two sides of the same coin. In Ferrara, my aunt once told me that a ruler's clothing is armor of a different kind. Deep crimson, I think. Or perhaps cloth-of-gold. Something with structure. So. Tomorrow, the Masters. Then the courtiers of Toledo. Letters to the kingdom announcing my role. Then travel: Madrid first, then Valencia, then Rome by sea. The Pope. Reform. What exactly do you hope to achieve in Rome? Tell me about the Pope, about Basel, about what you need from Rome before Constantinople becomes possible.

encounters.recap: On their wedding night, Juan and Lucia consummate their marriage and share intimate confessions. Juan reveals his divine sense of purpose and grand ambitions for a Christian empire, while Lucia transforms from a guarded political pawn into his strategic partner. They plan their joint rule, with Lucia attending all meetings and serving as regent when Juan campaigns. Their partnership deepens into a shared vision of conquest and reform.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The Pope. Reform. What exactly do you hope to achieve in Rome? And what resistance do you expect? I know the Church is... fractured. Basel and Rome pulling in different directions. But I do not yet understand the full shape of it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Teach me, husband. Start now. We have—a few hours before the world demands us. Tell me about the Pope, about Basel, about what you need from Rome before Constantinople becomes possible.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rise and begin to dress, your body servants arriving to assist with the layers of clothing appropriate for a king the morning after his wedding. As they work, you explain the situation to Lucia, who listens from the bed, wrapped in silks, her sharp mind absorbing every detail. The Church is fractured. Pope Eugenius IV sits in Rome, but his authority is contested by the Council of Basel, which claims that a general council of the Church holds authority superior to any pope. The conciliarists at Basel push for reforms—limits on papal power, restrictions on benefices, an end to certain abuses—while Eugenius resists what he sees as an assault on the very foundations of papal supremacy. Castile has walked a careful line. Fray Hernando led your delegation at Basel with skill, positioning Castile as a moderate voice—supportive of genuine reform, but not hostile to papal authority. The situation with Constantinople complicates everything. The Byzantine Emperor desperately needs Western aid against the Ottomans, but he also needs Church unity—specifically, reunion between the Eastern and Western churches.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: So we need the Pope's blessing for Constantinople, but we cannot appear to be his creature, or we lose influence at Basel. And we need Basel's reform energy, but we cannot openly defy Rome, or we lose the Pope's support for the expedition.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And I thought Ferrarese politics were complicated.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The private dining chamber is warm, a fire crackling against the December chill. Catalina sits at the table, her feet dangling above the floor, attacking a crostata with determined enthusiasm. Doña Beatriz hovers nearby, ready to intervene against the worst excesses of toddler dining.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá! Lucia! You are wearing the same colors.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good. Now you match. Like... like a set.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Breakfast passes in comfortable domesticity. Catalina provides a running commentary on her crostata, on the weather outside, and on her plans for the day.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: This one has nuts, Papá. It is cold, the birds are hiding. I want to see Tormenta. Can Lucia take me to see Tormenta?

encounters.recap: Juan briefs Lucia on the complex Church politics involving Rome and Basel while they dress after their wedding night, then they share breakfast with Catalina. Lucia quickly grasps the delicate balance needed between papal and conciliar factions for the Constantinople expedition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Breakfast passes in comfortable domesticity. Catalina provides a running commentary on her crostata, on the weather outside, and on her plans for the day. Lucia handles each pronouncement with patience and genuine warmth, promising they can visit Tormenta later, after the grown-ups attend to some boring matters first.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Boring matters? What boring matters?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Clothes. Lots and lots of clothes.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Can I have new clothes too?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You will have the best new clothes. Clothes that match Papá and me. So we all look like a set.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By mid-morning, the royal chambers have been transformed into a workshop of fabrics and sketches. Master Gonzalo de Ávila—Toledo's finest tailor—arrives with assistants bearing bolts of cloth. He is joined by Donna Francesca, who coordinates Lucia's wardrobe. The two regard each other with the wary respect of professionals who recognize a rival's competence.

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo_de_avila
exchanges.text: Your Majesties, I understand you wish to commission garments that... complement one another?

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: In Ferrara, the Duke and Duchess often appear in coordinated attire for formal occasions. Not identical, but harmonious. The same palette, similar motifs, fabrics that speak to one another.

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo_de_avila
exchanges.text: The Queen should not attempt to match armor directly—that would appear martial. Instead, she should complement it. Where the King shows strength through steel, the Queen shows strength through presence.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: High collars. Fitted sleeves. Nothing that impedes movement or suggests fragility. I am told I am to learn to command. I should look the part.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I want red. Like Papá's sword-coat.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think the queen and the princess should look alike. What do you propose regarding formal wear when we are receiving nobles?

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo_de_avila
exchanges.text: For His Majesty: a doublet of deep crimson velvet, embroidered with the castles and lions of Castile in gold thread. For Her Majesty the Queen: a gown of the same crimson velvet, with cloth-of-gold accents. For the Princess: the same crimson, but in softer wool—a simplified version of the Queen's gown.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: The effect, when all three stand together, will be unmistakable: the King in his strength, the Queen in her grace, and the Princess as the promise of the future. A dynasty, Your Majesty. Not merely a family.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. So we have one set for when I wear armour. One official set in deep red and gold. And maybe a more informal set. Less heavy with gold and bold colours.

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo_de_avila
exchanges.text: Three sets then, Your Majesty. First: The Martial Set. Second: The Formal Set. Third: The Informal Set. With Your Majesty's approval, we can begin work immediately.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia, will we really match?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Add wrappings in the same colour scheme for Fernando should Lucia carry him. Yes, you and Lucia will both look splendid in beautiful dresses. What do you think Lucia?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I think that I have never had a sister in matching dresses. And now I shall have something better—a daughter.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Daughter? That means... Lucia is my mama now?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You had a mama, little one. A wonderful mama who loved you very much, and who is with God now. I am not here to replace her. But I am here now. And I will love you, and care for you, and match dresses with you. What would you like to call me?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Can I call you Lucia-mama? So I remember both?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, Lucia-mama! See Catalina? This is how you treat a mama.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina watches with solemn attention, then marches over to Lucia and throws her small arms around her neck, squeezing with all her strength. She plants a wet, slightly off-center kiss on Lucia's cheek.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Like that. That is how you treat a Lucia-mama.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's composure breaks. Tears spill down her cheeks as she pulls Catalina close, burying her face in the child's dark hair.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Yes, little one. Exactly like that.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Don't cry, Lucia-mama. Crying is for when you are sad. This is happy.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. I think you have your instructions, master clothier?

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo_de_avila
exchanges.text: I do, Your Majesty. Three sets of coordinated garments for the King, Queen, and Princess. Wrappings for Prince Fernando in matching colors. The formal crimson set as first priority.

encounters.recap: The royal family commissions three coordinated sets of formal wear from Master Gonzalo and Donna Francesca. During the fitting session, Catalina asks to call Lucia 'Lucia-mama,' leading to an emotional moment where the new family bonds are formally acknowledged through the child's innocent acceptance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz has turned away, dabbing at her eyes with her sleeve. Even Master Gonzalo, that weathered professional, clears his throat gruffly and makes unnecessary adjustments to his fabric samples. Donna Francesca watches her mistress with an expression of quiet wonder—seeing perhaps a Lucia she has never seen before, one that the gilded cage of Ferrara never permitted to exist. Catalina, pleased with herself, pats Lucia's back with the clumsy comfort of a child who has seen adults do the same.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Don't cry, Lucia-mama. Crying is for when you are sad. This is happy.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. I think you have your instructions, master clothier?

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo
exchanges.text: I do, Your Majesty. Three sets of coordinated garments for the King, Queen, and Princess. Wrappings for Prince Fernando in matching colors. The formal crimson set as first priority. I will coordinate with Donna Francesca on the Queen's measurements and preferences, and with Doña Beatriz regarding the Princess's sizing.

exchanges.speaker: master_gonzalo
exchanges.text: If I may say, Your Majesty—in thirty years of serving the crown, I have dressed your father and now you. I have made wedding garments and mourning clothes, coronation robes and battle surcoats. But I have never been asked to dress a family before. Only kings. It is an honor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He departs with his assistants, Donna Francesca following after a quick curtsey and a warm glance at Lucia, who still kneels on the floor with Catalina in her arms. The room settles into quiet. Morning light streams through the windows. Somewhere in the Alcázar, the business of the kingdom continues—letters to be written, councils to be held, a campaign to Constantinople to be planned. But for this moment, there is only this: your wife, your daughter, and the simple truth that Catalina spoke without knowing its depth. This is happy.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesties, the Masters of the Military Orders await your pleasure in the council chamber. Don Álvaro sent word that they have assembled as requested.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It's time for the grown ups to do some boring things. You can go with Dona Beatriz and play with your wooden horses and look at baby Fernando. We will be back later and then we can go ride real horses if you like.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Very boring things?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Very boring.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Okay, Papá. You do the boring things. I will watch Fernando. He is also boring. He just sleeps and cries.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Come, Your Highness. Perhaps we can build a stable for your wooden horses while we wait.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A stable? With hay?

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: We shall see what we can manage.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama, you will come find me? After the boring?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I promise, little one. After the boring, we will ride Tormenta together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina nods, satisfied that all necessary commitments have been secured, and allows herself to be carried away. Her voice drifts back down the corridor: 'Doña Beatriz, did you know I have a Lucia-mama and a regular mama? The regular mama is with God...' The door closes. Silence settles over the chamber. Lucia stands beside you, her hand finding yours.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Well then, husband. Shall we go discuss Constantinople with your Military Orders?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And morocco as well. We will continue across the strait. We both go to the study room and I introduce the three masters to the queen.

encounters.recap: In a touching moment, Princess Catalina formally accepts Queen Lucia as 'Lucia-mama,' bringing tears to the chamber as Master Gonzalo speaks of dressing a family rather than just kings. The intimate family scene concludes as Juan and Lucia prepare to meet with the Masters of the Military Orders to discuss the campaigns to Constantinople and Morocco.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You walk together through the corridors of the Alcázar, Lucia's hand resting lightly on your arm. She has composed herself fully now—the tears of the nursery replaced by the sharp, attentive gaze of a woman preparing to enter a room full of powerful men who do not yet know what to make of her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me quickly. Which of the three will be most resistant to my presence? Which most likely to become an ally?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room is warm, a fire crackling in the great hearth. A large table dominates the center, spread with maps of the Mediterranean, the Strait of Gibraltar, and the distant waters approaching Constantinople. Álvaro stands near the window, and the three Masters of the Military Orders rise as you enter. Don Luis de Guzmán, Master of Santiago—the eldest of the three, his white mantle marked with the red cross of his Order. Don Pedro González de Padilla, Master of Calatrava—forty-five years old, the professional soldier who wept at your inspirational speech at Íllora. Don Juan de Zúñiga, Commander of Alcántara—second-in-command of the Order, representing Master Sotomayor in his absence.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. And...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My lords, allow me to present Her Majesty Queen Lucia of Castile. She will be attending our councils from this day forward. When I am absent from the kingdom—as I shall be when we sail for Constantinople—she will rule as regent in my name. It is therefore essential that she understand fully the matters we discuss.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The Order of Santiago welcomes you. We are... honored by your presence.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava stands ready to serve the crown. Both crowns.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Alcántara is at your command, Your Majesty. I confess I am curious to hear the Queen's perspective on our eastern enterprise. Fresh eyes often see what familiarity blinds us to.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Shall we begin, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Gentlemen, we have received reports from both Morocco and Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You begin with Morocco. Commander Martín's report: the delegation has established itself in Tangier and Tétouan, though Salé remains hostile. The Marinid Sultan is a boy of fourteen, his realm fragmenting under competing regents. Then you turn to Constantinople. The situation is grave. The 300 knights under Sotomayor arrived to find the city's defenses in worse condition than reported. The walls are crumbling in places, the treasury nearly empty, the garrison demoralized.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: And the seven hundred additional knights we discussed? Does Your Majesty intend to proceed?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I intend to proceed yes. I have given my word and I always keep my word. Masters, I intend to go and to give the emperor and his people a choice. I repair their walls and keep my word and then we leave to the fate of their own making. They can also come with us, and I will grant them sanctuary in my kingdom. Constantinople will fall and we prevent a violent conquest. Or we make arrangements to fight. But I will only accept this option if we have a chance to win. And they will have to acknowledge our authority. I dont know yet what this will look like, I will have to feel this out. But I promise to represent Castillian and Christian interests.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of three paths. Honor the commitment, repair the walls, and withdraw—leaving Constantinople to its fate. Or evacuate those who wish to leave—a mercy, but also an admission that the city cannot be saved. Or... Fight. But only if victory is possible, and only if the Greeks submit to our authority.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: The third option troubles me, Your Majesty. Not the fighting—Calatrava does not fear battle. But the conditions. János Hunyadi's letters were clear. Thirty-five to forty thousand professional soldiers, unified command, supply lines through Hungary. We speak of seven hundred knights. Even with the three hundred already there, we are far short of what the Hungarian says is needed.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Master Sotomayor writes from Constantinople that the Emperor is... proud. Desperate, yes, but proud. The Greeks remember the Fourth Crusade. They remember Latin armies that came to help and stayed to conquer. If Your Majesty demands acknowledgment of authority as the price of aid, the Emperor may refuse—even if refusal means his city's death. Pride can be stronger than survival.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: And yet, Your Majesty is right to demand it. We cannot spend Castilian blood and gold to prop up a throne that will not recognize our sacrifice. If we fight, we must fight for something lasting—not merely to delay the inevitable by a decade.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: There is also the question of the Pope, Your Majesty. And Basel. Both Rome and the Council seek to host the negotiations for Church reunion with the Greeks. Whoever brokers that reunion gains enormous prestige. If Castile is seen as the power that saved Constantinople and healed the schism...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The masters speak about important aspects. All I can say right now is that the wall repairs and the 1000 knights buys us some time. Time we will use to choose what option to take. To start a new crusade, call allies, plan the campain that requires 40.000 dedicated soldiers. But it all starts with a choice. I must also ask the masters; how are they adapting to the new situation now that Grenada has fallen? Do you plan to relocate forts? Maybe I can grant some of the Grenada forts to the orders. Forts who now still are crown property. And have the masters thought about switching more towards expanding to a naval presence as well?

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty raises the question that has occupied every chapter meeting since Granada fell. For two centuries, the Orders existed for one purpose: the Reconquista. Our lands, our fortresses, our very reason for being—all oriented toward the frontier with the Moors. And now... The frontier is gone. The Moors are defeated. We find ourselves warriors without a war.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava holds seventeen fortresses along what was the border. Good fortresses, well-maintained, strategically positioned for a conflict that no longer exists. My knights garrison walls that face... olive groves. Sheep. We train for battle and guard against farmers.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Alcántara faces the same question. Master Sotomayor took the Constantinople command in part because he saw the future clearly—the Orders must find new purpose or wither into irrelevance. Become landlords collecting rents, our martial traditions fading into ceremony. Granada fortresses would help, Your Majesty. New positions, new frontiers—even if the frontier is now the sea rather than the land. It gives our knights something to do.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty mentions naval presence. This is... a significant shift. The Orders have always been cavalry, heavy horse, fortress garrisons. Ships require different skills, different men, different traditions. Santiago has some experience with coastal defense, but true naval warfare? Galleys, marines, naval tactics? We would need to learn. To adapt.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava has no ships. No sailors. We are horsemen.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: And yet... if the next crusade is Constantinople, the path there is by sea. If Morocco is to be contested, it is across the Strait. If the Ottomans are the enemy, their navy is as dangerous as their armies. Perhaps the Orders must become naval powers, whether we wish it or not.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Alvaro, is it correct that all forts are now crown property? And how many forts and ports have been taken with the reconquista?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is correct. By the terms of the conquest and the papal decree granting crown authority over the Military Orders, all captured fortifications in Granada are crown property until formally granted otherwise. The conquest yielded the following: twenty-three major fortresses, including the alcazabas of Granada, Málaga, Almería, and Guadix. Fourteen secondary fortifications—smaller castles and fortified towers controlling mountain passes and river crossings. Eight fortified ports along the coast: Málaga, Almería, Almuñécar, Motril, Adra, Vera, Mojácar, and Marbella. Additionally, there are perhaps thirty to forty minor watchtowers and signal posts throughout the Sierra Nevada and along the coastal roads.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In order to make sure christian settlers are protected and keep the kings peace in Grenada, I am willing to grant all forts and watchtowers to be divided among the three orders. Regarding a transition to a naval presence; I am unsure. If we are fighting Ottomans, the orders just need transports to and from Constantinople and dont need ports on their own per se.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... most generous. Twenty-three major fortresses, fourteen secondary fortifications, and the watchtower network—divided among three Orders, that is perhaps twelve or thirteen significant positions each, plus the minor posts. This would give the Orders a renewed purpose in the south. Garrison duties, yes, but also the work of settlement—protecting Christian farmers, overseeing the transition of Moorish lands, maintaining the roads.

exchanges.speaker: don_pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava would welcome fortresses in the eastern reaches—toward Almería and Guadix. Our existing holdings lie that direction. It would create a coherent territory.

exchanges.speaker: don_juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Master Sotomayor would wish me to express gratitude on the Order's behalf, Your Majesty. The western positions—toward Málaga and Ronda—would suit Alcántara's current disposition. Though I cannot commit formally without the Master's approval.

exchanges.speaker: don_luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Santiago would take the central region. Granada city and its surroundings. The symbolic heart of the conquest. It seems fitting. Regarding naval matters, Your Majesty speaks wisdom. Transport is not the same as naval warfare. If the Orders require only passage to Constantinople and back, the crown's fleet—or hired Genoese and Venetian vessels—would suffice. Building our own naval capacity is a generation's work, not a season's. But I would ask Your Majesty to consider: if Morocco is truly the next horizon, the Strait must be controlled. And if the Ottomans are the enemy beyond that, their galleys raid as far as Sicily and Sardinia. The day may come when Castile needs more ships than the crown alone can provide.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The crown is building up it's fleet as we speak. For the Constantinople campain, the orders do not need a fleet of their own. As we develop a strategy for morocco, this may change. Alvaro, what pirate activity is there currently? And how does this affect our revenue?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the situation is... mixed. Since the fall of Granada, Barbary corsairs operating from the Moroccan coast have grown bolder. They no longer have Granada as a friendly port, which has pushed them westward—but it has also made them more desperate and aggressive. In the past six months, we have confirmed reports of fourteen merchant vessels attacked or seized in waters between Málaga and Almería. Another eight along the approaches to the Strait itself.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes a council meeting with the Military Orders to discuss Constantinople and Morocco strategy. He introduces Queen Lucia as his future regent and grants all Granada fortresses to the three Orders. The discussion covers three strategic options for Constantinople: honor commitments and withdraw, evacuate willing Greeks, or fight under Castilian authority. The Orders express concerns about their future purpose post-Reconquista and the challenges of naval warfare, while reports reveal increasing Barbary corsair activity affecting merchant shipping.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: But I would ask Your Majesty to consider: if Morocco is truly the next horizon, the Strait must be controlled. And if the Ottomans are the enemy beyond that, their galleys raid as far as Sicily and Sardinia. The day may come when Castile needs more ships than the crown alone can provide. I do not argue for haste. Only that the door not be closed entirely.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The crown is building up it's fleet as we speak. For the Constantinople campain, the orders do not need a fleet of their own. As we develop a strategy for morocco, this may change. Alvaro, what pirate activity is there currently? And how does this affect our revenue?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro sets aside his notes on the fortress distribution and retrieves another set of papers—these bearing the marks of naval reports and merchant complaints.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the situation is... mixed. Since the fall of Granada, Barbary corsairs operating from the Moroccan coast have grown bolder. They no longer have Granada as a friendly port, which has pushed them westward—but it has also made them more desperate and aggressive. In the past six months, we have confirmed reports of fourteen merchant vessels attacked or seized in waters between Málaga and Almería. Another eight along the approaches to the Strait itself. The corsairs operate primarily from Tétouan, Tangier, and most aggressively from Salé—the same city that rejected Commander Martín's delegation. Salé is effectively a corsair republic; the Marinid Sultan has no control there whatsoever. Direct losses to Castilian merchants: approximately twelve thousand florins in cargo and vessels over the past year. But the greater damage is indirect. Merchants now demand higher fees for the risk, or refuse certain routes entirely. Venetian and Genoese traders are beginning to favor other ports—Valencia, Barcelona—where the crown of Aragon provides better escort. This costs us perhaps another twenty to thirty thousand florins annually in trade that simply goes elsewhere. The crown fleet is growing, but it is designed for military transport and major naval engagements—not the constant patrol work required to suppress piracy. For that, we would need lighter, faster vessels stationed permanently at the coastal ports. Galleys or caravels that can chase corsairs into shallow waters where our larger ships cannot follow. This is where the question of ports becomes relevant, Your Majesty. If the Orders held coastal fortifications with associated harbors—even small ones—they could maintain patrol vessels as part of their garrison duties. It would give them naval experience gradually, in defensive operations, before any thought of offensive campaigns against Morocco.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But are the masters ready for such a responsibility? Do they truly want to also take on the responsibility of not only keeping the land safe, but also the sea who is becoming more and more important for this kingdom?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three men shift in their seats. This is no longer a discussion of gifts and grants—it is a challenge to their identity, their capability, their willingness to transform.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks a fair question. And I will give a fair answer. Santiago has guarded Castile's frontiers for two hundred years. We learned to fight Moors when our grandfathers' grandfathers were young. We adapted to new weapons, new tactics, new enemies. When the bombards came, we learned siege warfare. When Granada built its mountain fortresses, we learned to starve them out. We can learn the sea. But I will not pretend we already know it. If Your Majesty grants us coastal responsibilities, Santiago will need time—years, not months—to build the ships, train the men, develop the knowledge. We would need to hire experienced captains, perhaps Genoese or Catalan, to teach us. It would be... humbling. But Santiago has never feared hard work. Only irrelevance.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava is a cavalry order. Horsemen. I will not lie to Your Majesty and claim my knights are eager to trade saddles for ship decks. But Don Luis speaks truth. The alternative is to wither. To become ceremonial guards with pretty mantles and no purpose. If the sea is where Castile's enemies are, then Calatrava will learn to fight on the sea. But we will need guidance. And patience. And perhaps some assurance that our horses will not be expected to swim.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Master Sotomayor took three hundred knights to Constantinople precisely because he understood this moment was coming. Alcántara is the smallest of the three Orders. We cannot compete with Santiago or Calatrava in land holdings or numbers. But the sea... the sea is new ground for all of us. A smaller Order that masters naval warfare early could find itself more valuable than larger Orders still learning. I cannot speak for Master Sotomayor with certainty. But I believe he would say: yes. Alcántara is ready for this responsibility. Eager for it, even. We see it as opportunity, not burden.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room falls silent. The fire crackles. The maps of coastlines and distant waters seem to pulse with possibility.
