exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Velasco daughter's eyes went wide as Catalina was set beside her. She looked to her mother again, received a small nod of permission, and then turned to the princess with the serious expression of a child entrusted with important responsibility. Catalina, freed from her father's arms, immediately reached for the girl's braided hair, which had ribbons woven through it.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Velasco girl, emboldened, touched the embroidered lions on Catalina's stained gown.

exchanges.speaker: maria_velasco
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious to ask. House Velasco endures, as it always has. Our lands in the north remain productive. Our obligations to the crown are met.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: The Count was recently blessed with a grandson, Your Majesty. Our eldest son's wife delivered a healthy boy in September. We had hoped to bring him tonight, but the journey from Burgos was too arduous for an infant so young.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Really? Well congratulations! Seeing your family expand into a new generation is a blessing indeed. Your daughter seems to be getting with Catalina. What is her name?

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: Her name is María, Your Majesty. After my mother.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She is our unexpected blessing. We thought ourselves done with children when God saw fit to give us one more.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: María is... spirited. Her nurses say she has more energy than her three brothers combined. She was furious to learn she could not train with a sword like her brothers do.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She tried to steal one from the armory last month. The master-at-arms found her in the courtyard attempting to lift a blade twice her height.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maria...carrying a sword? Really? I must confess I do not know if I hope Catalina will follow her example.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: I confess I did not know whether to punish her or promote her to the household guard. She told me—with great indignation—that if Castile could have a warrior king, it should also have warrior ladies. She had heard some troubadour's tale of the crusade, I think.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She informed her brothers that she intended to conquer her own kingdom since they would inherit everything of ours. We have not yet determined which kingdom she has set her sights upon.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: She asks me every week when she will be allowed to learn to ride properly. Not side-saddle, as ladies do. Properly, like a knight. I have run out of excuses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Are we witnessing our very own Joan of ark? And how is the mother faring, now that her daughter is so interested in playing knight?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I have learned that God sends us the children we need, not the children we expect. When she was three, she refused to learn embroidery. She said the needle was too small to be a useful weapon. When she was four, she asked why her brothers were taught letters and she was not. When she was five...

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: When she was five, she organized the kitchen children into an army and laid siege to the henhouse. We lost six chickens before the assault was repelled.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: I have tried to teach her the womanly arts, Your Majesty. She can sew—when she chooses to. She can dance—though she prefers to lead. She has a fine singing voice, which she uses primarily to compose battle hymns. I confess I do not know what future awaits a girl such as María. She will not be content with an ordinary marriage, managing a household while her husband rides to war. But what else is there for a woman of noble birth?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: It seems Her Highness shares some of my daughter's... determination.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can I leave her with Maria for a moment while I meet with the other guests?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: Of course, Your Majesty. María will be gentle with her, I promise. For all her wildness, she is protective of those smaller than herself. She once stood guard over a nest of fallen sparrows for three days until they were strong enough to fly.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: We are honored, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: maria_velasco
exchanges.text: I will protect her. No one will hurt her while I am here.

encounters.recap: Juan continues his rounds among the nobility with Catalina, moving from House Manrique to House Velasco. The interaction transforms when Catalina bonds with six-year-old María Velasco, a spirited girl with martial ambitions. The informal play between the children breaks down the formal barriers, warming the previously guarded Count of Haro toward Juan. Juan entrusts Catalina to the Velasco family's care while he continues greeting other nobles.

roll.outcome: Transformative — Stories for Generations. The night becomes legendary. For years afterward, nobles will tell their children about when King Juan walked among them with Princess Catalina. The gesture transcends politics and becomes part of Juan's personal mythology. Houses that had grievances find them harder to maintain against a king who held their children's hands.

encounters.recap: A roll to determine how the Castilian nobility reacts to Juan's unprecedented behavior at the baptism feast—leaving the high table to circulate among guests with Catalina, sitting with families as near-equals, and trusting the Velascos with his daughter. The result shows the night becomes legendary, transforming Juan's reputation and beginning to heal old wounds, particularly with the Velasco house.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days following the baptism settled into a rhythm Juan had rarely known as king—domestic, quiet, almost ordinary. He took breakfast with Catalina each morning in the small solar adjoining his chambers, away from the formality of the great hall. She had developed firm opinions about food: bread was acceptable, eggs were suspicious, honey was essential. Juan learned to negotiate with a nineteen-month-old over the consumption of vegetables, a campaign that proved more challenging than several battles he had fought.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina. One bite of carrot.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For Papa?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For... the horse? The horse wants you to eat the carrot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long, suspicious stare. Then, grudgingly, one bite. Victory. Fernando was easier, in the way of infants—his needs were simple and immediate. Hungry. Tired. Wet. Content. Juan spent hours in the nursery, watching his son sleep, marveling at the smallness of his fingers. Sometimes he held the boy against his chest and simply breathed, feeling the tiny heartbeat against his own.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: He has Isabel's nose. She always hated her nose. Said it was too strong for her face. But on him...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It suits him.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: It suited her too. She just couldn't see it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The early November leaves had fallen from Toledo's trees and the first cold winds swept down from the Guadarramas when word came that the delegation from Ferrara had crossed the Pyrenees. Don Íñigo's courier reported their progress: Lucia d'Este traveled in a covered litter, accompanied by her Italian household, moving at the measured pace appropriate for a future queen.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Within the week. Shall I begin preparations for her reception, Your Majesty? The appropriate ceremonies, the—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. But... She asked to meet me privately first. Before any formal announcement. See that it happens.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And if she... if the meeting does not go well?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then we will discover that together. She is coming to see if my eyes match my letter, she said. I intend to show her that they do.

encounters.recap: Over ten days following the baptism feast, Juan settles into a domestic routine with his children—morning breakfasts with Catalina involving negotiations over food, quiet hours holding Fernando in the nursery. The Portuguese ladies find their footing in court, and Juan manages matters of state between family time. When word arrives that Lucia d'Este approaches Toledo, Juan makes careful preparations including commissioning an elegant sapphire ring and arranging for their first private meeting, choosing to present himself and his children to her rather than meeting alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The choice would be hers. Juan stood at the window of his chambers as the sun sank toward the western hills. Somewhere beyond the walls, a woman he had never met was approaching—a woman who had read his letter and declared she would see for herself whether his eyes matched his words. The ring sat in its box on the table beside him. The solar was prepared. The wines were ready. All that remained was the meeting itself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I go to the prepared dinner and wait for Lucia there and take Catalina, Fernando and two Doña's with me. I want her to meet me and my children as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The solar glowed warmly in the candlelight as Juan settled into his chair. A fire crackled in the hearth, casting dancing shadows across the walls. Through the arched windows, the last light of autumn faded over the garden courtyard below. Catalina sat on a cushion near the fire, engaged in serious conversation with her wooden horse. She had been bathed and dressed in a clean gown of pale blue—a minor miracle of negotiation with the nurses—though her hair was already escaping its ribbons. Fernando slept in a cradle nearby, wrapped in white linen, his tiny chest rising and falling with the steady rhythm of infant dreams. Doña Beatriz sat a respectful distance away, close enough to assist with the children if needed, far enough to allow privacy. Doña Leonor de Almeida had taken the other position, her eyes bright with curiosity about the woman who would become her new queen. The table was set for two, as planned. The wines stood ready—the Ribera del Duero already breathing, the white from Rueda chilled in a basin of cold water, the Málaga and the monastery vintage waiting in reserve. Ferrarese cheeses and Castilian delicacies occupied silver platters. Everything was elegant without being ostentatious. The ring box rested in Juan's doublet, a small weight against his chest.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Hungry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz moved to offer the princess a small piece of bread, which Catalina accepted with the gravity of a diplomat receiving tribute. Minutes passed. The fire crackled. Fernando stirred in his sleep, made a small sound, then settled again. Then—footsteps in the corridor. A soft knock at the door.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The Lady Lucia d'Este.

encounters.recap: Juan prepares for his first meeting with Lucia d'Este by setting up a private dinner in the solar with his children Catalina and Fernando present, along with their attendants. As evening falls, Lucia arrives at the prepared chamber where Juan waits with the engagement ring and an elegant but modest supper arrangement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The woman who entered the solar was not what the poets would have described. She was better. Lucia d'Este was tall for a woman—nearly Juan's own height—with a carriage that spoke of years learning to move through Italian courts without apology. Her hair was dark, almost black, worn in the Ferrarese fashion: partially braided and pinned, partially falling in waves past her shoulders. It framed a face that was striking rather than merely pretty—high cheekbones, a strong nose, a mouth that seemed poised perpetually on the edge of either a smile or a cutting remark. But it was her eyes that commanded attention. They were grey-green, the color of the sea before a storm, and they swept the room with an intelligence that missed nothing.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, how wonderful to meet you. I am Juan and I would like you to meet my little Catalina and baby Fernando as well.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Thank you, small one. I see. A fine horse. Does he have a name? An honest name. I approve.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: You bring your children to our first meeting. In Ferrara, such things would be handled by nurses until the marriage was secure. The children presented formally, once agreements were signed.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: You have gone to considerable trouble, Your Majesty. The wines. The food from home. This room. I am trying to determine whether this is thoughtfulness or strategy. In my experience, the two often wear the same face.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It just felt right to meet you with my children as well. You were going to meet them anyway and I did not want to occupy your mind with questions about who and how they are. But you have now seen them and I have asked to be alone for now. Come, have a seat, you must be tired after such a long journey.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Yes. I am tired. Five weeks on the road, through mountain passes and autumn rains, sleeping in monastery guest houses and provincial inns. There was one inn near Toulouse where the bed had more inhabitants than I did. I shall be writing a strongly worded letter to someone, though I have not yet determined whom.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: I was told Castilian wine is inferior to Italian. I was also told you are mad, that you speak to God directly, that you conquered Granada through divine intervention rather than military competence, and that your first wife died of a broken heart because you loved war more than her. I have learned to be skeptical of what I am told. Sit with me, Your Majesty. Pour me some of this allegedly inferior wine. And tell me which of the rumors are true.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What sort of wine do you like my lady? A strong red? A supple white? Or a sweet one?

roll.outcome: Cautious Interest. The approach lands acceptably. Lucia appreciates the informality but maintains her reserve—she did not travel across Europe to fall into anyone's arms on the first evening. She warms slightly to Catalina (children are hard to resist), asks appropriate questions about Fernando, but keeps Juan at a careful distance. A foundation, not a connection.

encounters.recap: Juan meets Lucia d'Este for the first time in his solar, introducing her immediately to his children Catalina and Fernando. The roll determines Lucia's reaction to this approach - she shows cautious interest, appreciating his informality while maintaining careful reserve. She engages politely with the children but keeps Juan at a distance, testing whether his actions match the promises in his letter. The meeting begins with mutual assessment rather than immediate connection.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I was told Castilian wine is inferior to Italian. I was also told you are mad, that you speak to God directly, that you conquered Granada through divine intervention rather than military competence, and that your first wife died of a broken heart because you loved war more than her. I have learned to be skeptical of what I am told. Sit with me, Your Majesty. Pour me some of this allegedly inferior wine. And tell me which of the rumors are true.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What sort of wine do you like my lady? A strong red? A supple white? Or a sweet one?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: That depends entirely on what I am drinking it for. A strong red when I wish to feel bold. A white when I wish to think clearly. A sweet wine when I wish to remember that the world contains pleasures as well as duties. Tonight I am meeting a man who may become my husband. A man I know only through a letter and the reports of others—reports which, as I mentioned, have been contradictory at best. I think I wish to think clearly. But I also wish to feel bold enough to ask the questions I came here to ask. Perhaps you should choose for me, Your Majesty. It will tell me something about you—whether you wish me clear-headed or pliable, whether you pay attention to what I actually said or simply hear what you expect to hear.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, let me start from the beginning then. I have been king since I was a child. I always knew those around me were taking advantage of me, but what could I do? I was often a captive in my own palace. One day I decided that it must end. And I realized that I had to do something extraordinary and unexpected for me to take control of my kingdom. To truly be king. So I went on a pilgrimage. Insane, since the realm was on the verge of rebellion. If I left but for a short while, the sharks would close in. But I had to try, so I gambled it all. I guess that is where the rumours started about me talking with God and all other nonsense. I indicated that I would leave on pilgrimage and would let the divine spirit guide me on my journey. I knew from the start that I had to go to Rome and ask for crusade. Only that would give me the authority to unite the realm not only under my rule, but it would also unite the kingdom against our common enemy. I had to rely on my divine guidance quite often for I went back to my palace to retrieve my father's sword, right at the moment when a rebellious plot was revealed. Maybe the divine inspired me to have someone signal to me when the rebels entered the meeting room or maybe the divine inspired me to actually want them to reveal themselves the moment they thought me gone. Or maybe both. Anyway, the result was that the rebels died an unfortunate death and my realm is now secure. And everyone thinks I am still the mad king who leaves to go on a pilgrimage while his nobles plot his downfall. But there is another side as well. I really do take my faith very seriously and I want to make sure I never become an arrogant, heartless king I see some others become. I do ride out at the head of my knights in my white armour, knowing full well that I am a major target for every enemy lance and archer. I have learned to not be afraid and I gladly lay my life in God's hands. Now dont confuse this bravery with recklessness. I try not to be. But I know that if I can approach a fort alone and negotiate a surrender, purely by my own presence, I know I will save my men and that it's a risk worth taking. More wine?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I have not yet tested this one, Your Majesty. You speak faster than I drink. So. The madness is a mask. The divine inspiration is... partly genuine faith, partly political theater. You let your enemies believe you a fool guided by heaven, while you arrange their deaths with precision. And you ride at the head of your knights not because you seek martyrdom, but because you have calculated that your presence saves more lives than your caution would. In Ferrara, my uncle is considered a master of such games. He has survived assassination attempts, rival claimants, and the endless scheming of Milan and Venice by letting everyone underestimate him. He plays the simple soldier, the bluff condottiero, while his mind works three moves ahead. I recognize the pattern. I am... familiar with the difference between what a ruler shows and what a ruler is. But there is something I do not yet understand. You speak of faith genuinely. You speak of not wishing to become heartless. You established a charity of twenty-five thousand florins in your dead wife's name—not from the treasury, but from your personal fortune. You carried your daughter through a feast, introducing her to every noble house like she was a treasure rather than a political asset. The mask I understand. The calculation I understand. But underneath it... is there actually a man who believes what he pretends to believe? Who loves what he appears to love? Or is that simply another layer of the performance?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is what is so difficult to explain. Every time I speak about this, I risk people thinking me mad, delusional or... having messianic thoughts. We live in this world Lucia. A world full of hunger, of pain, of injustice. But there is another world A world that is just, good and right. And every time we act not out of pride but out of generosity, when we act out of forgiveness and love instead of hate, we move our world just a little bit closer to God's kingdom on earth. I know we will never reach it Lucia. We never will, no matter how hard we try, there will always be enough greed and pride in the hearts of men to tear down every tower of goodwill. But we must try, for if we stop trying all is lost. It is in this struggle that we find out who we truly are, who we can be. How we can serve each other and God as well. And sometimes...when there is a special moment that belongs in His kingdom, I can see it. A true good deed. The prsence of God's kingdom in this world. It is beautiful Lucia. It is something no priest can bestow or take away. God exists between two people doing good things. It is what I truly fight for and believe in. What guides my every action. How can I bring this world closer to God's kingdom. Ha! Or to put it more simply and without complicated rethoric; how can I make this world better.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fire crackled in the silence that followed. Lucia did not move, did not speak. Her wine glass remained suspended halfway to her lips, forgotten. Juan had seen many reactions to his words over the years—confusion, suspicion, the careful blankness of courtiers who thought their king mad but dared not say so. He had seen Fray Hernando's troubled concern, Álvaro's pragmatic tolerance, the whispered worries of nobles who wondered if their monarch heard voices. Lucia's reaction was none of these. Her eyes glistened in the candlelight. Not tears—not quite—but something had shifted behind them. The sharp assessment, the political calculation, the careful distance she had maintained since entering the room... all of it had cracked, just slightly. She set down her wine glass with exaggerated care, as if she needed a moment to collect herself.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: My mother died when I was seven. Fever. I remember very little of her, but I remember one thing she told me. She said: 'Lucia, the world is full of men who want things. Power, gold, women, land. Be wary of all of them. But if you ever meet a man who wants to make things better—truly better, not just better for himself—hold onto him. They are rarer than diamonds.' I have been in courts my entire life. I have watched my uncle navigate between predators. I have seen cardinals speak of God while counting their gold. I have heard princes quote scripture to justify atrocities. I came here expecting to find another performer. A clever king with a good reputation and a talent for spectacle. I did not expect... this. You actually believe it. Not as doctrine, not as politics. You see something. Something real. My confessor in Ferrara would call what you describe heresy, you know. The presence of God between people, without the intercession of the Church? Dangerous talk. I think I like dangerous talk. You asked me which rumors were true. Now I ask you: the charity for the dowries, in your wife's name. The way you carried your daughter tonight. The way you speak of God's kingdom. Was Isabel part of this? Did she see what you see?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Where two or three of my number are gathered and my words are spoken, I am among you. Hardly heresy I believe. Maybe those who deny God's presence are themselves the heretics. I am trying to help reform the church, did you know? There is only so much I can do and a few weeks at Basel almost drove me insane, but we try. Isabel...she was always very pious. In a very committed way. She was very young when we married, maybe some more years would have granted her more wisdom. But she had a faith so pure and convincing, we shared this vision yes. But it mostly involved the joy of our family. Becoming a father has been the most pure vision of God's kingdom I ever saw. I see it still when I look at Catalina and how she is curious and discovers the world. The painting I had made of our wedding was meant to convey exactly that. The attainment of the kingdom of heaven through her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You loved her. Not merely as a king loves a queen who does her duty. You loved her. I have been told many things about what to expect from royal marriage. Duty. Alliance. Children. Tolerance of mistresses. A shared table and separate beds. No one told me to expect a man who speaks of his dead wife with such tenderness. Who sees the kingdom of heaven in his daughter's curiosity. I am not Isabel, Your Majesty. I am not young, not pure, not... uncomplicated in my faith. I have read things my confessor would burn me for. I have asked questions that made my tutors stammer. I have a tongue that has gotten me into trouble more times than I can count. My uncle once said I would either marry a king or be locked in a convent, because no ordinary man would tolerate me. I came here to see if your eyes matched your letter. They do. More than I expected. But I need to know something else. Something the letter did not address. If I marry you—if I become Queen of Castile, stepmother to your children, partner in this vision you speak of—what place will I hold? Will I be a companion in this work you describe? Will I have a voice, a role, a purpose beyond bearing heirs? Or will I be kept safe and comfortable while you ride off to Constantinople and Granada and wherever else God's kingdom calls you, waiting at home like a portrait on a wall?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My apologies my lady. We have dwelled on the dead for long enough now. I know you are not Isabel, nor do I require or expect it. I would like to get to know you better. Would you like to have a walk with me in the garden?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia looked at his offered hand for a moment. Then, unexpectedly, she laughed—a real laugh, warm and surprised.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You are remarkable, Your Majesty. I ask you a direct question about my future role as your queen, and you invite me to walk in a garden. In Ferrara, that would be considered an evasion. A deflection. But you are not evading, are you? You are telling me that such questions cannot be answered in a single evening. That you wish to know me before you promise me things you may not be able to give. That is either very wise or very infuriating. I have not yet decided which. I have been in carriages and litters and monastery guest rooms for five weeks. I have not walked anywhere simply for the pleasure of walking since I left Ferrara. Show me your garden, Your Majesty. And perhaps while we walk, you might tell me what you actually want from a wife. Not what duty requires. Not what diplomacy demands. What you want.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She placed her hand in his. Her fingers were cool from holding the wine glass, her grip firm and unhesitating. Up close, she smelled faintly of rosewater and travel dust—the latter a reminder that she had come to him straight from the road, without the hours of preparation most noble ladies would have demanded.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think God has given men and women different gifts and therefore different roles to play in the world. A king and a queen have different roles as well. Being queen of Castille can be quite exhausting, I must warn you. But now that I have gotten to know you a little bit, I think you will do just fine. Dont worry too much about what is expected of you as queen. Just do what feels right. It's what I do. You know, me and my advisors discussed many potential brides, and the fact you have a sharp tongue is well known. That and your sharp mind was what really made it easy to think you would be a great queen. And also...Lucia, you must know that men cannot talk about you without mentioning your beauty as well. Not only are you as sharp and quick as I had been told, you are simply the most beautiful woman I have ever met. And that is the honest truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The playful push caught her off guard—her eyes widened for a split second before she caught her balance, a surprised laugh escaping her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Did you just— The King of Castile just pushed me. In a garden. Like a boy teasing a girl at a village fair. My uncle told me it would be my downfall. That no man of consequence wants a wife who speaks her mind. I informed him that any man who could not tolerate my mind did not deserve the rest of me. He called me impossible. I thanked him for the compliment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But when Juan spoke of her beauty—called her the most beautiful woman he had ever met—she stopped walking. For a long moment, she said nothing. The moonlight caught her face, those grey-green eyes unreadable.

roll.outcome: Strong emotional connection established. Lucia is deeply moved by Juan's sincerity and vision. Mutual attraction confirmed.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia's first private meeting reveals deep compatibility as he explains his faith-driven kingship and she responds with unexpected emotional openness. Their conversation moves from political assessment to genuine connection, culminating in a moonlit garden walk where attraction and understanding flourish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The playful push caught her off guard—her eyes widened for a split second before she caught her balance, a surprised laugh escaping her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Did you just— The King of Castile just pushed me. In a garden. Like a boy teasing a girl at a village fair.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But she was smiling, and something in her posture had shifted. The last remnants of courtly formality were crumbling. They walked in silence for a moment, their footsteps soft on the stone path. The moonlight cast long shadows through the bare branches overhead. Somewhere, water trickled in a fountain.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: My uncle told me it would be my downfall. That no man of consequence wants a wife who speaks her mind. I informed him that any man who could not tolerate my mind did not deserve the rest of me. He called me impossible. I thanked him for the compliment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But when Juan spoke of her beauty—called her the most beautiful woman he had ever met—she stopped walking. For a long moment, she said nothing. The moonlight caught her face, those grey-green eyes unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Men have spoken of my beauty my entire life. They speak of it as if it belongs to them—as if my face is a painting hung for their pleasure, my body a territory to be claimed. They speak of it before they speak of anything else. Often, it is all they speak of. You spoke of my mind first. My tongue. You mentioned beauty last, almost as an afterthought. Do you know how rare that is? How many men have courted me who could not tell you a single thing I had ever said, but could describe my eyes in fourteen different poems?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She stepped closer. Close enough that he could see the faint freckles across her nose that the candlelight inside had hidden.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Isabel was fortunate. To have been seen by you. Truly seen. I think... I think I would like to be seen like that too.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I did not want to lie to you and be honest from the start. Being queen will not be easy. I am very demanding of myself and those around me. That usually involves me moving around a lot. Next spring I will leave for Rome and then Constantinople for example. And this will be a good example of what being queen will mean. I have a flagship, specially designed to accommodate a queen and her handmaidens. If you should want it, you can come with me. See the eternal city. Or if you prefer to stay in Toledo, you can choose to do so as well. You will have full freedom to be regent-queen in my absence should you desire it. You dont have to decide now, by the way. What I mean to say is...I hope for us to be a team.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You would take me to Constantinople? You would let me stand beside you as you meet the Emperor of the Romans? See the Hagia Sophia? In Ferrara, my aunt—my uncle's wife—has not left the city walls in eleven years. She manages the household. She bears children. She waits. When I asked her once if she wished to travel with my uncle on his campaigns, she looked at me as if I had suggested she sprout wings and fly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turned her hand in his, so that their fingers intertwined. It was a deliberate gesture—a choice.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: A team. Not a king and his ornament. Not a husband and his broodmare. You mean this. You actually mean this. I have spent my whole life preparing for a cage. A gilded cage, yes. Comfortable. Safe. But a cage nonetheless. Every lesson, every expectation, every warning from my uncle and my tutors—all of it preparing me to be kept. To smile and nod and produce heirs and never, ever want more. And now you stand here in a moonlit garden and offer me... partnership. Purpose. A ship designed for a queen. Either you are the most extraordinary man I have ever met, or this is an elaborate trap I am too tired to perceive. Tell me it is not a trap, Juan. Tell me you mean what you say.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: O but it is a trap Lucia! And I am about to spring it. After hearing about you from others and now after meeting you in person, I know that you are every bit the sharp and competent queen I would hope for. But you must choose me as well. What I ask of you is not easy. Not only will you work together with me to make Castille better, you will also become step-mother to Catalina and Fernando. Others will look to your every move and I will be called to war often. I promise to not only be a good husband but to treat you as partner. I will always value your council and will always trust you. I will protect you, shield you and keep you safe. Would you despite everything be my wife Lucia?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia stood frozen for a long moment, looking down at the kneeling king, the open box, the ring that caught the moonlight like a captured star. Then she laughed. Not a polite laugh, not a courtly titter—a real laugh, the kind that escaped before one could catch it. Her hand flew to her mouth, and when she lowered it, her eyes were bright with tears she did not bother to hide.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You impossible man. You impossible man. I crossed half of Europe expecting to find a political arrangement. A tolerable husband at best. A gilded cage. And instead I find a man who kneels in a garden and asks me to choose him. Who speaks of God's kingdom as if it were something real. Who pushed me like a village boy and showed me a ring designed for me, not for 'a queen'. Yes. Yes, I will be your wife. Yes, I will be stepmother to Catalina and Fernando. Yes, I will stand beside you in Rome and Constantinople and wherever else God calls you. Yes, I will be your partner, your counsel, your queen. But I warn you, Juan of Castile, I will not be a quiet wife. I will argue with you. I will tell you when you are wrong. I will drive your advisors to distraction and scandalize your court with my opinions. If you wanted meek and biddable, you have made a terrible mistake. But if you wanted a partner—a true partner—then you have found one. And I will fight beside you for this vision you speak of. This kingdom of heaven you see glimpses of. I want to see it too. Show me. Show me everything.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia let out a startled yelp as Juan swept her off her feet—a sound utterly undignified for a future queen, which only made her laugh harder. She did not struggle. Her arms wrapped around his neck instinctively, her face close to his as he carried her through the moonlit garden and back into the warmth of the solar. When he set her down in her chair, she was still laughing, wiping tears from her cheeks with the back of her hand—the hand that now bore his ring.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You are mad. The King of Castile, carrying his betrothed through the garden like a sack of Ferrarese grain. I will tell our children about this, you know. When they ask how their father proposed. I will tell them he knelt in the moonlight and then picked me up before I could say anything else. They will think us both mad. It will be wonderful. Sit. Eat. We have barely touched this feast you prepared. And I believe you promised to prove that Castilian wine is not inferior to Italian. The white is... acceptable. But I reserve judgment on the reds.

roll.outcome: Transcendent Moment. Something shifts in the moonlit garden. Lucia's acceptance becomes more than a yes—it becomes a vow. She speaks of what she sees in him, what she hopes to build together. The ring slides onto her finger like it was always meant to be there. This is the beginning of a true partnership, perhaps even love.

encounters.recap: Juan's marriage proposal to Lucia d'Este reaches its climax in the moonlit garden. After an evening of deep conversation, Juan kneels before her with the specially designed ring, honestly describing the challenges of being queen while promising true partnership. A roll of 83 produces a transcendent moment—Lucia accepts with overwhelming emotion, declaring her willingness to be his partner in all things while warning she will never be a quiet wife. The evening ends with Juan carrying her back to their table, both laughing and crying, the ring fitting perfectly on her finger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan filled two glasses with the robust Ribera del Duero—the wine Álvaro had sworn could silence Italian skepticism—and settled into the chair across from Lucia. The fire crackled between them, casting warm light across the remnants of their feast. He told her everything. He told her of the Emperor's letter—how Constantinople had shrunk from a million souls to barely forty thousand, how entire districts lay empty with fields growing inside the ancient walls. How the Theodosian Walls that had stood for a thousand years now crumbled, requiring more gold than the Empire possessed to repair. How the city that had preserved Roman civilization while the West fell into darkness now paid tribute to the Ottoman Sultan like a vassal, bleeding three hundred thousand silver coins each year simply to survive. He told her of Sotomayor's three hundred knights, already arrived, already working to shore up defenses. Of the remaining seven hundred he planned to bring in spring. Of the sixty thousand florins already sent for wall repairs—and how even that enormous sum was insufficient. He told her of the Emperor's request: not just soldiers, not just gold, but Juan himself. A personal visit. A statement to the world that Christendom had not abandoned the Queen of Cities. He told her of his promise to Pope Eugenius—made at Rome, sealed at the Council of Basel—that Castile would stand for the defense of the Faith. That the Reconquista's completion was not an ending but a beginning. And he told her the darker truth beneath it all: that Constantinople would likely fall regardless. That the Ottoman tide might be too great to stop. That he was committing treasure and knights and perhaps his own life to a cause that history might judge as hopeless.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But if we do nothing, if we let the city fall without raising a hand... then we are not the Christendom we claim to be. And whatever comes after, we will deserve it. That is where I am going in spring. That is what is at stake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia had listened without interruption, her wine untouched, her grey-green eyes fixed on his face throughout. The playfulness of moments before had vanished, replaced by something more serious—the sharp mind he had been promised, fully engaged. When he finished, she was quiet for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Forty thousand people. In a city built for a million. I have read of Constantinople in books. The libraries. The Hagia Sophia. The scholars who kept alive what Rome forgot. To think of it dying slowly, district by district, like a body losing feeling in its limbs... You said earlier that I could come with you. To Rome and Constantinople. Did you mean it? Truly? You would take your new queen into... that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Yes, exactly. We will be travelling with heavy escort, like I said brave but never suicidal. We have to listen to what the emperor has to say. If he is too proud to listen, If he rather die on his walls, I cannot stop him. My mind is already racing Lucia. I have not talked about this with anybody, but I will with you. I will demand heavy dependency of the Greeks on me before I will even consider help. Facing the ottomans for the coming 50 years is a colossal commitment and I will not do it as just a helper. Bleeding my own men dry for someone else's kingdom. That would be unjust to my men. I will demand they recognize my authority.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's eyes widened slightly. She set down her wine glass with deliberate care.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Your authority. You mean... more than an alliance. More than military coordination. The Emperor of the Romans—the inheritor of Constantine, of Justinian, of a thousand years of unbroken succession—recognizing the authority of the King of Castile. Juan, that is... that is extraordinary. The Byzantine court is the proudest in Christendom. They still call Western kings 'barbarians' in their private councils. They consider the Pope a schismatic upstart. But they are also desperate. You said it yourself: forty thousand people, tribute to the Sultan, walls crumbling. A drowning man does not argue about the hand that reaches for him. What form would this authority take? Vassalage? A personal oath to you? Integration into— You conquered Granada. You completed the Reconquista. You are building a fleet, reforming the Church, sending knights across the Mediterranean. Juan. What exactly are you building? What is the shape of the thing you see when you close your eyes and imagine victory?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan stood up and moved very close to her. He whispered in her ear his deepest ambition: to take the imperial crown of Constantinople and be emperor of Portugal, Castile, Navarre, Aragon, Naples, Sicily and Greece. Lucia went utterly still. Juan could feel her breath catch, her body frozen mere inches from his. For a long moment, she did not move, did not speak—did not even seem to breathe. Then, very slowly, she pulled back just enough to look at his face. Her grey-green eyes searched his, wide with something that was not quite fear, not quite awe, but some strange admixture of both.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Dios mío. You are not mad. You are terrifying. There is a difference. I see that now. Portugal through marriage—your mother's claim, or a future union. Navarre is contested, but achievable. Aragon through Alfonso, if he dies without heir—he has none, and you are close. Naples falls to Alfonso first, then to you by the same succession. Sicily follows Naples. And Constantinople... Constantinople you buy. With knights. With gold. With the only hand reaching for a drowning man. You make John VIII swear to you, and when the city survives because of Castilian steel, the people will remember who saved them. And when the Emperor dies... An empire. Not Holy Roman—that is German, and tied to electors who would never choose a Spaniard. But Roman. The true Rome. Constantinople and the West, united under one crown for the first time since... since Theodosius. Over a thousand years. And you whisper this to me. On the night of our betrothal. In a moonlit garden. What manner of husband have I chosen?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your mind works quickly. That is indeed more or less how I plan to do it. But please, we are too far away from it to even mention the possibility except between just us two. Please, be careful with what you say to whom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia nodded slowly, composing herself with visible effort. The trembling stilled. The sharp-tongued diplomat reassembled herself from the woman who had, for a moment, been shaken to her core.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I grew up in Ferrara. Where my uncle survives by knowing which words to speak aloud, which to whisper, and which to never say at all. Where a careless phrase at dinner can mean a dagger in the dark by morning. I know how to keep secrets, Juan. I have kept them since I was old enough to understand what they cost. This one I will carry to my grave if necessary. It will not pass my lips—not to confessor, not to family, not to any living soul. But know this: you have given me something tonight far more dangerous than a sapphire. You have given me the shape of your ambition. You have trusted me with the thing that could destroy you if spoken to the wrong ears. I will not forget that trust. And I will not betray it. Now. We should eat something, or the servants will wonder what we have been doing all this time. And I believe you still owe me proof that Castilian reds can stand against Italian.

encounters.recap: Juan reveals his deepest imperial ambitions to Lucia, sharing his plans to demand authority over Constantinople in exchange for military aid, ultimately seeking to unite Portugal, Castile, Navarre, Aragon, Naples, Sicily, and Greece under one crown. Lucia comprehends the vast scope of his vision and solemnly promises to keep this dangerous secret, understanding the trust he has placed in her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia blooms in the informal setting, her Ferrarese wit sharpening without the weight of court ceremony. You catch her one afternoon teaching Catalina Italian words for animals, your daughter solemnly repeating "cavallo" and "cane" with varying degrees of accuracy. The days grow shorter, then slowly begin to lengthen again. Christmas comes and goes, celebrated simply in Madrid's small church. The new year arrives—1434, the year that will see you sail to Constantinople, the year your second child will be born.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I make sure Catalina gets accustomed to the outside and riding regularly. I explain to her that we will go on a journey that will last many days and that Catalina should learn to ride a horse along with papa and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina receives this news with the grave attention she reserves for matters of supreme importance—the same expression she wears when inspecting a new wooden animal or deciding whether a particular food is acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Many days. On horses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Many days on horses. We will see new places. Big water—the sea. Ships. But Catalina must learn to ride well. To hold tight. To be brave when she is tired.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She considers this for a long moment. Then, with the decisive confidence of a general accepting a commission:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina brave.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Over the following days, you establish a routine. Each morning, weather permitting, Catalina rides with you or Lucia—short circuits around the lodge at first, then gradually longer excursions along the roads and paths near Madrid. She learns to grip the mane properly, to lean into turns, to anticipate the horse's movements. She falls asleep in the saddle twice and nearly slips once—caught easily, but it teaches her that holding tight is not merely a suggestion. After that, her small fists clutch with genuine determination.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Tight. Hold tight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the second week, she can manage an hour without complaint. By the third, nearly two—though she grows restless toward the end and requires distraction. Lucia proves skilled at this, pointing out birds, inventing games, singing fragments of Italian songs that Catalina attempts to mimic with enthusiastic inaccuracy. One afternoon, Catalina looks up at you from Hidalgo's back, her cheeks red from cold, her dark curls escaping from beneath her cap.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá. Catalina... good rider?

encounters.recap: Juan spends two weeks at the Madrid lodge training young Princess Catalina to ride in preparation for the Constantinople journey. Starting with short circuits, she gradually builds endurance to handle two-hour rides, learning proper grip and balance while Lucia provides encouragement and distraction during the longer sessions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The return to Toledo passes uneventfully—Catalina demonstrates her new riding endurance by lasting nearly the entire journey before demanding transfer to Lucia's arms for the final hour. She falls asleep before the Alcázar's towers come into view, and must be carried inside by Doña Beatriz, still clutching her small riding crop. Prince Fernando, now nearly four months old, has grown noticeably in your absence. The wet nurse reports he has been calm and content, sleeping well, beginning to focus on faces with evident interest. Doña Beatriz looks relieved to have the household reunited.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The next morning, you summon Álvaro to your study. He arrives with his customary efficiency, a leather satchel of documents under his arm. The weeks in Madrid have clearly not slowed the machinery of administration—the satchel looks full.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I trust the retreat was restful?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I ask Alvaro if the fleet is assembled in Valencia. And if we can have a carriage for the Princess.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The fleet assembles well. Eight transport vessels are already at anchor in Valencia—Genoese contracts, reliable captains. Two more expected by month's end. Capacity for the eight hundred crusaders, their horses, the household, and supplies for the crossing. The Santa Lucia will serve as the royal flagship. Newly fitted, spacious quarters for Your Majesties and the children. As for the carriage—I anticipated the need. A suitable vehicle is being prepared in Toledo as we speak. Enclosed, well-sprung, large enough for the Princess, a nurse, and one or two companions. It will slow the column somewhat on the road to Valencia, but not unacceptably. The Princess will travel with the column, then? Not remain in Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I refer of course to the flagship I had commissioned to be built. The one with the rooms for the queen, and named Princess Catalina. That ship should be ready by now right? Along with the other carracks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's expression shifts—a flicker of something that might be embarrassment, quickly suppressed beneath his usual composure.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty. The Princess Catalina, yes. The flagship is complete. Launched in November, sea trials conducted in December. The shipwrights report she handles well—stable in heavy swells, spacious quarters as designed. The Queen's chambers are fitted as you specified. The other carracks of the new fleet... three of the five commissioned vessels are complete and seaworthy. The remaining two require another six to eight weeks—they will not be ready for the Constantinople expedition, but will join the fleet upon your return. So you have the Princess Catalina as flagship, three new carracks, and the eight Genoese transports under contract. More than sufficient for the expedition's needs. The Santa Lucia I mentioned is one of the Genoese vessels—I had assumed, incorrectly, that you might prefer a hired ship for the crossing rather than risk the new flagship on its maiden true voyage. But of course, the Princess Catalina was built precisely for this purpose. She should carry her namesake. I will ensure she is provisioned and ready at Valencia. The royal quarters will be prepared for Your Majesties, the Princess, and Prince Fernando—unless the Prince remains in Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, who of your donna's will come? And what portugese dona's will we take with us? Have you given this thought?

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Toledo and meets with Álvaro to plan the Constantinople expedition. The fleet is nearly ready in Valencia, including the newly completed flagship Princess Catalina. Juan begins discussing which courtiers will accompany the royal family on the voyage.

encounters.recap: Juan inquires about the status of the royal fleet for the Constantinople expedition. Álvaro reports that the flagship Princess Catalina is complete and ready, along with three new carracks and eight Genoese transport vessels. Juan clarifies he wants to use his commissioned flagship rather than a hired vessel, and begins discussing travel arrangements with Queen Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, who of your donna's will come? And what portugese dona's will we take with us? Have you given this thought?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia sets aside the embroidery she has been working on—a project she claims to find soothing, though you have noticed she stabs the needle with rather more force than strictly necessary when frustrated.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I have given it considerable thought. A sea voyage to Constantinople is not a trip to Madrid. We will be gone for months, in unfamiliar waters, among strangers. I need women I can trust absolutely—and women who will not spend the entire journey vomiting over the rails.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Donna Francesca must come. She has managed my household since I was sixteen, and she will keep the others in order. Donna Isabella rides well, complains little, and has a steady stomach—she crossed from Ferrara to Castile without incident. Those two are certain. The others... Giulia is prone to seasickness even on river barges. Caterina is capable but has never traveled far from home—I do not know how she would manage. Alessandra and Beatrice are young and adaptable, but inexperienced.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Two Italian ladies, I think. Francesca and Isabella. More than that becomes unwieldy, and we will have limited space even on your magnificent Princess Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: As for the Portuguese ladies—that is more delicate. They were Isabel's household. Doña Beatriz has been with the children since Catalina's birth, and Fernando knows her. But asking her to leave Fernando for months, or asking Fernando to endure a sea voyage at four months old... Do we bring Fernando? That question determines much else. If he stays, Doña Beatriz should stay with him. If he comes, she must come too—he needs consistency more than Catalina does at this age.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We keep Fernando in Toledo, along with Beatriz I think. After that, we will not leave him anymore. Maybe we take one Portugese dona with us? Keep it small, three ladies should be enough I think.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia nods slowly, her expression thoughtful.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Three ladies. Francesca, Isabella, and one Portuguese. That is lean, but manageable. And you are right—we should not be encumbered by a vast household on a voyage like this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises and moves to the window, looking out over the winter garden.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The Portuguese ladies... there is Doña Leonor de Almeida. She is young, but steady. She accompanied Isabel on the journey from Portugal and did not complain once, even when the roads were terrible. She also has been making eyes at one of the Guzmán knights, so perhaps she will be motivated to return safely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia turns back to you.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz will understand. She loves Catalina fiercely, but Fernando needs her more right now. And truthfully—I think it may be easier for Catalina to have distance from Beatriz for a time. Beatriz was Isabel's. She is a living reminder of... before. I do not wish to erase that memory, but Catalina needs to learn to rely on others as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She crosses back to you, her grey-green eyes serious.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: So. Donna Francesca, Donna Isabella, Doña Leonor. Three ladies for the Queen. And for the children—we bring nursemaids for Catalina? Or do we manage ourselves, with the ladies' help?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do you think the ladies can nurse Catalina?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia raises an eyebrow, a hint of amusement playing at her lips.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Nurse her? She is weaned, husband. She eats bread and cheese and those dried apricots she hoards like a dragon with gold. She does not require a wet nurse.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She softens slightly, realizing you may have meant something broader.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: If you mean tend to her—feed her, change her, watch her, keep her from throwing herself off the ship in pursuit of a seagull—Francesca raised three younger siblings before entering service. Isabella is capable with children, though she has less experience. Doña Leonor... I do not know. But between the three of them, and between us...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She steps closer, placing a hand on your arm.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Juan. On this voyage, Catalina will not be raised by servants while we attend to matters of state in separate chambers. We will be on a ship. A large ship, yes, but still a ship. She will be with us—eating with us, sleeping near us, underfoot constantly. I think we can manage one small girl between five adults. And if we cannot, then we have no business raising her at all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She pauses, then adds more practically:

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: But we should bring one nursemaid. Someone young and sturdy, who can handle the less dignified tasks—the night wakings, the soiled linens, the moments when Catalina decides she hates everyone and everything. The ladies should not be scrubbing small clothes, and neither should the Queen of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: SO one nursemaid. And we should ask the portugese ladies ourself. We go to the four ladies from portugal and explain that we will be taking one with us to Constantinople it they want. Beatriz will stay with Fernando.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia plan the selection of ladies-in-waiting for their voyage to Constantinople. They decide on three ladies: Donna Francesca and Donna Isabella from Lucia's Italian household, plus Doña Leonor de Almeida from the Portuguese ladies. Doña Beatriz will remain in Toledo with Prince Fernando. They also decide to bring one nursemaid for Princess Catalina.
