The ladies should not be scrubbing small clothes, and neither should the Queen of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So one nursemaid. And we should ask the Portuguese ladies ourself. We go to the four ladies from portugal and explain that we will be taking one with us to Constantinople if they want. Beatriz will stay with Fernando.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find the Portuguese ladies in their shared quarters—a comfortable suite of rooms near the nursery that has been their domain since Isabel's time. They are engaged in quiet afternoon activities: needlework, reading, soft conversation. When you and Lucia enter, all four rise and curtsey.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz, the eldest at perhaps thirty-five, shows a flicker of concern at the unexpected royal visit. The others—Doña Leonor de Almeida, Doña Maria de Sousa, and Doña Inês de Castro—arrange themselves with the practiced grace of women accustomed to court life.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You explain the situation: the voyage to Constantinople in spring, the decision to leave Prince Fernando in Toledo with a trusted household, the need for one Portuguese lady to accompany Queen Lucia and Princess Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz's face cycles through several emotions—relief, perhaps, that she will remain with Fernando, but also something that might be loss at being separated from Catalina, whom she has tended since birth. She nods slowly, accepting.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_portugal
exchanges.text: I understand, Your Majesty. Prince Fernando is so young. He needs constancy. I will care for him as if he were my own.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: Your Majesties... this voyage. Constantinople. It is a great honor to be considered. But—may I ask—what would be required of us? And... how long would we be away from Castile?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A few months. And the main reason I would like one of you with us, is because I want to honour the Portuguese heritage she has.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words land softly in the room. Doña Beatriz's eyes glisten briefly before she looks away, composing herself. The younger ladies exchange glances again, the weight of what you have said settling over them.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: You wish Catalina to remember... to know where she comes from. Who her mother was.

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: The Princess is half Portuguese. Our Queen Isabel—God rest her soul—would have wanted her daughter to know Portugal. To speak some Portuguese. To understand that part of herself.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I would be honored to accompany you. I was with Queen Isabel from Lisbon to Toledo. I held Princess Catalina the night she was born, when— I would like to be there as she sees the world beyond Castile. To tell her stories of her mother's homeland. To teach her the words Queen Isabel would have taught her.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: If you will have me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Doña Maria, you are quiet. What would you say?

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I... Doña Leonor speaks well, and she was closer to Queen Isabel than I. She held the Princess that night, as she said. I was outside the chamber, praying.

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: I am not eloquent. I do not have Leonor's way with words or her... gentleness. But I have sailed before—my father held lands near Setúbal, and I spent my childhood on boats. I do not grow sick on the water. I am also told I am stubborn as a mule and twice as hard to move. If the Princess needs someone to chase her across a ship's deck and haul her back from the railings, I am perhaps better suited than Leonor.

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: But Leonor knew our Queen better. She can speak of Isabel with... with love. With memory. I can only speak of duty.

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: If you ask what I want, Your Majesty? I want to see Constantinople before I die. I want to be useful. And I want the Princess to grow up knowing that Portuguese women are not merely decorative. But I will not quarrel with whatever you decide.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Doña Inês. How about you?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Inês startles slightly at being addressed, color rising to her pale cheeks. She is the youngest of the four—barely eighteen, with the kind of delicate, almost ethereal beauty that poets write about and practical mothers worry over.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: I... Your Majesty, I am honored to be asked.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: I have never sailed. I have never been farther from home than Toledo. I came to Castile because my family thought... they thought service to a queen would be a good match for me. That I might meet...

exchanges.speaker: maria_de_sousa
exchanges.text: A husband.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: Yes. I am not brave like Maria. I am not warm like Leonor. I do not know what I would offer the Princess, except... except that I loved Queen Isabel. She was kind to me when I was frightened and far from home. She told me that courage is not the absence of fear, but choosing to act despite it.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: If you asked me to go, I would go. I would be terrified, but I would go. Because Queen Isabel would have wanted someone to be brave for her daughter, even if they were afraid.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: But I do not think I am the right choice. Leonor or Maria would serve you better.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I look at Lucia. It seems there are two suitable doñas who are willing to go. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia has been watching the exchange with quiet attention, her grey-green eyes moving from one woman to the next as each spoke. Now she considers, her expression thoughtful.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia meet with the four Portuguese ladies to discuss selecting one to accompany them to Constantinople. Beatriz will stay with Fernando. Leonor offers her close connection to Isabel and experience with Catalina, while Maria emphasizes her practical sailing experience. Inês expresses willingness despite her fears. The decision remains open as Lucia considers the options.

exchanges.speaker: dona_ines
exchanges.text: I have never sailed. I have never been farther from home than Toledo. I came to Castile because my family thought... they thought service to a queen would be a good match for me. That I might meet... A husband. Yes. I am not brave like Maria. I am not warm like Leonor. I do not know what I would offer the Princess, except... except that I loved Queen Isabel. She was kind to me when I was frightened and far from home. She told me that courage is not the absence of fear, but choosing to act despite it.

exchanges.speaker: dona_ines
exchanges.text: If you asked me to go, I would go. I would be terrified, but I would go. Because Queen Isabel would have wanted someone to be brave for her daughter, even if they were afraid. But I do not think I am the right choice. Leonor or Maria would serve you better.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I look at Lucia. It seems there are two suitable dona's who are willing to go. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: Two very different women. Leonor has the heart. She knew Isabel, loved her, can speak of her to Catalina with warmth and memory. She is gentle, and gentleness matters with children. But Maria has the stomach—literally. A sea voyage to Constantinople is not a pleasure cruise down the Tagus. If Leonor spends the journey green-faced and miserable, she will be of little use to anyone, no matter how pure her intentions.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: Maria is also right that chasing a twenty-month-old across a ship requires a certain... stubbornness. Catalina is sweet, but she is also fast, curious, and entirely without fear. Leonor might lose her overboard while composing a sonnet about the sunset. But there is something to be said for what Leonor offers. Catalina will have plenty of practical women around her—myself, Francesca, Isabella, the nursemaid. What she may lack is someone who can speak of Isabel with love, not just duty. Someone who can tell her stories of her mother as a person, not just a queen.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: If I must choose? Leonor. We can tie her to the mast if she gets seasick. But I would hear your thoughts, husband. This is your daughter's heritage we are preserving.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do you think we can take Maria with us and not a nursemaid?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: Maria is capable—that much is clear. And she has offered to chase Catalina across the deck, which is half of what a nursemaid does. But there is a difference between a lady-in-waiting who helps with a child and a nursemaid whose sole duty is that child. Night wakings—when Catalina cries at two in the morning because she has had a nightmare or wet herself, who rises? A nursemaid expects this. A lady-in-waiting... It is not the same. Soiled linens, the washing, the endless small tasks that are beneath a noblewoman's station but must be done regardless.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: I mean no offense. You are clearly competent and willing. But would you scrub a child's soiled clothes? Would you rise three times in a night without complaint? Would you accept being, in essence, a servant rather than a companion? If Maria is willing to blur that line—truly willing, not merely saying what she thinks we wish to hear—then yes, perhaps we can manage without a separate nursemaid. But she should answer for herself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is settled then. We take Leonor and a nursemaid, and your two Italian ladies. There will be another moment for Maria to see Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: dona_maria
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is wise. There will be other journeys, God willing. And someone must remain to help Doña Beatriz manage the household in your absence.

exchanges.speaker: dona_leonor
exchanges.text: Thank you, Your Majesty. I will not fail you—or the Princess. I will tell her of Portugal, of her mother, of the sea that connects our kingdoms. Queen Isabel would have wanted her daughter to see Constantinople. I am honored to be the one who carries that piece of her memory on the voyage.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz reaches out and squeezes Leonor's hand—a brief, maternal gesture. Doña Inês looks quietly relieved, her shoulders relaxing almost imperceptibly. The prospect of a terrifying sea voyage has been lifted from her, and she seems to breathe easier for it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_este
exchanges.text: Then it is settled. Donna Francesca, Donna Isabella, and Doña Leonor will accompany us, along with a nursemaid to be selected. We sail in spring. I will speak with Francesca about finding a suitable girl—someone young, sturdy, and unlikely to be troubled by the sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Portuguese ladies curtsey again as you take your leave. Behind you, you hear Doña Beatriz murmur something soft to Leonor—advice, perhaps, or a blessing. The words are too quiet to catch, but the tone is unmistakably that of a mother sending a daughter into the world.

encounters.recap: Juan finalizes the selection of travel companions for the Constantinople voyage. After deliberation with Lucia, he chooses Doña Leonor for her emotional connection to Queen Isabel, along with Lucia's Italian ladies and a nursemaid. Doña Maria gracefully accepts remaining behind, while Doña Inês is visibly relieved to avoid the journey.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I ask about the status of the 700 knights that will sail with us to reinforce the city. Have they been assembled and have they visited the war academy as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro consults his documents when you summon him again, flipping through several pages before finding the relevant reports.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The seven hundred knights, Your Majesty. The Military Orders have fulfilled their commitments. Santiago provides three hundred, Calatrava two hundred and fifty, Alcántara one hundred and fifty. All assembled in Toledo as of last month.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets down one document and picks up another.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: As for the War Academy—Sir Thomas Beaumont has been thorough. The knights have been rotating through in groups of fifty over the past several weeks. They have received instruction in Ottoman tactics, siege warfare, the particular challenges of defending walls against Turkish artillery. Sir Thomas reports that the quality varies. The Order knights are experienced fighters, but many have spent their careers in the Reconquista. Fighting Granadans is not the same as fighting Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks up.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: His assessment: they are competent heavy cavalry and solid garrison troops. They will hold walls, sally when ordered, and die bravely if required. But they should not expect to defeat Ottoman field armies in open battle. Constantinople's defense depends on the walls, not on sorties.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro sets the document aside.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The knights are currently quartered outside Toledo, awaiting orders to march to Valencia. They can be ready to move within a week of your command. Sir Thomas recommends they spend the sea voyage reviewing what they have learned—he has prepared written materials for the ship captains to distribute. Is there anything specific you wish Sir Thomas to emphasize before departure?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When should we depart? I want to go as soon as possible. The weather has constrained us as this was the main reason we would not travel in the winter. But how soon can we go?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro considers the question carefully, setting aside his documents.

encounters.recap: Juan receives a comprehensive status report on the 700 knights from the Military Orders who will sail to Constantinople. All have been assembled in Toledo and trained at the War Academy in Ottoman tactics, though their experience is primarily against Granada rather than the Ottomans. The knights are ready to march to Valencia within a week, and Juan presses for the earliest possible departure date.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The seven hundred knights, Your Majesty. The Military Orders have fulfilled their commitments. Santiago provides three hundred, Calatrava two hundred and fifty, Alcántara one hundred and fifty. All assembled in Toledo as of last month.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: As for the War Academy—Sir Thomas Beaumont has been thorough. The knights have been rotating through in groups of fifty over the past several weeks. They have received instruction in Ottoman tactics, siege warfare, the particular challenges of defending walls against Turkish artillery. Sir Thomas reports that the quality varies. The Order knights are experienced fighters, but many have spent their careers in the Reconquista. Fighting Granadans is not the same as fighting Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: His assessment: they are competent heavy cavalry and solid garrison troops. They will hold walls, sally when ordered, and die bravely if required. But they should not expect to defeat Ottoman field armies in open battle. Constantinople's defense depends on the walls, not on sorties. The knights are currently quartered outside Toledo, awaiting orders to march to Valencia. They can be ready to move within a week of your command. Sir Thomas recommends they spend the sea voyage reviewing what they have learned—he has prepared written materials for the ship captains to distribute.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When should we depart? I want to go as soon as possible. The weather has constrained us as this was the main reason we would not travel in the winter. But how soon can we go?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The constraints are threefold, Your Majesty: the roads, the seas, and the readiness of the fleet. The roads from Toledo to Valencia—in deep winter, they are passable but miserable. Mud, cold, the risk of storms. With a carriage for the Princess, progress would be slow. By late February, conditions improve significantly. By March, they are reliable.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Mediterranean in winter is treacherous. Genoese captains will not sail in January or early February—the storms are too unpredictable, the days too short. Mid-March is when the sailing season traditionally begins. Experienced captains might risk early March if the weather seems favorable, but earlier than that... You would struggle to find crews willing to make the voyage, and those who agreed would charge dearly for the risk.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The fleet at Valencia is nearly ready. Provisioning continues, but by the first week of March, all vessels could be fully supplied and seaworthy. If you depart Toledo in late February, you arrive in Valencia in mid-March—perhaps ten days to two weeks on the road with the carriage. The fleet sails as soon as you arrive and conditions permit. With fair winds, you reach Rome in ten to fourteen days. Then onward to Constantinople. The earliest practical departure from Toledo: the last week of February. The earliest realistic arrival in Constantinople: late April, perhaps early May. Sooner than that, and you risk the Princess's health on bad roads or the entire expedition's safety on winter seas.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Send a message now, I want to visit Barcelona as well and meet with my sister and the Cortes there. Or maybe not the Cortes, but the nobles there. We need allies in Aragon in the days to come. We leave mid-January for Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Mid-January, Your Majesty. That is... Three weeks from now. Perhaps less. The road to Barcelona is longer than to Valencia—nearly twice the distance. In January, through Aragón, with a carriage for the Princess... It can be done. But it will not be comfortable. Cold, slow, and with risk of delays if the weather turns foul.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your sister Queen María remains in Barcelona while King Alfonso pursues Naples. She holds court there as regent in his absence. The Aragonese nobles... They are not Castilians, Your Majesty. They guard their privileges fiercely—the fueros of Aragón limit royal authority in ways that would seem strange to a Castilian king. They will receive you with courtesy as their Queen's brother and as the conqueror of Granada, but they will also be watching. Assessing.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: What message shall I send to Queen María? And do you wish the visit announced publicly, or would you prefer to arrive with less ceremony—a brother visiting his sister, rather than a king visiting a kingdom? And—forgive me, Your Majesty—but does Queen Lucia know you intend to take the Princess through the Aragonese winter in three weeks' time?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A brother visiting his sister and to mark the excellent relations and alliance between the two kingdoms. We make it clear that we have been happy to help Aragon win Naples and mark this as an example what can happen when we work together.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: A family visit with political undertones, rather than a formal state occasion. That gives you flexibility—you can speak frankly with nobles without the rigidity of a Cortes, accept or decline invitations as suits your purpose, and leave when you wish rather than when protocol permits. I will draft a letter to Queen María informing her of your intention to visit in late January—a brother's visit, to share in the joy of the Aragonese successes in Naples and to strengthen the bonds between your kingdoms. I will emphasize that you travel with your wife and daughter, that this is a family matter, not a diplomatic mission requiring elaborate preparation.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Though of course, the Aragonese nobles will understand perfectly well what such a visit means. The King of Castile does not travel to Barcelona in winter merely to embrace his sister. They will prepare accordingly—you may find yourself receiving visitors whether you invite them or not. The news of Granada's conquest has spread throughout Christendom. The news that Castilian gold and ships support Alfonso's Naples campaign has spread through Aragón specifically. You will be received as a king worth cultivating, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Shall I also send word to Valencia to expect the fleet's departure delayed until after your Barcelona visit? Or do you intend to proceed from Barcelona directly to Valencia and sail from there?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We sail as soon as possible. Until we sail away, I want to use the time productively. We leave in three weeks or so. Is the carriage ready? I want to test if Catalina can travel with the carriage if possible.

encounters.recap: Juan II decides to accelerate his departure timeline, planning to visit Barcelona in mid-January before sailing to Constantinople. Despite Álvaro's concerns about winter travel conditions, the king chooses to frame the Barcelona visit as a family meeting with political undertones to strengthen Castilian-Aragonese relations and cultivate noble allies.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The carriage is nearly complete, Your Majesty. The wheelwright has finished the suspension—springs designed to soften the worst of the road. The interior is being fitted now: padded benches, curtains against the cold, space enough for the Princess, a nursemaid, and one companion.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It could be ready for a test journey within the week. Five days, perhaps, if I press the craftsmen.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: A test journey is wise. The Princess has never traveled by carriage—we do not know if she will tolerate confinement for hours at a time, or if she will find it unbearable. Better to discover this on a short trip near Toledo than halfway to Barcelona in a January snowstorm.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: We might send her on the road to Aranjuez and back—a day's journey each way, flat terrain, easy return if something goes wrong. Or if you prefer to accompany her, perhaps a circuit to one of the nearby hunting lodges? Close enough that if the Princess proves... resistant... to carriage travel, you could abandon the experiment without great disruption.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Princess has strong opinions, Your Majesty. If she decides she hates the carriage, we will all know it within the first hour. Better that hour be spent near Toledo than near Zaragoza.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, in five days me, Catalina and Lucia will leave on a short journey so Catalina gets comfortable with travel. She can switch between horse travel and carriage travel. In fact, we take the ladies with us as well. I want to see how good they can travel.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: It will be done, Your Majesty. The carriage completed within five days, provisioned for a short journey. I will arrange an escort—smaller than the Madrid trip, perhaps twenty men-at-arms. Enough for safety without the burden of a large column.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: For destination, I suggest Aranjuez. It lies south along the Tagus, perhaps seven leagues—a comfortable day's ride, or somewhat longer with the carriage setting the pace. The royal lodge there is modest but adequate, and the roads are well-maintained. You could depart one morning, arrive by evening, rest a day, and return. Three days total.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This will test everything: the carriage's construction, the Princess's tolerance for confinement, the ladies' ability to travel, and how well the entire party moves together. If something fails—a wheel, a temperament, a stomach—Aranjuez is close enough that we can manage.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: If the Princess proves unable to tolerate the carriage, we will know. And we will have time before Barcelona to consider alternatives—though I confess I am not certain what alternatives exist for a child who refuses both carriage and extended horseback.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: She will do fine. Lets get going with this plan.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find them in the nursery, where Catalina is engaged in a serious negotiation with her wooden animals. She has arranged them in a line and appears to be lecturing them about something—the words are unclear, but the tone is unmistakably authoritative. Lucia sits nearby, watching with quiet amusement while Donna Francesca mends a small tear in one of Catalina's gowns.

encounters.recap: Juan decides to test the new royal carriage with a short family journey to Aranjuez. The three-day trip will include Catalina, Lucia, and the court ladies to evaluate their traveling capabilities before the planned Barcelona visit. Álvaro arranges for the carriage to be completed within five days with appropriate provisions and escort.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find them in the nursery, where Catalina is engaged in a serious negotiation with her wooden animals. She has arranged them in a line and appears to be lecturing them about something—the words are unclear, but the tone is unmistakably authoritative. Lucia sits nearby, watching with quiet amusement while Donna Francesca mends a small tear in one of Catalina's gowns.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We have plans to discuss.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Plans that involve packing, I suspect.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You explain: the test journey to Aranjuez in five days, the carriage being prepared, the intention to see how Catalina manages both carriage and horseback over a longer trip. Then the larger journey—Barcelona in mid-January to visit your sister María, then onward to Valencia and the fleet.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Barcelona in January. Through Aragón. And Catalina in a carriage she has never seen, on roads she has never traveled, for weeks on end.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina go? On horses?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: On horses sometimes. And sometimes in a special box with wheels. A carriage. Like a little room that moves.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Box?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: A moving box. With cushions. And windows to look out. And room for Lucia-mama to sit with you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama come?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Yes, tesoro. Lucia-mama comes. And Papá. And some of the ladies.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina see box first?

encounters.recap: Juan explains the travel plans to his family in the nursery—first a test journey to Aranjuez, then a larger expedition to Barcelona and Valencia. Catalina shows cautious interest in the carriage concept but wants to see it first. Lucia notes the challenges of the winter journey through Aragón with a young child.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama come?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Yes, tesoro. Lucia-mama comes. And Papá. And some of the ladies.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina see box first?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The carriage stands in the courtyard, freshly finished and gleaming in the pale winter sunlight. The craftsmen have done excellent work on short notice—the body is sturdy oak, painted in deep Castilian crimson with subtle gold trim along the edges. The wheels are large and well-made, the iron fittings solid. The suspension system—leather straps and metal springs—looks robust enough to soften the worst jolts. The wheelwright stands nearby, nervous pride evident on his weathered face.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You help Lucia up the small folding steps, then lift Catalina to inspect the interior. The space is compact but well-designed: two padded benches facing each other, covered in dark wool cushions. Heavy curtains hang at the windows—they can be drawn against cold or opened for light and air. A small compartment beneath one bench holds blankets and provisions. The ceiling is high enough for an adult to sit comfortably without stooping.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: See outside!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Soft.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Box is good. Box moves now?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She wants a demonstration, husband. I think we must oblige her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia settles onto one of the padded benches, arranging her skirts, and holds out her arms for Catalina. Your daughter clambers across to her with the graceless enthusiasm of toddlerhood, immediately claiming the window seat.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina's spot.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Cosy.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The craftsmen have done well. It is warmer than I expected. And the cushions are thick enough to soften the road, I think. Well, husband? Shall we see if your daughter approves of movement, or only of sitting in stationary boxes?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá come inside too?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Papá will ride alongside on Hidalgo. Watching over us.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá protect. Go now! Box moves!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The driver clicks his tongue and the two sturdy horses lean into their harnesses. The carriage lurches forward—Catalina's face appears immediately at the window, eyes wide with delight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Moving! Box moving!

encounters.recap: Juan inspects the newly completed carriage with Lucia and Catalina. The toddler delights in exploring the interior, declaring it 'good' and 'cosy.' After settling Lucia and Catalina inside with blankets, Juan mounts Hidalgo to begin testing the carriage with a short ride, with Catalina excitedly watching the movement through the window.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Well, husband? Shall we see if your daughter approves of movement, or only of sitting in stationary boxes?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá come inside too?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Papá will ride alongside on Hidalgo. Watching over us.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá protect. Go now! Box moves!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The driver clicks his tongue and the two sturdy horses lean into their harnesses. The carriage lurches forward—Catalina's face appears immediately at the window, eyes wide with delight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Moving! Box moving!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You guide Hidalgo alongside as the small procession makes its way through Toledo's streets and out the southern gate. A handful of guards follow at a respectful distance—enough for propriety, not so many as to make this feel like a royal progress. The winter sun hangs low, casting long shadows across the road. The first quarter hour goes splendidly. Catalina maintains her position at the window, providing breathless commentary on everything she sees: 'Trees! Man with donkey! Birds!' Her enthusiasm is inexhaustible. Through the glass, you catch glimpses of Lucia smiling, occasionally pointing out something Catalina has missed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the half hour mark, Catalina has discovered that the carriage's movement creates interesting effects when she bounces on the cushions. The suspension absorbs most of it, but you hear Lucia's muffled voice saying something cautionary. At forty-five minutes, Catalina's face appears at the window again, but her expression has shifted. She looks... thoughtful. Perhaps slightly pale.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá, box moves too much.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She was bouncing. Enthusiastically. I suspect the combination of movement and bouncing has disagreed with her breakfast.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Want horse now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You bring Hidalgo alongside the carriage and reach through the window. Lucia lifts Catalina up—she is indeed slightly pale, her earlier enthusiasm dampened—and you settle her on the saddle before you, wrapping your cloak around her small body. She burrows against your chest immediately, one hand finding its customary grip on Hidalgo's mane. The cold air seems to help; after a few minutes, the color begins returning to her cheeks.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Better. Horse better than box.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The bouncing was her own doing. She discovered that if she jumped at just the right moment, she could make herself go higher. I believe she thought it was a game until her stomach disagreed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: After another fifteen minutes, the pallor has faded entirely. Catalina sits up straighter, looking around with renewed interest. She spots a farmer leading an ox cart in the opposite direction and waves imperiously. The farmer, recognizing the royal colors, bows so deeply he nearly falls over.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Man fell down.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He was bowing to you, mi pequeña. You are a princess.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina make people fall down?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From the carriage, you hear Lucia laugh.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse. Box good for sleeping. Horse good for... for seeing. For fast.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She pats Hidalgo's neck with her free hand, a gesture she has clearly copied from watching you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse is friend. Box is just box.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: A diplomat's answer, tesoro. You have learned that from your father.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina ride horse to Barcelona? With Papá?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The return journey to Toledo stretches before you—an hour's ride at an easy pace. Your daughter settles against your chest, warm beneath the cloak, her earlier queasiness apparently forgotten. The carriage rumbles alongside, Lucia visible through the window, the guards trailing behind. A family, traveling together. Testing the roads that will carry them across kingdoms.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can ride with papa until you get tired and you can then rest in the carriage. Do you think you can do that?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina ride. Then sleep in box. Then ride again?

encounters.recap: During a test journey with the new carriage, young Catalina becomes nauseous from bouncing enthusiastically on the cushions. She transfers to ride with Juan on Hidalgo, recovering quickly in the fresh air. When asked to choose between horse and carriage, she diplomatically declares the horse better for seeing and speed, while the carriage is good for sleeping.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The armory sessions are humbling. Months of councils and ceremonies have softened the reflexes that the Reconquista honed sharp. The first time you don the full harness, the weight feels unfamiliar—not unbearable, but no longer the second skin it once was. You spend hours over the following weeks reacquainting yourself with its constraints: the limited vision of the helm, the way the gorget restricts your neck, the particular balance required to mount Hidalgo in full plate. By the second week, the old rhythms begin to return. By the third, you can move without thinking about the steel encasing you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning of departure dawns cold and grey, a thin frost coating the courtyard stones. The column is assembling beyond the gates—the carriage, the escort, the packhorses laden with provisions and baggage. Donna Francesca, Donna Isabella, and Doña Leonor wait with the other ladies, their breath misting in the chill air. But first, the nursery.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando lies in his cradle, awake but calm, his dark eyes tracking the movement of a cloth rabbit that Doña Beatriz dangles above him. At four months, he has grown considerably—his cheeks have filled out, his limbs grown sturdy. He makes small sounds of contentment as the rabbit dances. When you approach, his gaze shifts to you. There is recognition there, you think—or perhaps only the instinctive attention an infant pays to faces. He does not smile yet, not truly, but his expression softens.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, he has been fed and changed. He will sleep soon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You look down at your son—this small life you are leaving behind for months, trusting to others' care while you sail to the edge of Christendom.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sleep the heavenly sleep Fernando. I will be back soon. Beatriz, I know you will take good care of him. I see you soon when I get back.

encounters.recap: Juan spends final weeks retraining in armor to prepare for the voyage, gradually recovering his warrior reflexes. On the cold morning of departure, he visits the nursery to bid farewell to his infant son Fernando, entrusting the child to Doña Beatriz's care.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sleep the heavenly sleep Fernando. I will be back soon. Beatriz, I know you will take good care of him. I see you soon when I get back.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You reach down and touch Fernando's cheek—soft, warm, impossibly delicate. He turns his head slightly toward your hand, an instinctive seeking. His dark eyes, so like Isabel's, hold yours for a long moment. Then his eyelids grow heavy, the rabbit forgotten, and he begins to drift toward sleep. The journey to Constantinople means nothing to him. He knows only warmth, milk, the familiar faces that appear above his cradle. The world beyond this room does not yet exist.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: I will guard him with my life, Your Majesty. When you return, he will be sitting up, perhaps. Reaching for things. Growing into the prince he will become. Queen Isabel... she would be proud of what you are doing. Sailing to defend Christendom. Taking Catalina to see the world. I will tell him stories of his father while you are gone. So he knows your voice when you return, even if he cannot remember why.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From somewhere beyond the nursery, you hear Catalina's voice—imperious, excited, demanding to know why the horses are not moving yet. Lucia's calm reply is too quiet to make out. The column waits. Constantinople waits. The future waits. But for this moment, there is only a sleeping infant, a faithful guardian, and the weight of leaving.

encounters.recap: On the morning of departure for Constantinople, Juan visits the nursery to bid farewell to his four-month-old son Fernando. Doña Beatriz promises to care for the prince and tell him stories of his father. The tender moment captures the weight of leaving his infant son for months while sailing to defend Christendom.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: I will guard him with my life, Your Majesty. When you return, he will be sitting up, perhaps. Reaching for things. Growing into the prince he will become. Queen Isabel... she would be proud of what you are doing. Sailing to defend Christendom. Taking Catalina to see the world. I will tell him stories of his father while you are gone. So he knows your voice when you return, even if he cannot remember why.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From somewhere beyond the nursery, you hear Catalina's voice—imperious, excited, demanding to know why the horses are not moving yet. Lucia's calm reply is too quiet to make out. The column waits. Constantinople waits. The future waits. But for this moment, there is only a sleeping infant, a faithful guardian, and the weight of leaving.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The realm will be here when you return. The reforms continue. The Council of Great Houses meets next month. Diego's tax collectors grow bolder by the week. I will try not to let everything collapse in your absence. Bring Constantinople our steel. Remind the Ottomans that Christendom still has teeth. And come home safely. Castile needs its king. Your children need their father. God speed you, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He clasps your arm—a rare gesture of familiarity from a man who guards propriety carefully. Then he steps back, the moment of warmth passing, the administrator returning. You mount Hidalgo and ride to where Lucia waits on Tormenta, the carriage standing ready nearby. Catalina is in Doña Leonor's arms, bundled against the cold, her small riding crop already clutched in one hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá! Catalina ready! We go now!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá. Catalina start with Papá.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You settle Catalina before you on the saddle, wrapping your cloak around her small form. She grips Hidalgo's mane with practiced determination, her riding crop tucked under one arm.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will ride for many days. Through hills and valleys. We will sleep in different places—castles, towns, inns. Some nights will be cold. Some days will be long. But Papá will be there, and Lucia-mama, and the ladies. Then we come to Barcelona. A great city by the sea. Aunt María lives there—she is Papá's sister. After Barcelona, we go on a ship. A great wooden vessel that floats on the water—bigger than any boat you have seen. It will carry us across the sea to Rome. And Rome is where Lucia-mama comes from.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Where I grew up, tesoro. I will show you.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: To Constantinople! In Nomine Patrii!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hidalgo surges forward, hooves striking sparks from the cobblestones. Catalina shrieks with delight, clutching the mane tighter as the cold wind rushes past. Behind you, the column lurches into motion—the carriage rumbling forward, Lucia urging Tormenta to match your pace, the escort falling in formation, the packhorses following. The banner of Castile snaps in the winter wind, crimson and gold against the grey sky. The gates of Toledo pass on either side, the guards saluting as you ride through. Citizens line the streets despite the early hour and the cold, drawn by word that the king departs for distant Constantinople. The column settles into its rhythm. The city falls behind. The winter sun climbs higher, pale but bright. The journey has begun.

encounters.recap: Juan II makes final farewells in Toledo before departing for Constantinople. After emotional goodbyes with infant Fernando and Álvaro de Luna, he mounts Hidalgo with young Catalina and leads the expedition column out of the city gates, beginning the long journey to Barcelona and ultimately to defend Constantinople against Ottoman forces.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey began well and never faltered. The weather held clear across the Meseta—cold but dry, the winter sun bright enough to warm faces by midday. Lucia's morning sickness, which had plagued her in Toledo, eased once they were moving; she claimed the rhythm of the carriage settled her stomach better than lying still. By the third day, she was riding Tormenta again in the afternoons, her color returned, laughing at something Donna Francesca said.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina proved herself the seasoned traveler her father had trained. She alternated between Hidalgo and the carriage without complaint, napped when told, and provided running commentary on everything she saw—sheep ("fluffy"), olive trees ("not fluffy"), mountains ("big rocks"), and the knights behind them ("Papá's friends with crosses"). The Aragonese villagers who lined the roads to watch them pass fell in love with the little princess who waved her riding crop at them like a tiny monarch reviewing troops.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Word of the Reconquista had indeed spread. In Calatayud, the town council presented Juan with a silver cup engraved with the date of Granada's fall. In Zaragoza, the Archbishop himself came out to bless the column, and church bells rang for an hour. The 700 knights, far from straining local resources, found themselves showered with gifts—local wines, cured hams, warm bread pressed into their hands by women who wanted to touch men who had driven the Moors from Iberia forever.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But the remarkable thing happened on the seventh day, in the town of Fraga, halfway between Zaragoza and Lérida. It was a rest day—the horses needed shoeing, two wagon axles required repair, and Lucia had woken pale and queasy after a difficult night. The royal party had taken rooms at the largest inn Fraga could offer, a rambling stone building called La Casa del Puente for its view of the old Roman bridge over the Cinca River.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By midafternoon, the adults were occupied. Juan was meeting with the local alcalde about provisioning. Lucia slept in the upstairs chamber, Donna Francesca watching over her. Doña Leonor had gone to the market to purchase fresh fruit. The nursemaid—a young woman named Inés—had been minding Catalina in the inn's small courtyard. What happened next was pieced together afterward from a dozen witnesses. Inés had turned away for perhaps three minutes—she would later weep and beg forgiveness, certain she would be dismissed—to help a servant carry water. When she turned back, Princess Catalina was gone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The courtyard gate stood open. A merchant's cart had passed through moments before, and in the bustle, a twenty-month-old princess had simply walked out into Fraga. The alarm spread quickly. Captain Fernán mobilized every available man. The town was not large—perhaps two thousand souls—but it was crowded with the Castilian column, and the streets were a maze of medieval alleys branching off from the market square.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: For nearly an hour, soldiers searched. Lucia, woken by the commotion, stood white-faced in the inn's doorway, Donna Francesca gripping her arm. The townspeople joined the hunt, calling "¡La Princesa! ¡La Princesita!" They found her at the river. The old Roman bridge had a low stone parapet—knee-height to an adult, chest-height to a toddler. Below it, the Cinca ran cold and fast with winter snowmelt, deep enough to drown a grown man.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A crowd had gathered at the bridge's eastern approach, blocking traffic. When Captain Fernán pushed through, sword drawn and face thunderous, he stopped dead. Princess Catalina sat on the cobblestones beside the parapet, her small hand resting on the head of a child—a boy of perhaps four years, soaking wet and shivering violently, wrapped in Catalina's own wool traveling cloak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: An old woman was telling the story to anyone who would listen, gesturing wildly: "The boy—he's Tomás, the fuller's son—he was playing on the parapet, the little fool, and he slipped. Went right into the river. His mother screamed, but who could reach him? The current had him. He was going under. Then this little one—this baby—she walked right up to the bridge like she knew exactly where she was going. She didn't cry, didn't call for help. She picked up a rope that the fishermen leave coiled by the mooring post—how did she even know it was there?—and she threw it. Threw it right to the boy. He grabbed it, and she held on."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The old woman crossed herself. "She's no bigger than a lamb, but she held that rope while three men ran to pull the boy out. Wouldn't let go. When they tried to take it from her, she said—" the woman's voice broke with something between laughter and tears, "—she said, 'No. Catalina helping.'"

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Boy warm now? Boy not cold?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the time Juan arrived, the fuller and his wife were on their knees before their princess, weeping, trying to kiss her hands. Catalina looked profoundly unimpressed by this attention. The story spread through Fraga like fire through dry brush. By evening, the priests were calling it a miracle—the Holy Virgin guiding the infant princess's steps. By the next morning, when the column prepared to depart, half the town had gathered to see her off.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina helped. Boy was wet. Now boy is dry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The story would be told in Fraga for generations. They would build a small shrine at the bridge—La Capilla de la Princesita—and every year on the anniversary, the town would process to the river to give thanks. Tomás the fuller's son would grow up to become a priest, and he would tell the story of the princess who saved him until the day he died, always ending the same way: "She was not yet two years old. And she did not hesitate."

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am so proud of you Catalina! You helped someone. That is one of the greatest things one can do. We must always help others.

roll.outcome: Remarkable Fortune. Princess Catalina saves a drowning boy in Fraga, creating a legendary story that will be told for generations.

encounters.recap: The royal journey from Toledo to Barcelona proceeds exceptionally well with favorable weather and enthusiastic reception from Aragonese towns celebrating the Reconquista. The remarkable event occurs in Fraga when twenty-month-old Princess Catalina wanders away from her nursemaid and saves a drowning boy by throwing him a rope and holding it until help arrives. The miracle becomes legendary, leading to the construction of a shrine and annual commemorations.

exchanges.text: Before we leave I lift Catalina up high.

encounters.recap: During a rest day in Fraga, twenty-month-old Princess Catalina wanders from the inn and performs a miraculous rescue at the old Roman bridge. When a four-year-old boy falls into the fast-flowing Cinca River, Catalina throws him a rope and holds it while men pull him to safety. The townspeople hail it as a miracle, and the story spreads throughout Aragon. A shrine will be built to commemorate the event.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the afternoon of the eleventh day since leaving Toledo, the column crested the final ridge of the coastal range and saw Barcelona spread before them—red rooftops tumbling down toward the glittering Mediterranean, the great cathedral rising above the old Roman walls, ships crowding the harbor like floating houses. Catalina stared at the sea—the first time she had ever seen it.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Big water. Very big water.

exchanges.speaker: queen_lucia
exchanges.text: That's the sea, pequeña. And somewhere beyond it is Rome, where I was born. And beyond that, Constantinople, where your father's knights will go to help people who need them.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina help Constantinople too?

exchanges.speaker: queen_lucia
exchanges.text: Someday, perhaps. When you are older.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina older soon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The gates of Barcelona opened before them. Trumpets sounded from the walls. A herald's voice rang out across the afternoon air: 'His Most Catholic Majesty Juan the Second, King of Castile and León, Conqueror of Granada! Her Majesty Queen Lucia! Her Royal Highness the Infanta Catalina!' And there, waiting in the plaza before the cathedral, surrounded by the nobles of Aragon and attended by her household, stood Queen María—Juan's sister, regent of Aragon in her husband Alfonso's absence. She was thirty-one years old, tall like all the Trastámaras, her dark hair threaded with the first hints of grey. She had not seen her brother in nearly four years—not since before the Reconquista, before his marriage to Isabel, before everything that had transformed the young king she remembered into the man who rode toward her now. Her composure held for precisely three seconds. Then she was moving forward, protocol forgotten, her ladies scrambling to keep up.

exchanges.speaker: queen_maria
exchanges.text: Juan. Oh, Juan.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have missed you Maria. I want to introduce you to queen Lucia and Catalina.

encounters.recap: The royal family arrives in Barcelona to a ceremonial welcome. Catalina sees the sea for the first time, and Juan is emotionally reunited with his sister Queen María, regent of Aragon, whom he has not seen in nearly four years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And there, waiting in the plaza before the cathedral, surrounded by the nobles of Aragon and attended by her household, stood Queen María—Juan's sister, regent of Aragon in her husband Alfonso's absence. She was thirty-one years old, tall like all the Trastámaras, her dark hair threaded with the first hints of grey. She had not seen her brother in nearly four years—not since before the Reconquista, before his marriage to Isabel, before everything that had transformed the young king she remembered into the man who rode toward her now. Her composure held for precisely three seconds. Then she was moving forward, protocol forgotten, her ladies scrambling to keep up.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Juan. Oh, Juan.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have missed you Maria. I want to introduce you to queen Lucia and Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María held Juan tightly, her composure abandoned entirely. When she finally pulled back, her eyes were bright with tears, though she was laughing.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Look at you. The boy who came through here four years ago, terrified he was in love with the wrong woman—and now you return a conqueror with a wife and daughter. I prayed for you every day, Juan. Every single day. When word came of Granada's fall, I wept for an hour. The servants thought someone had died.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She released him and straightened, visibly collecting herself back into the dignity expected of Aragon's regent. But her smile remained—warm and unguarded in a way she rarely permitted herself in public. At the mention of Lucia and Catalina, María turned toward where the Queen of Castile was being helped down from Tormenta by Donna Francesca. Lucia approached with the measured grace she had perfected in Ferrara's courts, but there was uncertainty in her grey-green eyes—she was meeting her husband's sister for the first time, a woman who had known Juan far longer than she had.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_este
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I have heard much of you from your brother. He speaks of your wisdom with great—

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: None of that. You are my sister now. We shall be María and Lucia to each other, at least when the ambassadors are not watching.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She studied Lucia's face with frank curiosity—not unkindly, but with the assessing gaze of a woman who had spent years navigating royal politics.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Italian. Ferrarese, yes? I can see it in the cheekbones. And my brother writes that you are formidable. Good. He needs someone formidable. The last time he was here, he nearly threw away a crusade for a pair of pretty eyes. I trust you will keep him focused.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Before Lucia could respond, a small imperious voice cut through the moment.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Leonor had carried Catalina forward, but the princess was squirming with obvious intent, reaching toward the ground. Once set on her feet, she straightened her traveling cloak—the new one, since the old had become a relic in Fraga—and walked directly up to Queen María with the confident stride of someone who had recently saved a life and knew her own worth. She stopped before her aunt, looked up, and conducted a thorough inspection. María, to her credit, stood very still and submitted to this examination.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: You are Papá's sister.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I am.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Like Fernando is Catalina's brother.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Exactly so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina nodded, satisfied with this evidence of proper family structure. Then she raised her arms in the universal toddler demand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Up. Catalina tired. You carry now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's composure cracked completely. She laughed—a full, delighted sound—and swept Catalina into her arms.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Oh, you are exactly like your father was at this age. Giving orders to everyone and expecting immediate obedience. I see you have already conquered Aragon, little one. The whole kingdom is talking about the Princess of the Rope.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Catalina helped. Boy was wet.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: So I heard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María looked over Catalina's head at Juan, her expression soft with an emotion beyond words.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: She has Isabel's eyes. Did you know? The shape of them. The way they watch everything.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The formal reception could wait no longer—the nobles of Aragon were growing restless, and protocol demanded acknowledgment. But María kept Catalina on her hip as she led the way toward the cathedral plaza, and the people of Barcelona watched their regent carry the little Castilian princess as though she were her own.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You will stay in the Palau Reial. I have prepared the old king's chambers—our father stayed there when he visited Barcelona. And there is much to discuss. Alfonso writes from Naples. The situation there is... complex. But that is for tomorrow. Tonight, we feast. Tonight, I have my brother back.

encounters.recap: Juan reunites with his sister María, regent of Aragon, after four years apart. She warmly welcomes Queen Lucia and is immediately charmed by Princess Catalina, who imperiously demands to be carried. The emotional reunion strengthens family bonds as María prepares to host them at the royal palace while hinting at complex political matters regarding Alfonso in Naples.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María waited until the formal reception had concluded and the nobles had dispersed to their lodgings before she drew Juan aside. They walked together through the cloisters of the Palau Reial, their footsteps echoing on ancient stone, while Lucia settled Catalina in the royal apartments with Doña Leonor.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I have news from Alfonso. A courier arrived three days ago from Sicily. I wanted to tell you in person, not in front of the Aragonese court.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She produced a letter from her sleeve—the seal already broken, the paper worn from multiple readings.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Louis of Anjou is dying. The physicians give him weeks, perhaps a month or two at most. The malaria he contracted last autumn—it never truly left him. He has been bedridden in Cosenza since November, unable to ride, barely able to hold a quill.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Alfonso landed forces at Reggio two weeks ago. Not a full invasion—a positioning. The Calabrian barons who had been waiting to see which way the wind blew are now declaring for Aragon. Three major houses switched allegiance in the past month alone. The Count of Catanzaro. The Duke of Sessa. The Prince of Taranto himself.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The papal endorsement you secured—Juan, you cannot know what that meant. The Angevins had always claimed legitimacy through Rome. When Eugenius declared for Alfonso, it cut the ground from beneath them. Italian princes who would never have risked supporting Aragon against a pope-backed Angevin are now free to follow their interests.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The letter was in Alfonso's own hand—cramped and hurried, written by a man with too much to do and not enough hours.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: He has changed. The defeat at Ponza—being captured, being ransomed, the humiliation of it—I thought it would break him. Instead it... refined him. He writes differently now. He thinks differently. Less glory, more strategy.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: He speaks of you constantly in his letters. 'Juan would understand.' 'Juan would approve.' 'When Juan hears of this.' You have become his measure, brother. The king who actually finished what he started.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: He asks about your Constantinople expedition. He wants to know if there is anything Aragon can provide. Ships. Supplies. Men, even, if you need them. He says that if Castile is going to save the Eastern Empire, Aragon should not be left out of the glory.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He should first help himself before he should help others. He should secure Naples first, then we can look towards new campaigns together.

roll.outcome: Significant Progress. Alfonso has achieved a breakthrough. He has landed forces in southern Italy and secured a major coastal stronghold. Louis III is dying and the Angevin cause is collapsing. Multiple Neapolitan nobles have switched sides.

encounters.recap: María privately informs Juan of Alfonso's breakthrough in the Naples campaign. Louis of Anjou is dying, Alfonso has landed at Reggio, major barons are switching sides, and the papal endorsement has isolated the Angevins diplomatically. Alfonso's approach has become more strategic and patient following his earlier defeats.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall of the Palau Reial had been dressed for the occasion—Aragonese banners alternating with Castilian lions along the walls, fresh rushes on the floor scented with rosemary, and enough candles to make the winter afternoon bright as summer noon. The nobles of Aragon and Catalonia had assembled in their finest: velvets and brocades, gold chains of office, swords polished to mirrors. María sat on the regent's throne—not the king's seat, which remained conspicuously empty, but the smaller chair beside it. She wore a gown of deep crimson, the colors of both Castile and Aragon meeting in her person. Juan entered with Lucia on his arm, Catalina walking between them holding both their hands. The princess had been bribed into good behavior with promises of crostatas afterward, and she maintained an expression of solemn dignity that would have done credit to a child twice her age.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The herald's voice rang out: "His Most Catholic Majesty Juan the Second, King of Castile and León, Conqueror of Granada! Her Majesty Queen Lucia of Castile! Her Royal Highness the Infanta Catalina!" The hall rose. The applause was genuine—not thunderous, but respectful, the measured acknowledgment of peers recognizing an achievement they could not diminish even if some wished to.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_urgell
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the Reconquista's completion honors all Christian Iberia. My grandfather spoke of the day when Granada would fall—he did not live to see it, but I drink to his memory tonight knowing his prayers were answered.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It was well said. It was also careful—Christian Iberia, not Castile. The count was acknowledging the achievement while claiming a share of it for all the peninsula's kingdoms. Others followed. The Viscount of Cardona, whose trading ships competed with Castilian merchants in the Mediterranean, offered congratulations with a merchant's smooth smile. The Baron of Montcada, whose family had fought alongside Castilians in campaigns a generation past, was warmer—he clasped Juan's arm and spoke of shared blood spilled against the Moors. The Bishop of Barcelona blessed Juan in sonorous Latin and expressed hope that the crusading spirit would continue eastward.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is new. Old one saved boy.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your daughter has conquered more hearts in an hour than most diplomats manage in a year. The story from Fraga reached Barcelona before you did. The fishermen's guild has already commissioned a small icon of her for their chapel. They say she has the Virgin's own protection. It does not hurt that she is half-Portuguese, a quarter Castilian, and now beloved by Catalans. She belongs to everyone.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your queen is impressive. Ferrara trains its women well. She knows exactly how much warmth to offer and how much to withhold. May I speak frankly, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course sir.

roll.outcome: Respectful Welcome. The reception goes well, though the Aragonese nobles hold something back.

encounters.recap: Juan receives a respectful but measured welcome at the Aragonese court in Barcelona. The nobles acknowledge his Reconquista achievements while carefully emphasizing shared Iberian heritage rather than Castilian dominance. Catalina charms the court, and Don Ramon de Perellós, María's chief councilor, requests to speak privately with Juan about the political situation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The applause fades into the murmur of renewed conversation. Nobles turn to one another, commenting in low voices—you catch fragments: "ben dit"... "el rei de Castella"... "la princesita"... The mood is warmer than when you entered. Not effusive, but genuinely respectful.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Before you can take three steps, a weathered figure in slightly old-fashioned velvet intercepts you.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. A moving address. The kingdom of heaven. We simple soldiers rarely hear such... poetry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls into step beside you, guiding you subtly toward the tall windows overlooking the harbor. His voice drops.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I knew your father, you know. Met him at Caspe, during the Compromise. He understood Aragon. Understood that a kingdom needs its king present, not chasing dreams across the sea. You speak of Christian kingdoms working together. Of fighting together. Fine words. But tell me—when you counsel your cuñado Alfonso, do you counsel him to fight here, where his kingdom needs him? Or do you encourage his... Italian enthusiasms?

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: Every ship you see carries taxes that cross the sea to feed soldiers in Calabria. Every young man you passed in this hall has brothers, cousins, sons who may never return from Italy. We have bled for Naples for years. Some of us wonder if Castile's gold and Castile's pope made it easier for Alfonso to keep bleeding us.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: My lord Count, surely you're not monopolizing our honored guest?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Guillem de Vic appears at your other elbow—thirty-ish, dark hair oiled and gleaming, clothes that probably cost more than most knights earn in a year. His smile is warm, his bow elaborate.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, what an honor. Your speech— When you spoke of glimpsing heaven at your daughter's birth, I confess my eyes grew damp. And the crostatas! You will find our Catalan cuisine more than adequate to her Highness's refined palate, I assure you.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: I hope my lord of Pallars has not been burdening you with our domestic concerns. The Count is passionate about... economy. Understandable, of course. Not everyone has vision enough to see beyond the accounting books. The news from Naples is extraordinary, is it not? Louis of Anjou failing, the barons turning, your sister speaks of Alfonso expecting victory by summer. With Castile's continued friendship— the three kingdoms united at last. Your father's blood ruling from Toledo to Syracuse. Surely that is a glimpse of heaven itself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My main concern is to end the war in Naples as soon as possible. The war has lasted long enough and has cost us coin and sons. When I shared this concern with the pope, he agreed. I have good hope that with papal support and the recent cooperation between Castille and Aragon in terms of fleet and treasury, we can bring the war to a swift conclusion. And fortunately, I have just received encouraging news.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: I show them both the letter from Alfonso.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will be passing by Naples on my way to Constantinople and will give my cousin every help he may need. The war is not won, but it truly seems we are close now. Truly, I hope we can put the past and the conflicts between our kingdoms behind us.

roll.outcome: Cautious Respect - The acknowledgment of 'coin and sons' lands. Pallars didn't expect a Castilian king to validate Aragonese suffering. He reads the letter more carefully, asks a pointed question or two about Alfonso's position. Still skeptical, but willing to give Juan credit for understanding the stakes. Withdraws with genuine (if restrained) courtesy. Door left open for future conversation.

encounters.recap: At the Barcelona court, Juan is approached by two rival faction leaders after his speech. The Count of Pallars challenges him about Aragon's costly Italian wars, while Don Guillem de Vic promotes continued support for Alfonso's Naples campaign. Juan diplomatically acknowledges the war's costs while showing Alfonso's encouraging letter and promising personal support, earning cautious respect from the skeptical Count.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Count Pallars takes the letter from your hand, his weathered fingers careful with the parchment. His eyes move slowly—he reads Castilian well enough, but without hurry. Don Guillem cranes slightly, trying to read over his shoulder without appearing to.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: Louis of Anjou dying. The barons turning. If this is true, then perhaps the end is indeed near.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: You acknowledge the cost. That is... more than most Castilians trouble themselves with. I pray you are right about the swift conclusion. Aragon has bled enough for Italian dreams.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gives a short bow—correct, neither warm nor cold. He withdraws, but positions himself near a pillar where he can observe without participating. Watching. Reserving judgment.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: You must forgive the Count. He is a good man, but he sees only expenses, never investments. Every ship out there—imagine them sailing to Naples, to Syracuse, carrying Catalan goods to Italian markets without Angevin tariffs strangling our trade.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of helping King Alfonso. This is welcome news—more than welcome. Though I confess I am curious what form this help might take. Forgive my directness. We who have invested in King Alfonso's success are naturally eager to understand how Castile's support... manifests.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have always given my cousin everything he asked for. I plan to visit him again and if even more help can bring the war to a decisive conclusion, I will not hesitate. I want Alfonso to win. I have the resources to help him even more, but know that gifting more than is being asked might be perceived...in a different light.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... perceptive. There are those who might indeed misread generosity as something else. Ambition. Interference. Aragon has its pride. King Alfonso would never doubt your intentions, but asking for help—especially from a king who has just conquered Granada while Alfonso spent three years besieging Gaeta—it is difficult for a proud man.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: If there were a way for such help to be... offered rather than requested. If it came through proper channels, with proper framing. As a gesture between brothers-in-law, blessed by Her Majesty the regent, perhaps even suggested by certain Aragonese voices rather than imposed by Castilian ones...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course! If pride or hesitation would halt my cousin from asking for aid, then please convince him or broker the aid if you can. Like I said, I want him to win and want to help him as family should. I would be in your debt.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But maybe we can develop cooperation even further. As soon as the war is won, should we not all benefit from the greater trade opportunities? I now command much new lands with ports and silk production facilities. An alliance and cooperation between the kingdoms would create a large and powerful trade area. Have you considered this?

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is too generous. I will write to King Alfonso myself. Tonight. And I have... friends... in his court who can ensure the message reaches him properly framed. As a brother's love, not a rival's condescension.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Trade cooperation. Yes, of course. The possibilities are... considerable. Your Majesty must understand, the Mediterranean is... complex. Barcelona has traded these waters for centuries. We have relationships, routes, agreements. The established powers do not welcome disruption.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Granada's silk, certainly, has potential. But silk is also produced in Lucca, in Valencia, in Almería under Genoese factors. The markets are established. To develop new production, new ports, new routes—this requires expertise. Capital. Connections that take generations to build.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: But these are matters for after the war, no? First Naples. First Constantinople. The great deeds of Christendom. And then, when peace reigns, when King Alfonso sits secure in Naples... then we can speak of trade. Of cooperation. Of how Catalan expertise might assist Castilian ambitions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: An excellent idea. If my cousin requires more aid and you can help him see fit to accept it, that would indeed be a notable deed. Now tell me, how do you feel about our two kingdoms? There have been some...difficulties in the past. Do you think we can now move past them?

encounters.recap: Juan negotiates with Count Pallars and Don Guillem de Vic in Barcelona. Pallars remains cautiously skeptical about Castilian involvement in Naples despite Alfonso's letter showing progress. Don Guillem eagerly offers to broker additional Castilian aid to Alfonso, securing a promise of royal debt. When Juan proposes broader trade cooperation involving Granada's new resources, Guillem deflects to post-war discussions while protecting Catalan commercial interests.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: For now, let us focus on the matter at hand. Your aid to King Alfonso. This I can help with. This I will help with. You have my word.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: An excellent idea. If my cousin requires more aid and you can help him see fit to accept it, that would indeed be a notable deed. Now tell me, how do you feel about our two kingdoms? There have been some...difficulties in the past. Do you think we can now move past them?

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I am a practical man. I leave the old grievances to the old men. The Infantes, the wars, the disputes over borders and succession — these were my father's concerns. And his father's. Every generation, it seems, we find new reasons to quarrel. But I look at you, Your Majesty, and I see something... different. A king who finished the Reconquista. A king who sails to save Constantinople. A king who speaks of cooperation rather than conquest. If such a king wishes friendship with Aragon, then only a fool would refuse.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: The question, perhaps, is what 'moving past' means. To some, it means forgetting. To others, forgiving. To others still... Your Majesty's sister has governed well as regent. Your support for King Alfonso is genuine — I see that now. These are good signs. But Aragon is proud. Catalonia is proud. We have been... wary of Castile for a long time. Trust is not built in a single conversation, even with a king.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do you truly mean that? That you are a progressive and practical man that can let old grievances lie? And do you believe that I am that king that can bring us together?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
