exchanges.text: The smile falters. For just a moment, Don Guillem de Vic looks like a man who has misplaced something important and can't remember where he put it. The smooth courtier's mask slips — not much, but enough.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks if I truly mean it. You are the first king to ask me that. I am a practical man. That much is true. I have had to be practical. My family is not ancient. We do not have castles full of ancestors. We have trade. Contracts. Relationships. All of this is... built. Maintained. It requires saying what people wish to hear. Surely Your Majesty understands this.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: As for whether I believe you are the king who can bring us together... I believe you are the king who conquered Granada. I believe you are the king sailing to Constantinople while other monarchs count their coins and guard their borders. I believe you are the king standing in this hall asking a Catalan merchant whether he means what he says, as if the answer matters to you. Whether that makes you the king who can unite Castile and Aragon? I do not know, Your Majesty. I do not know if any king can do that. There is too much history. Too much pride. Too many men like Count Pallars who remember every slight, every war, every insult from grandfathers long dead.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: But I think you might be the king who believes he can. And perhaps... perhaps that is rarer. And worth more. Forgive me, Your Majesty. You asked for truth. I am... not accustomed to providing it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And do you think I am certain of myself? That I will bring kingdoms and family together? No, of course not. All I can do is try. All we can do is try. My question is: will you try as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Guillem stares at Juan. The hall's noise seems far away — the music, the murmured conversations, the clink of silver. Here, in this small space, a King of Castile has just admitted uncertainty to a man who sells wool futures and flatters nobles for access.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: I have spent my life trying to win. Trying to be on the right side. The profitable side. I do not know if I have ever tried for something I might fail at. Something that could not be measured in ledgers. Your Majesty, I am not a brave man. I am not a visionary. I am this. A man who saw which way the wind was blowing and positioned himself accordingly.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: But you ask if I will try. I... do not know what that means. For a man like me. In practical terms. If you tell me to write to Alfonso advocating for more aid, I will do it. If you tell me to speak well of Castile among my faction, I will do it. These things I know how to do. But trying — trying for kingdoms to come together, for old wounds to heal, for something larger... I do not know if I am that man, Your Majesty. I have never had to find out.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: What would you have me do? Not the easy things. The things I already promised. What would trying look like, for someone like me?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We all have a role in Gods plan with different skills. I could never negotiate a trade contract like you could. Maybe I am a better general. My sister who has never wielded a sword in her life maybe has done more to bring our kingdoms together than anyone. Alone we can not do everything, but together we might. And all we can do is try. Try our best. You are an influential trader and noble. You can do something. Will you try with me?

encounters.recap: Juan presses Don Guillem beyond diplomatic platitudes to genuine commitment. After initial deflection, Guillem's courtier mask slips as Juan asks for truth and admits his own uncertainty. The conversation becomes unexpectedly intimate as both men reveal vulnerability — Juan his doubts about uniting the kingdoms, Guillem his inexperience with idealism beyond profit. Juan frames unity as a shared effort using each person's unique skills, asking simply if Guillem will try alongside him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Guillem is silent for a long moment. The hall continues around them—somewhere a woman laughs, glasses clink, a musician shifts from one melody to another. None of it seems to reach this small space between a king and a merchant who has forgotten, briefly, how to be a merchant.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Different skills. Each with a role in God's plan.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He laughs—a strange sound, more breath than voice.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I have never thought of myself as having a role in God's plan. I have thought of myself as having a role in my plan. In my family's plan. In the plan to become wealthy enough that no one could dismiss me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks up. His eyes are bright—not with tears, not quite, but with something raw and unguarded.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: You ask if I will try. I have a confession, Your Majesty. When I approached you tonight, I had a strategy. Flatter the Castilian king. Position myself as useful. Extract what advantages I could. I am not proud of this. But it is what I do. What I have always done.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens slightly. When he speaks again, his voice is steadier.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: But you did not... you did not treat me as someone to be managed. You asked me questions no one has ever asked. You showed me doubt—your doubt—as though I were someone worth confiding in. And now you tell me that my skills, the skills of a merchant, have value in bringing kingdoms together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shakes his head slowly, wonderingly.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: I do not know if I can be the man you are describing. The man who tries for something larger than profit. But... There is a Catalan banking family. The Gualbes. They have connections in Florence, in Genoa, in Venice. Old relationships, built over generations. If Castile and Aragon are to truly work together—in trade, in finance, in the movement of goods and gold—these connections would be valuable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He meets Juan's eyes directly.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: I can introduce you. Or rather—I can begin building the groundwork. Quietly. Merchant to merchant. The kind of work that does not appear in treaties but makes treaties possible. It is a small thing. But it is something I can do. Something I know how to do.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He takes a breath.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. I will try. In my own way, with my own skills, as you said. I do not know if I will succeed. I do not know if I am capable of being more than what I have been. But I would like to find out.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The courtier is still absent. What stands before Juan is something rarer: a man who has just offered not flattery, not service, but himself—uncertain, imperfect, genuinely trying.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Will you... will you hold me to it? When I retreat into old habits—and I will, I know myself that well—will you remind me of this moment? Of what I said I would try to be?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He's asking for accountability. Asking Juan to not let him off the hook. It might be the most honest thing he's ever said to anyone.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fortunately, we are not the only one trying friend.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: I turn to the crown and clap my hands loudly to get attention.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Friends! Something important has just happened. Don Guillem has made the important choice to help and bring the kingdoms of Castille and Aragon closer together. He will write my cousin about Castillian aid and for that he has my gratitude. I hope that this court will see his heart and help him in this noble goal. He will try, I will try and if someday enough have tried, we can finally see each other as family and not as enemies.

roll.outcome: Inspiring Moment: The hall responds. Juan's words—about trying, about family, about each person's role—echo his earlier speech and amplify it. When the applause comes, it's robust, genuine. Nobles who hadn't planned to commit find themselves moved. Don Guillem receives not just acknowledgment but embraces from unexpected quarters. A Catalan merchant lord announces he'll support Guillem's efforts with his own connections. Someone calls for a toast to the kingdoms united. María rises from her seat and adds her voice: 'My brother speaks truth. Let us be family at last.' Even Count Pallars, from his pillar, raises his cup—not enthusiastically, but without hostility. The factional lines blur, just slightly. Something is shifting.

encounters.recap: After Guillem de Vic makes a private commitment to help unite Castile and Aragon through his merchant connections, Juan makes a public announcement to the entire Aragonese court declaring Guillem's commitment. The court responds with genuine enthusiasm, with María publicly endorsing the vision and even Count Pallars showing cautious support. The factional divisions begin to blur as nobles rally around the idea of the kingdoms as family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first hour goes well enough. Nobles approach, Juan receives them, Lucia smiles graciously, Catalina waves her small hand at admirers. The momentum from the announcement carries them through the initial rush of well-wishers. But the evening is long, and Barcelona's nobles are many.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the second hour, Juan notices Catalina growing restless. She squirms in Lucia's arms, refuses a candied almond (unprecedented), and when the Viscount of Cardona's wife attempts to compliment her cloak, Catalina buries her face in Lucia's shoulder and will not look at the woman.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is tired, caro. It has been a very long day for little legs and little eyes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The third time Juan explains his vision of cooperation to a politely skeptical merchant, he hears his own words growing stale. The phrases that rang with power during the announcement begin to feel rehearsed. He sees it in the merchant's eyes: Yes, yes, very inspiring, but what does this actually mean for tariffs on Valencian cloth?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina's patience finally breaks during an encounter with a well-meaning but tone-deaf baron who insists on telling her about his own grandchildren at length. She lets out a wail that cuts through the hall's murmur, loud enough to turn heads.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No! No more talking! Catalina done!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Without Catalina, the dynamic shifts. Lucia soldiers on admirably, but she's tired too. Her responses become shorter, her smile more fixed. A Catalan merchant's wife makes a comment about Italian women and their 'delicate constitutions' that might be innocent or might be pointed; Lucia cannot tell and responds with coolness that may have given offense.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds himself in a conversation with three Aragonese faction lords who arrived together—clearly coordinated. Their questions are probing: 'Your Majesty speaks of cooperation, but what of the Infantes' claims? Do you consider those matters... settled?' 'The Military Orders now answer to Castile's crown, we hear. How does this cooperation extend to institutions that once served all Iberian kingdoms?'

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: You should retire soon. The evening has been... eventful. Better to end while the memory of your announcement is still warm. Another hour of small talk will not improve on it.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: The Countess of Pallars told me Lucia seemed unwell. Perhaps the journey, perhaps the child she carries. It would be... understood if the Queen of Castile needed rest.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think we have exhausted ourselves and will exhaust others. We have other matters to attend to, but be sure to accept invitations on our behalf. I would really like to get to know everyone and address any concerns.

roll.outcome: Diminishing Returns: The evening drags. Juan repeats his themes too often; what sounded inspiring once sounds rehearsed. Catalina grows fussy and must be taken to bed early. The conversations become repetitive, and by the end people are tired rather than inspired. The announcement's impact fades into 'a nice moment' rather than a turning point.

encounters.recap: The evening reception starts well but deteriorates as fatigue sets in. Catalina has a public tantrum and must be taken to bed, removing Juan's most effective ambassador. The royal couple grows tired, conversations become repetitive, and the magic of the earlier announcement begins to fade. Juan wisely chooses to retire before further damage is done, though the transformative moment has already diminished into mere diplomacy.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You meant it. Truly meant it. I could see it in his face when he understood that you meant it. I have watched my father's court my whole life. I have never seen a king speak to a merchant that way. Ask him to try. Ask him to be more than he thought he was. Who taught you to do that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No one love. No one. I take this world, lay it on the anvil and hammer it until it is better.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia is silent for a long moment, her eyes reflecting the firelight. Then she laughs—soft, so as not to wake Catalina, but genuine. The kind of laugh that comes from surprise and recognition together.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Dio mio, I married a blacksmith king. In Ferrara, we are taught that the world is a garden. That a wise ruler tends it—prunes here, waters there, waits for things to grow in their season. Patient. Careful. Never forcing. But you do not tend. You forge. You put the metal in the fire and strike it until it becomes what you see in your mind. It is terrifying to watch, caro. And beautiful. And I do not know if it will work.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina stirs between them, mumbles 'crostata' in her sleep, and settles again.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The Reconquista. The pope. The Military Orders. Now Aragon. Constantinople next. How many hammers can one man swing before his arms give out?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How much I can carry? How many hammers can any one man swing? As a man, after a while my arm will give out, for sure. But I am not just hammering out a knife or a pot. I am working on the kingdom of heaven. And God gives me the strength to do it. And when I swing the hammer like that, it can do extraordinary things. I have seen it. As long as I walk in God's glory, I will never tire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's hand stills on his. The fire crackles. Catalina breathes softly between them. The distant sounds of the reception have faded now—Barcelona settling into sleep. Lucia does not respond immediately. Her dark eyes study Juan's face in the flickering light, and there is something in her expression that was not there before. Not fear, exactly. Not doubt. Something more complex.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Juan. I believe God works through you. I have seen it. Fraga—What our daughter did at that bridge. The Reconquista. The way you spoke to Don Guillem tonight, and he heard you. These are not ordinary things. But caro... the men who believe God gives them endless strength... My grandmother told me stories of such men. Crusaders who marched into the desert certain that faith would sustain them. Holy emperors who believed their cause so righteous that defeat was impossible. They did not all return from those deserts, Juan. Their certainty did not protect them from thirst, from arrows, from the limits of flesh and bone. God may have loved them. But He still let them die.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches out, touches his face. Her fingers trace the line of his jaw, the exhaustion she can see even in the dim light.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are mortal, husband. Holy purpose does not make you less so. And I... I am carrying your child. Catalina is sleeping between us. We need you to return from Constantinople. We need you to live. Not as a saint or a martyr, but as a father and a husband who knows when to rest. Promise me something. Not tonight—you are too tired, and I am too tired. But soon. Promise me you will speak to your confessor about this. About the strength you feel. About what it means. Not because I doubt God. Because I love you. And I have seen what certainty can do to good men.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Don't worry love. I do not fear death should God demand it of me. But he has a purpose for me still and he will not let me die. I will not walk into the desert without water. That is just stupid and God does not reward stupidity. What I mean when I talk about God and the kingdom of heaven, I mean just what you saw tonight. That when I am honest, I can turn the hearts of men through a divine purpose. Not my purpose, but God's purpose. Do you see? My strength is my honesty and the fact that I can unite men through a common vision, purpose that is greater than just Juan. Imagine the court encounter we just had but now without us being christian. We could never have been able to unite as much. Christianity grants purpose, good deeds, family values, it grants us so much. Too much to even to start to number. I place my faith in that and you can place your faith in me. I will always protect you and Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia listens. Her face is still in the firelight, unreadable. When Juan finishes—I will always protect you and Catalina—she is quiet for a long moment. Her hand remains on his chest, over his heart, but it has gone still.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You did not answer me. I asked you to promise to speak with your confessor. About the strength you feel. About what it means. You explained to me instead why you do not need to. Juan. I am not a child who needs theology explained to her. I am not a nervous courtier who needs reassurance. I am your wife. I am carrying your heir. I told you I was frightened. I asked you for one thing. A promise to speak with Fray Hernando. Not to doubt yourself. Not to abandon your purpose. Just to... let someone else look at what is happening inside you. Someone who knows the difference between holy purpose and... And you told me that God will not let you die. That I should place my faith in you.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: My father said those words to my mother once. Before he rode to a battle he was certain God had ordained. He came back. But not every man does. And the ones who do not—their wives are left with nothing but 'place your faith in me' and an empty bed. I am not asking you to doubt God. I am asking you to remember that you are a man. That even holy men have confessors for a reason. That the sin of presumption is real, and it does not announce itself—it feels like certainty. Will you speak with Fray Hernando? Yes or no. Not because I doubt you. Because I love you. And because I need to know that someone is watching.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No one can ask me to talk to a confessor. No one but you. What is said between a confessor and me is sacred. If I approach him because someone else told me to, I would not be seeking out confession because I wanted to but to please others. What you talk about has been discussed with Hernando many times. And let me be as clear as possible. I could be sitting comfortably in Toledo right now. Ignore the plight of the Greeks. Let nobles shower me with gifts and flattery. Let Alvaro and other advisors run the kingdom. Try and make the best choices for the kingdom, sure. Be a just and rightful king, easy when you never leave the capital. Maybe once make a large donation to a crusade or found a church and feel like you contribute. That is how most men live their lives. I push myself to do the maximum possible to make the world better. I call it the kingdom of heaven, but it really means a better world. Thinking about this, makes me happy. Knowing that I am working on making the world better. Theologically, I would say that I am divinely inspired and Hernando agrees that this is the case. But that does not mean that I will not go thirsty in the desert. I will just like anyone. So you could say that God sets me to task, but he does not chop the wood for me. That I have to do myself. God does not protect me in battle. Me being careful and a good armour does. Speak to anyone who was with me in the battles. I do participate in charges and lead from the front, but I am never reckless. I accept danger, sure, but never without reason. I could die in battle, you could die in childbirth. The things we can not change are in God's hands. I will surround you with the best care when delivering and will love and support you as best I can. But the rest is in the hands of God. And then I say: place your trust in him. We cannot worry about the things we cannot control. When I next seek out confession, I will discuss with Hernando if presumption is being kept at bay. And I value your council love. I really do. I do not always act the way you would want me to, but I do always want to hear from you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan leans across Catalina's sleeping form and kisses Lucia. She accepts it. Her lips meet his, briefly, correctly. But there is something missing—a warmth that was there before, now held in reserve. When he pulls back, her eyes are closed. She does not open them immediately.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Thank you for explaining. I am very tired, caro. The child takes much from me these days. We should sleep. Tomorrow will be long.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her breathing slows. Her eyes remain closed. Whether she is actually falling asleep or simply ending the conversation, Juan cannot tell. Catalina murmurs between them, dreaming of crostatas or horses or the big water she saw today. The fire crackles low in the hearth. Outside, Barcelona sleeps. The harbor waits. Constantinople waits. The hammers of the kingdom of heaven wait to be swung again. But here, in this bed, something small and quiet has shifted. A wife asked her husband for something. He explained why he would not give it. And now she is turned away, eyes closed, one hand on her daughter's back. Tomorrow will be long. The night settles around them, and Juan is left with the silence. Juan falls asleep. The fire burns low. The shadows lengthen across the Catalan tapestries, the hunting scenes fading into darkness. Outside, the last sounds of Barcelona's night—a distant dog, a watchman's call, the creak of ships in the harbor—slowly quiet.

encounters.recap: In their private chambers, Lucia expresses both wonder and fear at Juan's divine certainty after witnessing his speech to Don Guillem. She asks him to speak with his confessor about presumption and the limits of mortal strength, but Juan responds with theological explanations rather than the simple promise she seeks. The conversation ends with Lucia withdrawing emotionally, accepting his kiss but turning away in disappointment, leaving Juan with silence and a subtle shift in their relationship.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The palace corridors are quiet in the early morning—servants flattening themselves against walls with murmured "Majestad" as Juan passes in his sleeping clothes, surprised to see a king fetching his own drink. The kitchens are warm, fragrant with bread baking for the day's meals. A cook nearly drops a ladle when Juan appears in the doorway. He returns with two cups—watered wine for Lucia, warm milk with honey for Catalina—and something wrapped in cloth that smells suspiciously of the promised crostata.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bedchamber is brighter now, morning light finding its way through the shutters. Catalina has colonized the center of the bed, building a fortress from pillows while narrating her construction in a mixture of Castilian and invented words. Lucia is awake, sitting up against the headboard, watching their daughter's engineering efforts. Her dark hair is loose around her shoulders, her face still carrying the softness of sleep. When Juan enters, she looks up. Her expression is... neutral. Not cold. Not warm. The careful composure of a woman who has decided something in the night but has not yet said what.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: You went yourself. Kings do not fetch drinks.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Crostata?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But first, you should have something to drink.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Thank you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room is quiet except for Catalina's determined drinking and the sounds of the palace waking beyond the walls. Morning light catches the dust motes in the air. Somewhere, a bell rings—one of Barcelona's churches calling the faithful to early Mass. Lucia sets down her cup, half-finished. She looks at Juan now, her expression still that careful neutral—a woman deciding whether to speak or to let the night's conversation stay buried.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: You were restless. In your sleep. You spoke once—I could not hear the words. What did you dream?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont really know. But yesterday left a sour aftertaste somehow. I did not like how it ended. I feel like we grew apart somehow.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Yes. We did. I asked you for something, Juan. One thing. And you explained to me why I was wrong to ask. I know you did not mean it that way. I know you were trying to help me understand. But... When I told you I was frightened, you told me not to be. When I asked for a promise, you gave me theology. When I said I needed to know someone was watching over you, you said you and Fray Hernando have already discussed it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: I do not doubt that you love me, caro. I do not doubt that you believe everything you said. But last night, I needed my husband to hear me. Not to teach me. Not to reassure me. Just to... You compared my death in childbirth to your death in battle. As if they were the same. As if my fear for you and your acceptance of risk were... parallel. They are not the same, Juan. I do not choose to risk death in childbirth. It simply is. But you choose, every day, to ride toward danger. And when I asked you to be careful—when I asked you to let someone watch for the sin of presumption—you told me to trust God. I do trust God. It is you I am frightened for.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont really know what to say love. I am glad you know I love you. I do. I will speak with Fray Hernando today. What do you feel I should be discussing with him?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: No. I will not tell you what to confess, Juan. That is between you and God and Fray Hernando. If I give you a list, then you are not examining your conscience—you are completing a task I assigned you. And when you return, you will say 'I discussed what you asked,' and we will be no closer to... I do not want to be your instructor in this. I want to be your wife. There is a difference.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: What I want—what I have been trying to say—is not about a specific topic. It is about... It is about whether you can see yourself clearly. Whether anyone can help you see yourself clearly. Whether the certainty you feel leaves room for doubt. Last night, you told me God would not let you die because He has a purpose for you. You said it like a fact. Like the sun rising. Do you understand why that frightened me? Not because I doubt God. Because I have heard men say such things before. And some of them were saints. And some of them were madmen. And from the inside, Juan, they feel exactly the same.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: I cannot tell you what to discuss with Hernando. But I can tell you this: if you go to him only to be reassured, you will be reassured. He loves you. He believes in you. He will tell you what you wish to hear unless you demand otherwise. So my question is: can you go to him wanting to be challenged? Not wanting to be told you are right, but genuinely asking—am I wrong? Am I presuming? Is there something I cannot see? Can you do that, Juan? Truly? Not for me. For yourself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe, we are in agreement more than we realize. I may not have said it so eloquently, but this sounds exactly what I was feeling last night. I do not want to go to confession just because someone told me so. I will speak with Hernando today. He is a very critical confessor, dont worry. He has challenged me a lot, especially in Basel. We could even talk with each other. The three of us. Not a confession, just a talk. He is a very smart man. Now, is there something my pregnant wife requires? Maybe a crostata of her own?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: A talk. The three of us. I would like that. If Fray Hernando is willing. Not to interfere in your confession. But to understand. To be... part of it. Whatever it is. This thing you carry.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: You think pastry will solve everything, caro? You are as bad as your daughter.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_trastamara
exchanges.text: Papa bad?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: No, piccola. Papa is not bad. Papa is... trying.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Yes. A crostata would be welcome. And then we should dress. Your sister will want to speak with you, I think. And I should... I should write to my mother. It has been too long.

encounters.recap: During a morning conversation in their bedchamber, Lucia confronts Juan about their argument from the previous night. She articulates her fear that Juan's certainty about his divine purpose could be dangerous presumption, asking him to genuinely examine his conscience with Fray Hernando rather than seeking reassurance. Juan offers to include Lucia in a three-way conversation with his confessor, and they reach a tentative reconciliation, though underlying tensions remain about Juan's spiritual certainty and risk-taking.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's private solar is warm with morning light, the windows thrown open to let in the salt breeze from the Mediterranean. Maps are spread across a heavy table—Italy, the western Mediterranean, shipping routes marked in colored inks. María stands by the window, dressed more simply than last night in a deep blue gown, her dark hair braided and coiled. She looks tired—the kind of tired that doesn't come from one sleepless night but from years of carrying weight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Tía!

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: There she is. The little rope-thrower of Fraga. Did you sleep well, pequeña? I heard you were very tired last night.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Catalina had crostata. Two crostatas. And Papa was bad but not really bad.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Is that so? Papa was bad? Why don't you show this to your mother by the window, pequeña? I need to speak with Papa for a moment. About his badness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María straightens, smoothing her gown. Her eyes meet Juan's.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You look better than I expected. I thought you might have a longer night, after that announcement. It was bold, Juan. Very bold. Don Ramon spent an hour after you left trying to calculate what it means for the factions. Sit. We have much to discuss, and I suspect we won't have long before the nobles start requesting audiences.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits until he's seated before taking her own chair, arranging herself with the practiced economy of a woman who has spent four years conducting state business from rooms like this one.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: So. Constantinople. Naples. Don Guillem de Vic. The speech about the kingdom of heaven. Tell me what you're actually trying to do, little brother. Not the version for the court. The truth.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I seek to end the Trastamara conflict and unite our family again. Together, we stand so much stronger. We should not be fighting now, should we? I will never forget what you did for this goal sister. I will always take care of you because you are family. Can you tell me sister how we can best achieve this? You know Aragon better than I ever could.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María listens. Her face remains still, giving nothing away — the mask of a woman who has spent four years hearing proposals, complaints, and flattery from men who wanted something from her. When Juan finishes, she doesn't respond immediately. Her fingers tap once, twice, against the arm of her chair.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: That is a lovely sentiment, Juan. And I'm grateful for your gratitude. Truly. But I asked you a specific question. I asked what you're actually trying to do. And you've given me... this. Unity. Family. Taking care of me. The Trastámara conflict.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her eyes sharpen.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I've spent four years in this chair, little brother. Four years balancing factions while our husband chases Naples. Four years explaining to Catalan merchants why their taxes feed Italian wars. Four years smiling at nobles who wonder why the regent's womb remains empty while the king is never home. I do not need to be taken care of. I have been taking care of myself, and Aragon, and Alfonso's dreams, while you conquered Granada and charmed the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her voice doesn't rise, but something in it hardens.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I am not angry with you, Juan. I am proud of what you've accomplished. Genuinely. But do not come into my solar and offer me family warmth when I asked for truth. So. Again. What are you actually trying to do? Not the vision. Not the kingdom of heaven. The plan. Constantinople — what do you expect to achieve there? Naples — how much more are you prepared to give Alfonso? Don Guillem — what did you actually promise him last night? And this talk of unity... Does 'uniting the family' mean something specific? Are you proposing a formal alliance? A treaty? A marriage for Catalina when she's of age? Are you asking for Aragonese ships, Aragonese gold, Aragonese blood for your Eastern crusade?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She spreads her hands.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Tell me what you want, Juan. Because kings do not give speeches about unity without wanting something. I have been in this game long enough to know that.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask me to be honest sister. So I will be. But know that this is the hard truth that I would not announce openly. Please bear this in mind. I seek that Alfonso announces me as his heir so that when he eventually passes, the two kingdoms become one. And together we stand a chance to stand up to challenges like the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room goes very still. María does not move. Her face does not change. But something behind her eyes shifts — a door closing, or perhaps a wall going up. The silence stretches. Outside, seabirds cry. Catalina's voice drifts from the window, chattering to Lucia about the painted bird. The sounds feel very far away.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises from her chair — slowly, deliberately — and walks to the table with the maps. Her back is to Juan. Her fingers trace the coastline of Aragon, then Castile, then the Mediterranean beyond.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You want my husband to name you his heir. You want, when Alfonso dies, for his kingdom to become yours. For Aragon to become Castile. For the crown I have spent four years protecting to pass to my brother.

encounters.recap: In a private meeting with María of Aragon, Juan reveals his true plan: he wants Alfonso to name him heir, effectively uniting Castile and Aragon under one crown to face threats like the Ottomans. María responds with cold calculation, immediately grasping the personal and political implications of what Juan is asking her to facilitate.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María listens to Juan's clarifications. Her face remains still, composed — the regent's mask firmly in place. When he finishes, she does not respond immediately. She turns away, walking back to the window, her back to him. The morning light catches the grey threads in her hair, the slight stoop in her shoulders that wasn't there four years ago.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: A new kingdom. Not Castile, not Aragon. Something else. And I would continue as regent. Hold court in Barcelona. Under you.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You have thought about this carefully, Juan. I can see that. You have answers prepared for my objections. You have reassurances for my fears. You have even promised to support children I do not have and may never have.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: But here is what I notice, brother. You came to Barcelona with this plan already formed. You gave your speech about unity last night. You recruited Don Guillem to your cause. You charmed the court with your daughter and your beautiful queen and your talk of the kingdom of heaven.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: And only now — the morning after — do you tell your sister what you actually want. After the ground has been prepared. After the factions have been stirred. After you have positioned yourself as the great unifier.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Did it occur to you to tell me first? Before the speeches? Before the announcements? To ask my counsel before you began reshaping the political landscape of my regency?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You say family cuts both ways, Juan. But you did not treat me as family. You treated me as... an audience. Someone to be brought along after the decisions were made. Someone to be managed with reassurances and promises.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I have spent four years holding this kingdom together. Four years writing letters to a husband who sends back battle reports and requests for money. Four years smiling at nobles who wonder why the queen cannot produce an heir. Four years being strong because someone had to be.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: And you walk in with your conquests and your visions and your plans for union, and you offer me... what? A continued role. In your kingdom. Under your crown. As your regent.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I am not saying no, Juan. I am saying I cannot say yes. Not like this. Not this morning, with your ships in the harbor and your knights eating our food and your merchants making deals with our merchants.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I need time. I need to think. I need to write to Alfonso and hear what he wants, not what you want me to tell him he should want.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You asked for truth, so here is mine: I love you, Juan. You are my brother. But right now, I do not trust you. You have handled this badly, and I am hurt, and I do not know how to feel about any of it.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Go. Receive your nobles. Accept your invitations. Play the great king. We will speak again before you sail. Perhaps by then I will know what to say.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I should have consulted you sooner sister. I'm sorry I didn't. Talk and write to Alfonso. I shall await your decision.

encounters.recap: María rejects Juan's succession proposal, hurt that he presented his plan only after publicly positioning himself. She acknowledges his clarifications but feels treated as an audience rather than family. Though not saying no definitively, she needs time to consult Alfonso directly and cannot commit to supporting the union under these circumstances.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: And perhaps... we do not mention the succession question to the bishop. Not today. One difficult conversation at a time, yes?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Agreed. Lets go.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The servants scramble to accommodate—a brief delay while matching garments are found and adjusted. In the end, Juan and Lucia descend to the bishop's audience in complementary velvets of deep burgundy trimmed with gold, the lions of Castile and the Este eagle subtly echoed in their embroidery. They look, as intended, like a unified front. A partnership made visible in silk and thread. The servant leads them through the Palau Reial's corridors to a reception chamber overlooking the cathedral square. Through the tall windows, the spires of Barcelona's great cathedral rise against the winter sky—construction still ongoing after nearly a century, scaffolding clinging to the unfinished façade like wooden vines.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. You honor me with your presence. And together, no less—a vision of Christian matrimony that warms an old churchman's heart. Please, sit. I have taken the liberty of having wine brought, and some small refreshments. The morning is cold, and you have traveled far.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gestures to chairs arranged near the window, a small table between them bearing cups, a flagon, and a plate of neules—thin Catalan wafer biscuits rolled into delicate cylinders. Once they are seated, the bishop settles across from them, arranging his robes with practiced grace.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: I wished to offer my blessing upon your expedition to Constantinople, Your Majesty. A noble undertaking—the defense of Christendom's eastern bulwark against the Ottoman tide. God's work, truly. But I confess, I also wished to speak with you of other matters. Matters closer to home. Your speech last night was... remarkable. The kingdom of heaven. Unity between Castile and Aragon. Don Guillem de Vic's public commitment. The court is buzzing with it this morning. Some say they witnessed the beginning of a new era. Others wonder what it means for... existing arrangements. I am merely a shepherd of souls, of course. Politics is not my domain. But I find myself curious, Your Majesty: when you speak of the kingdom of heaven, what precisely do you envision? And how might the Church—how might Barcelona's Church—serve this vision?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, and let me just say that we both are happy to meet with you. I have asked the queen to come with me since I believe both king and queen are important in the realm, taking inspiration from how my sister has been managing Aragon. We are here to listen and to learn, this is the first time we really visit Aragon. I have discussed ecclesiastical matters at great length with my own church representatives in Castille. The church and it's position matters greatly to me. Even if I as a king stand outside it's structure. I understand that there are worries about existing arrangements. Maybe if you would educate me and tell me what these concerns are, I am eager to work together and address them if within my power.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop studies Juan for a long moment. His fingers tap once against his pectoral cross—a thinking gesture, perhaps unconscious. Then something in his posture shifts. Not dramatically—he's too practiced for that—but the benevolent mask relaxes slightly, revealing something sharper and more genuine beneath.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: You wish me to educate you. Very well, Your Majesty. I will speak more frankly than I had intended. I have been Bishop of Barcelona for eleven years. In that time, I have watched three popes, two antipopes, a council that nearly tore Christendom apart, and a king of Aragon who visits his kingdom perhaps once every three years. I have learned to be... cautious. About what I say. To whom I say it. But you bring your queen. You speak of listening. You reference Her Majesty the regent with respect. And you have the favor of Pope Eugenius, which is not nothing in these times. So. Frankly.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: There are three concerns that keep Aragonese churchmen awake at night, Your Majesty. I will name them. First: the Military Orders. You now control Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara by papal decree. The masters answer to Castile's crown. These orders have commanderies in Aragon. They hold lands, collect revenues, wield influence. When Aragonese clergy look at what happened in Castile, they wonder: are we next? Will Your Majesty seek similar authority over institutions that have traditionally answered to... other powers? Second: appointments. The bishops of Castile are, increasingly, men who align with royal interests. This is natural—kings prefer cooperative clergy. But Aragon has its own traditions. The Cathedral Chapter of Barcelona has elected its own bishops for centuries. If 'unity' means Castilian influence over Aragonese appointments—if Toledo begins to speak for Barcelona—there will be resistance. Quiet resistance, perhaps. But real. Third: Basel. Your Majesty supported Pope Eugenius against the Council. This was wise—Eugenius prevailed, and you have his gratitude. But some Aragonese clergy supported the Council's reforms. They believed—still believe—that the Church needs change, that papal authority has grown too absolute, that councils should check papal power. These men are not heretics. They are not your enemies. But they wonder if Your Majesty's closeness to Eugenius means they will be... remembered. Punished. Passed over for preferment because they chose the wrong side in a dispute that is supposedly resolved.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: These are the concerns, Your Majesty. Spoken plainly, as you requested. Now. You said you wished to address them if within your power. I am listening. What does the Conqueror of Granada, the Champion of Constantinople, the man who speaks of the kingdom of heaven—what does he say to a tired bishop who worries about the Church he has spent his life serving?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Grant you blessing from the lord sir. When we open our hearts and step into the light, we serve the lord. It's what I have always tried to do. And let me thank you for being so open. Let me first address your concern about military orders. I seek not to establish more control over other institutions of the church. And I can add that the current arrangement was done with total mutual agreement and cooperation. The military orders were left without a purpose after the reconquista so we have found a new way, a new goal to set our sights to. If the masters of the orders were here, they would tell you that the arrangement is mutually beneficial. They have gained a new purpose and I have granted them even more lands in Granada as well. In short, the situation with the military orders are unique, I do not seek to acquire other institutions and I now and always seek to cooperate with the church and its institutions.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia meet with Bishop Francesc Climent Sapera of Barcelona in the Palau Reial. The bishop initially probes diplomatically about Juan's 'unity' speech, but Juan's respectful approach encourages frank discussion. The bishop reveals three major Aragonese Church concerns: fears about royal control over institutions following the Military Orders precedent, worries about Castilian influence over traditional Aragonese episcopal appointments, and anxiety among clergy who supported the Council of Basel. Juan begins addressing these concerns, starting with reassurances about the Military Orders being a unique situation born of mutual benefit rather than a template for broader church control.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: These are the concerns, Your Majesty. Spoken plainly, as you requested. Now. You said you wished to address them if within your power. I am listening. What does the Conqueror of Granada, the Champion of Constantinople, the man who speaks of the kingdom of heaven—what does he say to a tired bishop who worries about the Church he has spent his life serving?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me first address your concern about military orders. I seek not to establish more control over other institutions of the church. The military orders were left without a purpose after the reconquista so we have found a new way. The situation with the military orders are unique, I do not seek to acquire other institutions and I now and always seek to cooperate with the church. Your second issue touches on how bishops are elected. You may be pleased to learn that I have already openly committed to this position. Our Basel delegation is supporting this. I fully support that cathedral chapters elect their own bishops. And concerning your third issue, I support quite some reforms of the council. I feel like the church must reform and should also find a way to re-establish its authority and keep the church united. I support reforms and consider them essential to prevent another schism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia reaches into the document case she carries and produces a sealed letter, heavy parchment bearing both the Castilian arms and the Imperial eagle.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: We have a copy, caro. Though perhaps His Excellency should see the summary of positions rather than the personal correspondence?

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: You travel with Imperial correspondence. And your queen knows which documents to produce. You are better prepared than most kings who claim to be 'listening and learning,' Your Majesty. Before I read, I must ask directly. Your Majesty has the favor of Pope Eugenius. You carry letters co-signed with the Emperor. You claim to support Council reforms while maintaining papal relationships. How? How does one hold both positions without being torn apart? One cannot serve two masters, Your Majesty. So tell me — which master do you actually serve?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The reality is indeed complicated. Fortunately, I can tell you that even the pope supports reforms and the council. I support both in a sense as the situation is nuanced.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan lifts the entire satchel and carries it to the bishop's writing desk, spreading documents across the polished wood. The Documents Revealed: The Declaration of Como signed by Emperor Sigismund and Juan, the Letter to Pope Eugenius IV proposing parallel legislation, the Castilian Delegation Instructions outlining support for reforms while maintaining neutrality on papal supremacy, and the Council of Basel Session 12 Decree on electoral reform.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I came to this meeting expecting diplomatic pleasantries. Perhaps some vague assurances. Instead you have shown me... everything. Your position. Your alliances. Your actual policy. Kings do not do this. Kings guard their positions, reveal nothing, commit to nothing until they have extracted maximum advantage. Why? Why show me all of this? What do you want from Barcelona's Church that is worth revealing your entire hand?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What do I want from you? I wish for Barcelona's church to bless marriages of devout Christians who live fruitful lives. I hope the church in Barcelona educates and tells the gospel with conviction. I hope that church generosity helps the poor. That the stories from the bible help guard against sin. I want us to do good. I truly believe that if we do, we walk in God's glory. I support these positions because I believe it best allows the church to do the things I just described. A unified and reformed church with elected bishops are in my opinion better equipped to bring us this. That is what I want.

roll.outcome: Deeply moved and convinced. The Bishop's cynicism crumbles in the face of Juan's genuine faith and comprehensive documentation. He becomes a strong ally.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the Bishop's concerns about military orders, episcopal elections, and church reform by revealing his complete diplomatic position. He shows all documents including the Declaration of Como with Emperor Sigismund, correspondence with Pope Eugenius, and Basel delegation instructions. When asked what he wants from Barcelona's Church, Juan gives a deeply spiritual answer about doing good works and walking in God's glory. The Bishop's cynical expectations are completely overturned by Juan's transparency and genuine faith.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Why? Why show me all of this? What do you want from Barcelona's Church that is worth revealing your entire hand?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! What do I want from you? I wish for Barcelona's church to bless marriages of devout christians who life fruitfull lives. I hope the church in Barcelona educated and tells the gospel with conviction. I hope with all my heart that the confession services provided open hearts and lift spirits. That church generosity helps the poor. That the stories from the bible helps guard against sin. I want us to do good. I truly believe that if we do, we walk in God's glory. A slice of heaven here on earth, metaphorically speaking. I have pledged to fight for it and I will do so until my dying breath. I support these positions because I believe it best allows the church to do the things I just described. A unified and reformed church with elected bishops are in my opinion better equipped to bring us this. That is what I want. For doing good it is it's own reward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop is silent for a long moment. He looks down at the documents spread across his desk—the Declaration of Como with its Imperial seal, the reform positions, the twenty-three pages of electoral decree. Then he looks back at Juan. Something shifts in his face. The politician recedes. What remains is older, more tired, more human.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. May I speak to you not as Bishop of Barcelona to King of Castile, but as... as a priest? As a man who took vows forty years ago and has spent most of that time forgetting why?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He doesn't wait for permission. He rises from his desk and moves to the window, looking out at the unfinished cathedral—the scaffolding, the half-completed spires reaching toward heaven.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I was twenty when I entered the Church. I believed... I believed what you just said. That the Church existed to do good. To marry the faithful, educate the young, comfort the dying, feed the hungry. I believed that if we did these things, we walked in God's glory. A slice of heaven on earth.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Do you know what forty years of church politics does to that belief, Your Majesty? It doesn't kill it quickly. That would be merciful. It kills it slowly. One compromise at a time. One appointment made for political reasons rather than pastoral ones. One reform delayed because the timing wasn't right. One principle set aside because the greater good required flexibility.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair, sitting heavily.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I have not thought about why I became a priest in... I cannot remember how long. Years, perhaps. I think about revenues and appointments and factions and which cardinal to cultivate and which bishop to avoid. I think about Barcelona's position relative to Tarragona, about the chapter's privileges, about protecting what we have built.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: And then a king walks into my study, shows me everything—everything—and when I ask what he wants, he tells me he wants the Church to bless marriages and teach the gospel and hear confessions and feed the poor. I had forgotten that was the point. Do you understand? I had forgotten that was the point.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I have met many kings, Your Majesty. I have met kings who wanted Church lands, Church gold, Church influence. I have met kings who wanted bishops in their pockets and abbots who would bless their wars. I have met kings who spoke of God while reaching for power, who wrapped their ambitions in holy language. I have never met a king who wanted what you want. Who showed me his entire hand and asked for nothing except that I do my duty to God.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: You spoke last night of the kingdom of heaven. Of glimpsing it in moments—at Alcalá, at your daughter's birth. I confess I thought it was rhetoric. Beautiful words for a beautiful speech. I do not think it is rhetoric. I think you mean it. And I think... I think I have been waiting a very long time to meet a king who meant it.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: So let me tell you what I can offer in return—not as payment, but as... partnership. As a priest who has remembered, thanks to you, why he took his vows. First: I will write to the Archbishop of Tarragona and to the bishops of Girona, Vic, and Urgell. I will tell them what I have seen here today. Second: I will speak to the Catalan clergy about your Constantinople expedition. Not as a political venture, but as what it is—a crusade to defend Christendom. Third: When you return from Constantinople—when, Your Majesty, not if, for I will pray daily for your safe return—I will be here. And if your vision of unity between Castile and Aragon moves forward, you will find in Barcelona's Church not an obstacle but an ally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, and moves to stand before Juan.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am too old and too tired to kneel easily. But will you permit an old priest to give you his blessing? Not a diplomatic blessing. A real one. For a man I believe is doing God's work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like to recieve your blessing father. And I am grateful for your support.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before I leave, I would like to pray with you, or attend a mass that you are leading. I would love to see the priest at work who joined the church at twenty who believed.

roll.outcome: Spiritual Recognition: The bishop sees genuine faith in Juan that hasn't been corrupted by power. He responds as a priest rather than politician, sharing his own struggles and hopes for the Church. A true alliance forms rooted in shared faith.

encounters.recap: When Juan reveals he wants nothing from Barcelona's Church except for it to fulfill its spiritual mission, the Bishop experiences a spiritual awakening. The old priest remembers why he entered the Church forty years ago, admits he had forgotten the Church's true purpose amid decades of politics, and offers genuine partnership. He promises to write supportive letters to other Aragonese bishops, support the Constantinople expedition as a crusade, and provide blessed alliance when Juan returns. The meeting ends with Juan kneeling to receive the Bishop's genuine blessing and requesting to pray together or attend mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop looks down at Juan kneeling before him. For a moment, his hands tremble. This is not the ceremonial blessing he has given a thousand times to nobles seeking favor, to merchants wanting church approval for their ventures, to diplomats who needed the appearance of ecclesiastical support. This is something else. He places his hands on Juan's head. His voice, when it comes, is rougher than he intends.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Benedictio Dei omnipotentis, Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, descendat super te et maneat semper. May the Lord bless you and keep you. May He make His face to shine upon you, and be gracious unto you. May He lift up His countenance upon you, and give you peace. Go to Constantinople, Your Majesty. Defend the faith. And come home safely to your wife and your daughter and the kingdoms that need you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hands remain on Juan's head a moment longer than necessary. He withdraws his hands, and Juan rises. Then Juan speaks of prayer. Of Mass. Of seeing 'the priest who joined at twenty who believed.' The bishop's expression flickers — something crosses his face that he cannot quite hide. He turns away, moving back toward the window, and is quiet for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is different. Smaller. Less certain.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: You ask to see a man I am not sure still exists, Your Majesty. I have said Mass thousands of times. Thousands. The words are... they are words now. I say them correctly. I perform the liturgy with precision. The faithful receive the sacrament and go home satisfied. But the priest who believed... he would have meant every word. He would have felt the presence of God in the bread and wine, not merely affirmed it doctrinally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to face Juan and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: You have given me something today. Something I thought I had lost forever. But I cannot simply... become that man again in an afternoon. Faith is not a garment one puts on and takes off. I am afraid, Your Majesty. Afraid that if I try to pray with you as that young priest would have prayed, you will see what I fear is true — that he is gone, and only the politician remains wearing his vestments.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He spreads his hands — a gesture of helplessness from a man not accustomed to admitting helplessness.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: I will say Mass tomorrow morning. The Feast of... no, it is simply an ordinary day. An ordinary Mass for ordinary faithful. You are welcome to attend. You and the Queen. But I ask that you not expect... I ask that you understand I am only beginning to remember. I cannot promise that the priest who believed will be there. Only that I will try to find him. Is that enough? For a king who speaks of trying, who told his court that all we can do is try — is my trying enough?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But father, of course it is enough. It is always enough if we try. I think that God places obstacles on our path to test us sometimes. How we deal with them, we discover who we are. Do not put burden to perform on yourself father. Just try to reach for whatever inspires you and you may yet surprise others and yourself. We will see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises gracefully from her chair, smoothing her burgundy gown. Her eyes move between Juan and the bishop, and there is something soft in her expression—she has witnessed something unexpected this morning, and it has touched her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: Your Excellency. Thank you for your honesty. It is... rarer than it should be.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. You have married a remarkable man. I suspect you already know this.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: I am learning it. Day by day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop walks them to the door of the reception chamber. At the threshold, he pauses.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Tomorrow. The Mass will be at the hour of Terce—mid-morning. The Cathedral of Santa Eulàlia. It is not complete, but... perhaps that is fitting. Neither am I. I will not promise the priest who believed. But I will try not to be only the politician. It has been a very long time since anyone asked me to try.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He makes the sign of the cross over them both—a small gesture, almost reflexive, but genuine.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Go with God, Your Majesties. I will see you tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As they walk, Lucia takes Juan's arm. She is quiet for a moment, then speaks softly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: That was not what I expected, caro. Not at all. You did something to that man. Something real. Is this what you meant, last night? About turning hearts through honesty? I have watched my father's court for twenty years. I have never seen a king do what you just did. Show everything. Ask for nothing. And receive... that.

encounters.recap: Juan receives a deeply personal blessing from the Bishop of Barcelona, who confesses his spiritual crisis and admits he no longer feels the faith he once had as a young priest. Juan's request to see 'the priest who believed' moves the bishop to vulnerability and self-reflection. The bishop invites them to Mass the next morning, promising to try to rediscover his lost faith.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And if you are uncertain what to say, you may wink at me. I will be watching. Now. Let us see what diplomatic crisis Catalina has created with the nursery staff.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I love you Lucia d'Este.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And I love you, Juan of Castile. Even when you swing your hammer at things that do not need hammering. Especially then.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They find Catalina in a sunlit room overlooking a garden, surrounded by evidence of extensive negotiations. Donna Francesca sits in a chair with the expression of a woman who has been thoroughly outmaneuvered. A young Aragonese nursemaid hovers nearby, looking uncertain. On a small table sits an empty plate with suspicious crumbs. On another table sits a second empty plate with more suspicious crumbs. Catalina herself is on the floor, engaged in serious diplomatic discussions with a boy of perhaps four years — dark-haired, solemn-faced, dressed in fine clothes that mark him as noble-born. Between them are arranged several wooden animals, a small cloth ball, and what appears to be a torn piece of parchment that has been folded into something vaguely boat-shaped.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No. Bird goes here. Horse goes there. Is obvious.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: But the horse wants to be with the bird.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse is wrong.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. The princess has been... she has been very well-behaved. She has made a friend. This is young Lord Bernat, son of the Viscount of Cardona. His mother brought him to play while she attends the regent.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Mama! Catalina has a friend. His name is... His name is Boy.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Bernat.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Ber-nat. Catalina taught him about horses. He did not know horses go there.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And how many crostatas did this important lesson require, piccola?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: One and a half. Like we agreed.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Perhaps... perhaps there were two and a half, Your Majesty. The young lord was hungry, and the princess felt it was only fair to keep him company.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Fair. Company.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And has Catalina been good? Have you been playing nice with Bernat?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina is always good.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She took my horse. And she said birds are better than horses. And she said her papa conquered a whole kingdom and my papa only has a... A viscounty.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse was in the wrong place. And Papa did conquer a kingdom. Is true.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Lord Bernat. Did Catalina share her crostatas with you, at least?

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She gave me half of one. She said it was generous.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Half. Catalina is very generous. Papa. Bernat does not know about rope. Or about the boy in the water. Should Catalina tell him?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina, my daughter. It is always better to let others talk about the good things you did. And when we are with others, we always share with them equally as they share equally with us.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But... But if Catalina does not tell, how will Boy know?

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Bernat.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: How will Bernat know?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Others will tell him, piccola. The story travels on its own. And when you do not tell it, but others do, it becomes even more... impressive.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: More impressive. Share... equally? Catalina had two. Bernat had half. That is not equal. But Catalina was hungry.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She said she was a princess and princesses get more.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Maybe. Maybe Catalina gives Bernat a crostata next time.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe you can play that Bernat is the king, and you are a viscountess for a while no? See how you like it. We will be back in a short while love, me and Lucia have some boring stuff to do yet.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But... But Catalina is a princess.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And Bernat is a viscount's son. But in play, we can be anything. That is what makes it play.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: I could be king?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Bernat can be king. For a little while. And Catalina will be... Vis-coun-tess. But a very important viscountess. Who has a horse. And a bird. And the king listens to her advice because she is very smart.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Can the king have the horse?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: The king can borrow the horse. Because he is king. But the viscountess still owns it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have fun!

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: A very important viscountess. Who owns the horse but graciously allows the king to borrow it. I wonder where she learned to negotiate like that.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia visit the nursery where Catalina has been playing with young Lord Bernat. They discover she has been dominating their games and eating more than her share of treats. Juan teaches her about sharing equally and letting others tell her stories, while Lucia suggests they play with reversed roles. Catalina reluctantly agrees to let Bernat be king while she is a viscountess, but negotiates to remain 'very important' and retain ownership of the toy horse.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning sun has climbed higher over Barcelona by the time you emerge from the bishop's study. The bells of Santa Eulàlia toll the end of Terce somewhere behind you, their bronze voices echoing through the narrow streets of the Barri Gòtic.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, Don Ramon de Perellós awaits in the regent's council chamber. He sent word asking whether you wished him to attend you here, or if you preferred to meet in the Palau Reial.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back to the palace would take perhaps a quarter hour through the winding streets. The morning air is crisp but not cold—mild for January, even by Mediterranean standards. Lucia remained at the palace with Catalina after your departure for the bishop's meeting. The Consell de Cent, Barcelona's powerful city council and merchant guilds, expects you at midday. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience for the afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will visit the regent in his palace. We go there now.

encounters.recap: After his meeting with Bishop Climent, Juan decides to meet with Don Ramon de Perellós at the Palau Reial to discuss court administration and the itinerary for his remaining time in Barcelona, with other important meetings scheduled for the day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Palau Reial rises at the heart of the old city—less imposing than Toledo's Alcázar, but older, its stones worn smooth by centuries of Catalan counts and Aragonese kings. The guards at the gate snap to attention as you approach, and a steward appears almost immediately to escort you through the courtyard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon de Perellós receives you in the regent's council chamber—a long room dominated by a heavy oak table and tapestries depicting the conquest of Majorca. He rises from behind a desk cluttered with documents, bowing precisely.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Majesty. I trust the morning has been productive. I have prepared a proposed itinerary for Your Majesty's remaining time in Barcelona. The Consell de Cent at midday, as arranged. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience—I have suggested the fourth hour after noon, if that suits. Don Guillem de Vic wishes to present certain communications he has drafted on Your Majesty's behalf. I understand Your Majesty visited Bishop Climent Sapera this morning. A lengthy meeting, by all accounts.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for the effort and care you took for facilitating these meetings. I trust there are issues or matters you yourself want to discuss with us as well? We are here and you have our ear.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon inclines his head at Juan's offer, his expression revealing nothing. He does not immediately continue. Instead, he moves to the window, adjusting the angle of a shutter as if the light offended him. When he turns back, his hands are clasped behind his back—the posture of a man preparing to deliver a report.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. The matter of the itinerary is not... merely logistical. Barcelona is not Toledo, Your Majesty. The Consell de Cent guards its prerogatives jealously. The Count of Pallars speaks for nobles who remember when Aragón's king lived in Aragón. The merchants want to know whether Castilian trade agreements will respect Catalan privileges. In four years as head of the regency council, I have learned that scheduling is governance. Who sees the king, and when, and in what order—these things matter. They send signals. They create expectations. They establish... hierarchies. Your Majesty arrived yesterday evening. Since then, you have spoken privately with Don Guillem de Vic, with the Count of Pallars, and this morning—at considerable length—with Bishop Climent Sapera. The regency council was not consulted regarding any of these conversations. Queen María has requested that I coordinate all further meetings through Her Majesty's secretary. She wishes to be informed in advance of Your Majesty's appointments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I appologize immediately for not consulting with you sooner. An oversight I cannot take back. You have my word that not seeing you sooner was somehow a deliberate act to undermine your authority or to diminish it. I simply took audiences with anyone willing to speak with me. But now that we are here, what matters should we discuss? And what are the concerns of the regency council?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon accepts the apology with a slight bow—correct, minimal. He does not say accepted. He does not say of course or think nothing of it. He simply... notes it.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's word is noted. Your Majesty asks what the council's concerns are. That is a... complex question. The council's concerns depend greatly on circumstances. On what is being proposed. On what commitments may already have been made. I have served as head of this council for four years. In that time, I have learned that I cannot advise a king on what he should do until I understand what he has done. Don Guillem de Vic left the reception last night speaking of 'great things to come' and 'bringing the kingdoms together.' The Count of Pallars sent a messenger to his estates at first light—I do not know why. Bishop Climent Sapera has reportedly cancelled his morning appointments to draft letters to the Archbishop of Tarragona. What should the regency council's concerns be, Your Majesty? What has been discussed? What has been offered? What expectations now exist that did not exist two days ago?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I tell the regent exactly what has happened and do not hold back. I tell him about my vision for a better world and how bringing the kingdoms closer together might help this. That I have been able to share this vision with others who are now also trying to achieve this. That the kingdoms uniting should not be Aragon joining Castille, but both kingdoms joining to become something else with neither holding dominance. I also tell him that I talked about the crown succession with Maria. And that I should have asked her about the current situation regarding succession and my own role in this.
