Juan offers to personally assess the situation when meeting Alfonso, leading to the compromise that the letter travels separately from Juan's diplomatic mission.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber empties slowly. Soon only Juan, Lucia, and María remain—and Don Ramon, hovering near the door with his papers. María stands at the head of the table, her hand resting on the regent's chair.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Brother. Will you walk with me? There is a garden. We could speak. Just the two of us. If your queen permits.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Of course. Sister. Take all the time you need. I will be with Catalina. She will want to hear about the very important meeting where Papa sat in a big chair and talked to important people.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia withdraws. Don Ramon departs, closing the heavy door behind him. The council chamber falls silent. María moves toward a small door half-hidden behind a tapestry. The garden is small—an intimate courtyard enclosed by high walls, invisible from the rest of the palace. A fountain murmurs at its center. Winter roses climb a trellis, their blooms sparse but fragrant. María walks to the fountain and stands with her back to Juan, looking down at the water.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I watched you today. In the council. You could have pressed us. On Constantinople. On the trade agreements. On a dozen small things where you held advantage. Why didn't you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Advantage or imbalance also creates conflict. I seek none with Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Conflict. I have spent four years managing conflict. Between the factions. Between what Alfonso wants and what the kingdom can give. Between what I am told to do and what I know must be done. You hurt me, Juan. When you first came. I know. Lucia told me you understood. That you learned. I watched you prove it today—with the Consell, with Don Ramon, with the council itself. But I need to understand something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves to a stone bench and sits, her hands folded in her lap. She looks up at him, and for a moment she is not the Regent of Aragón. She is his sister. A woman in her thirties, childless, governing a kingdom for a husband who may never return, watching her brother build an empire while she holds together what remains.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You speak of unity. Of kingdoms joining to become something new. Of neither holding dominance. But you are King of Castile. Conqueror of Granada. Heir presumptive to this throne I sit upon in Alfonso's absence. If Alfonso dies—when Alfonso dies—you will have everything. Castile. Aragón. Perhaps Naples, if his war succeeds. The largest Christian kingdom since Charlemagne. What happens to me, Juan? In this vision of yours. What place is there for a childless queen whose husband is gone and whose brother wears all the crowns?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are my sister Maria. I want nothing but for you to be happy. You already told me you do not want an estate somewhere to live in peace. What do you want? If you are interested in statecraft, I need many governors I can trust. Or you can stay at my court. Watch Catalina and my other children grow up. Educate them, be their aunt. But I do not know what you would want Maria. All I can say is that I will take care of you. What do you want?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María stiffens at first when Juan's arms close around her—the reflex of a woman who has held herself rigid for four years, who cannot afford softness. Then something breaks. She sags against him. A shudder runs through her. She does not weep—perhaps she has forgotten how—but her breath comes ragged, and her hands grip the fabric of his doublet like a drowning woman gripping driftwood.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: What do I want. Alfonso wanted Naples. So I wanted Alfonso to have Naples. Father wanted a strong alliance with Castile. So I wanted to be a good wife, a good queen, a good regent. No one has ever asked me what I want, Juan. Not once. Not in thirty-four years. You offer me an estate. A governorship. A place at your court, watching your children grow. These are kind offers. Generous offers. The offers of a brother who wishes to take care of his sister. I have governed Aragón for four years. I have held together a kingdom while its king chased dreams in Italy. I have managed factions that wanted to tear each other apart. I have signed levies and heard petitions and made decisions that cost men their lives and livelihoods. And you offer me... an estate. Children to watch. A quiet corner where I will not be in the way. Is that what you see when you look at me, brother? A woman to be taken care of? Given a comfortable place and a gentle purpose?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No, not at all! I just offered them up as possibilities. And I just said you do NOT want an estate somewhere. I love you sister. I will never forget how you taught me about love when we met four years ago when I fell in love with that noble woman. It made me realize how important family is and how much I needed a sister. I love you Maria, but please let me love you. I cannot give what I cannot see. You have not answered my question. What do you want?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I don't know. I have never— When I was a girl, I wanted to ride horses and read books about faraway places. Then I was told I would marry Alfonso, and I wanted to be a good wife. Then Alfonso left for Naples, and I wanted to be a good regent. Then the years passed, and I wanted— I wanted a child. Just one. Something that was mine. Something I had not been given or assigned or obligated to. God did not grant me that. So I governed. Because governing was what was needed. Because if I could not be a mother, I could at least be useful. And now you ask me what I want, and I stand here like a fool, because I have spent so long wanting what others needed me to want that I do not know if there is anything left underneath. You want to give me something, brother? Then give me time. Time to answer a question I have never been allowed to ask myself. And if I find an answer—if I discover that what I want is something you cannot give, or something that frightens you, or something that does not fit neatly into your vision of unity and family— Will you still love me then?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maria. When I was struggling with matters of love, you spoke with such certainty. Such wisdom. I will never forget it. It surprises me you now seem so uncertain. Maybe it is so much easier to help others than we can help ourselves. Why don't you come and visit us tomorrow? Bring a crostata or better yet, a Catalan treat Catalina may like. I think it will do you much good. Family can see things other can not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María stares at him. For a moment, something flickers across her face—a dozen emotions too quick to name. Surprise. Uncertainty. Something that might be the beginning of a smile, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: A crostata. You are offering me... a crostata. And time with your daughter. I just told you that I do not know who I am. That I have spent my entire life being what others needed. That I am terrified of becoming irrelevant. And your answer is pastry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns away, her hand covering her mouth. Her shoulders shake. When she turns back, there are tears on her cheeks—but she is smiling. A strange, broken, genuine thing.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You impossible man. You absolute fool. I pour out my heart and you invite me for crostatas. Yes. Fine. Tomorrow. I will bring ensaïmadas. They are Mallorcan. Catalina will make a mess of herself. The nurses will despair. I do not have answers yet, Juan. I may not have them before you sail. I may not have them for years. But I will... try. To find them. To ask the question. And yes. I will come tomorrow. To see your daughter. To meet your wife properly—not as a wounded queen, but as... As a sister. If she will have me.

encounters.recap: In a private garden conversation, María opens up to Juan about her deep uncertainty about her own desires and identity after years of living only to fulfill others' expectations. She reveals her fears about becoming irrelevant and her struggle with never having been asked what she wants for herself. Through tears and vulnerability, they reach a breakthrough when Juan's simple invitation to visit with pastries breaks through her walls, leading to genuine laughter and her agreement to try discovering her own wants while building a relationship as his sister.

roll.outcome: Survives childhood healthy. Fortune and constitution carry her through to adulthood.

encounters.recap: A survival roll determined that Princess Catalina will survive the dangerous years of medieval childhood. Despite high infant mortality rates of the era, she will live to grow up, experiencing only minor illnesses and accidents. Additional trait rolls revealed her as brilliant (87), commanding (76), musically gifted with an angelic voice (5), indifferent to faith (7), and beautiful (70). The cruel irony emerges that her divine singing voice moves others to tears during sacred music, yet she feels no spiritual connection herself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ensaïmadas arrive before María does. A servant brings them on a silver tray—spiraled pastries dusted with powdered sugar, their surfaces glistening with rendered pork fat in the Mallorcan style. The scent fills the nursery: butter, sweetness, something faintly exotic.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: What are those.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Those are ensaïmadas, cariño. Your Aunt María is bringing them. We must wait for her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But they are here.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The pastries are here. Your aunt is not.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina will guard them. Until Aunt María comes. So no one eats them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A noble sacrifice.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Yes. Very noble.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María arrives at the hour of Terce. She wears a simpler gown than yesterday—still fine, but less formal. The regent's chain of office is absent. Her hair is braided in a style Juan remembers from their childhood, before crowns and politics complicated everything. She hesitates at the nursery door.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sister. Thank you for coming.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I... brought ensaïmadas. For Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: AUNT MARÍA! I guarded them! The pastries! No one ate them! I was VERY NOBLE!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She collides with María's skirts, wrapping her arms around the queen's legs. María looks down at the small face beaming up at her. Something in her expression cracks.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Very well, little one. You guarded them. You should have the honor of first choice.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: This one. No. This one. The big one has more sugar. Catalina will take... the swirly one. Because swirly is special. You take the big one. Because you are the queen and queens get the big ones.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Thank you, Catalina. That is very generous.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They settle around the small table—Juan, Lucia, María, and Catalina, with Inés hovering nearby. The ensaïmadas are everything promised: light, buttery, the sugar melting on the tongue. Catalina gets powdered sugar on her nose, her cheeks, somehow in her hair.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Aunt María, do you have a horse?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I do. Several, actually.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: What are their names?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Well, there is Estrella—that means 'star.' And Ventisco—

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I have a horse. His name is Hidalgo. He is very brave. Can your horses jump?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I believe Estrella jumps quite well.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Hidalgo jumps higher.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Shall we go horse riding later today? We still have some time. Catalina loves to ride on horses. We can watch the ships.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Horse riding. To watch the ships.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Yes. The harbor is beautiful from the Montjuïc hill. And Catalina has been asking to see the big ships since we arrived.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: THE BIG SHIPS! With the sails! And the flags! Inés says they go very far away across the water!

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I... cannot remember the last time I rode for pleasure. There is always a procession, or a formal hunt, or some delegation to receive. Riding has become... another duty. But today there is no procession. No delegation. No council. I would like that. Very much.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: AUNT MARÍA IS COMING! We will see the ships AND the horses will jump AND— Aunt María, can you race?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I used to. When I was young.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You are not that old. You can probably still go a little fast.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I suppose we shall find out.

encounters.recap: María visits the royal family in their private apartments, sharing ensaïmadas with young Catalina. The informal setting allows María to drop her regent's formality and reconnect with her family, particularly bonding with her energetic niece. The visit culminates in plans to go horseback riding together to watch the ships in Barcelona's harbor, marking a significant softening in family relationships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The royal party draws looks as it passes through Barcelona's streets—but not the formal stares that greet processions. This is something else: a king on horseback with a small child before him, two queens riding side by side, a handful of guards trailing at a respectful distance. No banners. No heralds. Just family. Catalina sits before Juan on Hidalgo, her small hands gripping the pommel with fierce determination.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Faster, Papa.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We are in the city, cariño. We must be careful of people.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But the ships.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The ships will wait.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: What if they leave?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then we will watch other ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They pass through the Porta de Mar and the city falls away behind them. The road winds upward toward the hill of Montjuïc, the harbor spreading out below like a map painted in blue and white and the warm brown of wooden hulls. Dozens of vessels crowd the harbor—fishing boats and merchant carracks, sleek war galleys with their oars shipped, fat-bellied traders from Genoa and Venice and places beyond.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: SHIPS! Many ships!

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I used to come here as a girl. Before I was married. I would watch the ships and wonder where they were going. I never found out.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You know Catalina, we will be going on a big ship and leave over the water in a few weeks time? We will travel for many days on the big ship.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: On the water? In a ship?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, cariño. A very big ship. With sails and flags, just like those.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Will Hidalgo come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hidalgo will stay here and rest. But there will be other horses where we are going.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Will Mama come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Mama is coming.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Will Aunt María come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Aunt María has to stay here. She has an important job. She takes care of Aragón while King Alfonso is away.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But who takes care of Aunt María?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: That is a very good question.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Yes. We will take care of Aunt María. Aunt María, do you like crostatas?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I... yes. I suppose I do.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good. Catalina will give you a crostata. And a hug. That is what we do when people are sad or need taking care of. Papa said we don't have to give hugs to everyone. But you are family. Family gets hugs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's composure cracks. She turns her horse away slightly, one hand rising to her face. Her shoulders tremble.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Aunt María? Did Catalina say something wrong?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: No, little one. No, you said something very right. Thank you, Catalina. I would very much like a crostata. And a hug. I cannot remember the last time someone offered me either.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They find a baker in the Plaça del Pi. Juan pays twice what the crostata is worth. They gather in María's private chambers rather than the formal apartments—smaller, warmer, less like a throne room. Cushions and chairs pulled close together. No servants. No ceremony. Catalina has claimed a position on María's lap, which María accepted with an expression of stunned wonder.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You must take the first piece, Aunt María. Because you are the queen here. Then Papa, because he paid. Then Mama. Then Catalina. Then Catalina again, if there is more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They eat. The crostata is sweet and sticky and imperfect and wonderful. At some point, María's arm settles around Catalina's small body—not stiffly, not formally, but naturally. As if it belongs there. When Catalina's energy finally fades, she slumps against María's chest, eyelids drooping.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Aunt María? You are not so sad anymore.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: No. No, I am not so sad anymore.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María looks at Juan over the child's head. Her eyes are bright.

encounters.recap: A family horseback ride to Montjuïc Hill becomes a healing moment for María of Aragón. Through Catalina's innocent offer of care and a shared crostata in María's chambers, the lonely regent experiences genuine familial connection for the first time in years, finding comfort in the simple act of being part of a loving family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Seven hundred knights in white tabards marked with the crosses of their orders—Santiago's red sword-cross, Calatrava's crimson fleur-de-lys cross, Alcántara's green cross—stand in formation on the fields beyond the city walls. They have been assembling for weeks, arriving in groups from their commanderies across Castile and Aragón. Veterans of the Granada campaign, most of them. Men who stormed the walls of Málaga and Loja, who stood in the breach at Alhama, who watched the Sultan's banner fall over the Alhambra. Now they prepare for a longer journey. Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The men are assembled for inspection.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles' expression tells Juan something is wrong before they reach the first rank.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty should be aware... There have been difficulties.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The inspection reveals the problems starkly. Sickness. A fever has swept through the camp over the past week. Nearly sixty men lie in the infirmary tents, shivering under blankets. Three have died. The physicians speak of bad water from a nearby stream, or perhaps tainted provisions. The illness is not plague—thank God—but it has spread fear through the ranks. Supply Issues. A shipment of preserved meat from Valencia arrived spoiled. The replacement shipment is delayed—perhaps another week, perhaps longer. The men have food, but not the stocks needed for a long sea voyage. The quartermasters are scrambling. Morale. The waiting has worn on them. These are veterans of Granada—men who fought and won. Now they sit in muddy fields outside Barcelona while their commanders negotiate politics and their supplies rot. Rumors have spread: Constantinople is hopeless. The Greeks will betray us like they betrayed the last crusaders. We will die far from home for a city that cannot be saved.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks the ranks. The men stand at attention, but he sees it in their eyes. Exhaustion. Doubt. The hollow look of soldiers who have begun to wonder if their leaders know what they are doing. A Santiago knight coughs violently as Juan passes, barely suppressing it. His face is pale, sheened with sweat. He should be in the infirmary. He is standing inspection through sheer will.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Order commanders blame each other for the supply failures. Santiago says Calatrava's quartermaster accepted the spoiled meat without proper inspection. Calatrava says Santiago's camp placement contaminated the water. Alcántara's men feel overlooked entirely—they claim their equipment requests have been ignored. The men need to see leadership, Your Majesty. They need to know this expedition has purpose. Right now, they see only confusion and sickness and delay.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The white tabards flutter in the February wind. Seven hundred men—or six hundred and forty, with the sick—waiting for a king to tell them why they should sail to the edge of the world.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: What would Your Majesty like to do?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Assemble the men who can stand. I will address them. I don my full armour and let the white banner be presented. I tell Lucia and Catalina to wait at a distance. This is something for soldiers. I steel myself. This is the first act in a new campaign. One much grander than the Granada campaign.

roll.outcome: Troubled. Supply issues, low morale, sickness in the camp. Problems need addressing.

encounters.recap: Juan inspects his assembled knights preparing for the Constantinople expedition but discovers a crisis: fever has sickened sixty men with three deaths, spoiled supplies from Valencia have created shortages, and morale is collapsing among the veteran Granada campaigners who see only delay and confusion. The Order commanders blame each other while six hundred and forty healthy men await leadership to restore their faith in the mission.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The armor weighs on Juan's shoulders like memory. It is the same harness he wore at Málaga, at Loja, at the final assault on Granada's gates. The dents have been hammered out, the metal polished until it gleams, but it remembers. And so does his body—the particular way it settles, the restriction of breath, the way the world narrows to what can be seen through the visor. He leaves the visor up. These men need to see his face. The white banner of the crusade snaps in the February wind—the same banner that flew over Alhama, that was carried through the breach at Alcalá la Real, that Giovanni Rossi prayed beneath every night of the campaign. Brother Guillem's hands once steadied it. Marco Tornesi fought beneath its shadow. Those men are in Constantinople now. Or dead on the road there. Juan does not yet know which.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The knights assemble in ragged ranks. Six hundred and forty-three men able to stand. Some lean on their neighbors. The Santiago knight who coughed during inspection is there, pale as milk, swaying slightly but upright. Pride holds him vertical where strength cannot. Behind them, the infirmary tents. Sixty more men who will hear this speech through canvas walls, straining to catch words that might give meaning to their suffering. The Order commanders stand before their contingents: a Santiago captain with a scar across his jaw, a Calatrava veteran missing two fingers from a Moorish blade, an Alcántara sergeant who looks like he has not slept in days. Their faces are guarded. They have been blaming each other for a week. Now they wait to see who their king blames.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers. We are about to embark on a great journey. A journey that will take us from Barcelona to Rome and beyond to Constantinople. Much is at stake. The church is divided and the eternal city, the last light of Christendom is about to be snuffed out. We have just won a great victory against the Moors and have done things no-one had deemed possible. We ended the reconquista. It was hard in the beginning. We have suffered setbacks and even defeats here and there. The muslims are hard fighters and they made us bleed made us suffer. Cut our supply lines. Left us hungry and miserable while we were sieging mighty walls. Right now, we are tired, sick. Maybe even hungry. Such is the fate of knights and soldiers. But have we not been here before? Have we not overcome hunger and pain? Yes! we have. We know what to do as well. We lack supplies, so we aquire more. We are sick, so we tend to our brothers until we are better. And when we are ready to move out, when we are ready to go on this incredible journey, only then we will leave. When I met the Greek delegation in Basel, they had given up all hope. No-one was going to help them. No-one had the courage, the will, the determination. No-one but the sons of Castille! We go where no-one else dared journey. We face what no-one else dared face. We fight for what everyone else seems to have forgotten. We know that when we raise our swords in the name of Christ, we serve a higher purpose.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I stand before you today on the first day of this incredible journey to speak the words. Words that have carried us over blood-soaked fields and towards victory. Non nobis Domine!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The wind carries the words across the field. For a moment—a long, terrible moment—there is only silence. Then, from somewhere in the Santiago ranks, a voice answers: 'Non nobis Domine.' Another joins. Then another. The response spreads—but slowly, unevenly, like fire struggling to catch in wet kindling. 'Non nobis Domine, non nobis, sed nomini tuo da gloriam.' It is not the thunder of Granada. It is not the roar that shook the walls of Málaga or echoed through the Alhambra's halls. It is tired men doing what they have been trained to do. Speaking words they remember because their bodies remember, even when their hearts are uncertain.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: They answered, Your Majesty. That is something. But they need more than words now. They need to see the supply wagons arrive. They need to see the sick recover. They need to see that someone is solving the problems, not just acknowledging them. You have bought time, Your Majesty. Perhaps a week. Perhaps less. What would you have me do?

roll.outcome: Grudging acknowledgment. The response comes—'Non nobis Domine'—but muted, tired. The veterans remember Granada, but Constantinople feels different. Doubt lingers. The speech bought time, not belief.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses his assembled knights in full armor beneath the white crusade banner, acknowledging their hardships while calling upon memories of Granada's victory and their destiny as the only hope for Constantinople. The knights respond to the traditional prayer but with tired voices and lingering doubt. Captain Robles warns that the speech has bought only time—practical problems must be solved quickly or the words will turn to resentment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent is cramped, utilitarian—a campaign shelter, not a throne room. A table dominates the center, covered with supply manifests, maps, and the detritus of a troubled expedition. The canvas walls snap in the wind. Juan enters still in armor. Captain Robles follows, then the three Order commanders file in behind. They do not sit. No one has offered, and the tension in the air does not invite comfort.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Commanders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence. The three men eye each other like wolves sharing a kill—allies in name, rivals in truth.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's speech was stirring. But speeches do not fill bellies or cure fevers. If we are to address problems, let us begin with who created them. Calatrava's quartermaster accepted meat that a blind man could smell was rotten—

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Santiago's camp placement put us downstream from a tanner's waste. My men did not poison the water. Yours did.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: If either of you had listened to Alcántara's concerns three weeks ago—

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara has one hundred men. This is not your expedition to command.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Enough! Lets focus on the problem. Care for the sick first. They are now taken care of in tents right? Could we not accomodate them in a hospital or grant them other and better accomodation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand rigid, their accusations still hanging in the air like smoke. But Juan's voice—sharp, commanding—has cut through the noise.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is a hospital, Your Majesty. The Hospital de la Santa Creu, within the city walls. It is run by the Church—the canons of the Cathedral. It is one of the finest in Aragón. They have tended plague victims, pilgrims, soldiers. If anyone can help our sick, they can. Shall I send word to Don Ramon to arrange it? We could have the men moved by nightfall.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Moving sixty men through the city... it would be visible. Public. Word would spread that the expedition is weakened. That the King of Castile's knights are dying in camp before they even board ships.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: They are already dying in camp. Three dead. More to follow if we do nothing.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara speaks truth, for once. The tents are inadequate. Cold at night, damp, no proper drainage. The physicians do what they can, but... They need walls. Hearths. Clean water. Things we cannot provide in a field camp.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will secure the hospital for our brothers. Food is next. What are we missing? Both what we consume right now and what we need for the journey.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles spreads a supply manifest across the table, weighting the corners with a dagger and a cup.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: For current consumption, we are... adequate. Barely. For the voyage, the situation is worse. We need, at minimum: Salted meat: Four hundred barrels. We have sixty-three. Ship's biscuit: Six hundred crates. We have four hundred. How long is Your Majesty willing to delay departure?

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: My men have been on half-portions of meat for six days. The Alcántara quartermaster has been requesting resupply since before the fever struck. We were told to wait. We waited.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The meat is the crisis. Without it, men weaken. Weak men sicken. Sick men die—especially at sea. Valencia failed us. We need another source. Quickly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will have to pay either way. Can we send riders for other markets? And can we resupply in Naples and other cities we pass along the way?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Riders to Tarragona—one day there, one day back. If their salting houses have stock, we could see barrels arriving within the week. I can dispatch riders within the hour, Your Majesty. And send word ahead to Rome and Naples to prepare provisions for our arrival.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Rome will be expensive. The papal court inflates prices for everything. But the markets there are vast—we can find what we need if we pay. Naples is better. Alfonso's army has established supply lines.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I want to leave with enough meat in stock to last us a while. Send riders for more meat. I want to sail with around 250-300 barrels. Pay their price to secure this. And finally, we must adress the situation of half ration while we are still in friendly territory. Now, if we assume the sick will have proper accomodation, we are getting enouth supplies and the men have a full belly, are there other issues we should adress?

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: Equipment, Your Majesty. Alcántara requisitioned replacement armor and weapons six weeks ago. Twelve hauberks. Twenty swords. Horse tack for the mounted sergeants. We were told supplies were limited and priority went to the larger Orders. My men are patching rust with prayer.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of... command structure. At Granada, Your Majesty led. The Orders followed. Clear. Simple. Here, we have three commanders, three quartermasters, three chains of supply. We have been working beside each other, not together.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Calatrava speaks truth. When problems arose, each Order blamed the others because no one had authority to solve them. We need a single commander under Your Majesty. Someone who can knock heads together when quartermasters squabble over spoiled meat.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Regarding the command structure; we need one subordinate commander under myself. And one quarter master. Lets not make a choice right now, but rather think about it for one day. Either you have chosen a commander and quarter master yourself from your own ranks or I will appoint someone on the spot. Either way, we will have one quarter master and one commander.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand frozen, processing what Juan has just done. He has not chosen between them—which would have created a winner and two resentful losers. He has told them to solve it themselves, or have the decision taken from their hands.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is wise to give us time. Santiago will... confer with the other Orders.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Calatrava concurs. One day. We will present a unified recommendation. Or we will accept Your Majesty's judgment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We all have our assignments, we meet back here tomorrow. I get out and immediately leave to arrange hospital for the sick crusaders. I do not rest until these matters are resolved.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes an urgent meeting with his military commanders to address critical expedition problems: sick men in inadequate tents, spoiled supplies, and command structure disputes. He secures hospital care for the ill, orders supply missions to procure 250-300 barrels of meat, and gives the three Order commanders one day to choose unified leadership or face his direct appointment. The meeting transforms from finger-pointing to problem-solving.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hospital's prior, Father Bernat Metge, receives Juan in the stone courtyard where patients once walked during the Black Death. The building is vast—arched cloisters, clean wards, the smell of herbs and lye soap rather than rot and despair.

exchanges.speaker: father_bernat_metge
exchanges.text: Your Majesty does us honor. The knights who conquered Granada are heroes of Christendom. How could we refuse them?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within two hours, carts begin transferring the sick from the muddy camp to clean beds with fresh linens. The hospital's physicians—experienced men who have treated everything from plague to sword wounds—examine each patient with professional efficiency. "The fever is not plague," the chief physician reports to Juan. "Waterborne, likely. With rest, clean water, and proper care... most will recover. A week, perhaps two." The sick Santiago knight who stood through Juan's speech is among those carried in. He grips Juan's arm as he passes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María listens to Juan's request without interruption.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: You need to feed seven hundred men. Not just feed them—feast them. This will cost a fortune.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will pay.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: You will not. These men defended Christendom at Granada. They go now to defend it at Constantinople. Aragón can spare a feast for such a cause.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She summons Don Ramon.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Open the palace stores. Send word to the Boqueria—we need roasted meats, good bread, wine, fruit, whatever can be gathered by nightfall. This is not charity. This is honor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María looks at Juan.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: You are not the only one who can take care of family, brother.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon becomes a blur of activity. Water: Fresh barrels arrive from the city on a train of carts—clean mountain water from Barcelona's cisterns. The contaminated stream is marked with warning posts. Men drink deeply, gratefully, for the first time in days. Latrines: Juan inspects them personally. The sight of a king examining drainage trenches spreads through the camp like wildfire. Within hours, soldiers who had grown complacent are digging new trenches, relocating the old ones downhill and away from the water supply. A Calatrava sergeant who served at Granada takes charge, organizing work parties with renewed purpose. "If His Majesty can stand in shit," one knight mutters, "so can we." Drainage: The camp's lowest areas—where mud has pooled and tents have grown damp—are abandoned. New positions are established on higher ground. It is hard work, but men who were listless that morning find energy they did not know they had.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As the sun sets over Barcelona, carts roll into camp. Roasted pork. Lamb. Fresh bread still warm from the ovens. Wheels of Catalan cheese. Almonds and dried figs. Casks of good wine—not the thin camp stuff, but proper Aragonese red. The men gather around fires that burn brighter than they have in weeks. There are no speeches. No ceremony. Just food, wine, and the slowly returning warmth of men who had begun to forget what it felt like to be valued.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: The men are asking who arranged this.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Her Majesty the Regent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan returns to the palace exhausted, still wearing armor that has accumulated mud from latrine inspections and dust from supervising water deliveries. Lucia meets him at the door of their chambers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You smell like a stable.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Worse, probably.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She helps him remove the armor, piece by piece.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The camp?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Better. Not healed. But better.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: María told me what she did. The feast.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: She did not have to.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: No. She wanted to.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From the nursery, the sound of Catalina's voice, singing something tuneless and sweet as Inés puts her to bed.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The commanders meet tomorrow. They must choose a single leader.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Will they?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not know.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia kisses his forehead.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You did what you could today. More than most kings would do. Tomorrow will come soon enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The camp sleeps with full bellies for the first time in weeks. The sick rest in clean hospital beds. Fresh water flows. The latrines no longer poison the stream. The crisis is not over. But the bleeding has stopped.

roll.outcome: The city embraces the cause. Hospital, merchants, even common citizens contribute. The feast becomes a celebration—Barcelona honoring the men who saved Granada. The sick begin recovering within days. The expedition is reborn.

encounters.recap: Juan resolves the camp crisis through systematic action: moving the sick to Barcelona's hospital, securing María's support for a feast, personally inspecting and improving camp conditions, and ensuring fresh water supply. The men's morale is restored through the feast provided by María, and the camp becomes functional again, though command structure issues remain unresolved.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The day has dawned grey and cold, but the camp is transformed. Men move with purpose. Cook fires burn cleanly. The new latrine trenches steam in the morning chill, properly distant from the water supply. Fresh bread is being distributed—María's generosity extending into a second day. Word has spread about the king who inspected latrines. About the Regent of Aragón who opened her stores. About the sick brothers now resting in the finest hospital in Catalunya. The men do not cheer as Juan passes. They do something better. They stand straighter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The command tent is the same as yesterday—cramped, utilitarian, the table still covered with manifests and maps. But the atmosphere has shifted. The three commanders are already present when Juan arrives. They stand together—not in their separate corners as before, but clustered near the table. They have been talking.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We have... conferred. As Your Majesty commanded. It was not easy. Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara have proud traditions. None of us wished to kneel to another.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty was clear. One commander. One quartermaster. Unity, or have the choice made for us.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: We have a proposal, Your Majesty. If you will hear it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets have it then.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Command should go to the man with the most experience leading combined forces. That is not me. Santiago has fought alone, gloriously—but this expedition requires coordination between Orders.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: At the siege of Antequera, I served as second to the Infante Ferdinand. Three Orders under one banner. I know how it is done—the politics, the rotations, the wounded pride that must be managed. I am not the youngest, nor do I command the largest contingent. But I have done this before.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: Alcántara supports Commander Mendoza for overall command. In exchange, the unified quartermaster position goes to our man—Sergeant Tomás de Palencia. He has served Alcántara's supply lines for eleven years. He predicted the spoiled meat. He warned about the camp placement. No one listened.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Santiago concurs. Mendoza commands. Alcántara supplies. I will serve as Mendoza's second. My men will follow his orders as they would follow mine.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: This is our proposal, Your Majesty. If it does not please you, we will accept whatever command structure you impose. But we believe this can work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have chosen a commander and quartermaster from your ranks. I accept. Commander Mendoza, some men lack proper equipment. I expect every men to be fighting fit and properly equipped. Take measures to make it so. Quartermaster, how are we on the meat? When do we have enough for us to leave?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I will conduct a full inspection today. Every man, every blade, every hauberk. What is lacking, we will procure. Barcelona has armorers. What cannot be bought, we will requisition from the Orders' reserves in the city. Alcántara's equipment requests will be filled first. They have waited longest.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A new figure steps forward. Sergeant Tomás de Palencia is perhaps fifty, lean and weathered, with the permanent squint of a man who has spent decades reading manifests in poor light. His hands are ink-stained. He carries a leather satchel stuffed with papers.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I received the supply reports an hour ago. We have sixty-three barrels of salt meat in camp. The riders reached Tarragona yesterday evening. The salting houses there have stock—they can provide one hundred twenty barrels, ready for transport. At a premium. They know we are desperate. The barrels should arrive by March third. That gives us one hundred eighty-three total. Short of Your Majesty's target of two hundred fifty to three hundred. But I have also sent word to Tortosa—smaller market, but closer. If they can provide another forty to sixty barrels... March fifth, Your Majesty. Perhaps March fourth if the Tortosa shipment arrives early. We could sail with two hundred forty barrels—near the lower end of your requirement—and resupply in Rome as planned. Will this suffice, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This will be sufficient. This gives the men more time to recover as well. We plan to sail at march 5th. Anything else for now?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: The sick, Your Majesty. Sixty men in the hospital. The physicians say most will recover—but perhaps not all by March fifth. Some may need another week. Perhaps two.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Do we leave them behind? Or delay further?

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: We could sail with reduced numbers and arrange for recovered men to follow on later vessels. Merchant ships make the Rome passage regularly. It would cost, but... It is possible.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: The men who recover should have the choice. Some will want to follow, even if it means traveling alone. Others may... Not every man who survives fever survives it whole. Some may never fight again.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: We will know more by March fifth. The physicians can tell us who is fit, who will recover, and who...

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the fleet, Your Majesty. The ships have been waiting in harbor. I have sent word that we sail on the fifth, but the captains will want confirmation. And the flagship—the Princesa Catalina—should be inspected before departure. Will Your Majesty wish to address the men again before we sail? Now that they are fed and rested, the words might land differently.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will adress them again, but later when we are about to depart. I want to make sure no other issues crop up. I will inspect the fleet shortly. And will be at camp regularly from now on. The campain has begun.

encounters.recap: The three military order commanders present their negotiated proposal for unified command structure. Commander Mendoza of Calatrava will lead overall forces, with Sergeant Palencia of Alcántara as quartermaster and Commander Cervantes as second. Juan accepts their decision and sets March 5th as the departure date, pending final supply deliveries and equipment inspections.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey from the palace to the harbor is short, but Catalina makes it feel like an expedition to distant lands. "The ship is called what?" Lucia smiles, adjusting Catalina on her hip as they descend toward the docks. "Princesa Catalina, my love. Named after you."

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A whole ship? With my name?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: A whole ship. The biggest one in the fleet.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Does the ship know it has my name?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I think the ship is very proud.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good. It should be. Catalina is a very good name.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The harbor spreads before them—a forest of masts and rigging, the snap of canvas, the cries of gulls and dockworkers. And there, riding at anchor in the outer harbor, is the Princesa Catalina. She is a carrack—three-masted, high-castled, her hull painted in the red and gold of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one? The big one?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Named after you, cariño. Not quite the same thing.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mine.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. And the Princess herself. The ship has been waiting to meet its namesake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The boat crosses the harbor in minutes, but for Catalina it might as well be a voyage to the edge of the world. The Princesa Catalina looms above them as they approach. Up close, she is even more impressive—her hull freshly caulked and painted, the Castilian lions gleaming gold against crimson.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Welcome to the Princesa Catalina. She completed sea trials in December. Stable in heavy swells. Handles better than any carrack I've commanded in thirty years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Sotomayor leads them through the ship with the pride of a man showing off his life's work. The queen's cabin is surprisingly spacious—paneled in dark wood, with windows of thick glass looking out over the stern. It was designed for Isabel. She never saw it.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: This is mine?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: This is the queen's cabin, little one. For your mama.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama. She can have it. It's nice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They tour the great cabin below, where councils will be held and meals taken. Catalina immediately climbs onto one of the chairs and declares herself "Captain." On the gun deck, twelve bombards crouch like iron beasts.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Twelve bombards. Six to each side. Not the heaviest—we sacrificed weight for speed and stability—but enough to discourage pirates and punish any galley foolish enough to close with us.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But I want to see it boom.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Perhaps when we are at sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the hold, stores for three months if needed. The forecastle offers an extraordinary view—the harbor spreads before them, Barcelona's spires rising beyond. The sea stretches to the horizon, grey-green and endless.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where is Constanti-popple?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Constantinople. Far away, cariño. Many days sailing. Past Rome, past Naples, past many islands.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Eighty souls, Your Majesty. Sailors, marines, gunners, officers. Every man knows his duty. She is ready. The Princesa Catalina will carry you wherever you need to go.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: It is a good ship.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Can we sail now?

encounters.recap: Juan brings his family to inspect the flagship Princesa Catalina. The young princess Catalina is delighted to discover the ship bears her name and declares it hers. Captain Sotomayor gives them a comprehensive tour of the carrack, showing the royal chambers originally designed for Queen Isabel, the gun deck with twelve bombards, and the crew quarters. The ship is revealed to be well-prepared for the upcoming journey to Constantinople, capable of carrying eighty souls and provisioned for three months at sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk through the Barri Gòtic is pleasant despite the weight of the morning's conversations. Lucia walks beside you, her hand resting lightly on your arm. She says little, but her presence is steady. The Palau Reial rises at the heart of the old city—less imposing than Toledo's Alcázar, but older, its stones worn smooth by centuries of Catalan counts and Aragonese kings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon de Perellós receives you in the regent's council chamber—a long room dominated by a heavy oak table and tapestries depicting the conquest of Majorca. He rises from behind a desk cluttered with documents, bowing precisely.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Majesty. I trust the morning has been productive. I have prepared a proposed itinerary for Your Majesty's remaining time in Barcelona. The Consell de Cent at midday, as arranged. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience—I have suggested the fourth hour after noon, if that suits. Don Guillem de Vic wishes to present certain communications he has drafted on Your Majesty's behalf. I understand Your Majesty visited Bishop Climent Sapera this morning. A lengthy meeting, by all accounts.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for the effort and care you took for facilitating these meetings. I trust there are issues or matters you yourself want to discuss with us as well? We are here and you have our ear.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. The matter of the itinerary is not... merely logistical. Barcelona is not Toledo, Your Majesty. The Consell de Cent guards its prerogatives jealously. The Count of Pallars speaks for nobles who remember when Aragón's king lived in Aragón. The merchants want to know whether Castilian trade agreements will respect Catalan privileges. In four years as head of the regency council, I have learned that scheduling is governance. Who sees the king, and when, and in what order—these things matter. They send signals. They create expectations. They establish... hierarchies. Your Majesty arrived yesterday evening. Since then, you have spoken privately with Don Guillem de Vic, with the Count of Pallars, and this morning—at considerable length—with Bishop Climent Sapera. The regency council was not consulted regarding any of these conversations. Queen María has requested that I coordinate all further meetings through Her Majesty's secretary. She wishes to be informed in advance of Your Majesty's appointments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I appologize immediately for not consulting with you sooner. An oversight I cannot take back. You have my word that not seeing you sooner was somehow a deliberate act to undermine your authority or to diminish it. I simply took audiences with anyone willing to speak with me. But now that we are here, what matters should we discuss? And what are the concerns of the regency council?

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's word is noted. Your Majesty asks what the council's concerns are. That is a... complex question. The council's concerns depend greatly on circumstances. On what is being proposed. On what commitments may already have been made. I have served as head of this council for four years. In that time, I have learned that I cannot advise a king on what he should do until I understand what he has done. Don Guillem de Vic left the reception last night speaking of 'great things to come' and 'bringing the kingdoms together.' The Count of Pallars sent a messenger to his estates at first light—I do not know why. Bishop Climent Sapera has reportedly cancelled his morning appointments to draft letters to the Archbishop of Tarragona. What should the regency council's concerns be, Your Majesty? What has been discussed? What has been offered? What expectations now exist that did not exist two days ago?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan tells the regent exactly what has happened and does not hold back. He tells him about his vision for a better world and how bringing the kingdoms closer together might help this. That he has been able to share this vision with others who are now also trying to achieve this. That the kingdoms uniting should not be Aragon joining Castille, but both kingdoms joining to become something else with neither holding dominance. He also tells him that he talked about the crown succession with Maria. And that he should have asked her about the current situation regarding succession and his own role in this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon listens without interruption. His face remains carefully composed throughout—the practiced stillness of a man who has spent decades hearing kings and nobles speak of grand designs. When Juan finishes, Don Ramon is silent for a long moment. He moves to the window again, looking out at the courtyard below where servants cross on their errands.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has been... remarkably candid. You ask about the succession. That, at least, is a matter of law rather than vision. King Alfonso has no legitimate children. Queen María has borne none, and the physicians hold little hope after so many years. Should Alfonso die, the Crown of Aragón passes to his nearest male relative. The Infantes Juan and Enrique are dead. Their legitimate male issue—Carlos of Viana—is also dead. This leaves... King Ferdinand of Aragón, Alfonso's father, had one other son who survived infancy. That son married into the House of Trastámara. His daughter María is our regent. His son... His son is Your Majesty. By strict succession law, should Alfonso die without heir, the Crown of Aragón would pass to the descendants of Ferdinand's second son—that is, to Juan II of Castile. Your Majesty is, in fact, Alfonso's heir presumptive. The regency council is aware of this. The factions are aware of this. When Your Majesty speaks of 'bringing kingdoms together,' every man in Barcelona hears it through this lens. I would suggest that further discussions regarding succession—or visions of unity—include Her Majesty the Regent and the full council. These are not matters for private conversations with faction leaders and bishops. Is there anything else Your Majesty requires for the midday reception with the Consell de Cent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You indicate that further discussions about unity should include the full council. Since everybody seems to be thinking about this already, can such a meeting be arranged?

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Don Ramon de Perellós, head of the regency council, who questions his private meetings with various factions. Juan makes full disclosure of his unity vision and succession concerns. Don Ramon reveals that Juan is legally Alfonso's heir presumptive to Aragón, explaining why his talk of 'bringing kingdoms together' alarms everyone. He insists future discussions involve the full council.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: The regency council is aware of this. The factions are aware of this. When Your Majesty speaks of 'bringing kingdoms together,' every man in Barcelona hears it through this lens.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back toward the desk, straightening papers that do not need straightening.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: I would suggest that further discussions regarding succession—or visions of unity—include Her Majesty the Regent and the full council. These are not matters for private conversations with faction leaders and bishops.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: Is there anything else Your Majesty requires for the midday reception with the Consell de Cent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Since everybody seems to be thinking about this already, can such a meeting be arranged?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon's expression flickers—something that might be satisfaction, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: A meeting can always be arranged, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, pulling a ledger toward him and opening it with the practiced ease of a man who lives by schedules.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: The question is when, and with what preparation. The Consell de Cent expects you at midday. The Count of Pallars has the afternoon. Don Guillem wishes to present his drafted communications. Your Majesty departs for Rome within... how many days?

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: A full council meeting requires the presence of all principal members. Don Berenguer de Bardaxí is at his estates—two days' ride. The Bishop of Girona sits on the council; he is in Girona. The Viscount of Rocabertí... These men cannot be summoned like servants. They must be invited, given time to arrange their affairs, travel to Barcelona.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He closes the ledger.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: And Her Majesty the Regent must, of course, preside. Given Your Majesty's conversation with her this morning, I would suggest... I would suggest that Her Majesty's consent to such a meeting should be obtained before invitations are dispatched.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: Shall I inquire of Her Majesty whether she finds such a meeting advisable, and if so, when it might be convened? I could have an answer for Your Majesty by this evening. After the Count of Pallars, perhaps.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Don Ramon, I have 4-5 weeks before I have to leave for Rome. I realize that I cannot summon the council. You have told me that everyone is thinking about succession right now. And you have indicated that talk about succession should happen through the council. Would it please the council to discuss these matters? To create stability and clarity perhaps? I will refrain from succession talk and refer to the council should the subject come up. Would this be in accordance with your wishes?

encounters.recap: Juan requests a full regency council meeting to address succession matters that are already on everyone's minds. Don Ramón carefully explains the logistical requirements and political protocols needed for such a meeting, emphasizing that Queen María must consent and preside. Juan agrees to defer all succession discussions to the council's authority.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Saló de Cent—the Hall of the Hundred—occupies the heart of the Casa de la Ciutat, a stern stone building that speaks of civic pride and commercial power. Inside, the hall is smaller than Toledo's throne room but no less impressive in its way. Pointed arches rise to a wooden ceiling painted in red and gold. The walls bear the arms of Barcelona—the red and gold bars of Aragón quartered with the cross of Sant Jordi. Wooden benches line the chamber in rising tiers, and upon them sit the jurats: one hundred men in dark robes and furred caps, the elected governors of one of the Mediterranean's greatest trading cities.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesties of Castile. Barcelona welcomes you. I am Pere Joan de Sant Climent, conseller en cap. We are honored by your presence in our city. We understand Your Majesty has recently achieved a great victory against the Moor. The Consell wishes to offer its congratulations. Granada's fall is a triumph for all Christendom. We also understand that Granada's ports now fly Castilian banners. Málaga. Almería. Ports that once competed with Barcelona for the African trade. Perhaps Your Majesty would honor us by sharing how Castile intends to... organize these new commercial opportunities?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for granting us audience and to introduce us to this chamber and this intricate system of governance. I am here with my queen to meet with my sister and to learn about Catalan customs. You ask specifically about how to exploit the trade in Grenada. I must confess that I have not yet made any major decisions. Maybe I should summon all the traders in the region in one council and come up with a system or structure for trade. But I can already tell you what my aim is going to be; I want trade to increase and cooperation as well. There are many fields where Aragonese and Castillian interests align. Already I am moving against Muslim piracy that has plagued our coasts for so long. Areas where Castille can indeed draw upon the expertise of friends like Aragon, should they choose to give it.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentions summoning traders to create a system. A worthy thought. Might we ask—which traders? Castilian traders from Seville, who already control the Atlantic routes? Or will Catalan houses receive equal voice in this... council? Your Majesty speaks of cooperation. Of aligned interests. We hear these words and we are grateful for them. But Your Majesty will forgive us—we are merchants. We think in contracts, not sentiments. When Málaga's harbor opens to Christian trade, will a Catalan ship pay the same duties as a Castilian ship? Will Barcelona's cloth merchants have the same rights in Granada's markets as Burgos wool factors? These are not challenges, Your Majesty. Merely... the questions that keep merchants awake at night.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe I should take a step back and let you explain what you are really concerned about. And what a king such as I could do to address them. I do not set or control prices of trade goods. If Grenada weavers choose to now enter the Christian market, they are free to do so. My question to you would be: Is this not free commerce? Please tell me what a king of a kingdom not even your own gathers so much interest from this council.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks a fair question. You are correct. You are King of Castile. Aragonese trade policy is a matter for King Alfonso and the regency council. We overstep. And yet. Your Majesty will forgive us if we speak plainly. We are Catalans. Plainness is our vice. King Alfonso pursues his destiny in Naples. Queen María holds Aragón in trust. And the man who stands before us today is... a man of great consequence. A man who has achieved what no Christian king has achieved in two centuries. A man whose shadow falls long across all of Iberia.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks what a Castilian king could do to address our concerns. The answer is simple: nothing. Today. But we are merchants. We plan for tomorrow. We sign contracts that bind our grandchildren. We think in generations. Every man in this chamber knows the succession laws of Aragón. Every man knows that King Alfonso has no heir. Every man knows who stands next in line. We do not ask Your Majesty to make promises you cannot keep. We ask only... to understand what kind of king you are. Whether you see Barcelona as a partner or as a... subject.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! I consider plainness no vice at all. And even if it is a sin, I am a likewise a sinner like you. You ask me what kind of king I am. That I can do. Though I risk a bit of pride about my accomplishments, but I have taken my queen with me, who is sure to let me know when I do. When developing trade policy, I ask myself one question. What will increase trade the most? What develops ports? How can trade goods reach workshops? In short; how will this benefit the kingdom the most. And I must confess that trade and naval matters are not areas of Castillian strengths. My kingdom barely has a fleet compared to Aragon. A matter I intend to address and I have moored my full fleet in Valencia, putting it at the disposal of your king in support of his Naples campaign. I honestly do not know what trade policies to adopt. I have never done so yet. But I have already said what I want these policies to achieve. Should anything change, I can assure this council that I will always seek out advice from bodies such as these and that I aim for policies that increase trade. Does this address your question?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says you will seek advice from bodies such as ours. We are grateful. But seeking advice and heeding advice are different things. Castile has a Cortes. Aragón has Corts. Both give advice. Kings do not always listen. You say you want policies that increase trade. So do we. But whose trade? When a Castilian merchant and a Catalan merchant both want the same contract in Málaga, whose trade increases? This is not philosophy, Your Majesty. This is Tuesday.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, I can be specific in case of the example of the Catalan merchant and the Castillian merchant competing for the same contract on a tuesday. In the current situation, what would happen? Is the Castillian merchant in an advantage because he is trading in what essentially is Castillian territory?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: An excellent question, Your Majesty. At present, Granada's ports are... chaos. Forgive my bluntness. Málaga fell less than two years ago. Almería even more recently. The old Moorish trading houses are disrupted. The new Christian administration is still finding its feet. In such chaos, advantage flows to those with connections. Castilian merchants from Seville know your port officials. They speak the same language. They worship in the same churches. They have cousins and brothers-in-law in the customs houses. A Catalan merchant arrives in Málaga and he is... a foreigner. Tolerated, yes. But a foreigner. So when we ask whether Catalan ships will be welcomed as friends—we ask whether Your Majesty will instruct your officials that Catalans are not foreigners. That we are... partners. With the same rights, the same access, the same three days for a license. That is not a trade policy. That is a letter. A few sentences. 'Treat Aragonese merchants as you would Castilian merchants.' Nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have already told you what my policy should aim to accomplish. And treating Catalan merchants the same as Castillian ones would fit that narrative.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Barcelona's Consell de Cent to discuss trade relations. The councillors, led by Pere Joan de Sant Climent and merchant representative Bernat Fiveller, press him about preferential treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's newly conquered ports. They acknowledge Juan's likely future as King of Aragón and seek concrete assurances about equal treatment. Juan offers philosophical support for fair trade but avoids specific commitments, ultimately agreeing that equal treatment would align with his stated goals.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: There is no law against Catalan trade in Granada's ports. But law and practice are different things. A Castilian factor obtains a license in three days. A Catalan factor waits three weeks. A Castilian ship unloads at the prime berths. A Catalan ship anchors in the outer harbor.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: These are not conspiracies, Your Majesty. They are... human nature. Your officials favor their own. As ours would. So when we ask whether Catalan ships will be welcomed as friends—we ask whether Your Majesty will instruct your officials that Catalans are not foreigners. That we are... partners. With the same rights, the same access, the same three days for a license. That is not a trade policy. That is a letter. A few sentences. 'Treat Aragonese merchants as you would Castilian merchants.' Nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have already told you what my policy should aim to accomplish. And treating Catalan merchants the same as Castillian ones would fit that narrative. If you want for me to draft official trade policy right here and right now, I must disappoint you. Imagine your king Alfonso drafting Aragonese trade policy while talking with Castillian traders in Castille! No, that would be unfair to those not represented. Do traders from Aragon and Castille meet somewhere? Maybe we should invite Portugal as well. Does such a structure yet exist? And if not, should we try and set up such a meeting?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ripple passes through the hall. Men exchange glances—some intrigued, others skeptical. Fiveller's expression tightens almost imperceptibly.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: An international meeting of traders. A noble thought, Your Majesty. Truly. Such meetings have been proposed before. At Bruges. At Genoa. They take years to arrange. They produce... documents. Declarations of intent. Frameworks for future cooperation. Meanwhile, my ships sail to Málaga next month. Not next year. Next month.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: Senyor Fiveller speaks from... urgency. Which is understandable. But Your Majesty raises an interesting question. Such a structure does not exist—not formally. The crowns negotiate. The merchants... adapt. Barcelona would be honored to host such a gathering, should one be arranged. It would be... good for the city. But this is a matter of years, not weeks.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I asked for a letter. A few sentences instructing your port officials to treat our merchants as equals. Not a policy. Not a treaty. A letter. Is that truly something that requires an international conference to decide?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. Can I have ink and quill? Lucia, would you be so kind as to draft this letter? Are there other issues we should include in the letter? Cooperation about piracy maybe? Or other matters?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall stirs. Whatever the merchants expected, it was not this. Fiveller stands frozen for a moment—a man who asked for a fish and has been handed the net. Sant Climent gestures to a clerk, who scurries forward with writing materials. A small table is brought, set before Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty is inclined to address matters of mutual concern... the piracy question is indeed pressing. A statement of intent—that Castile and Aragón will cooperate against the Salé corsairs—would be most welcome.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: And perhaps... clarification on customs rates? If Catalan merchants are to be treated as equals, does this extend to the duties they pay? Equal access means little if we are taxed more heavily.

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: The silk, Majestic. You spoke of increasing trade. But trade in what? If Granada's silk floods our markets without restriction... Can the letter say something about... balance? That Your Majesty will not permit Granada's looms to destroy Valencia's? Some protection for those who weave, not only those who trade?

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: And information, Your Majesty. When Castile makes decisions that affect our merchants, will Barcelona be informed? Consulted? Or will we learn of new policies when our ships are turned away?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we start, I want to make sure that you all understand that I write this letter as king of Castille, aiming to increase cooperation and good standing between my kingdom and Aragon. Lets start with the pirates. The military orders have been ordered to construct a navy to fight pirates. Order them to focus their efforts on Sale. Coordinate with Aragon should they support this effort. We await what they should choose to commit. Harbour officials should know that Aragonese, Portugese and Castillian merchants should be treated equally and are subject to the same treatment and tax. Regarding the silk trade from Grenada, inform the duke of Grenada to develop policies to prevent Grenada silk to flood and disrupt the christian markets as we integrate Grenada into Castille. We adopt a policy where Portugese and Aragonese traders are informed about our taxes and any significant changes to them so traders can make better informed decisions. And finally, If Barcelona would be so kind as to host a meeting of traders of these kingdoms so we can further develop and discuss these issues, I would encourage the Castillian traders to attend, send a delegation and to work in good spirit towards a common purpose where trade flourishes. Does the council have anything else to add?

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says the Governor of Granada should 'develop policies to prevent disruption.' Forgive me, Majestic—but what policies? Tariffs on Moorish silk entering Christian markets? Quotas on how much can be sold? Policies can mean many things. My weavers need to know if they will have work next year.

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty offers to inform us of tax changes. We are grateful. But I asked whether Barcelona might be consulted. These are... different things. To be informed is to learn what has been decided. To be consulted is to speak before the decision is made.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
