Six hundred and forty-three men able to stand assemble in ragged ranks. Some lean on their neighbors. The Santiago knight who coughed during inspection is there, pale as milk, swaying slightly but upright. Behind them, the infirmary tents. Sixty more men who will hear this speech through canvas walls.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers. We are about to embark on a great journey. A journey that will take us from Barcelona to Rome and beyond to Constantinople. Much is at stake. The church is divided and the eternal city, the last light of Christendom is about to be snuffed out. We have just won a great victory against the Moors and have done things no-one had deemed possible. We ended the reconquista. It was hard in the beginning. We have suffered setbacks and even defeats here and there. The muslims are hard fighters and they made us bleed made us suffer. Cut our supply lines. Left us hungry and miserable while we were sieging mighty walls. Right now, we are tired, sick. Maybe even hungry. Such is the fate of knights and soldiers. But have we not been here before? Have we not overcome hunger and pain? Yes! we have. We know what to do as well. We lack supplies, so we aquire more. We are sick, so we tend to our brothers until we are better. And when we are ready to move out, when we are ready to go on this incredible journey, only then we will leave. When I met the Greek delegation in Basel, they had given up all hope. No-one was going to help them. No-one had the courage, the will, the determination. No-one but the sons of Castille! We go where no-one else dared journey. We face what no-one else dared face. We fight for what everyone else seems to have forgotten. We know that when we raise our swords in the name of Christ, we serve a higher purpose. I stand before you today on the first day of this incredible journey to speak the words. Words that have carried us over blood-soaked fields and towards victory. Non nobis Domine!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: For a moment—a long, terrible moment—there is only silence. Then, from somewhere in the Santiago ranks, a voice answers: 'Non nobis Domine.' Another joins. Then another. The response spreads—but slowly, unevenly, like fire struggling to catch in wet kindling. It is not the thunder of Granada. It is not the roar that shook the walls of Málaga or echoed through the Alhambra's halls. It is tired men doing what they have been trained to do. Speaking words they remember because their bodies remember, even when their hearts are uncertain. The sick Santiago knight mouths the prayer, but no sound comes. His neighbor grips his arm to keep him upright.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: They answered, Your Majesty. That is something. But they need more than words now. They need to see the supply wagons arrive. They need to see the sick recover. They need to see that someone is solving the problems, not just acknowledging them. You have bought time, Your Majesty. Perhaps a week. Perhaps less. What would you have me do?

roll.outcome: Grudging acknowledgment. The response comes—'Non nobis Domine'—but muted, tired. The veterans remember Granada, but Constantinople feels different. Doubt lingers. The speech bought time, not belief.

encounters.recap: Juan inspects his 700 knights assembled for the Constantinople crusade but finds the camp in crisis—fever has struck sixty men, supplies have spoiled, and morale is broken. Despite donning his Granada armor and delivering an inspiring speech invoking their past victories, the men's response is lukewarm. The speech steadies them temporarily but does not restore their faith, leaving Juan with only days to solve the practical problems before losing them entirely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent is cramped, utilitarian—a campaign shelter, not a throne room. A table dominates the center, covered with supply manifests, maps, and the detritus of a troubled expedition. The canvas walls snap in the wind. Juan enters still in armor. Captain Robles follows, then the three Order commanders file in behind. They do not sit. No one has offered, and the tension in the air does not invite comfort.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Commanders.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's speech was stirring. But speeches do not fill bellies or cure fevers. If we are to address problems, let us begin with who created them. Calatrava's quartermaster accepted meat that a blind man could smell was rotten—

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Santiago's camp placement put us downstream from a tanner's waste. My men did not poison the water. Yours did.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: If either of you had listened to Alcántara's concerns three weeks ago—

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara has one hundred men. This is not your expedition to command.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Enough! Lets focus on the problem. Care for the sick first. They are now taken care of in tents right? Could we not accomodate them in a hospital or grant them other and better accomodation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand rigid, their accusations still hanging in the air like smoke. But Juan's voice—sharp, commanding—has cut through the noise.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is a hospital, Your Majesty. The Hospital de la Santa Creu, within the city walls. It is run by the Church—the canons of the Cathedral. It is one of the finest in Aragón. They have tended plague victims, pilgrims, soldiers. If anyone can help our sick, they can.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Moving sixty men through the city... it would be visible. Public. Word would spread that the expedition is weakened. That the King of Castile's knights are dying in camp before they even board ships.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: They are already dying in camp. Three dead. More to follow if we do nothing.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara speaks truth, for once. The tents are inadequate. Cold at night, damp, no proper drainage. The physicians do what they can, but... They need walls. Hearths. Clean water. Things we cannot provide in a field camp.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: If Her Majesty the Regent were to request the hospital's assistance—or if Your Majesty were to ask directly—I do not think they would refuse. The Church has been... favorable to Your Majesty's cause since the Granada campaign. Shall I send word to Don Ramon to arrange it? We could have the men moved by nightfall.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will secure the hospital for our brothers. Food is next. What are we missing? Both what we consume right now and what we need for the journey.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles spreads a supply manifest across the table, weighting the corners with a dagger and a cup.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: For current consumption, we are... adequate. Barely. Bread from Barcelona's bakers—that supply holds. Wine from local merchants. Cheese and oil. The men are not starving. But they are not eating well either. Morale suffers when soldiers see thin rations.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: My men have been on half-portions of meat for six days. The Alcántara quartermaster has been requesting resupply since before the fever struck. We were told to wait. We waited.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: For the voyage, the situation is worse. A sea journey from Barcelona to Rome—ten days to two weeks, depending on weather. Then Rome to Naples, if Your Majesty visits King Alfonso. Then onward to Constantinople—another three weeks, perhaps a month, with stops for water and provisions. We need, at minimum: Salted meat: Four hundred barrels. We have sixty-three. The Valencia shipment was to provide two hundred—all spoiled. The replacement is delayed. Ship's biscuit: Six hundred crates. We have four hundred. Sufficient if we resupply in Rome. Dried fish: Two hundred barrels. We have one hundred twenty. Wine: Eight hundred casks. We have six hundred. Sufficient. Dried legumes and grain: Three hundred sacks. We have two hundred. Olive oil and vinegar: Adequate. Fresh water barrels: The ships carry these. That is the fleet's concern, not ours.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The meat is the crisis. Without it, men weaken. Weak men sicken. Sick men die—especially at sea. Valencia failed us. We need another source. Quickly.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Barcelona's markets could provide some. But four hundred barrels for an army? We would drain the city. The Consell de Cent would not thank us for emptying their storehouses.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There are other options, Your Majesty. Tarragona has salting houses. Mallorca trades in preserved pork. We could send riders, ships, purchasing agents—but all of this takes time. And money. How long is Your Majesty willing to delay departure?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will have to pay either way. Can we send riders for other markets? And can we resupply in Naples and other cities we pass along the way?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Riders to Tarragona—one day there, one day back. If their salting houses have stock, we could see barrels arriving within the week. Mallorca requires a ship, but they export preserved pork throughout the Mediterranean. Two weeks, perhaps, if winds favor us. As for resupply along the way... yes. It is possible. Even advisable—fresh provisions keep men healthier than salt-stores alone.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Rome will be expensive. The papal court inflates prices for everything. But the markets there are vast—we can find what we need if we pay. Here is better. Alfonso's army has established supply lines. If His Majesty is visiting the King of Aragón, we could arrange provisions in advance. Neapolitan salt pork is serviceable. Not as good as Castilian, but it keeps.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Sicily. If we stop there. Messina has warehouses. Cheaper than Rome, better quality than Naples.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: If we are dividing the supply burden across multiple ports... we need fewer barrels from Barcelona. Carry enough to reach Rome. Resupply there for Naples. Resupply in Naples for Constantinople. We stretch our coin further and reduce the risk of another spoilage.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: If we reduce our Barcelona requirement to... one hundred fifty barrels of salt meat instead of four hundred... combined with what we have... Achievable. Tarragona alone might provide that within a week. I can dispatch riders within the hour, Your Majesty. And send word ahead to Rome and Naples to prepare provisions for our arrival. We would need letters of credit. The Gualbes banking arrangements Don Guillem negotiated—they could facilitate payments in Rome and Naples without carrying chests of gold aboard ship.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: This could work.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: If we do not delay further. Every day in camp is another day for fever to spread.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I want to leave with enough meat in stock to last us a while. We can supplement our stock as we visit ports along the way. Send riders for more meat. I want to sail with around 250-300 barrels. Pay their price to secure this. And finally, we must adress the situation of half ration while we are still in friendly territory. Make sure the men have enough to eat and drink the coming days. They must regain their strength, it will not get easier. I will speak with my sister about how the men can be fed properly. Now, if we assume the sick will have proper accomodation, we are getting enouth supplies and the men have a full belly, are there other issues we should adress?

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: Equipment, Your Majesty. Alcántara requisitioned replacement armor and weapons six weeks ago. Twelve hauberks. Twenty swords. Horse tack for the mounted sergeants. We were told supplies were limited and priority went to the larger Orders. My men are patching rust with prayer.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of... command structure. At Granada, Your Majesty led. The Orders followed. Clear. Simple. Here, we have three commanders, three quartermasters, three chains of supply. We have been working beside each other, not together.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Calatrava speaks truth. When problems arose, each Order blamed the others because no one had authority to solve them. We need a single commander under Your Majesty. Someone who can knock heads together when quartermasters squabble over spoiled meat.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the camp water, Your Majesty. We have moved the latrine trenches and forbidden use of the contaminated stream. But the men are wary. Some have been drinking only wine for days. Clean water barrels from the city would help. A visible sign that the problem is solved.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Regarding the command structure; we need one subordinate commander under myself. And one quarter master. Lets not make a choice right now, but rather think about it for one day. I want the most experienced and capable commander and quarter master in command. We will meet back here tomorrow. Either you have chosen a commander and quarter master yourself from your own ranks or I will appoint someone on the spot. Either way, we will have one quarter master and one commander. I will make sure there is fresh water.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand frozen, processing what Juan has just done. He has not chosen between them—which would have created a winner and two resentful losers. He has not imposed an outsider—which would have united them in indignation. He has told them to solve it themselves, or have the decision taken from their hands. It is elegant. And uncomfortable.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is wise to give us time. Santiago will... confer with the other Orders.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Calatrava concurs. One day. We will present a unified recommendation. Or we will accept Your Majesty's judgment.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: I will arrange the fresh water barrels, Your Majesty. And dispatch riders to Tarragona within the hour. Is there anything else before we adjourn?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We all have our assignments, we meet back here tomorrow.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with his military commanders to address the expedition's crisis. After breaking up their feuding, he secures hospital care for sick men, arranges expanded food supplies through multiple Mediterranean ports, and forces the three Order commanders to choose unified leadership or have it imposed upon them by tomorrow.

roll.outcome: Strong success. Hospital welcomes the sick; physicians optimistic. María provides generously—roasted meats, good bread, Catalan delicacies. Camp conditions improve visibly. Men begin to believe.

encounters.recap: Juan personally oversees comprehensive improvements to the crusader camp. The Hospital de la Santa Creu accepts all sixty sick knights, María arranges a generous feast from palace stores, fresh water barrels arrive, and latrines are properly relocated. The camp transforms from a place of despair into one of renewed hope and purpose.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The nursery is warm, lit by a single candle. Catalina lies in her small bed, blankets pulled up to her chin, her dark hair spread across the pillow like spilled ink. Her eyes flutter open as Juan enters.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Papa smells funny.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Inés stifles a laugh from her corner, then curtsies and withdraws to give them privacy. When Juan asks about singing, Catalina nods solemnly.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I was singing to the horse. He was scared. The dark is scary for horses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches up, small fingers finding Juan's hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Sing, Papa. Sing the good one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan sings. Catalina's eyes grow heavy. Her grip on his hand loosens. Her breathing slows, deepens. Somewhere in the middle of the lullaby, she slips away into dreams—perhaps of horses that jump very high, or ships with many sails, or crostatas shared with queens. When the song ends, she is asleep. The candle flickers. Beyond the window, Barcelona lies quiet under winter stars. Somewhere in the camp, seven hundred men sleep with full bellies. Somewhere in the hospital, sixty sick knights rest in clean beds. And here, in this small room, a princess sleeps with her wooden horse watching over her. Lucia appears in the doorway, silhouetted by the light from their chambers. She says nothing. She does not need to.

encounters.recap: After the day's crisis, Juan visits his daughter Catalina in the nursery. She asks him to sing a lullaby, and he does so until she falls asleep. Queen Lucia appears silently in the doorway, sharing this quiet family moment after the troubles of the day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The day has dawned grey and cold, but the camp is transformed. Men move with purpose. Cook fires burn cleanly. The new latrine trenches steam in the morning chill, properly distant from the water supply. Fresh bread is being distributed—María's generosity extending into a second day. Word has spread about the king who inspected latrines. About the Regent of Aragón who opened her stores. About the sick brothers now resting in the finest hospital in Catalunya. The men do not cheer as Juan passes. They do something better. They stand straighter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The command tent is the same as yesterday—cramped, utilitarian, the table still covered with manifests and maps. But the atmosphere has shifted. The three commanders are already present when Juan arrives. They stand together—not in their separate corners as before, but clustered near the table. They have been talking.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We have... conferred. As Your Majesty commanded. It was not easy. Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara have proud traditions. None of us wished to kneel to another.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty was clear. One commander. One quartermaster. Unity, or have the choice made for us.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: We have a proposal, Your Majesty. If you will hear it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets have it then.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Command should go to the man with the most experience leading combined forces. That is not me. Santiago has fought alone, gloriously—but this expedition requires coordination between Orders.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: At the siege of Antequera, I served as second to the Infante Ferdinand. Three Orders under one banner. I know how it is done—the politics, the rotations, the wounded pride that must be managed. I am not the youngest, nor do I command the largest contingent. But I have done this before.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: Alcántara supports Commander Mendoza for overall command. In exchange, the unified quartermaster position goes to our man—Sergeant Tomás de Palencia. He has served Alcántara's supply lines for eleven years. He predicted the spoiled meat. He warned about the camp placement. No one listened.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Santiago concurs. Mendoza commands. Alcántara supplies. I will serve as Mendoza's second. My men will follow his orders as they would follow mine.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: This is our proposal, Your Majesty. If it does not please you, we will accept whatever command structure you impose. But we believe this can work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have chosen a commander and quartermaster from your ranks. I accept. Commander Mendoza, some men lack proper equipment. I expect every men to be fighting fit and properly equipped. Take measures to make it so. Quartermaster, how are we on the meat? When do we have enough for us to leave?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I will conduct a full inspection today. Every man, every blade, every hauberk. What is lacking, we will procure. Barcelona has armorers. What cannot be bought, we will requisition from the Orders' reserves in the city. Alcántara's equipment requests will be filled first. They have waited longest.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I received the supply reports an hour ago. We have sixty-three barrels of salt meat in camp. The riders reached Tarragona yesterday evening. The salting houses there have stock—they can provide one hundred twenty barrels, ready for transport. At a premium. They know we are desperate. The barrels should arrive by March third. That gives us one hundred eighty-three total. Short of Your Majesty's target of two hundred fifty to three hundred. But I have also sent word to Tortosa—smaller market, but closer. If they can provide another forty to sixty barrels... March fifth, Your Majesty. Perhaps March fourth if the Tortosa shipment arrives early. We could sail with two hundred forty barrels—near the lower end of your requirement—and resupply in Rome as planned. Will this suffice, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This will be sufficient. This gives the men more time to recover as well. We plan to sail at march 5th. Anything else for now?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: The sick, Your Majesty. Sixty men in the hospital. The physicians say most will recover—but perhaps not all by March fifth. Some may need another week. Perhaps two.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Do we leave them behind? Or delay further?

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: We could sail with reduced numbers and arrange for recovered men to follow on later vessels. Merchant ships make the Rome passage regularly. It would cost, but... It is possible.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: The men who recover should have the choice. Some will want to follow, even if it means traveling alone. Others may... Not every man who survives fever survives it whole. Some may never fight again.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: We will know more by March fifth. The physicians can tell us who is fit, who will recover, and who...

exchanges.speaker: ferran_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the fleet, Your Majesty. The ships have been waiting in harbor. I have sent word that we sail on the fifth, but the captains will want confirmation. And the flagship—the Princesa Catalina—should be inspected before departure. Will Your Majesty wish to address the men again before we sail? Now that they are fed and rested, the words might land differently.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will adress them again, but later when we are about to depart. I want to make sure no other issues crop up. I will inspect the fleet shortly. And will be at camp regularly from now on. The campain has begun.

encounters.recap: The three military order commanders present a unified proposal for command structure after private negotiations. Mendoza of Calatrava becomes overall commander, Palencia of Alcántara becomes quartermaster, and Cervantes of Santiago accepts second-in-command. Juan accepts their proposal, sets March 5th as the departure date, and commits to regular presence at camp as the campaign officially begins.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey from the palace to the harbor is short, but Catalina makes it feel like an expedition to distant lands. "The ship is called what?" Lucia smiles, adjusting Catalina on her hip as they descend toward the docks. "Princesa Catalina, my love. Named after you." Catalina's eyes grow very round. "A whole ship? With my name?" "A whole ship. The biggest one in the fleet." Catalina processes this information with the gravity it deserves. Her small brow furrows. "Does the ship know it has my name?" "I think the ship is very proud," Lucia says. "Good." Catalina nods firmly. "It should be. Catalina is a very good name."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The harbor spreads before them—a forest of masts and rigging, the snap of canvas, the cries of gulls and dockworkers. The smell of tar and salt and fish hangs thick in the air. And there, riding at anchor in the outer harbor, is the Princesa Catalina. She is a carrack—three-masted, high-castled, her hull painted in the red and gold of Castile. The royal standard flies from her mainmast. She is not the largest ship ever built, but she is substantial—a vessel meant to carry a king across dangerous waters.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one? The big one?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That one.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mine?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Named after you, cariño. Not quite the same thing.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mine.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. And the Princess herself. The ship has been waiting to meet its namesake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The boat crosses the harbor in minutes, but for Catalina it might as well be a voyage to the edge of the world. She grips the gunwale with white-knuckled intensity, staring at everything—the oarsmen, the seabirds, the approaching bulk of "her" ship. "It's big," she whispers.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Welcome to the Princesa Catalina. She completed sea trials in December. Stable in heavy swells. Handles better than any carrack I've commanded in thirty years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cabin beyond is surprisingly spacious—paneled in dark wood, with windows of thick glass looking out over the stern. A bed built into the bulkhead, wide enough for two. Cushioned benches along the walls. A writing desk secured to the deck. Tapestries hang to soften the wood and muffle the creak of timber. It was designed for Isabel. She never saw it. Lucia steps inside, her hand trailing along the polished wood. Her expression is unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: This is mine?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: This is the queen's cabin, little one. For your mama.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama. She can have it. It's nice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Sotomayor leads them through the ship with the pride of a man showing off his life's work. The king's cabin adjacent to the queen's chambers, smaller and more functional—a soldier's space. The great cabin below, spanning the width of the stern, where councils will be held and meals taken. A long table dominates the space, bolted to the deck.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where are the cannons?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Twelve bombards. Six to each side. Not the heaviest—we sacrificed weight for speed and stability—but enough to discourage pirates and punish any galley foolish enough to close with us. She's not a warship. Not built to stand in a battle line. But she can fight if she must, and outrun what she cannot fight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But I want to see it boom.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Perhaps when we are at sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the hold, the smell changes—bilge water, tar, the mustiness of stored provisions. "Stores for three months if we must," Sotomayor explains. "Water barrels here, salt meat, biscuit, dried fish. Wine. Oil. Everything a crew of eighty needs to cross any sea."

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: It smells funny.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: All ships smell funny, little one. You get used to it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The view from the bow is extraordinary. The harbor spreads before them, Barcelona's spires rising beyond. The sea stretches to the horizon, grey-green and endless. Catalina grips the rail, the wind whipping her dark hair.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where is Constanti-popple?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Constantinople. Far away, cariño. Many days sailing. Past Rome, past Naples, past many islands.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Eighty souls, Your Majesty. Sailors, marines, gunners, officers. Every man knows his duty. Every man has sailed with me before. She is ready, Your Majesty. The Princesa Catalina will carry you wherever you need to go.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: It is a good ship.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Can we sail now?

encounters.recap: Juan takes Lucia and Catalina to inspect the flagship Princesa Catalina in Barcelona harbor. The young princess is delighted that the great carrack bears her name, while Captain Sotomayor gives them a comprehensive tour of the vessel's royal cabins, gun deck, holds, and fighting platforms. The ship is well-built and ready for the coming voyage to Constantinople, though the queen's cabin—originally designed for Isabel—carries poignant reminders of the past.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Tiber runs brown with spring melt, swollen and sluggish, carrying your barge past marshes thick with reeds and the ruins of ancient aqueducts that stride across the landscape like the bones of giants. The oarsmen work in steady rhythm, their calls echoing across the water as Rome rises slowly from the flatlands ahead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your fleet anchored at Ostia this morning after three days from Cagliari—a mercy, given the Mistral disaster of March 7th that cost you 75 souls and scattered your formation across half the Tyrrhenian Sea. The Princesa Catalina weathered the storm, though barely. Now ten ships rest in the harbor while river barges ferry your household upriver to the city.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia sits beside you on cushions arranged against the barge's low gunwale, her hand resting on her belly where your second child grows. The pregnancy is perhaps three months along now—early enough that travel remains possible, late enough that the sickness has begun to ease. She watches the approaching city with the quiet attention of someone returning to familiar territory after long absence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina—two years old, imperious, and entirely unimpressed by ancient capitals—has claimed the bow of the barge as her personal domain, where Doña Leonor prevents her from leaning too far over the water while the child points at every passing bird and demands to know its name.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first domes and towers of Rome appear through the river haze. You can make out the bulk of Castel Sant'Angelo, the old mausoleum of Hadrian converted to papal fortress, its round mass dominating the river approach. Beyond it, the jumble of medieval construction rises—churches, towers, the crumbling shells of ancient temples repurposed as markets and stables.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán stands near the stern, conferring quietly with the barge master about landing arrangements. The 591 knights who survived the storm will march overland from Ostia tomorrow, but tonight the household must be settled.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The barge rounds a bend, and Rome spreads before you in full.

encounters.recap: Juan II arrives in Rome by river barge with his family and household after anchoring at Ostia. The journey follows a devastating storm that cost 75 lives, but the royal party reaches the eternal city safely with 591 surviving knights to follow overland.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The river bends again, and you let your mind turn to the leather satchel that sits beside Captain Fernán at the stern—the accumulated correspondence of months, couriers finding you at Cagliari, at Barcelona, at every port and relay station where your fleet paused. The Castilian delegation has written faithfully, as you instructed. Abbott Rodrigo's letters arrive in his cramped, scholarly hand; Bishop Alfonso's in the elegant script of a trained diplomat. Since September, Fray Hernando has been with you rather than at Basel, but the others have maintained the flow of intelligence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: What you know from your delegation's reports: The Declaration of Como had the effect you hoped. When Emperor Sigismund arrived at Basel in late June with your joint declaration in hand, the moderate faction found their spine. The French extremists under Cardinal d'Allemand continued to push for papal deposition, but the German pragmatists and your Castilian delegation formed a working coalition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Three major reform decrees passed in rapid succession: Session 15 (September 14, 1433): Clerical Concubinage — A graduated penalty system for priests keeping women. Warning for first offense, suspension for second, deprivation for third. Your delegation reports that Bishop Alfonso spoke powerfully in favor, citing Granada's newly-conquered churches as places where reform must begin fresh rather than inherit old corruptions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Session 16 (September 28, 1433): Pluralism — No cleric may hold multiple benefices with cure of souls. Cardinals limited to one bishopric. The critical innovation: dispensations now granted by local ordinaries, not Rome, and only for three narrow causes. This closes the loophole that destroyed every previous anti-pluralism decree. Abbott Rodrigo writes with evident satisfaction that the decree follows the Como principle exactly—grandfather existing lawful arrangements, reform going forward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Session 17 (October 19, 1433): Annates Reform — Papal taxation of benefices reduced by seventy-five percent, but not abolished entirely. Abbott Rodrigo emphasizes this distinction in three separate letters. The historical Council of Basel, he warns, made the catastrophic error of eliminating annates completely with no replacement revenue—financially destroying the papacy and guaranteeing schism. This decree preserves a papal revenue stream while adding transparency and accountability. Something Pope Eugenius might actually accept as 'parallel legislation.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Bohemian Peace (November 1433): The news that made Abbott Rodrigo weep, by his own admission. On November 30, 1433, the Council of Basel and the Kingdom of Bohemia signed the Compacts of Basel—a bilateral treaty ending thirty-five years of religious war. Not a decree imposed by victors, but a negotiated peace between equals. The Hussites received communion in both kinds, their central demand. The Church preserved doctrinal integrity through the doctrine of concomitance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Crusade Decree (December 14, 1433): Session 19 passed the Decree for the Defense of Constantinople with extraordinary conciliar support. Abbott Rodrigo reports the vote was nearly unanimous—a remarkable achievement given Basel's usual factional paralysis. But Bishop Alfonso's assessment is blunt: 'The decree is, in essence, an ecclesiastical endorsement of Your Majesty's personal crusade, dressed in the language of pan-Christian mobilization. You will receive the Council's blessing and the legitimacy of conciliar authority. You will not receive significant military reinforcement from other kingdoms.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The barge passes beneath a crumbling Roman bridge—ancient stonework supporting medieval wooden repairs. Ahead, the bulk of Castel Sant'Angelo grows larger. You carry all this in your satchel, and in your mind. The question is what you will do with it when you stand before Pope Eugenius IV.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando, what does concomitance actually mean? Also, explain to me what loophole has now been closed regarding plurality.

encounters.recap: As Juan approaches Rome, he reviews months of correspondence from his delegation at Basel. The Council has passed major reforms on clerical concubinage, pluralism, and annates, negotiated peace with the Hussites through the Compacts of Basel, and proclaimed a crusade for Constantinople. Though successful, the crusade decree provides more legitimacy than actual military support, leaving Juan to carry the burden himself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando sits across from you on the barge, his grey Franciscan habit travel-worn but clean. The journey from Barcelona has restored some color to his cheeks—he is no longer the exhausted man who worked through the night drafting the Declaration of Como, though the lines around his eyes have deepened. He considers your question with the careful attention he gives to all matters of doctrine.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Concomitance is the teaching that Christ is wholly present—body, blood, soul, and divinity—under each species of the Eucharist. When you receive the bread alone, you receive the entire Christ. When you receive the wine alone, you receive the entire Christ. The two species are not two halves of a whole.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He watches Catalina at the bow, still demanding bird names from the patient Doña Leonor, before continuing.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This matters for Bohemia because it allowed the Council to grant the Hussites what they wanted—communion in both kinds—without admitting that the rest of Christendom has been receiving an incomplete sacrament for centuries. The Bohemians get their chalice. The Church maintains that those who receive bread alone are not deprived of anything. Both sides preserve their dignity. Theological face-saving, Your Majesty. The Council has become skilled at it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the question of pluralism, Fray Hernando's expression sharpens.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The loophole was simple, and it destroyed every previous reform. The Fourth Lateran Council prohibited pluralism in 1215. The prohibition lasted perhaps a decade before it became meaningless. Why? Because Rome could grant dispensations. A bishop holds three dioceses? Forbidden by canon law—unless the Pope grants a dispensation. And dispensations were always granted, for the right price or the right connections.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Every anti-pluralism decree for two hundred years has been undermined the same way. The law says 'no,' but the Pope says 'yes, for you, this once'—and 'this once' becomes always, for everyone who matters. The Basel decree closes this by removing dispensations from Rome entirely. Now only the local ordinary—the bishop—can grant dispensation, and only for three narrow causes: two tiny benefices that together barely feed a man, benefices annexed by ancient right, or university professors who need support while teaching. That is all. Cardinals, archbishops, papal favorites—none of them can receive dispensation from Rome, because Rome no longer grants them.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And the grandfathering provision is clever. Those who currently hold multiple benefices lawfully, with existing dispensations, may keep them for life. But when they die, the arrangement dies with them. No renewal, no inheritance, no perpetuation. The abuse ends naturally, without requiring mass deprivations that would create chaos.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your third question makes him sigh.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Can the Council conclude? In principle, yes. The stated purposes—ending the Bohemian heresy, reforming the Church in head and members—have been substantially addressed. The Hussites are reconciled. The reform decrees are passed. The crusade is proclaimed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks toward Rome, now visible as a jumble of towers and domes beyond the Castel Sant'Angelo.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But the Council will not conclude, Your Majesty, because the real question was never Bohemia or reform. The real question is Haec Sancta—the decree of Constance that declared councils superior to popes. Cardinal d'Allemand and the French faction came to Basel to finish what Constance started. They want a permanent constitutional settlement that places the papacy under conciliar authority forever.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: They have been patient. They supported the reform decrees because reform strengthens the Council's legitimacy. They supported the Bohemian peace because success proves the Council's necessity. They supported the crusade decree because it demonstrates the Council can act where popes cannot. But all of this, for them, is preparation for the final battle.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Eugenius has not accepted the reform decrees as papal legislation. He has not endorsed the Compacts. He tolerates Basel because he cannot suppress it, but he has not surrendered his claims. The French faction will eventually force a vote on supremacy—whether the Pope must obey the Council or the Council must obey the Pope. When that vote comes...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He trails off, watching a flock of starlings wheel above the riverbank.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: When that vote comes, Your Majesty, everything we have built may shatter. The reform decrees become weapons in a constitutional war rather than foundations for a renewed Church. The Bohemian peace becomes a precedent for councils overruling popes on doctrine. The crusade becomes a sideshow while Rome and Basel tear each other apart.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The barge rounds a final bend. The Castel Sant'Angelo looms directly ahead now, its massive cylinder reflected in the brown water.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So no. The Council cannot conclude. Not until someone wins. Or until someone finds a way for both sides to stop fighting without either side admitting defeat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at you directly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Which is, I believe, why you insisted on coming to Rome before Constantinople. And why you carry the Declaration of Como in your satchel.

encounters.recap: As the royal barge approaches Rome, Fray Hernando explains the doctrine of concomitance that resolved the Bohemian communion dispute, details how the Basel reform decrees close the dispensation loopholes that undermined previous reforms, and reveals why the Council cannot conclude—the fundamental conflict between papal and conciliar supremacy remains unresolved, with the French faction preparing for a final constitutional battle that could shatter all the progress made.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But if the radicals force a vote on authority and they cannot get it passed? Or if someone passes another vote in favor of papal authority, will that not end the council? Anyway, who or what determines when the council concludes? Is that a vote as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando tilts his head, appreciating the precision of your questions.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You think like a king, Your Majesty. You see a problem and ask: how do we end it? But councils do not work like kingdoms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shifts on the cushions, finding a more comfortable position as the barge rocks gently.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: If the radicals force a vote and lose—say, Cardinal d'Allemand demands a decree declaring councils perpetually superior to popes, and the German moderates vote it down—what happens? Nothing. The radicals remain at Basel. They continue attending sessions. They wait. They try again in six months, or a year, when circumstances favor them. A lost vote is a delay, not a defeat.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And if someone proposed a decree affirming papal authority? The French faction would never allow it to reach a vote. They would raise procedural objections. They would demand it be referred to the deputation of faith for study. They would walk out and hold their own session, declaring the other session illegitimate. Basel operates by consensus of the four deputations—faith, peace, reform, and common affairs. Any faction with enough votes in even one deputation can obstruct almost anything.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward, warming to the topic as scholars do.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: As for who determines when the Council concludes—this is the constitutional question that has no settled answer. Three possibilities exist in theory.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He raises one finger.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: First: the Pope dissolves the Council. Pope Eugenius tried this in December 1431, immediately after his election. He issued the bull Quoniam alto, commanding the Council to disperse and reconvene at Bologna in eighteen months. The Council refused. They declared that a legitimately assembled council cannot be dissolved, transferred, or prorogued by the Pope without conciliar consent. They continued meeting as if the bull did not exist. Eugenius eventually had to rescind his dissolution and recognize the Council's legitimacy, because he could not enforce his command.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A second finger.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Second: the Council votes to dissolve itself. This requires agreement across all four deputations—a consensus that the Council's work is complete. In principle, possible. In practice... Who decides when 'reform of the Church in head and members' is complete? The French faction will say reform is incomplete until papal supremacy is broken. The moderates will say reform is complete when the decrees are passed. They will never agree.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A third finger.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Third: Pope and Council agree jointly to conclude. This is what happened at Constance—the Council ended by mutual consent after resolving the schism. But Constance ended because both sides wanted it to end. Martin V was elected, the schism was healed, everyone was exhausted. Basel is different. Neither side wants to end it on the other's terms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He drops his hand and looks at you with something like sympathy.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are asking whether there is a mechanism to simply stop the conflict. There is not. The Council continues until one side wins decisively, or until both sides exhaust themselves into irrelevance, or until some external force—invasion, plague, the death of key figures—changes the calculus entirely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The barge passes into the shadow of the Castel Sant'Angelo. Above you, papal guards watch from the battlements.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Constance lasted four years and ended in triumph. The Council of Basel has already sat for three years with no end in sight. It could continue for another decade. It could still be meeting when Catalina is grown.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia, who has been listening quietly while resting against the cushions, speaks for the first time.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Then what is the point of the parallel legislation Juan carries? If neither side will yield, what does it accomplish?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando turns to her with evident respect.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: An excellent question, Your Majesty. The parallel legislation does not end the conflict. It... routes around it. If Pope Eugenius adopts the reform decrees on his own authority—the same text, issued as papal legislation—then the substance of reform is achieved regardless of who wins the constitutional war. The Church is reformed whether councils rule popes or popes rule councils.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The French faction would hate this, of course. They want reform to prove conciliar supremacy. If the Pope simply adopts the reforms himself, their victory becomes hollow. They reformed the Church... and gained nothing from it.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Which is precisely why they may try to prevent parallel legislation from succeeding. And why your audience with Eugenius matters so much, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The barge bumps gently against a wooden dock. Roman porters wait to receive you, and beyond them, the eternal city sprawls in the afternoon light.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando explains the constitutional mechanisms by which the Council of Basel might end, revealing there is no clear path to dissolution. He outlines three theoretical possibilities—papal dissolution, conciliar self-dissolution, or mutual agreement—but demonstrates why none are viable in practice. The discussion clarifies how the parallel legislation Juan carries could route around the constitutional conflict by achieving reform through papal authority alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's eyebrows rise—the expression of a teacher pleased by a student's attentiveness.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You have read Frequens, Your Majesty. Good. But you have the dates slightly wrong, and the history is more complicated than simple papal defiance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He counts on his fingers as the barge is secured to the dock.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Constance opened in 1414 and closed in 1418, after electing Martin V. Frequens was passed in 1417, requiring councils at intervals of five years, then seven, then every ten years thereafter. So: a council in 1423, another in 1430, then 1440, 1450, and so on into perpetuity. Martin did summon a council for 1423, as required. It met at Pavia.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He grimaces.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: It was a disaster. Poorly attended—most bishops found excuses not to come. Then plague broke out in Pavia, and the council transferred to Siena. More plague. More empty seats. The French were fighting among themselves and sent almost no one. The Germans were distracted by Hussite wars. The Spanish kingdoms were consumed by their own quarrels.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The porters have laid a gangplank. Fray Hernando remains seated, finishing his explanation.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Martin dissolved the Council of Pavia-Siena in 1424, having accomplished almost nothing. He was not defying Frequens—he had called the council as required. But a council that no one attends is merely an empty room with candles.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stands slowly, stretching muscles stiff from the river journey.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The next council was due seven years later—1430 or 1431. Martin called it for Basel, to open in March 1431. He chose Basel precisely because it was convenient to the Germans, hoping for better attendance than Pavia. And because the Hussite question had grown desperate—five crusades had failed, and someone had to negotiate with the Bohemians. But Martin died in February 1431, weeks before the council opened. His successor, Eugenius IV, inherited a council he did not summon, in a city he did not choose, to address problems he had not created.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando steps onto the gangplank, then pauses to look back at you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Eugenius tried to dissolve Basel immediately, as I mentioned. The council refused. And here we are, three years later, with Pope and Council still at war over who commands whom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He offers a thin smile.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: So you see, Your Majesty—Martin did not ignore Frequens. He complied with the letter of the law. But compliance and success are not the same thing. Pavia-Siena proved that you can summon a council and still accomplish nothing. Basel is proving that a council can accomplish much and still tear the Church apart.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia has risen carefully, one hand on her belly, and Captain Fernán moves to assist her onto the dock. Catalina is already ashore, tugging at Doña Leonor's hand and pointing at a Roman soldier's plumed helmet.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The question is whether anyone learned anything from Pavia's failure. Or whether we are doomed to repeat it, with higher stakes and sharper knives.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How strong is the French faction in the council? Do they really control so much votes?

encounters.recap: As the royal barge docks in Rome, Fray Hernando provides Juan with a detailed historical explanation of the Council Frequens requirements and the failures of past councils, from Pavia-Siena's poor attendance to Basel's current conflict with the Pope, ending with Juan's inquiry about French factional influence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando pauses on the dock, letting the porters handle the baggage while he considers your question. The Roman afternoon sun catches the grey in his tonsured hair.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Strong enough to obstruct. Not strong enough to command. But the Council's structure makes obstruction almost as powerful as command.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances around, ensuring no Roman clergy are within earshot—papal territory demands discretion when discussing conciliar politics.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You must understand how Basel votes, Your Majesty. It is unlike any parliament or cortes you have seen. The Council does not vote by nation, as Constance did. It does not vote by rank—bishops over abbots over doctors. Instead, it operates through the four deputations: faith, peace, reform, and common affairs. Every member of the Council is assigned to one deputation. Every deputation must approve a measure before it reaches the general session. And within each deputation, a simple majority carries the vote.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He steps aside as porters carry a trunk past him.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This means that every priest, every abbot, every doctor of theology has the same vote as a cardinal or archbishop. A Franciscan friar from Lyon counts equally with the Archbishop of Trier. Now consider what this means for the French faction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's voice takes on the precise cadence of a man who has spent eight months watching these dynamics unfold.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Cardinal d'Allemand does not command a majority of the Council. If you counted heads across all four deputations, the moderates—Germans, Castilians, some Italians, the Emperor's supporters—likely outnumber the French radicals. This is why the reform decrees passed. This is why the Bohemian peace was achieved. On matters of genuine reform, the moderates can assemble enough votes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But Cardinal d'Allemand does not need a majority to obstruct. He needs only to control one deputation sufficiently to prevent measures from reaching the general session. And he needs allies willing to use procedural tactics—demanding referrals, raising objections, questioning credentials, walking out to deny quorum.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He counts on his fingers again.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The French have perhaps sixty to eighty committed supporters. The University of Paris sends a steady stream of doctors who vote as d'Allemand directs. French bishops and abbots follow their cardinal. Some Burgundians align with them, though Burgundy's politics are complex. A scattering of radical conciliarists from other nations who genuinely believe councils must rule popes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Against them, the Germans number perhaps one hundred to one hundred twenty, but they are divided between Sigismund's loyalists, who want cooperation with Rome, and those who simply want reform regardless of constitutional questions. The Italians are few—most Italian clergy stay close to Rome rather than traveling to Basel. The Spanish delegations—Castile, Aragon, Portugal—are small but respected. The English send almost no one; they are consumed by their French wars.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando spreads his hands.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: They cannot pass a decree of papal deposition over moderate opposition. They tried to force this issue in 1432, before the Declaration of Como, and failed. The Germans would not support it. But they can prevent any decree that favors papal authority. They can block attempts to conclude the Council. They can ensure that every session becomes a battlefield over procedure and precedent. They can make Basel so hostile to Eugenius that he refuses to cooperate with any conciliar legislation, even reforms he might otherwise accept.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks toward the city, toward the Vatican visible in the distance.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And there is a deeper problem, Your Majesty. The moderates grow weary. Bishop Alfonso writes that attendance has declined since the great decrees passed. Men who came to Basel for reform have achieved reform; they wish to go home to their dioceses. Men who came for the Bohemian peace have achieved peace; they see no reason to remain. But the French radicals do not go home. They stay. They wait. They attend every session while others drift away. And as the moderates leave, the radicals become proportionally stronger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's expression is grim.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Time favors Cardinal d'Allemand, Your Majesty. Every month that passes without resolution, his faction grows stronger relative to those who remain. If this continues another two or three years, he may yet command the majority he currently lacks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia has reached the dock now, Catalina pulling at her hand impatiently. The child has discovered a street vendor selling roasted nuts and is making her desires known with characteristic volume.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is why parallel legislation matters. If Eugenius adopts the reforms now, while the moderates still hold Basel, the substance is secured regardless of what happens later. If he waits, hoping the Council will collapse on its own... he may wait too long.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando provides a detailed analysis of the French faction's strength at Basel, explaining how the Council's unique voting structure allows Cardinal d'Allemand to obstruct decisions without commanding a majority. He warns that time favors the French radicals as moderate delegates leave, making immediate papal action on reforms crucial.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando stops walking. The Roman street bustles around you—porters, merchants, a Franciscan brother hurrying past with a basket of bread—but he stands still, studying you with an expression you recognize. It is the look he gives when you have said something that requires genuine thought rather than ready answers.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are proposing to flood the Council. To change its composition so dramatically that the French faction becomes a minority even with their current numbers unchanged.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gestures for you to step aside, into the shade of a crumbling Roman archway, away from the bustle of the dock. Captain Fernán keeps the porters moving while Lucia waits with Catalina and the ladies, understanding that this conversation requires privacy.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Let me think through this with you, Your Majesty. The strategy has... merit. But also difficulties. First, the mechanics. New arrivals at Basel are assigned to deputations by the Council's administrative officers. In theory, this is done to balance the deputations. In practice, it is political. If one hundred Italian clergy arrive at once, all known to favor dissolution, the officers—who include French sympathizers—could scatter them across all four deputations, diluting their impact. Or they could delay seating them while 'verifying credentials,' which can take months. Or they could assign them all to the deputation of common affairs, which handles administrative matters but rarely touches constitutional questions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He holds up a hand before you can respond.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is not insurmountable. If Eugenius coordinates with Cardinal Cesarini, who still holds significant influence as papal legate, the assignments could be managed. But it requires preparation and allies within the Council's administration. Second, the perception. If one hundred Italian clergy arrive in Basel carrying papal legislation, and immediately begin voting to conclude the Council, what will Cardinal d'Allemand say?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He answers his own question, his voice taking on a mocking French accent.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: 'The Pope has sent his lackeys to suppress legitimate reform! These are not independent prelates seeking the good of the Church—they are Roman agents doing Roman bidding! Their votes should not count because they did not come to deliberate, but to execute a predetermined command!'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice returns to normal.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And here is the problem, Your Majesty: he would not be entirely wrong. If the Italians arrive with the obvious purpose of ending the Council, their legitimacy is tainted. The moderates—the Germans who have worked for genuine reform—might not support a dissolution that looks like papal manipulation. They want the Council to end honorably, not to be strangled by Roman hands. Third, the walkout.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando pushes off from the wall, pacing in the small shaded space.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Suppose your strategy succeeds. Suppose the Italians are seated, the votes are counted, and the Council of Basel votes to dissolve itself. What prevents Cardinal d'Allemand from simply... refusing to leave? The French faction could declare the dissolution vote illegitimate. They could claim the Italian newcomers were not properly credentialed, or that the vote violated procedural requirements, or that a council cannot dissolve itself while reform remains incomplete. They could continue meeting—a rump council, perhaps, but a council nonetheless. They ignored Eugenius's dissolution in 1431. Why would they accept a dissolution orchestrated by his Italian supporters?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops, facing you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You would have two bodies claiming to be the legitimate Council of Basel. One dissolved, one continuing. The schism you seek to prevent would occur anyway, merely in different form. And fourth... Would Eugenius actually do this? Would he sign the Basel decrees?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances toward the Vatican, visible over the rooftops.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: By signing, he acknowledges that Basel has passed legitimate legislation. He validates the Council's authority. Some of his advisors will argue he should never concede this—that he should wait for Basel to collapse under its own contradictions rather than dignifying it with papal endorsement. The annates decree alone reduces papal revenue by seventy-five percent. The pluralism decree strips Rome of the power to grant dispensations. These are not small concessions, Your Majesty. You are asking Eugenius to sign away powers his predecessors accumulated over centuries, and to do so in coordination with a council that has declared itself his superior.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls silent for a moment, watching a cat pick its way along the ancient stones.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And yet... The core of your strategy is sound. You understand that the Council ends when there is nothing left to fight over. If Eugenius adopts the reforms, the reform grievance disappears. If the Bohemian peace holds, that grievance disappears. If Constantinople is defended, the crusade grievance disappears. What remains? Only the constitutional question—whether councils rule popes. And the constitutional question, by itself, is not enough to sustain Basel indefinitely. Men came to Basel for reform, for Bohemia, for crusade. If those are achieved, attendance will decline. The French faction cannot maintain a council alone. They need moderates present to give their proceedings legitimacy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He strokes his chin thoughtfully.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A wiser strategy, perhaps, would be slower. Not a flood, but a tide. Eugenius signs the decrees—not because Basel demands it, but because reform is good and right. This removes the accusation that he opposes reform. Over months, Italian attendance increases—not dramatically, but steadily. The moderates, seeing reform achieved and papal cooperation offered, begin to argue that the Council's work is complete. The French find themselves increasingly isolated, defending a constitutional war that no one else wishes to fight. The Council does not end by dramatic vote. It ends by... exhaustion. By irrelevance. By men going home because there is nothing left to do. Cardinal d'Allemand can continue meeting with his French doctors if he wishes, but if no one else attends, he is merely an old man talking to himself in an empty cathedral.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is slower than you would like, Your Majesty. It could take two years, perhaps three. But it ends the Council without creating a schism, without validating the charge of papal manipulation, and without giving the French a martyrdom to rally around. Of course, this assumes Eugenius is willing to play a long game. And that nothing happens in the meantime to inflame passions further. And that you are willing to remain involved in church politics for years rather than months.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A wry smile crosses his face.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Which, I suspect, is precisely what the Declaration of Como committed you to. Whether you fully understood that at the time.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have always been worried by the mechanism of the council. That they operate on a principle of giving a vote to whoever decides to show up. This seems unfair to faithful far removed from Basel and opens up for what the French are doing; flooding the council with doctors from Paris who vote as a bloc. I have always considered that the council if left to very few attendants could pass critical legislation with full legitimacy. But you seem to say that a council with very few members have no legitimacy. But would the decrees they pass not have the full weight of haec sancta?

encounters.recap: In a Roman archway, Fray Hernando analyzes Juan's proposal to flood Basel with Italian clergy to end the Council. He identifies four major obstacles: administrative manipulation, perception of papal coercion, potential French walkout, and papal reluctance to validate conciliar authority. He proposes instead a gradual strategy where Eugenius voluntarily adopts reforms and slowly increases Italian attendance, allowing the Council to end through exhaustion rather than dramatic confrontation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's expression shifts—the look of a teacher who has been waiting for a student to reach precisely this question.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Now you have found the wound at the heart of conciliarism, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He settles against the archway again, clearly prepared for a longer discussion. Lucia catches his eye and nods slightly, guiding Catalina toward the shade of a nearby fountain where the child can splash her fingers in the water while the adults talk.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Let me answer your question with another question. What gives Haec Sancta its authority?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He does not wait for you to respond.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The decree claims that a general council, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal Church, holds authority directly from Christ—authority that even the Pope must obey in matters of faith, schism, and reform. This is the foundation of everything Basel claims.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But consider: Haec Sancta was passed at Constance in 1415 by perhaps three hundred prelates, in the midst of a schism when three men claimed to be Pope and none commanded universal obedience. Was that assembly 'representing the universal Church'? The Greeks were not present. The Russians were not present. Most of Africa and Asia were not present. Spain was barely represented. Even within the Latin West, many bishops refused to attend because they did not recognize the council's legitimacy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He spreads his hands.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Yet we treat Haec Sancta as binding. Why? Because enough of Christendom accepted it as binding. Because it resolved the schism. Because Martin V was elected under its authority and ruled as Pope for ten years without repudiating it directly. Legitimacy came not from the mechanism, but from the acceptance.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Now apply this to your question.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's voice takes on a harder edge.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are correct that Basel's mechanism is absurd. A doctor of theology from Paris, who holds no pastoral responsibility, who shepherds no flock, who answers to no one but his university faculty, has the same vote as the Archbishop of Toledo, who governs a province of two million souls. A wandering friar can arrive in Basel, claim credentials, and vote on matters affecting the entire Church. The system practically invites manipulation.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And you are also correct that a council reduced to a handful of attendees could, procedurally, pass any decree it wished. Fifty French doctors could vote tomorrow to depose Eugenius, elect a new Pope, and declare themselves the supreme authority in Christendom. The mechanism permits it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses, letting the implications settle.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But would anyone obey?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is the distinction you are grasping toward, Your Majesty. There is procedural legitimacy—following the rules as written—and there is actual legitimacy—the acceptance of Christendom that makes decrees effective.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The decrees Basel has passed so far carry weight because they were passed by a broadly-attended council with German, Castilian, Italian, English, and yes, French participation. The Compacts of Basel ended the Hussite Wars because Bohemia and the Empire and the moderate council fathers all accepted them. The reform decrees have moral force because they address genuine abuses that the whole Church acknowledges.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But a decree passed by fifty Frenchmen in an empty cathedral? The Archbishop of Toledo would ignore it. The German princes would ignore it. The Italian bishops would laugh at it. Even if Cardinal d'Allemand waved Haec Sancta and screamed that councils are supreme, no one would care. A council that claims to represent the universal Church but manifestly does not... is merely a collection of men with opinions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando pushes off from the wall and steps closer, lowering his voice.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is the trap the French faction has set for themselves, Your Majesty. They exploit the mechanism—flooding Basel with Parisian doctors, maintaining attendance while others leave, using procedures to obstruct and delay. But every manipulation undermines the legitimacy they claim to defend.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: When Cardinal d'Allemand packs the deputations with university theologians who have never governed a parish, he weakens the Council's claim to represent the Church. When the French faction remains while the Germans and Italians and Spaniards depart, they transform Basel from a general council into a French conventicle. They may retain procedural control, but they lose the moral authority that made Haec Sancta powerful in the first place.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shakes his head slowly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The French do not see this. Or perhaps they see it and do not care. They believe that if they can pass decrees claiming authority, the authority becomes real. They confuse the words with the substance.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And here is the deepest irony.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando's smile is thin and bitter.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Pope Eugenius makes the same error in reverse. He believes that if he simply denies the Council's authority, it has none. He issues bulls declaring Basel dissolved, and when Basel continues meeting, he pretends this is mere rebellion that will eventually collapse. He refuses to engage with the reform decrees because engaging would acknowledge the Council's right to pass them.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But denial does not make Basel disappear. The reform decrees exist. The Bohemian peace exists. The crusade decree exists. Bishops across Christendom read these documents and ask: 'Are these laws? Must I obey them?' And Eugenius has no answer except 'No, because I say no.'

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Which is precisely as weak as Cardinal d'Allemand saying 'Yes, because I say yes.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls silent for a long moment, watching Catalina splash in the fountain while Doña Leonor tries to prevent her from soaking her dress entirely.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You asked about a strategy to end the Council, Your Majesty. The true answer is this: the Council ends when both Pope and Council stop pretending that legitimacy flows from their own declarations.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: If Eugenius signs the reform decrees, he acknowledges that councils can do good work—but as parallel legislation, adopted by papal authority, not conceded to conciliar supremacy. He gains the moral high ground of reform while denying that he was compelled to reform.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: If the Council, in turn, accepts that its reforms have been adopted and its work is complete, it acknowledges that papal cooperation was necessary to make reform effective. It gains the substance of what it sought while quietly abandoning the claim that it could command the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Both sides yield something. Both sides gain something. Neither side admits defeat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is what the Declaration of Como proposed, Your Majesty. This is what you must persuade Eugenius to accept. Not because it is philosophically pure—it is not. But because it is the only path that does not end in schism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances toward the Vatican.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Whether the Pope is wise enough to see this... that is what we are about to discover.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando explains to Juan II the paradox at the heart of conciliarism: the distinction between procedural and actual legitimacy. He argues that Basel's French faction exploits voting mechanisms while undermining their moral authority, and that Pope Eugenius makes the same error in reverse by simply denying the Council's authority. The friar proposes that the only path to avoid schism is mutual compromise where both sides yield something - the Pope accepting reform while the Council abandons claims of supremacy over papal authority.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Two different treasuries serving two different purposes, Your Majesty. And the decree's division between them is one of its most significant—and controversial—innovations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gestures for you to walk with him toward the fountain where Lucia waits, speaking as you move through the Roman street.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
