He does not forbid a king from determining where mosques may stand. What trades Muslims may practice. What lands they may own. What positions they may hold. Whether their testimony holds weight against a Christian's in court. You asked what I propose. I propose nothing, Your Majesty. I am a humble Dominican with no authority in Castile. But I ask you this: in twenty years, what do you wish Granada to be? And what will you permit today that makes that future impossible?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have made effort to destroy nearly all mosques in Granada. Some I have left standing in the first years of conquest to ease the transition. But soon they will all be churches. And we will slowly drive the muslims out of Granada of course. This takes time. And please speak freely. You have no authority in Castile but I do and you clearly have something to say. I would hear it.

encounters.recap: Brother Tomás de Torquemada, a Dominican serving the Aragonese Inquisition, meets with Juan II to probe his religious policies in Granada. Through careful questioning about converted Muslims like Commander Martín de Alcalá, Torquemada reveals his skepticism about the sincerity of mass conversions and advocates for systematic pressure to ensure religious conformity. Juan admits his pragmatic approach and reveals his plans to destroy all mosques and gradually expel Muslims from Granada.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And please speak freely. You have no authority in Castille but I do and you clearly have something to say. I would hear it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada is still for a moment. Then he returns to his chair and sits, and something in his posture shifts—less the interrogator, more the counselor.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You destroy mosques. Good. You drive them out slowly. This is... prudent. But consider, Your Majesty. You drive them out—where? To Morocco? To Tunis? To the Ottoman lands? You send Commander Martín to Morocco now. In twenty years, you may face those same exiled Muslims returning with Moroccan armies, knowing every pass and fortress in Granada because they grew up there.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: And those who remain—those who convert to avoid exile—how will you know them from those who converted truly? They will attend Mass. They will baptize their children. They will eat pork when Christians are watching. And in their homes, behind closed doors, they will wash the baptismal water from their infants' heads and whisper the shahada over them.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: I have seen this, Your Majesty. In Aragon. With the Jews who converted a generation ago. Conversos who light candles on Friday nights. Who refuse to eat shellfish. Who marry only among themselves. Who are Christian in the streets and Jewish in their hearts.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You asked what I propose. Very well. First—records. Every conversion documented. Every baptism recorded with witnesses. The names of godparents, the officiating priest, the date and place. A register that follows the converso and his descendants. Second—observation. Not persecution. Observation. Neighbors who report irregularities. Priests who note which conversos attend Mass faithfully and which find excuses. Patterns, Your Majesty. The apostate reveals himself through patterns. Third—investigation. When patterns emerge, when accusations accumulate, then—and only then—formal inquiry. Conducted by men trained to distinguish true faith from performance. Men who understand that the apostate will lie, and who know how to find truth regardless.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: This is not the sword at the throat. This is the shepherd watching his flock for wolves in sheep's clothing. The Pope cannot object to a king who documents baptisms, notices irregularities, and investigates accusations of apostasy. This is not forced conversion. This is the protection of the Church from those who would corrupt it from within.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Prudent measures. I know that having Castillians settle in Grenada is the only sure way to completely christianize the area in the long term. I have only just finished the conquest. Focus is on stability for now. Then the inquisition can move in and can start observing their habits. Do you have contacts with the Castillian inquisition? I will need their help.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada's expression does not change, but something stills in him—the stillness of a hunter who sees his quarry turn toward him.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The Castilian Inquisition. It exists, Your Majesty. Bishops hold inquisitorial authority in their dioceses. Occasionally they exercise it. Occasionally. In Aragon, the Inquisition is... more developed. More systematic. We have experience with the converso question that Castile has been spared, until now.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: I have contacts, yes. In Aragon. Among the Dominicans who staff the tribunals. Among those who understand that this work requires training, method, patience. Whether such contacts would be useful in Castile depends upon what Your Majesty intends.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: A bishop in Granada, newly appointed to a see that did not exist two years ago, with a flock of fresh conversos he does not know and cannot watch—what resources does he have? What experience? The Inquisition you need in Granada does not yet exist, Your Majesty. It would need to be built.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me more about how the inquisition in Aragon operates and how we may shape the inquisition in Grenada.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada settles back into his chair. His posture shifts subtly—the scholar now, the expert consulted on his field of knowledge.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The Inquisition in Aragon operates under papal authority. Inquisitors are appointed by the Pope, or by the Inquisitor General acting in his name. They answer to Rome, not to the Crown. This has advantages. The inquisitor is not subject to local pressures—not the bishop who wishes to protect his flock's reputation, not the nobleman whose converso banker is too useful to lose, not the merchant guild that profits from trade with secret apostates.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The tribunal operates through a system of denunciations, investigations, and trials. When the Inquisition arrives in a district, it proclaims an Edict of Grace—thirty days, sometimes forty, during which apostates may confess voluntarily and receive lenient penance. This separates the sincere penitent from the hardened deceiver.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: After the grace period, the work begins in earnest. Witnesses are called. Testimony is gathered. Patterns emerge—who attends Mass irregularly, who refuses certain foods, who observes strange customs behind closed doors. When sufficient evidence accumulates, the accused is summoned.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: For Granada, you would need to build this from nothing. The structures do not exist. The trained men do not exist. First—a chief inquisitor for the territory. A man of experience, not a local bishop distracted by a thousand other duties. Someone who understands the particular dangers of the Islamic apostate, which differ from the Jewish apostate in important ways. Second—familiares. Lay servants of the Inquisition who live among the people, who watch and listen and report. They must be trustworthy Christians of clean blood—no converso heritage themselves. Third—a network of informants. This need not be sinister, Your Majesty. Good Christians wish to report apostasy. They simply need to know that their reports will be heard, investigated, acted upon. Fourth—coordination with the secular arm. The Inquisition does not execute. It determines guilt and releases the unrepentant to secular authority for punishment.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: All of this takes years to build properly. But Granada is new. The conversions are fresh. If you wait too long, the apostates will learn to hide, will teach their children to hide, will create networks of deception that become impossible to penetrate. The time to plant this seed is now, Your Majesty. While the soil is still soft.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see. I will follow up and install inquisition in Grenada upon my return. Now tell me, did you want to meet me because you wanted to impress the importance of Grenada upon me? Or was there something else you wanted to share?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada's expression shifts almost imperceptibly. Something like satisfaction crosses his gaunt features before vanishing behind monastic composure.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Granada is important. But no—it is not why I asked for this meeting. I told your confessor that there are those in Rome who would speak with you away from Vatican eyes. I meant myself, yes. But I also meant to warn you.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You come to Rome seeking audience with the Pope. You carry proposals from Como. You hope to find some middle ground between His Holiness and Basel. You are not the only one watching these developments, Your Majesty. And not all who watch wish you well.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The French have agents in Rome. Cardinal d'Estouteville dines with the French ambassador weekly. The University of Paris sends men who are not merely theologians. They watch Basel. They watch the Emperor. And now they watch you. You marched six hundred men to St. Peter's this morning. By tonight, a report will travel north describing what you said, how you said it, how the Romans reacted. By next week, Cardinal d'Allemand in Basel will know every word.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: And there is talk, Your Majesty, among certain circles, that the King of Castile has grown too influential. That his crusade gives him moral authority that threatens the balance of power. That he should be... managed. I do not know what form this management might take. But I know that men are asking questions about your household. Your finances. Your conversos. Your intentions toward Aragon after Alfonso dies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! Let them. I carry on with my charge regardless. I was good to meet you, you have told me much about the inquisition. One last question; what happens to converso who have been found to still be muslim?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada pauses. His expression does not change, but something in his stillness suggests this question pleases him—a king who asks practical questions about consequences.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: That depends on the nature of their sin and the state of their soul. First—those who confess during the Edict of Grace, before any accusation is made. These receive light penance. Prayers, fasting, perhaps a pilgrimage. They are reconciled to the Church with minimal shame. This is mercy, Your Majesty. The door held open for the sincerely repentant.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Second—those who confess after accusation but before trial concludes. These are reconciled, but with heavier penance. Public abjuration of their error. The sanbenito—a penitential garment worn for months or years, marking them so all may know. Fines. Sometimes imprisonment. Their names recorded, their descendants marked.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Third—those who refuse to confess despite evidence, or who confess but are judged insincere, or who are convicted and later relapse into apostasy. These are relaxed to the secular arm. The Church does not kill, Your Majesty. She is a mother, and mothers do not slay their children. But when a child proves to be no child at all—a wolf that infiltrated the fold, a disease that threatens the flock—the Church must protect the faithful. She releases the unrepentant to secular authority, with a plea for mercy.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The secular authority acts as it sees fit. In Aragon, the unrepentant burn. This is rare, Your Majesty. The purpose of the Inquisition is not execution—it is salvation. Every tool, every method, every procedure exists to give the apostate opportunity to repent and return to Christ. Only those who refuse every chance, who cling to their false faith unto the end, face the fire. And even then, those who repent at the stake—truly repent, in their final moments—are granted the mercy of strangulation before the flames are lit.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You will find me a pious and faithful servant of the lord who seeks to expand christianity. I will remember this meeting. Good day, and walk with the lord sir. I go back to Lucia

encounters.recap: Brother Torquemada presents a systematic plan for establishing the Inquisition in Granada, detailing methods of surveillance, investigation, and punishment for Muslim converts suspected of secret apostasy. He warns Juan of French intelligence networks in Rome and positions himself as a valuable contact for implementing inquisitorial authority in newly conquered territories.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back through Rome is quieter than the march to St. Peter's. Just you, Fray Hernando, and the two men-at-arms trailing behind. Fray Hernando says nothing for several streets. His sandals scuff against the cobblestones. His grey habit sways with each step. His face remains unreadable. Finally, as you pass the Pantheon's great bronze doors, he speaks—not looking at you, his voice carefully neutral.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You told him you would install the Inquisition in Granada upon your return.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It is not a question. It is not quite an accusation. It is simply a statement, placed in the air between you like a stone laid on a scale. He does not elaborate. He does not ask for explanation. He walks beside you in silence, waiting to see if you wish to discuss what just passed in that sparse Dominican cell—or if you wish to let it lie. The afternoon sun hangs over Rome. The palazzo is not far now.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course. Creating good christian rule with respect to both christians and muslims is important. I like the idea of an institution guiding souls to salvation. I dont like to burn people at the stake, even infidels, I will find something else. What do you think about the inquisition? I have not really met them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando walks several more paces before responding. His sandals find each cobblestone with the deliberate care of a man choosing his words.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Inquisition is a lawful institution of Holy Mother Church. It has existed for two centuries. It has protected the faith from heresy—Cathars, Waldensians, others who would corrupt doctrine from within.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His tone is measured. Factual. The voice of a man reciting what cannot be disputed. Then silence. More cobblestones. More careful steps.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Dominicans staff the tribunals. They are trained for this work. Domini canes—the hounds of the Lord, they call themselves. Franciscans have a different charism. We preach. We beg. We live among the poor and trust that example teaches better than coercion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at you for the first time since leaving Santa Maria sopra Minerva.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You say you will find something other than burning. This is good. But consider—you made a commitment to a man you met an hour ago. A man who told you what he wished you to hear. A man who clearly wants something, though he has not yet named his price. What do you know of Brother Tomás, Your Majesty? Beyond what Brother Tomás chose to reveal?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe you are right. I will examine them thoroughly before installing them. If I then determine I do not want to install them, then so be it. I will have to swallow my words. We will be careful. I like Franciscans and their ways. Maybe Castille will have a Franciscanian inquisition, who knows?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando makes a sound—somewhere between a cough and a laugh, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A Franciscan Inquisition. Brother Francis would spin in his grave at Assisi. We are not made for such work. We are made for begging bread and preaching to birds.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But something in his posture eases. The tension that has held his shoulders since you left Torquemada's cell releases, just slightly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Examine them thoroughly. Yes. Speak to men who have lived under inquisitorial authority—not only the inquisitors themselves. Speak to the conversos in Toledo, in Seville. Ask them what the Inquisition means to those who are watched rather than those who watch.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls silent as you turn onto the street where the palazzo stands. The Castilian banner hangs limp in the afternoon stillness.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will say one more thing, Your Majesty, and then I will hold my peace on this matter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops walking, turning to face you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Brother Tomás spoke of wolves in sheep's clothing. Of apostates hiding among the faithful. This is a real danger—I do not deny it. But there is another danger he did not mention. When shepherds see wolves everywhere, they begin to mistake sheep for wolves. And a shepherd who slaughters his own flock to protect it from wolves he imagines...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaves the sentence unfinished.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are a good king, Your Majesty. You have a good heart. Guard it carefully in the days to come. Your queen is waiting. And I suspect she will want to know what a Dominican inquisitor wanted with her husband.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I lay my hand on his shoulder. I am glad to have you by my side Fray. Maybe we can find a way, a way towards salvation in a gentle way, through example. Who knows. I will never let you or your brothers do anything that is against your nature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando is still beneath your hand. For a moment, his weathered face softens—the face of a man who has walked beside you through rebellion and crusade and the long bloody road to Granada.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I know, Your Majesty. I have never doubted your heart.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He places his own hand briefly over yours—a gesture more intimate than any he has offered in the four years you have known him.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: It is not your heart that concerns me. It is the world that presses upon it. The men who whisper that harshness is strength. The voices that say mercy is weakness. You will hear such voices often in the years to come. More often as your power grows.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He steps back, composing himself. The confessor's mask settles back into place, but something warmer remains beneath it.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Go to your wife. Hold your daughter. Remember what you fight for. And perhaps... do not mention Brother Tomás to Queen Lucia immediately. She has had a long morning watching from the Castel Sant'Angelo, wondering if her husband's hammer would crack the Vatican in two. Let her enjoy her relief before you tell her you have been discussing inquisitions with Dominicans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—shallow, familiar, the bow of a friend rather than a subject.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will be in the chapel if you need me. I find I have much to pray about.

encounters.recap: Walking back from meeting Torquemada, Fray Hernando cautiously questions Juan's promise to install the Inquisition in Granada. Through careful dialogue, the Franciscan friar warns against hasty commitments and suggests examining the institution thoroughly, advocating for gentler approaches to salvation. Their relationship deepens as Juan reassures him of his good intentions and values his counsel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The palazzo is quiet in the afternoon heat. Servants move softly through the corridors, speaking in hushed tones. The household has learned the rhythms of a traveling court—when to bustle, when to fade into the walls.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Lucia in your chambers, seated by the window where she can see the street below. She has changed from her morning clothes into a loose gown of Florentine blue, her hair unbound. A plate of bread and cheese sits beside her, barely touched. A cup of something—water, perhaps, or watered wine—rests in her hands.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are still in your armor. And you have not been arrested. These are both good signs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She sets down her cup and rises, moving to you. Her hands find the straps of your breastplate, beginning to work them loose with practiced fingers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I watched from the Castel Sant'Angelo. The Medici agent arranged it—a room with a view of the piazza. I saw the march. I saw you speak, though I could not hear the words. I saw Catalina wave at the Vatican. And I saw someone wave back.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me everything. From the beginning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The armor comes off piece by piece—pauldrons, vambraces, greaves. Lucia works with the methodical patience of a woman who has done this before, though her fingers were not made for buckles and straps. She listens without interrupting as you speak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You describe the mass. Canon Della Rovere's careful neutrality. The elderly cardinal who ignored you. The papal secretaries with their notebooks. The prayers for the seventy-five, brief but dignified. Catalina's behavior—better than expected. The speech in the piazza. The Roman whispers afterward. The butcher who spoke loudly of faith versus politics. The curious crowd that lingered without cheering.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She told me. Three times. The Pope waved at her specifically, she is certain of it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then you describe the Dominican. Lucia's hands slow on the final buckles as you tell of Brother Tomás de Torquemada. The sparse cell. The dark eyes. The questions about conversos, about Commander Martín, about how you know a conversion is genuine. She sets aside the last piece of armor and moves to pour you wine. Her back is to you when you describe Torquemada's proposals—records of every conversion, observation, informants, investigation. The Inquisition that Granada does not yet have but would need to build.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She is silent when you tell her you said you would install the Inquisition upon your return. You describe the warnings about French agents. Cardinal d'Estouteville. Reports traveling north. Men asking questions about your household, your finances, your intentions toward Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: This Dominican. He sought you out. He had answers ready for questions you had not yet thought to ask. He told you exactly what you needed to hear about Granada's future, and then—conveniently—warned you about enemies watching. In Florence, we call this l'amo. The hook. You bait it with something the fish wants. Then you set it with something the fish fears. And then you wait for the fish to swim exactly where you wish it to go. What does Brother Tomás want, husband? He did not arrange this meeting from the kindness of his heart.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I discussed this with Fray Hernando as well. I will not burn infidels at the stake. I will start an institution to help souls reach salvation, but more in a Franciscanic way I think. How, I'm not sure yet.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That is what you will not do. And that is what you hope to build. These are good things to know. But I did not ask what you intend, husband. I asked what he intends. What Brother Tomás wants. A man does not position himself as indispensable to a king—offering expertise, offering warnings, offering to build institutions—without wanting something in return.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises and moves to the window, looking out at the Roman afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: In Florence, when a man offers you exactly what you need before you knew you needed it, you ask yourself: what does he gain when I accept? Not what he says he gains. What he actually gains. You told him you would install the Inquisition in Granada. You told him you liked his ideas about records and observation. You listened when he warned you about French agents. What did you offer him, Juan? What did he walk away with? Does he now return to his masters—whoever they are—and say 'The King of Castile is ours'?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think he wants more or less what everyone wants. Power, position, prestige. Through me as king. I will examine the inquisition when I return. If needed, I will retract what I told him today. We will see. I have given him nothing I cannot take back.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Lucia and recounts his eventful day in Rome, including his encounter with Brother Tomás de Torquemada and his agreement to install an Inquisition in Granada. Lucia displays her Florentine political instincts, warning Juan that the Dominican may be manipulating him and questioning what the friar truly wants in return for his counsel.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Casual meetings are possible. The churches, the markets, the public spaces where one might happen to encounter someone. Cardinal Capranica has not approached us. But he has also not avoided us. He appeared at Mass this morning—that was not accident.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Let me think on it while you find oranges. I will write to our family's agent again. Ask who might be... approachable. Who attends which churches, which markets, which social gatherings.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Now go. Before I decide I want figs as well, and you must search all of Rome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon air is warm as you step into the Roman streets. Without armor, without guards, without the trappings of kingship, you are simply a man in good Spanish wool—foreign, clearly, but unremarkable. Captain Fernán would be furious if he knew. You do not care.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The market near the Pantheon is a riot of color and noise. Vendors call their wares in rapid Italian, competing for attention. Bolts of cloth hang beside strings of garlic. A fishmonger argues with a priest over the price of sardines. Children dart between legs, chasing a spotted cat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find the fruit sellers in a corner of the piazza, their stalls bright with the harvest of southern Italy. Lemons from Amalfi. Figs from Calabria. And oranges—piles of them, some pale and golden, others dark as wine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back is slower. You take a longer route, through narrow streets where laundry hangs between buildings and old men play cards in doorways. Rome layers itself around you—ancient stones beneath medieval walls beneath Renaissance facades. A city that has seen a hundred kings come and go.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Near the palazzo, you pass a group of men talking in low voices. One of them glances at you, does a double-take, nudges his companion. You catch a fragment: '...il re spagnolo...' The Spanish king. Word has spread.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia is dozing when you return, curled in her chair by the window. The afternoon light falls soft across her face, smoothing the lines of worry and weariness. One hand rests on her belly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You found them?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The knife works slowly. You are not skilled at this—there are servants for such things, and before that there were cooks, and before that your mother never let you near sharp instruments. But you manage. The skin comes away in uneven strips, revealing the flesh beneath. Dark as garnets, the old woman said. She was right. The orange bleeds crimson where your knife has nicked it, juice running down your fingers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sweet. And tart. Perfect.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are very bad at this, husband.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sit with me. Share them. We have perhaps an hour before Catalina wakes and demands attention. Let us have this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light slants golden through the window. Rome murmurs beyond the walls. For this moment, there is only the taste of blood oranges and the quiet company of your wife.

encounters.recap: Juan ventures alone into Rome's markets to buy oranges for Lucia, enjoying the anonymity of walking without guards or royal trappings. He purchases blood oranges from an old Sicilian woman and returns to find Lucia resting. They share the oranges together in a tender domestic moment, with Lucia skillfully peeling the fruit while they enjoy a rare hour of peaceful intimacy before their daughter wakes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The blood orange rinds lie curled on the table between you, their bitter-sweet scent filling the small chamber. Through the narrow window, Rome's afternoon light stretches long shadows across the floor. Catalina has been taken to the nursery by her nurse, exhausted from the morning's Mass and the excitement of the market. Lucia sits across from you, one hand resting absently on her belly—the habit has already begun, though she's barely showing. The color has returned to her face after the oranges. She's been quiet since your account of Torquemada, processing.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: So. Cardinal Orsini treats Fray Hernando like a stranger. The Camera clerk spoke for thirty minutes and said nothing. The French are watching us. And a Dominican has offered to make himself useful in ways that should make us uncomfortable. What do we actually know before your audience with the Holy Father?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hangs in the air. You know less than you'd like. Eugenius summoned you—that means something. Cardinal Capranica caught your eye at Mass, murmured that the Pope was watching. Someone in the Vatican waved back at Catalina. The French faction monitors your movements. But the substance—what Eugenius actually thinks about parallel legislation, about Basel, about the crusade termination problem—remains opaque.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The Medici agent. I could try a different approach. Ask not about Camera finances—clearly they won't speak of that—but about people. Who in the Vatican might actually receive us. Who owes the Medici money and might welcome a new friend. Or there's Capranica. He made himself visible deliberately. That was not accident.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Capranica. The Medici connection. The Dominican who wants something. Cardinal Orsini, if we can understand why he's suddenly cold. Or we wait. The papal audience is in three days. Perhaps the information will come to us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light shifts. Somewhere below, you hear the distant sound of your crusaders in the courtyard—the clink of harness, a burst of laughter. 591 men waiting to march to Constantinople, and you still don't know what the Pope will say when you kneel before him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets see if we can speak with anyone before the audience. Take care love, but if you can help me with this, I would appreciate it a lot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia nods, a flicker of determination crossing her features.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I'll try the Medici approach differently this time. Not asking about finances—asking about people. Cosimo's agent here deals with half the cardinals in Rome. He knows who owes money, who's ambitious, who might welcome a conversation with a king who has actual soldiers. And Capranica. He showed himself at Mass for a reason. Perhaps I send word that we noticed, and we're grateful for his... attention.

roll.outcome: Context Without Access: The Medici agent provides useful background but no direct contacts. Lucia learns: Eugenius is financially desperate; the French faction has 8-10 cardinals who oppose papal-Castilian ties; Cardinal d'Allemand in Basel has allies here; the Pope is interested in Juan but deeply cautious. Capranica sends brief, noncommittal acknowledgment. Juan enters knowing the landscape but not the Pope's mind.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia discuss their limited intelligence before the papal audience in three days. They decide to use the Medici banking connections to gather information about Vatican personnel and follow up on Cardinal Capranica's signal from Mass, seeking contacts who might provide insight into Pope Eugenius's intentions regarding the crusade and parallel legislation proposals.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia returns after dark, her face drawn with fatigue. She waves away the servant offering wine and sinks into the chair across from you, pulling off her gloves with deliberate care.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Context. Not access. But context.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She spent the afternoon with the Medici agent—a Florentine named Bardi who manages Cosimo's Roman interests. He received her graciously, served excellent wine, and spoke for two hours without ever quite answering a direct question. But Lucia knows how to listen to what isn't said.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: The Camera is in trouble. Real trouble. Bardi wouldn't say how bad, but the way he didn't say it told me enough. Eugenius has been Pope for three years and the treasury has bled the entire time. Milan's wars, the Colonna troubles, Basel draining his authority—and with it, his revenues. The annates reform decree? Bardi laughed when I mentioned it. Said if Basel's version passes, the Camera loses three-quarters of its income from benefices.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: The French. Eight to ten cardinals here are aligned with Cardinal d'Allemand in Basel. They send reports. Everything you do, everything we do—it reaches Basel within a week. Bardi says they've been... interpreting your arrival. A foreign king with 600 soldiers, marching on St. Peter's. They're not calling it piety. They're calling it pressure.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: And the Pope himself? Interested. Cautious. Bardi says Eugenius genuinely cares about Constantinople—it's not political theater for him. But he's been burned before. He trusted the Council at first, sent Cesarini as his legate, and then they declared themselves superior to him. He trusted Sigismund's mediation, and Como gave him nothing but delay. He's a man who wants to believe but has learned that belief costs him.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Parallel legislation. Bardi had heard of it—which means it's reached Rome through Basel correspondence. He said Eugenius hasn't rejected it outright. But he hasn't accepted it either. Bardi's sense is that the Pope is waiting to see what kind of man proposes it. Whether you're offering him a ladder out of a hole, or digging the hole deeper.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches into her sleeve and produces a small folded paper. The note is brief, written in a secretary's careful hand: His Eminence thanks the Queen of Castile for her gracious words and hopes that Providence will guide all servants of Christ toward understanding. He remains, as always, attentive to the needs of Holy Mother Church.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: He's interested. But he won't move before your audience. No one will. The entire Vatican is waiting to see what Eugenius does with you before they decide what they think.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: So. You enter your audience knowing the Pope is desperate, suspicious, genuinely devout, and surrounded by people telling him to fear you. You know the French are whispering. You know the money is bad. You know parallel legislation hasn't been rejected. You don't know what he'll say when you kneel before him. But you know what he's afraid of.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, we have been trying to speak to anyone of the vatican before the meeting. It has all come up dry. Do you think there is anything left we can do? I can visit St Paul's every day, hoping I meet someone.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Juan. Amore mio. The Vatican has answered us. We simply don't like the answer.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Every door we've knocked on has opened just enough to say wait. Orsini won't see us. The Camera clerk spoke and said nothing. Capranica sends polite words and no invitation. The Medici agent gives us context but no contacts. This is not failure. This is instruction. They are telling us: the Pope will see you in two days. Present yourself. Stop trying to go around him.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: If you go to St. Peter's every day, kneeling conspicuously, hoping someone important notices—what does that look like? A king who is anxious. A king who doesn't trust his own position enough to simply wait for his audience. The French faction is already whispering that you marched on St. Peter's to pressure the Holy Father. Do you want to give them more to whisper about?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: You completed the Reconquista. You brought 591 knights to fight for Constantinople. You carry letters from the Emperor. You have earned this audience. You don't need to scheme your way into the Pope's favor. You need to walk in there and be the man who wrote me that letter in Ferrara—the one who said he only ever set out to do good, and fight for what is right.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: What would Fray Hernando tell you? That God's timing is not ours to force?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Rest. Pray. Prepare what you will say. And trust that when you kneel before Eugenius, the truth of who you are will be enough.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know enough. Thank you for the clarity. I have things to do. Keep good rest love, I will be back later today. Captain! We ride to Ostia. Get a guard ready to come along with me.

roll.outcome: Constrained intelligence gathering - receives context through Medici agent about papal finances, French faction opposition, and Capranica's cautious interest, but no direct Vatican access before the audience

encounters.recap: Lucia's intelligence gathering through the Medici agent reveals crucial context about Pope Eugenius: the papal treasury is severely depleted, French cardinals are reporting to Basel and characterizing Juan's arrival as military pressure, and the Pope is cautious but hasn't rejected the parallel legislation proposal. Despite Juan's desire for more Vatican contacts, Lucia counsels patience, arguing that the consistent message to wait indicates the Pope himself will determine all outcomes at the upcoming audience.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: What would Fray Hernando tell you? That God's timing is not ours to force? Rest. Pray. Prepare what you will say. And trust that when you kneel before Eugenius, the truth of who you are will be enough.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know enough. Thank you for the clarity. I have things to do. Keep good rest love, I will be back later today. Captain! We ride to Ostia. Get a guard ready to come along with me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia blinks at your sudden pivot, mouth half-open to respond. But she knows you well enough by now. She closes her mouth, nods once, and the ghost of a smile crosses her face. She doesn't ask why. She doesn't try to stop you. She simply rises on her toes, kisses your cheek, and says: "Don't drown. I'm not raising these children alone."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles looks up from the game of dice he was losing to Sergeant García. His weathered face shows no surprise—he learned long ago that kings do not explain themselves. "Ostia, Your Majesty? Now?" The sun is already low. It's fifteen miles to the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You ride with twelve men—enough to discourage bandits, few enough to move fast. The Via Ostiense stretches before you, ancient stones worn smooth by a thousand years of traffic. The Tiber flows dark and slow to your left, carrying barges toward the sea. The air changes as Rome falls behind. Cooler. Cleaner. Salt on the wind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torches burn along the quay. Your fleet rides at anchor—ten ships, dark shapes against the moonlit water. The Princess Catalina sits proudest among them, the flagship you commissioned for this journey. The harbor watch recognizes your banner and word spreads fast.

exchanges.speaker: sebastian_de_morales
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We weren't expecting— The ships are ready. Whatever you need.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Greetings captain. I am here to conduct some naval exercises. I plan to conduct them from the Princess Catalina. It is already late. Can the captains of all the vessels be summoned to come aboard at this hour? Or is it prudent to wait until morning?

encounters.recap: After Lucia's counsel about approaching the Pope with truth rather than schemes, Juan abruptly decides to ride to Ostia to inspect his fleet. He arrives at night with twelve guards and announces plans for naval exercises from the Princess Catalina, asking Captain Morales about summoning the other ship captains.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The harbor watch recognizes your banner and word spreads fast. By the time you dismount, men are emerging from taverns and billets, pulling on clothes, straightening themselves. Not the 591 in Rome—these are the sailors, the ship's officers, the skeleton crews keeping the fleet ready. A grizzled figure pushes through the gathering crowd. Captain Sebastián de Morales, master of the Princess Catalina, veteran of the Málaga blockade. He bows stiffly—a sailor's bow, not a courtier's.

exchanges.speaker: sebastian_de_morales
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We weren't expecting— The ships are ready. Whatever you need.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The salt wind pulls at your cloak. The harbor water laps against the hulls. Your men stand waiting, uncertain why their king has ridden through the night to stand on a dark quay.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Greetings captain. I am here to conduct some naval exercises. I plan to conduct them from the princess Catalina. It is already late. Can the captains of all the vessels be summoned to come aboard at this hour? Or is it prudent to wait until morning?

exchanges.speaker: sebastian_de_morales
exchanges.text: Five captains are aboard their ships now, Majesty—night watch routine. The other five... Ashore. Taverns, billets. Sober, mostly—I've kept them on short leash since the Mistral. I can have runners fetch them within the hour. Faster if they haven't found comfortable company. As for exercises—depends what you have in mind. Signals, formations, sail handling—that wants daylight and sea room, not harbor at night. But if it's council you're after, getting the captains around a table to plan, talk through maneuvers before we execute them... That can happen whenever Your Majesty commands. The Catalina's great cabin has room enough. The men have had weeks of idleness, Majesty. Waiting in harbor while Rome decides things. A king who comes to drill them, who shows he remembers they exist—that's worth something. Whether tonight or dawn.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The actual naval exercises will be done tomorrow. The planning, we do this evening. Summon all the captains to the Catalina. You can have a rest. I will be with the fleet for the biggest part of tomorrow and will return tomorrow evening with you. You can take a rest until then.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Morales nods at your command. 'Aye, Majesty. All captains to the Catalina within the hour.' He turns and barks orders—runners scatter into the darkness toward the harbor-front buildings. Captain Fernán receives your dismissal with a slight frown—he doesn't love leaving you, even among your own fleet—but he knows better than to argue.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Tomorrow evening, then. We'll find billets here in Ostia. God keep Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The twelve guardsmen lead their horses toward the town's modest stable, their torches bobbing into the darkness. You're left on the quay with Morales and the salt wind. A longboat carries you across the black water to the Princess Catalina. She's beautiful even in moonlight—fresh timber, clean lines, the Castilian banner hanging limp at her stern. You commissioned her for this voyage. For Lucia. For Constantinople. The great cabin is smaller than a palace chamber but larger than any other ship could offer. A heavy table dominates the center, bolted to the deck. Charts already spread across it—the Italian coast, the route to Rhodes, the Aegean approaches. Morales lights lanterns while you wait. One by one, the captains arrive. Some neat, some rumpled from hasty waking. Ten men commanding ten ships—what remains of your expedition fleet after the Mistral took her toll. They file in, bow, find places around the table. Curious. Alert. A king who rides through the night to plan exercises is a king who takes his fleet seriously. When all ten are assembled, Morales closes the cabin door.

exchanges.speaker: sebastian_de_morales
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your captains.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you all for coming. I have an audience with the pope in two days. I may need a few days after that to wrap up business in Rome, afterwards we sail to Naples immediately. The storm has shook us all and I want to take some time tomorrow to prepare. If ever we are hit again by a storm, we know exactly what to do.

encounters.recap: Juan rides to Ostia Harbor at night to meet with his fleet captains aboard the Princess Catalina. He announces plans for naval exercises the following day to prepare for future storms, and informs them of the upcoming papal audience and departure to Naples.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One by one, the captains arrive. Some neat, some rumpled from hasty waking. Ten men commanding ten ships—what remains of your expedition fleet after the Mistral took her toll. They file in, bow, find places around the table. Curious. Alert. A king who rides through the night to plan exercises is a king who takes his fleet seriously. When all ten are assembled, Morales closes the cabin door.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your captains.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you all for coming. I have an audience with the pope in two days. I may need a few days after that to wrap up business in Rome, afterwards we sail to Naples immediately. The storm has shook us all and I want to take some time tomorrow to prepare. If ever we are hit again by a storm, we know exactly what to do. First of all. When we first saw the mistral, what actually happened on every ship? Did everyone knew what was going on? We used some flag signals. Did anyone actually see them and was it usefull?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cabin falls quiet. The lanterns sway gently with the harbor's slight motion, casting shifting shadows across weathered faces. You've asked the question no one wanted to revisit.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: The truth, Majesty? When the Mistral hit, every ship fought alone. That's not how it should be. That's how it was.

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: We saw the flags from the Catalina. The signal to form line and run southeast, away from the coast. We saw them. But by the time we read them, the squall was already on us. I had men fighting canvas, the helm bucking like a mule. I couldn't hold course to follow anyone. I did what I had to do to keep my ship alive.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Flag signals in a Mistral are like shouting across a battlefield when the cannons fire. Everyone's too busy staying alive to look up. It's not a failing of the men. It's a failing of the method. Flags need clear sky, calm sea, time to read and respond. A storm gives you none of that.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: We lost sight of each other within minutes. The rain came horizontal. Couldn't see the ship ahead, couldn't see the ship behind. I didn't know who'd survived until we limped into Cagliari two days later and started counting masts.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asked if the signals were useful. Honest answer: no. Not once the storm was on us. Maybe—maybe—if we'd had more warning, if we'd formed up before the weather turned, the signals might have kept us together. But once the wind hit...

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: There's another problem, Majesty. We've never drilled this. Not properly. Every captain in this cabin knows his own ship, knows how to fight a storm alone. But fighting a storm together? Keeping formation when the sea wants to scatter us? Knowing where to regroup if we lose sight? We've never practiced it. We assumed we'd figure it out when the time came. We figured it out. Seventy-five men paid for the lesson.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets focus our energy on being better prepared now. Was there a difference in the moment each ship realized that a storm was coming for us? That some had more time to react and prepare? And if there was a difference, what can we do to alert others in the future?

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: We saw the cloud bank first. Low on the horizon, moving fast—dark grey with that yellow tinge underneath. I've seen Mistrals before, sailing out of Valencia. I knew what it was maybe... ten minutes before it hit us? Ten minutes. Enough to get the men on deck, shorten sail, secure loose cargo. Not enough to do more than that.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: We had less. The Nuestra Señora was on the southern edge, closer to the coast. Sardinia blocked our view of the northwest. First warning I had was when the Santa Clara's sails started thrashing. Then the wind was on us. Five minutes, maybe. Men were still coming up from below when the first wave broke over the bow.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: I had a man in the crow's nest who's sailed the Gulf of Lion for twenty years. He called it before anyone. Saw the way the sea was changing—the chop getting shorter, angrier—before the clouds were even visible from the deck. He shouted down, I looked up, and I started giving orders. Fifteen minutes. Maybe more. We had time to rig lifelines, double-lash the boats, get every man who couldn't swim tied to something solid.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: And you lost how many?

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Three. Three men. Not eleven. Not fifteen.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: So the lesson is clear enough. The ships that saw it coming survived better. But seeing it coming depended on where you were in the formation, and whether you had a man aloft who knew what to look for.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_soria
exchanges.text: Not just aloft. Aloft and watching for weather, not watching for pirates or coastline. A dedicated weather eye. That's different from a normal lookout.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: So. We post weather watches. Experienced men, eyes on the horizon, looking for exactly this. That's one thing.

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: But that only helps the ship that sees it. How do we tell the others? I saw the Mistral coming, I started preparing my own ship—I didn't have time to signal anyone else. And even if I had, what signal? We have flags for 'enemy sighted' and 'form line' and 'follow me.' Do we have a flag for 'storm coming, prepare immediately'?

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: No. We don't.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Flags won't work anyway, not if the weather's already turning. You need something faster. Something you can't miss even if you're not looking.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: Cannon. One gun. Every captain knows: a single gun fired outside of battle means attend, something is wrong. Three guns in succession—that could mean storm warning. You hear cannon, you don't need to see anything. You react.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: Cheaper than seventy-five men.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: A dedicated weather watch with experienced eyes. A cannon signal for immediate danger—something every ship will hear regardless of visibility. And perhaps... a predetermined plan for what to do when we hear it. Not waiting for flag orders that may never come. Every captain knowing: if you hear three guns, you shorten sail, rig lifelines, secure cargo, and make for the nearest safe bearing. No waiting for instructions. What else would Your Majesty have us consider?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was thinking the same thing. As soon as we hear a cannon firing means all hands on deck anyway and to get ready. It could also mean actual combat but I think everyone will be able to determine what is going on. Before we depart on a major journey, we have a council with all captains so everyone knows where we are going, what to look for and what we could do when a storm hits us, what harbour we can take shelter in.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes his ten remaining ship captains to analyze the recent Mistral storm and develop better preparation protocols. The captains reveal that flag signals failed during the storm and ships with earlier warning suffered fewer casualties. They agree to implement dedicated weather watches, cannon warning signals, and pre-voyage planning councils to coordinate storm responses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The captains look at each other. A few grimace. Morales answers first. "The Catalina has four bombards. Small ones, but enough to make noise." He gestures around the cabin. "We're a flagship. We were built for a king."

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: The San Marcos carries two. Old, but they fire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One by one, the captains report. The picture that emerges is uneven: four ships carry nothing that can make the signal.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: We're transports, Majesty. Genoese contracts. They gave us hulls to carry men and horses, not to fight. I've got crossbows and some hand-gonnes for boarding defense. No bombards.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_pardo
exchanges.text: Same. We were never meant for battle.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: So four ships can't give the signal. And if they're the ones who see the storm first...

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: We could redistribute. Take one bombard from the Catalina, one from the San Marcos, put them on two of the unarmed ships. That leaves only two without.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_soria
exchanges.text: Or we assign the unarmed ships to positions in the formation where they'll never be the first to see weather coming. Keep them in the center, let the armed ships hold the edges.

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: There's another option. Horns. A ship's horn, blown in a pattern—three long blasts, say—carries almost as far as a cannon shot. Every ship has a horn. Every ship can make that signal.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: So we have choices, Majesty. Redistribute the guns we have. Rely on formation discipline to keep unarmed ships protected. Use horns as a secondary signal. Or we find four bombards in Rome or Naples before we sail for Constantinople, and make sure every ship can speak when it needs to.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will not redistribute cannons. And we keep the cannon shot as the signal to be alert. The carracks have the biggest masts dont they? Do they have a crow's nest?

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Aye, Majesty. The Catalina here, the San Marcos, the Santiago Apóstol, the Santa Clara—these are proper three-masted carracks. Crow's nests on the mainmast, thirty feet up or more. A man up there can see weather coming from leagues away, well before anyone on deck.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: It's why I saw the Mistral first on the San Marcos. Height. My man was looking down on the weather while the transports were still blind to it.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: So the carracks become our eyes. We position them at the edges of the formation—north, south, east, west. Transports in the center. The carracks watch the horizon, and when they see something...

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: The Catalina has the tallest mainmast in the fleet. If Your Majesty wants the sharpest eyes in the highest nest, this is the ship to carry them. The question is—do we keep the flagship in the center where she's protected, or put her on the edge where she can see?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have led many charges from the front, also in this case we do not hide behind others if we dare not do it ourselves. We put the Catalina at the head of the formation in the best position to spot anything coming our way. When we spot anything, we fire three cannons and this should alert every captain that a storm is coming. When a transport for example hears a shot, what are the first things they need to do?

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: First thing—all hands on deck. Every man, no exceptions. The ones below when the storm hits are the ones who drown when the hull breaches or the hatch seals them in. I had men still climbing up when the first wave took us. They never had a chance.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_pardo
exchanges.text: Shorten sail. Immediately. You hear that cannon, you don't wait to see how bad it is. You reef everything down to storm canvas or bare poles. A ship with too much sail up in a Mistral—the wind will roll you over or tear your masts out.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_lepe
exchanges.text: Secure cargo. Especially the horses. A panicked horse breaking loose below decks in heavy seas...

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Lifelines rigged bow to stern. Every man who can't swim—tied to something solid. Hatches secured but not sealed, you need to be able to get below if you must. Bilge pumps manned and ready.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_soria
exchanges.text: And know where you're going. Before the signal even comes. Every captain should know: if a storm hits here, I run there. Predetermined bearing toward safe harbor or open sea, whichever's wiser. No hesitation, no waiting for orders that won't come.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: So. Three guns from a carrack means: all hands on deck, shorten sail, secure cargo and horses, rig lifelines, man the pumps, and run your predetermined heading. That's six things. Every man on every ship needs to know all six, in that order. No thinking. Just doing. We could drill this tomorrow. Not a full storm drill at sea—but the preparation. Time each crew from cannon signal to ready-state. See who's fast, who's slow, who needs more practice.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will do so tomorrow. We will drill tomorrow by sailing to open sea, then a carrack will 'see a storm' and fire his cannons. We all get ready and sail back into Ostia harbour. What happens if we spot an enemy fleet? Could we adopt similar procedures for this?

encounters.recap: Juan holds a fleet council to establish storm warning procedures. The captains report their cannon capabilities, revealing four transport ships lack any artillery. They develop a system using the carracks as lookouts positioned at formation edges, with three cannon shots as the storm signal. Emergency procedures are established: all hands on deck, shorten sail, secure cargo, rig lifelines, man pumps, and follow predetermined bearings. Juan orders storm drills for the following day and considers adapting the system for enemy fleet encounters.

exchanges.speaker: francisco_morales
exchanges.text: So. Three guns from a carrack means: all hands on deck, shorten sail, secure cargo and horses, rig lifelines, man the pumps, and run your predetermined heading. That's six things. Every man on every ship needs to know all six, in that order. No thinking. Just doing. We could drill this tomorrow. Not a full storm drill at sea—but the preparation. Time each crew from cannon signal to ready-state. See who's fast, who's slow, who needs more practice. Make it a competition. Sailors love to prove their ship is better than the next.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will do so tomorrow. We will drill tomorrow by sailing to open sea, then a carrack will see a storm and fire his cannons. We all get ready and sail back into Ostia harbour. What happens if we spot an enemy fleet? Could we adopt similar procedures for this?

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: Storm and enemy require opposite responses, Majesty. Storm means shorten sail, scatter if you must, every ship fights to survive alone. Enemy means more sail, form up tight, strength in numbers.

exchanges.speaker: francisco_morales
exchanges.text: Different signal then. Three guns for storm. What for enemy? One gun has always meant attend—something's happening. Two guns could mean enemy sighted.

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: Two guns, then flags to show direction and size. We have flags for that already—compass bearing, number of sails. That part works, as long as the weather's clear enough to read them.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: The question is what happens next. With a storm, every captain knows what to do—we just agreed on the six steps. But enemy fleet? Do we fight? Do we run? Do we protect the transports and let the carracks engage?

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: Depends on the enemy. Ottoman war galleys? Genoese pirates? A French squadron that claims we're in their waters? Each demands something different.

exchanges.speaker: francisco_morales
exchanges.text: This is where the pre-voyage council matters most, Majesty. Before we sail, we agree: if we meet enemies in this stretch of water, we do this. The transports carry the men. Five hundred knights matter more than four carracks. If it comes to it, we buy time. That's what warships are for.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We do not expect to run into an enemy fleet of note on this journey. At least not while in Italian waters. We may drill this later. Tomorrow we focus on storm preparation. Is every captain able to sail out tomorrow? And participate in this exercise?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The captains glance at each other, taking stock. One by one, they report their readiness. Most are ready, though the Santa Clara needs rigging inspection, the San Vicente has men ashore on leave, and the Buenaventura has a leak below the waterline.

exchanges.speaker: cristobal_medina
exchanges.text: We're taking on water. Slow leak, somewhere below the waterline. My carpenter's been searching for two days. We can sail, but I wouldn't want to be caught in actual heavy weather until we find it and patch it properly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is an exercise. I think it is much more important that the Buenaventura gets repaired. We sail tomorrow without her. Make sure this leak is found and repaired. The rest will sail. We dont blame the San Vicente for getting some deserved rest. If they are a bit hung over, adds to the challenge. Imagine if they react the fastest despite this! Tomorrow, we sail out in formation. Carracks on the corners, transports in the middle. I will instruct someone in secret to spot a storm and when to shout it. This will start the procedure and exercise. We all pull down sails as fast as we can and turn about. A ship that has performed all work blows his horn. We then sail back to Ostia and give the fastest captain and his crew an extra round of drink. Any questions?

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: Who fires the signal, Majesty? The ship whose lookout spots the 'storm'? Or does he alert the flagship first and the Catalina fires?

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: The six steps—all hands, shorten sail, secure cargo, rig lifelines, man pumps, take heading—some take longer than others. When we blow the horn to signal completion, what's the standard? All six done? Or ready to weather the storm, even if the pumps aren't yet manned because there's no water coming in?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Look, as soon as someone spots a storm, one of the carracks should give the cannon signal as soon as possible. This signal need not be repeated by the other carracks. You blow the horn when all six steps are completed and your bow points at Ostia harbour. Transports stay in the middle. We sail tomorrow one hour after first light if you can manage it. This gives us some time to prepare. Questions?

exchanges.speaker: francisco_morales
exchanges.text: Clear enough. One hour after first light. That means crews roused at dawn, fed, and ready. No excuses.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. After the Mistral... Some of us wondered if we'd ever sail together again as a proper fleet. Wondered if we'd be scattered to different commands, or blamed for what happened. This—tonight—this is what we needed. A king who asks questions and listens to answers. A plan that makes sense. A chance to prove we've learned.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dismissed.

encounters.recap: Juan finalizes storm drill procedures with his captains, establishing cannon signals and response protocols. Nine ships will participate in tomorrow's exercise while the Buenaventura stays in port for repairs. The captains express renewed confidence in their king's leadership after recent setbacks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Laughter around the table. The tension of the evening has eased. These men came in uncertain why their king had ridden through the night to summon them. Now they know. They have purpose.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. After the Mistral... Some of us wondered if we'd ever sail together again as a proper fleet. Wondered if we'd be scattered to different commands, or blamed for what happened. This—tonight—this is what we needed. A king who asks questions and listens to answers. A plan that makes sense. A chance to prove we've learned.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Murmurs of agreement.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: If there's nothing else, Majesty, I'll dismiss the captains to their ships. They'll need sleep before dawn.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dismissed. I get to my cabin and get some sleep and arise tomorrow early.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The captains file out into the darkness, their voices fading as longboats carry them back to their ships. Within the hour, the harbor falls quiet save for the gentle creak of timber and rope. Morales shows you to your chambers—though 'shows' is generous, as you commissioned these rooms yourself. The king's cabin sits at the stern, windows looking out over the water. Not large by palace standards, but comfortable. The bed is built into the hull, padded with good Castilian wool, secured against the ship's motion. A writing desk, bolted down. A chest for clothes. A small altar with a crucifix—Lucia's touch, you recognize.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sheets smell faintly of cedar. New. Unused until now. You lie in the darkness, listening to the ship breathe around you. The lap of water against the hull. The distant call of a night watchman. So different from Rome's stone chambers, from the Vatican's watching eyes and closed doors. Tomorrow you drill your fleet. In two days you kneel before the Pope. In weeks, God willing, you sail for Constantinople. Sleep comes easier than it has in days.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A knock at the cabin door. Grey light through the stern windows.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Majesty. Half hour to first light. Coffee's hot. Wind's from the southwest, mild—good conditions for the exercise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rise, wash your face in the basin, dress simply. No crown today. No ceremony. Just a king and his fleet. On deck, the Catalina is already stirring. Men moving with purpose, checking lines, readying sail. Across the harbor, you can see lanterns on the other ships—nine crews preparing, just as ordered.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: The captains await your orders, Majesty. Which ship fires the signal, and when?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I get up as soon as possible and ask Morales how many men will be participating in this exercise.

encounters.recap: After dismissing his captains, Juan retires to his chambers aboard the Princess Catalina for his first night sleeping on his flagship. At dawn, he prepares for naval exercises with his fleet, asking about the number of participants as the ships ready themselves across the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Dawn, March 21, 1434. A knock at the cabin door. Grey light through the stern windows.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Majesty. Half hour to first light. Cook's got warm ale and bread ready. Wind's from the southwest, mild—good conditions for the exercise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rise, wash your face in the basin, dress simply. No crown today. No ceremony. Just a king and his fleet. On deck, the Catalina is already stirring. Men moving with purpose, checking lines, readying sail. Across the harbor, you can see lanterns on the other ships—nine crews preparing, just as ordered. Morales hands you a cup of warm ale.

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: Nine ships sailing today. The four carracks carry larger crews—the Catalina has sixty-two men, the others forty to fifty each. The transports run lighter, twenty-five to thirty-five. All told, Majesty? Perhaps three hundred and forty souls on the water today. Give or take a few nursing sore heads on the San Vicente. Plus yourself, Majesty. Three hundred and forty-one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The longboat carries you to the quay. Ostia at dawn is already stirring—fishermen mending nets, dockworkers preparing for the day's labor, a few bleary-eyed sailors stumbling back toward their ships from whatever beds they found ashore. You walk the harbor front in simple clothes, no crown, no banner. The first tavern you find is a low-slung building called La Sirena, its sign a faded painting of a woman with a fish's tail.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Kitchen's not open yet. Ale I can do. Food's another hour.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I'm not here to eat. I need drink. Ten casks. Wine or ale, whatever you have enough of. For my ships.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Ten casks. I've got ale. Local stuff, nothing fancy, but sailors don't complain. Wine—I could do five of red, maybe six. Not my best, but drinkable. You're with the Castilian fleet.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Ten casks, delivered to the quay within the hour. Half now, half on delivery.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Afternoon suits me fine. I'll have the casks ready and waiting. Just send your men to the back door—easier for loading. Fancy wine? In Ostia? You'll not find Tuscan vintages here, my lord. This is a harbor town. We serve sailors, not cardinals. There's Giacomo. Runs a warehouse two streets up, toward the old temple ruins. Imports goods for the Roman market—spices, cloth, some wine. He keeps a few barrels of the better stuff. Umbrian, mostly. Maybe some Orvieto if you're lucky. Tell him Maria sent you. Won't get you a better price, but he'll know you're not a thief.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you Maria. My sister has your name as well. Go with God and see you later today!

encounters.recap: Before the fleet exercise, Juan visits Ostia harbor at dawn to purchase provisions. He arranges to buy ten casks of drink from Maria at La Sirena tavern for pickup after the fleet returns, and receives directions to find Giacomo for better wine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You follow Maria's directions through Ostia's narrow streets. The town is modest—nothing like Rome's grandeur—but it has the honest bustle of a working port. The smell of salt and fish gives way to sawdust near the cooper's yard, then to something sweeter as you approach the old temple ruins. The blue door is faded but unmistakable. The building is larger than the surrounding structures—a proper warehouse, built of old Roman brick, likely standing since Caesar's time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You knock. A moment passes. Then the door opens a crack, and a thin face peers out—a young man, an apprentice perhaps. The apprentice hesitates, then opens the door wider after you mention Maria's name. He disappears into the dim interior. You catch glimpses of stacked crates, bolts of cloth, the gleam of amphorae. The smell of dust and dried herbs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A minute later, a different man emerges. Giacomo is perhaps fifty, olive-skinned, with the careful eyes of a man who weighs everything—goods, words, customers. He wears a merchant's practical clothes, but the fabric is good. Business has been kind to him. He looks you over the same way Maria did, but slower. More thorough.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo
exchanges.text: Maria sent you. You want wine. The good wine, not the sailor's swill she serves at La Sirena.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo
exchanges.text: I have Orvieto. Last year's vintage, from the bishop's own vineyard—don't ask how I got it. I have Umbrian red, smooth as velvet, the kind they serve in Roman palaces. I also have one barrel of Vernaccia from the Cinque Terre. Rare. Expensive. The sort of wine a man serves when he wants to be remembered. What are you looking for, and how much do you want to spend?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How much for the Umbrian red? I might be willing to buy it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Giacomo studies you for a moment, recalculating. A man who asks 'how much' before haggling over quality is either wealthy or in a hurry. Perhaps both.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo
exchanges.text: The Umbrian red. One barrel—proper size, not a half-cask—will run you eight florins. In Rome, a cardinal's steward would pay ten and consider it fair. I'm giving you the Ostia price because Maria sent you and because I'd rather move goods than guard them. It's good wine. Not the best I have—that would be the Vernaccia—but good. The kind you serve to men you respect. Smooth, not too sweet, holds up well in the cup.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes narrow slightly, still taking your measure.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo
exchanges.text: You're from the Castilian fleet. Eight florins for wine to celebrate something, yes? A victory? A voyage? None of my business. But if you want two barrels, I could do fifteen. Three for twenty-one.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I'll have the one for 8. I will send men to pick them up this afternoon. I am with the Castilian fleet.

encounters.recap: Juan purchases a barrel of quality Umbrian red wine from Giacomo, a merchant in Ostia Harbor, for eight florins. The transaction is for victory celebrations with the Castilian fleet, with pickup arranged for later that afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sun is cresting the horizon now, painting the harbor in shades of gold and pink. The fleet is alive with activity—sails being readied, anchors prepared for raising. You can hear the distant shouts of boatswains and the creak of rope through block and tackle. You hail a longboat and have them row you not to the Catalina, but to the San Marcos—Diego Fernández's ship. The grey-bearded veteran who lost only three men in the Mistral because his lookout knew what to look for. The crew of the San Marcos scrambles to attention as you come aboard. Diego Fernández himself emerges from below decks, still chewing a mouthful of breakfast bread. He swallows hastily and bows.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I hadn't expected— Welcome aboard the San Marcos. How can I serve?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I came here to perform an inspection. And to meet the man in your crows nest who spotted the storm first.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego Fernández's weathered face shows a flicker of surprise, then something like pride. He nods slowly.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Aye, Majesty. You'll want to meet Pascual. Pascual! Down here! Now!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A moment passes. Then a figure begins descending from the mainmast with the easy grace of a man who's spent more of his life aloft than on solid ground.
