He drops the last few feet to the deck and turns. Pascual is perhaps fifty, perhaps older—the sea ages men strangely. His face is leather-brown and deeply lined, his hands rope-scarred and strong. He's small and wiry, the build of a man who fits comfortably in a crow's nest. His eyes are the pale grey of a winter sky, and they meet yours without flinching. He doesn't bow. Perhaps he doesn't know how. Diego clears his throat meaningfully, and Pascual offers an awkward bob of his head.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: This is the man. Twenty-three years sailing the Gulf of Lion before he signed on with me. Knows the Mistral like a wife who's tried to kill him more than once. Tell His Majesty what you told me. What you saw before the storm hit.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: The sea tells you first. Before the clouds, before the wind. The waves get shorter. Choppier. They stop rolling and start fighting each other. Then the birds—they go quiet. Disappear. They know before we do. I've seen it enough times. Felt it in my knees, maybe. I called down to Captain Diego. He listened. Not every captain listens.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets go to the cannons. Are you prepared to fire them today? And who are your gunners?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego nods and gestures for you to follow. Pascual melts back toward the rigging—his place is aloft, not among kings and cannons. The San Marcos is a working ship, not a flagship, and it shows. The deck is clean but worn, the wood weathered by years of salt and sun. Diego leads you toward the ship's waist, where the guns are mounted.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: She's no Catalina, but she bites when she needs to. Bernardo! Tomás! Attend!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Two men approach. Bernardo is thick-necked and broad, with arms like anchor chains and powder burns on his forearms—old marks, the signatures of his trade. He moves with the careful economy of a man who works with things that can kill him. Tomás is younger, leaner, with quick eyes and nimble fingers. The experienced gunner and his apprentice, you'd wager. They bow—properly, unlike Pascual.

exchanges.speaker: bernardo
exchanges.text: Majesty. The guns are ready. Charged them at first light when we heard about the exercise. Blank charges, of course. No shot. Powder and wadding only.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Show His Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bernardo walks you through it—the powder stored in the magazine below, the wadding, the slow match kept burning in a covered tub, the firing procedure. His hands move over the gun with the unconscious familiarity of long practice.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How fast can you fire?

encounters.recap: Juan II inspects the San Marcos and meets Pascual, the experienced lookout who spotted the approaching Mistral storm. He examines the ship's cannons and crew, learning about their storm-warning methods and gun procedures from Captain Diego Fernández and his gunners.

exchanges.speaker: diego
exchanges.text: Show His Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bernardo walks you through it—the powder stored in the magazine below, the wadding, the slow match kept burning in a covered tub, the firing procedure. His hands move over the gun with the unconscious familiarity of long practice.

exchanges.speaker: bernardo
exchanges.text: Two guns, Majesty. Tomás and I work them both, but properly you want two men per gun—one to load, one to aim and fire. In battle, Captain Diego gives us two deck hands to assist. Tomás here has been with me four years. Knows enough not to blow us all to heaven.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tomás grins but says nothing.

exchanges.speaker: bernardo
exchanges.text: Safety. Powder stays below in the magazine until we need it. Sealed tight, away from spark or flame. Only I go down there—no lanterns, no metal tools that might strike a spark. We bring up charges one at a time in leather cartridges.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He points to a covered wooden tub nearby, a thin wisp of smoke curling from beneath the lid.

exchanges.speaker: bernardo
exchanges.text: Slow match. Stays lit, stays covered. Never near the powder. Never. I learned young what happens when you forget.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He walks you through the firing sequence: load powder, tamp wadding, aim, uncover the slow match, touch it to the vent, step back. The whole process takes perhaps a minute with a trained crew, he explains. Faster if you're not being careful. But careful keeps men alive.

exchanges.speaker: bernardo
exchanges.text: For today's exercise—three shots in succession for the storm signal, yes? We can do that in three minutes, maybe less. Reload between each shot. Tomás prepares the next charge while I fire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego stands with arms folded, watching his gunner with evident pride.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have an experienced crew captain. I give you my compliments.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The old lookout listens, his pale grey eyes fixed on yours. His weathered face betrays little, but you catch the slight shift in his posture—a straightening of the spine, a lift of the chin. He's been watching the sea for twenty-three years from the Gulf of Lion. He's called storms that saved ships. And now a king is asking him to start an exercise that will teach an entire fleet.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: One hour past zenith. I watch the sun, I know when. I shout Mistral, Bernardo fires the guns. The fleet learns. The other ships—they won't know it's coming from the San Marcos?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: They wont. Storms strike unexpectedly. We will see who reacts the quickest. They probably suspect I will signal it myself from the flagship or something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ghost of a smile crosses Pascual's weathered face—the first expression you've seen from him beyond stoic watchfulness.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: Good. A real storm doesn't announce which horizon it comes from.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances toward the Catalina across the harbor, where your flagship's crew scrambles in preparation.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: They'll be watching you, Majesty. Watching the flagship. Not watching the San Marcos.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The smile fades back into his usual granite expression, but something lingers in those pale eyes. Satisfaction, perhaps. Or the quiet pride of a man who has spent his life being overlooked, now trusted with something that matters.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: One hour past zenith. I'll be ready.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gives that same awkward bob of the head—his version of a bow—and turns to go back to his place in the rigging. Then he stops, half-turns.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: Majesty. The men who died in the Mistral. On the other ships. This—what you're doing—it's good. So more don't die.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He doesn't wait for a response. He's already climbing, hand over hand, back toward the crow's nest where he belongs.

encounters.recap: Juan assigns the crucial role of initiating the storm exercise to Pascual, the experienced lookout on the San Marcos. Pascual will shout the mistral warning one hour past zenith, prompting the cannon signals that will test the fleet's reaction time. The weathered sailor takes quiet pride in being trusted with this responsibility.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning passes pleasantly enough. Nine ships sail out of Ostia in loose formation, the carracks taking their positions at the corners, the transports clustering in the center. The southwest wind fills the sails gently. The sea is calm, almost glassy. Perfect conditions. Too perfect, perhaps. The men grow comfortable. Relaxed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One hour past midday. You watch the San Marcos. Nothing. Then—a distant shout, thin across the water. And three cannon shots in rapid succession, the sound rolling across the sea like thunder. For a heartbeat, nothing happens. Then chaos.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the Catalina, Morales reacts instantly—bellowing orders, sending men scrambling up the rigging. Your flagship's crew is the best in the fleet, and it shows. But even here, there's confusion. Men look toward you, toward Morales, toward the San Marcos—loss of precious seconds as they process that the signal came from somewhere unexpected.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Santiago Apóstol responds well—Luis de Córdoba runs a tight ship. But the Santa Clara hesitates, Gaspar de Vega's crew clearly caught off-guard, their attention on the flagship rather than the horizon. The transports are worse. The San Vicente—Alonso Pardo's ship with the hungover crew—moves like men wading through honey. On the Nuestra Señora, Rodrigo Ibáñez's ship, a horn blows. Too soon. Far too soon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet turns for Ostia. Eventually. The Catalina completes the six steps in just over seven minutes—not shameful, but not impressive. The San Marcos, naturally, finishes fastest—they knew it was coming—at just under six minutes. But the transports straggle. Eight minutes. Ten. Twelve. The San Vicente limps in at nearly fifteen, her crew moving like ghosts.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: It worked. The signal, the response, the six steps. It all happened. But ragged, Majesty. Very ragged. The carracks did well enough. The transports... They need more drilling. Much more.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: The good news: no one was hurt. No collisions. The Santa Clara's rigging held. And every captain now knows exactly where his crew failed. That knowledge cost us nothing but pride today. In a real Mistral, it would have cost lives.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: The drinks, Majesty. The San Marcos was fastest, but they knew the signal was coming. Do we reward them? Or the Santiago Apóstol, who matched them without foreknowledge?

roll.outcome: Ragged but Functional. The carracks perform adequately with seasoned crews. Transports struggle badly - San Vicente's hungover crew, premature horn signals, tangled lifelines. Fleet completes drill but scattered, not coordinated. Clear foundation exists but much more drilling needed.

encounters.recap: The fleet's first storm drill exercise reveals serious coordination problems. While the carracks perform adequately, the transports struggle with confused signals, hungover crews, and equipment failures. Completion times range from six to fifteen minutes, and the formation dissolves during the return to Ostia. No injuries occur, but the exercise exposes the fleet's unpreparedness for real emergencies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Morales stands beside you at the rail, watching the last ships anchor. His face is carefully neutral, but you can read the disappointment in the set of his shoulders.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: It worked. The signal, the response, the six steps. It all happened. But ragged, Majesty. Very ragged. The carracks did well enough. The transports... They need more drilling. Much more.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: The good news: no one was hurt. No collisions. The Santa Clara's rigging held. And every captain now knows exactly where his crew failed. That knowledge cost us nothing but pride today. In a real Mistral, it would have cost lives.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: The drinks, Majesty. The San Marcos was fastest, but they knew the signal was coming. Do we reward them? Or the Santiago Apóstol, who matched them without foreknowledge?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, the fleet is moored and the captains are rowing across to the Catalina. They file into the great cabin one by one, the same room where you met last night. But the mood is different now. Last night was planning, possibility, theory. Now they've seen the reality.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You catch Pascual's arm before he enters the cabin, drawing him aside into the narrow passage. When you're alone, Pascual meets your eyes with that same steady grey gaze.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: Bernardo. The gunner. I had to tell him to listen for my shout. Otherwise he's watching the horizon like everyone else, not watching me. The signal doesn't fire fast enough. I told him nothing else. Not when. Not why me. Just: 'When I shout Mistral, you fire. Don't wait, don't ask, just fire.' He thought I'd gone mad. But he's worked with me six years. He trusts my eyes.

exchanges.speaker: pascual
exchanges.text: Captain Diego, the rest of the crew—they knew nothing. When I shouted, they scrambled like everyone else. Maybe half a breath faster, because they heard my voice above them instead of cannon across the water. But they didn't know.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captains! What an afternoon! So not everything went smoothly but this is exactly why we do these exercises, so we find what we can improve. This man here is Pascual. I have told him and only him that he was to give the signal. The rest of his ship knew nothing. They deserve the prize for the fastest ship today because they were also burdened with having to fire the cannons as well which they performed impeccably.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: Pascual shouted. Bernardo fired. The rest of us scrambled like everyone else. We were fast because we've drilled before—not this exact exercise, but storm preparation. My crew knows what 'all hands' means. Six minutes. We can do better. The pumps were manned last—that's the wrong order if we're actually taking water. We'll fix it.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: We matched the San Marcos without knowing the signal was coming. I'll take that. But we got lucky. My lookout happened to be watching northwest when the guns fired. He saw the smoke, shouted down before the sound even reached us. If he'd been looking the other way... We need dedicated weather watches, like we discussed. A man whose only job is watching the horizon. I didn't have one today. I will tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: gaspar_de_vega
exchanges.text: The rigging held. That's the good news. The bad news—we hesitated. My crew was watching the Catalina, waiting for your signal, Majesty. When the cannon came from the San Marcos, there were three or four seconds where everyone just... looked at each other. Three or four seconds. In a real storm, that's men dying. We need to drill the response until it's automatic. Until my men don't think, they just move.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: We blew the horn early. That was my fault—I gave the order. I thought we'd completed the six steps. We hadn't. The pumps weren't manned. I was so focused on being fast that I forgot to be right. It won't happen again, Majesty. I've already told my crew: we run through the checklist out loud. Every step, called and confirmed. No horn until every man reports ready.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_soria
exchanges.text: We were middling. Not the fastest, not the slowest. No disasters, no glory. Our problem was cargo. We'd stowed some barrels this morning without thinking about quick access to the lashings. Took us an extra two minutes to secure what should have taken thirty seconds. From now on, we stow with the storm in mind, not just with space in mind.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_pardo
exchanges.text: Fifteen minutes. Worst in the fleet. My men were not fit for duty. That's my responsibility. I let them go ashore, I let them drink, I assumed they'd recover by morning. They didn't. Half of them couldn't climb the rigging without stopping to retch. One man fell—caught himself on a line, but it could have been worse. No more shore leave the night before we sail. Ever. And any man who reports unfit for duty answers to me personally.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_lepe
exchanges.text: The lifelines. God above, the lifelines. They were stored properly, coiled and ready. But when we went to rig them, they'd gotten tangled with another line overnight. Someone was careless. Two of my men spent four minutes sorting rope while everyone else waited. We've changed the storage. Lifelines go in their own chest now, nothing else. And I've got the man who was careless splicing rope until his fingers bleed.

exchanges.speaker: francisco_ruiz
exchanges.text: The horses. You all heard them. They felt the crew's urgency and spooked. Once one started, they all started. My men couldn't get close enough to secure them without risking a kick to the skull. We need a different approach. Hobbles on before we leave harbor, not after the signal. Hoods for the nervous ones. And handlers who stay with them throughout the voyage, so they're calm around familiar hands. Horses on ships are always trouble, Majesty. But we can make them less trouble with preparation.

exchanges.speaker: captain_morales
exchanges.text: Seven minutes. Not shameful, but not what this ship should do. We're the flagship. We should set the standard. We didn't. Crew was watching you, Majesty, not the horizon. When the signal came from elsewhere, they looked to me for confirmation before acting. That hesitation cost us. We also had men below who didn't hear the first gun—only came up after the third. Our internal signals need work. Tomorrow, we drill again. Just the Catalina, at anchor. Signal to ready-state, over and over, until my men can do it in their sleep.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So we all know what to do. What to work on. Let the men have some rest, we won't sail away today or tomorrow, so they can have a deserved drink.

encounters.recap: Juan debriefs his fleet captains after the storm readiness exercise, confirming that only Pascual knew the signal timing. Each captain honestly reports their ship's performance and failures, from the San Marcos's six-minute success to the San Vicente's fifteen-minute disaster due to hungover crew. Juan decides to grant shore leave for rest and improvement before the next drill.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cabin falls quiet. Nine reports. Nine honest assessments. Nine sets of lessons learned. The afternoon light has shifted to gold. The ale on the table remains untouched. The captains wait for your response.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let the men have some rest, we wont sail away today or tomorrow, so they can have a deserved drink. I have arranged something to drink for the men. And a special barrel of wine for the fastest ship in the fleet. I will have it delivered on board shortly. Any questions?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ripple of surprise passes through the cabin. They expected criticism, perhaps harsh words for the ragged performance. Instead—drinks for everyone and a prize for the winners.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: The San Marcos is grateful, Majesty. The men will drink to your health tonight.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: When do we sail for Naples, Majesty? So we know how much time we have to drill before departure.

exchanges.speaker: alonso_pardo
exchanges.text: And... will there be another exercise before we leave? My men owe the fleet a better showing than today.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_ibanez
exchanges.text: The transports could use another run, Majesty. Now that we know what went wrong.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets take today and tomorrow to rest and finish up repairs. If our final ship is also ready, we can do another exercise. I will be in Rome the coming days but you are free to do another exercise. I think it's good for morale if we can also have an exercise that goes very well. And give the men something to drink afterwards like today. Gives them a reason to work and perform. And buy a good barrel for the winner or course. A good tradition. Questions?

exchanges.speaker: morales
exchanges.text: I'll coordinate the exercise if the Buenaventura is ready, Majesty. And I'll see to the drinks. Should I draw from the fleet's funds, or...?

exchanges.speaker: cristobal_medina
exchanges.text: My carpenter and yours have been working all day, Captain Morales. They believe they've found the sprung plank. If the repair holds overnight, we can test her tomorrow morning. I'd... very much like to participate in the next drill.

exchanges.speaker: diego_fernandez
exchanges.text: If we drill again without Your Majesty, who fires the signal? And from which ship? Same trick won't work twice—the men will be watching every crow's nest now.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have a casket for every ship, including Buenaventura. And I have a cask set aside for the winner of some good wine. Give it with my compliments. I will leave the next test to you, you can arrange for another way to get the signal. You can do it one hundred different ways, good luck! We have a few days yet. I will return to Rome now and will see you when we are about to leave.

encounters.recap: After the fleet exercise debrief, Juan rewards all ships with drinks and establishes a tradition of giving wine to the best-performing vessel. He authorizes the captains to conduct another drill while he's in Rome, delegating command to Morales and encouraging them to devise new signaling methods for future training.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ride takes longer in darkness. By the time you pass through Rome's gates, the city's churches are ringing Compline. The streets are quiet, lit by occasional torches, the great ruins casting deeper shadows against the night sky. The guards at the Palazzo recognize your party and wave you through without challenge. A groom takes your horse. The courtyard is still, most of the household already abed. But light flickers in the window of your chambers. You climb the stairs two at a time. The door opens before you reach it—Lucia must have heard your boots on the stone. She stands in the doorway in a simple sleeping gown, a shawl pulled around her shoulders against the March chill. Her dark hair is loose, unpinned for the night.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks you over once—dusty from the road, smelling of salt and horse and honest sweat—and something in her face relaxes. Relief, perhaps. Or simply the comfort of having you back.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You went to the sea. Not a question. She can smell it on you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She steps aside to let you enter. A single candle burns on the table, alongside a plate of bread and cheese—she waited up, had food ready in case you returned hungry.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Catalina asked for you at bedtime. I told her Papa was visiting the ships. She informed me that she wants to visit the ships too. Apparently horses are no longer sufficient.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She settles into a chair, watching you, waiting to hear what you've been doing while she navigated the treacherous waters of Roman gossip and Medici bankers.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I take off my sweaty clothes and tell about what I have been doing. And that I plan to rest tonight before I meet the pope tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia listens as you shed the day's dust and salt. A servant brings warm water for washing; you wave away offers of a full bath. Tonight, simple will do. She sits curled in her chair, feet tucked beneath her, the shawl pulled close. Her grey-green eyes follow you as you move about the chamber, stripping off the riding clothes, splashing water on your face and arms. When you describe the captains' council—the honest accounting of failures, the discussion of signals and storm preparation—she nods slowly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You gave them a way to speak of the Mistral without shame. That's harder than it sounds. Men who lose comrades... they either bury it or drown in it. You gave them something else. A way to make the deaths mean something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At the mention of Pascual—the old lookout who called the storm, who kept your secret—she smiles faintly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Every fleet needs men like that. Men who watch while others sleep. I hope you remember his name.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you tell her about the prizes—the casks for every ship, the Umbrian red for the winners—she laughs softly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The Ferrarese way. My uncle always said: 'A man fights for duty, but he runs for wine.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises as you finish washing, crosses to you, and rests her hand briefly on your chest. The skin is cool against your damp skin.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You needed this. The ships, the sea, something real after days of closed doors and whispers. You look more like yourself than you have since we arrived in Rome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She steps back, gestures toward the bed.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sleep. Tomorrow you kneel before the Pope. And tomorrow, amore mio, you cannot solve the problem with cannons and wine.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Rome from inspecting his fleet at Ostia and reunites with Lucia at the Palazzo di San Marco. She has waited up for him with food, and they share an intimate evening as he tells her about his day with the naval captains. Lucia offers wise counsel about his leadership and warns him that tomorrow's papal audience will require different skills than commanding ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You sleep deeply, dreamlessly—the exhaustion of a day at sea, the clarity of honest work. When you wake, grey dawn light filters through the shutters. Lucia is already up, seated at the small table, reviewing something. She glances over as you stir. "The summons came at first light," she says. "The Holy Father will receive you at the tenth hour."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Three hours. Time enough to prepare. Servants bring breakfast—bread, cheese, olives, watered wine. You eat without tasting, your mind already moving ahead. Lucia helps you dress: not armor, not the crusader's white, but the formal attire of a Christian king. Dark velvet doublet, the Castilian arms embroidered at the breast. A gold chain of office. Your sword—ceremonial, but present. You are a king come to treat with the Vicar of Christ, not a penitent come to beg.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando arrives as you finish dressing. He looks tired—he has been praying, you suspect, much of the night. "Your Majesty." He studies your face. "Are you ready?" The question has layers. Ready for the ceremony, yes. Ready for whatever Eugenius will demand, will offer, will withhold? That remains to be seen. Lucia adjusts your collar, a wifely gesture that settles something in your chest. "Remember what we learned," she says quietly. "He's desperate. He's cautious. He's been burned before." Her grey-green eyes meet yours. "Show him you're different."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk to the Vatican is short but weighted. You bring only Fray Hernando and four guards—enough for dignity, not enough to threaten. The papal guards admit you through the bronze doors. A chamberlain in red robes leads you through corridors you remember from your first visit—was it only a year ago? The marble saints watch from their niches. The air smells of incense and old stone. Finally, a set of doors. The chamberlain announces you: "His Most Catholic Majesty, Juan the Second, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber beyond is smaller than you expected—not the great audience hall but a private reception room. Tapestries on the walls, a fire burning low, windows looking out over Rome. A throne-like chair at one end, but not the formal papal throne. And there, rising from that chair as you enter: Pope Eugenius IV. He is perhaps fifty, thin-faced, with deep-set eyes that have seen too much disappointment. He wears simple white robes—no tiara, no ceremonial vestments. This is a private audience, then. Intimate. The kind where real things might be said.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Two figures flank him: a secretary with quill and parchment, and—your eyes catch—Cardinal Capranica, standing quietly to one side. The cardinal who caught your eye at Mass. Who murmured that the Pope was watching. Eugenius extends his hand, the Fisherman's Ring glinting.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Fili dilecte. Beloved son. We have waited with great anticipation to speak with the king who completed what seven centuries could not.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father, I have returned after having visited Basel. Much has been done already but much work remains. I seek to learn first about how your holyness has been faring before I can determine how I can dedicate myself to help the church.

encounters.recap: Juan prepares for his papal audience, dressing as a Christian king rather than penitent. He meets Pope Eugenius IV in private chambers with Cardinal Capranica present. Juan kneels and diplomatically inquires about the Pope's wellbeing before offering his service to the Church.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father, I have returned after having visited Basel. Much has been done already but much work remains. I seek to learn first about how your holyness has been faring before I can determine how I can dedicate myself to help the church.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius's expression softens—slightly. The deep-set eyes remain watchful, but the initial guardedness recedes a fraction.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He comes forward himself, takes Juan's arm with thin but steady fingers, guides him to stand. It's a gesture of respect, if not warmth. The Fisherman's Ring catches the light from the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask how We fare. We shall tell you: We fare better this week than last. Do you know why?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He doesn't wait for an answer.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Because a king who completed the Reconquista has brought six hundred knights to Rome and knelt before Us asking how he might serve the Church. This is... not nothing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He settles into his seat now, gestures for Juan to take the chair opposite. It's placed facing the papal chair directly—a conversation between near-equals, not a supplicant before a throne. Cardinal Capranica shifts position, moving closer. The secretary's quill hovers over parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have heard reports from Basel. We know of Como. We know you signed declarations with the Emperor. We know you addressed the Council, that you spoke of reforms, that the Castilian delegation has become—influential among the moderate voices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A longer pause. Those deep-set eyes study Juan's face.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We also know that you have tried to walk a middle path. Between Us and the Council. Between authority and reform. Between those who would make the Pope a figurehead and those who would make reform impossible.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans back slightly, fingers steepled.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Middle paths are treacherous, beloved son. They satisfy no one and anger everyone. The French whisper that you are Rome's creature. Rome wonders if you have been seduced by Basel's promises. You cannot serve two masters. Scripture is clear on this point.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fire crackles. Outside, Rome's bells mark the hour.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tell Us—do you still believe such a path is possible? Or has Basel taught you otherwise?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There are many different ways you can look at our church, not just as a divide between papal and council parties. You can also divide the church in terms of culture, such as the french, Iberian, German... There are those of rigorous faith and those more lenient. The church is as diverse as it is enormous. And it is my firm belief that we should unite in one single church and there should be a place for almost everyone. Frenc, Germans, rigorous, and lenient, all aspects of our faith that indicate that men are different from one of another. How we can achieve this, that is indeed the difficult middle path you mentioned. I have often thought back to our first meeting where you expressed the desire to reform the church. Im sure you have heard of paralell legislation and how this principle will allow reform to proceed without papal authority bowing down to the council. Basel has passed reforms, has our holiness have had time to review these decrees?

roll.outcome: Cautious Interest: Eugenius softens slightly, acknowledges Juan's completed Reconquista and arrival with knights, but probes his loyalty regarding Basel and middle path strategy.

encounters.recap: Juan kneels before Pope Eugenius asking how he might serve the Church after visiting Basel. The Pope shows cautious interest, acknowledging Juan's credentials but questioning his middle path strategy between papal and conciliar authority, ultimately challenging whether such a position is sustainable.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We also know that you have tried to walk a middle path. Between Us and the Council. Between authority and reform. exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There are many different ways you can look at our church, not just as a divide between papal and council parties. You can also divide the church in terms of culture, such as the French, Iberian, German... There are those of rigorous faith and those more lenient. The church is as diverse as it is enormous. I have often thought back to our first meeting where you expressed the desire to reform the church. Basel has passed reforms, has our holiness have had time to review these decrees?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Parallel legislation. We have heard this term. From Basel. From the Emperor's letters. Now from you. You propose that We independently promulgate the same reforms that Basel has passed. That We claim them as Our own initiative rather than Council decree. That both authorities take credit, neither bows to the other. A elegant solution. On parchment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back, silhouetted against the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But tell Us, beloved son—if Basel passes a decree in September, and We pass the identical decree in April, who does Christendom believe truly authored the reform? The Council that acted first? Or the Pope who... followed? You ask if We have reviewed Basel's decrees. We have. Pluralism. Annates. Concubinage. Much of it is... reasonable. Even necessary. But how reform comes matters as much as what reform comes. If We simply sign what Basel has already written, We become a notary. A clerk who stamps documents prepared by others. Explain to Us how this is not surrender with better rhetoric.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The council has been unexpectedly productive. They have been able to agree on many subjects, much more so than I thought possible. Since the council passed many reforms already, if Rome passes the same reforms as well, the impression can indeed be made that Rome follows Basel. I must confess that I did not expect this. I had hoped that both entities could pass some reforms and could demonstrate that they could both sign each other's decrees. I agree with you that the reforms themselves are good. Looking at just the church and how it should be reformed, we should be signing them today. If your holiness agrees with me, but only has reservations about authority, we should now seek a way to reform the church while maintaining papal authority.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You confess you did not expect this. That Basel moved faster than you anticipated. We find your honesty... refreshing. Most who come before Us have answers for everything. You admit to miscalculation. You say We should seek a way to reform while maintaining papal authority. Yes. Obviously. But how? You speak in principles. We must act in specifics. Basel has passed decrees on pluralism, on annates, on concubinage. The ink is dry. The documents are being copied and sent across Christendom as we speak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If We sign identical decrees tomorrow, We follow. If We refuse to sign, We appear to oppose reform itself—which We do not. If We modify the decrees, We invite endless negotiation about which version holds force. Basel will claim theirs is superior because the Council is superior. We will claim Ours. Christendom will have two sets of laws and obey neither. You have come with 600 knights, with letters from the Emperor, with the moral weight of Granada behind you. You have not come empty-handed, and you have not come without purpose. So speak plainly, King Juan. What specifically do you propose We do? And what do you want in return for helping Us do it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What we could do, is we sign the reforms everyone agrees on. Pluralism for example and concubinage, maybe some other decrees as well. And then immediately and without delay start enforcing these decrees. Start enforcing the concubinage decree in France for example and demand the French to cooperate and in effect bow down to your authority. The council has already passed the decree so they have no other choice than to defer to your judgement. This creates equality and demonstrates Rome holds authority. Secondly, pass a decree yourself the council has not addressed. Choose a subject no-one can object to and request the council to pass the decree as well. If they don't it will make them look like extremists who use politics to advance their own positions. The more decrees are passed by both sides using this system, the more the council loses in significance. We can start sending Italian delegates as well until the council is simply not relevant anymore.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to Pope Eugenius for resolving the Basel crisis through parallel legislation and strategic enforcement. While acknowledging that Basel moved faster than expected, Juan outlines a two-part plan: first, Rome should adopt and actively enforce Basel's uncontroversial reforms to demonstrate papal authority in implementation; second, Rome should initiate new reforms that Basel must then follow, gradually diminishing the Council's relevance through strategic maneuvering and Italian delegate participation.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If We sign identical decrees tomorrow, We follow. If We refuse to sign, We appear to oppose reform itself—which We do not. And then immediately and without delay start enforcing these decrees. Start enforcing the concubinage decree in France for example and demand the french to cooperate and in effect bow down to your authority. The council has already passed the decree so they have no other choice than to defer to your judgement. This creates equality and demonstrates Rome holds authority. Secondly, pass a decree yourself the council has not adressed. Choose a subject no-one can object to and request the council to pass the decree as well. If they don't it will make them look like extremists who use politics to advance their own positions. The more decrees are passed by both sides using this system, the more the council loses in significance. We can start sending Italian delegates as well untill the council is simply not relevant anymore.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You propose that We sign decrees, enforce them across hostile territories, issue counter-decrees, flood Basel with delegates—a comprehensive campaign requiring years of effort and substantial resources. And you have not yet mentioned what Castile receives in return. We have learned, beloved son, that gifts freely offered are never free. The Emperor offered mediation and produced Como—which bound Us to nothing and gave Basel legitimacy. Now you offer strategy. What is the price beneath the wrapping? Speak it plainly, or We shall assume the worst.

roll.outcome: Suspicious Probing - Pope demands clarification on Juan's true intentions and price

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to outmaneuver Basel: sign agreed reforms immediately, enforce them aggressively to demonstrate papal authority, then issue papal decrees forcing Basel to follow. Pope Eugenius responds with deep suspicion, demanding to know Juan's true price and comparing him to the Emperor's failed mediation at Como.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius listens. His face remains impassive throughout—no nods of agreement, no sharpening of interest. When Juan finishes, the Pope does not respond to the strategy at all. Instead, silence stretches.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You propose that We sign decrees. Enforce them across hostile territories—France, no less. Issue counter-decrees. Flood Basel with Italian delegates until the Council withers. A comprehensive campaign. Years of effort. Substantial resources. Political capital spent across Christendom. And you have not yet mentioned what Castile receives in return.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have learned, beloved son, that gifts freely offered are never free. The Emperor offered mediation at Como. He spoke of cooperation, of bridges between Rome and Basel, of shared purpose. And what did Como produce? A declaration that bound Us to nothing and gave Basel legitimacy to continue. Words. Paper. Nothing that cost Sigismund anything.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Now you come. With knights. With letters. With strategies that sound reasonable and cost you nothing to propose. You speak of enforcing decrees in France—but Castilian swords will not march on Paris. You speak of flooding Basel with delegates—but Castile has already positioned itself as a moderate voice there, which serves your interests regardless of what We do. What is the price beneath the wrapping, King Juan? What does Castile want that you have not yet named? Constantinople support? We expected that. What else? Naples recognition for your ally Alfonso? Permanent administration of your Military Orders? A cardinal's hat for someone in your household? Speak it plainly. All of it. Or We shall assume the worst—that you seek to make the Pope of Rome dependent on Castilian strategy while appearing to serve the Church.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Father, I come before you as a christian king. Castille owes it's entire existance to Christianity and the church. In that case the fate of the church and Castille are intertwined. Crusades have formed my kingdoms and has given me and my fathers so much purpose. We would be nothing without our faith and we would have not been able to unite without the church. I seek no monetary support, no position for a bishop, no recognition of claims. The fact alone that there exists a strong and unified church is of enormous importance to me and my kingdom. But there is also another matter that makes me want a unified church father, and that reason is more personal. I have a strong personal belief that the church is of enormous benefit, not just to my kingdom but to any kingdom. Farmers being called to mass by church bells all across the lands fills my heart with joy. To know God is being praised, confessions are being taken. To know we all lift one another up to live fulfilling lives in service. It is all I want, what I am fighting for and strikes me in my very core. I dont need the church to endorse my crusade and aid me in my aid to Constantinople, I have already pledged the aid. But even I cannot defeat the Ottomans alone and I see no world where all christians unite to fight without a strong church.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises from his chair. For a moment he simply stands there, looking at Juan. Then he turns—not to the window, but to Cardinal Capranica.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Domenico. Leave Us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cardinal hesitates only a moment longer. Then he bows—deep, formal—and withdraws. The secretary gathers his parchment and quill with trembling hands, following without being told. The heavy door closes behind them. The Pope and the King are alone. Eugenius moves closer. Not to the window, not to his chair—to Juan. He stops an arm's length away, and when he speaks, his voice is barely above a whisper.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We are going to say something We have not said to anyone. Not to Our cardinals. Not to Our confessors. Not even in the silence of Our own prayers, because We feared God would hear and judge Us for it. We have been losing Our faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words seem to cost him something physical. His shoulders bow slightly, as if a weight has been lifted and a greater one placed in its stead.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Not in God. Never in God. But in the Church. In whether she can be saved. Whether she is worth saving. Basel calls Us corrupt. Perhaps they are right. The Camera is empty. The cardinals scheme—even the loyal ones scheme, they simply scheme in Our favor. Rome itself is held together with prayers and threats and the memory of what it once meant.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: For three years We have been told that We are a tyrant. An obstacle to reform. That the Church would flourish if only We would yield, or abdicate, or die. For three years We have defended the authority of Peter's throne, and We no longer remember if We defend it because it is sacred or because surrendering would mean admitting they were right about Us. And then you come. Speaking of church bells. Of farmers gathering for Mass. Of confessions and purpose and the joy of knowing God is praised across the land. Do you know how long it has been since anyone spoke to Us of why the Church exists? Everyone speaks of what she controls. What she costs. What she forbids. No one speaks of what she gives.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He grips Juan's arm—not as Pope to supplicant, but as a man reaching for something solid in dark water.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know if you are the answer to Our prayers or the most dangerous man We have ever met. We do not know if this is Providence or the most sophisticated manipulation ever attempted against the Holy See. We do not care. Tell Us everything, King Juan. Constantinople. The Ottomans. The reforms. What you need, what you fear, what you hope to build. We are listening—not as Pope to king, not as authority to supplicant—but as one Christian to another. As a man who has forgotten why he became a priest, speaking to a man who seems to remember why he became a king.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases Juan's arm. Steps back. The mask of the papacy lies somewhere on the floor between them, and the man beneath stands exposed.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Help Us remember, Juan of Castile. Help Us believe the Church is worth saving. And We will give you whatever is in Our power to give.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But father! The church has always been worthy! We as men fail. We fear sometimes before we remember that stepping forward into the light is scary because it exposes us, shows everyone we are not perfect. But it also sets us free. The church itself is holy, it are the men who sin. We all know this and we fear that speaking this aloud, lets others think that the church sins as well. But this is not true. I would say we should sign all decrees passed by Basel and one of our own as well. And start enforcing them immediately. The scism must have drained the coffers of the camera, we should immediately start collecting again. I have no access to the camera itself, but I suspect that a decree properly enforced could actually increase the amount of income the camera recieves.

roll.outcome: Genuine Connection - The Pope reveals his deepest spiritual crisis, admits to losing faith in the Church, and opens himself completely to Juan's vision.

encounters.recap: Confronted about his true motives, Juan delivers an impassioned declaration of pure faith, speaking of church bells and farmers at Mass. The Pope initially remains skeptical, but after rolling 93 on the response table, experiences a profound emotional breakthrough. He dismisses all attendees, confesses he has been losing faith in the Church itself, and opens himself completely to Juan as one Christian to another, offering whatever aid is in his power.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not care. Tell Us everything, King Juan. Constantinople. The Ottomans. The reforms. What you need, what you fear, what you hope to build. We are listening—not as Pope to king, not as authority to supplicant—but as one Christian to another. As a man who has forgotten why he became a priest, speaking to a man who seems to remember why he became a king.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii

The church itself is holy, it are the men who sin. We all know this and we fear that speaking this aloud, lets others think that the church sins as well. But this is not true.
