These are good reforms—necessary reforms—but they will cost the Camera dearly. If we also cancel existing obligations and debts, we must understand what remains. The answer may be: almost nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should not cancel existing obligations just yet. First, lets look at the expenses side of the camera. You told me that the salaries of the camera scribes are a few thousand a year. Surely, the camera has other expenses?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The expenses. Yes. This is where the money goes, and it reveals much about why the Camera is always empty. The clerical salaries I mentioned—eight to twelve thousand florins—are actually among the more defensible expenses. Scribes must be paid. Notaries must be paid. The work of the Church requires administration.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But beyond salaries, the expenses multiply. First: The Papal Household. His Holiness must be fed, clothed, housed, and attended. The apostolic palace requires servants—cooks, cleaners, stewards, grooms. The papal chapel requires chaplains, singers, musicians for ceremonies. There are physicians, confessors, secretaries for personal correspondence.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Holiness lives more simply than your predecessors. This is known. But even a modest papal household consumes fifteen to twenty thousand florins annually. A immodest household— Martin V spent nearly twice that. And he was considered restrained compared to the Avignon popes.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second: The Sacred College. Cardinals receive subsidies from the Camera. Not all of them—those with wealthy benefices need nothing. But cardinals in curia—those residing in Rome, attending to Church business—receive allowances for housing, servants, and maintenance appropriate to their dignity.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It varies by cardinal and by what they can negotiate. Some receive a few hundred florins. Others, thousands. In total? Perhaps twenty to thirty thousand florins annually flows to the College in direct subsidies. And this does not count the indirect benefits—the benefices reserved for their nominees, the dispensation fees they share, the appointments they influence.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Visconti threat has cost Us dearly these past years.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holy Father. Military expenses in a troubled year might reach thirty or forty thousand florins. Perhaps more.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sum it all, Your Majesty. In a typical year, the Camera must spend—at minimum—one hundred thousand florins. Salaries: ten thousand. Papal household: twenty thousand. Cardinals' subsidies: twenty-five thousand. Curial operations: fifteen thousand. Diplomacy: fifteen thousand. Military: ten thousand in peacetime, far more in war. Building: ten thousand for maintenance alone. Charity: five thousand. Debt service: six thousand.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: That is one hundred sixteen thousand florins, and I have been conservative in every estimate. The Camera receives perhaps one hundred thousand florins in a good year. It spends one hundred sixteen thousand in a quiet year. The deficit is covered by borrowing—which increases debt service—which increases the deficit. This is why the Camera is always empty. This is why your crusade treasury vanished.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And the reforms we have just signed will reduce revenue further, while leaving expenses unchanged. Unless we also reform the expenses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should both address income and expense. Tommaso, I expect you can reform the salaries or expenses cardinals receive from the camera to a more modest and acceptable level? This is what I would mean by starting with a clean slate. To live not in poverty but to maintain papal dignity and to perform the tasks expected of it, a certain salary is appropriate.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Or maybe...the Basel decree separates the camera from the college of cardinals. Are the cardinals not expected now to receive their income and salary from this college? What part of the expenses just listed should be directed to this college and what expenses stay with the camera?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides a comprehensive breakdown of Camera expenses totaling 116,000 florins annually against revenues of only 100,000 florins. Major expense categories include papal household (20,000), cardinal subsidies (25,000), military costs (10,000+), and debt service (6,000). Juan proposes reforming cardinal expenses and questions whether the Basel decree's separation of Camera and College of Cardinals might redistribute some costs.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: That is one hundred sixteen thousand florins, and I have been conservative in every estimate. I have not included extraordinary expenses—a council, a jubilee, a war, a major building project. I have not included the informal expenses that never appear in ledgers—the gifts to secure loyalty, the bribes to prevent opposition, the quiet payments that keep the machinery turning.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Camera receives perhaps one hundred thousand florins in a good year. It spends one hundred sixteen thousand in a quiet year. The deficit is covered by borrowing—which increases debt service—which increases the deficit. This is why the Camera is always empty. This is why your crusade treasury vanished. Not because any single man stole it, but because the institution consumes faster than it receives.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And the reforms we have just signed will reduce revenue further, while leaving expenses unchanged. Unless we also reform the expenses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tommaso, I expect you can reform the salaries or expenses cardinals recieve from the camera to a more modest and acceptable level? This is what I would mean by starting with a clean slate. To live not in poverty but to maintain papal dignity and to perform the tasks expected of it, a certain salary is appropriate. With you in full control of Camera expenses, we can trim the fat.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Or maybe...the basel decree separates the camera from the college of cardinals. Are the cardinals not expected now to recieve their income and salary from this college? What part of the expenses just listed should be directed to this college and what expenses stay with the camera?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli goes still. His eyes unfocus slightly—the look of a scholar whose mind has seized upon a problem.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Basel decree on annates. Half to the Camera, half to the metropolitan—which in practice means the cardinals controlling those provinces... Your Majesty asks the essential question. If we divide the income, should we not also divide the expenses?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, pulling the annates decree closer, scanning its text though he likely knows it from memory.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Basel fathers did not address this. They thought only of reducing Rome's extraction from the provinces. They did not consider—or did not care—how Rome would then fund itself. Perhaps they hoped we would simply wither.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets down the document and begins to pace, his movements quicker now.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But let us think through the logic. The Camera, as currently constituted, funds everything. Papal household. Cardinals' subsidies. Curial offices. Diplomacy. Military. Building. Charity. All from one purse, with no clear accounting of which revenues support which functions.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we accept the Basel framework—truly accept it, not merely sign it—then we must ask: what is the Camera for? What is its essential function? The Camera exists to fund the papacy. The Holy Father. The administration that serves him directly. The household. The guards. The diplomatic missions he sends. The buildings he maintains. The charity he dispenses in Christ's name. These are papal expenses. They should come from papal revenue—the Camera's half of the annates, plus whatever other fees remain.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But the cardinals? The Sacred College? They are not the Pope's servants. They are—in theory—his advisors, his electors, his partners in governance. Why should the Pope fund their palazzos? Why should papal revenue pay for their households, their retinues, their libraries and banquets?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If the College of Cardinals receives half the annates under Basel's decree, then let the College fund itself from that half. Let them determine among themselves how to divide it. Let them decide which of their number deserves a subsidy and which can live from his benefices alone.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: They will not accept this willingly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: No, Holy Father. They will not. But consider the alternative they face. If they refuse—if they demand the Camera continue funding their subsidies—then they are admitting they cannot govern themselves. They are admitting they need papal charity. And they must make this admission publicly, after Basel has just given them an independent revenue stream.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The beauty of this approach, Your Majesty, is that it uses Basel's own decree against the cardinals who supported it. They wanted independence from papal control? Very well—they shall have it. Independence means funding themselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, his mind clearly racing.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me think through the division. Expenses that remain with the Camera—the papal expenses: Clerical salaries for Camera staff—yes, perhaps eight thousand florins. Papal household—twenty thousand. Papal guard—eight thousand. Diplomatic missions sent in the Pope's name—fifteen thousand. Building maintenance for papal properties—ten thousand. Charitable works—five thousand. Debt service on existing obligations—six thousand, until debts are cleared. Perhaps seventy thousand florins in core papal expenses. Possibly less if we trim carefully.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Cardinals' subsidies—twenty-five thousand florins, gone from the Camera entirely. Let them fund themselves. And certain curial offices might also shift. The Rota Romana hears appeals that benefit the whole Church, not just the Pope. The Penitentiary serves all Catholics. Perhaps some portion of curial expenses—say five to ten thousand florins—should come from the College's share.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we execute this cleanly, the Camera's expenses fall from over one hundred thousand florins to perhaps seventy thousand. Meanwhile, the College inherits responsibility for thirty to forty thousand in expenses—from a revenue stream that might generate only twenty to thirty thousand florins, depending on appointments. They will have to economize, Holy Father. They will have to choose between subsidizing Cardinal Colonna's palazzo and funding the Rota's operations. They will have to govern rather than merely extract.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Is this what Your Majesty envisions? The Camera stripped to essential papal functions, the College made responsible for itself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Is this not the spirit of what the Basel reforms envisioned as well?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides a detailed breakdown of Camera expenses (116,000 florins annually vs 100,000 in revenue) and proposes restructuring papal finances by using the Basel decree to force the College of Cardinals to fund itself from their share of annates, reducing Camera expenses to essential papal functions of around 70,000 florins.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli

Meanwhile, the College inherits responsibility for thirty to forty thousand in expenses—from a revenue stream that might generate only twenty to thirty thousand florins, depending on appointments. They will have to economize, Holy Father. They will have to choose between subsidizing Cardinal Colonna's palazzo and funding the Rota's operations. They will have to govern rather than merely extract. Is this what Your Majesty envisions? The Camera stripped to essential papal functions, the College made responsible for itself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Is this not the spirit of what the Basel reforms envisioned as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli pauses. A strange expression crosses his face—something between admiration and dark amusement.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The spirit of Basel. Yes. And no. And that is what makes this so elegant.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the window, gathering his thoughts.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Council fathers at Basel sought to decentralize Church governance. To break Rome's monopoly on revenue and power. To give metropolitans and provinces greater authority over their own affairs. The annates decree does precisely this—half the revenue stays closer to where it originates, under the metropolitan's control rather than the Camera's. But the Council fathers made an assumption. They assumed that reducing papal revenue would weaken papal power. They assumed the Pope would be forced to come begging to the Council for funds, making him dependent on conciliar goodwill. What they did not consider is that a Pope might accept reduced revenue and reduce expenses accordingly. They did not imagine that Rome might say: 'Very well. We shall live within our means. And so shall the cardinals.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins pacing again, his voice taking on the cadence of a lecturer.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Basel's reformers hate two things above all: papal tyranny and curial corruption. They see both as intertwined—the Pope extracts money from Christendom to fund a bloated, venal court that serves no one but itself. What we propose addresses both concerns. The Camera's extractions are reduced—Basel's explicit goal. But the curial bloat is also reduced—the cardinals must fund themselves from their own share rather than feeding at the papal trough. The Pope becomes leaner, more focused, more... apostolic. Less a Renaissance prince and more a shepherd.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes meet Juan's.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If Basel's spirit is genuine reform of Church governance, then yes—this fulfills that spirit more completely than Basel itself imagined. We are not merely reducing revenue. We are restructuring responsibility. But I must be honest, Your Majesty. The men at Basel—Cardinal d'Allemand, the French faction—they do not want a reformed papacy. They want a subordinate papacy. A Pope who must ask the Council's permission before acting. They will not celebrate this interpretation. They will call it trickery, evasion, a perversion of their intent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shrugs.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let them. The decree says what it says. Half to the Camera, half to the metropolitans and cardinals. It does not say the Camera must continue funding cardinals' subsidies from its diminished share. It does not say the Pope must beggar himself while cardinals live in splendor. When this is announced—when the full implications become clear—Basel will face a choice. Do they denounce reforms they themselves decreed? Do they demand the Pope increase spending on cardinals? Do they argue that Church revenues should fund palazzos rather than charity?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A cold satisfaction enters his voice.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Every argument they make will expose them. They claimed to want reform. We are giving them reform—more reform than they ever intended. If they object, they reveal that their true goal was never reform at all. It was merely power. So yes, Your Majesty. This is the spirit of Basel. Distilled. Purified. Turned back upon those who thought themselves clever. The Council wanted to teach Rome a lesson about living within its means. We shall be excellent students.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would the bishops and cardinals. The offices who will have their revenues reduced be able to perform their function properly? Do we not unduly reduce their income?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli presents his economic reform proposal that would shift expenses from the papal Camera to the College of Cardinals while reducing overall spending. He argues this fulfills Basel's reform spirit better than the Council intended, forcing cardinals to economize while making the papacy leaner and more apostolic. Juan questions whether reduced revenues would impair ecclesiastical functions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would the bishops and cardinals. The offices who will have their revenues reduced be able to perform their function properly? Do we not unduly reduce their income?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: A fair question, Your Majesty. And one I should address honestly. Not all cardinals are equal. Not all bishops are wealthy. The Sacred College contains men of vastly different circumstances.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Consider Cardinal Colonna. His family has held lands around Rome for centuries. His personal income from family estates alone—before any benefice, before any curial position—exceeds what most bishops see in a decade. If the Camera ceased his subsidy tomorrow, he would not miss a single meal. His palazzo would remain full of servants. His stables would remain full of horses.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But then consider Cardinal Albergati. A Carthusian monk who rose through sanctity and scholarship. He has no family wealth. His benefices are modest. He lives simply because he believes in simplicity—but also because he has no choice. Without some support, he could not maintain even a minimal household. He could not travel to councils. He could not perform the functions expected of a cardinal.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we strip away all subsidies indiscriminately, we punish the Albergatis to spite the Colonnas. We make the Sacred College a preserve of the wealthy—only men with family fortunes or rich benefices could afford to serve. The poor scholar, the holy monk, the bishop from a minor see—these men would be excluded.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The same applies to bishops. The Archbishop of Toledo commands revenues that would make some princes envious. Reducing his annates by three-quarters still leaves him wealthy beyond measure. But the Bishop of some mountain diocese in Savoy? A see with thirty parishes and peasants who pay tithes in goats and cheese? That man struggles to maintain a cathedral chapter. Further reduction might genuinely impair his function.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So the reform must distinguish. Between those who have much and those who have little.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holy Father. The principle of reform is sound—the Camera should not fund luxury for those who need no help. But the application must be... discerning.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Perhaps the solution is this: the College of Cardinals receives its half of the annates as a common fund. From this fund, the College must pay for shared expenses—the Rota, the Penitentiary, whatever curial functions we assign to them. What remains after these obligations is divided among the cardinals themselves. But divided how? Not equally—that would give Cardinal Colonna the same subsidy as Cardinal Albergati, which serves no purpose. Instead, divided according to need. Cardinals with wealthy benefices or family fortunes receive nothing. Cardinals with modest means receive support sufficient to perform their functions with dignity—not luxury, but dignity.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This forces the College to govern itself. To make decisions. To look their brother cardinals in the eye and say: 'You have enough. You need nothing from the common purse.' Or: 'You have little. We shall support you.' It makes them accountable to each other rather than simply drawing from an endless papal fountain.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The same principle could apply to bishops, through their metropolitans. The metropolitan receives the provincial share of annates. He distributes support to suffragan bishops according to need—wealthy sees receive nothing, poor sees receive help. The metropolitan becomes responsible for his province's welfare, not merely its extraction.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Will some bishops and cardinals see their income reduced? Yes. Substantially. But these will be the men who least need it—those with multiple benefices, family wealth, comfortable arrangements. Will the truly poor be protected? They can be, if the system is designed properly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The question is whether the College and the metropolitans can be trusted to distribute fairly. History suggests... caution. The wealthy look after the wealthy. The powerful protect the powerful. But that is where enforcement matters. If the Camera reform decree includes provisions requiring transparent accounting from the College—if Albergati can see exactly how much Colonna receives and demand justification—then the pressure for fairness increases. Sunlight, as we discussed. Let them make their decisions, but make them publicly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Does this address Your Majesty's concern? The reform need not impoverish those who are already poor. It need only cease enriching those who are already rich.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. This sounds great. I am thinking about if we should include corruption investigations into the reforms as well. If the rot is indeed as deep as we fear, we may put a great part of the church against the wall and we reduce the chance of this reform succeeding. Maybe curb the largest excess?

encounters.recap: Juan raises concerns about whether reducing church revenues will harm poor bishops and cardinals. Parentucelli proposes a nuanced reform system that protects clergy with modest means while cutting subsidies to wealthy prelates through needs-based distribution and transparent accounting. Juan expresses satisfaction but wonders about adding corruption investigations to the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The question is whether the College and the metropolitans can be trusted to distribute fairly. History suggests... caution. The wealthy look after the wealthy. The powerful protect the powerful. But that is where enforcement matters. If the Camera reform decree includes provisions requiring transparent accounting from the College—if Albergati can see exactly how much Colonna receives and demand justification—then the pressure for fairness increases. Sunlight, as we discussed. Let them make their decisions, but make them publicly. Does this address Your Majesty's concern? The reform need not impoverish those who are already poor. It need only cease enriching those who are already rich.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. This sounds great. I am thinking about if we should include corruption investigations into the reforms as well. If the rot is indeed as deep as we fear, we may put a great part of the church against the wall and we reduce the chance of this reform succeeding. Maybe curb the largest excess?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli is silent for a long moment. His jaw works. Something wars behind his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... Your Majesty is wise to consider this carefully. I spoke earlier of justice. Of finding the men who pledged Church property to bankers. Of holding them accountable. Part of me still wants this. Twenty years of watching, Your Majesty. Twenty years of seeing good priests ground down while corrupt men prospered. The ledger in my heart cries out for balance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the window, his back partially turned. He turns back. His face is composed, but something burns beneath.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But you are right. If we announce investigations alongside the reform—if cardinals wake tomorrow fearing not just reduced income but imprisonment, disgrace, ruin—they will unite against us. Every man with a secret becomes an enemy. Every family with something to hide becomes a faction seeking our destruction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius stirs in his chair.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have thought on this as well. When We spoke of bringing down the hammer, We meant reform. Structural change. Not... Not trials. Not executions. Not dragging princes of the Church before tribunals. The Church has seen such purges before. They do not end well. Accusations breed counter-accusations. Factions form. Men who might have accepted reform peacefully instead fight to the death because they have nothing left to lose.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, moving slowly toward the window where Parentucelli stands.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The mathematics of fear, Holy Father. A man who loses income grumbles but adapts. A man who faces investigation panics. A man who faces ruin has no reason for restraint. If we focus the decree purely on structural reform—the clean ledger, the separation of Camera and College, the reduction of expenses—we give the corrupt a path forward. They lose privilege, yes. They lose the system that enriched them. But they keep their positions. Their dignity. Their freedom. Some will even prosper under the new system, if they adapt. A cardinal who learned to extract under the old ways might learn to economize under the new. We offer them... conversion. A chance to become what they should have been.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius turns from the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And if they refuse? If corruption continues despite reform?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression hardens.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Then we address it then, Holy Father. Specifically. Individually. When the new system is established, when the Camera is reformed, when we have evidence gathered under proper authority—then a single corrupt cardinal can be pursued without threatening the whole College. The system will be strong enough to survive removing one bad actor. But now? Tonight? If we try to reform the institution and punish its abusers simultaneously, we attempt too much. We create too many enemies at once. We give them common cause.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan, and something like pain crosses his face.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It galls me to say this, Your Majesty. After everything I have seen. After everything I have burned to see corrected. But you are right. We should focus the decree on reform. On the future. On building something clean. Let the guilty keep their ill-gotten gains. Let them sleep peacefully in beds bought with stolen coin. The price of their comfort is a reformed Church that will never again permit such theft. Perhaps that is justice enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He does not sound convinced. But he sounds resigned. Eugenius speaks quietly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We could include language. Something that preserves the possibility without creating immediate threat. 'The Holy See reserves the right to examine past practices as circumstances warrant.' It promises nothing. It threatens nothing specific. But it reminds them that mercy today does not guarantee mercy forever. Would such language serve? A door left open, but not walked through?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should first set the church straight. Stop the bleeding. And if there are some festering and visible corruption still visible, so much so that it harms our reform, we come after them. But I also think that most offenders also should be given a new chance. I think many would say; we did as we did because everyone did it and we had to do it to get ahead. Some took more advantage than others sure, but we should let bygones be bygones. I think we should make it clear that we do not prosecute actions that were aligned with the old way and habits of conducting business, but will from now on no longer tolerate it. We should make all well-meaning cardinals and bishops into allies not enemies. Yes, we should put that centrally. We need allies not enemies. We should make it easy for those cardinals who want to better their ways to join us without fear of prosecution.

encounters.recap: Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli debate whether to include corruption investigations in their church reforms. Despite Parentucelli's desire for justice after twenty years of witnessing abuse, they agree to focus solely on structural reform rather than punishment, offering corrupt officials a path to redemption rather than creating enemies through fear of prosecution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Would such language serve? A door left open, but not walked through?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should first set the church straight. Stop the bleeding. And if there are some festering and visible corruption still visible, so much so that it harms our reform, we come after them. But I also think that most offenders also should be given a new chance. I think many would say; we did as we did because everyone did it and we had to do it to get ahead. Some took more advantage than others sure, but we should let bygones be bygones. I think we should make it clear that we do not prosecute actions that were aligned with the old way and habits of conducting business, but will from now on no longer tolerate it. We should make all well-meaning cardinals and bishops into allies not enemies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, we should put that centrally. We need allies not enemies. We should make it easy for those cardinals who want to better their ways to join us without fear of prosecution.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence holds the room for a long moment. Parentucelli stands motionless by the window. His hands have clenched at his sides. When he finally speaks, his voice is quiet. Controlled. The voice of a man setting something down that he has carried for a very long time.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Allies. Not enemies. Yes. Yes, Your Majesty is... correct. If a cardinal looks at this reform and sees only threat—only loss, only danger—he will fight it. But if he looks and sees... a path forward. A way to become something better without first being destroyed for what he was...

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Church I have watched for twenty years was not built by monsters. It was built by ordinary men making ordinary compromises. 'Everyone does it.' 'This is how things are done.' 'I must play the game or be crushed by those who do.' These are the whispers that corrupt good men by degrees. If we declare that all who whispered these things are criminals, we declare most of the Church criminal. But if we declare that the whispers were wrong—that the game itself was wrong—and offer a new game with new rules... Then the man who compromised his conscience has a choice. He can cling to the old ways and be exposed as corrupt. Or he can embrace the new ways and be reformed. Redeemed, even. His past sins... not forgotten, but... covered over by present virtue.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is the Gospel, is it not? Repentance and new life. The prodigal son returns and is welcomed, not punished for his years of dissolution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have spent three years as Pope treating Our cardinals as enemies to be managed. Factions to be balanced. Threats to be contained. Perhaps We created enemies by expecting enemies. Perhaps if We had offered trust... No. The corruption was real. The threat was real. But now—with reform, with structure, with clear expectations—perhaps We can offer what We could not before. A new beginning. For them as well as for the Camera. Tommaso. You have the gift of language. How would you frame this? An amnesty that does not excuse—that acknowledges wrong was done—but offers forgiveness to those who embrace the new way?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: We might say something like this, Holy Father: 'We acknowledge that practices have taken root which, though long tolerated by custom, do not accord with the ancient discipline of the Church nor the Gospel of Christ. We do not seek to punish those who followed paths that circumstance and precedent seemed to permit. Rather, We call all servants of the Church to walk henceforth in newness of life, setting aside former ways as a man sets aside the garments of his youth.' 'Let no man fear prosecution for what was done under the old dispensation, provided he embraces in good faith the reforms herein decreed. The past is rendered to God's mercy. The future is committed to our common labor.'

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Something of this nature. It acknowledges wrongdoing without naming criminals. It offers amnesty without excusing sin. It frames reform as invitation rather than prosecution. And it leaves one door open. 'Provided he embraces in good faith.' Those who publicly accept reform but secretly continue the old corruption—they have rejected the amnesty by their own actions. They can be pursued later, individually, as violators of new law rather than practitioners of old custom.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The hand extended in peace. But the sword kept ready for those who spit upon the hand.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Just so, Holy Father. Your Majesty spoke of stopping the bleeding first. Of making well-meaning men into allies. This is wisdom I did not possess an hour ago. I was thinking of justice. You are thinking of victory. They are not the same thing. And tonight, victory matters more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Tommaso, there may still come a time to bring those to justice who have commited corruption so large that they fall even outside the customs and habits we have just described. When the waters have calmed, when the bleeding is stopped, then there is a time and place for your fury. If we all work and fight in the grace of our lord, we all will see the reformed church we want in our hearts.

encounters.recap: Juan advocates for pragmatic amnesty over prosecution in Church reform, arguing for transforming potential enemies into allies. Parentucelli struggles with abandoning his desire for justice but ultimately accepts Juan's strategic wisdom. They craft language for an amnesty that acknowledges wrongdoing without prosecuting past corruption, while preserving the option to pursue future violations. The Pope embraces this reconciliation approach as both Gospel-centered and politically wise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli turns to Juan. Something has shifted in his bearing. The burning fury has not vanished—it has been... banked. Controlled. Channeled.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty spoke of stopping the bleeding first. Of making well-meaning men into allies. This is wisdom I did not possess an hour ago. I was thinking of justice. You are thinking of victory. They are not the same thing. And tonight, victory matters more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Tommaso, there may still come a time to bring those to justice who have commited corruption so large that they fall even outside the customs and habits we have just described. When the waters have calmed, when the bleeding is stopped, then there is a time and place for your fury. If we all work and fight in the grace of our lord, we all will see the reformed church we want in our hearts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli goes very still. For a long moment he does not speak. His eyes glisten in the candlelight—though whether from the flickering flames or something else is impossible to say. When he finally responds, his voice is rough. Barely above a whisper.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... kind. To say so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns away, moving toward the window. His hand rises briefly to his face—a gesture quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I have carried this weight for a long time. Watching. Recording. Remembering. Telling myself that someday—someday—it would matter. That someone would want to know what I had seen. There were nights I thought myself a fool. A secretary with delusions. Who was I to judge princes of the Church? Who was I to catalogue their sins as if I were the recording angel? A physician's son from Sarzana. A man who tutored other men's children to pay for his education. Nobody.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back. His eyes are bright, but his face is composed.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And now I stand in a room with the Pope and a king, and they speak of reform as if it might actually happen. They ask my counsel. They value my knowledge. I do not know what to do with this, Your Majesty. I have prepared myself for disappointment so long that hope feels... dangerous.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Hope is dangerous, Tommaso. It has wounded Us more times than We can count. But despair is worse. Despair is surrender. And We have not come this far to surrender now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli looks at the Pope—his Pope now, in a way that was not true an hour ago. Something passes between them.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: No, Holy Father. We have not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens, squaring his shoulders. When he speaks again, the scholar has returned—but underneath, something new. Something warmer.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty spoke of a time for fury. I will hold to that promise. When the waters calm. When the bleeding stops. When the reformed Church stands strong enough to bear the weight of justice. On that day, I will remember every name. Every transaction. Every sin committed not from custom but from pure greed. But until that day, I will build. I will count coins and audit ledgers and trim expenses. I will be the most meticulous, most boring, most relentless administrator the Camera has ever seen. The corrupt will learn to fear me not because I threaten them, but because I notice them. Because nothing escapes the ledger. Because every florin must be accounted for.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This is how I will serve, Your Majesty. Not with a sword. With a quill. With patience. With the certain knowledge that the day of reckoning is delayed, not cancelled.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—a formal gesture, but one that carries genuine feeling.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Thank you. For seeing what I might become. Not just what I have been.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The day of reckoning is not delayed or cancelled Tommaso. It is merely coming. Like all good things, they take time. Look what we are accomplishing today. Rome was not built in one day.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Back to the reform itself. What else do we need to define in the reform to adress the corruption in the camera?

encounters.recap: Tommaso Parentucelli undergoes a profound emotional transformation, shifting from burning fury to controlled purpose. He reveals his deep personal pain from years of witnessing corruption while feeling powerless, and finds hope in Juan's promise of future justice. The Pope and Juan acknowledge his pain and offer him a meaningful role in reform, leading to a new bond of trust and shared purpose between all three men.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Thank you. For seeing what I might become. Not just what I have been.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The day of reckoning is not delayed or cancelled Tommaso. It is merely coming. Like all good things, they take time. Look what we are accomplishing today. Rome was not built in one day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A surprised sound escapes Parentucelli—something that might, in other circumstances, be called a laugh. Eugenius's lips twitch.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Rome indeed, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back to the desk, his manner shifting. The wounded idealist has retreated; the administrator has emerged. He begins arranging the documents already signed, creating space for notes. He picks up a quill, not to write but to gesture with—a lecturer's habit.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: What else. Yes. Let me think through the structure systematically. We have established the principle: separation of Camera and College, reduction of expenses, amnesty for past practices. But principles require mechanisms. The decree must answer practical questions, or it becomes merely aspirational.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: First: The existing officials. The Camera currently employs dozens of men—clerks, notaries, collectors, auditors. What happens to them? If we dismiss everyone, we lose institutional knowledge. But if we retain everyone, we keep the very men who built and benefited from the corrupt system. I would suggest a middle path. All current officials are suspended pending review—my review, under the commission His Holiness has signed.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second: The banking relationships. The Medici. The other lenders. The decree should establish that all Camera revenues flow through accounts controlled solely by papal officials. No banker retains funds on the Camera's behalf. No banker deducts fees without explicit written authorization for each transaction.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Medici will not like this. They profit enormously from being papal bankers—not merely from interest, but from the prestige, the information, the ability to say 'we handle the Pope's money.'

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Third: Transparency and audit. The current Camera operates in darkness. The decree should mandate regular accountings. Quarterly, perhaps. Published ledgers showing all revenues received and all expenses paid. Sunlight. As we discussed. When everyone can see the numbers, lies become difficult.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fourth: The collection system. Currently, annates and fees are collected by a web of agents, sub-collectors, and local representatives—each taking a percentage, each adding delays, each creating opportunities for... leakage. The decree should simplify this. Fewer intermediaries.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fifth: Document retention. This is crucial, Your Majesty. The Camera's records are... scattered. The decree should mandate that all Camera documents—past and present—are property of the Holy See and must be surrendered to central archives.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sixth: Future violations. The amnesty covers the past. But what of the future? The decree must establish clear penalties for officials who continue corrupt practices under the new system.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First of all, The offer of Castille stands. Best to keep it out of the decree itself. I think we should look at how much is still in the treasury and how much debt is owed. Are there other forms of corruption that we can adress? Or have we captured most with this draft?

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Other forms. Yes. There are... layers to this, Your Majesty. What I have described addresses the Camera's operations—how money flows in and out. But there are practices that exist alongside the Camera. Adjacent to it. Feeding on the same system.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me describe what else festers. Simony. The sale of sacred offices. A bishop dies. Three candidates seek his see. One is learned and holy but poor. One is mediocre but has a wealthy patron. One is utterly unqualified but offers ten thousand florins to the right cardinal. Which one receives the appointment?

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Expectancies. Promises of future benefices. This creates a market in futures. Men trade expectancies like merchants trade grain contracts. The benefice becomes property to be bought and sold before its current holder is even cold.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Coadjutors with right of succession. The coadjutor pays for the privilege. The old bishop receives a pension from his own see's revenues. When he dies, the coadjutor inherits smoothly—because he has already purchased the position. The bishopric has become, in effect, heritable property.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Pensions charged on benefices. This allows a man to hold a benefice in all but name while appearing to comply with rules against pluralism. 'I have resigned the bishopric of X,' he says. 'I hold only Y.' But the bishop of X sends him three thousand florins annually, and everyone knows the truth.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Compositions. When a man is caught in violation—holding incompatible benefices, living in concubinage, neglecting his duties—the Camera offers a choice. Face canonical penalties or... pay a fine. We have made confession itself a revenue stream. The worse the sin, the higher the fee.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: But simony itself? The quiet exchange of favors for appointments? That requires changing hearts, not systems. As long as men value wealth over holiness, they will find ways to buy what should be given by grace. We can make it harder. We can make it riskier. We cannot make it impossible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This all sounds good. Especially declare that we will no longer participate in the practice of compositions will be giving a good signal. This is much more than just a decree. It is a signal that the church is turning a page.

encounters.recap: Parentucelli systematically outlines comprehensive reform mechanisms for the Camera's operations, covering personnel review, banking relationships, transparency requirements, collection systems, document retention, and penalties for future violations. He then catalogs additional forms of Church corruption including simony, expectancies, coadjutors, pensions, and compositions. Juan affirms Castile's financial support and emphasizes that ending compositions will signal the Church's new direction.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This all sounds good. Especially declare that we will no longer participate in the practice of compositions will be giving a good signal. Your commission gives you a lot of power to find the worst offenders. But I think this decree should first and foremost signal that from now on, the church is faring a new course. This is much more than just a decree. It is a signal that the church is turning a page. Holy father, what you are doing is incredible. To announce this decree will be a historic moment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius is silent for a long moment. He stands by the window, his white robes pale in the dying light. Outside, Rome stretches toward the horizon—the city that has been his prison and his burden for four years. The city that tomorrow will learn its Pope has found his spine. When he speaks, his voice is rough.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Historic. We have thought of Our pontificate in many terms, Your Majesty. Beleaguered. Threatened. Survival. We have not dared to think of it as... historic.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns from the window. His eyes are bright.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: When they elected Us—when the cardinals placed this burden upon Our shoulders—We believed We might accomplish great things. We had plans. Visions. The reform of the Church. The reunion with the Greeks. The defense of Christendom against the Turk. Three years. Three years of councils that defied Us. Cardinals who schemed against Us. Armies at Our gates. We fled Rome in a fisherman's boat, Your Majesty. Disguised. Hunted. The Vicar of Christ, rowing across the Tiber in the dark like a common fugitive.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops before the desk where the signed documents lie—the commission, the declaration, the Basel reforms with papal seal.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We learned to think small. To survive today. To postpone tomorrow. To call it wisdom when it was merely... fear. And now this. In a single afternoon. A king who speaks of church bells and farmers at Mass. A scholar who has waited twenty years for someone to ask what he knows. And a Pope who remembers—finally remembers—why he wanted this throne at all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hand reaches out, fingers brushing the parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You say what We are doing is incredible. Perhaps. But We could not do it alone. We have not done it alone. This is not Our achievement. This is... communion. Three men, in a room, deciding to stop being afraid.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He draws himself up. Something of the papal dignity returns—but warmer now, less defensive.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tomorrow will be difficult. The cardinals will rage. Basel will denounce Us. The Colonna and Orsini will scheme. There will be moments when We doubt. When We wish We had remained silent, remained safe, remained the frightened Pope who asked nothing and risked nothing. When those moments come—and they will come—We will remember this night. This room. The King of Castile, kneeling to pledge his sword to a cause not his own. The scholar from Sarzana, setting aside his fury for the sake of victory. And a Pope who finally stopped running.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reaches out and grips Juan's arm—the same gesture from hours ago, when he first began to believe.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Thank you. Whatever comes tomorrow, thank you. For seeing what We might become. For refusing to let Us remain what We were.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases Juan's arm and turns to Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And you, Tommaso. Our Commissarius Extraordinarius. We suspect you will make Us uncomfortable many times in the months ahead. You will tell Us things We do not wish to hear. You will find rot We would prefer not to know about. You will be... relentless. Good. We have had enough men who tell Us what We wish to hear. We need men who tell Us the truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at the window. The light has faded almost entirely now. Evening has come to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But first, before We draft the final decree— We should have candles. And perhaps more wine. The night is young, and We have a Church to reform. Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rings the bell.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tommaso, can we now touch pen to parchment? Create a new document and put the decree in it.

encounters.recap: Juan praises the Pope's reform decree as historic, prompting Eugenius to reflect emotionally on his pontificate's struggles and failures. The Pope expresses profound gratitude to Juan and Parentucelli for helping him rediscover his courage and purpose, acknowledging this moment as transformative communion between three men deciding to stop being afraid. They prepare to draft the final reform decree.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Good. We have had enough men who tell Us what We wish to hear. We need men who tell Us the truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at the window. The light has faded almost entirely now. Evening has come to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But first, before We draft the final decree—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the small bell on the side table.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We should have candles. And perhaps more wine. The night is young, and We have a Church to reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rings the bell.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli nods, moving to the desk with purpose. He selects a fresh sheet of parchment, tests his quill, and pauses—gathering the threads of hours of conversation into a single coherent document.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me structure this clearly, Your Majesty. His Holiness can amend as I draft.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to write, speaking aloud as his quill moves.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: We begin with the arenga—the preamble explaining why this decree is necessary. Then the dispositio—the operative clauses, organized by subject. Then the amnesty and protection clauses. Finally, the dating and signature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks up.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This will be lengthy. The most comprehensive reform of papal finance in... perhaps ever. But length serves a purpose here. Every clause we include is a door closed against future corruption. Every mechanism we specify is a tool for enforcement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bends to his work. The candles burn low as Parentucelli writes. His quill moves steadily, pausing only when Eugenius suggests a word change or Juan raises a question of clarity. The room fills with the scratch of pen on parchment, the occasional murmur of Latin phrases being tested aloud. Hours pass. When Parentucelli finally sets down his quill, his hand is cramped and ink-stained. But his eyes are bright with something that might be triumph.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It is done.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reads the complete document aloud—all twenty articles, from the separation of Camera and College through the amnesty provisions to the final anathema against those who would oppose the reform. His voice grows stronger as he proceeds, the scholar giving way to something else. A man who has found his purpose. When he finishes, silence holds the chamber. Eugenius rises slowly from his chair. He moves to the desk and looks down at the document—page after page of careful Latin, the most comprehensive reform of papal finance in the history of the Church.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Bulla Reformationis. The Bull of Reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan, then at Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tomorrow, when We announce this—when the cardinals learn what We have done—everything changes. There is no path back from this document. No retreat. No compromise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He picks up the quill.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have spent four years surviving. Tonight, We begin to reign.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He signs. † Eugenius PP. IV. The seal follows—the Fisherman's Ring pressed into crimson wax for the final time tonight. When Eugenius lifts his hand, the impression of Saint Peter's nets marks this document as authentic, binding, irrevocable. He steps back.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. God help Us all.

encounters.recap: Working late into the night, Parentucelli drafts the comprehensive Bull of Reform—twenty articles covering papal financial reform from Camera separation to amnesty provisions. After hours of careful composition, Pope Eugenius signs the document, officially enacting the most comprehensive reform of papal finance in Church history.

encounters.location: Rome, Vatican Palace to Palazzo di San Marco

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The seal follows—the Fisherman's Ring pressed into crimson wax for the final time tonight. When Eugenius lifts his hand, the impression of Saint Peter's nets marks this document as authentic, binding, irrevocable.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. God help Us all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli glances toward the window. Beyond the glass, Rome lies dark—no trace of twilight remains. The candles have burned down to stubs, wax pooling on the silver holders.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Late, Your Majesty. The bells of Saint Peter's rang Compline some time ago. I would guess... the tenth or eleventh hour of the night? Perhaps later.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The cardinals will be asleep in their palazzos. Dreaming of tomorrow's intrigues. They do not know that tomorrow's world will be nothing like today's. Your Majesty should rest. Your queen waits at the Palazzo di San Marco—she will be worried. And tomorrow... Tomorrow will require strength none of us possess tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We keep these documents with the pope for now. Tomorrow, I will again march my crusaders to st peter's to attend mass. I have done so before. One hour before eugenius makes the decrees public, we instruct the vatican guard to secure the camera. Tommaso will be needed there to make sure no-one destroys documents and that the treasury itself is secured. Then we will see what happens. But we should also be open for others to display good faith and good intentions. We rest tonight, tomorrow we continue God's work.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: A sound plan. The crusaders at Mass provide... context. Protection that appears as piety rather than force. You have done this before. The cardinals will think it merely the Castilian king's excessive devotion. Until it is too late.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father, I will be at the Camera doors at dawn. Before dawn, if you wish. I want to see the building before the officials arrive. To understand the layout. To know which rooms hold the records, which hold the treasury. I have waited twenty years for tomorrow. I find I am... impatient for it to arrive.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We do not have words adequate to this night. What you have given Us—what you have helped Us become—Go to your queen. Hold your daughter. Pray with your confessor. And return tomorrow ready to shake the pillars of Christendom. Until tomorrow, Juan of Castile. God keep you through the night.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before you move to the Camera Tommaso, we should place a few dozen men under your command. You will need to secure the building. We meet again tomorrow, two hours before the adress. Until then, sleep the heavenly peace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Vatican corridors are empty at this hour. Juan's footsteps echo against ancient stone as a single papal guard leads him through darkened passages toward the entrance where his escort waits. Outside, the March night is cold. Rome spreads before him—a city of domes and towers, of palazzos and ruins, all silver-blue under a crescent moon. Somewhere in those darkened buildings, cardinals sleep in their silk sheets, unaware that the world they know is about to end.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Palazzo di San Marco is dark save for a single window on the upper floor. Lucia's window. Still lit, despite the hour. She is waiting. Juan finds her in the small sitting room adjoining their chambers, wrapped in a heavy robe against the night chill.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Nine hours. I was about to send men to inquire. You look... different. What happened in that room, my husband?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candle burns. Outside, Rome sleeps, unknowing. Tomorrow, everything changes.

encounters.recap: After sealing the papal documents for reform, Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli finalize plans for tomorrow's public announcement. They arrange for Castilian soldiers to secure the Camera, with Parentucelli taking charge of protecting the records and treasury. Juan returns late at night to the Palazzo di San Marco, where Lucia waits, noting the change in her husband after this historic day of church reform planning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The grey light before dawn seeps through the shuttered windows as the servant leads you through the quiet corridors of the palazzo. Your footsteps echo against marble floors that have heard the tread of cardinals, ambassadors, and conspirators for generations. Rome sleeps, but you carry documents that will wake her with a thunderclap.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The door to Lucia's chamber stands slightly ajar. A single candle burns within—she has been waiting. You push the door open. Lucia sits in a high-backed chair near the window, wrapped in a fur-lined robe against the March chill. Her dark hair falls loose around her shoulders—she has not slept. Her grey-green eyes, sharp as ever, track you as you enter. On the table beside her, an untouched cup of wine has grown a skin of dust.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She takes in your appearance in one long, measured look: the ink stains on your fingers, the rumpled clothing, the particular quality of exhaustion that comes from something beyond mere physical labor. She does not rise. Does not rush to embrace you. Does not speak. Instead, she tilts her head slightly—that gesture you have come to know well. The one that says: I have been sitting here for hours imagining you dead in a Vatican cellar, and you will explain yourself thoroughly before I decide whether to be relieved or furious.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You smell of incense and old books. And something else. Fear, perhaps. Though not your own. Whose fear have you been breathing, marito mio?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your sense of smell is impeccable love. I have been hammering away. And with result. Tomorrow, the pope will declare a reform that will shake the foundations of the church. Remember today and tomorrow love.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The kiss lands on lips that remain still for a moment—not cold, but evaluating. Then she softens, just slightly, and her hand comes up to rest against your chest. She can feel your heartbeat, still quick from the night's work. When you pull back, her expression has shifted. The sharp edge remains, but curiosity has joined it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Shake the foundations. You have been with Eugenius all night. Drafting something. The Camera reform you spoke of. You actually convinced him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns back to you. She crosses her arms beneath her robe, studying you with that penetrating gaze that misses nothing.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And Parentucelli? The scholar Eugenius summoned? He is involved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves closer, and now you can see the shadows under her eyes, the tension in her shoulders from a night of waiting and imagining the worst.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me what you have done, Juan. Not poetry—specifics. Because if the Pope announces reform that shakes foundations, there will be men in this city who would rather see those foundations buried atop anyone who threatens them. And I have been sitting here in the dark while my husband walked into that nest of vipers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits, one hand unconsciously moving to rest on her belly where your child grows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I take her to bed and tell her everything of what happened.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Lucia's chamber at dawn after spending the night drafting church reform documents with Pope Eugenius. Lucia, who has waited anxiously through the night while pregnant, confronts him about the dangers he has exposed himself to. Juan decides to share the full details of what transpired during the night-long session with the Pope and Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And Parentucelli? The scholar Eugenius summoned? He is involved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves closer, and now you can see the shadows under her eyes, the tension in her shoulders from a night of waiting and imagining the worst.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me what you have done, Juan. Not poetry—specifics. Because if the Pope announces reform that shakes foundations, there will be men in this city who would rather see those foundations buried atop anyone who threatens them. And I have been sitting here in the dark while my husband walked into that nest of vipers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits, one hand unconsciously moving to rest on her belly where your second child grows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I take her to bed and tell her everything of what happened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bed is still warm from where she had lain earlier, trying and failing to sleep. You settle against the pillows together, her body curling against yours despite the residual tension in her frame. The candle gutters low. Through the cracked shutter, Rome's rooftops catch the first grey hints of dawn. You tell her everything. The audience. Eugenius's initial guardedness, then the moment something cracked open when you spoke of faith—real faith, not political faith. The Pope's confession that he had lost belief in his own Church. The fear in his eyes when he spoke of the Camera, the corrupt cardinals, the Basel faction watching his every move. You tell her about the crusade treasury—how it may already be gone, consumed by the structural deficit that devours everything Rome touches. You tell her about the clean slate. The elegant trap: nullify all existing arrangements, transfer the obligations to the College of Cardinals, let the corrupt men fight among themselves over scraps while a reformed Camera rises lean and honest. You tell her about the scholar summoned in the middle of the night—Tommaso Parentucelli, a man with ink-stained fingers and twenty years of quiet fury at what he had witnessed. A man who knew everything about how the corruption worked because he had watched it happen, powerless, for two decades. You tell her about the documents signed before dawn. The Extraordinary Commission. The Motu Proprio declaration. The Bull of Reform with its twenty articles. You tell her about the plan for tomorrow—today, now—the Mass at St. Peter's, the public announcement, Parentucelli securing the Camera building with Castilian knights before the corrupt officials can burn their records or flee with what remains of the treasury.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you finish, the candle has burned to a stub. Pale light fills the room. Lucia is silent for a long moment. Her hand has found yours, gripping it tightly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tommaso Parentucelli. A secretary. No family, no income, no protection. And you have made him the most dangerous man in Rome. He will need guards. Not just for today—for months. Years, perhaps. The men whose arrangements he will unravel... they will not simply accept this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She shifts, propping herself up on one elbow to look at you directly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The cardinals. Colonna, Orsini, the French faction. They will know by noon that their world is ending. What stops them from... You said Castilian knights will secure the Camera. How many? And what of us? What of this palazzo? What of Catalina, sleeping down the hall?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I wanted to move you, Catalina and the rest of the court back to the ships. If there is trouble, you can just sail away to Naples. You will be secure there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression flickers—something passes behind her eyes too quickly to name. She pulls back slightly, sitting up against the headboard.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: To the ships. While you remain here.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks toward the window where dawn is strengthening, painting the walls in shades of rose and gold. When she speaks again, her tone has an edge to it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I remember a garden in Toledo. A man kneeling before me with a ring. He said I would stand beside him in Rome and Constantinople. That I would be his partner. And now Rome grows dangerous, and the partner is sent to wait on a ship while her husband walks into the fire alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her jaw tightens. For a moment, the Lucia who warned you she would argue, who promised to drive your advisors to distraction, is fully present. But then her hand moves to her belly again. The gesture is unconscious, protective. And something in her face shifts—the sharp edge giving way to something more complicated.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Catalina cannot be here if there is violence. That much is certain. And I...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She trails off, looking down at where her hand rests. When she looks up again, her eyes are bright with something that might be frustration, might be fear, might be both.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I hate this. I hate that you are right. I hate that I cannot stand beside you tomorrow because I carry the future of your dynasty in my body and that makes me a liability instead of an ally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches for your hand again, gripping hard.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Promise me something.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can come if you want to Lucia. I will not stop you, but I think it may be better for you to be safe with Catalina.

encounters.recap: In their bedchamber at dawn, Juan reveals to his pregnant wife Lucia the full scope of his nocturnal negotiations with Pope Eugenius—the planned Church reforms, the scholar Parentucelli's role, and the dangerous implications. Lucia grasps the political peril and argues against being sent to safety on the ships, torn between her desire to stand as Juan's partner and her duty to protect their unborn child.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I hate this. I hate that you are right. I hate that I cannot stand beside you tomorrow because I carry the future of your dynasty in my body and that makes me a liability instead of an ally. Promise me something.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can come if you want to Lucia. I will not stop you, but I think it may be better for you to be safe with Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You will not stop me. But you think it would be better. This is how it begins, you know. The slow retreat into the women's quarters. First it is better that I wait on the ship. Then it is better that I remain in Toledo while you ride to war. Then it is better that I manage the household while the men discuss politics. My aunt in Ferrara. Eleven years. That is how it started for her, too. One reasonable decision at a time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She pushes herself up, swinging her legs over the side of the bed. For a moment she sits with her back to you, shoulders tight.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: But I am not a fool. If something goes wrong today—if there is blood in the streets—I cannot run. I cannot fight. I can only be captured and used against you, or...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She does not finish the sentence. When she turns back, her face has composed itself into something harder. The Ferrarese noblewoman who survived two decades of Italian court politics.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will go to the ships. I will take Catalina and my ladies and I will wait like a good wife while you reshape the Church. But you will finish what you started with that promise, Juan. The one I asked for before you interrupted me. Promise me that when this is done—when the Camera is secured and Parentucelli has his commission and the cardinals have learned to swallow their fury—you will come back to me. Not to a ship, not to Naples. To me. Alive and whole. Promise me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I'll come back, I promise. I must write some orders to the men.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia watches as you rise from the bed, her expression unreadable. The promise hangs in the air between you—accepted, but not forgotten.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Today. It is today. You have perhaps three hours until the sun is properly up. You have 591 knights at Ostia. Ten ships. How many do you need for the Camera? Parentucelli cannot secure a building with clerks and good intentions. And the rest? Do they attend the Mass armed? That will send a message, but perhaps not the one you want. Five hundred armored Castilians in St. Peter's looks less like piety and more like conquest.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will need time to prepare Catalina and the ladies. Two hours at minimum, more if you want us gone before the announcement. When do you want the ships ready to sail? And who commands them if... Who commands them, Juan?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have a son Fernando. If I die today, you will be queen-regent until he comes of age. But I will not die today. Write a command to all my knights. I want them in white tabards to attend mass today and me at St Peter's at midday. They are to bring one weapon with them. No crossbows, just one sword, mace or axe per person. They will attend mass and will further instructions from me later. Make sure they get a good breakfast. Get your ladies and Catalina ready to get to the ships soon Lucia. Take my personal guard with you for now, you will be safe and I will be with my knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression tightens almost imperceptibly at the mention of Fernando. Your son by Isabel. The heir. A reminder of the hierarchy she occupies—wife, but not mother of the succession.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: White tabards. Mass at midday. One weapon each. Breakfast first. And the men for Parentucelli? The Camera building? You said fifty to one hundred could secure it. That needs to be a separate order, does it not? Different instructions, different timing. Parentucelli takes the Camera before the announcement, not during. Unless you want the corrupt officials to have warning while five hundred knights are visibly assembling for Mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When the orders are complete and sealed, Lucia rises. The sky outside has shifted from grey to pale gold. Rome is waking.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will have the household ready within two hours. Catalina will be... difficult. She does not like the ship when it is not moving. But I will manage her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves toward the door, then pauses. Turns back. For a moment, the mask slips. She crosses to where you sit on the edge of the bed, exhaustion finally pulling at your limbs. She takes your face in her hands—her fingers cool against your skin—and kisses you. Not gently. Fiercely.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sleep. You cannot reshape the Church if you collapse during Mass.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I get some sleep and then get back to the vatican and set everything in motion. I ask the pope if he has a handful of men ready to give to Tommaso to secure the camera.

encounters.recap: Lucia reluctantly agrees to withdraw to safety at the ships with Catalina while Juan prepares his knights for the papal reform. Despite her strategic mind and desire to participate, she recognizes the political reality of her pregnancy making her a liability. Juan promises to return alive and issues orders for his knights to attend Mass in white tabards with limited weapons, while planning separate orders for securing the Camera Apostolica.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sleep is shallow and dreamless—the exhausted rest of a body that has pushed too far. You wake to find the sun well up, golden light streaming through the shutters. Someone has left bread, cheese, and watered wine on the table. Lucia is gone. So is Catalina. A servant informs you that the Queen departed for Ostia two hours ago with her household and your personal guard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Vatican — Late Morning, March 23, 1434. The walk through Vatican corridors feels different in daylight. Servants and minor clergy move about their business, unaware that their world is about to crack open. You catch glances—curious, wary, speculative. Word has spread that the King of Castile spent the night with the Pope. Rome is whispering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
