The smell of wood smoke mingles with the cooling Roman air. Marco Tornesi rises from a cluster of men dicing near the colonnade. His weathered face creases with attention as you approach.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Majestad.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You brief him quietly—the reform proceeding, resistance passive rather than active, the need for continued vigilance without alarm. He listens without interruption, nodding at key points.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: The men are steady. Fed, rested enough, ready if needed. Though some are asking how long we stay. Not complaint, Majestad. Just soldiers wanting to know the shape of things.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You tell him: for now, we provide security while the Church transitions. Days at least. Perhaps longer.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: I'll rotate watches. Keep the men sharp without wearing them down. The priests have been coming out to bless us. Three times now. The men don't mind it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his duties, and you make your way into the Vatican. The corridors are quieter now. The frantic energy of the day has subsided into something more subdued—servants moving with purpose but without urgency, clergy walking in pairs and speaking in low voices. At the entrance to the papal apartments, a guard—one of Pallavicini's men—straightens at your approach. You are shown to an antechamber. A secretary disappears to announce you. Minutes pass. Then the door opens, and you are admitted to the Pope's private study.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius sits in a high-backed chair near the window, still wearing his white vestments though they are rumpled now, the crispness of the morning's ceremony long gone. A single candle burns on the desk beside him. The room smells of beeswax and old books. He looks exhausted. More than exhausted—diminished.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Forgive me. I find I have little ceremony left in me tonight. Sit. Please.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you are seated, he is quiet for a moment, staring at the candle flame.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The consistory. You will want to know how it went. They agreed. To everything. Every proposal, every appointment, every measure. Not a single cardinal voted against. Not a single objection raised. And not a single man in that room will lift a finger to help us succeed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, moving to the window. Rome spreads out below, torches and candles beginning to flicker in the darkness.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Colonna has fled. Orsini cooperates—though I suspect his cooperation is purchased rather than given. Rochetaillée... Rochetaillée spoke to me after the consistory. He was... different. He spoke of reconciliation with Basel. Of declaring victory and ending the constitutional conflict. I do not know what to make of him. And my nephew came to see me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words hang in the air. Eugenius's face is carefully controlled, but you can see the pain beneath the mask.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Francesco believes I have betrayed him. Humiliated him before all of Rome. Made him a fool to elevate a commoner—Parentucelli—to authority over the office he nominally held. He is not wrong. I did humiliate him. I did not warn him. I did not include him. I treated him as part of the problem rather than part of the family. He will not oppose us openly. He has too much pride for that—and too much fear of what it would cost him. But he has withdrawn. From me. From the reform. From everything. I have purchased reform at the cost of my nephew's love. Perhaps that is an acceptable price. Tonight, it does not feel acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at you—and for a moment, you see not a pope but a tired old man who has spent everything he had and is not certain it will be enough.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You wished to plan next moves, Your Majesty. I am here. But I confess I do not know what moves remain. The documents are signed. The Camera is secured. The cardinals have agreed to everything and committed to nothing. What more can we do except wait and see if Parentucelli can build something lasting from the wreckage? Tell me what you see. You have clearer eyes than mine tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We made our statement, now we call in allies and keep those close to us who are on our side.

encounters.recap: Juan conducts an evening security briefing with his captain Marco Tornesi, ensuring continued protection of the Vatican during the reform transition. He then meets with an exhausted Pope Eugenius, who reports that while the consistory approved all reforms, the cardinals offer only hollow compliance. The Pope reveals his personal costs: his nephew Francesco's withdrawal and bitter disappointment at being passed over for Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Francesco believes I have betrayed him. Humiliated him before all of Rome. Made him a fool to elevate a commoner—Parentucelli—to authority over the office he nominally held. He is not wrong. I did humiliate him. I did not warn him. I did not include him. I treated him as part of the problem rather than part of the family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair, lowering himself slowly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: He will not oppose us openly. He has too much pride for that—and too much fear of what it would cost him. But he has withdrawn. From me. From the reform. From everything. I have purchased reform at the cost of my nephew's love. Perhaps that is an acceptable price. Tonight, it does not feel acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at you—and for a moment, you see not a pope but a tired old man who has spent everything he had and is not certain it will be enough.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You wished to plan next moves, Your Majesty. I am here. But I confess I do not know what moves remain. The documents are signed. The Camera is secured. The cardinals have agreed to everything and committed to nothing. What more can we do except wait and see if Parentucelli can build something lasting from the wreckage? Tell me what you see. You have clearer eyes than mine tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We made our statement, now we call in allies and keep those close to us who are on our side. I think we should write Basel with this decree and ask them to also enforce this reform decree. This will finish the process of parallel legislation. The vatican has signed decrees from Basel. Now it is Basel's turn to do the same and also sign a decree from the Vatican. I will write to all christian monarchs to indicate what we have done and ask them for support. And I think we should make new appointments. Make sure everyone understands that actively working with the reform is rewarded. Your captain for example. Do you have the power to appoint someone new? Consider promoting someone who actually believes in what we are doing. Apply this to other positions as well. But overall, I think everything went very well. No major uprisings and no armed conflict at all. It could have gone a lot worse.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius listens, his exhaustion slowly giving way to something more attentive. You can see him gathering himself—the statesman emerging from beneath the tired old man.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Parallel legislation. Yes. Basel signs what Rome has decreed, as Rome signed what Basel decreed. Neither submits to the other. Both authorities acting toward the same end.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises and moves to his desk, where parchment and ink wait. His movements are deliberate now, purposeful.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The framing will matter. We do not demand Basel's compliance—we invite their participation. We present the Camera reform as complementary to their work on annates and benefices. The same spirit, the same goals, different spheres of application. Rochetaillée spoke of reconciliation. If his conversion is genuine—and I confess I do not fully understand it—he may help prepare Basel to receive this well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets the quill down without writing, turning back to you.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The letters to Christian monarchs—yes. From both of us, I think. Your voice carries weight that mine does not. A pope asking for support is expected. A king who has just sworn to defend the Church without asking anything in return... That is something new. Something they will not know how to categorize.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At the mention of appointments, Eugenius's expression grows more complex.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: New appointments. Rewards for those who believe. You mention Pallavicini. The captain has served competently, but... There is something in him that troubles me. He follows orders. He does his duty. But when I look in his eyes, I see a man calculating odds, not a man committed to a cause. Parentucelli tells me the guards are slow to respond. Not defiant—just... slow. Promoting a man who does not believe may simply elevate doubt to a higher position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to face you.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But you raise the true question: who does believe? Who has demonstrated commitment beyond words? Parentucelli—but he is already elevated as high as I can raise him without making him a cardinal, and that requires time and process. Albergati believes, but he is seventy and better suited to prayer than administration. Rochetaillée—if genuine—but promoting a Frenchman who spent eight years fighting us would confuse everyone, including him.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cardinal Capranica has energy and capability, but I cannot read his heart. He applauded this morning. He supported proposals this afternoon. But he has never committed to anything before it was safe, and I do not know if today was conviction or calculation.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: There is Orsini. He has provided genuine assistance—intelligence about Camera corruption, information about which officials are compromised. But his cooperation is opportunism, not faith. With Colonna fled, he positions himself as the indispensable Roman aristocrat. Useful, but not trustworthy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair, lowering himself with a heavy sigh.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are right that we must reward those who support us. I simply find myself uncertain who those people are. The Mass produced many converts. The afternoon revealed most of them to be... temporary.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But at your final words—everything went very well—Eugenius looks up with something like surprise.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Well. Yes. I suppose it did. No blood. No schism. No cardinals declaring us illegitimate. Colonna fled rather than fought. The French faction speaks of reconciliation rather than war. The Medici provide records rather than obstruction. When I woke this morning, I thought there was a reasonable chance I would be dead by sunset. Or deposed. Or held hostage by my own College.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Instead, the documents are signed. The Camera is secured. The worst actors have fled or cooperate. And a king who owes me nothing sits in my study offering practical counsel about appointments and letters. You are right, Your Majesty. It could have gone much worse. I have spent so many years expecting catastrophe that I have forgotten how to recognize success. Thank you. For the reminder. And for... all of it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens in his chair, and something of the pope returns—the office reasserting itself over the man.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Very well. Let us plan.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reaches for parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: First: the letter to Basel. I will draft it tonight—or begin it, at least. We present the Camera reform as extension of their work. We invite their endorsement. We propose... What do we propose? Simple endorsement? Joint oversight? A delegation from Basel to observe implementation? Rochetaillée spoke of being a bridge. Perhaps we should use him. Send him to Basel as our voice, carrying the letter personally. It would demonstrate that former opponents have joined our cause.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Second: letters to the monarchs. Castile, Aragón, Portugal, France, the Empire, Naples. Each will require different framing. Your letter to your own kingdom. My letters to the others, with your signature alongside mine where appropriate. The Emperor's response matters most. Sigismund has been neutral in the papal-conciliar conflict. If he endorses this approach, it strengthens everything.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Third: appointments. I will think carefully on who deserves elevation. Perhaps...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops, his quill hovering.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: There is something else. Something you said earlier, that I have been turning over in my mind. My nephew. Francesco. Cardinal Rochetaillée said something similar when he spoke with me—that wounded men become dangerous, that grievances left to fester can poison everything. I cannot heal this wound myself. I am the one who inflicted it. But you...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He chooses his words carefully.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are outside our family. You owe Francesco nothing, and he owes you nothing. You have no history with him, no obligations, no debts. Sometimes a word from an outsider reaches where family cannot. Would you consider speaking with him? Not to apologize on my behalf—that is not your place. But simply to... see him. To let him know he is not forgotten in the rush of reform. To give him a chance to speak to someone who will listen without judgment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: I do not ask this lightly. I know you have a thousand demands on your time. But I fear what Francesco may become if he is left alone with his grievance. And I fear what others may make of him if they see an opportunity.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will talk with Francesco. Let us first draft the letter to Basel together.

encounters.recap: Juan and Pope Eugenius strategize post-reform consolidation, planning letters to Basel for parallel legislation and to Christian monarchs for support. The Pope confesses his uncertainty about appointments and grief over alienating his nephew Francesco. Juan agrees to speak with Francesco and help draft diplomatic correspondence.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are outside our family. You owe Francesco nothing, and he owes you nothing. You have no history with him, no obligations, no debts. Sometimes a word from an outsider reaches where family cannot. Would you consider speaking with him? Not to apologize on my behalf—that is not your place. But simply to... see him. To let him know he is not forgotten in the rush of reform. To give him a chance to speak to someone who will listen without judgment. I do not ask this lightly. I know you have a thousand demands on your time. But I fear what Francesco may become if he is left alone with his grievance. And I fear what others may make of him if they see an opportunity.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will talk with Francesco. Let us first draft the letter to Basel together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius nods, a flicker of gratitude crossing his face at your willingness to approach Francesco. But he sets it aside—there is work to do first. He moves to his desk properly now, arranging parchment, ink, and sand for blotting. A second chair is brought, and you sit beside him, the candle casting warm light across the blank page.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The framing. This is everything. We must acknowledge Basel's work without submitting to their authority. We must invite their participation without demanding their approval. We must present the Camera reform as extension of their principles without admitting they have jurisdiction over papal household matters. Let us begin with what we agree upon, and find the difficult language as we go.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The work takes over an hour. Eugenius writes in elegant Latin, pausing frequently to read phrases aloud, to ask your opinion, to scratch out words and try again. The floor around the desk slowly accumulates crumpled parchment—failed attempts, abandoned phrasings, ideas that sounded better in the mind than on the page.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have already signed their decrees on pluralism, concubinage, and annates. Motu proprio—on our own authority. But we should acknowledge that their work inspired ours. Not that they commanded us, but that the Holy Spirit moved both authorities toward the same ends. The reforms which the Sacred Council, moved by the same Spirit that guides the Apostolic See, has wisely advanced... Too much? Too little?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is the delicate part. The Camera is papal household. Basel has no jurisdiction over how we organize our own administration. But if we say that too bluntly, we invite conflict. In the same spirit of renewal that has guided the Council's deliberations, we have undertaken reform of the Apostolic Camera, that the administration of the Church's temporal affairs might better serve her spiritual mission...

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We cannot demand they sign our decree. But we can invite them to add their voice to ours. To declare that the principles underlying our reform are consistent with the principles they themselves have championed. We invite the fathers assembled at Basel to receive this decree in the spirit in which it is offered—as evidence that Rome and Council labor toward the same holy ends, though by different paths... Is that too weak? Should we be more direct?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rochetaillée spoke of being a bridge. If we propose sending him to Basel as our messenger, carrying this letter personally, it demonstrates that former opponents have joined our cause.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is what we must not say. Nothing about supremacy. Nothing about whether councils can command popes or popes can dissolve councils. We speak only of cooperation, shared purpose, parallel efforts. Let the constitutional question remain unresolved—if both authorities are reforming the Church together, perhaps the question becomes academic.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: After much revision, a working draft emerges. Eugenius reads it aloud, his voice steady now, the exhaustion temporarily forgotten in the satisfaction of craftsmanship:

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text:
EUGENIUS, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD

To Our Venerable Brothers, the Cardinals, Archbishops, Bishops, and other Fathers assembled in Sacred Council at Basel, greeting and apostolic benediction.

The renewal of Holy Mother Church, for which all faithful Christians pray, advances by many paths. The Sacred Council, moved by the same Spirit that guides the Apostolic See, has wisely addressed the disorders of pluralism, concubinage, and excessive taxation that have long troubled the Body of Christ. These reforms, which we have received and promulgated by our own apostolic authority, demonstrate that Council and Pope, when animated by shared devotion to Christ's Church, labor toward the same holy ends.

In this same spirit of renewal, we have undertaken reform of the Apostolic Camera, that the administration of the Church's temporal affairs might better serve her spiritual mission. We have appointed our beloved son Tommaso Parentucelli as Extraordinary Commissioner, with authority to examine all arrangements, audit all accounts, and restructure all procedures according to principles of transparency, accountability, and honest stewardship. The enclosed decree sets forth these reforms in detail.

We invite the fathers assembled at Basel to receive this decree in the spirit in which it is offered—not as assertion of authority over Council, nor as submission of papal household to conciliar jurisdiction, but as evidence that Rome and Basel labor toward the same sacred purpose. As we have added our apostolic voice to the Council's reforms, so we invite the Council to add its voice to ours, that all Christendom might see the Church united in renewal.

To this end, we propose to send Our Venerable Brother Jean, Cardinal Priest of San Sisto, to Basel as our messenger and voice. Cardinal Rochetaillée has witnessed the events in Rome and can bear testimony to what he has seen. We commend him to you as one who has journeyed from opposition to cooperation, and whose counsel may assist in discerning how Council and Apostolic See might best coordinate their efforts.

We beseech the fathers at Basel to receive our messenger with charity, to consider our proposals with wisdom, and to join with us in prayer for the unity and renewal of Christ's Church.

Given at Rome, at Saint Peter's, on the [date] day of March, in the year of Our Lord 1434, in the fourth year of our pontificate.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: What say you, Your Majesty? Does this strike the right tone? Is there anything you would add, remove, or change?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. Give me a moment while I draft letters to christian monarchs.

encounters.recap: Juan II and Pope Eugenius IV collaborate to draft a diplomatically delicate letter to the Council of Basel, carefully balancing acknowledgment of the Council's reforms with papal authority. The letter proposes sending Cardinal Rochetaillée as a messenger to demonstrate cooperation while avoiding constitutional questions about papal-conciliar relations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You work through the evening and into the night. The scribe—a young Castilian clerk who traveled with your household—struggles to keep pace as you dictate, revise, and dictate again. Each letter requires different framing, different emphasis, different tone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To Emperor Sigismund — The warmest letter, building on your alliance forged at Como. You remind him of your shared vision, the parallel legislation framework you proposed together, and inform him that it has now been achieved. You ask for his public endorsement, which would carry enormous weight with Basel and all German-speaking lands.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To King João I of Portugal — To your father-in-law, you write with familial respect. You inform him of events in Rome, emphasize the reform's religious rather than political character, and express hope that Portugal will add its voice to Christendom's renewal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To King Alfonso V of Aragón — To your brother-in-law, whose claim to Naples the Pope has already endorsed, you write of mutual interest. A reformed papacy allied with both Iberian crowns strengthens all three. You remind him gently that papal support for his Neapolitan ambitions flows more reliably from a pope who is not beholden to corrupt cardinals or French factions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To King Charles VII of France — The most delicate letter. You write with formal courtesy, making no assumptions about his position. You emphasize that the reform threatens no French interests—indeed, Cardinal Rochetaillée himself now supports reconciliation. You invite France to participate in the Church's renewal rather than oppose it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To King Henry VI of England — A formal letter to a young king ruled by regents, emphasizing shared Christian duty and inviting England's support for Church reform during this troubled time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To King Władysław II Jagiełło of Poland — You write of the Ottoman threat that concerns both your kingdoms, framing Church reform as strengthening Christendom's ability to defend itself. A united, reformed Church can mount the crusade that a corrupt, divided Church cannot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: To the other Christian princes — Shorter letters of similar character, informing them of events and inviting their support.

roll.outcome: Diplomatic triumph. The letters catalyze a wave of support. Sigismund declares the Como vision achieved and pressures Basel toward reconciliation. Multiple monarchs send letters to Rome praising Eugenius's courage. France, unwilling to stand alone against European consensus, joins the chorus of approval. Juan's correspondence has transformed a Roman reform into a Christendom-wide movement. Basel will find it difficult to resist such unified pressure.

encounters.recap: Juan spends the night drafting letters to all major Christian monarchs informing them of the papal reforms and requesting their support. The diplomatic outreach achieves remarkable success, creating a wave of European endorsement that transforms the Roman reforms into a continent-wide movement backed by unified monarchical support.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fires have burned low in the braziers. Your knights have arranged themselves in the patterns of men accustomed to sleeping in uncertain places—backs to walls, weapons within reach, small groups positioned to watch approaches. The Vatican looms above them, its windows dark except for scattered candles where clerks or cardinals work through the night.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Majestad. All quiet. A few servants coming and going. One cardinal's secretary hurried past an hour ago—looked frightened, but that seems to be the normal state of things here.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: The men will hold, Majestad. They've slept in worse places than Roman marble. Some of them are saying this is the best-fed watch they've ever stood.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You clasp his shoulder briefly, then make your way to your quarters. The rooms feel empty without Lucia. Her things have been packed and taken to the ships—the small personal items, the letters she was writing, the embroidery she never finished. Catalina's wooden toys are gone from the corner where they were scattered this morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You undress without assistance, hanging your sword where you can reach it from the bed. Old habit. The mattress is soft—Roman luxury after weeks of shipboard hammocks—but sleep does not come immediately. The day replays behind your closed eyes. Golden light falling through high windows. Cardinals kneeling on cold stone. Eugenius's voice breaking as he confessed his failures.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You wake to Roman bells calling the faithful to morning Mass. Gray light filters through shutters. For a moment, disorientation—where is Lucia? Where is the rocking of the ship? Then memory returns. Rome. The reform. The work that continues.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This day, I send all letters and speak with the french delegation again. Asking if they can accompany the letters to Basel where they can ask for parallel legislation on the camera reforms. I speak with the camerlengo and see if I can soften his wound. I then speak with the Orsini family and their cardinal.

encounters.recap: After reassuring his guards that no challenges appear imminent, Juan retires to his empty chambers where he reflects on the day's momentous events before sleeping. He awakens on March 24th to a full agenda of diplomatic meetings, planning to send letters across Europe, negotiate with the French delegation about Basel, and meet with key Vatican figures including the wounded Cardinal Condulmer and the Orsini family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You break your fast quickly—bread, cheese, and watered wine—while a secretary organizes the letters drafted through the night. Each is sealed with your personal seal, the arms of Castile pressed into red wax. Couriers are summoned: reliable men from your household guard who have carried sensitive correspondence before.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The letter to the Emperor travels fastest. Sigismund's endorsement matters most. Portugal and Aragón next—family ties should yield quick responses. The others as roads allow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The couriers depart within the hour, riding out through Rome's gates toward the roads that web across Europe. Weeks will pass before responses return. But the seeds are planted. You find the French cardinal in a small chapel adjacent to the Vatican, kneeling in prayer. He rises when he hears your footsteps, crossing himself before turning.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I have spent the night in prayer. And in writing. A letter to Cardinal d'Allemand, as I promised. Recommending reconciliation. Explaining what I witnessed yesterday. It is... not an easy letter. I am telling a man I have worked beside for eight years that the cause we fought for has been achieved by the very authority we fought against.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: D'Allemand will not be pleased. But I believe he will listen. He is ambitious, but he is not a fool. If Rome and the princes of Europe unite behind this reform, continued opposition serves no one.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You would send me as the Pope's messenger. The man who spent eight years fighting papal authority, now carrying papal correspondence to the Council that was meant to humble Rome. It is... audacious. And perhaps effective precisely because it is audacious. D'Allemand knows me. He trusts my judgment, even when he disagrees with it. If I stand before the Council and say 'I have seen what Rome has done, and it is genuine reform'—that carries weight that no letter can match.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Yes. I will go. But I will need a few days to prepare. Letters of credential from His Holiness. Safe-conduct documents. And... I would ask that one or two of your Castilian delegation at Basel—Fray Hernando's people—be informed of my coming. If they can prepare ground before I arrive, speak with moderates, lay the foundation for reception...

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: This will not be easy, Your Majesty. D'Allemand has invested too much to simply accept defeat. But if we present this not as defeat but as victory—the Council's reforms achieved, the constitutional question set aside rather than resolved—he may find a path to acceptance. I will be your bridge. God grant I do not collapse under the weight.

encounters.recap: Juan dispatches letters to European rulers seeking support for papal reforms, then meets with Cardinal Rochetaillée who agrees to travel to Basel as papal messenger. The French cardinal has written to d'Allemand recommending reconciliation and will personally carry the Pope's letter to the Council, using his credibility to present the reforms as victory rather than defeat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope's nephew has taken chambers in a remote corner of the Vatican, far from the bustle of the papal apartments. When you request an audience, his secretary—a nervous young priest—hesitates visibly. The room is dim, shutters drawn against the Roman sun. Condulmer sits in a chair by the cold fireplace, still wearing his cardinal's robes but with the rumpled look of a man who has not changed since yesterday. He does not rise when you enter.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: The King of Castile. Come to see the humiliated nephew. To offer comfort, perhaps. Or counsel. Or to ensure I will not cause trouble for the great reform. Sit, if you wish. I have nowhere to be. No duties to perform. My office has been given to a commoner with ink-stained fingers, and my uncle did not see fit to warn me before announcing it to all of Rome. What do you want, Your Majesty? Truly. Not the diplomatic answer. The real one.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am here because your uncle asked me to come. But he did not send me with instructions or arguments or offers. He asked because he cannot reach you himself—he is the one who wounded you, and wounds do not hear clearly from the hands that made them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was not in the room when the decision was made to exclude you. I do not know why your uncle chose as he did. Perhaps he feared you would warn others. Perhaps he thought to protect you from association with what was coming. Perhaps he simply did not think of you at all, consumed by the weight of what he was about to do.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: He chose a commoner over his own blood. A secretary. A man with no family, no name, no—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A man with no complicity. Parentucelli has been watching the Camera for twenty years, burning with fury at what he saw, powerless to act. He is not your replacement, Your Eminence. He is a surgeon called to cut out a cancer. You were never the cancer—but you were standing in the operating theater.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: That does not make it hurt less. Being told I was not the disease, merely... irrelevant.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The reform is real. The corruption was real. Seventy thousand florins meant for crusade—for the defense of Constantinople against the Turk—vanished into 'administrative expenses' in ten months. Men skimmed and stole and called it tradition. Your uncle knew something was wrong but feared to look. When he finally looked, he found rot so deep that only fire could cleanse it.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: And I was part of the rot.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You were part of the system. Whether you were part of the rot— I do not know. I do not think your uncle believes so, or he would not grieve as he does. But that question is between you and God, not you and me.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: I did not know. I should have known—I held the office, I signed the documents—but I did not know. They showed me what they wanted me to see. I asked the questions they expected me to ask. And I told myself that this was how things worked, that my inexperience simply needed time to understand the complexities. Is that corruption? Or merely cowardice?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is a question for confession. Not for a foreign king standing in your chamber.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: You speak honestly. I did not expect that.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have no reason to lie to you, Your Eminence. I have no history with you, no obligations, no debts. I am simply a man who believes the reform is necessary and who would prefer not to see it poisoned by wounds that fester. Your uncle loves you. He does not know how to say so while also doing what he believes God requires of him. These things are not incompatible—but neither are they easy to hold together.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_condulmer
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I will... think on what you have said. I make no promises. But I will think.

roll.outcome: Painful honesty. Juan speaks truthfully about what happened and why. Condulmer listens—not happily, but genuinely. He cannot accept everything Juan says, but he recognizes honesty when he hears it. The conversation plants seeds that may grow over time. Condulmer remains wounded, but the possibility of healing opens.

encounters.recap: Juan attempts to reconcile with the wounded Cardinal Condulmer, who feels betrayed and humiliated by his exclusion from the papal reform. Through painful honesty about the corruption and necessity of change, Juan plants seeds of understanding. Condulmer remains hurt but agrees to consider Juan's words, opening the possibility of future healing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Orsini palazzo lies across the Tiber, a fortress-like structure that has housed one of Rome's two great families for generations. The walk takes you through streets that watch you pass—Romans who have heard rumors of yesterday's events, who see the Castilian king moving through their city with a small escort of knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Giordano Orsini receives you in a private study, richly appointed but not ostentatious. He is a man in his sixties, with the weathered face of someone who has survived Vatican politics for decades. His eyes are shrewd, assessing.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am honored by this visit. Please, sit. Wine?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: I must confess some surprise. I expected perhaps a summons to the Vatican. A formal interview with Parentucelli's investigators. Not a personal call from the King of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: You have spoken with His Holiness, I presume. And with that remarkable French cardinal who seems to have discovered a new vocation as bridge-builder. And now you come to see old Orsini. The family man. The survivor.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: I have provided what assistance I can to the reform, Your Majesty. Information about Camera operations. Intelligence about which officials were most deeply involved. I have done this not from sudden conversion to righteousness—I think we can be honest with each other—but because I recognize which way the wind blows.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: So. You have come to see me. What would you have of House Orsini?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Cardinal Orsini, I am glad to have you on our side in this important and pivotal moment in church history. I shall not forget it, nor shall I forget our first meeting when I was just beginning to emerge as the king I am now. I have sent letters to all the christian princes, many of whom I have previously discussed the need for reform and the need for a strong church. They will support this reform, but they are not in Rome. They are not here. Can I count on the Orsini support to let the pope execute his reforms when I travel on to Constantinople?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: You speak of Constantinople. Of sailing east to face the Turk. Your Majesty, I am not a young man. I have watched three pontificates. I have seen reforms proclaimed and reforms forgotten. I have seen men of genuine conviction ground down by the machinery of this city until they became what they once opposed.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: When you sail east—and you will sail, because you are the man you appear to be—this reform remains in whose hands, exactly? Parentucelli. Yes. A brilliant man. Incorruptible, perhaps. But he is a secretary with a commission. He has no family, no army, no network of obligations built over generations.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: So. You ask if you can count on Orsini support. I ask you: support for what, precisely? A reform built on one man's knights and one man's faith? What happens to that reform—and to those who backed it—when the knights sail east and the faith is tested by distance?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: What is the plan, Your Majesty? When you sail for Constantinople, what holds this together?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am still young at 22 years and I have indeed known nothing but success. Maybe caution will come with the years, who knows. But I will tell you what is within my power and how I will act. The pope has started a reform that has been embraced by both myself and the holy roman emperor. The cardinals have endorsed it and while the council of basel has it's own process, I suspect that they will also sign the camera reform decree. Of the two families, you are the one who has chosen to cooperate. Embrace this reform or not, I do not care. But I will take issue with anyone who opposes it. I have already declared my allegiance to the pope and the reform and I will consider any hostile action against the pope as an act war and will react accordingly. You know what power and influence I command. And I always keep my word. You have a choice. You can let the church reform itself. Or you can join with those who want to violently oppose it. Those who choose violence, I will react in kind. I would rather count you among the allies of the pope, but the choice is yours. The plan is that Basel will sign into law the camera reform decree. Tommaso will seek out the rot in the church and grant amnesty to those who deserve it. Provided no-one decides to attack Rome, the reform will be enacted with or without blood. I prefer without.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: I see. Thank you for clarifying Your Majesty's position.

roll.outcome: Cold withdrawal. Orsini's expression closes completely. Juan has transformed a cooperating ally into a cautious neutral at best. The intelligence, the active assistance, the genuine engagement ends today.

encounters.recap: Juan visits Cardinal Orsini seeking assurances of support when he departs for Constantinople. Orsini asks legitimate questions about structural sustainability of the reform, but Juan responds with threats and ultimatums rather than partnership. The negotiation fails catastrophically, transforming an active ally into a withdrawn neutral who will provide only minimal compliance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The change in Orsini is immediate and unmistakable. The shrewd engagement drains from his face, replaced by something closed and careful. He sets down his wine cup with deliberate precision. When he speaks, his voice has lost all warmth—not hostile, but empty. The voice of a man conducting necessary business.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: I see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises from his chair. The movement is unhurried but final—the audience is over.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Thank you for clarifying Your Majesty's position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the door of the study, clearly expecting you to follow. The walk back through the Orsini palazzo feels different now. The tapestries depicting family glories seem less like welcome and more like reminder: We were here before you. We will be here after. At the entrance, Orsini pauses. His face remains composed—a lifetime of Vatican politics has taught him to reveal nothing.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: House Orsini will not oppose the reform. Your Majesty has made the consequences of opposition quite clear. We are not fools.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A servant appears with your cloak.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: The intelligence I have provided to Parentucelli stands. It is accurate. It will serve the investigation. I do not believe I have anything further to offer that would be of value. House Orsini has other matters requiring attention.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—correctly, precisely, without a degree more warmth than protocol demands.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: God grant Your Majesty success in Constantinople. I am certain the reform will... proceed as it will proceed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The doors of the Orsini palazzo close behind you.

roll.outcome: Cold Withdrawal. Alliance that was valuable cooperation transforms into minimal compliance only.

encounters.recap: A diplomatic ultimatum backfires catastrophically with Cardinal Orsini, who had been actively cooperating and providing intelligence for the reform. His reasonable question about long-term plans meets with threats rather than reassurance, transforming valuable partnership into cold, minimal compliance. A willing ally becomes a cautious neutral.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of Rome's churches toll Prime, calling the faithful to morning prayer. Grey light seeps through the windows of the Palazzo di San Marco. Yesterday changed everything—and nothing. The golden light at St. Peter's. Cardinal Albergati kneeling. Rochetaillée's impossible conversion. The letters dispatched to Christian monarchs. And then the sobering reality: Cardinal Orsini withdrawing to mere compliance, the consistory's passive acceptance, Parentucelli's report of subtle obstruction in the Camera, Cardinal Condulmer's festering grievance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At Ostia, ten ships wait at anchor. Lucia, two-year-old Catalina, and three ladies-in-waiting remain aboard the Santa Catalina, as arranged. Five hundred ninety-one knights—veterans of Granada and the sea journey—await orders. The Constantinople expedition's August deadline presses closer with each passing day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In Rome, the reform hangs by threads of faith and determination. Rochetaillée prepares to depart for Basel as papal messenger. Parentucelli labors against institutional resistance. The Pope has made his grand gesture; now comes the grey work of implementation. Somewhere in the palazzo, Fray Hernando de Talavera has spent the night in prayer, considering Juan's request that he remain in Rome for a year to guide the Pope through the critical implementation period.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning waits.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I assemble all my knights to address them.

encounters.recap: On the morning after the Pope's historic address, Juan faces the complex aftermath of yesterday's miraculous events. While the papal reforms have been announced, institutional resistance remains strong. With his expedition fleet waiting at Ostia and Constantinople's deadline approaching, Juan decides to address his assembled knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Word spreads quickly through the knights' quarters. Within the hour, they have assembled in the courtyard of the Palazzo di San Marco—the largest space available that can accommodate nearly six hundred men. They stand in ranks, these veterans of Granada. Many bear the scars of the Reconquista—a missing finger here, a limping gait there, the weathered faces of men who have seen siege and battle. Their white surcoats with red crosses are travel-worn but clean, maintained with the discipline of soldiers who take pride in their appearance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Among them stand the faces Juan knows well: Marco Tornesi, the former mercenary seeking redemption. Andrea Vescovi, the gangly farmer's son who was the first to take the crusader oath in Barcelona four years ago. Giovanni Rossi, the former blacksmith who prays more than anyone. Brother Guillem, the Benedictine monk-warrior. Captain Rodrigo and Sergeant García, who have been with Juan since the beginning. The morning sun catches the red crosses on their chests. Five hundred ninety-one men who followed their king across the sea, witnessed the golden light in St. Peter's, and now wait to learn what comes next.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers, Yesterday, we have witnessed how the pope reformed the church. A truly momentous occasion we have had the privilege to bear witness of. Today we continue our journey east to Constantinople. I have pledged myself to protect the church and in order to protect the pope, I will require some of our number to remain behind. To observe and to signal if anyone decides to take up arms against the holy father. I require about 10 to remain here. You will not remain here forever, just for a while as the church absorbs this change. You will all return to Castille. Brothers! Have a good meal and cast your eyes on Rome for a final time, for we leave in a few hours for Ostia and the ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur ripples through the assembled knights—not dissent, but the sound of men absorbing news. Constantinople. The name carries weight. They knew this was coming, had known since they boarded ships in Castile, but hearing it spoken aloud makes it real. Marco Tornesi straightens almost imperceptibly, the former mercenary's eyes bright with something that might be anticipation. Andrea Vescovi glances at the men beside him, then back to Juan, his young face solemn. Giovanni Rossi's lips move silently—a prayer, likely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When Juan calls for ten to remain, hands begin to rise. Not eagerly, not reluctantly—with the steady resolve of men who understand duty. More than ten. Perhaps fifteen or eighteen hands.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo
exchanges.text: We'll sort it among ourselves, Your Majesty. Ten good men who can keep their eyes open and their mouths shut.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A rumble of assent from the ranks. Fray Hernando meets Juan's gaze. The Franciscan's weathered face is still, but something passes between them—acknowledgment of the choice being offered, the weight of it. He does not speak. Not here, not before the men. But he inclines his head, very slightly. The conversation will come. Later.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "¡Por Castilla y por Cristo!" someone shouts from the ranks—and five hundred voices take up the cry, echoing off the palazzo walls. "¡Por Castilla y por Cristo!"

encounters.recap: Juan addresses his 591 assembled knights in the courtyard of Palazzo di San Marco, announcing their departure for Constantinople and requesting ten volunteers to remain in Rome as protectors of the Pope during the church reforms. The veterans respond with discipline and loyalty, more than enough volunteering to stay behind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pope Eugenius IV receives Juan in the same private chamber where they drafted the letter to Basel. The Pope looks tired—the grey exhaustion of a man who slept little after a day of momentous action—but there is steel beneath the weariness that was not there a week ago. Tommaso Parentucelli stands beside him, dark circles under his eyes, ink stains on his fingers. The scholar-administrator has clearly worked through the night.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: A kind gesture. Though ten knights against Rome's factions... We are grateful nonetheless. They will be housed and fed at Vatican expense.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of Cardinal Orsini's cooperation. I would... temper that assessment somewhat. The Cardinal fulfills his obligations. He provides information when asked directly. But he no longer volunteers intelligence. No longer anticipates needs. The difference is subtle but significant.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And Cardinal Condulmer remains in his chambers. My own nephew. He has not spoken to me since yesterday morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises, moving to the window that overlooks the city.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You sail east to aid Constantinople against the Turk. A holy mission. We will pray for your success daily. But understand what you leave behind. The reform has the support of princes and bankers. It has the acquiescence of cardinals who cannot oppose it. What it lacks... What it lacks is men who believe in it. Aside from Parentucelli here, and perhaps Rochetaillée—who departs today for Basel—the reform stands on fear and calculation, not conviction.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I leave it to the pope to appoint those who operate in this reformed church. Who have the conviction we seek. This will take time. Even a thousand knights would not help in this regard. You are secured. If anyone moves against you, Naples and Castille stand ready to come to your aid immediately, and our enemies know this. Our reform has been received very well. Now comes the work to follow up. Maybe the pope will be able to find those servants in Basel. Speak to cardinal Rochetaille before he leaves and ask him for men who can replace who have been tainted by corruption. You have the treasury as well. Guard it and use it if need be to build a new church. Almost everything has been going our way. What remains is just honest work.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Basel. Yes. Perhaps there are men there who hunger for a Church worth serving, not merely a benefice worth holding. Tommaso, before Cardinal Rochetaillée departs—speak with him. Ask him to identify reformers of genuine conviction. Men who can be brought to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holiness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope crosses to Juan and takes his hands—an intimate gesture, monarch to monarch, but also something more. Spiritual father to spiritual son.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You speak wisdom beyond your years, Juan of Castile. 'Honest work.' Yes. That is what remains. We have grown accustomed to miracles these past days. Golden light and impossible conversions. Now comes the grey labor of making those miracles permanent. Benedictio Dei omnipotentis, Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, descendat super te et maneat semper. Go with God to Constantinople. Defend the faith against the Turk as you have defended it against corruption. And return to us safely.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. What you have begun here... I will not let it fail. Whatever it costs.

encounters.recap: Juan bids farewell to Pope Eugenius IV and Tommaso Parentucelli before departing for Constantinople. They discuss the fragile state of the church reform, acknowledging that while secured by fear and calculation, it lacks true believers beyond a few key figures. The Pope blesses Juan's mission and commits to finding genuine reformers from Basel to strengthen their cause.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds Lucia aboard, in the great cabin. Two-year-old Catalina sits on the floor, playing with a wooden horse carved by one of the sailors. She looks up as Juan enters, her face breaking into a smile.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises from where she has been watching their daughter. Her belly has begun to show now—five months along, perhaps six. She moves more carefully than she once did.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Juan. The men say we sail today.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina squeals with delight as Juan lifts her, her small hands reaching for his face. At two years old, she has her mother's dark eyes and a child's boundless curiosity.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Barcos! Agua!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She has been fascinated by everything. The sailors. The ropes. The seabirds. One of the men—Pascual, I think—carved her that horse. She won't let it out of her sight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Caballo!

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The port... Busy. Roman merchants, mostly. Some looked at our ships with too much interest for my comfort. Doña Beatriz thinks they were merely curious, but... I will be glad when we are at sea again. What happened in Rome? The men speak of golden light and cardinals kneeling. Some say it was a miracle.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He tells her everything. The Mass at St. Peter's—the golden light that poured through the windows as Eugenius spoke, the cardinals who knelt, the 'Deo gratias' that shook the basilica. RochetaillÃ©e's impossible conversion. The letters dispatched to every Christian monarch. And then the rest. Cardinal Orsini's face when Juan pushed too hard. The consistory's passive acceptance without conviction. Parentucelli's reports of subtle obstruction. Cardinal Condulmer nursing his grievance.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: A blacksmith knows when the metal is ready. And when it needs more time at the forge. You have done what you could in Rome. More than anyone expected. More than anyone had a right to ask. But Constantinople is not Rome, Juan. The Turks are not cardinals who can be shamed into kneeling. What waits for us in the East?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds the captain of the Santa Catalina on deck—a weathered Castilian named Diego de Vargas, grey-bearded and sun-darkened from decades at sea.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_vargas
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The exercises. Better than the first day. Not yet what I'd want if the Mistral caught us in open water. We've run the storm drill twice more since you left for the Vatican. The San Marcos and Catalina perform well—Pascual's crew especially. They've taken to the competitions. The converted carracks still struggle. Their crews weren't trained for war or weather—merchant sailors, most of them. They're learning, but... The journey to Naples is short. The journey to Constantinople is not. We'll be ready for Naples by the evening tide, Your Majesty. As for what comes after—we'll keep drilling. Every calm day, every safe harbor. The men understand the stakes now.

encounters.recap: Juan reunites with his family aboard the Santa Catalina in Ostia. He shares the full account of his Roman triumph and setbacks with Lucia, who offers wisdom about the challenges ahead. Captain Diego reports on fleet exercises and readiness for the voyage to Naples, noting improvement but acknowledging the need for more training time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first day passed without incident—fair winds from the north, the fleet making good time along the Italian coast. Catalina delighted in watching the dolphins that played in the Santa Catalina's wake. The carrack crews, drilled relentlessly by their captains, showed signs of improvement. Then, on the morning of the second day, the lookout's cry shattered the calm.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan reaches the deck to find Captain Vargas already at the rail, shading his eyes against the morning glare. Three ships on the southern horizon, their lateen sails unmistakable.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: Corsairs. Out of Tunis or Algiers, most like. Galleys—fast and nimble. They've seen us.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: They won't attack ten ships, Your Majesty—not unless they're mad or desperate. But our carracks are slow. If they shadow us, probe for weakness, catch a straggler... We can hold formation and protect her—but that slows everyone. Or we can signal the warships to chase them off—but that splits the fleet and leaves the carracks vulnerable.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captain, we form up with the carracks on front, shielding the slower, less defended ships. If they come close, fire the cannons. We are well-armed, let them know that we are looking for a fight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Signal flags run up the mast. Across the fleet, captains respond. The five warships—galleys built for speed and combat—spread into a protective screen. The carracks, heavy and bristling with cannons, form up at the front of the formation, their gun ports open, bronze barrels glinting in the morning sun. The rumble of cannon carriages rolling forward echoes across the water.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corsair galleys continue their approach for several minutes, closing the distance. Then, as the formation becomes clear—as the morning light catches the cannon barrels and the red crosses on white surcoats lining the rails—the lead galley's oars shift rhythm. They're turning.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: They're not fools. Three galleys against this? They'd take one ship, maybe two, and lose all three in the doing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan brings Catalina to the deck, holding her securely as she points at the distant sails. Her dark eyes are wide with curiosity—at two years old, she does not yet understand danger.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: ¿Barcos, Papá?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No quiero.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She's too young to understand, but not too young to remember. My grandmother used to tell me stories of Barbary raids on the Portuguese coast. Whole villages taken. Children who never saw their parents again. This is why you go to Constantinople. This is why you build ships.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corsairs finally turn away as darkness falls, vanishing into the southern blackness. By morning, the fleet is exhausted. The carrack crews, already inexperienced, have been pushed hard maintaining formation through the night. The fleet limps into Naples under the shadow of Vesuvius.

exchanges.speaker: captain_vargas
exchanges.text: We made it, Your Majesty. But if those had been Turkish galleys instead of Tunisian corsairs—faster, better armed, more numerous... The men need rest. The carrack crews need more drilling. And we need to think hard about the route east.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Start training for hostile naval encounters as well captain. I head for the harbour and meet with the master.

roll.outcome: Serious trouble. Corsair sighting forces defensive formation. Fleet limps into Naples with problems to solve.

encounters.recap: Three Barbary corsairs shadow the fleet during the voyage to Naples, forcing a defensive formation with carracks screening the passenger ships. Juan's tactical decision to display cannon strength deters attack, but the night passage exhausts crews and exposes the fleet's vulnerabilities for the longer journey to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The streets of Naples are tense. Armed men in Aragonese colors patrol in groups, watching rooftops and alleyways. Merchants have shuttered early. Women hurry children indoors. The atmosphere is not that of a city preparing for victory—it is the brittle quiet of a city bracing for siege. At the gates of Castel Nuovo, a harried official recognizes the Castilian royal standard and nearly weeps with relief.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the courtyard, wounded men sit against walls, being tended by surgeons. Their bandages are fresh—days old, not weeks. A cluster of knights in battered armor speak in low, angry voices. One has his arm in a sling. Another bears a half-healed gash across his face.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso V of Aragon stands at a table covered with maps, correspondence, and the detritus of desperate planning. He is forty years old, but today he looks older. His clothes are fine but rumpled, as though he dressed without the aid of servants. Dark circles rim his eyes. His jaw is shadowed with several days' growth.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Juan. You've heard, then.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I heard de Anjou brought an army and that you were defeated.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Defeated. Yes. Defeated. Louis died in November. We thought that was the end of it. The Angevins had no army here, no money, no support. Queen Joanna was ready to sign the adoption. The Calabrian barons were with me. I held Reggio, Catanzaro, half the south. Sforza's condottieri were marching north toward Naples itself. Then René came.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Ten thousand men. French knights, Provençal infantry, Genoese crossbowmen. He landed at Gaeta in January with a fleet we never saw coming. Genoa provided the ships. Milan provided the money. They'd rather see a French puppet on the Naples throne than an Aragonese king controlling the western Mediterranean.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Aversa. Two weeks ago. Sforza's men broke. Broke. The finest condottieri in Italy, and they broke against French heavy cavalry. René's knights went through them like paper. I lost two thousand men in an afternoon. The rest scattered. Sforza himself fled to Milan to renegotiate his contract—with René. I hold Naples. This city, this castle, and perhaps a dozen miles in any direction. The barons who swore to me are 'reconsidering their positions.' Queen Joanna has gone silent. And René of Anjou sits at Aversa with an army I cannot match, waiting for me to starve or surrender.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How is he able to sustain such a large campaign and for so long? Does he indeed have such deep pockets?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: René? Deep pockets? The man was ransoming his own jewelry to pay debts three years ago. Duke of Anjou, Duke of Bar, Duke of Lorraine through his wife—titles enough for three kings, and barely the income of a prosperous count. No. René is the sword. Others provide the arm.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Genoese hate me. Hate Aragon. We threaten their trade routes, their dominance in the western sea. They provided the fleet that brought René's army—forty ships, Juan. Forty. And they didn't do it for love of France. Filippo Maria Visconti. The snake of Milan. He funded Sforza to fight for me, then funded René to fight against me. He plays all sides, always. A strong Aragon in Naples threatens his ambitions in Lombardy. A weak French puppet he can manipulate? That serves him perfectly.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Between them—Genoa's ships, Milan's gold—René has what he needs. For now. But such coalitions are fragile. Visconti will betray René the moment it suits him, just as he betrayed me. The question is whether I survive long enough to see it. There are also whispers about French gold directly. Charles VII is no longer the desperate dauphin hiding behind Joan of Arc's skirts. France recovers. And René is married to Charles's sister-in-law. The French crown may see Naples as worth an investment.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I am not fighting one man, Juan. I am fighting half of Italy and perhaps France itself. And right now, I am losing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What is the naval situation? Can we reinforce Naples from Iberia? Can I land a Castilian army?

roll.outcome: French intervention. René of Anjou arrived with a French army. Alfonso's forces crushed in battle. He's alive but his army is shattered. Years of work undone.

encounters.recap: Alfonso reveals the catastrophic defeat at Aversa two weeks prior, where René of Anjou's French army of 10,000 men crushed his forces and Sforza's condottieri. Backed by Genoa and Milan, René now controls most of southern Italy while Alfonso holds only Naples itself, facing potential siege or surrender.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: There are also whispers about French gold directly. Charles VII is no longer the desperate dauphin hiding behind Joan of Arc's skirts. France recovers. And René is married to Charles's sister-in-law. The French crown may see Naples as worth an investment. I am not fighting one man, Juan. I am fighting half of Italy and perhaps France itself. And right now, I am losing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso moves to the window overlooking the bay, where the masts of ships are visible in the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: My fleet survives. Mostly. Fourteen war galleys. Eight armed carracks. Some smaller vessels. They're anchored here, under the castello's guns. René has no fleet of his own in these waters—the Genoese returned home after landing his army. They're merchants, not soldiers. They delivered their cargo and left.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The sea is... contested but not closed. Genoese raiders harry the approaches. They took two of my supply ships last month. But they cannot blockade Naples. Not with what they have here. The route from Sicily remains open. My brother controls Palermo. Grain still reaches us.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: From Castile? From Aragon? The voyage is long. A thousand miles from Barcelona. Fifteen hundred from Seville. Through waters where Genoa is strong—the Balearics, Sardinia, the Tyrrhenian. An army would need transport ships, escort vessels, supplies for weeks at sea. Could you land a Castilian army? Yes. In theory. But how large? How soon? René has ten thousand men. To break him in the field, I would need... eight thousand? Ten? Fresh, well-supplied, well-led. And time to coordinate, to plan, to strike before Visconti sends more gold or Genoa sends more ships.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You have ten ships in my harbor, Juan. Knights enough to hold a wall, not storm a field. What exactly are you asking? What are you offering?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso exhales slowly. He moves to a chair and sits heavily, the first time he has allowed himself to show physical exhaustion since Juan entered.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I have three choices. First. I hold Naples and wait. René's coalition is unnatural—Genoa and Milan despise each other. Visconti is already negotiating with Florence against Genoa's interests. Given time, they will turn on each other. They always do. But time requires food, gold, and men. I have perhaps two months of supplies. My treasury is nearly empty. And every week I sit here, more barons abandon me for René.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Second. I negotiate. René is not unreasonable. He might accept my withdrawal in exchange for... something. Recognition of his claim. Perhaps some territorial concession in Sicily or Sardinia. I go home to Aragon with my life and my fleet, and I abandon twelve years of work.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Third. I withdraw to Sicily. Regroup. My brother holds Palermo. The island is loyal. I could rebuild, wait for René's coalition to collapse, return in a year or two or five. My father spent twenty years fighting for this crown. Perhaps I am meant to spend twenty more. What this means for my position? It means I am not yet defeated, but I am not far from it. It means the three-kingdom alliance we dreamed of in Granada is... delayed. Perhaps for years. Perhaps forever. Unless something changes.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Joanna. She is sixty-one years old. She has outlived two husbands, three adopted heirs, and countless predictions of her imminent death. Her health? Failing. She does not leave the Castel Capuano. Her physicians attend her constantly. Some say it is her heart. Others say her lungs. She coughs blood, they whisper. She has been 'dying' for five years. And yet she persists.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: She adopted me in 1421. Revoked it in 1423 for Louis. Was negotiating to restore it when René arrived. Now she waits. She has always waited—playing suitors against each other, never committing until the last possible moment. It is how she has survived. If she dies without naming an heir, Naples descends into chaos—every faction fighting for the crown. If she names René, his position becomes unassailable. If she names me... She will not name me while René sits at Aversa with ten thousand men and I cower behind these walls. Joanna respects strength. She adopted me when I was ascendant. She abandoned me when Louis seemed stronger. Now René holds the field. Why would she choose the losing side?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It's time for Castille to enter this war. If you would accept it. I will sail on to Constantinople and I will write my regent to raise an army to come to Sicily. The Genoese have no reason to fight a christian army on it's way to Sicily. Only when they have arrived do I declare officially. When I have returned from Constantinople, the Castillian army will have arrived. Then we land, strike and end this war. And we cement the three crowns alliance in blood if needed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso goes very still. For a long moment, he simply stares at Juan. The mask of careful diplomacy, the shield of wounded pride—both slip, revealing something raw beneath. Hope. Desperate, dangerous hope. He opens his mouth, closes it. Turns away toward the window. His shoulders rise and fall with a deep breath. When he turns back, his eyes are wet, though no tears fall.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You would do this. Commit Castile to war in Italy. For me. For Naples. The timing... yes. The Genoese cannot justify attacking a Christian fleet bound for Constantinople. By the time your army reaches Sicily, René will have grown complacent. His coalition will have frayed. And then... How many men? An army large enough to break René in the field—eight thousand? Ten? Castile has strength, but your Military Orders have obligations, your nobles have their own concerns. And the cost— Transporting an army across the Mediterranean is ruinously expensive. Feeding them, supplying them, paying them while they wait...

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: What do you want, Juan? We spoke in Granada of alliance. Of three kingdoms united. But this— This is not alliance. This is salvation. You would be rescuing the King of Aragon from his own failed war. That is not a debt easily repaid.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This will however unite our kingdoms and our family. I have spent some time in Barcelona and everyone seems to be talking about the Aragonese succession. That I am the next in line. I have never spoken about this with you personally. How can we prevent another succession war not only for Aragon but for Naples as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso is silent for a long moment. His hand moves absently to the edge of the map, fingers tracing the coastline of Aragon as though touching something precious. When he speaks, his voice is quieter than before. The bluster is gone.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You know, when I was young, I thought I would have sons. Many sons. An heir for Aragon. An heir for Sicily. An heir for Naples, when I won it. A dynasty to rival the Capetians. María and I... we tried. For years. The physicians, the pilgrimages, the prayers. Nothing. And now she is past the age. There will be no sons of my body.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Everyone talks of it. Barcelona, Valencia, Zaragoza, Palermo. They look at me and they see a king without an heir. They look at you and they see... Granada. Constantinople. Two healthy children. A young wife who may give you more. I am not a fool, Juan. I know what the lawyers say. I know the genealogies. If I die without legitimate issue, the Crown of Aragon passes to your line through your mother. And if I win Naples and then die without issue, Naples becomes... complicated.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: So. You offer me an army. You raise the succession. These are not separate things in your mind, I think. What are you proposing, exactly? That we formalize what the lawyers already assume? That we bind Naples to the arrangement somehow? I am not opposed to discussing this. I would rather my life's work pass to you than be torn apart by squabbling cousins and Angevin pretenders.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: But I am also not a man who signs documents while a French army sits ten miles from his walls. Such agreements would look like... coercion. My nobles would question whether I acted freely. Your nobles would wonder what you promised to extract such terms. Win this war with me first. Fight beside me, not merely for me. And when René is broken and Naples is secure—then we discuss how to bind our kingdoms together properly. In strength, not in desperation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Is that acceptable?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont want Naples to fall into war again. It deserves a clear succession. And it indeed fits into my vision for a christian alliance that can challenge the Ottomans. Let us first win you the crown of Naples cousin. And with me on the field, we shall not fail.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan summons a scribe and dictates a letter to Álvaro. He orders the raising of an army of 15,000 Castilians consisting of noble and crown troops to be ferried to Sicily. The Mendozas are to command the army, which will assemble in Sicily and await Juan's return from Constantinople.

encounters.recap: Juan commits Castile to war in Italy, promising Alfonso a 15,000-man army to be assembled in Sicily while Juan continues to Constantinople. They discuss the Aragonese succession, with Alfonso acknowledging Juan as his likely heir while insisting they win the war before formalizing any agreements. The two kings shake hands on a partnership that will unite their kingdoms and secure Naples against René of Anjou.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso grips Juan's hand firmly. Something passes between them—not quite brotherhood, not yet, but the foundation of it. An understanding.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Cousin

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A scribe is summoned—a nervous Aragonese clerk who was not expecting to take dictation from the King of Castile. He sets up his writing desk with trembling hands, quill poised. Juan dictates a letter to Don Álvaro de Luna, commanding him to raise an army of fifteen thousand men consisting of noble levies and crown troops, to be transported to Sicily under the command of Don Íñigo López de Mendoza. The army is to assemble in Palermo by July 1434 and await Juan's return from Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scribe looks up, quill hovering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The date for assembly, Your Majesty? And shall I note anything regarding funding for such an enterprise?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The nobles will be assembling as is their noble obligation. Supplies and transport will be provided by the crown treasury. Assemble the men in Palermo in July 1434.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
