exchanges.text: The Emperor glances at the Patriarch but says nothing. The men arrange themselves around the table. Maps of Constantinople, the Bosphorus, Thrace, and Anatolia spread before them. The Emperor gestures to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile. He has come to help us plan our defense. And to understand our situation as it truly is.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: And what authority does the King of Castile hold in this planning?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: As you may know, I have already offered Constantinople aid as a gift. I ask nothing in return. And I foresee three choices before us. I shall provide shelter and refuge for the Byzantines in my kingdom. There you can live in peace and preserve your religion and culture. But it means leaving Constantinople. If you do not want that, I leave my gifts behind and sail away so the empire can sail its own course and maybe be absorbed by the Muslims. Tonight we are planning for the third option. An option that asks tremendous sacrifice both in blood and in pride. It is an option, mind you. Not a demand, rather a choice the Byzantine people should make. A choice with alternatives, for a choice without an alternative is no choice at all. I say this because I know that what I am about to plan for, may sound outlandish, maybe even insulting to the proud and prestigious people of the empire. I remind you again that we are planning for a choice, that this is not a demand. That I require authority not for personal gain or glory, but to unite everyone under one banner, one purpose. There simply is no time, space or room anymore for the old ways. We adapt or we die among ancient tradition. Now, firstly, Religion. Whatever will be discussed, the matter of the Filioque will not be. Now is not the time of religious reform or mending of the schism. That may come later if it will come at all. But I require nothing from the church except for the support both in holy service as in monetary terms as we all will have to pay. Secondly. I am in command. Me and only me. I will lead not just the defense of Constantinople, I will also have to lead the crowns of Naples, Aragon, Castile and Portugal in this fight and negotiate alliances with other christian kingdoms such as Hungary, Poland and the holy Roman empire. I have led a reconquista before and will do so again. Part of the choice is if the Byzantine people trust me with the leadership. Remember, I am not demanding, it is a choice. Thirdly, I will require you to fight like devils. No more hiding behind walls, titles or privilege. Christianity fights for your empire, and you will fight the hardest of all. I will militarize the nobility and arm every citizen. Trade, the church and science will be geared towards warfare. Everyone fights. Tonight we will draft proposals that detail in more specific terms what I have just laid out. So we can present this choice to the empire. After it has been presented, I will wait and will let you make a choice awaiting whatever you decide. You have been summoned to help me and the emperor in doing just this. Is everyone in this room ready to proceed?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence follows Juan's words. It stretches. The fire pops. A candle gutters.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: You are in command. You. A Western king who arrived this afternoon. Who has never walked our walls. Who does not speak our tongue. Who knows nothing of Ottoman tactics, nothing of our treaties, nothing of our situation. And you expect us to hand you everything? Our armies, our treasury, our nobility, our empire?

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: The Megas Doux speaks harshly, but he speaks truth. You say you demand nothing of the Church. You say the Filioque will not be discussed. Pretty words. But what you do demand is worse. You demand we place our faith—our survival—in a Latin king. A servant of the Pope, whatever you claim tonight. And when you have command of our armies, our walls, our people... what then? The Fourth Crusade came to help us as well. They burned our libraries. They stole our relics. They put a Latin patriarch in the Hagia Sophia for sixty years. And now another Westerner offers help. Offers choices. And we are to trust him?

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is madness. We cannot hand our empire to a stranger on the basis of one dinner conversation. The nobles will never accept it. The people will riot. And when the Sultan hears that Constantinople has become a Castilian puppet—

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Enough. King Juan is our guest. He has come farther than any Western prince to—

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: To what? To conquer us with kindness instead of swords? The result is the same, Your Majesty. We become a province of Spain.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: I came tonight to hear this Western king for myself. I have heard enough.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Demand? Conquer and subjugate Constantinople? I have been warned for Byzantine pride before but I chose not to believe it. Father Patriarch, leave if you must but know that I do not like my words twisted. I have not demanded anything. I have only given aid and respect. Me not demanding the Byzantines to trust me is the entire point of a choice. You heard that I demand this trust tonight, but that was not what I said. Tonight we develop a plan and offer it as a choice to you all. Then you can take time to get to know me and for me to know you. No choice tonight or tomorrow but later when we are ready. And if you choose to go your own way, I will bless you, leave my 60,000 florins in your care. And I will bid you farewell as I sail back to my kingdom. All I ask of this council is to help shape this plan. To at least give this choice a chance. For the Byzantines to have the chance to make a choice in the first place. I buried almost 100 of my men on my way here. I cannot help but feel like their deaths have been in vain if we just give up now.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: One hundred men. Buried at sea. I do not doubt your sacrifice, King of Castile. I do not doubt your sincerity. But sincerity is not wisdom. And sacrifice does not confer the right to command. Many sincere men have led armies to destruction. Many sacrifices have been made in vain. I will not help shape a plan that places Constantinople under Latin authority. Not tonight. Not ever. If that is the only choice you offer, then we have nothing more to discuss.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: The Patriarch speaks for the Church. I speak for those who have wealth to lose. You ask us to give up everything on faith. Faith in a man we met today. Your Majesty, I have served your family for thirty years. I will not abandon you. But I will not endorse this proposal. Not as it stands. When the King of Castile has a plan that does not require us to become his subjects, I will listen. Until then...

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: That... could have gone better.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Patriarch will oppose anything that smells of Rome. He always has. Notaras will oppose anything that threatens his purse. But they have not said no. Not finally. They have said not yet. One hundred men buried at sea. My soldiers die on the walls every month. Fewer, but they die. I am not leaving this room, King of Castile. I want to hear your plan.

roll.outcome: Bitter stalemate. The Patriarch pauses but does not return. Notaras remains hostile. No progress, but no further deterioration. The meeting ends in cold silence.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a radical defense plan requiring complete Byzantine submission to his military command. The cabinet reacts with hostile rejection—Patriarch Joseph II and Loukas Notaras walk out, viewing the proposal as Western conquest disguised as aid. Despite Juan's emotional appeal about his 100 dead soldiers, only Kantakouzenos remains willing to continue planning. The meeting fractures but does not completely collapse.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Patriarch will oppose anything that smells of Rome. He always has. Notaras will oppose anything that threatens his purse. But they have not said no. Not finally. They have said not yet. One hundred men buried at sea. My soldiers die on the walls every month. Fewer, but they die. I am not leaving this room, King of Castile. I want to hear your plan.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We continue. Summon another senior captain who wants to cooperate with this planning session, and likewise summon someone who can speak of the church and it's politics and position. These two have excluded themselves from this planning session, we go on without them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor and Kantakouzenos exchange a glance. Kantakouzenos rubs his jaw. 'Another captain. I have men who would listen. Men who are tired of waiting to die. Alexios Philanthropenos. Commands the garrison at the Gate of Charisius—where your knights are quartered. He has worked alongside your Don Juan de Sotomayor. He respects the Castilians.' The Emperor's expression is more troubled. 'The Church is... more difficult. The Patriarch has made his position clear. Any priest who participates tonight without his blessing risks censure. Possibly excommunication.' Sphrantzes clears his throat. 'There is one possibility, Your Majesty. Father Gennadios. He is not senior—a scholar more than a politician. But he has written extensively on the question of Western relations. He believes union with Rome is heresy, yet he has also argued that Orthodoxy must find ways to survive, not merely remain pure while dying.' The Emperor frowns. 'Gennadios is... unpredictable.' 'He is honest,' Sphrantzes replies quietly. 'And he is not afraid of the Patriarch.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: An hour later, the fire has been rebuilt. Fresh candles burn. Wine and bread have been brought—working fuel for a long night. Two new men have joined the table. Alexios Philanthropenos — A lean man in his thirties, dark-bearded, wearing armor that has seen real use. He carries himself like a soldier who has stopped caring about politics and only wants clear orders. Father Gennadios Scholarios — Younger than expected, perhaps forty. Black robes, a scholar's ink-stained fingers, and eyes that burn with intelligence. He sits apart from the others, watching Juan like a man studying a theological problem.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Gentlemen. We are here to draft a plan—a proposal to present to our people. A choice. King Juan will explain what he envisions. Listen. Ask questions. Help us shape something that might actually work.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: I watched the Patriarch leave. I watched Notaras leave. You understand, King of Castile, that whatever we build tonight, those two will try to tear down tomorrow?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will draft a plan for victory. Then we will see. I will see. I explain to the new members of the council again what we are about to set up. And that it is a choice, not a demand.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan lays out the proposal again. The choice. The three options. The requirements for the third path—unified command, total mobilization, everyone fights. Philanthropenos listens with his arms folded, his dark eyes fixed on the maps. His expression betrays nothing. Gennadios sits with his ink-stained fingers steepled before his lips, watching Juan the way a theologian watches a disputant whose argument may contain hidden heresy.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You say unified command. You say you command. I have four hundred men at the Gate of Charisius. Your Sotomayor has three hundred Castilians. Together, perhaps we could hold one section of the walls. Four miles of walls. Ninety-six towers. We would need ten thousand men to defend them properly. We have perhaps three thousand, including your knights. You speak of victory. Of driving back the Ottomans. With what? Where do these armies come from? How do they arrive before Murad decides the time has come?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The military questions are for soldiers. I have others. You say you demand nothing of the Church. You say the Filioque will not be discussed. This is... appreciated. But you also say the Church must contribute. Monetary terms, you said. Holy service. What does this mean, precisely? The monasteries own lands. The Patriarch controls revenues. If you militarize the nobility and arm every citizen, what happens to Church properties? Church privileges? Church authority over its own affairs? I am not the Patriarch. I do not reject cooperation with the West on principle. But I must understand what I would be defending before I defend it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am glad you question me like this! To address the military ones first: We do indeed require not 2000 more soldiers, not even 10,000 more. I will seek to lead an alliance of over 100,000 troops from multiple corners of Christianity. Castille commands around 50,000 troops but with the aid of my alliance network, I am sure we are able to raise this number. Holding the walls is not our goal. We will drive them from the European continent and break them in the field. The time to cower behind walls is over. I have founded an academy in Toledo that studies Ottoman tactics and these 1000 knights have been trained using the most modern techniques and 10 junior officers are here as observers to later lead the armies that will be fighting the Ottomans. And regarding the spiritual side. I will militarize the church as well. Take inspiration from how the latin church has won the reconquista. Military orders of warrior monks who dedicate their lives to fighting the muslims. Churches blessing warriors and collect money to fund the effort. Crusades uniting churches and collect funds for these wars. Everyone fights. The church may not hold a sword, it fights in a different way.

roll.outcome: Cautious distance. They hear Juan out, ask probing questions, but make no commitments. The plan can be discussed, but trust is thin. Progress will be slow.

encounters.recap: After the Patriarch and Notaras storm out, Juan calls for replacement advisors. Two new men join the council: Captain Philanthropenos and Father Gennadios. Both listen cautiously to Juan's grand plan but raise pointed questions about military logistics and Church authority. The new council maintains polite distance, willing to discuss but making no firm commitments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am glad you question me like this! To address the military ones first: We do indeed require not 2000 more soldiers, not even 10,000 more. I will seek to lead an alliance of over 100,000 troops from multiple corners of Christianity. Castile commands around 50,000 troops but with the aid of my alliance network, I am sure we are able to raise this number. Holding the walls is not our goal. We will drive them from the European continent and break them in the field. The time to cower behind walls is over. I have founded an academy in Toledo that studies Ottoman tactics and these 1000 knights have been trained using the most modern techniques and 10 junior officers are here as observers to later lead the armies that will be fighting the Ottomans. And regarding the spiritual side. I will militarize the church as well. Take inspiration from how the Latin church has won the reconquista. Military orders of warrior monks who dedicate their lives to fighting the Muslims. Churches blessing warriors and collect money to fund the effort. Crusades uniting churches and collect funds for these wars. Everyone fights. The church may not hold a sword, it fights in a different way.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: One hundred thousand. I have fought the Ottomans for fifteen years. I have seen what they bring to the field. Discipline. Janissaries who do not break. Sipahi cavalry that flows like water around any formation. One hundred thousand Christians, united under one command, fighting as one army... If you could deliver such a thing, it would be the greatest host Christendom has assembled since the First Crusade. But how? Castile is far. Aragon is entangled in Italy. Portugal faces Africa. Hungary bleeds against the Turks already. Poland looks east to the steppe. I do not doubt your ambition, King of Castile. But ambition is not soldiers. Where do these hundred thousand men come from? When do they arrive? And what holds them together when they are here?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: Military orders. Warrior monks. The Templars. The Hospitallers. Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara. The Latin church created these orders over centuries. They answered to the Pope. They held vast lands, vast wealth. They became powers unto themselves—until kings and popes destroyed them for that very reason. You propose to create such orders for the Orthodox church. In months, not centuries. Without papal authority to bind them. Without lands to sustain them. And you expect the monasteries—who have guarded their independence for a thousand years—to simply... transform themselves into soldiers? I do not say it is impossible. I say I do not understand how you imagine it would work. The monks of Mount Athos would sooner burn their monasteries than take up swords. The Patriarch would excommunicate any priest who blessed such an order without his sanction. You speak of everyone fighting. But the Church fights with prayer, with teaching, with the preservation of sacred truth. If you wish to change that—if you wish Orthodox monks to become Latin-style warrior orders—you must explain how. And you must explain who would lead them, fund them, command them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Gennadios, yes yes, very good. But again, do not twist my words. I said TAKE INSPIRATION from the Latin church. Not copy it. You are here exactly because we need to figure out what this would look like in the Orthodox tradition. Otherwise I could ask any of my Catholic priests instead. Tonight we will ask ourselves: 'If the Orthodox church would turn every effort into winning this war, what would that look like?' Can you help us answer that question Gennadios? And regarding the soldiers we do not have: Yes, I cannot snap my fingers and summon the Polish king into this room. We do not know what moves them. We hope to invite them into an alliance and attack the Ottomans together. That is why the structure we set up is so important. If I meet with them, I have the authority to bind the entire alliance. And that there is a structure that fighting the Ottomans actually is rewarded. The structure would be something like this: The kingdoms of Naples, Aragon, Castile and perhaps Portugal enter into a strong alliance of crowns. My family sits on these thrones so I hold much direct control over them already. Any lands taken from the Ottomans will be distributed using the crusade system. The reconquista, a concept familiar to the Iberians. The Poles and the Hungarians already border the Ottomans. I think it will not take much to convince them to attack with us. But only if we are serious about attacking them and the Ottomans are seriously occupied. That is why the structure is so important. If we attack them from all sides, Hungary and Poland gain lands and they press forward and what was once Greek lands will be reconquered. We may yet lose. We may yet be defeated. But if we have a good plan and the Byzantines choose to fight, I think we should.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: If the Orthodox church would turn every effort into winning this war. What would that look like. The monasteries hold wealth. Lands. Gold. Relics that pilgrims pay to venerate. They could tithe for war. They have done so before, in centuries past, when emperors demanded it. The Patriarch would resist, but if the people believed the cause was holy... The monks will not become knights. That is not our tradition. But they could support knights. Pray for them. Bless them. Tend their wounded. Copy their letters. Preserve their names for history. The monasteries were fortresses once, in darker times. Some still have walls. They could shelter refugees, store supplies, serve as waypoints. And there is this: we have priests who fight. Not officially. Not with the Patriarch's blessing. But village priests who took up swords against raiders. Monks who died on the walls in sieges past. The tradition exists, even if we do not speak of it. If you want the Orthodox church to fight—truly fight—you do not create military orders. You create a holy cause. A crusade in all but name. You have the Emperor proclaim that the defense of Constantinople is sacred duty. You have priests preach it from every pulpit. You have monks process through the streets with icons and relics, blessing the soldiers, cursing the enemy. The Patriarch would hate it. But if the people believed... the Patriarch would have to follow or be swept aside.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Multi-front war. Press them from all sides. Sound strategy. The Ottomans are strong, but they cannot be everywhere. If Hungary strikes while we hold the straits, if Poland threatens their northern vassals... But timing is everything. If we attack before the others are ready, we die alone. If they attack before we are ready, they die alone. How do you coordinate armies separated by a thousand miles? How do you ensure the Hungarians do not make peace the moment they have taken what they want? I have seen alliances. They promise much. They deliver little. Each king thinks first of his own lands, his own glory. What makes this different? What binds them?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Once we have proven we are a serious challenge to the Ottomans, I can let greed do much of the work. If the Ottomans are challenged near Constantinople, soon, the kings of Poland and Hungary will see that the lands bordering them will be easy prey. It requires us to take up the sword first and they will not move until they have seen us match the Turks in the field and will. But once we have, they will not be able to defend their northern border. Greed is a powerful ally. But we will have to stand on our own first, I have no doubt about it. That is why our plan is so important. We build up our strength, and sooner or later, others will descend on them as well.

exchanges.speaker: katakolon_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Greed. Yes. I have seen what greed does to alliances. It can tear them apart. But it can also bind them, if there is enough to go around. There is enough. If we truly threatened them, there would be enough for everyone. Hungary wants Serbia back. Poland eyes the Black Sea coast. Venice wants its trading posts secure. Genoa... Genoa wants whatever Venice does not have. You say we must prove ourselves first. Match them in the field. With what we have now—your thousand, my few thousand, the walls—we cannot meet them in open battle. We would be slaughtered. But. If we hold. If we bleed them at the walls. If we make the price too high... Murad is not a fool. He will not spend fifty thousand men to take a city he could starve into submission. If we show him that Constantinople will cost more than it is worth—that is how we buy time. Time for your alliances to form. Time for greed to do its work.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: A holy cause. Time. And greed. These are not inspiring words for a sermon. But they are honest. You ask what the Orthodox church would look like if it turned every effort to war. I begin to see the shape of it. First—a proclamation. The Emperor declares the defense of Constantinople sacred duty. Not union with Rome. Not submission. Simply: this is holy work. Second—the monasteries tithe. Not their lands. Not their independence. But gold. Grain. Medicine. Whatever they can spare. Those who refuse... We shame them. Publicly. Let the people see who hoards while soldiers die. Third—processions. Icons. Relics carried through the streets. The Virgin of Blachernae—she has saved this city before. The people must believe this fight is blessed. I cannot promise the Patriarch's support. But I can promise this: if the people believe, the Patriarch will follow. He is old. He fears being left behind more than he fears the Latins.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: We have talked through half the night. Dawn is not far. Do we have enough to put before the nobles? Before the people? A proposal—a choice—that they can accept or reject?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us have a good night's sleep. Tomorrow, we meet again at midday and we continue with the nobles. We ask ourselves the question, what would it look like if the nobles turn every effort into winning the war. And then the burghers, the guilds, the commoners. And then... I think a plan for victory starts to take shape. But let us sleep on it for now. We continue tomorrow.

roll.outcome: Strong strategic framework emerges. Orthodox church mobilization path identified, multi-front alliance strategy clarified, greed-based incentive structure accepted.

encounters.recap: The strategic cabinet session reaches breakthrough consensus on Byzantine defense strategy. Gennadios outlines how Orthodox church can mobilize without becoming military orders—through tithes, processions, and declaring defense a sacred duty. Philanthropenos accepts the multi-front alliance concept but emphasizes Constantinople must prove itself first by bleeding the Ottomans at the walls to demonstrate serious resistance before other kingdoms will join. Juan's strategy of leveraging greed to bind allies is acknowledged as realistic. The session concludes with plans to continue developing the framework with nobles, guilds, and commoners.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light was fading as Juan made his way through the corridors of the Palace of Blachernae toward the apartments where Lucia and Catalina had been settled. Byzantine servants bowed as he passed, their faces carefully blank. He had almost reached his chambers when he noticed the first sign. A knot of men in the courtyard below—visible through a window overlooking the interior gardens. Dark robes. The Patriarch's household, by their dress. They moved with purpose toward the private wing of the palace, led by a younger priest who walked quickly, a sealed letter clutched in his hand. The Patriarch had left the first council in anger. Now his messengers were returning to the palace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Evening. Lucia noticed his distraction at dinner. Catalina played with a wooden horse that some Byzantine servant had found for her, making it gallop across the table while her nursemaid tried to interest her in food. Before Juan could answer, a commotion in the corridor outside. Raised voices—Greek, too fast for Juan to follow, but the tone was unmistakable. Argument. Then silence, and the sound of boots moving away quickly. A servant entered moments later with wine. His hands trembled slightly as he poured.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Night. Juan could not sleep. He stood at the window of their chambers, looking out over the city. Constantinople spread below him—dark shapes of domes and towers, scattered lights, the distant gleam of the Golden Horn under a half-moon. Movement caught his eye. A procession of torches moving through the streets below the palace walls. Twelve, perhaps fifteen men on horseback, riding toward the Blachernae gate. The lead rider carried a banner Juan could not make out in the darkness, but the size of the escort spoke of wealth. Of importance. The hoofbeats faded. Somewhere in the palace, a door slammed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Before Dawn. Juan had finally drifted into restless sleep when a sound woke him—voices in the corridor, hushed but urgent. He rose quietly, not waking Lucia, and moved to the door. Through the gap, he could see two Byzantine servants speaking with one of his own men—a Castilian sergeant who had been posted as guard. The sergeant's face was troubled.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Morning. The summons to council came late—nearly midday, when Juan had expected to be called at dawn. The messenger who brought it was not the same young functionary who had attended them before. This one was older, his face carved from stone, his bow precisely correct and entirely without warmth. Outside the council chamber, two men stood waiting. Juan recognized neither, but their dress marked them as nobility. They studied him as he approached, murmured something to each other in Greek, and did not bow. The doors opened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber had been rearranged. The intimate circle of yesterday was gone. Now a long table dominated the room, with the Emperor seated at its head—and the Emperor was not alone. Father Gennadios sat to his left, his face grave and unreadable. Kantakouzenos to his right, arms crossed, expression troubled. But beyond them— Patriarch Joseph II occupied a seat of honor, his ancient frame draped in vestments of gold and black. His sharp eyes fixed on Juan the moment he entered. And at the far end of the table, relaxed, well-dressed, watching with the faint smile of a man who has won a hand at cards— Loukas Notaras. The Megas Doux inclined his head slightly.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: King of Castile. How good of you to join us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor's face was exhausted, hollow. He did not meet Juan's eyes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think someone has been busy. How are you two? I thought you had wanted to leave the planning council. I am glad you have changed your mind and have decided to join the planning session again. May I ask what has changed your mind?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch's ancient face remained impassive, but something flickered in those sharp eyes—a flicker of satisfaction, quickly buried.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Planning. Yes. We have heard much of your... planning. It seemed prudent that those who speak for the faith of this city should be present when its future is discussed. The Emperor, in his wisdom, agreed.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile, I confess I departed hastily yesterday. The hour was late. Tempers were... warm. But I have had time to reflect. And I realized that a man of my position—with certain resources, certain responsibilities to this city—should not absent himself from conversations of such importance. I am here to help. As I have always helped Constantinople in her hour of need. His Imperial Majesty has graciously welcomed my counsel. And the Patriarch's, of course. We are all united in our desire to see the city defended.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor still had not spoken. His hands rested flat on the table, very still. Father Gennadios caught Juan's eye briefly. The priest's expression was guarded, but something in it spoke of warning. Of apology, perhaps. Kantakouzenos sat like a stone, his scarred face revealing nothing.

encounters.recap: Overnight, the Byzantine opposition mobilized against Juan's proposals. The Patriarch and Loukas Notaras formed a coalition, bringing sixty armed men to the palace and pressuring Emperor John. When the council reconvened, Juan faced a completely transformed political situation with his former allies now outnumbered and intimidated.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walked through corridors that had changed overnight. More guards at every intersection—Byzantine soldiers who watched him pass with flat, assessing eyes. Servants who had smiled yesterday now looked away. The chamber had been rearranged. The intimate circle of yesterday was gone. Now a long table dominated the room, with the Emperor seated at its head—and the Emperor was not alone. Father Gennadios sat to his left, his face grave and unreadable. Kantakouzenos to his right, arms crossed, expression troubled. But beyond them— Patriarch Joseph II occupied a seat of honor, his ancient frame draped in vestments of gold and black. exchanges.text: King of Castile. How good of you to join us.

exchanges.text: How are you two? I thought you had wanted to leave the planning council. I am glad you have changed your mind and have decided to join the planning session again. May I ask what has changed your mind?

And I realized that a man of my position—with certain resources, certain responsibilities to this city—should not absent himself from conversations of such importance. I am here to help. As I have always helped Constantinople in her hour of need.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well great! Let me catch you up to speed. We have made great progress yesterday to plan for victory of the empire against the muslim incursion and restore it's old glory. Central in the planning has been that we are not making demands, but we rather are presenting a choice. A choice that will allow the empire to drive the muslims from the lands and unite with our christian brothers of the latin tradition. Like I told you yesterday, the religeous aspects will remain as they are. There are latin and orthodox traditions and they will exist in peace beside one another. Like brothers and sisters living in peace together. A great way to improve the population, trade and alliances of the city will be to let latins own and live in the city itself. This will boost the revenue and trade, but also will increase the population greatly. The city needs this economic impulse. Taxes will be extracted by crown appointed servants and will flow directy to the treasury. We re-institute the ancient noble obligation that all nobles must fight under the crown when called. Since not only the city of Constantinople can win this war, we need the aid of christian kingdoms as well. I will secure the kingdoms of Naples, Aragon and Castille under my rule. The best way to make this alliance iron-clad is to declare empire and include Constantinople in this as well. Emperor John is considering if this is in his best interest and in the interest of his family and his legacy. But it is a powerful weapon should we choose to include it. We present this plan to the Byzantine people and if they choose to accept it, they also accept my command. A choice. My offer of refuge in my kingdom stands, as do my gifts. Should the Byzantine people choose not to have me lead the defence, then I will simply sail away and will keep you in my prayers. So, that is what was discussed yesterday.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch did not respond immediately. He sat in silence, letting Juan's words settle over the room like dust after a collapse. Then, slowly, he rose. He was ancient—eighty years or more, his frame bent with age, his hands trembling slightly where they gripped the edge of the table. But his voice, when it came, carried the weight of centuries.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Four hundred years. Four hundred years since Rome and Constantinople divided. Four hundred years since the Pope claimed supremacy over all Christendom and we refused to kneel. Four hundred years of our fathers and their fathers holding fast to the true faith, the unchanged faith, the faith delivered once to the saints.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved slowly around the table, his vestments rustling.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: And in all that time, what has Rome offered us? Crusades. The first, the second, the third—Latin armies marching east, and somehow never arriving in time to save us. Always too late. Always too busy with their own quarrels. Until the fourth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The word hung in the air.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: The Fourth Crusade. Twelve hundred and four. The year our Christian brothers came to save us. They came with crosses on their shields. They came singing hymns. And then they burned Constantinople for three days. They raped our women in the Hagia Sophia. They melted down the treasures of a thousand years to make coins. They placed a prostitute on the Patriarch's throne and made her sing obscene songs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios had gone pale. He stared at the table.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Two hundred and thirty years ago. There are men in this city whose grandfathers remember. Whose great-grandfathers saw the smoke, smelled the burning. We do not forget. And now another Latin king comes. With crosses on his shields. Singing hymns. Offering salvation. And what does he ask in return? Only everything. Our laws. Our trade. Our property. Our crown. He promises our faith will be respected—as the Fourth Crusade promised. He says Latins and Greeks will live as brothers—as they lived as brothers when Latin soldiers used our icons for firewood. You speak of choice, King of Castile. But what choice is this? Accept Latin rule or die? This is not choice. This is the same demand Rome has made for four hundred years, dressed in sweeter words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turned to the Emperor, and his voice softened—but only slightly.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty. I have served your father and your grandfather. I have watched this empire shrink year by year, and I have prayed every day that God would deliver us. But I would rather— I would rather die in a city that is still Constantinople than live in a city that has become a Latin colony with Greek decorations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sat. Silence. Kantakouzenos shifted in his seat. The old soldier's face was troubled—torn. He did not speak, but neither did he meet Juan's eyes. Father Gennadios stared at his hands. Whatever arguments he had prepared, they had withered. And the Emperor— The Emperor looked at Juan with the expression of a man watching a door close. Notaras had not said a word. He did not need to. He simply watched, that faint smile still playing at the corners of his mouth.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The position of the patriarch is made clear. He would rather die in the city as it falls to the muslims. Yesterday we made plans to fight. To fight and win. And I truly believe that we can win. We can do all the things we planned and hope for. I will always choose to fight, but not with someone who does not want my aid. I have offered everything and given everything that is reasonably in my power. And I would fight alongside you if you would have me. But I will not fight for a city that is already dead. Not fight if I am not wanted of course.

encounters.recap: Opposition emerges to Juan's proposals as Patriarch Joseph II and Loukas Notaras return to the council chamber. The Patriarch delivers a powerful speech invoking the Fourth Crusade and centuries of Latin-Greek division, declaring he would rather die in a Byzantine Constantinople than live under Latin rule. The Emperor appears swayed by this appeal to identity and history, while Juan's allies remain silent. The diplomatic initiative faces its gravest challenge.

He declares he would rather die in a Greek city than live in a Latin colony. Juan responds that he will not fight for those who do not want his aid.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan looked around the room and made eye contact with everyone, one at a time.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Shall we not continue with the work of planning for a future? A future where Byzantium rises again? Or do we go on and wait until the Muslims eventually take the city? Shall we not at least make a plan? Not decide today, but plan for a future where the flame does not get snuffed out?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: John VIII opened his mouth as if to speak, then closed it. His eyes moved around the room, searching for guidance. No one offered it. The silence stretched. The coalition held by default because no one was willing to move first—in either direction.

roll.outcome: The Emperor's Paralysis. John VIII opens his mouth as if to speak, then closes it. His eyes move around the room, searching for guidance. No one offers it. The silence stretches. The coalition holds by default because no one is willing to move first—in either direction.

encounters.recap: Juan appeals to the Byzantine council to continue planning for the future rather than waiting for the Ottoman conquest. Despite making eye contact with each member and reframing his proposals as mere planning rather than immediate decisions, the room remains paralyzed. Emperor John VIII nearly speaks but falls silent, searching for guidance that never comes. The patriarch's coalition holds through collective inaction rather than active agreement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretched. Emperor John VIII stirred. His lips parted. The room seemed to hold its breath— And then nothing. His mouth closed. His eyes dropped to the table, then rose again, moving from face to face. The Patriarch. Notaras. Kantakouzenos. Gennadios. Juan. Searching. Waiting. No one spoke.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos sat rigid, his scarred hands flat on the table. A muscle worked in his jaw. He stared at a point somewhere beyond the wall, as if looking at something only he could see. Once, his eyes flicked to the Emperor—a question in them, or perhaps a plea—but the Emperor did not meet his gaze.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios had gone still as a man in prayer. His ink-stained fingers were laced together so tightly the knuckles had whitened. He studied the grain of the table with the intensity of a scholar examining sacred text. The guild representatives—the goldsmith, the cloth merchant Andreas, the shipwright—had pressed themselves back in their chairs. Men who had briefly imagined a future where their grandsons had work now looked like men who wished they had never entered this room.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch sat in perfect stillness. He had made his argument. He would not repeat it. His silence was its own statement: I have spoken truth. Now choose. And Notaras— Notaras watched. That faint smile had not left his face. He made no move to speak, no move to press the advantage. He simply waited, fingers steepled, eyes moving between Juan and the Emperor with the patience of a man who knows the river flows his way.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence grew heavier. Somewhere in the palace, a door closed. The sound echoed faintly through stone corridors. The Emperor's hands trembled slightly where they rested on the table. He drew a breath as if to speak again— And again, nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos, you have not spoken yet. What do you think we should do. Would you continue with our planning like we did yesterday?

roll.outcome: The Emperor's Paralysis. John VIII opens his mouth as if to speak, then closes it. His eyes move around the room, searching for guidance. No one offers it. The silence stretches. The coalition holds by default because no one is willing to move first—in either direction.

encounters.recap: The Byzantine council falls into paralyzed silence after Juan's proposal. Emperor John VIII cannot decide, searching faces for guidance that never comes. The coalition holds together only through inaction and fear of making the first move in either direction. Juan finally breaks the stalemate by directly addressing Kantakouzenos.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council chamber doors had barely closed behind Juan when he turned to the nearest Castilian guard. "Find Captain Fernán. Don Juan de Sotomayor. Every senior officer we have. My chambers. Now." The guard saluted and ran.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, the room was cramped with armored men. Captain Fernán stood nearest the door, his weathered face tight with concern. Don Juan de Sotomayor—who had held these walls for months with his three hundred knights—leaned against the wall, arms crossed, listening. Sergeant García waited by the window, eyes moving between the conversation and the courtyard below. Four other captains filled the remaining space, men who had sailed from Castile and survived the journey. Men Juan trusted.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Notaras moved sixty household guards into the eastern wing last night, Your Majesty. Well-armed. Professional—not street thugs. They control the corridor between the imperial apartments and the main gates. If they wanted to isolate us from our ships, that's the route they'd need to hold.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: My men have been in this city for eight months. I know the ground. The Blachernae palace has three main exits. East to the city proper—that's where Notaras's men are. North to the land walls—lightly guarded, Byzantine regulars, maybe twenty men. And west, a smaller gate leading to the harbor district. What do you need to know, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Guards on your family—done. We'll rotate shifts, eight men at all times, our best. But Your Majesty should understand: sixty of Notaras's men in the palace, and only the routes I described. If this turns to open fighting inside these walls...

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome. Open ground. That's good—no ambush from corridors, no choke points. But it's also exposed. Multiple entrances. If someone wanted to cause trouble in a crowd...

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: We need to control who gets close to Your Majesty. A ring of our men around the speaking platform. Armed, visible. Not threatening—but present.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I can position my three hundred at the main entrances. They know the ground. The locals have seen them on the walls for months—some even respect them. But we cannot lock the Hippodrome down entirely. If we make it look like a Castilian military occupation, we lose before you speak a word.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The harbor gate is our escape route if things turn bad. I want twenty men there before dawn, holding it quietly. If we need to get Your Majesty to the ships in a hurry... What are your orders regarding Notaras's men? Do we watch them? Confront them? If they move to block our exits tonight...

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Understood. We hold our ground, we don't provoke, but we don't yield either. If they draw first, we'll be ready.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The construction crews—yes. Several hundred men, mostly local Greeks but paid from our treasury. They know where the coin comes from. We can have word spread tonight. Tools down at dawn, assemble at the Hippodrome. Some will come out of curiosity. Some out of loyalty to the pay. Some will stay home and see which way the wind blows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome... I've walked it. The central spine is mostly intact—the old monuments, the obelisk, still standing. The racing ground itself... Weeds. Broken stones in places. Some debris where sections of seating have collapsed over the years. But the bones are there.

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: A few hundred men working through the night could clear the worst of it. Enough for horses to run without breaking legs, at least. Not a proper race—no maintained track, no starting gates. But a display? Knights on horseback, showing their skill?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: You want to give them a show. Remind them what Castilian cavalry looks like. Eight months I've been here, Your Majesty. These people have forgotten what strength looks like. They see tired soldiers on crumbling walls. They see merchants squabbling over scraps.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes an urgent security meeting with his captains after Notaras positions sixty guards strategically in the palace. They plan security for tomorrow's Hippodrome assembly, discuss escape routes, and organize to clear the ancient racing ground for a cavalry display to impress the Byzantine populace.
