"You ask me to sit across from the man whose people shelter Fieschi's murderer. To draft a future together, as if we were friends. As if there were no blood between us." His voice was hard, but something beneath it had shifted. "Do you understand what you ask?"

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: If I go to your palace tonight, word will spread. By morning, every Genoese in this quarter will know their podestà broke bread with Venetians while Fieschi lies unavenged. The Fieschi family will hear of it within the week. They will write to Genoa. They will say Lomellini has gone soft. That he has been bought by a Castilian king and Venetian gold. And yet. If I do not go, and this new order you speak of comes to pass... Genoa is not at the table. Venice shapes the future while we sulk behind our walls. I have seen what happens to those who refuse to adapt. They become irrelevant. Then they become poor. Then they become nothing. I will come tonight, King of Castile. But I will not pretend friendship with Contarini. I will not smile and clasp hands while my merchant's blood cries out. And I will need something to show my people. Some sign that Genoa's grievance is heard. That this... cooperation... does not mean surrender. Can you give me that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not expect nor demand kinship between the two cities. But I do hope that common interests wins, that we can see that by not resorting to violence, we have much to gain. That through true justice, trade flourishes. Let tonight be of common interest. I thank you for your trust. Until tonight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lomellini inclined his head—not a bow, but an acknowledgment. The closest thing to respect a Genoese podestà would offer a foreign king under these circumstances.

encounters.recap: Juan negotiates entry to the Genoese Quarter by acknowledging the murder of Domenico Fieschi and offering to serve as neutral adjudicator. Despite skepticism from Podestà Lomellini about Venetian influence and the Fieschi family's demands for blood vengeance, Juan convinces him to attend a joint meeting by promising a reformed commercial system that would benefit all Latin quarters equally through lawful trade rather than violence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall had been prepared. Not the intimate cabinet chamber where councils had fractured and reformed—something larger. A long table. Candles and oil lamps casting warm light against Byzantine frescoes. Wine and food laid out, though Juan suspected little would be eaten.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán arrived first, with Sotomayor and García. They positioned themselves around the room—not sitting, but present. Watching.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Queen and Princess are secure on the flagship. The harbor gate remains in our hands. No movement from Notaras's men since this afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Finding the twelve proved more difficult than Juan had hoped. The men he sent returned with only three: the wall worker, whose name was Theodoros; the young firebrand, called Demetrios; and—unexpectedly—the merchant's wife, whose name was Anna.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: The others were afraid. When your men came asking, they thought... they worried it was a trap. That Notaras had sent men dressed as Castilians.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: I told them they were cowards. That the Latin king had shaken our hands and promised protection.

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: I came because my husband forbade me to. Sometimes that is reason enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos arrived as the sun set, still in military dress, his scarred face unreadable. He surveyed the room—the Castilian knights, the three commoners looking lost among the finery—and raised an eyebrow but said nothing.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: You invited them?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini arrived first, as promised—slipping in through a side entrance, dressed plainly, without the usual Venetian finery. He noted the presence of the common Byzantines with visible surprise but masked it quickly. Then they waited. The candles had burned down a finger's width before footsteps echoed in the corridor. Lomellini entered like a man walking into enemy territory—which, in his mind, he probably was.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Bailo.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Podestà.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Men and women of the city. We are gathered here to set to paper that will define the destiny of the city and christianity in the east. I have always maintained that asking for aid is a choice. Especially if I will only conditionally help if we can win the war permanently. We will discuss tonight what it will take for Constantinople not just to survive, but to rise like a phoenix. And in order to do so, it will have to shed it's old skin to be born anew. What this shape will be is as of yet unclear. What the people will choose remains unclear as well. But we must try.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We have assembled a nice mix of what can become of this new city. I am grateful for Anna to come. We all need mothers who care and worry for her children. Theodoros and Demetrios, I am grateful for your attendance as well. We have the Byzantine military and spirituality represented as well. And finally the Bailo and the Podesta. Deciding to fight means that the city will become Latin as well as orthodox. And even within the latin people, there are some stark differences. If this future is to become reality, we will have to find a way to live together if we are to fight together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us start by reminding ourselves what we are fighting for. If we do nothing and the turks eventually capture the city, what will happen to the city and to the Greeks living there? Kantakouzenos, can you start by painting us a picture of what this future would look like?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I was at Thessalonica. 1430. Four years ago. I was younger then. Faster. The Ottomans besieged the city for years. The Venetians held it—had bought it from us, in our weakness. They thought their walls would hold. They thought relief would come.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Relief did not come. The walls broke. Sultan Murad gave his men three days. Three days. That is the Ottoman custom when a city resists and falls. Three days of... whatever the soldiers wish. It is their payment. Their reward for the blood spent taking the walls.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Seven thousand dead. The rest—women, children, old men, priests—enslaved. Marched away in chains to be sold in Adrianople, in Bursa, in markets I cannot name. The churches stripped. The icons burned or carried off as trophies. The bells melted down.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You ask what happens if the Turks take this city. I will tell you. Everything I described—but worse. Constantinople is the prize. The Queen of Cities. The Ottomans have dreamed of her for a hundred years. When she falls—if she falls—Murad will not give his men three days. He will give them a week. Perhaps more. Every church will burn. The Hagia Sophia will become a mosque. Every man who resists will die. Every woman will be... The children will be taken. Raised as Muslims. Janissaries. They will forget they were ever Greek. Ever Christian.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Your sons, mother. If they survive, they will serve the Sultan. They will forget your name. Your faith. Everything you taught them. That is the future if we do nothing. That is what waits beyond these walls. I have seen it. I have smelled it. I still dream of it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now let me explain my own position. I have just finished the reconquista. I am a devout christian and I want to defend christians and this city. But there are limits to what even I can do. The Ottomans are an impressive opponent and will require not just one simple campain of a few years. It will require multiple kingdoms to unite into one single purpose and to fight for decades. If I am to defend this city and start to defeat the turks, I need a chance for victory. That is why I make me fighting in service of the city conditional of certain reforms and command structures that will allow us victory. There is no time or space left for old traditions. Either we adapt or we perish like Kantakouzenos just explained.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One of the most important consequences will be that if the people agree to let me lead the city in it's defence, the city will be opened up for latins to settle, own property in the city. This may well mean that many more latins move into the city. The city will continue to be governed by Orthodox Greeks, but the Latins will found their own churches as well. This will populate the city, make it thrive again. Provide work and bread. Anna, and the other apostles who have come. You live in the city. Do you think you and the other citizens will be open to this new future?

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks if we will be open. I am a mother. I think like a mother. When Kantakouzenos speaks of Thessalonica, I do not hear politics. I hear my sons screaming as they are dragged away. If Latins in the streets means my boys grow up Christian and free... then let there be Latins in the streets. I do not care what language they speak. I do not care what church they pray in. I care that my children live.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: I work the walls, Your Majesty. I have worked beside your Castilians for months. Sotomayor's men. They are... not what I expected. They share their bread. They do not look at us like we are dirt beneath their boots. But I am one man. There are others who remember stories. 1204. The stories do not go away just because we wish them to. If you ask will the people accept Latins—some will. Some will not. The question is whether there are enough of the first kind, and whether the second kind can be... convinced. Or at least silenced.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: The people are afraid. Afraid of the Turks. Afraid of the Latins. Afraid of Notaras. Afraid of their own shadows. But fear is not the same as refusal. Fear can become courage if someone shows them the way. You gave us bread today. You spoke to us like we mattered. Do you know how long it has been since anyone spoke to common people like we mattered? The Emperor hides. The Patriarch preaches doom. Notaras counts his gold. And then a Latin king stands in the Hippodrome and says choose. Give them something to believe in, Your Majesty. Something real. And yes—they will accept Latins. They will accept anything that is not slow death behind crumbling walls.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Byzantine restored? If the city becomes part of a grand kingdom alliance that can stand up to Ottomans and we retake the lands taken from us? A city no longer diminishing, but growing, bustling with activity? An empire on the rise again? Would this be something that the city can believe in?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: Yes. An empire rising. Lands retaken. Constantinople as it was—as it should be. This is what we dream of, Your Majesty. This is what our grandfathers told us stories about. The city of Constantine, the city of Justinian, the city that was the center of the world.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes a crucial council including Byzantine nobles, Italian merchants, and common citizens to discuss Constantinople's future. Kantakouzenos delivers a harrowing account of Thessalonica's fall to illustrate the stakes. Juan proposes opening the city to Latin settlement in exchange for military protection, with the common people expressing cautious support for survival and imperial restoration despite historical fears.

exchanges.text: Yes. An empire rising. Lands retaken. Constantinople as it was—as it should be. This is what we dream of, Your Majesty. This is what our grandfathers told us stories about. The city of Constantine, the city of Justinian, the city that was the center of the world.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: And the races! Today was only the beginning. More races. More games. Let Greeks compete alongside Latins. Let them win sometimes. Give them something to cheer for together. Shared joy is stronger than shared bread.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would the Venetians and the Genoese would like to participate as well? Provided it is safe for all participants?

exchanges.speaker: francesco_contarini
exchanges.text: Venetians racing in the Hippodrome. It has... symbolic value. The ancient games, restored. Latins and Greeks competing as equals. Venice is not opposed. In principle. These things can spark violence faster than any murdered merchant.

Venetians against Greeks. Genoese against Castilians. Let us learn to share the same ground before we compete on it directly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us first set the rules and let them race seperately. It will be done. And my men will be working on restoring other parts of the city as well. Not just the walls, the hippodrome, but the aquaducts as well. Now, lets go to another part of what fighting for the city would include. It would include a past that everyone fights. Not everyone with swords in their hands, but with what they can contribute. Monks pray and care for the wounded, traders provide supplies and pay taxes. And nobles provide their men and themselves to the crown in this fight. No one can hide anymore behind old privilege. We all fight and we all contribute. How will the Byzantines feel about this principle?

exchanges.speaker: constantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: How will the Byzantines feel? The common people will cheer. The nobles will howl. For years I have begged—begged—for the great families to contribute their household guards to the defense. Do you know what I receive? Excuses. Delays. Promises that vanish like morning mist. Notaras alone commands three hundred armed men. Three hundred! Sitting in his warehouses, protecting his gold, while I scrape together enough bodies to man the walls.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: We know. We have always known. We dig, we carry, we stand watch in the cold. And we see the great lords pass by in their fine clothes, surrounded by guards who never lift a spear for the city. If your law forces them to fight beside us—truly fight—then yes, the people will support it. Gladly.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: It is justice. Finally, justice. Why should a man with gold be worth more than a man with calluses? Why should his sons live while ours die?

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Every mother knows this unfairness. We send our husbands, our sons. The rich send nothing. If you change this, the women will bless your name.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: A moment. The principle is sound. But the Church... how does this apply to monasteries? To clergy? You said monks pray and tend wounded. But some will ask—is this enough? Will there be... quotas? Requirements?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A requirement that all must contribute within their means. In the case of the church, this means helping when called upon. And taxes as well. One tenth to the crown, would this be fair?

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: One tenth. A tithe to the crown. From the Church. Your Majesty, I must be frank. What you propose is... unprecedented. The Orthodox Church has never paid secular taxation. Our monasteries, our lands, our holdings—these are consecrated to God. To tax them is to tax God Himself. The Patriarch will call this sacrilege. He will say you seek to make the Church a servant of the crown. He will preach against it from every pulpit in the city. And many will listen. The monasteries are beloved. They feed the poor. They shelter the sick. If the people believe you are robbing God's houses... But I am not blind. The monasteries hold wealth while the walls crumble. Some abbots live like princes while soldiers starve. This is not what Christ intended. This is not holiness—it is hoarding. If you frame this correctly—if the tithe goes visibly to defense, to the survival of Christian Constantinople—some clergy will accept it. The younger priests. The ones who see what I see. But you will need to offer something in return. Some guarantee of Church autonomy. Some promise that this is taxation, not domination. What assurances can you give?

encounters.recap: Juan presents his vision of imperial restoration to gather support for allowing Latin forces into Constantinople. The common people respond with mixed hope and skepticism, seeking practical improvements over grand promises. Discussions turn to organizing inclusive Hippodrome races and requiring universal civic contribution, including from nobles and the Church. The proposal for Church taxation meets resistance but some clerical support, contingent on guarantees of autonomy.

exchanges.text: And the races! Today was only the beginning. More races. More games. Let Greeks compete alongside Latins. Let them win sometimes. Give them something to cheer for together. Shared joy is stronger than shared bread.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is actually a good idea. Let everyone compete in the races. Would the Venetians and the Genoese would like to participate as well? Provided it is safe for all participants?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini and Lomellini looked at each other. It was perhaps the first time their eyes had met directly since Lomellini entered the room. The air between them could have frozen wine.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Venetians racing in the Hippodrome. It has... symbolic value. The ancient games, restored. Latins and Greeks competing as equals. Venice is not opposed. In principle. But I would need assurances. If Venetian riders compete alongside Genoese... Passions run hot. A collision on the track, a perceived foul, an insult shouted in the heat of competition. These things can spark violence faster than any murdered merchant.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: The Venetian speaks of assurances. For once, we agree on something. Genoa has fine horsemen. We would not shame ourselves on the track. But Contarini is right—though it pains me to say it. Put a Venetian and a Genoese on horses, racing for glory, and you put a knife's edge between peace and bloodshed. If this is to work, there must be rules. Clear rules. Enforced by your men, King of Castile. Not Byzantine guards—yours. Men who owe nothing to Venice or Genoa. And perhaps... separate races. Venetians against Greeks. Genoese against Castilians. Let us learn to share the same ground before we compete on it directly.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: A gradual approach. Build trust before testing it. This could work. If managed carefully.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us first set the rules and let them race separately. It will be done. And my men will be working on restoring other parts of the city as well. Not just the walls, the hippodrome, but the aqueducts as well. Now, lets go to another part of what fighting for the city would include. It would include a pact that everyone fights. Not everyone with swords in their hands, but with what they can contribute. Monks pray and care for the wounded, traders provide supplies and pay taxes. And nobles provide their men and themselves to the crown in this fight. No one can hide anymore behind old privilege. We all fight and we all contribute. How will the Byzantines feel about this principle?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: How will the Byzantines feel? The common people will cheer. The nobles will howl. For years I have begged—begged—for the great families to contribute their household guards to the defense. Do you know what I receive? Excuses. Delays. Promises that vanish like morning mist. Notaras alone commands three hundred armed men. Three hundred! Sitting in his warehouses, protecting his gold, while I scrape together enough bodies to man the walls.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: We know. We have always known. We dig, we carry, we stand watch in the cold. And we see the great lords pass by in their fine clothes, surrounded by guards who never lift a spear for the city. If your law forces them to fight beside us—truly fight—then yes, the people will support it. Gladly.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: It is justice. Finally, justice. Why should a man with gold be worth more than a man with calluses? Why should his sons live while ours die?

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Every mother knows this unfairness. We send our husbands, our sons. The rich send nothing. If you change this, the women will bless your name.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: A moment. The principle is sound. But the Church... how does this apply to monasteries? To clergy? You said monks pray and tend wounded. But some will ask—is this enough? Will there be... quotas? Requirements?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A requirement that all must contribute within their means. In the case of the church, this means helping when called upon. And taxes as well. One tenth to the crown, would this be fair?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios was silent for a long moment. His ink-stained fingers tapped slowly on the table. The scholar's mind working through implications.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: One tenth. A tithe to the crown. From the Church. Your Majesty, I must be frank. What you propose is... unprecedented. The Orthodox Church has never paid secular taxation. Our monasteries, our lands, our holdings—these are consecrated to God. To tax them is to tax God Himself. I do not say this to refuse. I say it so you understand the weight of what you ask. The Patriarch will call this sacrilege. He will say you seek to make the Church a servant of the crown. He will preach against it from every pulpit in the city. And many will listen. The monasteries are beloved. They feed the poor. They shelter the sick. If the people believe you are robbing God's houses... But. But I am not blind. The monasteries hold wealth while the walls crumble. Some abbots live like princes while soldiers starve. This is not what Christ intended. This is not holiness—it is hoarding. If you frame this correctly—if the tithe goes visibly to defense, to the survival of Christian Constantinople—some clergy will accept it. The younger priests. The ones who see what I see. But you will need to offer something in return. Some guarantee of Church autonomy. Some promise that this is taxation, not domination. What assurances can you give?

encounters.recap: Juan presents his conditions for defending Constantinople: Latin settlement rights, universal civic obligation including noble military service, and Church taxation at one-tenth. The three Byzantine commoners support Latin integration and noble obligations as matters of survival and justice. Venetian and Genoese merchants cautiously agree to separate racing competitions. Father Gennadios warns that Church taxation will face fierce resistance from the Patriarch but acknowledges some clergy may support reform for the city's survival.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles had burned low in the cabinet chamber of the Palace of Blachernae. The evening council had stretched past compline, past the bells that no longer rang from half the churches in this dying city. Through the windows, Constantinople lay dark—darker than any Christian city should be, with vast stretches between the ancient walls where no lights glowed because no one lived there anymore.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios Scholarios sat with his hands folded on the table, waiting for Juan's answer to his question about church taxation. The scholar-priest's face betrayed nothing, but his eyes were sharp beneath heavy brows—calculating, measuring, the look of a man who had survived Byzantine court politics for decades.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: What assurances can you give?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hung in the air. Marco Contarini had gone still, his Venetian merchant's instincts sensing negotiation in progress. Lomellini stroked his scarred jaw, watchful. Kantakouzenos, the grey-bearded military commander, kept his arms crossed—a soldier waiting for the politicians to finish.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If church taxes are outside of established traditions of the orthodox church, then maybe we should not ask it of them. They have other tasks you say? Feed the poor? How can the church contribute in a way that honours their legacy? Is donation perhaps a good idea? How can they turn their vast wealth towards winning the war?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: You... withdraw the taxation proposal?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room shifted. Contarini exchanged a glance with Lomellini—the Venetian's expression calculating, the Genoese's skeptical. Kantakouzenos uncrossed his arms for the first time all evening.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The Orthodox Church has traditions of charity that predate Constantine's city. We feed the hungry. We shelter the orphan. We tend the sick. These are sacred obligations, not negotiable taxes. You ask how the Church might contribute voluntarily. This is... a different question entirely. A question the Patriarch would find less easy to denounce as Latin tyranny.

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Father, the monasteries have granaries. Everyone knows this. When the siege comes—

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: When the siege comes, those granaries could feed defenders on the walls. Yes. The Church has given to holy causes throughout our history. We built the great churches. We funded expeditions against Persia. We ransomed prisoners from the Saracens. But donation requires... framing. The Patriarch must be able to tell his monks that they give freely to a sacred cause, not that a Latin king has his hand in their purse. How would you frame this cause? What would make it worthy of the Church's treasure?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How indeed? The latin church invented the concept of crusade. To re-take the holy land. Maybe the orthodox church could do something similar? To fund the re-taking of lands that were previously orthodox and Byzantine? What name would the Greeks attribute to such an endeavour?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: You propose that the Orthodox Church create its own... crusade?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returned slowly to his seat, fingers pressed to his lips in thought. The silence stretched. Contarini shifted in his chair; even Lomellini seemed to recognize that something significant was being weighed.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The Latins invented the crusade to solve a problem. Warrior knights with too much energy and too few wars. Pope Urban gave them an enemy and a promise of salvation. Elegant, in its way. But the Orthodox Church has never... we do not grant indulgences. We do not promise heaven in exchange for killing. And yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos leaned forward. The old soldier had been silent for most of the evening, but now his scarred face showed keen interest.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: And yet, we have analepsis. Recovery. Restoration of what was stolen. Thessalonica. Adrianople. The lands of Anatolia where Orthodox Christians lived for a thousand years before the Turks came. These are not conquest—they are reclamation. Apokatastasis. The restoration of all things. It is a theological concept—the eventual return of creation to its proper order. Some Church fathers wrote of it. Others called it heresy. But as a political framing...

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: If the Emperor proclaimed a sacred apokatastasis—a holy restoration of Orthodox lands—and if the Patriarch blessed it... The Patriarch will not bless anything you touch. Not willingly. But if the people demanded it? If the monasteries saw their brothers in Christ suffering under Turkish rule and chose—freely chose—to open their granaries and treasuries for their liberation?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: The people would demand it. If someone told them they could demand it.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The question is who would speak for this... apokatastasis. Who would give it theological authority, if not the Patriarch?

encounters.recap: Juan withdraws his church taxation proposal and instead suggests the Orthodox Church create its own form of holy war. Gennadios explores the theological concept of apokatastasis—the restoration of Orthodox lands—as a framework for voluntary church contributions, positioning himself as a potential theological authority for this new doctrine.

Kantakouzenos, the grey-bearded military commander, kept his arms crossed—a soldier waiting for the politicians to finish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Theodoros, Anna, and Demetrios sat at the far end of the table, uncomfortable in the presence of such men. The wall worker's callused hands rested flat on polished wood worn smooth by generations of imperial advisors. Anna glanced between the churchman and the foreign king as if witnessing a joust conducted in words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Gennadios had asked the question that would determine whether any Orthodox clergyman could support Juan's proposal without being branded a traitor to the faith. One-tenth of church wealth to the crown was unprecedented. The Patriarch would call it sacrilege. But the monasteries did hoard gold while the walls crumbled. Everyone in this room knew it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose from his seat and walked to the window, looking out over the darkened city.

Father Gennadios, surprised by this tactical retreat, explains that voluntary donations require proper theological framing to avoid charges of Latin tyranny. Juan suggests creating an Orthodox equivalent to the Crusade concept for reclaiming Byzantine lands.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios

exchanges.speaker: narrator

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stood again, pacing now, his black robes swirling.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: Apokatastasis. The restoration of all things. It is a theological concept—the eventual return of creation to its proper order. Some Church fathers wrote of it. Others called it heresy. But as a political framing...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stopped, facing Juan.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: If the Emperor proclaimed a sacred apokatastasis—a holy restoration of Orthodox lands—and if the Patriarch blessed it... The Patriarch will not bless anything you touch. Not willingly. But if the people demanded it? If the monasteries saw their brothers in Christ suffering under Turkish rule and chose—freely chose—to open their granaries and treasuries for their liberation?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: The people would demand it. If someone told them they could demand it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Gennadios turned to regard the young man with something approaching approval.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: The question is who would speak for this... apokatastasis. Who would give it theological authority, if not the Patriarch?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes met Juan's. The question beneath the question was plain: What role do you envision for me in this?

encounters.recap: Gennadios Scholarios introduces the theological concept of apokatastasis—the restoration of all things—as a potential Orthodox framework for holy war. Unlike Latin crusades, this would focus on reclaiming traditionally Orthodox lands from Turkish rule through voluntary Church support, positioning it as restoration rather than conquest. He subtly positions himself as the theological authority who could legitimize such a movement if the Patriarch refuses to cooperate.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: If the Emperor proclaimed a sacred apokatastasis—a holy restoration of Orthodox lands—and if the Patriarch blessed it... The Patriarch will not bless anything you touch. Not willingly. But if the people demanded it? If the monasteries saw their brothers in Christ suffering under Turkish rule and chose—freely chose—to open their granaries and treasuries for their liberation?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: The people would demand it. If someone told them they could demand it.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The question is who would speak for this... apokatastasis. Who would give it theological authority, if not the Patriarch?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Gennadios did not answer immediately. Instead, he returned to his seat and drew a fresh sheet of parchment toward him, his movements deliberate, almost ritualistic. The scratch of his pen filling the silence was the only sound in the chamber.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: You ask me to build a cathedral in an evening. But let me... sketch the foundations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He wrote for several minutes. The others waited—Kantakouzenos with a soldier's patience, Contarini with a merchant's calculation, the commoners with visible confusion at watching a priest do theology in real time.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The Latin crusade rests on three pillars. Papal authority to declare holy war. Indulgences to remit sin for participants. And the cross taken as a vow. We cannot use any of these. The Patriarch is not the Pope—he cannot command, only bless. We do not sell forgiveness. And our monks do not take up swords. But Orthodoxy has its own traditions. Different roots, different flowers.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: First: Anastasis—Resurrection. Our most sacred icon shows Christ descending to Hell to raise Adam and Eve. He does not wait for them to climb to Him. He reaches down and pulls them up. This is the heart of Orthodox soteriology. God acts. God restores. God does not merely forgive—He heals.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You speak of theology. Soldiers need something simpler.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: Patience, strategos. Second: Martyria—Witness. Not merely dying for faith, but living for it. The Orthodox tradition honors those who suffer for Christ, yes. But also those who build for Christ. Who defend His people. We do not promise heaven for killing Turks—as the Latins promised heaven for killing Saracens. But we can promise remembrance.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The Diptychs. The lists of names read during the Divine Liturgy. The living and the dead whom the Church remembers before God. To have one's name inscribed in the diptychs of Hagia Sophia—read aloud where Chrysostom preached, where Justinian built, where emperors were crowned for a thousand years... This is not an indulgence. We do not say 'your sins are forgiven.' We say 'you will be remembered. Your children's children will hear your name spoken in the holiest place in Christendom, until Christ returns.'

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: That would matter. To common people. To know they would be remembered.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: Third: What does the Church actually give? Grain and oil from monastery storehouses. Not taxed—offered for the sustenance of defenders. The monasteries of Mount Athos alone could feed an army for months. Gold and silver from treasury reserves. Not seized—consecrated to holy purpose. Horses, mules, wagons from church lands. Monks as healers. We do not fight. But we tend the wounded. We pray over the dying. We copy documents, keep records, write letters for illiterate soldiers to send home. The presence of monks sanctifies the endeavor—proves this is no mere war of conquest.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Grain, gold, horses, and healers. Yes. That I understand.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: Now the difficult part. How do we make this... binding? Without the Patriarch's blessing? A Synod. Not a full Ecumenical Council—that requires the Patriarch, and he will not cooperate. But a local synod. Bishops who support the cause gathering to issue a tomos—a formal theological statement.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How many bishops?

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: For legitimacy? At least five. For real authority? The more the better. The metropolitans of Thessalonica, Adrianople, Trebizond—all currently in exile or under Ottoman rule—would have obvious interest. They want their sees back.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Bishops in exile have little power.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: They have legitimacy. If the Metropolitan of Thessalonica—driven from his city by Turkish conquest—blesses the apokatastasis and calls on the faithful to support the restoration of his flock... who can call that illegitimate? He is not attacking. He is recovering what was stolen.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The tomos would establish: One: That the defense and restoration of Orthodox lands is a sacred duty, blessed by God. Two: That contributions to this cause—freely given—constitute works of piety equivalent to pilgrimage, almsgiving, or building churches. Three: That those who give—whether gold, grain, or service—shall have their names inscribed in the diptychs of restored churches, to be commemorated in perpetuity. Four: That monks and clergy who serve as healers, scribes, or chaplains do so with the blessing of the Church, without violation of their vows. Five: That this is not a Latin crusade. No indulgences. No papal authority. No promise of heaven for killing. Only the restoration of what was Orthodox to Orthodox hands.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: This I could draft. Whether I could sign it... That would make me the Patriarch's enemy. Permanently.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: But if it worked—if the monasteries opened their granaries and the people believed this was holy—the Patriarch couldn't stop it. Could he? Not if everyone else was already moving.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: No. He could denounce. He could excommunicate. But if the Emperor proclaimed it, if the bishops blessed it, if the people believed... The Patriarch is powerful. But he is one man. And even patriarchs can be... replaced.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Time is the one currency Constantinople cannot afford to spend.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The scriptorium adjoins the imperial chapel. I know it well. This will take hours. Perhaps until dawn. You understand that once I put pen to parchment, I cannot unwrite it. If this tomos exists, the Patriarch will learn of it. There will be no returning to how things were.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios. How things were is a slow death. You said so yourself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scholar-priest considered this for a moment. Then he nodded once and disappeared through the doorway, his black robes swirling behind him.

encounters.recap: Gennadios develops a comprehensive theological framework for the Apokatastasis - an Orthodox alternative to Latin crusading that promises remembrance rather than indulgences, relies on synodical authority rather than papal decree, and mobilizes church resources through voluntary contribution. He agrees to draft the formal proclamation despite the personal risk of opposing the Patriarch.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Back in the council chamber, the conversation had turned to more immediate matters.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Fieschi murder. Tell me what happened. Both of you. Contarini first.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Three days ago. Domenico Fieschi, a Genoese cloth merchant, was found dead in an alley between our quarters. Throat cut. His purse was gone, but his rings remained—suggesting the robbery was staged.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Or that the killer was interrupted.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Perhaps. The Genoese accused a Venetian merchant named Alessandro Duodo. They claim Fieschi had accused Duodo of adulterating silk shipments—a serious charge that would have ruined him. Motive enough for murder.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Duodo?

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Denies everything. Says he was at a tavern in our quarter when Fieschi died. Three witnesses confirm this.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Venetian witnesses. His friends. His business partners. The Fieschi family is powerful in Genoa. Domenico was their factor here. They demand justice—real justice, not Venetian theatre.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What evidence points to Duodo specifically?

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: A witness. A Greek boy—the baker's apprentice who died in the fighting afterward. Before he died, he told his master he saw a man in Venetian colors leaving the alley. Tall, fair-haired.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Half the Venetians in Constantinople are tall and fair-haired.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Duodo matches the description.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: As do dozens of others.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two Italians glared at each other across the table. Kantakouzenos watched with the weary expression of a man who had seen this exact argument a hundred times.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Here is what will happen. Tomorrow morning, I will sit in judgment. Neutral ground—not the Venetian quarter, not the Genoese quarter. The Hippodrome, in view of whoever wishes to watch.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: You would judge a Genoese matter?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would arbitrate a dispute that is poisoning this city. You want justice. Contarini wants his man proven innocent. Neither of you trusts the other to judge fairly. But you both came here tonight, which means you both accept that someone must judge.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: And if you find Duodo guilty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then I enforce the penalty appropriate to the crime.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Genoese law demands hanging for murder.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If Duodo murdered Fieschi, Duodo hangs. I did not come to Constantinople to make friends with murderers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini stirred uneasily, but said nothing.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: And if he is innocent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then the real killer remains free, and we must find him. Bring your witnesses tomorrow. Bring your evidence. Let Constantinople see that Latins can resolve disputes without burning each other's quarters to the ground.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles burned lower. Theodoros, the wall worker, had fallen asleep in his chair—the exhaustion of a man who had labored all day and then sat through hours of politics he barely understood. Anna remained alert, her merchant wife's mind clearly working through implications. Young Demetrios listened with hungry intensity.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The principle that everyone fights. You understand what this means for the noble houses?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I understand it will make me enemies.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Notaras has three hundred household guards. Armed men who sit in his compound eating his food while workers man the walls for copper coins. If you demand that noble retainers serve...

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Then Notaras loses his private army. And gains... what? Enemies who remember that the foreign king took their comfortable positions and put them on the walls?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: Or gratitude from everyone else who already serves. The workers know who fights and who doesn't. They talk.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The noble contribution need not be their household guards specifically. Gold. Grain. Horses. The same principle as the Church—let them choose how they contribute, so long as they contribute something proportional to their wealth.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: That I could enforce. A general levy based on assessed holdings. Standard Byzantine practice, in theory—though the theory has rotted into nothing these past decades.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then let us restore the practice along with the lands.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You speak of restoration often, King of Castile. The father in the chapel writes theological justifications. But theology does not fill granaries or man walls.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No. That requires something simpler. The belief that this time might be different.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos held his gaze for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I have served three emperors. I watched Thessalonica fall. I have seen promises from the West before—cardinals who spoke of armies that never came, kings who pledged support and then found reasons to delay. You brought nine hundred knights. You work on the walls beside common laborers. You sit in this room past midnight discussing baker's apprentices and noble levies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He uncrossed his arms.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I do not yet believe. But I am... less certain of disbelief than I was this morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From a Byzantine commander who had watched his world crumble for decades, it was almost an endorsement.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes to arbitrate the Fieschi murder dispute between Venetians and Genoese by holding a public trial in the Hippodrome. He discusses implementing universal military service and noble levies with the Byzantine council, gradually earning Kantakouzenos's cautious trust through practical governance rather than empty promises.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini leaned forward at the mention of commercial courts, his silver-haired patrician reserve giving way to genuine interest. This was familiar ground—the language of trade, contracts, disputes.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: A tribunal with rotating judges. Venice, Genoa, and... Castile as the third party. When two of us dispute, the third adjudicates.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: And when a Greek merchant disputes with a Latin? Who judges then?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: A separate question. We speak now of disputes between Latin nations. The Greek courts are...

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Corrupt. You may say it. Everyone knows.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: The current system is that each nation judges its own. Venetians judge Venetians. Genoese judge Genoese. When disputes cross quarters, we negotiate—or we fight. Hence our present difficulties.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: You suggest that if a Venetian wrongs a Genoese, Castile judges. If a Genoese wrongs a Venetian, Castile judges. And if either of us wrongs a Castilian...

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: There are few Castilians trading here. For now. But if this city survives—if trade expands—there will be more. Aragonese. Catalans. Portuguese, perhaps.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: Then we need more than three nations in this system. Or Castile becomes permanent arbiter of everything.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: A rotating panel. Representatives from each trading nation with significant presence. When disputes arise, judges are drawn from nations not party to the dispute. Speed matters. Commercial disputes must resolve quickly or contracts become worthless. We cannot wait months for judges to be summoned from distant lands.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: Resident judges. Each nation with a quarter maintains a trained jurist. When called to sit, they sit.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: The Fieschi case. You propose to judge it yourself tomorrow. This would be... the first test. Precedent.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: If the system is to have legitimacy, the first judgment must be seen as fair. By both parties.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For my ruling to have any effect, both parties must declare that they will respect the outcome beforehand. Whatever I decide, both parties will have to have their peace with it. I may need a few days to render judgement. Do you both accept my ruling in this matter?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: You ask us to bind ourselves before we know the process. What evidence will be heard? Who may testify? Will Duodo be permitted to speak in his own defense, or will he be judged on accusation alone?

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: And what of appeal? If one party believes the judgment unjust, is there recourse? Or does your word become final the moment it leaves your lips? I must answer to Genoa. To the Fieschi. If I bind myself to accept a verdict and that verdict is... unsatisfying... I will be asked why I surrendered Genoese justice to a foreign king.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: As I must answer to the Doge. The Serenissima does not lightly place her citizens under foreign jurisdiction.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: You judged no one in Castile before you were crowned, I presume. You inherited laws, traditions, precedents built over centuries. Here you propose to create a court from nothing, with yourself as sole judge, and ask us to accept the outcome before a single witness is called. I am not refusing. I am asking: why should I trust this? What guarantees can you offer that this is justice and not... theatre, as I said before?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: If we are to accept your judgment as binding, we must know the rules by which you will judge. Written. Clear. Agreed upon before the trial begins—not invented as you go.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But of course, let us take a moment to shape the court structure. I have attended many judges at work before, but I have never drafted a court system from scratch. What should be included? What is the legal foundation of any court system? What laws should we use? Are there standard christian laws we can rely upon? What should be in this document?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: You ask the right question. Every court rests on three pillars: jurisdiction, procedure, and authority. Miss any one, and the whole edifice collapses.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Roman law. That is the foundation you seek. Justinian's Corpus Juris Civilis—the codification of a thousand years of legal reasoning. It governs the Empire still, or what remains of it. The Basilika is our Greek adaptation.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Roman law serves for matters of property, inheritance, crime. But for commercial disputes between merchants of different nations, there is something else. The lex mercatoria. The law merchant.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: Custom, not code. Developed over centuries in the great trading ports—Venice, Genoa, Barcelona, Bruges, the Champagne fairs. It governs how merchants deal with merchants, regardless of what king they serve.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini took the lead, explaining the principles of lex mercatoria: good faith in contracts, witness and document evidence, speed of resolution, and proportional remedy. The discussion expanded to cover Byzantine criminal procedure, canon law, and the essential framework any court requires—jurisdiction, standing, composition, procedure, evidence standards, judgment methods, penalties, appeals, and enforcement.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So we are now determining not a commercial matter, we consider criminal law. We will use a legal system that can deal with all matters. It will apply to everything and everyone once accepted. For merchant disputes, we use the lex mercatoria. For others, such as capital cases, we use the Byzantine law. I will use Byzantine law for this criminal case and will follow their procedure.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You would adopt the Basilika—our codification of Justinian—for criminal procedure. This I can explain to the Emperor, if he will listen. It is our law, applied by a neutral party. Not Latin imposition.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: The lex mercatoria for commercial matters, Byzantine procedure for criminal cases, and a framework that allows new trading nations to join as they establish presence. This could work. It gives each party something familiar. Merchants keep their customs. The Greeks keep their legal tradition. And the system grows as Constantinople grows—if it survives.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: I bring it. As podestà, I represent Genoese interests here. The Fieschi have authorized me to seek justice on their behalf. I received this two days ago. They demand satisfaction.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Then you are the accusator. Under Byzantine procedure, you bear the burden of proof. If you fail to prove guilt, you yourself may face penalty for false accusation—though this is rarely enforced against officers acting in official capacity.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: For the permanent court—the one that will outlast this single case—you will need the framework written and signed by representatives of each participating nation. A charter, essentially. Establishing jurisdiction, procedure, composition, and enforcement as you have described.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Greeks must sign as well. Or it remains a Latin institution imposed upon a Greek city. That will breed resentment.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Can you sign for the Emperor?

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I command walls, not policy. The Emperor must agree—or at minimum, not forbid. Given his current disposition toward our Castilian guest, that may prove difficult.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: Extradition and collective responsibility for harboring fugitives. This has teeth. If a Venetian flees to his quarter after wronging a Genoese, and the Venetian authorities refuse to surrender him, the entire quarter faces sanction.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: It forces cooperation. No quarter becomes a sanctuary for criminals. We must police our own or face consequences. Venice can accept this. We have nothing to hide.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us remember what we are actually doing here. We are designing a legal structure that will only be ratified by the Byzantines after they choose me as their commander. My condition is a strong legal system that will judge latins and Byzantines fairly. So the emperor will be ratifying it when the city makes the choice to fight. But we can draft the system for now and use it in this murder case. If nothing else, it will prove it works at least. But dont worry about ratification just yet, it is part of a broader package if the city accepts me. Ok! So can we now draft a document that established this court?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Ah. The cart before the horse, but deliberately so. You demonstrate the system works, then ask the Greeks to adopt it. Sound strategy. The Fieschi case becomes proof of concept.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: I will draft. Genoa has extensive experience with commercial courts in our colonies. Caffa, Chios, Pera across the Golden Horn. I know what language works and what invites dispute.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: As does Venice. Perhaps we draft together. Two perspectives will catch weaknesses one might miss.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Work through the night if you must. It seems to be the fashion this evening.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Charter has been drafted. Contarini and Lomellini bent over the document as it took shape, the two rivals finding unexpected common purpose in legal architecture. Occasionally one would object to a phrase, the other would counter, and a compromise would emerge.

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You two have been at each other's throats for a century, and now you draft law together.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Law is business. And this is good business—for both of us.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: If it works.

exchanges.speaker: anna_paleologina
exchanges.text: This court—it judges Latins fairly. But what of Greeks? What happens when a Venetian cheats a Greek merchant?

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Article One, Section One, Clause C. Civil matters between subjects of different nations. A Greek is a subject of the Empire. A Venetian is a subject of Venice. The court has jurisdiction.

exchanges.speaker: anna_paleologina
exchanges.text: But the judges are all Latin.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_lomellini
exchanges.text: Article Eight, Section Four addresses this. If a Greek party requests and the Latin party agrees, a Byzantine jurist may be included.

exchanges.speaker: anna_paleologina
exchanges.text: If the Latin party agrees. And if they don't?

exchanges.speaker: konstantine_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The imperial subscription would change things. If the Emperor signs, he could demand Greek judges be added to the panel. Make it a condition of ratification.

exchanges.speaker: antonio_contarini
exchanges.text: Which brings us back to the Emperor. Who is not, at present, inclined to cooperate with anything bearing a Castilian seal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles had burned lower. Through the windows, the sky showed the first grey hint of approaching dawn. Somewhere in the palace, Father Gennadios was still writing his theological framework. Here in the council chamber, a legal framework had taken shape. Two pillars of a new order—one spiritual, one temporal. Both waiting for a city to choose whether it wanted to live.

encounters.recap: Juan works with Venetian and Genoese representatives to design a comprehensive legal system for Constantinople, combining lex mercatoria for commercial disputes with Byzantine law for criminal cases. The framework establishes rotating impartial judges, clear procedures, and enforcement mechanisms. A formal charter is drafted as proof of concept, with the Fieschi murder case to serve as the first test of the new judicial system.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The imperial subscription would change things. If the Emperor signs, he could demand Greek judges be added to the panel. Make it a condition of ratification.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Which brings us back to the Emperor. Who is not, at present, inclined to cooperate with anything bearing a Castilian seal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles had burned lower. Through the windows, the sky showed the first grey hint of approaching dawn. Somewhere in the palace, Father Gennadios was still writing his theological framework. Here in the council chamber, a legal framework had taken shape. Two pillars of a new order—one spiritual, one temporal. Both waiting for a city to choose whether it wanted to live.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You ask the right man. I have spent forty years studying why our armies fail. And watching it happen regardless.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose and moved to a map on the wall—old, faded, showing the Empire as it had been a century ago. His finger traced boundaries that no longer existed.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Empire once had three systems of military obligation. All three have rotted to nothing. First, the themata. For five hundred years, this was the spine of Byzantine power. Soldier-farmers. The Emperor granted land to families in exchange for military service. When the beacon fires lit, every stratiotēs took up arms and marched. No wages required—the land was their payment. The Turks took the land. The system died with it. What remains of Thrace cannot support a tenth of what Anatolia once provided.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Second, pronoia. Your Western lords would recognize it. Grants of revenue—tax collection rights over villages, estates, harbors—in exchange for military service. The pronoiar was obligated to appear with horse, armor, and often additional men proportional to his grant.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: This still exists?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: In theory. In practice, the great families have converted their pronoiai into hereditary possessions. They collect the revenue. They do not provide the service. Notaras holds grants that should obligate him to field three hundred cavalry. He fields three hundred household guards who protect him, not the walls.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Third, the city itself. Constantinople has ancient traditions of civic defense. The dēmoi—the circus factions, Blues and Greens—once maintained armed contingents. The guilds organized their members for wall defense. Every able-bodied man knew which section of wall he was to defend when the bells rang.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The factions are social clubs for the remaining aristocracy. The guilds still exist. They still know their wall sections. But they are few, poorly armed, and utterly untrained. When I call for workers to man the walls, they come with hammers and mattocks. Not swords. Not bows.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: We come because no one else will. The nobles sit in their palaces. The merchants count their gold. We stand on the walls because if we don't, no one does.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The spirit remains. The structure does not. You asked about Orthodox traditions specifically. The Latin church created military orders—Templars, Hospitallers, the orders of Iberia. Monks who fight. We have nothing equivalent. But we have other traditions. The Emperor is isapostolos—'equal to the apostles.' When he calls men to defend the faith, it carries religious weight. The Patriarch can bless armies, consecrate banners, declare that those who die defending Constantinople die as martyrs.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: There is also the tradition of the akritai. The border warriors of Anatolia. They were not monks, but they fought for faith as much as Empire. Songs are still sung of Digenes Akritas, the hero who held the frontier against the infidel. The common people remember these stories.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The bones of a system exist. Obligations that have been ignored, traditions that have been forgotten, spirit that has been crushed but not extinguished. Whether they can be revived... That depends on whether anyone has the authority to compel revival. The Emperor could—if he would. The great families will not voluntarily surrender their guards or their gold. The guilds will serve if called, but they need arms, training, leadership.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: What would it take? To make the guilds into real soldiers?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Weapons—we have some in the arsenals, though not enough. Training—three months of regular drill would make a difference; a year would make them dangerous. Leadership—officers who know how to command men who are not professional soldiers. And most importantly... Time. Time we may not have.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We reinstate the urban militia. I will make sure that everyone starts drilling and training like they should. And after we start driving the turks from the city and the city is no longer under threat, how would the guilds contribute best to the war? We reinstate the pronoia system again. Justice. Everyone fights, including the nobles. And as we take more land, the most successful nobles get more title and prestige.

encounters.recap: Kantakouzenos explains the three failed Byzantine military systems: the thematic soldier-farmers, the pronoia revenue grants, and the urban militia traditions. Despite their decay, the foundations remain—guild knowledge of wall sections, religious authority of the Emperor, and memories of the akritai border warriors. Juan decides to reinstate both the urban militia with proper training and the pronoia system to compel noble military service.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: That depends on whether anyone has the authority to compel revival. The Emperor could—if he would. The great families will not voluntarily surrender their guards or their gold. The guilds will serve if called, but they need arms, training, leadership.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: What would it take? To make the guilds into real soldiers?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Weapons—we have some in the arsenals, though not enough. Training—three months of regular drill would make a difference; a year would make them dangerous. Leadership—officers who know how to command men who are not professional soldiers. And most importantly... Time. Time we may not have.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We reinstate the urban militia. I will make sure that everyone starts drilling and training like they should. And after we start driving the turks from the city and the city is no longer under threat, how would the guilds contribute best to the war? We reinstate the pronoia system again. Justice. Everyone fights, including the nobles. And as we take more land, the most successfull nobles get more title and prestige. But I have questions regarding the thematic system. We will be retaking lands where greeks are already living. How can we best design a system that makes soldier farmers from the lands we retake?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Now you touch on something real. The themata were the greatest military innovation the Empire ever produced. For five centuries, they made us unconquerable. Understanding why they worked is essential to rebuilding them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos leaned forward, his weathered face showing the first genuine enthusiasm of the evening. He explained the original thematic system—how soldiers received land in exchange for military service, with obligation tied to the land itself across generations. He outlined the challenges of reconquered territories where Greeks had lived under Turkish rule for generations, forbidden to bear arms, their martial traditions broken.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: These people remember they are Greek. They remember they are Christian. Many still speak of the Empire with longing. But they have not held swords for generations. The martial tradition is broken.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: My grandfather's grandfather came from Adrianople. He said the Greeks there still tell stories of when the city was ours.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Stories, yes. But stories do not teach a man to hold a shield wall. The question is how to transform farmers who have been subjects into farmers who are soldiers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He outlined practical considerations: land redistribution from Ottoman timars, equipment provision for new soldier-farmers, regular training schedules, and command structures. He proposed a three-tiered system: basic infantry obligations for all fighting-age males, cavalry obligations for larger landholders, and a professional core of standing forces.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: This is theory. Implementation raises a thousand questions. Who surveys the land and assigns obligations? Who resolves disputes over boundaries? What happens to a soldier-farmer who is crippled in service—does his family keep the land? What about widows? Orphans?

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: And what of the Greeks who have converted? Under Turkish rule, some took the faith of their masters to escape the jizya, to keep their sons from the devşirme. They are still Greek by blood. Do they receive land? Must they convert back?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will be using a mix of granting lands to new soldier farmers and those already farming it. We train and equip them ourselves, especially in the beginning. We train them for a good year to make a solid army. And no more strategoi's. The soldiers answer summons and join an army under the crown command, not their local governor. We establish an officer's core that commands our armies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I like your suggestions. And I understand your questions we cannot answer for now. Lets just decide on them later. The principle is that we create a structure for an army to grow. How we deal with converted Greeks exactly, this we will determine later. As long as they can fulfill their obligations as soldiers, I think it will be fine. If their religion prooves to be an obstacle...we have to take measures. But let us take lands first.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One final question. You seem to attribute religious roles to your emperor, giving him a position similar the apostles. I am asking to be the commander, the defender, the restorer of the Byzantine empire. Has this happened before? Is there a precedent or a name of title that cn be given to me? Would I also have some religous significance in my role?

encounters.recap: Juan II and his Byzantine advisors plan the revival of the thematic military system for reconquered territories. Kantakouzenos explains the historical themata and proposes a three-tiered structure of infantry, cavalry, and professional forces. They discuss practical challenges including land redistribution, training, equipment, and the status of converted Greeks, with Juan deciding to implement crown-commanded forces rather than regional strategoi.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos went very still. The question had struck something deep—the old soldier's face showed a complex mixture of emotions. Respect for the directness. Discomfort at the implications. And beneath it all, the calculation of a man who had spent his life navigating Byzantine politics.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You ask a question that touches the very heart of what the Empire is. And I must answer honestly, even if the answer is... complicated.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose and walked to the window, looking out over the darkened city.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Roman Emperor—our Emperor—is not merely a ruler. He is isapostolos, equal to the apostles. He is God's vice-regent on earth, chosen by divine providence to lead the Christian people. When he processes into Hagia Sophia, he enters the sanctuary where no layman may go. He receives communion in the manner of priests. He calls councils, confirms patriarchs, defends the faith.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: This is not mere ceremony. It is theology. The Empire exists because God wills it. The Emperor rules because God chose him. When Justinian built the Great Church, he declared 'Solomon, I have surpassed you'—meaning he had created a temple greater than Jerusalem's. The Emperor is Solomon, David, and Constantine combined.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: This is why we have endured a thousand years while other empires crumbled. The people believe. Even now, with the walls falling and the Turks at the gates, they believe that God has not abandoned His Empire. That somehow, someday, a true Emperor will restore what was lost.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Now you ask: can a Latin king hold such a role? I will not deceive you. The answer is... difficult.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You are Catholic. You acknowledge Rome's Pope as head of the Church. To the Orthodox faithful, this is not a minor difference—it is the great schism that has divided Christendom for four centuries. The Patriarch will never—never—grant you religious authority over Orthodox Christians. To do so would be to admit that Rome was right all along.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Anna shifted uncomfortably. Even Demetrios, the young idealist, looked troubled.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: And yet. There are precedents. Not exact. But... instructive.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The first: the Megas Domestikos. The Grand Domestic. Supreme commander of all imperial armies, second only to the Emperor in military authority. This is a secular title—it carries no religious significance. Foreigners have held it before, though rarely. If you sought only military command, this would suffice.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: But you speak of something more. You speak of being defender and restorer. This touches on sacred ground.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The second precedent: the relationship between Emperor and symphoneia. In Orthodox political theology, there should be symphoneia—harmony—between Emperor and Patriarch, between secular and spiritual authority. They are two arms of one body. In times when the Emperor was weak or absent, others have stepped into the breach.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: During the Latin occupation after 1204, the Emperors of Nicaea claimed to be the true Roman Emperors even while Constantinople was held by Crusaders. They maintained the idea of Empire even without the city. Could someone maintain the defense of Empire while the Emperor remains... incapacitated by circumstance?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I am reasoning at the edge of what theology permits. Father Gennadios would be better suited to this question.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: If we are to find a title that grants you authority without claiming imperial status, there are possibilities.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Megas Domestikos ton Scholon kai ton Tagmaton—Grand Domestic of the Schools and Regiments. Supreme military command over all forces. Historical, legitimate, secular.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Protostrator—originally commander of the imperial cavalry, later a general honorific for trusted military leaders. Less comprehensive than Megas Domestikos.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Sebastokrator—'Venerable Ruler.' A title created by Alexios I Komnenos for his brother, ranking just below Emperor. It has been granted to foreign allies before—the Serbian kings held it briefly. But it implies subordination to the Emperor, not independent authority.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: There is one more possibility. It has no precedent, but it might be... created.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Defensor Romaniae—Defender of Romania. 'Romania' is what we call the Empire—the Roman realm. A title that explicitly frames your role as defender, not ruler. Protector, not Emperor. Guardian of the Roman people until... until such time as the Empire can stand on its own.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Such a title would need to be granted by the Emperor himself. It would require theological justification—perhaps Father Gennadios's apokatastasis framework provides this. It would face fierce opposition from the Patriarch and men like Notaras.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: But it would give you something no military title alone can provide: a sacred dimension to your authority. Not the Emperor's holiness—that is impossible for a Latin. But a recognition that God has raised up a defender for His people in their hour of need. That your victories are blessed. That those who follow you serve a holy cause.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Whether such a thing is possible... that is not for a soldier to say. That is for theologians, for the Emperor, and ultimately for God.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles guttered. Dawn was coming—the grey light beginning to creep through the windows. Somewhere in the scriptorium, Father Gennadios was still writing. The legal charter lay on the table, awaiting signatures. And now, a question of sacred authority hung in the air. Kantakouzenos waited.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Defensor Romaniae then. With the understanding that I will command all armies and navies. And that all reforms we are now proposing are passed into law. I want to have the authority to prosecute and win this war.

encounters.recap: Juan inquires about religious precedents for his proposed role as defender of the Byzantine Empire. Kantakouzenos explains the sacred nature of Byzantine imperial authority and the theological challenges of granting such power to a Catholic king, but proposes the unprecedented title 'Defensor Romaniae' as a solution that would provide sacred legitimacy without claiming imperial status. Juan accepts this title with full military command authority.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: But it would give you something no military title alone can provide: a sacred dimension to your authority. Not the Emperor's holiness—that is impossible for a Latin.
