But a recognition that God has raised up a defender for His people in their hour of need. That your victories are blessed. That those who follow you serve a holy cause. Whether such a thing is possible... that is not for a soldier to say. That is for theologians, for the Emperor, and ultimately for God.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candles guttered. Dawn was coming—the grey light beginning to creep through the windows. Somewhere in the scriptorium, Father Gennadios was still writing. The legal charter lay on the table, awaiting signatures. And now, a question of sacred authority hung in the air. Kantakouzenos waited.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Defensor Romaniae then. With the understanding that I will command all armies and navies. And that all reforms we are now proposing are passed into law. I want to have the authority to prosecute and win this war. Can we now draft the document detailing military obligations?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Defensor Romaniae. Defender of the Roman realm. With supreme command of all military forces, land and sea. You understand that I cannot grant this. Only the Emperor can create such a title. What we draft tonight is a... proposal. A framework for what could be, if the city chooses to accept it. But I can tell you this. If such a document existed—clear, comprehensive, promising justice alongside obligation—it would give men like me something concrete to support. Not vague promises. Not Latin ambitions dressed in pretty words. A system. Let us draft it. And let us make it worthy of what we attempt.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The document took shape as Kantakouzenos dictated and a scribe—summoned from elsewhere in the palace—wrote. The old soldier's voice was steady, precise, drawing on decades of military experience and bitter knowledge of where Byzantine systems had failed. Contarini and Lomellini had finished their work on the court charter and now listened, the commercial implications of military reorganization clearly occupying their merchant minds. A stable military meant secure trade routes. Effective defense meant Constantinople survived to remain a marketplace. Anna had long since fallen asleep in her chair, exhaustion overwhelming her. Theodoros dozed beside her. Only young Demetrios remained alert among the commoners, his eyes bright despite the hour, absorbing everything.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Three documents. A theological framework for the Church's contribution. A legal framework for justice among nations. A military framework for the Empire's defense. More comprehensive reform than any Emperor has attempted in a century, drafted in a single night.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: It is done. The Tomos of the Apokatastasis. Seven articles establishing the theological foundation for sacred restoration, the mechanisms of Church contribution, and the framework for commemoration. Whether anyone will sign it remains to be seen. But the document exists.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: What you propose is nothing less than the refounding of the Empire. New religious purpose. New legal structures. New military obligations. If Constantinople accepts this... You are not asking them to accept a foreign protector. You are asking them to become something they have not been for generations.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Something we were, once. Before the rot set in.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: Perhaps. Or perhaps something new entirely. Roman in name. Orthodox in faith. But shaped by a Latin hand.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first rays of true sunlight crept through the windows, painting golden lines across the documents on the table.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: The Fieschi trial. You proposed to judge it yourself, to demonstrate the court system works. When?

encounters.recap: Through the night, Juan and his advisors draft three comprehensive reform documents: a theological framework (Tomos of the Apokatastasis), a legal charter for international courts, and a military taktikon establishing Juan as Defensor Romaniae with supreme military command. The framework represents the most comprehensive imperial reform in a century, transforming Constantinople's governance structure while awaiting the Emperor's approval.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: A single document. A Chrysobull—a golden bull, in the old imperial style. The formal proclamation that presents the choice and binds together all the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: It must contain: First, the preamble—the situation as it stands. The threat. The choice that must be made. Second, the three options clearly stated, with their consequences. Third, for those who choose the path of restoration—what they accept. The Defensor's authority. The military obligations. The legal framework. The Church's role.

exchanges.speaker: francisco_contarini
exchanges.text: And fourth, the terms for Latin settlement. Property rights. The conditions under which Venetians, Genoese, and others may own land and buildings outside our traditional quarters.

exchanges.speaker: battista_lomellini
exchanges.text: This is... essential, if we are to invest in Constantinople's future. Merchants will not build warehouses or establish families if their property can be seized on a magistrate's whim.

exchanges.speaker: george_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Granting Latins property rights throughout the city will be deeply unpopular with many Greeks. There are those who remember 1204 not as distant history but as living grievance.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: Which is precisely why it must be part of the choice. Not hidden. Not imposed after acceptance. Let the people know the full price of survival. Latin soldiers on their walls. Latin judges in their courts. Latin merchants in their neighborhoods. Latin property protected by Latin law.

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Property rights for Latins. My husband has dealt with Venetian traders for twenty years. They are not... unkind. But they protect their own. If a Greek disputes with a Venetian over a property line, and the judge is from the Latin courts...

exchanges.speaker: francisco_contarini
exchanges.text: The Charter addresses this. Judges are drawn from nations not party to the dispute. A Greek-Venetian property dispute would be judged by... Genoese, perhaps. Or Castilians.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Refugees will be living as Castilian citizens in my lands. I have recently come into the possession of Granada. I can give out lands to fellow Christians. You will not be treated differently or taxed more. Your religion will be kept and honoured.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Everyone in the city chooses what religion to follow. This cannot be forced. If a man and woman marry and come from different religions, the household chooses which one to follow. The children will be of this faith, sealed the moment they are married.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Also include in the bull that if the city chooses me as defender, I shall in turn command the Mediterranean kingdoms I rule to the same purpose as well. I am king of Castile and León, heir to the throne of Aragon and Naples and will use these kingdoms together with Constantinople to form the building blocks of something that seeks to restore Roman pride and honour.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios_scholarios
exchanges.text: Then let us write it. The Chrysobull of the Choice. Everything laid bare—the threat, the options, the consequences, the future we are building.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scribe's hand finally stopped. Gennadios set down his quill and flexed fingers cramped from hours of writing. Sunlight now streamed through the windows—full morning, the city awakening around them. Four documents lay on the table: The Tomos of Apokatastasis—the theological framework calling the Orthodox Church to sacred contribution. The Charter of the Latin Courts—the legal system binding Greek and Latin under common justice. The Taktikon of Romania—the military obligations transforming every man into a defender. And now the Chrysobull of the Choice—the proclamation that would present everything to the people of Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: george_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Four documents. Drafted between sunset and sunrise. More comprehensive reform than any Emperor has attempted in living memory.

encounters.recap: After an all-night drafting session, Juan II and his advisors complete the Chrysobull of the Choice—the formal proclamation presenting Constantinople's three options: refuge in Castile, independence, or accepting Juan as Defensor with full reforms. The document addresses property rights for Latins, religious freedom, citizenship questions, and Juan's commitment to use all his Mediterranean kingdoms for the restoration effort.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The night's work was done. The day's battles awaited.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos clasped the offered hand firmly, the old soldier's grip still strong despite his years. His weathered face showed something that might have been respect. He said nothing—soldiers rarely did at such moments—but the nod he gave carried weight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Gennadios's handshake was briefer, more formal, the scholar-priest already calculating the theological battles ahead. But his eyes held a flicker of something unexpected—perhaps hope, perhaps merely curiosity about what would come next.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini took the hand with Venetian grace, a slight bow accompanying the gesture. Lomellini followed, his scarred jaw set but his grip honest. The two rivals had found common ground this night; whether it would last remained to be seen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Anna curtsied rather than shook hands—old habits of deference—but her eyes were bright with exhausted hope. Theodoros, still half-asleep and confused about much of what had transpired, nonetheless gripped firmly, the calluses of a working man rough against skin more accustomed to sword hilts than stone walls. Young Demetrios shook hands with barely contained energy, the idealist who had stayed awake through everything, unwilling to miss a moment of history being made.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The servants materialized as servants do—silent, efficient, somehow aware of what was needed without being told. One took charge, guiding the way toward chambers prepared for the Castilian king, murmuring assurances that he would be wakened in time for the afternoon's events.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind, in the council chamber, the others began to disperse. Contarini and Lomellini departed together—still talking, the legal charter between them, old enemies become temporary allies. Kantakouzenos lingered, studying the military document one final time before rolling it carefully and tucking it beneath his arm. Gennadios gathered his theological framework with the reverence due sacred text, already composing arguments against the objections he knew would come.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Anna and Theodoros helped each other toward the door, exhaustion finally claiming them. Only Demetrios remained alert, volunteering to carry copies of the documents, to help spread the word, to do something rather than simply sleep.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning sun climbed higher over Constantinople. In a few hours, the Hippodrome would fill again. The races would run. And the Fieschi trial would test whether the night's work had any meaning at all. But for now—a few hours of rest, stolen from a day that promised to be long.

encounters.recap: After an all-night council session that produced four major documents, Juan takes his leave with handshakes and farewells from all participants. The diverse group disperses with their respective documents, while Juan retires for a brief rest before the afternoon's races and the crucial Fieschi trial.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk from the palace to the Hippodrome took only minutes, but it revealed much. The streets were busier than yesterday—word had spread. People watched from doorways and windows as the Castilian king passed with his escort. Some crossed themselves. Some spat. Most simply stared, faces unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ancient arena was filling steadily. Four thousand, perhaps more, spreading across the tiered stone seats that had once held a hundred thousand Romans cheering for chariot races. The morning's bread distribution had drawn them; curiosity kept them.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The Venetians and Genoese are here, with the accused and their witnesses. Kantakouzenos holds the military section. Father Gennadios has been moving through the crowd since dawn. The Emperor has not come. Nor the Patriarch. Notaras sent no representative, but his agents are present—I've counted at least thirty, spread throughout.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Of the twelve who stepped forward yesterday, eight had returned. Theodoros the wall-worker. Anna the merchant's wife. Young Demetrios. Five others—frightened but present. Four had not come. Whether from fear, pressure, or change of heart, none could say. Those who came gathered near the kathisma, joined by others drawn by curiosity—perhaps forty people in all, clustering around the documents that had been copied through the morning by scribes working frantically.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: I have not announced races in fifteen years. Not real races. Not races that mattered. This is... this is how it was. Before.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd quieted as Nikephoros stepped forward, his ceremonial staff striking the stones three times—the ancient signal for attention.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: PEOPLE OF CONSTANTINOPLE. Today you will hear a proclamation. A choice laid before you by one who has come from the West—not to conquer, not to demand, but to offer. Listen. Consider. And in the days to come, decide.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stepped aside. A younger man—one of Gennadios's scribes, chosen for his clear voice—took his place, the Chrysobull in hand. And then, for nearly an hour, the choice was read aloud. The threat. The three options. The conditions of restoration. The military obligations, the legal framework, the property rights, the religious arrangements, the alliance of kingdoms. All of it, concealing nothing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd listened. Some murmured. Some shouted. Notaras's agents stirred, but the sheer length and detail of the reading made interruption difficult—there was always another section coming, another point to hear. When it finished, silence hung over the Hippodrome. Four thousand people digesting what they had heard.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: The races will now begin. Bread will be distributed. And afterward—a demonstration of the justice promised in these documents. A trial, conducted fairly, for all to witness.

encounters.recap: Juan assembles supporters at the Hippodrome before four thousand citizens. The full Chrysobull is read aloud publicly, laying out the three choices for Constantinople's future. Eight of the twelve 'apostles' return, with Anna and others helping explain the reforms. The ceremony includes bread distribution, planned races, and an upcoming trial demonstration, all orchestrated by elderly master of ceremonies Nikephoros.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The reading ended. Four thousand people sat in silence for a long moment—not the hostile silence of rejection, nor the enthusiastic silence before cheering. Something else. The silence of people thinking. Then the murmuring began. It spread through the crowd like wind through wheat—clusters of conversation, heads leaning together, fingers pointing at the documents being passed among the apostles. The tone was not what Notaras's agents had hoped for. Not anger. Not dismissal. Questions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Nikephoros managed the spectacle with the skill of long practice. Castilian knights demonstrated horsemanship—not the chariot races of ancient tradition, but displays of skill that drew genuine appreciation. The crowd watched. They cheered the skilled passes, gasped at near-misses, applauded the horsemanship. It was not the wild enthusiasm of a city celebrating, but it was engagement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Anna found herself surrounded by women—wives, mothers, widows. They asked sharp questions about legal courts, military obligations, and property rights. She answered as best she could, pointing to specific sections of the documents, admitting when she didn't know. The women listened. They did not commit. But they listened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Theodoros had similar experiences among the workers. The 'everyone fights' principle had landed exactly as hoped. Men who had labored on the walls while noble retainers lounged in palaces heard their resentment given official voice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Demetrios counted them—thirty-seven new people who approached wanting to know more. Not committed supporters. But genuinely curious, willing to engage, asking for explanations rather than shouting denunciations.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Better than I expected. Not victory—but not defeat. The common people are listening. The workers especially. Your 'everyone fights' has given them something they've wanted to hear for a generation.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The trial is now everything. If you judge fairly—if both Venetians and Genoese accept your verdict—it proves the system works. It gives these cautious people a reason to believe the rest might work too. They want to believe. They're afraid to believe. Show them something real.

roll.outcome: Cautious Interest. Something in the reading has resonated. The crowd engages with the races, asks genuine questions, and thirty-seven new people approach wanting details. The mood is wary but no longer hostile. The trial becomes genuinely important—proof of concept.

encounters.recap: The public reading of the Chrysobull generates cautious interest rather than hostility. The comprehensive documents and honest assessment of Constantinople's peril earn grudging respect. Thirty-seven new people approach the apostles with genuine questions, especially about military obligations and legal protections. While not yet committed, the crowd is willing to listen and judge the proposals by their implementation in the upcoming trial.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: PEOPLE OF CONSTANTINOPLE. The races have concluded. Now witness something new—justice administered fairly, between nations, according to law. The case of Domenico Fieschi, murdered in our streets. The accusation against Alessandro Duodo, Venetian merchant. Judgment by the King of Castile, under the terms of the Charter you have heard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd settled. Contarini and Lomellini took positions on opposite sides of the cleared space before the kathisma. Between them, flanked by guards, stood a tall, fair-haired man in merchant's clothes—Alessandro Duodo, the accused. Four thousand people watched. Thirty agents of Notaras waited for a misstep. Eight apostles held their breath. And the future of everything drafted in the long night hung on what happened next.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The proceedings lasted nearly two hours. Lomellini presented the Genoese case methodically—the enmity between Fieschi and Duodo over accusations of adulterated silk, the witness who had seen a tall, fair-haired man in Venetian colors leaving the alley, the staged robbery that fooled no one. His voice carried across the Hippodrome, and the crowd listened with the rapt attention people always give to tales of murder.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's defense was equally measured. Three witnesses placed Duodo at a tavern in the Venetian quarter when the killing occurred. The description—tall, fair-haired, Venetian colors—matched dozens of men. The enmity was real, yes, but enmity was not evidence. Where was the weapon? Where was the blood on Duodo's clothes? Where was anything beyond suspicion and coincidence?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan questioned both sides. He called witnesses forward, asked them to repeat their testimony under oath, probed for inconsistencies. The crowd watched a king do something kings rarely did—listen carefully, weigh evidence, treat a merchant's murder as worthy of genuine attention. The turning point came when Juan called for the tavern keeper who had served Duodo that night. The man was Greek—nervous, clearly uncomfortable testifying in such a setting. But his account was detailed and specific.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How do you remember this so clearly?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Because he didn't pay his full tab, Your Majesty. I remember men who owe me money. Laughter rippled through the crowd. The Greek tavern keeper, unintimidated by Venetian or Genoese, demanding what he was owed. It was a small moment, but it mattered. This was not Latin theatre. This was real.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The accusation against Alessandro Duodo fails for want of sufficient evidence. Suspicion is not proof. Enmity is not guilt. The witness who saw a man in Venetian colors saw exactly that—a man in Venetian colors. Not Alessandro Duodo specifically. Not anyone specifically. This does not mean Domenico Fieschi's death goes unanswered. It means the answer has not yet been found. The investigation will continue. If new evidence emerges pointing to Duodo or any other man, the court will hear it. Justice delayed is not justice denied—but justice without evidence is no justice at all.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Genoese accusation is dismissed without prejudice. You may bring it again if you find proof. The Venetian merchant is released. But released is not exonerated. If he is guilty and evidence emerges, he will hang. Make certain he understands this.

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: The court has judged according to the evidence presented. Genoa accepts the verdict. We will continue to seek the true killer.

exchanges.speaker: contarini
exchanges.text: Venice thanks the court for fair judgment. We accept the verdict and its conditions. The accused understands that release is not exoneration.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur swept through the crowd. Both sides had accepted. The system had worked—or at least, had not immediately collapsed. Anna, watching from among the apostles, heard a woman near her speak to her husband about how the king had actually tried to find the truth.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Well done. You could have freed him to please Venice. You could have condemned him to please Genoa. Instead you made them both slightly unhappy in exactly the same way. That is what fair judgment looks like.

exchanges.speaker: gennadios
exchanges.text: The documents are being copied through the night. By morning, they will be posted at every major church, every guild hall, every market square. The city will have time to read, to debate, to decide. The Patriarch has summoned a council of clergy for tomorrow. He will denounce the Tomos. But several priests have told me privately that they find the framework... not without merit. The battle is not yet lost.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: From now on, when we hold races in the hippodrome, we keep an eye on the men of Notaras. As soon as we identify them, we have one crusader shadow him. No need to hide this, we are there to make sure that these men do not intimidate others. Also, invite the italians and the greeks to participate in the races. separate the italians for now, give emotions to cool.

encounters.recap: Juan presides over the first trial under the new legal charter, judging the case of Alessandro Duodo accused of murdering Domenico Fieschi. After hearing evidence from both Genoese and Venetian representatives, Juan dismisses the charges for lack of sufficient proof while keeping the case open. Both sides accept the verdict, establishing the credibility of the new legal system before four thousand witnesses in the Hippodrome.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captain, from now on, when we hold races in the hippodrome, we keep an eye on the men of Notaras. As soon as we identify them, we have one crusader shadow him. No need to hide this, we are there to make sure that these men do not intimidate others. Also, invite the italians and the greeks to participate in the races. separate the italians for now, give emotions to cool. Also, see if you can find the true murderer of that merchant. It would be great if the murder can be solved. And send invitations for the nobles of the city to join me at the hippodrome. I am not their enemy. Maybe Notaras will not attend, but the rest...why would they not?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The shadowing we can begin immediately, Your Majesty. Thirty of Notaras's agents identified today—my men know their faces now. We put a knight on each, visible, not hiding. They'll understand the message. And if any of them tries something foolish with a Castilian knight watching... well. That solves itself.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The races—yes. Greeks and Italians both. Separate competitions for now, as you say. The Greeks have no tradition of mounted lance work, but they have horsemanship of their own. Let them show it. Let them feel this is their hippodrome again, not just a stage for foreigners. Kantakouzenos might know which Greek families still keep proper war horses. The military households. Give them a reason to attend that isn't political.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Fieschi killing. That's delicate work. We're foreigners—we can't move through the Greek quarters asking questions without causing suspicion. And the Venetian and Genoese quarters are... Not welcoming to outside inquiry. But there's a way. The Greek boy who died in the fighting after the murder—the baker's apprentice who saw the man in Venetian colors. He told his master before he died. That baker is still alive. He might know more than was said at trial. And he's Greek—he might talk to Greeks who won't talk to Latins.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: I'll need someone with local knowledge. One of the apostles, perhaps. Young Demetrios has energy to spare, and the workers know him. Or Anna—merchants hear things. Give me a few days, Your Majesty. If there's a truth to find, we'll find it.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The nobles. I'll send the invitations with proper ceremony. Formal, respectful, emphasizing that you seek counsel, not confrontation. Most will refuse—Notaras has them frightened or bought. But not all. There are houses that have feuded with Notaras for generations. The Philanthropenos family—Alexios commands the Gate of Charisius and has been working alongside our men. His kin might welcome a counterweight to Notaras's influence. The Bryennios family lost holdings to Notaras's maneuvering twenty years ago—they haven't forgotten. And there are younger sons of great houses with no inheritance to protect, nothing to lose.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: I'll have the invitations delivered tonight, Your Majesty. For the races tomorrow, or whenever you wish to receive them. Shall I suggest a private audience first, or a public welcome at the Hippodrome?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will receive them in the hippodrome, those who want to come. Those wanting a private audience may make their wishes known and I will meet with them.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Understood, Your Majesty. Public welcome at the Hippodrome for those willing to be seen. Private audiences arranged discreetly for those who... prefer to test the waters before committing.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: One more thing, Your Majesty. The strategos Kantakouzenos asked if you would sup with him this evening. Privately, at his quarters near the walls. He said there are things a soldier can say away from priests and merchants that he cannot say in council. He seemed... not unfriendly. More like a man who has made a decision and wants to speak of it plainly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Outside the Hippodrome, the evening light was fading. Constantinople's domes and towers caught the last gold of sunset. Somewhere across the city, church bells began to ring for vespers—Greek and Latin both, their tones mingling over the rooftops. The first day of public presentation was over. The documents were being copied. The trial had established precedent. The crowd had shifted from suspicion to cautious interest. Small victories, all of them—but victories nonetheless.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Shall I send word to Kantakouzenos that you'll attend, Your Majesty? Or do you have other plans for the evening?

encounters.recap: Juan issues comprehensive orders to Captain Fernán: shadow Notaras's agents at races, organize separate Greek and Italian competitions, investigate the Fieschi murder through local contacts, and invite Constantinople's nobles to the Hippodrome. Fernán provides detailed tactical responses and suggests Kantakouzenos has requested a private dinner to discuss sensitive military matters.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Three days after the trial, Anna sent word to the palace. She had been moving through her networks—the merchant wives, the market women, the invisible web of female commerce that operated beneath the notice of men who thought they controlled the city. And she had found something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The woman was perhaps thirty, though she looked older. Life had not been kind. She worked in a tavern near the alley where Fieschi died—a tavern that offered more than wine to sailors with coin. She called herself Eudokia, though Anna suspected that was not her birth name.

exchanges.speaker: eudokia
exchanges.text: I saw him. The night the Latin was killed. I was... working. In the alley nearby. I heard the struggle. Then footsteps, running.

exchanges.speaker: eudokia
exchanges.text: I pressed myself into a doorway. I didn't want to be seen. He ran past me, close enough to touch.

exchanges.speaker: eudokia
exchanges.text: Tall. Yes, tall, as the boy said. But not fair-haired. Dark. Dark hair, dark beard. Greek or Italian, I couldn't say—it was night. But not fair. The boy was wrong about that, or he lied, or... I know what I saw.

exchanges.speaker: eudokia
exchanges.text: A cloak. Venetian colors—the red and gold. But... It didn't fit him. Too small in the shoulders. He kept pulling at it as he ran, like it was borrowed. Or stolen.

exchanges.speaker: eudokia
exchanges.text: And say what? A whore's word against... anyone's? The Genoese wanted the Venetian dead. The Venetians wanted him freed. No one wanted the truth. But you... at the trial... you actually tried to find it. The truth. I watched. I thought maybe...

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: You thought maybe someone would listen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The new testimony changed everything—and complicated everything. If Eudokia was right, the killer was not fair-haired Alessandro Duodo. The dying apprentice had either been mistaken in the darkness or had seen a different man entirely—perhaps someone fleeing the scene after discovering the body, not the killer himself.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: A dark-haired man in an ill-fitting Venetian cloak. That could be half the Greeks in the city. Or a Genoese trying to frame Venice. Or someone else entirely.

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: It narrows and widens at once. We know Duodo probably didn't do it. But we don't know who did.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The news that a new witness had emerged—and that the investigation continued despite the trial's conclusion—spread through Constantinople within days. The court had not simply rendered judgment and moved on. It was still seeking truth.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: We're looking for a dark-haired man with connections to both the Genoese community and access to Venetian clothing. Someone who owed Fieschi money, or had reason to want him dead. Eudokia's testimony gives us a description to work with, and both Italian quarters are now cooperating—neither wants to harbor a man who tried to start a war between them.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: It may take weeks, Your Majesty. But we have a thread to pull. And every day the investigation continues, every day we're seen pursuing justice rather than convenience... it matters. The people are watching.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I invite those close to Fieschi to come to me. I want to know about what he was doing the days around his death.

roll.outcome: A Witness Emerges. A Greek prostitute who works near the murder scene comes forward through Anna's network. She was too frightened to speak before, but the trial's fairness gave her courage. She saw a man leaving the alley—tall, yes, but not fair-haired. Dark-haired, she insists. Wearing a Venetian-style cloak, but she thinks it was borrowed or stolen, because it fit poorly. This contradicts the apprentice's testimony or suggests the apprentice was wrong about the hair color in the dark. A different suspect entirely? The investigation shifts direction.

encounters.recap: A new witness emerges in the Fieschi murder investigation. A prostitute named Eudokia comes forward through Anna's network, describing seeing a dark-haired man in an ill-fitting Venetian cloak fleeing the scene. This contradicts the earlier testimony about a fair-haired killer and suggests someone deliberately wore Venetian colors to frame Venice. The investigation shifts direction to seek a dark-haired man with connections to both communities, while Juan's continued pursuit of justice despite the trial's conclusion earns growing respect among Constantinople's people.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They came to a chamber in the Blachernae Palace that had been prepared for the purpose—neutral ground, neither Italian quarter nor Greek street. Captain Fernán stood by the door. A scribe recorded everything. Three people answered the summons.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Giacomo Fieschi, a cousin of the deceased, perhaps forty-five, with the soft hands of a man who counted coins rather than earned them through labor. He had arrived from Genoa only a month before Domenico's death, sent by the family to assist with the Constantinople operations.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_fieschi
exchanges.text: Domenico was... careful. Methodical. He kept detailed records of every transaction. Every debt owed to him, every debt he owed others.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The moneylending. We have heard he lent money as well as trading cloth.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_fieschi
exchanges.text: A sideline. Many merchants extend credit. Domenico was... more systematic about it than most.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Who owed him money?

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_fieschi
exchanges.text: I would have to consult his records. Many people. Small amounts, mostly. Sailors needing advance on wages. Craftsmen awaiting payment for commissions. A few larger debts. There was a Genoese sailor—Pietro something—who had lost badly at dice. Three hundred ducats, perhaps more. Domenico was... not patient with defaulters. He had threatened to have the man's wages seized. All of them, for years, until the debt was cleared.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In the days before his death. Did Domenico seem worried? Frightened? Did he mention any threats?

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_fieschi
exchanges.text: He was... preoccupied. The week before he died, he spent much time with his records. Checking them, cross-referencing. He said something strange to me. He said, 'Someone has been lying to us, Giacomo. Lying to all of Genoa.' I asked what he meant. He said he needed to be certain before he spoke.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Certain of what?

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_fieschi
exchanges.text: He never told me. He died before...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Maria of Chios, a Greek woman, perhaps thirty, beautiful in a worn way. She had been Domenico's mistress for two years—a fact Giacomo clearly found distasteful but could not deny. She lived in a small house near the Genoese quarter, paid for by Fieschi. She wept as she spoke, though whether from grief or fear was difficult to say.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_chios
exchanges.text: He was afraid. The last week. He would not tell me why. He came to me less often, and when he did, he checked the windows, the doors. He asked if anyone had been watching the house.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Did you see anyone?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_chios
exchanges.text: Once. A man in the street, looking up at my window. Dark-haired. I told Domenico. He went pale. He said, 'They know I know.' I asked who. He said it was better I didn't understand.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Did he say anything about what he had discovered? About who was lying?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_chios
exchanges.text: Only... only once he mentioned ships. That someone was selling information about ships. Which ones carried what cargo, when they sailed, how many guards. I didn't understand. I still don't.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lorenzo della Torre, an older Genoese merchant, white-bearded and dignified, who had known Fieschi for twenty years. He came reluctantly, clearly uncomfortable speaking to a foreign king about Genoese matters.

exchanges.speaker: lorenzo_della_torre
exchanges.text: Domenico was ambitious. Perhaps too ambitious. He made enemies. Men who owed him money. Men whose business he had undercut. Men whose wives he had... He was not universally beloved.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Did he speak to you about something he had discovered? About lies, about ships?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see that he did.

exchanges.speaker: lorenzo_della_torre
exchanges.text: He came to me ten days before he died. He said he had found discrepancies in shipping records. Cargo manifests that didn't match what was actually loaded. Schedules filed with the harbor master that differed from actual sailing times.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Someone was falsifying records.

exchanges.speaker: lorenzo_della_torre
exchanges.text: Yes. And he believed someone in the Genoese community was selling this information. Using the false records to cover their tracks. Telling someone—he didn't know who—which ships were vulnerable, when they would sail, what they carried.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Pirates?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: lorenzo_della_torre
exchanges.text: No. He said he needed more proof. He was going to confront someone, he said, but he wanted evidence first. Something that couldn't be denied. Three days later, he was dead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When the interviews concluded, Fernán stood with Juan in the empty chamber.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: A dark-haired Genoese who owed Fieschi money—this Pietro, the sailor with the gambling debt. A conspiracy to sell shipping information, possibly to the Ottomans. Fieschi discovered it and was killed before he could expose it. This is bigger than a merchant's murder, Your Majesty. If there are traitors in the Genoese quarter selling information to the Turks... this touches the city's survival. Do we tell Lomellini? He's Genoese—the conspiracy may reach into his own circle. Or do we investigate quietly, find the traitors ourselves?

encounters.recap: Juan conducts formal interviews with three people close to Domenico Fieschi. The testimonies reveal that Fieschi had discovered falsified shipping records and suspected someone in the Genoese community was selling information to enemies—possibly the Ottomans. He was murdered before he could expose the conspiracy.

roll.outcome: Family Feud. The Fieschi family has enemies in Genoa—old feuds stretching back generations. Someone from a rival family paid for Domenico's death, using the Constantinople posting as an opportunity to strike far from home. The killer may never be identified; he was likely a professional who has already left the city. The investigation reaches a dead end. Justice cannot be served because the true architects are in Genoa, beyond reach.

encounters.recap: A roll to determine the true motive behind Domenico Fieschi's murder revealed it was not Ottoman espionage but an old family vendetta. The Adorno family of Genoa ordered Fieschi's death over an affair with Caterina Adorno, sending a professional killer to Constantinople. The investigation uncovers the truth through witness testimony but justice remains beyond reach as the perpetrators are in Genoa.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: If this is true, Your Majesty, the killer is probably already gone. Back to Genoa, or wherever men like him go between jobs. We can investigate the Genoese quarter, look for anyone who arrived recently and left suddenly, but... The men who ordered this—the Adorno—are in Genoa. Beyond our reach. Beyond anyone's reach, short of the Doge himself. And the Doge will not move against a powerful family over one dead merchant, no matter how the evidence points. We can tell Lomellini. He may want to know the truth, even if justice cannot be served. Or we can let it lie—a murder unsolved, the killer escaped, the matter quietly forgotten.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When we arrived a few days ago, the harbour was blocked off because of this murder. Have many ships left since the murder? Genoese ships?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The harbor was closed the day of the killing, and the day after. The Genoese and Venetians were at each other's throats—Lomellini feared open fighting if ships tried to leave and were accused of harboring the killer. But the blockade couldn't hold. This is Constantinople—trade is the city's lifeblood, what little remains of it. By the third day, pressure from the merchants forced the harbor open again. That was... Two days before we arrived, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: García. Find out which Genoese vessels departed in that window—from when the harbor reopened until now. Crew manifests if they exist. Passenger lists. Anyone who boarded at the last moment, anyone who paid for passage in cash without prior arrangement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: García nodded and left.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The harbor master keeps records—Greek officials, not Italian. They may be incomplete, but they'll show which ships sailed and when. If our killer is a professional, he'd want to leave quickly once the job was done. But if the harbor was closed for two days after the murder... He may have been trapped here. Waiting for a ship. And if he's still waiting...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: See what we can find. Inform the Podesta anyway. I have dinner with the military commander who wanted to speak with me privately.

encounters.recap: Captain Fernán organizes an investigation into ships that departed after the harbor blockade was lifted, hoping to trace the suspected Genoese assassin. Juan orders the Podestà to be informed while he prepares for his dinner with the military commander.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The strategos lived simply for a man of his rank—a suite of rooms in a military barracks near the walls, not in the palace. The furniture was old but well-maintained. A single servant admitted Juan and withdrew. No scribes. No attendants. No witnesses. Kantakouzenos had changed from his formal attire into a simple soldier's tunic. He looked older this way—the weight of his years more visible without the trappings of office. A small table had been set with plain fare: roasted lamb, bread, olives, cheese, a pitcher of wine that smelled of resin.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Greek wine. An acquired taste for Latins, I'm told. But it's what we have.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gestured for Juan to sit, then lowered himself into his own chair with the careful movements of a man whose joints had seen too many campaigns. For a moment, he simply studied his guest—the appraising look of a soldier measuring another soldier.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I asked you here because there are things I cannot say in council. Not in front of Gennadios, who thinks in theology. Not in front of the Italians, who think in profit. Not in front of the common folk, who need hope more than truth. I have commanded the defense of this city for eleven years. I have watched it die slowly—the population shrinking, the walls crumbling, the treasury emptying. I have written reports that no one reads, requested reinforcements that never come, proposed reforms that are ignored. And now you arrive. Nine hundred knights. Four documents drafted in a single night. Promises of alliance, restoration, a future worth fighting for. I need to know—soldier to soldier, without priests or merchants or politics—whether any of it is real.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is real. All of it. I have much to do and Constantinople is one of my goals. It is out of my hands now that I have given them a choice. I will leave my knights here for a few years while you contemplate your situation. I cannot and will not force the issue. Only when the golden decree is signed by the emperor and patriarch, will I come to the city's aid again. Until then, I will consolidate Naples. My forces are gathering in Sicily as we speak and I will push out the Anjou. I will be named heir to both Naples and Aragon. This is still the future and all futures are uncertain. But I have every trust in my own capacities that I will succeed. And then I will truly have the capacity to come to Constantinople's aid. I will set up a system that as soon as the decree is signed, ships will sail, reserves will be released, orders will go out and a relief fleet will sail to the city. That is what will happen.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: A few years. With nine hundred knights holding the walls while the Emperor and Patriarch debate whether to accept salvation. You understand what you are asking of me. Of the men who serve under me. We must hold. For years, perhaps. Against an enemy who could come at any time. Waiting for a signature that may never come, from an Emperor who hides in his chambers and a Patriarch who would rather see the city fall than accept Latin help. I have held these walls for eleven years on nothing but duty and stubbornness. I can hold them longer. But I need to know that when the moment comes—if it comes—the ships will actually sail. Not promises. Not intentions. Ships. You speak of Naples, of Aragon, of futures uncertain. I understand. A king has many concerns, many enemies, many obligations. Constantinople is one piece on a large board. But for us, Constantinople is not a piece. It is everything. The last piece. When it falls, there is nothing left. You say you will set up a system. Reserves released, orders sent, ships sailing the moment the decree is signed. Tell me how. Tell me what forces, from where, how quickly they can arrive. Not to hold you to numbers—I know plans change. But so I can plan in turn. So I know what we are holding for.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Also understand my own position. I am a latin king who's presence is now unwanted by both the emperor and the patriarch. What I think will happen is that either the city signs the decree at it's own pace. But it will require something to shift in the city itself. The emperor is too scared and the patriarch too...old. But that is not up to me. Imagine if I took the city by force. I would be everything they accuse me of when they remember 1204. No, this choice must come from within. As soon as my help is accepted, I will activate my forces. They will sail. First, the order of the knights of Rhodes. I will instruct them to increase their number and to be ready to sail to Constantinople as soon as my commander has witnessed that the decree is signed lawfully and is in the possession of a signed copy. He will then send out messages to me and to other forces already positioned to aid. I will come at best speed depending on where I am personally. I will ready an army in Naples and Sicily with plans to reinforce the city when the moment comes. At least 10.000. And the knights of Rhodes will deliver at least 2000 as well. Maybe more. They only have to hold out long enough for me to arrive with my main force of 25.000. Then, together, we will have more than enough to defend the city and to drive them back.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Knights of Rhodes. Two thousand. They could sail within days of receiving word—Rhodes to Constantinople is what, a week with good winds? Less if they push. That's the first wave. Enough to reinforce the walls, buy time for the main force. Naples to here. Three weeks, perhaps four, depending on weather and how many stops for water. If your army is already assembled in Sicily, waiting... you could cut that to two weeks. Ten thousand from Naples. Two thousand from Rhodes. Twenty-five thousand as your main force. That's nearly forty thousand men. More than the Turks brought against Thessalonica. Enough to not merely defend but to strike back. The question is time. From the moment the decree is signed to the moment the first knights of Rhodes arrive—one week, perhaps two. From that moment to when your main force arrives—another three weeks, maybe four. Five to six weeks total. Can we hold for five to six weeks against a full Ottoman assault? With nine hundred Castilian knights, the current garrison, and proper preparation? Yes. Probably. The walls have held against worse odds, when they were properly manned. But only if we have warning. If the Turks march tomorrow, before any of this is in place... Your commander who will witness the signing. Who holds the decree, sends the messages. This man carries the survival of Constantinople in his hands. Who do you intend for this duty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My commander is Sotomayor. He is an honourable man and well capable of this responsibility. I will supply your foundries with ore so you can smelt bronze cannons. That will aid in the defence as well. It is also my hope that the city does not wait to sign the decree until the walls have been breached, but would rather have the foresight to sign it as soon as the sultan starts to call up his army. Or even sooner.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I have watched him work these past days. He commands respect from his men. He speaks little and does much. These are good qualities in a man who must wait, and watch, and judge the moment. Bronze ore. That is... We have foundries. We have men who know the craft—the tradition has not entirely died. What we lack is material. The treasury cannot afford to purchase ore at Venetian prices, and what little we had has gone to church bells and desperate repairs. Cannons change sieges. The Turks know this—they have been experimenting, building larger and larger bombards. If we had our own, mounted on the walls, we could break their siege engines before they reach us. Kill their sappers. Shatter their formations as they advance. Give me bronze and time, and I will give you walls that bite back. Your hope is my hope. That wisdom prevails before desperation forces the issue. But I know this city. I know its Emperor, its Patriarch, its nobles. They will debate. They will delay. They will convince themselves that the threat is not imminent, that something will change, that God will provide a miracle that does not require them to swallow their pride. The decree will be signed, if it is signed at all, when Turkish campfires are visible from the walls. When the first stones strike the gates. When it is almost too late. That is why your system of swift response matters so much. We will not have months of warning. We will have weeks. Days, perhaps. But you have given me something I have not had in years. A plan that is not fantasy. Forces that are real, not promised by distant cardinals who never deliver. A timeline measured in weeks, not 'someday' or 'God willing.' I will hold these walls, King of Castile. I will train the militia, enforce the obligations, prepare for the storm. And when the Emperor and Patriarch finally find their courage—or have it forced upon them—I will make certain Sotomayor's message reaches you. Now. Tell me of these Turks you have fought. The Moors of Granada. I have read what the ancients wrote of siege warfare, but you have lived it recently. What have you learned that books do not teach?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I won a great victory at the start of the campaign. I had deployed my bombards against their fort and the sultan had force-marched his men into the field. I had left my cannons deliberately exposed and he took the bait. Our armies were relatively equally matched but they were exhausted and we knew they were coming. I led my heavy cavalry as we rode them down. A crushing victory that set the tone. They would never dare face me in the field again. But the war was far from over. They resorted to attacking our supply lines and would scatter when we formed up. They made us bleed and sweat for every piece of land. My cannons were my strength. They reduced forts in weeks and we assaulted them if they did not surrender. I would always ride out in front of the fort or city myself to demand surrender. Sometimes they betrayed the flag of truce and tried to kill me. They did not succeed. Last year, I accepted the Sultan's surrender after I had taken all the lands around his city. There was nowhere left for him to go.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You baited him with your cannons. Let him think you had made a mistake, overextended. And when he committed... That takes nerve. To expose your greatest strength as a lure, trusting that you can recover it before it's lost. The Turks will not make that mistake. Murad is patient. He learned from his father's failures—the disaster at Ankara, when Timur shattered the Ottoman army. He does not force-march into traps. He prepares. He waits. He lets time do his work. But his son, Mehmed, the young one—I have heard he is different. Ambitious. Impatient. Hungry to prove himself. If the father dies before the son has learned patience... The siege warfare. The cannons reducing forts in weeks. This is what we must prepare for—but in reverse. We will be inside the walls, not outside. When you assaulted a fort that would not surrender—how did you break them? Scaling ladders? Breaches in the walls? Mining? And the attacks on supply lines—the bleeding, the scattering. This is what we have suffered for decades. Raiders who strike and vanish. How did you counter it? How did you protect your supplies while still advancing?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I reduce the walls until the rubble piles high enough you can clamber inside. Then we offer one chance of surrender, then we push. In order to protect my supplies, I deployed lots of cavalry myself. And large and protected convoys. Try and keep the sieges short. And strike at their bases of operation. They cannot attack themselves if they cannot feed their horses. I have founded an academy to study the Ottoman tactics and to develop new tactics myself. I have taken ten officers of that academy with me to learn.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: An academy. To study the enemy. To develop new tactics. Not merely training soldiers to fight as their fathers fought, but... systematically learning. Adapting. Do you know what we have, King of Castile? Old books. Treatises written centuries ago by men who fought Persians and Arabs—enemies who no longer exist, using tactics long obsolete. The Strategikon of Maurice. The Taktika of Leo. We copy them, study them, revere them. And we lose. Battle after battle. City after city. Because we fight the wars of our grandfathers while the Turks learn and change and grow. Ten officers. Studying Ottoman tactics. Developing counters. This is worth more than a thousand knights. Knights can hold a wall. But officers who understand the enemy—who can predict what he will do before he does it—they can win wars. These officers. I would speak with them. Learn what they have learned. And perhaps... share what we know of the Turks from this side. We have fought them longer than anyone. We have lost more than anyone. Surely in all that losing, we have learned something worth preserving. When you leave for Naples—these officers. Could some of them remain? Work with my men, share their methods? And learn from us in turn what the Ottomans do in this theater, how they move, how they think?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe, I will have to see if they will want to stay. It is not even clear if the city will sign the decree. That brings me to another question. Should I not ask the emperor if he wants me to send the ore for the cannons? I ask nothing in return, it is a gift, like the walls. But I feel like I should discuss this with the emperor.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You touch on a delicate matter. The Emperor is... wounded. His pride. His authority. You spoke to his people directly, in his Hippodrome, without his blessing. The Patriarch and Notaras have been whispering in his ear ever since—telling him that you seek to supplant him, that your generosity is merely conquest by another name. If you approach him now, asking permission to send ore for cannons... it could go two ways. He might see it as respect. A foreign king acknowledging that the Emperor's consent matters, that Constantinople is still his city. It might begin to heal the breach. Or he might see it as mockery. The conquering Latin, flush with triumph from the Hippodrome, coming to ask permission for a gift the Emperor cannot refuse without looking foolish. Notaras would frame it that way. 'See how he humiliates you, Majesty. He asks for permission he does not need, knowing you must grant it. He makes you a puppet blessing your own subjugation.' I know this Emperor. I have served him for eleven years. He is not a bad man. Not a weak man, not truly. But he has been Emperor of a dying Empire his entire reign. Every year, less territory. Every year, fewer soldiers. Every year, more humiliations. It has... curdled something in him. Made him suspicious of strength, because strength reminds him of his own weakness. My counsel? Yes, approach him. But not alone. Not publicly. And not asking permission—offering consultation. 'Your Imperial Majesty, I intend to send bronze ore to aid in the city's defense. I wished to inform you personally, and to ask if there are other materials the foundries require.' You make the decision, but you give him the dignity of being informed first. You treat him as what he is—the sovereign—without actually needing his approval. But I am a soldier, not a courtier. There are subtleties I may be missing. And much depends on his mood, on who has spoken to him most recently, on whether the Patriarch has been filling his head with fears.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Understood. After I have left and after I have arranged my affairs in Naples, I will develop my plan to aid the city and send you a copy. But please do what you can to let the powers that be sign the decree. It gives us the best chance.

encounters.recap: In a private military meeting, Juan and Kantakouzenos discuss the detailed logistics of defending Constantinople. Juan outlines his relief plan: Knights of Rhodes arriving within 1-2 weeks, followed by his main force of 25,000 within 5-6 weeks total. Kantakouzenos commits to holding the walls and shares his concerns about Byzantine political delays. They exchange military experiences and discuss Juan's tactical academy. The conversation reveals the pragmatic military alliance beneath the diplomatic tensions, with Kantakouzenos accepting Juan's promise of bronze ore for cannons and advice on approaching the wounded Emperor diplomatically.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The night air was cool, carrying the salt smell of the Golden Horn. Somewhere in the darkness, the walls stretched endlessly, manned by too few men guarding too much.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan goes to meet with the nobles who want to meet with him at the Hippodrome. He has drafted comprehensive proposals for reform but has not met any nobles apart from Notaras. The Byzantine nobility may regard him as friend or enemy regardless of his intentions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Nearly twenty nobles appear at the gathering, including representatives from several significant houses. The Philanthropenos patriarch himself attends—a statement, given his family's longstanding rivalry with Notaras. He asks thoughtful questions and listens carefully to the answers. The conversation becomes genuinely substantive: how to implement reforms without chaos, how to phase in obligations, how to handle households that resist. Some nobles still hold back, but others are clearly positioning themselves as potential allies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One noble says openly: 'The Emperor hesitates. The Patriarch preaches. Notaras schemes. Meanwhile, the Turks sharpen their swords. Perhaps it is time for those of us who will actually fight to make our voices heard.' The gathering reveals emerging cracks in the opposition to Juan's proposed reforms, with military families particularly interested in his defense-focused approach.

roll.outcome: Emerging Support. Nearly twenty nobles appear, including representatives from several significant houses. The Philanthropenos patriarch himself attends. The conversation becomes genuinely substantive, with some nobles clearly positioning themselves as potential allies.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Byzantine nobles at the Hippodrome to present his reform proposals. Nearly twenty nobles attend, including the influential Philanthropenos patriarch, representing a significant cross-section of Constantinople's aristocracy. While some remain cautious, others position themselves as potential allies, with military families showing particular interest in Juan's defense-focused reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon sun slanted across the Hippodrome as the nobles began to arrive. They came in small groups at first—twos and threes, moving cautiously, glancing around to see who else had dared attend. But as the seats filled, something shifted. Safety in numbers. Nearly twenty nobles eventually gathered, representing houses whose names stretched back centuries in Constantinople's history.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos—the patriarch himself, not a proxy. Bryennios—three of them, including the old man's eldest son. Raoul, Laskaris, Asanes... These are not minor houses, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alexios Philanthropenos the Elder was perhaps sixty, with the weathered look of a man who had actually worn armor in his youth rather than merely owning it. His family had commanded the Gate of Charisius for three generations; his younger kinsman still held that post and had worked alongside the Castilian knights on the walls. He took a seat near the front—a deliberate choice, visible to all. His presence alone was a statement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The conversation that emerged was more substantive than Juan had yet experienced with Byzantine nobles. A Bryennios cousin asked about enforcement: 'The pronoia obligations—you speak of enforcement. How? The Emperor has issued such decrees before. They are ignored. What changes now?' A Laskaris uncle questioned: 'The thematic system requires land. We have no land. Thrace is ravaged, Anatolia is lost. Where do these soldier-farmers come from?' A younger Asanes challenged: 'You ask us to give up our household guards, to serve personally in campaign. What guarantee do we have that this is not simply a Latin scheme to disarm us before conquest?'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A cluster of nobles from houses with genuine military traditions gathered to one side, their conversation growing animated. One of them, a Raoul with a scarred cheek and the bearing of a professional soldier, spoke loudly enough for others to hear: 'My grandfather held the Hexamilion Wall with two hundred men against ten thousand. He died there, but he held. Now I am told I cannot be asked to serve because my household guards are private property? My grandfather would be ashamed.'

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I will say what others are thinking but afraid to voice. The Emperor hesitates. We all know why—his pride is wounded, the Patriarch whispers poison, Notaras schemes for his own advantage. Meanwhile, the Turks sharpen their swords. How long do we wait? Until the Sultan's banners are visible from these seats? I have read these documents. All of them. The theology, the law, the military obligations. They are not perfect. They demand much of us—too much, some would say. But they are real. They are comprehensive. They were not written by men who intend to abandon us after extracting what they can. Perhaps it is time for those of us who will actually fight to make our voices heard.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask why the noble obligations will be upheld now, What changes? Well, I as defensor will be upholding them. I am determined to win. We all fight and if we first have to remind those who do not want to that even they should fight, then we do so together. Will you help me? I command enough men as well to make sure every noble remembers his obligations. But the most important thing is that it simply is the right thing to do and I am sure the Greeks will remember this as well.

roll.outcome: Emerging Support. Nearly twenty nobles attend, including representatives from several significant houses. The Philanthropenos patriarch himself attends—a statement, given his family's longstanding rivalry with Notaras. The conversation becomes genuinely substantive: how to implement reforms without chaos, how to phase in obligations, how to handle households that resist.

encounters.recap: Juan's public reception for Constantinople's nobility draws nearly twenty representatives from significant houses, including the Philanthropenos patriarch himself. The gathering produces substantive discussion of military reforms, with nobles from military families showing genuine support. Theodoros Kantakouzenos openly calls for action, and several nobles request private audiences, marking the first cracks in aristocratic opposition to Juan's proposals.

roll.outcome: The Military Families Commit. The Raoul soldier speaks for his faction: 'You ask when we start. You say the choice is ours. Very well—I choose. My forty men are yours the moment the decree is signed. I will tell others of my kind. The nobles who remember what we were meant to be.' The young Asanes joins him, then two others from military houses. The Philanthropenos patriarch watches this with interest but does not yet add his voice. A core of genuine supporters has emerged—small, but real. The cautious nobles remain cautious, but they have seen that supporting Juan is possible.

encounters.recap: Following Juan's direct address to the Byzantine nobles about unified command and military reforms, a roll determined their response. The military families, led by the scarred Raoul soldier, committed their support immediately, with the young Asanes and two other military houses joining them. While the cautious nobles remained uncommitted, a core of genuine supporters emerged, demonstrating that backing Juan's reforms was politically viable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A silence followed Juan's words. The nobles glanced at one another—the ancient Byzantine calculation of who would move first, who would risk being seen to lead.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_soldier
exchanges.text: You ask when we start. You say the choice is ours. Very well—I choose. My forty men are yours the moment the decree is signed. Not the best equipped, not the most numerous—but real soldiers who know which end of a sword to hold. I will tell others of my kind. The nobles who still remember what we were meant to be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The young Asanes moved first—stepping forward to stand beside Raoul, his face pale but determined.

exchanges.speaker: asanes
exchanges.text: I have no lands, no guards, nothing but a name. But the name is old and it means something. I stand with this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then Theodoros Kantakouzenos, the strategos's cousin who had spoken earlier.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: My garrison on the sea walls. Sixty men. They will answer when called.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A fourth noble—a Melissenos, from a family with a long military tradition—joined them. A fifth. A sixth. Men from houses whose names meant something in Constantinople's military history, even if their wealth and lands had dwindled with the Empire itself.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos_patriarch
exchanges.text: You have found your soldiers, King of Castile. A few hundred men, perhaps. Brave men, no doubt. But brave men die on walls as easily as cowards. I am not ready to commit House Philanthropenos today. We are not soldiers scrabbling for honor—we are one of the great families of this city, and our word, once given, cannot be taken back.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos_patriarch
exchanges.text: But I will say this. I have watched. I have listened. I have read your documents—all of them, not merely the summaries. And I have seen something I have not seen in many years. I have seen a man who means what he says. Whether he can do what he says—that remains to be proven. But the intention is genuine. This I believe.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos_patriarch
exchanges.text: I will not sign today. But I will not oppose those who do. And I will watch. If the military families commit and are not betrayed—if the reforms begin and are not abandoned—if the Latin king proves himself in deeds as he has in words...

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos_patriarch
exchanges.text: I would still speak with you privately, King of Castile. There are matters best discussed away from so many ears. Send word when you have time.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_soldier
exchanges.text: Seven houses. Not many. But it's a start—the first crack in the wall of noble cowardice. Word will spread that some of us chose to stand. Others will have to decide if they want to be remembered as men who hid behind Notaras's skirts while the real nobles acted. What do you need from us first?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I must remind you that the next step is really the signing of the decree and the choice be made. You have made up your mind, but others have not. If you believe that fighting is the best way forward, then you must do what I cannot. Convince your fellow men. The emperor must sign the decree, and then I will come.

roll.outcome: The Military Families Commit. Seven military houses pledge their forces and support, commanding approximately 250 soldiers between them.

encounters.recap: Seven Byzantine military houses commit to supporting Juan's reforms, led by the Raoul soldier who pledges his forty men. The Philanthropenos patriarch, while not committing, signals he will not oppose the reforms and requests a private meeting. A core of genuine supporters emerges among the nobility.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber was small, private—a room in the Blachernae that had once served for intimate imperial audiences. Now it held only a table set for two, wine, bread, olives, and cold lamb. No servants remained after setting the food. No scribes. No witnesses. The Philanthropenos patriarch moved stiffly as he sat, age weighing on joints that had once carried armor. But his eyes remained sharp, studying Juan with the careful assessment of a man who had survived decades of Byzantine politics.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I will speak plainly, because we have little time for the usual dances. You have impressed me. This is not easy to do. I have seen emperors, patriarchs, generals, and foreign kings beyond counting. Most are fools, knaves, or both. You are neither. This I have determined. But being neither fool nor knave does not mean you will succeed. Many good men have failed to save this city. Many wise plans have crumbled to dust.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I did not come today merely to evaluate your character. I came because I need to understand something that will determine whether House Philanthropenos commits fully or stands aside. Notaras controls the Emperor. You have seen this. The Patriarch reinforces it. Between them, they have convinced John that you are a threat—another Latin come to finish what the Fourth Crusade started. The Emperor is not evil, not stupid. He is afraid. Afraid of you, afraid of the Turks, afraid of his own nobles, afraid of making any choice that cannot be undone. How do you intend to break this? The decree requires the Emperor's signature. The Emperor will not sign while Notaras holds his ear. You cannot force him without becoming what they accuse you of being. So. What is your plan for the Emperor?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I like it when men speak their hearts openly and clearly. I command many men and am very rich. But my greatest asset is my reputation. Everyone knows I am honourable and will always keep my word. That I am just, generous, pious and I hope they regard me as a good person as well. What I ask is enormous. I ask a city that - while christian - is distinctly different from my latin roots. And this is needed if we want to win this war. It must be given freely. I am your friend, not your enemy. I could drum up more support and storm the imperial palace and make him sign with a knife on his throat. But this is not my way. The choice to name me defensor must come from within. If I were a Greek noble living in the city? Maybe I would rebel, take matters in my own hands. Maybe not. But I will leave you to your fate. I cannot help those who do not want to be helped. I have no plan for the emperor. You either sign or you do not and likely perish. But I will never overthrow a christian king for personal gain.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You will not overthrow a Christian king for personal gain. Even one who may doom his own city through fear and paralysis. This is... not what I expected to hear. I have known many men who spoke of honor while planning betrayal. I have watched emperors deposed by generals who claimed to act for the good of the Empire. I half-expected you to ask me to help you 'convince' the Emperor through means that would leave blood on both our hands. Instead you tell me you have no plan. That the choice must come from within. That you will leave us to our fate if we cannot save ourselves. Do you know how strange this sounds to Byzantine ears? We have spent a thousand years learning that power is taken, not given. That those who do not scheme are destroyed by those who do. That honor is a mask worn by clever men to hide their true intentions. And now a Latin king sits before me and says he will not force the issue. That he respects our choice even if that choice is death. Either you are the most honorable man I have ever met, or the most cunning. I confess I cannot yet tell which. You say if you were a Greek noble, perhaps you would rebel. Take matters into your own hands. Is this what you are suggesting I should do?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am not blind. The emperor is so afraid and in the control of Notaras that I doubt he will only sign when it is already too late. Maybe he surprises me who knows. The best outcome I see for the city is that they sign maybe in a years time without Ottomans knocking on the gates. For that to happen, something must change in the city. This may be chaotic and may even not be bloodless, but still better then risk letting the city fall. For your sake, I hope you or someone else does something to break the deadlock. So yes. In a sense, I hope that you will do something that breaks Notaras's hold over the emperor. It will be better for the city in the long run. But as I explained, I will not participate or interfere. Doing so would make me the latin crusader of 1204 everyone fears me to be.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Break Notaras's hold over the Emperor. You understand what you are suggesting. Notaras commands three hundred household guards. He controls much of the city's remaining trade. Half the noble houses owe him money or favors. The Patriarch supports him because they share a common enemy—you. To break his hold would require... what? Assassination? Civil war in the streets while the Turks watch and laugh? A palace coup that leaves the Emperor a puppet of different masters? These things are not unknown in Byzantine history. But they are bloody. They are uncertain. And they tend to devour those who begin them.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I am old, King of Castile. I have perhaps five years left, perhaps ten if God is generous. I have grandsons who will inherit whatever I build or destroy. If I move against Notaras and fail, House Philanthropenos falls with me. Everything my father and grandfather built, gone. My grandsons beggared or dead. If I move against Notaras and succeed... what then? I become the power behind a frightened Emperor.
