I spend my remaining years holding together a coalition of nobles who supported me only because they hated Notaras more. And when I die, it all falls apart again. You offer me no help. No Castilian swords to tip the balance. Only the observation that someone must act, and the hope that it will be me. Why should I risk everything for a city that may be doomed regardless? Give me a reason, King of Castile. Not flattery, not promises you will not keep. A reason.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Within ten years or so the Ottomans take the city, you will lose all if something is not done. All your legacy and prestige wiped out. Maybe even your bloodline. That is what the decree is aimed to prevent. This is not a power struggle internal to the city, it is a question about survival. But beyond that, if I am declared protector, I will need nobles who want to do the work. Not just support me but also help me run the empire as we restore it. I can offer you position in this new empire. If we succeed, I imagine your real wealth and prestige will multiply manyfold compared to your present situation.

encounters.recap: Juan dines privately with Alexios Philanthropenos, discussing the deadlock preventing his appointment as defensor. Juan refuses to use force against the Emperor, instead suggesting that Byzantine nobles must act to break Notaras's control. Philanthropenos weighs the risks of moving against Notaras, while Juan offers him a prominent position in a restored empire if they succeed.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Why should I risk everything for a city that may be doomed regardless? Give me a reason, King of Castile. Not flattery, not promises you will not keep. A reason.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If within ten years or so the Ottomans take the city, you will lose all if something is not done. All your legacy and prestige wiped out. Maybe even your bloodline. That is what the decree is aimed to prevent. This is not a power struggle internal to the city, it is a question about survival. But beyond that, if I am declared protector, I will need nobles who want to do the work. Not just support me but also help me run the empire as we restore it. I can offer you position in this new empire. If we succeed, I imagine your real wealth and prestige will multiply manyfold compared to your present situation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos stroked his beard, his eyes never leaving Juan's face. The silence stretched between them—the old man weighing, calculating, turning over every word that had been spoken.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You ask me to act without your help. To break Notaras's hold while you sail to Naples and fight your own wars. To risk my house, my grandsons' futures, everything my family has built over three centuries—on the strength of your reputation and your word.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reached for his wine, drank slowly, set the cup down with deliberate care.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I am not dismissing you. What you have said tonight... it has weight. The Turkish threat is real. Notaras's grip on the Emperor is poison. Something must change or we all perish—this I cannot deny.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaned forward, and his voice took on a harder edge. The courtier's mask slipped, revealing the patriarch beneath—a man who had not kept his house alive through decades of Byzantine intrigue by accepting vague promises.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: But you speak of position in a restored empire. Of wealth and prestige multiplied manyfold. These are fine words, King of Castile. Merchant's words. Payment upon delivery, with delivery uncertain. I am not a merchant. I am the head of House Philanthropenos. When I risk, I risk not merely myself but my sons, my grandsons, the blood of my blood for generations to come. I do not gamble on fine words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He fixed Juan with a steady gaze.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: If you want me to move against Notaras—to build the coalition you cannot build, to apply the pressure you cannot apply—then I need more than promises of future reward. I need specifics. What lands would House Philanthropenos hold in this restored empire? Not 'some lands'—which provinces, which cities, which revenues? What offices? Would my sons command armies? Govern territories? Sit on whatever council advises the Defensor? What guarantees for my grandsons? Written assurances that survive your death, should you fall in battle before the restoration is complete?

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You have asked me to trust you. Very well—I am prepared to trust you, if you give me something concrete to trust in. Write it down. Seal it. Make it binding. Then House Philanthropenos will act. So. What exactly are you offering?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So I could for example put into writing promising you the dukedom of Thrace for example? And a position for your son as commander? I give out command position only based on merit. Without seeing your son, I cannot promise anything. But I can promise you the title of lands or something similar when we eventually take these lands.

roll.outcome: Conditional Interest. Philanthropenos is prepared to trust Juan if given concrete terms - specific lands, offices, and written guarantees. He demands the dukedom be put in writing and sealed before House Philanthropenos will act against Notaras.

encounters.recap: After Juan's appeal combining the stick of Ottoman doom with the carrot of position in a restored empire, Philanthropenos responds with cautious interest but demands specific written terms. He wants concrete assurances about lands, offices, and guarantees for his descendants before committing House Philanthropenos to move against Notaras.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: But the details matter. Who drafts this charter? Who decides which house receives which territory? If you assign the titles yourself, some will cry Latin favoritism. If the nobles negotiate among themselves, they will argue for years and accomplish nothing. And there is the question of precedence. You say my family would receive a 'most prestigious' title. I believe you mean this sincerely. But without specifics written down, what happens if you die? If your heir has other favorites? If the reconquest takes longer than expected and memories of tonight's conversation fade? Propose a mechanism. How would this charter be created, and how would House Philanthropenos's position in it be guaranteed? Answer that, and I think we may have the foundation of an agreement.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will want to hear all claims and nobles interested. Maybe even all the nobles would have to be included in this document eventually. It is all conditional on me being the defendor and as defendor, I can give out the titles anyway. So having heard the claims, I will try and distribute the titles fairly, based on current capacity mostly. Right now, Constantinople only has the city left you say. What titles have been lost during the last 50 years?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos's expression shifted—something flickered behind his eyes. Pain, perhaps. Memory.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Fifty years. You ask what we have lost in fifty years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose and moved to a side table where maps had been laid out—old maps, showing an empire that no longer existed. His weathered finger traced boundaries that had become ghosts.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: When my father was a young man, we still held this. The second city of the Empire. The co-capital. Seat of a kingdom in its own right. Population of perhaps forty thousand. Lost to the Turks four years ago—1430. I knew men who died on those walls. The Duke of Thessalonica was a title worth holding. Adrianople. The old capital of Thrace. Lost before I was born, yes—1369—but the noble families who held lands there still live in this city. The Palaiologoi themselves once drew revenues from the Thracian countryside. All gone. The Ottomans rule from Adrianople now. They call it Edirne. The Black Sea coast. Mesembria. Anchialos. Sozopolis. These fell in my grandfather's time, but the titles remain—empty honors held by families who remember when they meant something. And beyond—though this was longer ago—Anatolia. Nicaea, where the Creed was written. Nicomedia. Prusa—which the Turks call Bursa and have made their holy city. Philadelphia held out until 1390, the last Christian city in Asia Minor. Forty-four years ago. Men still living in Constantinople remember when it fell.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: What titles have been lost? I shall list what I can recall. Thessalonica: The Doux of Thessalonica—military governor. The Kephale of the city—civil administrator. The various prokathemenoi of the surrounding districts. Noble estates throughout Macedonia that supported a dozen families. Thrace: The Doux of Adrianople—though that title has been empty for sixty years, the claim persists. The Strategos of the Thracian theme. The Kephalai of Didymoteichon, Tzurulum, Selymbria—though Selymbria we still technically hold, barely. The Black Sea Coast: The Doux of Mesembria. The Archon of Anchialos. The Strategos of the coastal theme. Fishing rights, harbor revenues, the grain trade from the northern shores—all lost. Macedonia beyond Thessalonica: Serres fell to the Serbs first, then the Turks. Christoupolis. Drama. Kavala. Each had its kephale, its local lords, its noble estates. The Islands: We have lost less here—the Venetians and Genoese took most of them centuries ago—but Lemnos, Imbros, Samothrace, these changed hands within living memory. Thasos. The northern Aegean was once ours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returned to his seat, suddenly looking older.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: And then there is what we still hold, barely, but may lose at any moment. The Morea—the Peloponnese—is ruled by the Emperor's brothers as Despots. It is the last substantial territory beyond these walls. If Constantinople falls, the Morea follows within a generation. You ask what titles have been lost. The answer is: everything. Every title that once meant something beyond these walls is either empty or extinct. What remains are memories, claims, and old men like me who remember when Philanthropenos meant something more than a house in a dying city. Create your charter. Distribute Thessalonica, Thrace, Macedonia, the Black Sea coast. Give us back what was taken. Some families will claim ancestral rights. Others will compete for what has no clear heir. Let them fight over it—let them want it—and you will have your coalition. But understand: these are not merely titles. They are identities. When you give House Philanthropenos the Duchy of Thessalonica—or whatever you deem appropriate—you are not giving us land we have never seen. You are giving us back who we were. That is worth more than gold. That is worth fighting for.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then let us call an aide and lets make a list of all titles, ordered in decending order of importance. The doux titles first I think.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos nodded slowly, something kindling in his eyes—the look of a man who sees an abstract discussion becoming concrete action. He rose and moved to the door, opening it to speak with the servant waiting outside. A few murmured words in Greek, and the servant hurried away.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I have sent for a secretary who knows his letters and can be trusted to keep silent. And for better maps than these—the imperial archives have surveys from when these territories were still ours. Outdated, but they show what we are dividing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within minutes, a young man arrived—perhaps twenty-five, with the ink-stained fingers and careful bearing of a trained scribe. He carried writing materials and several rolled documents. Behind him, another servant brought a larger map, which was spread across a second table.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: This is Nikephoros. My grandson's tutor. Educated at the Patriarchal Academy before it withered to nothing. He knows the old administrative structures better than most men twice his age.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The young scholar bowed nervously to Juan, clearly uncertain what he had walked into. Philanthropenos gestured for him to sit.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: We are compiling a list. Every title of significance that the Empire has lost in the past century—ordered by importance. The Doux titles first, then the lesser governorships, then the military commands, then the noble estates. You will write. We will dictate.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Nikephoros dipped his pen, hand steady despite his obvious anxiety. Philanthropenos turned to the map, his finger tracing the lost territories.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Let us begin with what matters most. The Doukai—the great military governorships. First: Doux of Thessalonica — Second city of the Empire. Commands the defenses of Macedonia. The title carried near-royal status; the last holder was Andronikos Palaiologos, the Emperor's own kinsman, who died when the city fell in 1430. Second: Doux of Adrianople — Ancient seat of Thrace. Lost in 1369. The title has been claimed by the Kantakouzenos family in exile, though it means nothing now. Whoever holds Adrianople controls the road to Constantinople. Third: Doux of the Fleet — The Megas Doux. This one still exists in theory—Loukas Notaras holds it. Though what fleet he commands is a question worth asking. A dozen galleys, perhaps. Once it meant hundreds of ships. Fourth: Doux of Mesembria — The Black Sea coast. Lost in 1396. Key to the grain trade from Crimea. The Asanes family held this title; some of their descendants still live in Constantinople. Fifth: Doux of Serres — Eastern Macedonia. Lost to the Serbs, then to the Turks after Kosovo in 1389. The Raoul family had connections there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Nikephoros wrote furiously, his pen scratching across the parchment. Philanthropenos paused, looking at Juan.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: These five are the great prizes—the titles that would make a man wealthy and powerful in a restored empire. Below them are the Kephalai, the Strategoi, the provincial commands. Dozens of them. Shall I continue?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Continue and complete the list. Include lesser titles within a doux as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos nodded and continued, his voice settling into the rhythm of a man reciting history he knew by heart. Nikephoros's pen never stopped moving.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The complete list of lost imperial titles. First, the Doukai and their subordinate offices. Thessalonica and Macedonia: Doux of Thessalonica — Supreme military governor of Macedonia and the second city. Near-royal dignity. Last holder: Andronikos Palaiologos, died 1430. Subordinate titles within the Duchy: Kephale of Thessalonica — Civil governor of the city itself. Responsible for markets, walls, and urban administration. Strategos of the Macedonian Theme — Field commander of the provincial army. Subordinate to the Doux but commanding troops in the field. Prokathemenos of the Harbor — Master of the port. Controlled customs, anchorage fees, naval supplies. Archon of the Lower City — Administrator of the commercial districts and foreign quarters. Kephale of Berroia — Governor of the inland city, second largest in Macedonia. Key position on the western road. Kephale of Edessa — Ancient city north of Thessalonica. Controlled mountain passes toward Serbia. Kephale of Rentina — Fortress town guarding the eastern approaches. Prokathemenos of the Axios Valley — Administrator of the rich agricultural lands along the river. Archon of Kalamaria — Lord of the coastal district east of the city. Kephale of Hierissos — Guardian of the approaches to Mount Athos. Prostates of Mount Athos — Imperial representative to the Holy Mountain. A position of spiritual prestige rather than military power, but significant nonetheless. Noble estates of note: The Metochion of the Philanthropenos — Our family held lands near Berroia for two centuries. The Palaiologos estates along the Axios. The Kantakouzenos properties near Rentina. The Tarchaniotes holdings in Kalamaria. Adrianople and Thrace: Doux of Adrianople — Military governor of Thrace. Commands the heartland between Constantinople and the Danube. Lost 1369. The Kantakouzenos family claims this title in exile. Subordinate titles within the Duchy: Kephale of Adrianople — Civil governor of the city. Now the Ottoman capital; they call it Edirne. Strategos of the Thracian Theme — Field commander. Once one of the most important military posts in the Empire. Kephale of Didymoteichon — Governor of the fortress city on the Maritsa River. Lost 1361. Once an imperial residence. Kephale of Tzurulum — Modern Çorlu. Controls the road from Constantinople to Adrianople. Kephale of Arcadiopolis — Lost 1365. Strategic junction town. Kephale of Bizye — Northern Thracian fortress. Lost 1373. Prokathemenos of the Ergene Valley — Rich agricultural lands, now Turkish. Archon of Mesene — Coastal district along the Marmara shore. Kephale of Selymbria — This one we still hold, barely. Twenty miles from Constantinople. Often raided. Kephale of Herakleia — On the Marmara coast. Technically ours; practically contested. Kephale of Raidestos — Lost 1354. Important port on the Marmara. Noble estates of note: The Palaiologos ancestral lands near Didymoteichon.

encounters.recap: Juan and Philanthropenos begin the systematic creation of a charter documenting all lost Byzantine titles. They summon Nikephoros, a trained scribe, and begin cataloguing the hierarchical structure of lost imperial positions, starting with the great Ducal titles and their subordinate offices. This represents the first concrete step toward formalizing Juan's proposed system for redistributing Byzantine territories to noble houses willing to support the reconquest.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: Subordinate titles within the Duchy: Kephale of Adrianople — Civil governor of the city. Now the Ottoman capital; they call it Edirne. Strategos of the Thracian Theme — Field commander. Once one of the most important military posts in the Empire.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: This date is wrong, my lord. Sozopolis fell in 1371.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: Apologies, still ours technically, but barely administered.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Now we move beyond the Doukai to the other great offices that have been lost or diminished.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos's voice grew heavier here. These have been lost longer—some for over a century—but the titles persist in memory and in the claims of families now living in Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros
exchanges.text: The list continues. Dozens more. Shall I—

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The pattern is clear. Continue to the offices of revenue.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The Morea is different. We still hold it. The Emperor's brothers rule as Despots. But if Constantinople falls...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Nikephoros set down his pen, flexing his cramped fingers. Three pages of dense script lay before him.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: There. The inventory of our losses. Every title represents lands that were ours, revenues that fed our treasury, fortresses that guarded our people. Now they are names on parchment.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Some of these—the Anatolian commands—are dreams. We will not retake Nicaea in my lifetime, or my grandsons' lifetimes. But Thrace? Macedonia? The Black Sea coast? These are possible. Difficult, but possible.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Distribute these wisely, King of Castile. Give men something to fight for—something specific, something theirs—and you will have your army. Give them vague promises, and you will have nothing but words.

exchanges.speaker: nikephoros_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Now. Which of these would you assign to House Philanthropenos?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Since it is true that you are the most prestigeous house after Notaras, it is only reasonable you get the first choice. Before I let you choose, I am sure that someone still holds a valid claim to these titles and lives in the city. Would they consider it unjust or would the people consider it theft if I now promise these lands to someone else?

encounters.recap: The comprehensive catalogue of lost imperial titles is completed, documenting hundreds of offices from the Duchy of Thrace to Anatolian commands. Philanthropenos explains the strategic value of specific titles versus vague promises, then asks Juan which territories House Philanthropenos should receive, while Juan questions the legitimacy of redistributing titles that existing families may still claim.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looked up at Juan. "My family held lands near there for two centuries. We knew the city, traded with its merchants, married its daughters. When it fell, we lost kinsmen on those walls alongside the Palaiologos duke." His voice hardened with something that might have been grief, or might have been determination. "Give House Philanthropenos Thessalonica, and we will take it back. Not for you—with you. My grandsons will grow up knowing that their inheritance is not a crumbling house in a dying city, but a great port, a proud name, a future worth fighting for." He met Juan's eyes. "Is this acceptable?"

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is. Can you help me invite the other nobles of the city to a meeting in the palace I am currently residing? Can you bring these maps and this document with you as well? So we may divide the titles fairly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos rose from his seat, and for a moment he simply stood there, processing what had just occurred. When he spoke, his voice carried a weight it had not held before.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: You have just made House Philanthropenos the future Dukes of Thessalonica. Conditional on reconquest, yes. Conditional on the decree being signed, yes. But you have said it, and I have heard it, and Nikephoros has written it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glanced at the young scribe, who looked up from his parchment with wide eyes, suddenly aware that he had just witnessed something historically significant.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: This changes everything for my house. You understand this. Yes. I will help you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He began pacing, thinking aloud.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The meeting must be handled carefully. If we simply invite 'the nobles of Constantinople,' half will refuse out of fear of Notaras, and the other half will come only to spy and report back to him. We must be strategic. First—the claimants. Those families who hold documents to lost titles. The Kantakouzenoi for Adrianople. The Asanes for Mesembria. The Raoul and Melissenos for the Serres region. The Laskaris for whatever Anatolian dreams they still cherish. These families have reason to come. You are offering them something they have wanted for generations. Second—the military families who committed today. Raoul, Asanes the younger, Kantakouzenos the strategos's cousin, the Melissenos brothers. They are already with you. Their presence will reassure others. Third—the waverers. The Bryennios, who sent their scholar but held back from commitment. The houses who came to watch but not to act. If they see the claimants gathering, if they see titles being distributed, they will not want to be left out.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He paused, frowning.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Fourth—and this is delicate—we must decide what to do about houses aligned with Notaras. Some hold legitimate claims to lost titles. Do we invite them and risk disruption? Or exclude them and confirm that this is a factional gathering rather than a restoration council? There is also the question of the Emperor. This meeting—distributing titles, creating a charter of restoration—these are imperial prerogatives. You act as Defensor, but the decree naming you Defensor has not been signed. Some will say you overstep. Others will say you are merely preparing for what will come. My counsel: hold the meeting, but frame it carefully. This is not a distribution of titles—it is a consultation. You are gathering information about who claims what, so that when the decree is signed and the restoration begins, you will know how to proceed justly. You make no final grants tonight. You listen, you record, you promise nothing beyond 'your claim is noted and will be honored if we succeed.' Except, of course, for those of us who have already committed. Our grants are... more concrete.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved toward the door.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Give me two days. I will speak to the families personally—those who trust me, at least. I will bring the maps and Nikephoros's document. And I will ensure that when you hold this council, the room is full of men who want to believe in what you are offering. When do you sail for Naples? We must time this carefully. The meeting should happen before you leave, so that the charter exists and the commitments are made. But not so soon that we cannot prepare properly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have time. I can stay for weeks if needed. So I can spare a few days. Put this into motion friend. And I will see you at the meeting.

encounters.recap: Juan grants the future Duchy of Thessalonica to House Philanthropenos, contingent on reconquest. Demetrios accepts and commits to organizing a strategic meeting of Constantinople's noble families to distribute titles and create a restoration charter, carefully managing political factions and timing.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Give me two days. I will speak to the families personally—those who trust me, at least. I will bring the maps and Nikephoros's document. And I will ensure that when you hold this council, the room is full of men who want to believe in what you are offering. When do you sail for Naples? We must time this carefully.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have time. I can stay for weeks if needed. So I can spare a few days. Put this into motion friend. And I will see you at the meeting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos paused, and something shifted in his bearing. The wary old politician who had entered this room hours ago was gone. In his place stood a man who had found, against all expectation, a reason to hope.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Friend. I have not been called that by a king before. Two days. Perhaps three. I will send word when the invitations have been accepted and the room is ready.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He gestured to Nikephoros, who gathered the maps, the parchment covered in titles, and his writing materials. The young scribe bowed deeply to Juan before following his master to the door.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: When I came here tonight, I intended to extract whatever I could from you and commit to nothing. You should know this. Instead, you have made me a Duke—or the future of one—and I find myself organizing a council that may determine the fate of this city. You are a dangerous man, King of Castile. Not because you threaten, but because you offer. I suspect I am not the first to underestimate you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bowed—a deep bow, the bow of a great lord acknowledging an equal—and departed into the night. The room fell silent. The candles had burned low, the wine was nearly gone, and through the window, the torches on Constantinople's walls flickered in the darkness like dying stars.

encounters.recap: Juan grants House Philanthropenos the future Duchy of Thessalonica in exchange for their support. Philanthropenos is transformed from cautious politician to committed ally and agrees to organize a restoration council meeting, carefully planning which Byzantine noble families to invite and how to frame the gathering as consultation rather than immediate title distribution.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council chamber smells of old stone and nervous sweat. Servants have arranged benches in a rough semicircle around a table spread with maps—Nikephoros's maps, the ones showing every lost city and title from Thessalonica to Nicaea. They came. Not all of them, but enough. Philanthropenos stands near the door, greeting arrivals with the quiet authority of a man who has gambled everything on this meeting. His grandsons flank him. Kantakouzenos arrived early and claimed a seat near the window, watching the courtyard below—watching, no doubt, for any sign of Notaras's men. The families filter in over the next hour. The Asanes send their patriarch, a white-bearded man who walks with a cane and studies the maps with hungry eyes—his family's name is written beside Mesembria. The Raoul contingent arrives in force: three brothers, all soldiers, all wearing swords despite the supposed peace of a council. One of the Melissenos cousins sits across from them, and neither party acknowledges the other. The Laskaris representative is young—a grandson of a grandson, his claim to Nicaea so distant that most have forgotten it exists. But he came. The Bryennios family sends a single man who sits in the back, arms crossed, face unreadable. And then there are others: minor houses, cadet branches, men whose grandfathers held kephalates that no longer exist. They crowd the benches, lean against walls, peer over shoulders at the catalogue of everything their families lost. Notaras has not come. Neither has the Emperor. Neither has the Patriarch. But their absence speaks.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Lords of Romania, we are gathered to discuss what the King of Castile has offered us—

exchanges.speaker: raoul_brothers
exchanges.text: What he has offered. Lands he does not hold. Titles he cannot grant. Cities in Turkish hands. Before we discuss dividing the carcass, perhaps we should hear how the Defensor proposes to kill the beast.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A fair question and I am glad you ask. Most of it is codified in the documents that support the decree of the choice, but I will happily restate my strategy. First, we must secure the city of Constantinople. This is our base of operation, our axis and anchor. We allow latins to own property in the city and we establish the mercantile courts to let trade give the economic and population boom the city needs. The city has been reducing in number every year. We must turn this around. We start building up our strength, we repair the walls, place cannons and eliminate the threat of immediate attack by the Ottomans. Then we can start planning our offence. I command a lot of forces and will gradually deploy them in this area. This will require the construction of transport fleets but with the fleets of Castille, Aragon and Naples combined in alliance, we can do this. I will come through Hungary in the beginning, weakening the Ottomans and retaking their lands is in their best interest. I have a military academy that studies Ottoman tactics and my officers will deploy these tactics and lessons in battle against them. I command personally the military orders numbering 5000 men and Castille fields 45.000 men in the field. History teaches us that with proper motivation, a crusade can field many times that number. My family controls many crowns of lands that were once part of a great empire and I will forge an alliance against the Ottomans that includes these kingdoms. We are restoring Roman glory so let the kingdoms from Naples to Iberia join in the fight as well. But I must also be honest. I cannot lay out an exact battle of campaign plan yet for re-conquest. Too much is yet unknown for we must first build up our own strength, make the city ready to receive and house an army that can face the Ottomans in the field. But I do know that the kingdoms that I command right now. The crowns of Leon and Castille. Combined with the crowns I am heir to - the crowns of Aragon and Naples. I directly command crowns to challenge the Ottomans. Add to that Constantinople that is not reducing in population and trade, but is becoming strong again. Combine that with a strong naval alliance with either Venice or Genoa. Add to that the knowledge that crusades can field armies in support. Add to that an alliance with Hungary and Poland who are waiting for years for a chance to take the fight to the Ottomans. Add the holy orders the church command and can commit to this fight. While none of this is set in stone yet, it is an array of forces so formidable we need not to have all to have such an advantage against the Ottomans that victory does not seem far-fetched to me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The eldest Raoul brother doesn't wait for the murmurs of approval that Juan might have expected. He rises from his bench, and his two brothers rise with him—a wall of scarred soldiers in a room full of old men and minor nobles.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_brothers
exchanges.text: Crowns you are heir to. King Alfonso lives, does he not? You speak of Aragon and Naples as if they were yours to command. They are not. Hungary and Poland have been waiting for years, you say. Yes. They have. They waited while Nicopolis drowned in Christian blood. They waited while Varna— No, Varna has not happened yet. But it will. It always does. The Latins promise great crusades. They march east with banners flying. And then they die in Ottoman mud while Constantinople burns. You want honesty, Defensor? I will give you honesty. My grandfather fought at the walls in 1204. Not against Turks. Against Latins. Against crusaders who came to help us. They burned the greatest library in Christendom. They melted down a thousand years of bronze and gold. They raped nuns in the Hagia Sophia and put a whore on the Patriarch's throne.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Someone in the back of the room stands and walks out. Then another.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_brothers
exchanges.text: My family has held the memory of Serres for fifty years. Fifty years of exile, of poverty, of watching our ancestral lands fall to Turkish dogs. And now a Latin king arrives with maps and promises and says trust me. How many of your grandfathers died fighting Latins? How many of your family treasures sit in Venice right now, in churches built with stolen Roman gold?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Melissenos cousin—the Raouls' rival for Serres—nods slowly. On this, at least, they agree. The Bryennios observer in the back has not moved. He is watching everything with the careful attention of a man composing a report. Raoul turns back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_brothers
exchanges.text: You have a thousand knights. I have seen them. They are impressive. But the Fourth Crusade had ten thousand knights, Defensor. And they used them to destroy us. So before we discuss your maps and your titles and your beautiful plans for restoration—answer me this one question. Why should we believe that you are any different?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Trust, yes. It all hinges on trust. If we are to fight together we must first trust one another. And trust is not won with words, nor can it be gained overnight. Instead it builds slowly over weeks, months and years. I would not trust someone I do not know. I would instead learn more about him. Not listen to what he will do, but rather look at what he has already done. What has shaped him and what others who have had dealings with him have to say.

encounters.recap: Juan presents his restoration strategy to assembled Byzantine nobles, emphasizing securing Constantinople first, then gradual expansion with Iberian and allied forces. The Raoul brothers lead hostile questioning, invoking the trauma of the Fourth Crusade and challenging Juan's claims about future inheritances. The council becomes tense as several nobles walk out, with deep skepticism about Latin promises dominating the atmosphere.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Bryennios observer in the back has not moved. He is watching everything with the careful attention of a man composing a report. Raoul turns back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You have a thousand knights. I have seen them. They are impressive. But the Fourth Crusade had ten thousand knights, Defensor. And they used them to destroy us. So before we discuss your maps and your titles and your beautiful plans for restoration—answer me this one question. Why should we believe that you are any different?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room is silent. Even Philanthropenos, who organized this council, who gambled his house's future on Juan's success, says nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Trust, yes. It all hinges on trust. If we are to fight together we must first trust one another. And trust is not won with words, nor can it be gained overnight. Instead it builds slowly over weeks, months and years. I would not trust someone I do not know. I would instead learn more about him. Not listen to what he will do, but rather look at what he has already done. Some have come to know me. Some have come to know my knights. If anyone has witnessed me being dishonest or untrustworthy, please speak now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence. Not the silence of agreement, nor even the silence of consideration. The silence of men who do not know Juan well enough to accuse him of anything—and who find no comfort in that fact. The eldest Raoul brother shakes his head slowly.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: You miss my meaning, Defensor. I do not accuse you of dishonesty. I do not know you well enough to accuse you of anything. That is precisely the problem. The knights of the Fourth Crusade were honest men, many of them. Pious men. They took the cross with sincere hearts. They meant to liberate Jerusalem. And yet when the Venetians whispered in their ears, when the debts mounted, when the politics shifted—they found reasons to turn their swords on us instead. Not because they were liars. Because they were Latins, and we were Greeks, and when the choice came, they chose their own.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Asanes patriarch stirs. His ancient voice creaks across the chamber.

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: My father was fifteen years old when the Latins came. He watched them burn manuscripts that had survived a thousand years. He asked one of the knights—a Frenchman, a man who wore the cross—why they were destroying books. Do you know what the knight said? He said, 'They are written in Greek. What use are they?' You ask if anyone has seen you be dishonest. No. But I have seen Latins be honest—honestly convinced that we are schismatics, that our faith is corrupt, that our culture is inferior. The knight who burned my father's books believed he was doing God's work. How do we know that you do not believe the same?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not and I have attributed your religion and culture every respect and honour in the written decrees I have drafted. I am an honourable man who wants christianity in all it's diversity to flourish. Recently I have stood up for the hussites. Another culture and scism from Rome who have their own convictions. Like them, I respect you as well. You ask what makes me different from other Latin crusaders. I consider myself christian before I consider myself latin. We once were one church. We have dirrerent language, customs and even interpretations. But I see much more commonalities than differences. I have given you gifts of aid without asking anything in return. I have come to your aid immediately without thought of reward. I choose to trust you in this without knowing you. I have pledged to aid you as best I can with all of my dedication, all of my might and faith. I have drawn up a plan of how to do so. A plan for victory. I have offered you sanctuary should you require it. I reject and despise what happened more than 200 years ago. I was not there. While I understand your hesitation, I cannot help you if you cannot see me for who I am instead of a crusader 200 years ago. And this is the limit of what I can do for you. I have written out exactly what will happen and what I require for victory. If you choose not to trust me and turn my aid away, that is your choice. And when Constantinople falls, I will weep and pray for the souls who are lost and the light that has been snuffed out. I humbly ask: What more could anyone in my position do? What can I do?

encounters.recap: Juan faces deep historical trauma as Byzantine nobles challenge his trustworthiness as a Latin. The Kantakouzenos and Asanes patriarchs invoke the Fourth Crusade's devastation, questioning whether Juan differs from those who betrayed Byzantium. Juan defends his Christian unity vision and offers his strategic plan as proof of good faith, but the nobles' wounds run centuries deep.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask what makes me different from other Latin crusaders. I consider myself christian before I consider myself latin. We once were one church. We have different language, customs and even interpretations. But I see much more commonalities than differences. I have come here to learn, to show my Catalina the Hagia Sofia. I may never see the day that our churches unite once more, but we may more closer to one another. Not so Rome may dominate over Constantinople or to let Orthodoxy rule over the Vatican. But we can learn to fight together and to live together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have given you gifts of aid without asking anything in return. I have come to your aid immediately without thought of reward. I choose to trust you in this without knowing you. I have pledged to aid you as best I can with all of my dedication, all of my might and faith. I have drawn up a plan of how to do so. A plan for victory. I have offered you sanctuary should you require it. I have offered to help you in every way possible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I reject and despise what happened more than 200 years ago. I was not there. While I understand your hesitation, I cannot help you if you cannot see me for who I am instead of a crusader 200 years ago. And this is the limit of what I can do for you. I have written out exactly what will happen and what I require for victory. If you choose not to trust me and turn my aid away, that is your choice. And when Constantinople falls, I will weep and pray for the souls who are lost and the light that has been snuffed out. I humbly ask: What more could anyone in my position do? What can I do?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hangs in the air like incense smoke—heavy, unmoving, impossible to dispel. The eldest Raoul brother opens his mouth. Closes it. His hand is still on his sword hilt, but the gesture has lost its meaning. He looks to his brothers. They look back. None of them speak. The Asanes patriarch stares at the maps on the table—at his family's name written beside Mesembria, at the catalogue of everything that was lost. His lips move slightly, as if rehearsing an answer, but no sound comes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretches. Ten heartbeats. Twenty. Philanthropenos shifts his weight. Kantakouzenos remains motionless by the window, watching the courtyard below with sudden intense interest in nothing at all. The young Laskaris looks around the room, clearly wanting someone—anyone—to speak. No one does. The Bryennios observer in the back has produced a small tablet and is writing something. His stylus scratches against wax—the only sound in the chamber.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And still no one answers Juan's question. Because they do not have an answer. They know only that two hundred years of grief sits in their bones, and no speech—however sincere, however humble—can reach it. They cannot say what Juan could do differently. They only know that they cannot trust, and that this inability feels less like a choice than like a wound that never healed. The eldest Raoul finally exhales. He does not sit, but he does not advance either. He simply stands there, caught between his anger and his lack of anywhere to direct it. The council has not failed. But it has stopped.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well I am glad you acknowledge at least my effort in this regard. Last year, your representative met me and asked for aid. I have promptly given it the best way I could. As fast as I could. And here I am. Do you want my help? What I wanted to do tonight is to create clarity for when we start retaking lands back and restoring the empire. So we know what we are fighting for. It does not bind you to any choice. You can still choose what you want later. Let the trust build, learn about me more.

roll.outcome: Impasse — Silence stretches. No one leaves, but no one engages either. The question hangs: what MORE could Juan do? But no one answers. They don't know. They only know they cannot trust, and cannot say why that should change. The meeting stalls.

encounters.recap: Juan makes an impassioned appeal distinguishing himself from Fourth Crusade crusaders, listing his concrete aid and protections offered. He challenges the Byzantine nobles to say what more he could do. The room falls into profound silence—they have no answer but cannot overcome their ancestral trauma. The council reaches an impasse, neither failing nor succeeding, but simply stopping in the face of wounds too deep for words to heal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One of the minor nobles coughs. And still no one answers Juan's question. Because they do not have an answer. They know only that two hundred years of grief sits in their bones, and no speech—however sincere, however humble—can reach it. They cannot say what Juan could do differently. They only know that they cannot trust, and that this inability feels less like a choice than like a wound that never healed. The eldest Raoul finally exhales. He does not sit, but he does not advance either. He simply stands there, caught between his anger and his lack of anywhere to direct it. The council has not failed. But it has stopped.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well I am glad you acknowledge at least my effort in this regard. Last year, your representative met me and asked for aid. I have promptly given it the best way I could. As fast as I could. And here I am. Do you want my help? What I wanted to do tonight is to create clarity for when we start retaking lands back and restoring the empire. So we know what we are fighting for. It does not bind you to any choice. You can still choose what you want later. Let the trust build, learn about me more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The directness cuts through the heavy silence like a blade. The eldest Raoul brother's jaw tightens. The question—do you want my help?—is not one he can dance around. His family has a claim to Serres. He came to this council for a reason, whatever his grandfather's ghosts might whisper. Before he can respond, the Asanes patriarch speaks.

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: Yes. My family has held the memory of Mesembria for thirty-eight years. I am eighty-one years old. I will not see it restored in my lifetime—I am not a fool. But my grandsons might. If someone fights for it. You ask what we are here for. I am here because my name is written on that document beside a city I will never see again. And if there is even a small chance that my grandsons might walk those streets as governors rather than beggars— Then yes. I want your help. And I want to know what my family must do to earn our claim when the time comes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls silent. The Raoul brothers exchange glances. The eldest has not moved, has not spoken. But his hand has fallen from his sword hilt. The room waits.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos, why don't you explain this document and what purpose it serves?

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: What you see here is a catalogue of everything we have lost. Every title. Every office. Every city and fortress and fishing village that once flew Roman eagles. Nikephoros—my grandson's tutor—spent two days compiling this from family records, church archives, and the memories of old men. It is not complete. It cannot be. Too much has been forgotten. But it is a beginning. The purpose is simple. When reconquest begins—if reconquest begins—there will be confusion. Disputes. Men claiming lands their families never held, or denying the claims of those who held them for centuries. We have all seen what happens when armies take cities without clear agreements. Chaos. Betrayal. Civil war before the enemy is even defeated.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: This document establishes three categories. First: titles with clear ancestral claimants. The Kantakouzenoi held Adrianople. The Asanes held Mesembria. These claims are confirmed—when those cities are liberated, those families govern them. No debate. No auction. No Latin lord swooping in to claim what is rightfully Greek. Second: titles that are disputed. Serres, for example. Two houses claim it. This council—or a future council—adjudicates. We decide among ourselves, according to evidence and merit. Not the Defensor. Us.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Third: titles with no living claimant. Lands held by Turks for so long that the families have died out or abandoned hope. These are granted to those who earn them. Who fight. Who bleed. Who commit to the restoration when others hedge their bets and wait to see which way the wind blows. Nothing in this document binds you to any choice about the Defensor or the Golden Decree. It merely establishes what you are owed and what you might earn. So that when the day comes—if it comes—we are not scrambling like beggars for scraps from a Latin table. We come as partners, with our rights written down and witnessed. That is its purpose. Questions?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber stirs. Philanthropenos's explanation has shifted something—moved the conversation from wounds of the past to calculations of the future. The Asanes patriarch is nodding, his gnarled fingers tracing the edge of the map where Mesembria sits on the Black Sea coast. For him, at least, the matter is settled. Category one. His family's claim confirmed. He has what he came for. The eldest Raoul brother, however, has fixed Philanthropenos with a hard stare.

exchanges.speaker: eldest_raoul
exchanges.text: Disputed. You place Serres in the disputed category. The evidence. My grandfather died defending Serres. His bones are buried in soil we can no longer reach. What evidence do the Melissenoi offer? A signature on a charter from a century ago?

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: My family held the prokathemenos of the Strymon Valley for three generations before yours ever set foot in Macedonia. The governorship was granted to your house by ours, as a military appointment. It was never hereditary. When reconquest comes, the original grant should be honored.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Gentlemen. This is precisely why the document exists. So that we may settle these questions before armies march, rather than after cities fall.

exchanges.speaker: young_laskaris
exchanges.text: The document mentions Nicaea. It says 'Laskaris—old claim.' What does that mean? Is my family's right acknowledged, or—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I step back and let the Greeks sort the claims out amongst themselves. I only indicate that military positions will be appointed based on merit not inheritance. And that there are plenty of titles to distribute even if two lay claim to the same title. The Greeks should first establish ancient rightful claims in this meeting. Then we can divide the remaining titles among the nobles who can fight but have no ancient claim.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The next hour is chaos—but productive chaos. The Asanes claim to Mesembria is confirmed without debate. The old patriarch signs his name beside the entry with a hand that trembles but does not waver. His grandsons, young men who have lived their entire lives in exile, watch with something like wonder. Adrianople goes to the Kantakouzenoi. The Tornikes put forward a claim to several Black Sea coastal offices below Mesembria. The young Laskaris approaches the table hesitantly. Nicaea is so deep in Ottoman territory that reconquest seems almost mythical. But Philanthropenos writes 'Laskaris claim acknowledged—to be confirmed upon liberation' beside the entry.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: It may be a hundred years. But your children's children will have this document.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Serres remains unresolved. The Raoul brothers and the Melissenos cousin have argued themselves hoarse. Finally, the eldest Raoul turns away in disgust.

exchanges.speaker: eldest_raoul
exchanges.text: We will settle this another day. When there is actually a city to govern.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The third category draws the most interest. Minor nobles crowd the table, studying the list of titles with no living claimants. The Macedonian kephalates. The Prokathemenoi of lost revenues. The island governorships. Dozens of positions that mean nothing now but could mean everything if reconquest succeeds.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Based on what the nobles stating a claim can contribute. What is the composition of the family? Are they of sufficient number that they can effectively govern once the title is reclaimed? And of course, how capable will they be during the fighting. Nobles can fight themselves and provide men. Both are needed in the fight to come. The bigger the contribution, the greater the reward.

encounters.recap: The noble council establishes a three-tier system for distributing Byzantine titles upon reconquest: confirmed ancestral claims, disputed claims requiring adjudication, and vacant titles to be granted by merit. Most ancient claims are confirmed, though Serres remains contested between the Raoul and Melissenos families. The framework creates clarity for future territorial restoration while allowing nobles to sort claims among themselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Minor nobles crowd the table, studying the list of titles with no living claimants. The Macedonian kephalates. The Prokathemenoi of lost revenues. The island governorships. Dozens of positions that mean nothing now but could mean everything if reconquest succeeds.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: How are these granted?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Based on what the nobles stating a claim can contribute. What is the composition of the family? Are they of sufficient number that they can effectively govern once the title is reclaimed? And of course, how capable will they be during the fighting. Nobles can fight themselves and provide men. Both are needed in the fight to come. The bigger the contribution, the greater the reward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur ripples through the minor nobles. This is what they came for—not the great Doukai, not the ancient claims of the Asanes and Kantakouzenoi, but the chance to earn something. To transform their families from footnotes into governors.

exchanges.speaker: stocky_knight
exchanges.text: My family holds no ancient claim to anything. We lost our lands three generations ago and have survived on military service ever since. I have four sons and eleven nephews of fighting age. If I bring fifty men to the reconquest—trained men, properly equipped—what might that earn?

exchanges.speaker: grey_haired_nobleman
exchanges.text: And what of those whose blood is ancient but whose purses are light? My family held the Kephale of Christoupolis for two centuries. We have documents, seals, the blessing of three Patriarchs. But the Turks took everything. I cannot field fifty men. I can barely field five. Does his money outweigh my lineage?

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: The Defensor speaks of contribution during the fighting. Not contribution now. A man with ancient lineage and empty pockets today might find backers tomorrow—if his claim is worth backing. Confirm your claim to Christoupolis in this document. Then find men who will fight for a share of your future revenues. This is how it has always been done.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Perhaps we should hear from those who wish to register interest in the unclaimed titles. Not final grants—those come later, when armies are assembled and contributions proven. But... expressions of intent.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: After the ancient claims have been settled, we should make a list of what every family can contribute to the fighting. How many fit fighting men and how many fit and fighting nobles. If we make a list of every family and what their contribution is, then we have established the principle by which the titles will be granted. Divide titles in Thrace first, these are the first lands we can target with our reconquest. Would this principle seem fair to you nobles?

exchanges.speaker: stocky_knight
exchanges.text: Fair. More than fair. A man knows where he stands.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: Thrace first. That is... sensible. The road to Adrianople runs through Thrace. We would be fighting to restore your lands before our own.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Geography does not care about our preferences. You cannot take Serres while the Turks hold everything between here and there.

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: The principle is sound. Contribution measured, titles allocated by merit and proximity to the front. But who judges the contribution? Who decides if fifty peasants with spears equal thirty trained men-at-arms?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: They will be judged on the basis of how much they contribute to the fight. I will not send men into a battle under-equipped and badly trained. Unless these men are unfit or refuse to train, i will consider every able bodied man as one soldier. The decrees established a system where men will be properly equipped. I will consider one noble knight equal to about 20 soldiers considering they have leadership qualities as well. Does this answer your question?

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: One to twenty. So a house that sends five knights and a hundred men contributes... two hundred soldiers' worth in the accounting? That values leadership. That is reasonable.

exchanges.speaker: grey_haired_nobleman
exchanges.text: Five men and myself. That is... twenty-five. There are merchants in this city who could field more than that. Are we to see traders governing ancient Roman cities?

exchanges.speaker: raoul_middle
exchanges.text: If they fight for them, why not? My grandfather bled for Serres. Bled and died. I would rather see a merchant who fought beside me on the walls than a nobleman who watched from his balcony and calculated his odds.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The principle is established. Contribution to the fighting determines reward for unclaimed titles. The ratio gives weight to leadership. Are there objections to recording this as the basis for future grants?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Asanes patriarch speaks first, followed by agreements from Kantakouzenos, the stocky knight, and one by one the minor nobles. The grey-haired nobleman stands alone in his silence.

exchanges.speaker: grey_haired_nobleman
exchanges.text: And those of us with ancient claims but no armies? Are we simply to be... outbid by butchers and horse-traders who can afford more swords? My family governed Christoupolis when some of your ancestors were still herding goats in Anatolia. And now I am to watch that inheritance sold to the highest bidder because I cannot match some merchant's purse?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It matters more now what you can contribute to the fight ahead of us. And there is more than enough chance for anyone willing to prove himself. We must remember what made us great in the first place. Waving papers with claims does not conquer cities. Men do. But maybe noble houses can attract followers without coin? Are Greek commoners not willing to serve a noble who has a claim to a town or city and help him take it?

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: The Defensor sees clearly. When I was young and my family had just lost Mesembria, my father gathered men the same way. He stood in the square at Thessalonica—before that city fell too—and called for any man willing to fight for the Black Sea. He promised them land, position, a share in the restoration. Forty men answered. Fishermen. Farmers. A blacksmith who had cousins in Anchialos. They followed my father for twenty years, waiting for a reconquest that never came. Your claim to Christoupolis is worth something. Not in gold—in hope. There are men in this city whose grandfathers came from that coast. Men who dream of returning. Find them. Promise them what my father promised his followers. You may be surprised.

exchanges.speaker: stocky_knight
exchanges.text: There is truth in this. My own men—some of them follow me because I pay them. But others? They follow because I have promised them a future. A farm. A shop in a city we take together. Coin runs out. Dreams do not.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Then let us record it thus: noble houses may recruit under their banners, and the men they bring—however recruited—count toward their contribution. A nobleman with an ancient claim and twenty followers he has gathered through that claim is worth the same as a merchant with twenty hired swords. The source of the men matters less than the fact of them.

exchanges.speaker: grey_haired_nobleman
exchanges.text: This is... acceptable. If my claim gives me the right to recruit, and my recruits count toward contribution, then I have a path forward.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would it be appropriate for the nobles to present themselves and their men at a chosen date? A declaration and a check as well to see how much every noble can contribute. All the nobles who contribute presenting their men before the city together?

encounters.recap: Juan establishes a merit-based system for granting unclaimed Byzantine titles, where contribution to the reconquest determines rewards. One noble knight equals twenty soldiers in the accounting. Initial resistance from impoverished ancient nobility transforms into acceptance when Juan clarifies that noble claims can attract followers based on hope rather than coin. The framework prioritizes Thrace as the first target and requires future military assemblies to verify contributions.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: We have perhaps three hundred men pledged tonight, not counting House Raoul's conditional seventy or the forces already under Strategos Kantakouzenos. A beginning. Not an army. But a beginning. How shall we proceed from here? When do we reconvene? And... Who adjudicates the Serres dispute?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I turn to the two parties who are in dispute. What do you propose how we reach resolution? In latin tradition, we let the nobles duel and grant the winner his right. Is there an Orthodox tradition that settles disputes definitively? Only one can have the claim and the other will recieve a title of similar size. How can we move on?

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: The Latin tradition has merit. Let God decide through strength of arms. My brothers and I—

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: Absolutely not. Trial by combat is a Latin barbarism. We are Romans. We settle disputes through law, through evidence, through the wisdom of judges. Not by seeing who can swing a sword harder.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: In Roman tradition, disputes of this magnitude were settled by the Emperor. Or, in earlier times, by a council of peers—a tribunal of noble houses with no stake in the outcome. We have such houses here. The Asanes have no claim on Serres. Nor do I. Nor do the Laskaris, the Bryennioi, the Doukai... But any tribunal we convene tonight would be seen as the Defensor's tribunal. A Latin judgment on a Roman matter. Unless...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Could we not form a roman tribunal of nobles that both sides accept? And let them examine the claims?

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: Yes. A tribunal of peers. This is the Roman way. Houses with no claim on Serres, no blood ties to either party. Let them examine the documents, hear the testimony, render judgment.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: A tribunal. Examining documents. Your family has always been better with parchment than with swords, Melissenos. I wonder how that might affect the outcome. Who would sit on this tribunal? Which houses? I want five. And I want the right to reject any house I believe is compromised.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room shifts uncomfortably. Serving on a tribunal means making a judgment—and making an enemy of whichever party loses. Silence stretches.

exchanges.speaker: asanes
exchanges.text: I have no stake in Serres. I could serve. If both parties accept.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: My family is... uninvolved. We have no claims in Macedonia. If my uncle permits, I could represent House Bryennios on such a tribunal.

exchanges.speaker: niketas_doukas
exchanges.text: House Doukas has no dog in this fight. We're a cadet branch with no Macedonian ties.

exchanges.speaker: kourtikios
exchanges.text: Kourtikios. My family held lands near Thessalonica before the fall. We have no ties to Serres, no dealings with either house. I came here hoping to register a claim on one of the coastal kephalates. I did not expect to be asked to judge my betters. But if both parties will accept a minor house on the tribunal, I will serve.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: Kourtikios. I know that name. Your grandfather fought at Thessalonica.

exchanges.speaker: kourtikios
exchanges.text: He died there.

exchanges.speaker: laskaris
exchanges.text: I have no connection to either house. No ties to Macedonia. My family's concerns are... elsewhere. I am young. I know this. But I can read documents and hear testimony. And I have no reason to favor either party.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: Your ancestors were emperors. Mine were soldiers. Will you understand what it means to hold a title with blood rather than ink?

exchanges.speaker: laskaris
exchanges.text: My ancestors won their throne on the battlefield, Lord Raoul. Before they were emperors, they were generals. I understand blood.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: Asanes. Bryennios. Doukas. Kourtikios. Laskaris. Three men whose families lost everything to the Turks. One who watches and reports. And a boy who claims imperial blood. House Raoul accepts this tribunal. Provided the Melissenoi accept as well. And provided the judgment is final. No appeals. No second hearings. No running to the Patriarch or the Emperor to overturn the verdict.

exchanges.speaker: melissenos_cousin
exchanges.text: House Melissenos accepts. The tribunal's judgment will be final. I trust the evidence will speak clearly.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_eldest
exchanges.text: As do I.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Let it be recorded. The tribunal for the Serres dispute: Lords Asanes, Bryennios, Doukas, Kourtikios, and Laskaris. Both parties have accepted. The judgment shall be final. When shall the tribunal convene?

encounters.recap: The noble assembly addresses the Serres succession dispute between Houses Raoul and Melissenos. After rejecting trial by combat, they agree to form a Roman tribunal of five neutral houses: Asanes, Bryennios, Doukas, Kourtikios, and Laskaris. Both parties formally accept the tribunal's authority and agree its judgment will be final.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Lord Raoul. A word, before we conclude. You spoke of 1204. Of Latin promises and Latin betrayals. These are real wounds. No one in this room denies them. But I must ask you something. When did the knights of the Fourth Crusade repair our walls before sacking them? When did they bleed beside our men for months before making demands?

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I have worked with the Castilian knights at the Gate of Charisius. I have seen them haul stones alongside our laborers. I watched a boy from Castile—seventeen years old—take an arrow through the shoulder during a Turkish skirmish last month. He is still here. Still serving. He has asked for nothing.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Ninety-three of them died on the voyage here. Storms, disease, a corsair attack. They buried their brothers at sea and kept coming. I have commanded men for forty years. I know what that costs.

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: I am eighty-one years old. I have seen many Latins come to Constantinople. Merchants who smiled while they cheated us. Diplomats who promised aid that never arrived. Knights who came for glory and left when the fighting grew hard. I understand your caution. I share it.

exchanges.speaker: asanes_patriarch
exchanges.text: But I have never seen a Latin king offer us the Alhambra as refuge if we choose to flee. I have never seen one draft documents protecting our faith before we even asked. I have never seen one say 'if you do not want my help, we part as friends' when he holds all the strength. This is not 1204. And pretending it is does not serve our interests. It only blinds us to what is actually before us.

exchanges.speaker: eldest_raoul
exchanges.text: You are right. I spoke from old grief. It is... easier to distrust than to hope. I have not seen your knights fight. I have not worked beside them as Philanthropenos has. But I see the men in this room who have, and I see that they believe you. That is worth something. Perhaps more than I credited.

exchanges.speaker: eldest_raoul
exchanges.text: House Raoul will participate in the tribunal. And if the judgment is fair, we will commit fully to what is being built here. You have my word on that.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: Let the record show what was accomplished tonight. Ancient claims confirmed. A system for merit established. A tribunal convened. And more than three hundred men pledged to a cause that did not exist when we walked through that door. We came here as scattered houses nursing old wounds. We leave as something else. Not yet an alliance. Not yet an army. But something that could become both.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The Defensor asked what more he could do. I think he has his answer. He has done enough to earn the chance to do more.

encounters.recap: The noble council concludes with a dramatic reconciliation. Senior nobles acknowledge Juan's demonstrated commitment through his knights' sacrifices and service. The eldest Raoul abandons his hostility, recognizing that 1434 is not 1204. All houses agree to participate in the merit tribunal, transforming scattered grievances into potential unity.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I will convey your acceptance. The Church of the Chora. Vespers. The day after tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning dawns clear and bright, the April sun warming the ancient stones of the Hippodrome. The great arena has not seen a crowd like this in years—perhaps decades. The awnings Theodoros arranged cast long shadows across the repaired benches, and the imperial banners along the spina stir in a light breeze from the Golden Horn. The shaded pavilion near the imperial box is comfortable, as promised. Cushions, a small table with wine and water, gauze curtains that filter the sun while allowing a clear view of the track. Lucia sits beside Juan, her hand resting on the curve of her belly—five months now, the child quickening. She looks out at the filling Hippodrome with wonder and something like disbelief.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I never thought I would see this. Constantinople. The Hippodrome. Races like the old chronicles describe.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina squirms in her nurse's arms, reaching toward the bright colors below—the pennants, the horses being led to their positions, the crowds in their faded finery. At fourteen months she understands nothing of titles or treaties, of Ottomans or Orthodox schisms. She sees only movement, color, excitement. Juan takes her from the nurse. She settles against his chest, one small hand gripping the fabric of his doublet, her dark eyes wide. Below, the stands fill. The Asanes patriarch is helped to his seat in the secondary imperial box, his grandsons flanking him. The Bryennioi arrive in force—the uncle himself, the observer who is now a judge, cousins and retainers. They are seen. They mean to be seen. Philanthropenos sits with Kantakouzenos, two soldiers watching the crowd with professional eyes. The committed houses display their colors openly. The uncommitted sit further back, watching, calculating. The Emperor's seat of honor remains empty. But a court official—a minor functionary in imperial livery—sits two rows behind it. Observing. Reporting. The Italians cluster in their own section: Venetians on one side, Genoese on the other, a careful gap between them. But they are here. Together. In a Greek arena. And everywhere, the common people of Constantinople. Thousands of them. More than came to the first races. Word has spread.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: Domine, the program for today, if you wish to explain to the little Princess. First: the horse races. Three heats. Greeks race against Greeks in the first heat—we have four teams, organized by district. The old faction colors are gone, but the competition remains. The second heat: Italians. Venetians against Genoese. We keep the course wide. For safety. Third heat: mixed. One Greek team, one Italian, one Castilian. This is... new. There was much discussion about whether it was appropriate. I decided it was appropriate. Between the heats: mounted demonstrations. Your Castilian knights will show horsemanship—the exercises they practice for war. Riding at rings, sword work from horseback, formation drills. The Greeks are curious about Western cavalry tactics. Let them see. After the races: a melee. Blunted weapons, no killing, first man unhorsed or disarmed loses. Greeks, Italians, Castilians, all mixed together. Eight men. The winner receives a purse of fifty florins and a silver cup. There was a request—from some of the younger Greek nobles—for a joust. Proper tilting, with lances. I told them this is not a Greek tradition, but they insisted they wished to try. If you permit, we could add it at the end. Informal. A demonstration, not a competition.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us see how the day goes. If everything goes without incident we can have a joust.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The four teams line up at the western end of the track. Each represents a district of Constantinople—not the old Blues and Greens of the faction riots, but neighborhoods: Blachernae, Phanar, Kontoskalion, and the harbor district near the Golden Gate. The horses are not the magnificent beasts of the old chronicles; they are sturdy, practical animals, the best the diminished city can muster. But their riders sit straight, and the ribbons on their harnesses catch the morning light. Theodoros raises a white cloth. The crowd falls quiet. The cloth drops. The horses surge forward, hooves thundering on the ancient track. The crowd rises to its feet. Lucia leans forward. Catalina shrieks with delight at the noise and motion, clapping her small hands. The Blachernae rider takes an early lead—a young man on a chestnut mare, riding low and fast. The Phanar team presses close behind. Kontoskalion and Golden Gate fall back, fighting for third. Then, on the second turn, the Blachernae mare stumbles. A gasp ripples through the crowd. The rider nearly falls, catches himself, loses three lengths. The Phanar horse surges past, then Kontoskalion. The young man from Blachernae is suddenly last, his mare limping slightly, the race seemingly lost. But he does not stop. He speaks to the horse—those nearby swear they can see his lips moving—and something changes. The mare steadies. Her stride evens. And slowly, impossibly, she begins to gain ground. The crowd notices. Murmurs become shouts. By the third turn, Blachernae has passed Golden Gate. By the fourth, Kontoskalion. The Phanar rider glances back, sees death coming, and whips his horse frantically. It is not enough. The chestnut mare crosses the finish line half a length ahead, her rider's face streaked with dust and tears. He slides from her back and embraces her neck, and the horse—as if she knows what she has done—stands perfectly still. The Hippodrome erupts. Not faction against faction. Not district against district. Simply thousands of people who have just witnessed something they will tell their grandchildren about: the day the lame horse won. The Asanes patriarch is on his feet, pounding his cane against the stone. The Bryennioi are applauding. Somewhere in the common stands, a chant begins—the rider's name, repeated over and over: 'Stavros! Stavros! Stavros!'

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Did you see that? Did you see?
