exchanges.text: I trusted him. For years. I let him control my household, my treasury, my guards. I let him...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He cannot finish. The Emperor nods slowly, his eyes still fixed on the letters spread across the desk.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Yes. A few days. I have not slept properly in... I cannot remember how long. And there is much to be done. The household to reorganize. The tagmata to rebuild. New men to trust. These will be locked in my personal vault. When the time comes for judgment, they will speak for themselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the window again, looking out over the city—his city, in a way it has not been for years.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_constantine_xi
exchanges.text: A muster. Greek nobles presenting their men. Their contribution to the restoration. I have not attended such a thing since my father's reign. Since before the walls began to crumble faster than we could repair them. I will consider it. Truly consider it, not as I have considered things these past years—weighing fears against fears until paralysis seemed the only safe choice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ghost of a smile crosses his exhausted face.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You have given me much to consider, King of Castile. A charter that binds your own hands. A palace free of spies. And now evidence that the man I trusted most was preparing to sell us all to the Sultan. Whatever I decide about the decree, know this: I will not forget what you have done. Constantinople will not forget.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand—not for a formal clasp, but openly, as one man to another.

encounters.recap: Raoul presents documents discovered in Notaras's private office revealing extensive correspondence with Ottoman officials. The letters detail Constantinople's military weaknesses, food supplies, and wall conditions, while Notaras negotiated personal guarantees for his family's survival under Ottoman rule. The discovery devastates Emperor Constantine, who realizes his most trusted advisor had been selling intelligence to the Sultan for eight months, but also liberates him to truly consider Juan's proposals for the first time in years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light streams through the windows of the Blachernae Palace, but today it illuminates something new: a palace under the Emperor's actual control for the first time in a decade. It has been only hours since the eldest Raoul—scarred veteran, newly appointed Captain of the Imperial Tagmata—led his seventy men alongside Kantakouzenos's fifty and the loyal remnants of the original tagmata to secure the gates, the kitchens, the treasury, the message rooms. Some eighty of Notaras's guards marched out at midmorning, disarmed and heading to their former master's estate. Most of the palace servants remain, nervous and uncertain, watching to see which way the wind truly blows.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In Notaras's private office, the documents sit in locked chests under guard: letters in Ottoman Turkish to the Sultan's court officials, negotiations for his family's survival when—not if—the city falls, detailed intelligence about food supplies, wall conditions, defender numbers. Evidence of treason spanning eight months. The logothetes tou dromou, once the most powerful man in Constantinople save perhaps the Patriarch himself, has fled to his estates with the proof of his correspondence with Rome's ancient enemy still warm in Juan's possession.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor—John VIII Palaiologos, Basileus ton Rhomaion—has thanked Juan with tears in his eyes. 'I finally remembered how to be brave,' he said. He has agreed to consider attending a muster. He has agreed to take a few days to settle into his new security before deciding about the decree—the comprehensive Chrysobull that would formalize Juan's role as Defensor Romaniae and establish the framework for restoration. But he has not signed it yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch withdrew in cold silence after yesterday's acclamation at the Hagia Sophia. His clergy council, assembled to denounce the Tomos of Apokatastasis, has not yet announced its verdict. The common people whispered blessings for the Defensor. The old priest gave Juan his father's wooden cross. None of this changes that the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople opposes the Latin king's presence with every fiber of his being.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And across the Golden Horn, in the estates of the Notaras family, Loukas Notaras has just received word that his decade of careful power has collapsed in a single night. His men. His guards. His control of the imperial household. Gone. And the documents—God, the documents—are in the hands of the man who came to save the city he was quietly negotiating to betray.

encounters.recap: The morning after Juan's liberation of the Byzantine Emperor from Notaras's control, the palace is secured by loyal forces. Evidence of Notaras's treasonous correspondence with the Ottomans has been seized. The Emperor is grateful but has not yet signed the decree formalizing Juan's role, while the Patriarch remains in opposition and Notaras has fled to his estates.

roll.outcome: Diplomatic Pressure - Murad sends an embassy to Constantinople ostensibly to discuss 'routine matters of tribute and commerce,' but clearly a reminder of Ottoman power. The ambassador will probe the Emperor's new arrangements, assess the Latin military presence, and deliver subtle threats about disturbing the peace.

encounters.recap: Sultan Murad II, learning of Juan's presence and the upheaval at Blachernae Palace through his lost intelligence network, opts for diplomatic pressure rather than immediate military action. He dispatches an embassy to Constantinople to probe the new Latin-Greek arrangements while delivering subtle threats about maintaining peace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Roll Result: 39 — Diplomatic Pressure. Murad II will send an embassy to Constantinople. This won't happen immediately—the Sultan needs time to learn of events, deliberate, and dispatch envoys. Juan may have 1-2 weeks before Ottoman ambassadors arrive at the Golden Horn demanding audience with the Emperor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Current Date: Approximately April 23, 1434 (the morning after the palace was secured). Juan's Arrival in Constantinople: Late March 1434 (after his audience with Pope Eugenius IV in Rome). Time in Constantinople: Approximately 3-4 weeks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's Pregnancy: She is now approximately 5½ months pregnant. Due date: late August / early September 1434. Time Pressure: Juan cannot stay indefinitely. The Naples campaign awaits, and he promised to be present for the birth. He has perhaps 2-3 months before he must depart—likely by late June at the latest to allow travel time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Ottoman Embassy: Based on the roll, expect Ottoman diplomats to arrive within 10-14 days (early May). News of Notaras's fall is probably already traveling toward Edirne. Murad will want to assess the situation before committing to any course of action.

roll.outcome: Diplomatic Pressure - Ottoman embassy dispatched to Constantinople

encounters.recap: Sultan Murad II responds to news of events in Constantinople by preparing to send a diplomatic embassy, giving Juan 1-2 weeks before Ottoman pressure arrives. Timeline established: Juan has been in Constantinople 3-4 weeks, Lucia is 5½ months pregnant, and time pressure mounts for his return to Castile.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days pass in Constantinople. The city slowly adjusts to its new reality—a palace under the Emperor's actual control, Notaras's men gone from the gates, and rumors spreading through every market and monastery about what was found in the logothetes's private chambers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You establish a pattern. Mornings: meetings with committed nobles, inspections of wall repairs with Kantakouzenos, correspondence. Afternoons: time with Lucia and Catalina in the quarters assigned to your household. Evenings: dinners with various factions—military families one night, Italian merchants another, the occasional cautious clergyman who slips in after dark.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You attend the Divine Liturgy at the Hagia Sophia again, this time without the drama of the first public appearance. The Patriarch presides with cold correctness, neither acknowledging nor denouncing your presence. The congregation's response is warmer than before. No spontaneous acclamation this time, but nods of recognition. A few whispered blessings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You put the question to Philanthropenos and the committed houses: Is there appetite for another gathering? More claims to register? More nobles ready to add their names?

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: The situation has changed dramatically since Notaras's fall. Houses that feared his retaliation now have... options. But they are Byzantine, Your Majesty. They will not rush. They will watch to see if the Emperor actually signs your decree.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: That said—yes, there is interest. I have received inquiries from three houses that sent no representative to the first council. The Doukas main branch wishes to discuss Lesbos and other Aegean claims.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: A second council would be wise, but frame it carefully. Not as 'who else wants to join'—that sounds desperate. Frame it as 'formalizing commitments already made and hearing petitions from claimant houses.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You propose another Hippodrome event. The response is enthusiastic from the committed houses—Stavros, the common hero who rides your horse Trueno, has become something of a celebrity.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: The first races established that Greeks, Latins, and Italians can compete together. Perhaps this time we emphasize cooperation rather than competition? A relay race—mixed teams of Greek and Latin riders.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let's do another race. Let's just keep it simple. Mixed contenders in every race leading up to the final race. Maybe four races? The winner of the first three races advance to the final one? I will put a prize of 250 florins as a prize for the final winner.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: Open entry? Anyone with a horse? Your Majesty, this will draw half the city. Grooms, merchants, minor nobles, soldiers—everyone who has ever dreamed of glory in the Hippodrome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Theodoros begins sketching notes immediately, outlining tryouts on Saturday and races on Sunday after morning liturgy. Heat structure with mixed Greek and Latin riders, a tribunal of five carefully balanced judges, and detailed rules to ensure fairness.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: A modest sum for the goodwill it purchases. The people will speak of this for months. 'The Castilian king who opened the Hippodrome to anyone with a horse and a dream.'

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: Stavros, the groom's son who won so dramatically at the first races—he will certainly wish to compete. He has become... something of a symbol. The common people adore him. I mention this not to suggest we fix anything—God forbid—but so you understand the stakes. Stavros matters to these people in a way that transcends a horse race.

encounters.recap: Juan organizes a second Hippodrome race with open entry for all free men with horses, featuring tryouts and elimination heats leading to a final race for 250 florins. He also considers holding another noble council to formalize previous commitments and hear new claims, while navigating the delicate political situation following Notaras's fall.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Theodoros raises one delicate matter: "Stavros, the groom's son who won so dramatically at the first races—he will certainly wish to compete. He still rides Trueno, the horse you gifted him. He has become... something of a symbol. The common people adore him."

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: If he wins again, it reinforces the story: a nobody can triumph through skill and courage. If he loses fairly, it shows the competition is genuine. But if he loses to a foul, or if the judges rule against him controversially... The crowd's mood could turn ugly.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: I mention this not to suggest we fix anything—God forbid—but so you understand the stakes. Stavros matters to these people in a way that transcends a horse race.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I let the judges handle it all. The emperor is of course invited.

roll.outcome: Observer with Message (Cautious) - The Emperor sends Sphrantzes with a polite message: His Imperial Majesty regrets that matters of state prevent his attendance, but he wishes the competitors well and hopes the event brings joy to Constantinople's people. Diplomatic, warm enough, but still hiding behind protocol.

encounters.recap: As preparations finalize for the second Hippodrome races, Theodoros warns Juan about the political significance of Stavros, the groom's son who has become a folk hero. A roll determines that Emperor John VIII will not attend personally but will send his secretary Sphrantzes with a diplomatic message of support—a cautious but positive response that avoids public commitment while maintaining cordial relations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning liturgy at Hagia Sophia was brief—the Patriarch presiding with his usual cold efficiency, the congregation quiet and reverent. Now, as your party emerges into the midday sun and makes its way toward the Hippodrome, you can already hear the noise. Constantinople has come alive. The ancient stadium stretches before you—the spina running down its center, the Egyptian obelisk casting its shadow across the track, the bronze serpent column from Delphi green with age. The tiered seats, which can hold perhaps 30,000, are not full—but they are filling. Perhaps 8,000 souls already, with more streaming through the gates.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, so many horses?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Soon, little one. Soon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your party is escorted to the imperial enclosure—the kathisma—a raised viewing area with carved marble seats, shaded by ancient awnings. The best view in the Hippodrome. The Emperor's seat is empty. As you settle Lucia into a cushioned chair, a familiar figure approaches. George Sphrantzes, the Emperor's secretary—the man who carried messages during the delicate negotiations, who watched the Charter of the Imperial Tagmata change hands.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Her Majesty. His Imperial Majesty sends his warmest regards and deepest regrets. Matters of state require his attention this afternoon, and he cannot attend in person. However, he asked me to deliver this message, to be read publicly before the races begin, if Your Majesty consents.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He hands you the scroll. You break the seal and read: 'To the competitors and people of Constantinople, greetings from John, by the Grace of God Emperor of the Romans. It is Our hope that today's races bring joy to Our city and honor to all who compete. Let Greek and Latin ride together in friendship, and let the swift and worthy prevail. We commend the competitors to God's protection and wish them good fortune. Given at the Blachernae Palace, this fourth day of May.' Diplomatic. Warm enough. But he isn't here.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: His Imperial Majesty asked me to remain and provide a full account of the day's events. He is... most interested in how the people receive the races.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You scan the tiered seats as your household settles in. The Committed Houses have claimed prominent positions: Philanthropenos surrounded by family members, the Raoul brothers together, Kantakouzenos absent but his cousin Theodoros present. The lower tiers are packed with common people—fishermen, craftsmen, laborers. You hear Stavros's name shouted more than once. The Venetian and Genoese contingents have claimed opposite ends of one section, a careful distance between them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Below, in the staging area near the starting gates, the riders prepare. Seventy-three men presented themselves yesterday; the judges qualified thirty-four for today's races, divided into three heats. Stavros stands apart from the others, brushing Trueno's coat. The big Castilian destrier looks almost comically powerful among the lighter Greek horses.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: People of Constantinople! Greeks and Latins! Today we race for glory and gold!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: His Imperial Majesty sends his blessing upon these games! And we thank His Majesty Juan of Castile, whose generosity makes this day possible! TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY GOLD FLORINS to the champion!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: First heat riders! To the gates!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eleven men lead their horses toward the starting position. Stavros is not among them—he must be in a later heat, preserved by the luck of the draw. The first race is about to begin.

encounters.recap: The second Hippodrome races begin with great pageantry. Emperor John Palaiologos sends regrets and a formal message but does not attend personally, instead dispatching George Sphrantzes to observe. The crowd of 8,000 includes committed noble houses, uncommitted observers, common people championing Stavros, and Italian merchants. Thirty-four qualified riders compete in three heats for 250 gold florins, with the first heat about to commence.

roll.outcome: Clean Race — Underdog Story. The expensive horses and noble names fade in the final laps. The winner is a surprise: a Greek stable hand, riding his master's second-best horse, edges out Demetrios Komnenos by half a length. The crowd erupts—another Stavros in the making? The young man looks stunned as he crosses the line. Komnenos takes second gracefully, saluting the winner. The Venetian takes third. A clean race with a story the common people will love. 'Anyone can win. Skill matters more than blood.'

encounters.recap: The first heat of the chariot races determines the initial qualifiers for the semifinals. A roll on the race outcome table results in an inspiring underdog victory where a Greek stable hand defeats the favored Demetrios Komnenos, creating the exact kind of 'common man triumphs' story that resonates with the crowd and validates the open entry format.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rise from your seat, touching Lucia's shoulder gently. You make your way along the imperial enclosure toward the Bryennios section—not far, perhaps twenty paces, but every eye tracks your movement. A king does not simply walk to another man's seat. The gesture itself is a statement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Bryennios patriarch sees you coming. He is perhaps sixty, with a neatly trimmed grey beard and sharp eyes that have seen much and committed to little. He rises as you approach—protocol demands it—but his expression is guarded. Beside him sit two younger men, nephews or sons, and a woman in fine silk who must be his wife.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lord Bryennios. I wished to congratulate you personally. Your rider—Nikephoros—brought great honor to your house today. His patience, his timing, his understanding of his horse... masterful. You must be proud.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios_patriarch
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. Though I confess the honor catches me... unprepared. I did not know Nikephoros had entered.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then the honor is doubled. A servant confident enough to test himself without his master's permission, skilled enough to win against nobles, and loyal enough to name your house when he crossed the line. Such men are treasures, Lord Bryennios. I hope you will reward him rather than punish him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The patriarch's eyes narrow slightly—not with hostility, but reassessment. You have just, very publicly, made it awkward for him to discipline Nikephoros. The crowd heard the herald announce the Bryennios name in victory. If the servant is punished, people will talk.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios_patriarch
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's wisdom is noted. Nikephoros has served my stables for seven years. He has... earned consideration.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good. I look forward to seeing him race in the final. Perhaps against Stavros—the people do love a story.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios_patriarch
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Will you... join us? The second heat is about to begin.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would gladly accept but I have my wife and daughter's company to keep. But I would gladly meet you another time when I can give the moment the attention and honour it deserves.

encounters.recap: Juan approaches the Bryennios patriarch to congratulate him on his servant Nikephoros's victory in the first heat. The diplomatic gesture publicly protects the servant from punishment and demonstrates Juan's respect for Greek achievement. Bryennios, initially guarded, extends an invitation to join him for the next race, which Juan politely declines while leaving the door open for future meetings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bryennios blinks—once, twice. He was not expecting you to refuse.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is most considerate of his family.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Another time. When we can speak properly, without—all this.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: I would welcome that, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You clasp his arm briefly—a soldier's gesture, not a courtier's—and make your way back to the imperial enclosure. A seed planted. Nothing more. But seeds grow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You settle back beside Lucia just as the trumpet sounds. Catalina immediately climbs into your lap for a better view.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is Stavros racing now, Papa?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, little one. Watch.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Twelve horses surge from the gates. You spot Trueno immediately—the big Castilian destrier stands out among the lighter Greek horses, his white coat brilliant in the afternoon sun. Stavros crouches low over his neck, finding his position.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He's not winning.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The race is long, mija. Watch.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then—disaster. Third lap, the far turn. A horse ahead of Stavros drifts wide, and Trueno's hooves clip the other animal's heels. The destrier stumbles badly, forelegs buckling. Stavros pitches forward, nearly over Trueno's neck—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But Stavros doesn't fall. Somehow—God knows how—he catches himself, hauls on the reins, drags Trueno's head up. The destrier recovers, shaking his head, confused and angry. By the time they're moving again, seven horses have passed them. Eighth place. Three and a half laps to go.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Watch. Watch him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fourth lap. Stavros asks Trueno for speed, and the destrier answers. They pass one horse, then another. The crowd begins to stir. Fifth lap. Fifth place. The crowd is chanting now: 'Stav-ros. Stav-ros. STAV-ROS.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Final Lap. Lucia has grabbed your arm. Catalina is bouncing so hard you can barely hold her. The entire Hippodrome is on its feet—8,000 souls screaming for a groom's son on a foreign horse. The far turn. Stavros is still third. He's looking at the gap between the soldier and the inside rail. Stavros asks Trueno for everything. The destrier runs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Stavros shoots through the gap. The Greek soldier shies away instinctively, giving ground he didn't mean to give. And suddenly Stavros is in second, then pulling even with Iñigo, then— The finish line. A neck. Less than a neck. Trueno's nose crosses first by the width of a hand.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome explodes. Eight thousand people screaming, weeping, embracing strangers. Stavros raises his fist to the sky. His face is streaked with tears—or sweat, or both. Trueno prances beneath him, head high, knowing somehow that he has done something extraordinary.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He won, Papa! He won!

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, mija. He won.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The baby is kicking. I think she felt the crowd.

roll.outcome: Legendary comeback victory. Stavros stumbles to 8th place after Trueno clips heels, then claws back lap by lap to win by a neck in dramatic final straight.

encounters.recap: After graciously declining Bryennios's dinner invitation to avoid forcing a public display, Juan watches Stavros race in the second heat. Despite a devastating stumble that drops him to eighth place, Stavros and Trueno mount an incredible comeback, passing horses lap by lap until they win by a neck in the final straight. The victory creates a legendary moment that electrifies the 8,000-strong crowd and advances Stavros to the final race.

roll.outcome: 1st Place: Venetian's son, 2nd Place: Komnenos, 3rd Place: Nikephoros

encounters.recap: The final race of the Hippodrome games determines the winners through a realistic assessment of horse and rider capabilities. The Venetian merchant's son on his Arabian horse takes first place, followed by Demetrios Komnenos and Nikephoros, with Stavros and his war-horse Trueno failing to place despite being the crowd favorite.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The trumpet sounds. Nine horses surge forward. Catalina squeals and clutches your arm, her small fingers digging in. 'Go, Stavros! GO!' You find him immediately—Trueno's white coat is unmistakable. Stavros starts well, settling into fourth position behind the Venetian's Arabian, Komnenos, and the Greek soldier.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is he winning, Papa?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Not yet, mija. It's early.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first lap passes. The Arabian leads—the Venetian's son is riding differently today. Controlled. Patient. The horse that fought its bit in earlier races now moves like water, fluid and fast. Second lap. The positions hold. Trueno is running well, but you can see it—a heaviness in his stride that wasn't there this morning. The Heat Two comeback took something from him.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Trueno looks tired.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Third lap. Fourth. The Venetian extends his lead. Komnenos moves into a clear second, riding the race of his life—the ancient name refusing to be embarrassed twice in one day. The Greek soldier fades; Stavros moves up to third.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He's winning now?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Third place, little one. He needs to catch two more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fifth lap. Stavros pushes. Trueno responds—but slowly, reluctantly. The destrier's great heart is willing; his legs are not. The gap to Komnenos stays the same. The gap to the Venetian grows. Behind Stavros, the race reshuffles. Nikephoros, who rode a conservative Heat One, moves up. The Bryennios stable hand is in fourth now, fresh, his chestnut mare running easily.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bell rings. Last lap. The Venetian's son leads by three lengths—an eternity. He's going to win. Behind him, Komnenos and Stavros battle for second, with Nikephoros a length behind them in fourth.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Come on, Stavros.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The far turn. Stavros makes his move, asking Trueno for everything. The destrier responds—but Komnenos responds too, his lighter horse fresher, faster. They round the turn neck and neck for second place. And then—Nikephoros. The Bryennios stable hand, riding the race of his life, surges up on Stavros's outside. Three riders for two positions. The crowd rises, screaming.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The final straight. Komnenos pulls ahead—second place is his. Behind him, Stavros and Nikephoros are stride for stride, fighting for third. You see the moment it happens. Stavros glances right. Sees Nikephoros beside him—the other underdog, the other common man, the stable hand who won Heat One and captured hearts just as Stavros did months ago. They are mirror images: sons of servants, riding borrowed dreams.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Stavros looks forward. The finish line is fifty yards away. He could fight for third. Trueno would give him everything—the horse always does. Instead, Stavros does something extraordinary. He eases up. Not dramatically. Not obviously. Just... a fraction less pressure on the reins. A slight shift of weight. Trueno, confused, slows almost imperceptibly. Nikephoros crosses the line a head in front of Stavros.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd doesn't understand at first. The Venetian's son crosses the finish line to polite applause—he won, after all. Komnenos takes second to respectful cheers. Nikephoros takes third, and the Bryennios section erupts. But those who were watching closely—the horsemen, the riders, the people who know what a race looks like—they saw. The murmur starts in the lower tiers and spreads.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, Stavros didn't win.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No, mija.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But he was so close! Why didn't he—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She stops. Even at her age, something in your expression tells her this is not a moment for questions. On the track, Nikephoros has realized what happened. He's staring at Stavros, mouth open. Stavros rides up beside him and says something—you cannot hear what. Then the people's champion reaches over and clasps the Bryennios stable hand's arm, raising it high. He's giving Nikephoros the moment, you realize. The cheers. The glory. The story.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd understands now. The roar that builds is not for the Venetian who won, not for Komnenos who took second, but for the man who finished fourth. 'STAVROS! STAVROS! STAVROS!' They're not cheering his speed. They're cheering his soul.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That boy. That beautiful, foolish boy.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, why are they cheering? He lost.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Venetian's son sits on his Arabian, 250 florins richer, and no one is looking at him. He won the race and lost the day. Sphrantzes, the Emperor's observer, is writing furiously. In the Bryennios section, the patriarch is on his feet. His servant Nikephoros—third place, a fortune in glory if not in gold—is surrounded by well-wishers. But the old man's eyes are on Stavros.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd continues to chant. Theodoros approaches the imperial enclosure, his expression asking a question: Do you wish to say anything? Do anything? The crowd is yours if you want it. You make your way to the riders and congratulate them, shaking their hands. You let the master of ceremony announce the top 5 finishers and give the 250 florins yourself to the winner.

roll.outcome: Grace in defeat — Stavros rode perfectly but deliberately eased up on the final straight to let Nikephoros take third instead of fighting his fellow common man for a losing position.

encounters.recap: In the final race of the Constantinople games, the Venetian's son wins on his Arabian while Stavros finishes fourth after deliberately allowing Nikephoros to take third place in an act of grace that moves the crowd more than victory itself. Juan presents the prize money personally as the people chant Stavros's name despite his fourth-place finish.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You hand Catalina to Lucia and rise. "I'll return shortly." The crowd notices immediately as you descend from the imperial enclosure. A king walking onto the Hippodrome track—it hasn't happened in living memory. Whispers spread like fire through dry grass. People crane their necks, stand on seats, push against their neighbors for a better view.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The nine finalists have gathered near the judges' platform. Horses steam in the cooling air; riders gulp water and wipe sweat from their faces. They see you coming and freeze—even the Venetian, clutching his winning purse of air, unsure if he's supposed to have received it yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You go to him first. The merchant's son is perhaps nineteen, dark-haired, with his father's soft hands and a horseman's new calluses. He's been ignored since crossing the finish line—250 florins await him, but no one seems to care. He looks at you with something between hope and terror. You extend your hand. He stares at it for a heartbeat, then takes it. His grip is damp with sweat but firm enough. The crowd watches in silence. A Latin king congratulating a Venetian—their commercial rivals, the people who sold Thessalonica to the Turks rather than defend it. But you won the race. The rules said so. The king honors the rules.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Stavros meets your gaze without flinching. There's no shame in his expression—no embarrassment at losing, no false modesty about what he did. He made a choice. He would make it again. You extend your hand. He takes it. The crowd exhales—a sound like wind through wheat. And then, softly at first, the chant begins again: "Stavros... Stavros... STAVROS..."

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: PEOPLE OF CONSTANTINOPLE! THE JUDGES DECLARE THE FINAL RESULTS OF TODAY'S RACES!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: IN FIFTH PLACE—IÑIGO DE MENDOZA OF CASTILE!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: IN FOURTH PLACE—STAVROS!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: IN THIRD PLACE—NIKEPHOROS, OF THE HOUSE OF BRYENNIOS!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: IN SECOND PLACE—DEMETRIOS KOMNENOS!

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: AND THE WINNER OF THE FINAL RACE, CHAMPION OF THE HIPPODROME, RECIPIENT OF TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY GOLD FLORINS—THE SON OF HOUSE CONTARINI OF VENICE!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You step forward with the purse. The leather bag is heavy—250 florins in gold, enough to buy a house, a ship, a future. The Venetian's son approaches you, and for a moment you stand face to face: Castilian king and Venetian merchant's heir, Latin and Latin, in the heart of a Greek city. You place the purse in his hands.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eight thousand faces look back at you. Greeks and Latins. Nobles and commoners. The committed and the uncommitted. They came for spectacle; they received something else. A race where the winner was not the champion. A day where the rules were honored but the crowd chose its own heroes.

encounters.recap: Juan personally congratulates all the race finalists, including the Venetian winner who receives 250 florins. The crowd cheers loudest for fourth-place Stavros, the people's champion. The ceremony demonstrates Juan's commitment to fair rules while the Greeks choose their own heroes, creating a complex political moment that honors both law and popular sentiment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sun has nearly set by the time your party reaches the palace gates. The sky is bruised purple and gold over the Sea of Marmara, and the first evening stars are emerging. The Blachernae Palace looks different now than it did two weeks ago. The same ancient walls, the same faded magnificence—but the men at the gates wear the colors of House Raoul, not the unmarked tunics of Notaras's household guards.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: George Sphrantzes enters, still carrying his writing tablet from the Hippodrome. He looks exhausted—the look of a man who has been composing a difficult report in his head for hours.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: His Imperial Majesty asks me to convey his gratitude for your patience. The Emperor has read my preliminary account of the day's events. He found the story of Stavros... particularly affecting. He asked me to describe the moment three times.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: He also asked about you, Your Majesty. How you conducted yourself. How you honored the Venetian winner despite the crowd's preference for Stavros. How you shook every rider's hand. I told him what I saw. A king who follows his own rules, even when breaking them would be popular. His Imperial Majesty found this... noteworthy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: John VIII Palaiologos looks better than he did a week ago. The haunted look has not entirely left his eyes, but there is color in his cheeks, and he stands straighter. He wears simple robes—no crown, no imperial regalia. A man in his own home, receiving a guest.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: King Juan, thank you for coming. I had hoped you would. Walk with me? I find I think better when I move. The physicians say it is good for the humors.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course. How have you been these last days? I trust you are enjoying the peace of mind now that your palace is truly secure. I also came because my departure is now coming closer and I was wondering if you think you sign the decree before I leave of if the empire will make up it's mind after I have left.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor leads you through the small door into a private gallery. The space is long and narrow, lined with windows that overlook an inner courtyard garden. Moonlight spills through the glass, silvering the ancient mosaics beneath your feet.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Peace of mind. I had forgotten what it felt like to walk in my own palace without wondering which servant was reporting my movements. To eat food without wondering if it had been touched. To sleep without listening for footsteps outside my door.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You must understand what you are asking me to sign, King Juan. If I sign, I am declaring to the world that the Roman Empire cannot save itself. That we require a Latin protector. The Patriarch will denounce me. What remains of the clergy loyal to him will preach against me in every church. Some of my own blood may see this as proof that I am unfit to rule.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: And yet Notaras sold us to the Turks, and called it prudence. The Patriarch preaches against Latin interference while the Sultan's armies grow stronger every year. My cousins scheme for a throne that will not exist in twenty years if nothing changes.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I find myself wanting to trust you, King Juan. That frightens me more than Notaras ever did. If I do not sign—if I thank you for all you have done, take your gold and your knights and your goodwill, and never put my name to your decree—what will you do? Tell me the truth, King Juan. Not what you think I want to hear.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If you decide that the choice of the empire is that it does not need any help, I will withdraw my knights. Not because I bear you ill will, but these are my men and I will not let them die in vain. If you do not decide the coming weeks and need more time, I will leave my knights a while longer. If I may also remind you that I in turn also need to trust you and the Byzantines. I know that patience is a virtue, but it wounds me as well that all the honour and gifts that I have given so far are sometimes recieved with suspicion. I also dont like that I am being blamed for 1204. I understand it, but it hurts and tests me as well.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You are right to wound me with that. I have spent so many years being suspicious that I forgot suspicion has a cost. I was not born when the Crusaders sacked this city. Neither was my father, nor his father. But I grew up with the stories. Every Greek child learns these stories before they learn to read. It is in our blood now, this wound.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You say it wounds you. I believe you. And I am sorry. That is not a word emperors use often. We are taught that apology is weakness. But I am learning that many things I was taught are wrong.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I will not sign tonight. I am not ready. There are still conversations I must have—with the Patriarch, with my cousins, with what remains of my council. But I will tell you this, and I will swear it on the bones of my ancestors: I will decide before you leave. One way or another.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets give it another week for you to consult. Whatever you need to consult with can be done in that time and staying longer will not make a difference. After you have decided or signed we need a few days to do the muster and set the claims. Then I will need a good day to set matters in motion and start preparing the city for the wars to come. That gives me enough time to get back to Naples for Lucia to deliver safely and for me to attend matters there.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: One week. Yes. That is reasonable. On the eleventh of May, I will give you my answer. The Patriarch will be the hardest. He has spent months preaching against Latin interference. To reverse himself now would humiliate him before his own clergy. But perhaps there is a way to let him save face.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: And Notaras. He is still out there. On his estates, with his guards, with his gold. The evidence you found—the letters to the Sultan—that is treason. I could have him arrested. Tried. Executed. But he has allies still. If I move against him openly, I may force a confrontation I am not yet strong enough to win.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: One week. On the eleventh of May, you will have your answer. And I will have made my choice—not just about your decree, but about what kind of emperor I mean to be. Thank you for your honesty tonight, King Juan. It has been... clarifying. For both of us, I think.

encounters.recap: Juan meets privately with Emperor John VIII at the Blachernae Palace after the races. The Emperor expresses gratitude for his restored security but reveals deep hesitations about signing the protection decree, citing fears of appearing weak and alienating the Patriarch and nobility. Juan responds with his own frustrations about being met with suspicion despite his generosity. The Emperor apologizes and acknowledges the wounds of 1204 still affecting Byzantine attitudes toward Latins. They agree on a one-week deadline—May 11th—for the Emperor's final decision, with discussions needed regarding the Patriarch, imperial cousins, and the lingering threat of Notaras.

roll.outcome: Crisis: Assassination Attempt — Notaras has not accepted his fall quietly. Someone attempts to kill a key figure: Juan, the Emperor, or a critical ally like Philanthropenos. Success or failure, the week becomes about survival, not negotiation.

encounters.recap: During the week of waiting for Emperor John VIII's decision on the decree, a roll determines what challenges arise. The roll of 3 indicates a crisis: an assassination attempt orchestrated by the fallen logothetes Notaras against a key figure, transforming the careful political week into a struggle for survival.

roll.outcome: George Sphrantzes - The Emperor's eyes and ears. His most trusted secretary. Sphrantzes knows everything—every conversation, every doubt, every wavering moment. Kill him, and the Emperor loses his best advisor. It also sends a message: Notaras can reach anyone, even those closest to the throne.

encounters.recap: Notaras, desperate after losing his position and with evidence of his treason in Juan's possession, plans an assassination to disrupt the Latin-Greek alliance. A roll determines his target: George Sphrantzes, the Emperor's most trusted secretary and advisor, chosen for both strategic impact and symbolic message.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. There has been an incident at the palace.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. He lives. But there was an attempt.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The story emerges in fragments over the next hour. It was early morning—before dawn, when the palace corridors are quiet and the night watch is tired. Sphrantzes had risen early to organize the Emperor's correspondence. The assassin was waiting in an alcove near the old chapel—a man in palace livery, unremarkable. He had a knife. What saved Sphrantzes was noise. The secretary stumbled on a loose flagstone, cursing aloud. The assassin, startled, struck too soon, missing flesh. Sphrantzes screamed. Two of Raoul's men came running. The assassin tried to flee but found himself cornered. He did not surrender. The fight was brief and brutal. The assassin was skilled but two armored guards against one man with a knife is not a fight. It is an execution. He killed one of the guards before the other opened his throat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The dead assassin carried little. No papers, no letters, no seal that would identify his master. But one of the surviving guards recognized his voice. In the brief struggle, the assassin had cursed in a particular dialect: Mesembrian. The Black Sea coast. Notaras's family holdings are in Mesembria.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You see what he does. You see what kind of man I was enslaved to for ten years. He cannot win, so he murders. He cannot rule, so he destroys.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I must thank your Captain Fernán. His insistence on security protocols—the doubled patrols, the irregular schedules—I believe they saved my life. The assassin expected the old routines. He did not expect guards at the chapel at that hour. One of the guards died protecting me. A boy named Alexios. He was twenty-two. He had a mother in the city.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Notaras will deny it. He will say the assassin was a madman, a lone actor, a Latin plot to discredit him. He will demand proof we cannot provide. And some will believe him—or pretend to believe him, because believing him is safer than admitting the truth. I should have had him killed the night we took the palace. Philanthropenos urged me to act. I wanted to be... merciful. Just. To show that I was not like him. One of my guards is dead because I was merciful.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You hold the letters. The proof of his correspondence with the Sultan. If we release them now—if we show Constantinople what Notaras truly is—it may be enough. His allies will abandon him. The wavering houses will see that there is no future in supporting a traitor. I could arrest him, try him, execute him. Or it may split the city. His allies will say the letters are forgeries. The Patriarch may use the chaos to move against me. My cousins may see opportunity in disorder.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The letters are genuine. Anyone who examines them will know. But Your Imperial Majesty is correct—some will choose not to examine them. Some will prefer comfortable lies to dangerous truths.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You have carried those letters for days, King Juan. You could have released them yourself—proven Notaras a traitor, humiliated him publicly. You did not. I suspect you have your reasons. What would you counsel? Release the letters and force the confrontation? Or hold them still, and find another way?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have enough evidence to start a trial. You ask for my council and right now I am just a guest. What I can do and council is limited. But if you sign the decree, I will remove him and his influence. He represents those who want to aid the Ottomans take the city and get a reward for themselves. If I were defensor, I would bring the proverbial hammer down, put him to trial and let justice reign.

roll.outcome: Attempt Foiled: Assassin Killed — The assassin is stopped and killed by palace guards. Sphrantzes survives, shaken but unhurt. The dead assassin provides some evidence of Notaras's involvement through his Mesembrian dialect, but not definitive proof.

encounters.recap: An assassin attempts to kill George Sphrantzes in the palace corridors but is thwarted when Sphrantzes stumbles and alerts guards. The assassin kills one guard before being slain. His Mesembrian dialect suggests Notaras's involvement, though proof remains circumstantial. The Emperor seeks Juan's counsel on whether to release the intercepted letters as evidence against Notaras.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I have survived ten years of Notaras, Your Imperial Majesty. One assassin with a knife will not send me running.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor nods slowly. Then he turns to you, and something in his expression has shifted. The caution is still there, but beneath it—resolution. A man approaching a decision, even if he has not yet reached it.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You have given me much to consider, King Juan. The letters. The offer. The... clarity.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand—not for a formal clasp, but palm-up. The same gesture as before, in the moonlit gallery. An offering. An acknowledgment.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Three more days. On the eleventh, you will have my answer. And I will remember what you said today—that if I give you the authority, you will use it. That is either a promise or a warning. Perhaps both.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Take care emperor. Notaras is becoming desperate. And desperate men do desperate things. Raoul, be extra vigilant the coming days as the emperor makes up his mind.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Emperor, you consider speaking with the patriarch. You have already scheduled to speak with him surely. I would just keep this schedule. It means you are not shaken by this event. That way you can still meet with this important figure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The eldest Raoul straightens at your words. The Captain of the Tagmata has been standing silent by the door throughout the conversation—a soldier's discipline, listening but not speaking unless addressed. Now his scarred face hardens with resolve.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks wisdom. Notaras has tried once and failed. He will try again—perhaps differently. Perhaps not the secretary next time.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty, with your permission, I will double the personal guard. No one approaches you without being searched. No food that has not been tasted. No servants who have not been vetted by men I trust personally.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Do what you must, Captain.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Raoul bows—a soldier's bow, sharp and brief.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: The boy who died—Alexios—I will see to his mother. She will not want for anything.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor considers your words about the Patriarch, his brow furrowing.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You are right. I was scheduled to meet with him tomorrow afternoon. My first instinct was to postpone—to wait until the blood was cleaned and the shock had faded.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: But that is precisely what Notaras wants. For me to hide. To look weak. To give the Patriarch time to hear rumors and draw his own conclusions.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: I will keep the meeting. I will walk into the Patriarch's presence as if nothing has happened—or rather, as if something has happened and I am unafraid. Let him see that assassins do not shake me. Let him wonder if perhaps he has misjudged which side is stronger.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: If I may suggest, Your Imperial Majesty—bring the torn sleeve.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: What?

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The sleeve the assassin's knife cut. Wear it to the meeting. Do not change your robes. Let the Patriarch see the evidence of the attack with his own eyes. Say nothing about it—simply let him notice. Let him draw his own conclusions about the kind of man Notaras is, and the kind of man you are.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long pause. Then, unexpectedly, the Emperor laughs—a genuine sound, surprised out of him.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: George, you are more devious than I give you credit for.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I have learned from a decade of watching Notaras, Your Imperial Majesty. I would prefer to use those lessons for better purposes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor turns back to you, and the laughter fades into something more somber.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Thank you, King Juan. For the counsel. For the clarity. For—for being here. I do not know yet what I will decide. But I know that I am grateful you came to Constantinople, whatever happens next.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: You should return to your wife. She is with child, and mornings after violence are not easy for anyone. Give her my regards—and the Princess Catalina as well. Tell her the Emperor remembers how she reached for his sleeve in the Hagia Sophia. It was the first time in years anyone touched me without wanting something.

encounters.recap: Following the assassination attempt, Juan counsels the Emperor to maintain his scheduled meeting with the Patriarch as a show of strength. Constantine agrees to the plan, setting his deadline for May 11th. Security is tightened and strategies are discussed for managing the political fallout from Notaras's desperate actions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You are with Lucia when the messenger arrives. She has been unwell—nothing dangerous, but the pregnancy wears on her, and the news of yesterday's assassination attempt did not help her rest. You have spent the morning quietly, letting Catalina play with wooden horses while Lucia dozes in a chair by the window.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Ottoman ships have entered the Golden Horn.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How many?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Three galleys. Flying diplomatic flags. They're larger than a typical embassy, Your Majesty. Fifteen men, perhaps more. And they've already sent a message to the palace requesting audience.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, you learn more. The embassy is led by a man named Hamza Bey—a diplomat of middle rank, neither so senior as to suggest crisis nor so junior as to imply insult. He has served the Sultan in various capacities for twenty years. He speaks Greek fluently. The messenger he sent to the Blachernae Palace carried two requests. The first was expected: an audience with His Imperial Majesty, Emperor John VIII Palaiologos, to discuss "matters of mutual interest between the Sublime Porte and the Roman Empire." The second was not. Hamza Bey also requests, "with the Sultan's compliments and warmest regards," an audience with "His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile, whose presence in Constantinople has reached the Sultan's ears." The request is framed as courtesy—one monarch extending greetings to another through his representative. The Sultan "wishes to convey his respect for a fellow sovereign who has traveled so far from his own lands." The subtext requires no translation: Murad II wants to take your measure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A note arrives from the palace, written in Sphrantzes's careful hand. He is recovering—shaken but functional.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, His Imperial Majesty is aware of the Ottoman request and wishes me to convey that he leaves the decision entirely to your discretion. He will not be offended if you accept, nor if you refuse. However, he asks me to note that if you do accept, it may be wise to meet with Hamza Bey separately from the Emperor's own audience. The Emperor will receive Hamza Bey tomorrow morning, May 9th. If you wish to meet with the Ottoman envoy, you might consider doing so this afternoon, before the Emperor's audience.

roll.outcome: Tomorrow, Requesting Audience with Both — The embassy arrives May 8 with fifteen men—larger than typical. Their leader requests audience not only with the Emperor, but also with "the Latin king who has honored Constantinople with his presence." They frame it as courtesy: the Sultan wishes to extend greetings to a fellow monarch. The subtext is clear: Murad wants to take Juan's measure personally, through his envoy's eyes.

encounters.recap: An Ottoman embassy of fifteen men led by Hamza Bey arrives in Constantinople, requesting audiences with both Emperor John VIII and King Juan II. The timing coincides with the Emperor's planned consultation with the Patriarch, adding diplomatic pressure as the Sultan seeks to assess the Latin military presence and Juan's intentions through his envoy.

roll.outcome: Legendary — The Tongue of Kings. Juan is a genuine linguistic prodigy with full fluency in Latin, Portuguese, French, Catalan, Italian. Strong Greek (reading and conversational). Functional Hebrew. Working Arabic (enough to read documents, conduct basic interrogations, surprise Moorish prisoners). He has deliberately cultivated this as a tool of statecraft, believing that a king who cannot understand his subjects, his enemies, and his allies in their own words is half-blind.

encounters.recap: A comprehensive assessment of Juan's linguistic abilities reveals him to be a prodigious polyglot. Beyond the expected royal languages of Castilian, Latin, Portuguese, and French, Juan has cultivated exceptional facility with Italian, Catalan, Greek, Hebrew, and even Arabic. This extraordinary linguistic range—deliberately developed as a tool of statecraft—gives him significant advantages in diplomacy and intelligence gathering that most do not suspect.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You receive Hamza Bey in the great hall of the house assigned to your household—a Byzantine merchant's mansion requisitioned for the Castilian delegation. It is not a palace, but it is dignified. Tapestries bearing the arms of Castile hang on the walls. Your household guard lines the entrance in polished armor. Captain Fernán stands at your right hand.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Ottoman delegation enters with measured formality. Fifteen men, as reported—Hamza Bey at their head, flanked by two secretaries and trailed by guards and attendants. They wear fine robes in muted colors, turbans wrapped with care. They move like men accustomed to courts, alert to every detail.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hamza Bey is perhaps fifty, with a grey-streaked beard trimmed close and dark eyes that miss nothing. His face is weathered by years of travel between courts. He carries himself with the quiet confidence of a man who has served three sultans and outlived countless rivals. He stops at the appropriate distance and begins to bow—the bow of a diplomat greeting a foreign sovereign, correct to the inch. And then you speak.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Salaam aleikum.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hamza Bey freezes mid-bow. For a single heartbeat, his mask slips. You see it—the flash of genuine shock in those careful diplomat's eyes. His secretaries exchange glances. One of the guards shifts his weight, uncertain. A Christian king. A Latin king. The conqueror of Granada. Speaking Arabic. The greeting hangs in the air between you. Peace be upon you. The words of the Prophet's tradition. The courtesy Muslims extend to one another. Coming from the mouth of a man who just completed the Reconquista.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Wa aleikum as-salaam, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes study you with new intensity. You are no longer the figure from his briefing—the young crusader king, pious and martial and presumably ignorant of the wider world. You are something else. Something that requires reassessment.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan, may God preserve him, extends his greetings to the King of Castile. He has heard of Your Majesty's presence in Constantinople and wished to convey his respect for a fellow sovereign.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank the Sultan for his greeting, which I return in kind. There is much in this world to be thankful for and this city offers many of the Lord's wonders.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks the tongue of the faithful with grace. The Sultan will be... interested to learn of this. It is not common among the kings of the West.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Indeed, Constantinople holds many wonders. The Sultan himself has long admired this city—its walls, its churches, its history. He considers the Emperor John a... neighbor of significance.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan notes that his neighbor has recently received guests from very far away. Knights in foreign colors upon the walls. Ships in the harbor bearing unfamiliar standards. A king who has traveled many months from his own lands to visit a city that is not his own. The Sultan is curious, as any good neighbor might be. He wonders what brings the King of Castile so far from Castile. What interests could draw a sovereign across the sea to a city he has no claim upon?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am here to learn from the Greeks and to offer aid from one Christian to another. Some structures have been in a state of disrepair and the emperor has accepted my help to restore them. I was just about to leave in a few days. But I am glad to meet you. Tell me everything about the sultan. How is he doing? What is on his mind?

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious to inquire after the Sultan's health. The Sultan, praise be to God, is well. He spends his days as a just ruler should—attending to matters of state, hearing petitions from his subjects, ensuring peace within his domains. What is on his mind? The same concerns that occupy any great sovereign. The welfare of his people. The security of his borders. The proper administration of justice. And, of course, the actions of his neighbors. A wise ruler attends to what occurs near his lands.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan is a man of peace, Your Majesty. This may surprise you. In the West, I think, the Ottomans are painted as... ravening wolves, perhaps. Destroyers of Christendom. The truth is simpler. The Sultan wishes stability. Prosperity. Trade that enriches all parties. He does not seek war for its own sake.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: But he is also not a man who tolerates... uncertainty. When he does not understand what is happening near his borders, he grows concerned. Concerned men sometimes make decisions they would prefer not to make.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says you came to learn from the Greeks. A noble pursuit. The Greeks have much wisdom to offer—their books, their theology, their ancient knowledge. The Sultan himself patronizes Greek scholars. He values learning. Your Majesty also mentions repairing structures. Walls, perhaps? The sea walls have long needed attention. A generous gift to the Emperor, certainly. Though some might wonder why a king from so far away concerns himself with the walls of a city that is not his own.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty says you are leaving in a few days. The Sultan will be pleased to hear it. He would not wish for Your Majesty to be... delayed. Castile is far away, and a king's duties call him home. A wife, perhaps? Children? The Sultan understands these obligations well. He is a devoted father himself.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: But before Your Majesty departs, perhaps we might speak more plainly? King to diplomat. Christian to Muslim. Two men who understand that the world is complicated. You have brought knights. Experienced soldiers. You have spent gold on walls and harbors. You have attended the Greek church, sat beside the Emperor, organized races in the Hippodrome. You have been here for weeks, not days. And now you tell me you are merely learning and offering charity. Your Majesty, I have served three sultans. I have heard many stories. I mean no disrespect when I say: I do not believe this one. So. What are you really doing in Constantinople? And what should the Sultan understand about your intentions?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How fares Thessalonica? The Byzantines fear subjugation by the Ottomans. I have come to give them what aid I can. Even if I am far from home.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Ottoman ambassador Hamza Bey, surprising him by speaking Arabic. After diplomatic probing about Juan's true intentions in Constantinople, Juan evades direct answers before finally admitting he came to aid the Byzantines against Ottoman threats, mentioning conquered Thessalonica.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Byzantines fear subjugation by the Ottomans. I have come to give them what aid I can. Even if I am far from home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The name lands like a stone in still water. Thessalonica. Conquered four years ago. The second city of Byzantium, sold to Venice by a desperate emperor, then taken by Ottoman siege. Its population enslaved. Its churches converted. Its Greek character erased in a matter of weeks. Hamza Bey's expression does not change, but something shifts behind his eyes. You have stopped playing the game of pleasant deflections. So will he.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Thessalonica prospers under the Sultan's rule. The markets are open. Trade flows. The people live in peace. But I take Your Majesty's meaning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hamza Bey is silent for a moment, studying you as one might study an opponent across a chess board. When he speaks again, his voice has lost its diplomatic warmth. It is not hostile—merely direct. Two professionals dispensing with pretense.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Byzantines fear subjugation. Yes. They have feared it for a century, since Bayezid first camped before these walls. They feared it when my grandfather served the first Murad. They will fear it when my grandsons serve sultans not yet born. And what aid can Castile offer, truly? You are far away, Your Majesty. Very far. Your knights are brave, I do not doubt. Your gold is welcome, I am certain. But when you sail home to your wife and your kingdoms and your wars in Italy—the Sultan will still be here. Across the water. Patient. Eternal.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Greeks have sought Latin aid before. They sought it at Nicopolis. They sought it at Varna. They have begged popes and kings and emperors for salvation. And where are those crusaders now? Bones in Bulgarian soil. The Ottomans remain.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: You conquered Granada. I know this. The Sultan knows this. It was... impressive. Eight centuries of Muslim rule ended in a single campaign. You are not a man to be dismissed. But Granada was yours. On your borders. You could march home each night to your own bed if you wished. Constantinople is not yours. You have no claim here. No obligation. No reason to bleed for Greeks who will call you heretic behind your back and schismatic to your face. Why do you care? Truly? What is Constantinople to Castile?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are right. I have no stake here at all. My knights cannot hold the walls. It seems it is just a question of time before the Ottomans finally pluck the fruit that is becoming more and more ripe by the year. Constantinople will fall before you, surrounded as they are by your impressive empire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hamza Bey blinks. For the second time in this conversation, you have caught him off-guard. He expected argument. Defiance. The proud declarations of a crusader king who has just conquered Granada and believes he can do anything. He did not expect... agreement. A moment passes. Then the Ottoman diplomat inclines his head—a gesture of acknowledgment, perhaps even respect.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks with unusual clarity. Most Christian kings prefer... grander narratives. Divine providence. Sacred duty. The eternal struggle. It is refreshing to speak with a man who reads maps.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tension in the room shifts. Hamza Bey seems to reach a decision—he has learned what he came to learn, or at least learned that he will learn no more through direct inquiry. A skilled diplomat knows when to stop probing.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan also reads maps. He is a man of peace, despite what the West believes. He has no wish to see Constantinople burn. The city has value—its harbors, its trade, its history. Corpses and rubble serve no one. The Sultan hopes that wisdom will prevail. That the Emperor will see the benefits of... accommodation. That unnecessary bloodshed might be avoided. This is the message I carry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hamza Bey straightens his robes, signaling a shift toward conclusion.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's presence here has been noted. Your generosity to the Greeks has been noted. Your... linguistic accomplishments have been noted. I confess, the Sultan's briefings did not mention that the King of Castile speaks the tongue of the faithful. I will correct this oversight in my report.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—properly, the bow of a diplomat concluding an audience with a foreign sovereign.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan extends his hopes that Your Majesty's journey home will be swift and safe. Castile is far, and a king's duties are many. He trusts that Your Majesty's... charitable work here will soon be complete. If Your Majesty has any message you wish conveyed to the Sultan, I am at your service.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Extend my warm regards to the Sultan and I hope that we are granted to meet in person once in the future.

encounters.recap: Juan candidly admits to Ottoman Ambassador Hamza Bey that Constantinople's fall seems inevitable and that Castile has no real stake in defending the city. This unexpected honesty catches the diplomat off-guard and shifts the conversation from confrontational to respectful. Hamza Bey delivers the Sultan's implicit message that Juan should complete his work and leave, while Juan extends diplomatic courtesies for a potential future meeting.

roll.outcome: Reluctant Signature — Duty Over Pride. The Emperor signs. He does not want to. Every stroke of the pen costs him something. But Sphrantzes almost died. Notaras serves the Sultan. The Ottomans are watching. He signs because he must, not because he believes. The decree is valid, but the Emperor's heart is not fully in it.

encounters.recap: Emperor John VIII Palaiologos makes his final decision on Juan's decree establishing him as Defensor of Constantinople. Despite his personal reluctance and the cost to his pride, the Emperor signs the decree out of duty—driven by the recent assassination attempt on Sphrantzes, evidence of Notaras's treason with the Sultan, and Ottoman pressure. The signature is valid but given without enthusiasm.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The messenger arrives at dawn. You are already awake—sleep came poorly, if at all. Lucia stirs beside you, her hand finding yours in the grey light. She does not ask. She knows what today is. "His Imperial Majesty requests the presence of King Juan at the palace," the messenger recites. "At the hour of Terce."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor receives you in the formal throne room of the Blachernae—not the private galleries where you have walked together, but the ancient chamber where Byzantine emperors have received ambassadors and vassals for centuries. John VIII sits on the throne of Constantine. He wears the imperial purple, the jeweled loros wrapped across his chest, the crown of the Palaiologoi upon his brow. Courtiers line the walls—what remains of the Byzantine court. Sphrantzes stands at the Emperor's right hand, his arm still in a sling from the assassin's blade.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: King Juan of Castile. You came to our city as a pilgrim and a friend. You have given freely of your gold, your knights, your counsel. You have asked nothing that we were not willing to give. You have conducted yourself with honor.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: We have consulted with our advisors. We have prayed for guidance. We have weighed the dangers of action against the dangers of inaction. The Logothete Loukas Notaras has proven himself a traitor to this throne. He has corresponded with the Sultan. He has attempted murder within our own palace. He has forfeited any claim to our protection or mercy.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: We require a sword to deal with traitors. We require strength to rebuild what has been broken. We require... help.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor gestures. A servant approaches bearing a gilded tray. Upon it lies the decree—the Chrysobull you have negotiated over weeks of careful conversation. Beside it: the imperial seal, a pot of purple ink, a quill.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: We have read this document many times. We have found nothing in it that dishonors our throne or our people. You have been... more generous than we had any right to expect. We sign this not because we wish to. We sign this because Sphrantzes nearly died in our own corridors. Because Notaras sold our secrets to the Sultan. Because Ottoman ships anchor in our harbor and their diplomats walk our streets and we cannot make them leave. We sign this because we are out of choices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The quill touches parchment. The Emperor writes his name—Ioannes en Christo to Theo pistos Basileus kai Autokrator Rhomaion Palaiologos—in the ancient formula. His hand is steady now, the trembling mastered by will. He sets down the quill. He presses the imperial seal into warm wax. It is done.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You have what you came for, King Juan. The authority you requested. The alliance you proposed. Use it well. Do not make us regret this.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: War council, now. Summon all the major houses, the captains of the watch and my crusader captains.

roll.outcome: Reluctant Signature - Signs but without full commitment

encounters.recap: Emperor John VIII reluctantly signs the Chrysobull granting Juan II the title of Defensor Romaniae. Despite his reservations and the absence of Church blessing, the Emperor feels compelled by recent betrayals and Ottoman pressure. Juan immediately calls for a war council upon receiving the validated decree.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor stiffens at your touch—for a moment, the old Byzantine formality rises in him, the instinct that says emperors are not touched, not by anyone, not ever. Then it passes. His shoulder settles beneath your hand. He looks at you, and something in his expression shifts—not quite gratitude, not quite resentment, but something in between. The look of a man who has jumped from a cliff and is still falling, not yet knowing if there is water below.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Yes. They should hear it from me. Not from rumor. Not from whispers in the corridors.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The throne room transforms over the next hour. Servants bring additional chairs, arranging them in a broad semicircle facing the throne. Maps are carried in—Constantinople and its environs, the Bosphorus, the Sea of Marmara, the Ottoman territories beyond. The room fills with arriving horsemen: Alexios Philanthropenos leaning on his cane, the Raoul brothers with their captain's insignia, Theodoros Kantakouzenos windswept from the walls, Lord Bryennios arriving alone and watchful.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Men, the emperor has made a choice and I have called you here to make our first plans for the future. Please read this document so we are all reminded of what has just been signed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Philanthropenos steps forward, taking the decree with the reverence of a man handling a holy relic. His voice, strong despite his years, carries the weight of imperial formula as he reads the unprecedented appointment of Juan as Defensor Romaniae—Defender of the Roman Empire.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
