exchanges.text: In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. We, John, in Christ God faithful Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, Palaiologos, do hereby name and appoint Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, as Defensor Romaniae—Defender of the Roman Empire.

exchanges.speaker: alexios_philanthropenos
exchanges.text: I have lived eighty-three years. I have seen this empire shrink and shrink and shrink. Today, someone came. Today, help arrived. Today, an emperor had the courage to accept it. Your Imperial Majesty, House Philanthropenos commits to you. To this choice. To this alliance. Whatever comes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank you all and the emperor for the trust placed in me. First things first. We dont need the Ottoman diplomats in the city any more. They will board their ships and leave in two hours. Who can see this order executed?

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I can have men at their compound within the quarter hour, Defensor. Escort them to their ships. Two hours is generous. They will know something has changed the moment armed men appear at their door. The faster we move, the less time they have to send runners or hide messages.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: The Defensor Romaniae acts within his authority. The Ottoman embassy has concluded its business. They will depart. Strategos Kantakouzenos, see it done.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: A bold first act, Defensor. The Sultan will not be pleased.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont care to please the Sultan. Tomorrow we hold a muster. Every noble can present their men and their person for war. This is also the last chance for nobles who have ancient claims to make them known so their names may be recorded on the list. We will also start listing titles to nobles who have no ancient claims but who contribute to the war. We list titles in Thrace mostly as this is the first lands I expect we will retake.

encounters.recap: Following the formal reading of Juan's appointment as Defensor Romaniae before the assembled Byzantine nobility, Juan immediately exercises his new authority by ordering the expulsion of Ottoman diplomats within two hours. The nobles witness the first demonstration of the new military alliance as Kantakouzenos executes the order with imperial approval. Juan then announces a military muster for the next day and begins planning territorial reconquest starting with Thrace.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: A bold first act, Defensor. The Sultan will not be pleased.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont care to please the Sultan. Tomorrow we hold a muster. Every noble can present their men and their person for war. This is also the last chance for nobles who have ancient claims to make them known so their names may be recorded on the list. We will also start listing titles to nobles who have no ancient claims but who contribute to the war. We list titles in Thrace mostly as this is the first lands I expect we will retake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The word lands heavily in the room. Muster. Not a council. Not a consultation. A military assembly—the counting of swords, the marshaling of forces, the preparation for war.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: A muster. You mean to know our strength. Numbers, equipment, readiness.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: And the claims. Yes. Nothing motivates a Greek noble like land he believes is rightfully his. Thrace... Thrace has been Ottoman for decades. But there are families here who remember. Who have documents. Who have grievances.

exchanges.speaker: laskaris
exchanges.text: My house held lands near Adrianople. Before... before Bayezid. My grandfather's seal is still on the deeds.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: You speak of ancient claims, Defensor. And of new titles for those who contribute. My house has served the Empire for three centuries. We have no claims in Thrace—our lands were elsewhere. But we have men. Ships. Gold. What might a house with no ancient claims but considerable... contribution... expect from this arrangement?

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: If I may, Defensor—a muster tomorrow requires preparation. Heralds to announce it. A location large enough to accommodate the forces. Scribes to record the claims and contributions. The Hippodrome, perhaps? It held races days ago. It could hold a muster.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, our knights should parade as well. Let the Greeks see what Castilian cavalry looks like in formation. It will encourage them—and remind them what they're allied with.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Like I said Bryennios, considerable contributions will count on significant titles as well. That is the whole point. Yes, the hippodrome is the ideal location for this. Can it be done?

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: Then House Bryennios will attend the muster tomorrow, Defensor. With our men. And our ships.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome can be ready. The infrastructure remains from the races—the viewing platforms, the judges' stands. We would need to clear the track for formation drilling rather than racing.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: By house, then by type. Infantry first—they're the bulk of any force. Then cavalry. Then specialists: archers, engineers, sailors. Each lord presents his men, states their numbers, their equipment, their experience.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: We will attend. The forces of the Empire muster before their Emperor. That is proper. The Defensor will conduct the military assessment. We will receive the oaths of loyalty from the noble houses. Together. As the decree intended.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now Notaras. He stands accused. Can we summon him and arrest him? Would this be dishonourable by your culture. In Castille, when a king summons a noble it is always under the protection of safe conduct. I could not arrest him after a summon. Is Byzantine custom the same?

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Byzantine custom is... complicated, Defensor. In theory, an imperial summons carries the Emperor's protection. A man who answers his sovereign's call should be able to trust that call.

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: That is the theory. The practice has been rather different over the centuries. We are Byzantines, Defensor. We invented the word 'byzantine' for a reason. Our hands are not clean.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: My hands will be clean. I spent ten years as Notaras's prisoner in all but name. I will not become him. I will not build my reign on treachery, even treachery against a traitor. If Notaras is summoned under imperial seal, he comes under imperial protection.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: There is another consideration, Defensor. Notaras is not a fool. If we send a summons, he will know it is a trap—whether we intend betrayal or not. He will not come.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: My men can take his estates. He has perhaps eighty guards—household troops, not soldiers. We have the Tagmata, the wall garrison, the Defensor's knights. If we move quickly, before he expects it, we can have him in chains by sunset tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We move against him now, with overwhelming force. We arrest him in his home and secure his estates. During the muster, the charges will be officially levvied against him and the proof presented. I will then install a new judge system and have him tried for treason. His title of admiral is stripped away from him immediately as is my power to give commander titles based on merit. If he is found guilty, his titles will defer to the emperor and he will be execuited. Raoul, man of action. If I give you command of 800 of my knights and the men of some of the noble houses who aid us as well, will you be able to carry out this task?

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: Eight hundred knights. Plus my Tagmata. Plus volunteers from the committed houses. Against eighty household guards on an estate with no significant fortifications. Defensor, I could take Notaras with a tenth of that force. With what you're offering, I could take him without a single man drawing blood.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you wish me to place eight hundred of our knights under Greek command?

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: House Philanthropenos will contribute fifty men to the arrest. Let it be known that the old families stand against the traitor.

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: Bryennios will contribute forty. And I will ride with them myself. Let no one say my house stood apart when justice was done.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Take him alive if you can. I want him to stand trial. I want Constantinople to see the evidence. I want him to answer for what he did—to me, to Sphrantzes, to this empire.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do it Raoul. Captain Fernan, make sure the knighgts understand they are currently under Raoul's command for this operation. Kantakouzenos, I have a task for you as well. You know the city gates and it's access points. There are spies everywhere. Spied from the Sultan and among our own people who seek advancement by aligning themselves with the sultan. Take every sensible precaution to catch them.

encounters.recap: Juan II organizes a military muster at the Hippodrome for the next day, promising titles in Thrace to nobles who contribute forces. The assembled nobles commit men and ships to the cause. The war council then turns to the arrest of Loukas Notaras, the accused traitor. Juan orders an immediate overwhelming assault on Notaras's estates, placing 800 Castilian knights under Greek commander Raoul's command, supported by forces from allied noble houses. The operation aims to capture Notaras alive for public trial while Kantakouzenos secures the city gates against spies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán salutes, fist to chest in the Castilian manner. "It will be done, Your Majesty. The knights will understand." He turns to the eldest Raoul and switches to accented but serviceable Greek—you had not realized he had learned so much during your weeks here. "My men are yours for this operation, Captain. I will ride with them to ensure there is no confusion in commands. Your orders will be obeyed as if they came from the King himself."

exchanges.speaker: eldest_raoul
exchanges.text: We ride within the hour. I want Notaras in chains before sunset.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to his brothers. "Demetrios, gather the Tagmata—every man not on essential palace duty. Theodoros, coordinate with the noble houses. I want their contributions assembled at the Golden Gate within the hour. We approach the estates from the land side, cut off any escape toward Ottoman territory." The younger Raouls move immediately, the machinery of command engaging.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The gates will be sealed within the hour, Defensor. No one leaves without being searched. No documents, no messages, no carrier birds. The harbor is more difficult—we cannot stop all small boats. But I can post men at every dock, every quay. Anyone attempting to leave by water will be questioned.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: As for the spies themselves... I know where to look. The Ottoman merchants in the Venetian quarter who are not truly merchants. The servants in noble houses who report to multiple masters. The clerks who copy documents they should not copy. I have watched them operate for years, Defensor. I knew who they were. I could do nothing because Notaras protected them—some were his agents as much as the Sultan's. Now...

exchanges.speaker: philanthropenos
exchanges.text: A word of care, Defensor. Some of those who have... accommodated Ottoman interests did so because they saw no alternative. Because Notaras made it clear that cooperation was the path to survival. Not all are traitors in their hearts. Some are merely survivors.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Justice, Strategos. Not terror. We are not Notaras. We do not punish men for thoughts they might have had or words they might have spoken. We punish acts. Documented acts. Proven acts.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I place no limits on your authority except the carrying out of sentences. Those are for the courts. You are to arrest, question, interrogate, detain anyone. And I mean anyone, no harbor master, high noble or duke can refuse you. Come to me if your authority is questioned and you cannot proceed without bloodshed. We are turning a page and let everyone know it.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The trial, Defensor. You mentioned installing a new judge system. The Empire has courts—ecclesiastical courts under the Patriarch, imperial courts under the Emperor's authority. Are you proposing something... different?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: One question: the Ottoman embassy. They will be boarding their ships within the hour. Do I let them go cleanly, or do I search them first? They may be carrying intelligence they gathered during their stay—reports on our walls, our forces, our... political situation.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Ten years I waited for something to change. Ten years I prayed for deliverance. And now it comes, and I find I am... frightened. Not of Notaras. Not of the Sultan. Frightened of hope. Frightened that this too will fail, and the fall will be farther for having dared to climb.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let the Ottomans go with honour. The intelligence is what they have seen. Destroying the paper that carries it accomplished nothing. The trials, yes. The decree allows me to install a new justice system based on Roman law but with new judges who are not bought or corrupt. That is what I mean.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, eight hundred knights riding under a Greek captain to arrest a Greek traitor. It is well done. When this is over, they will not be able to say the Latins came to conquer.

encounters.recap: Juan orders the immediate arrest of Notaras and launches comprehensive security operations across Constantinople. The eldest Raoul leads combined Byzantine-Castilian forces to capture the traitor, while Kantakouzenos seals the city and begins hunting Ottoman spies. Despite concerns about overreach, Juan grants broad authority while establishing new judicial structures based on Roman law.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You are with Lucia when the rider arrives. She has been resting, the pregnancy weighing on her more heavily these past days. Catalina plays quietly in the corner with wooden horses—she has learned to be quiet when her mother sleeps. You sit by the window, watching the shadows lengthen across Constantinople, waiting for news. The clatter of hooves in the courtyard brings you to your feet. Captain Fernán himself dismounts, his armor dusty, his face grim. There is blood on his surcoat—not his own, you judge from how he moves. He looks up at your window and nods once. It is done. But. That single nod tells you there is more to the story.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: We have him, Your Majesty. Notaras is in chains, on his way to the Blachernae dungeons.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: His guards fought. We didn't expect it. Raoul called for surrender three times—showed them the force we'd brought, read the charges, promised clemency for those who laid down arms. They refused. The first rank held the gates while others barricaded the inner compound. Professional work—someone had drilled them for exactly this. We broke through in minutes, but those minutes cost us.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Three of my knights wounded, one seriously—a lance through the thigh, he may lose the leg. Two of the Tagmata dead. Half a dozen Greek soldiers from the noble houses with cuts and bruises. We killed perhaps twenty of Notaras's men. The rest surrendered once we breached the inner courtyard.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Raoul found him in a cellar beneath the kitchens. A hidden room—you'd never know it was there unless you knew to look. He was burning documents when we broke down the door. Half a chest of papers gone to ash before we could stop him. He fought. An old man with a knife against armored knights. Raoul took a cut on the arm before they subdued him.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Alive. Bruised. Furious. He has not stopped talking since we chained him. Curses, threats, prophecies of doom. He says the Sultan will avenge him. He says Constantinople will burn for this. He says you are a fool who has doomed the city by giving it hope.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: He believes it. I have seen men lie under pressure, Your Majesty. Notaras believes what he says. He thinks he was saving the Empire. He thinks accommodation with the Ottomans was the only path to survival. He thinks you have destroyed everything by making the Greeks believe they can fight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernán reaches into his surcoat and produces a scorched piece of parchment. You take it. The edges are blackened, the text fragmentary, but what remains is clear enough: Ottoman Turkish script, a date from six months ago, and the unmistakable seal of a court official in Edirne.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There's more where that came from. Enough to hang him ten times over. But the full picture... Gone to ash.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Rodrigo de Mendoza. Iñigo's cousin. He was in the first rank through the gates. Took the lance defending one of the Philanthropenos men who'd been unhorsed.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Raoul asks what you want done with the prisoners—the guards who surrendered. Thirty-some men. They followed orders, fought against the Emperor's forces, killed imperial soldiers. By strict law, that's treason. But they laid down arms when the battle was clearly lost. And Notaras's family. His wife, two sons, a daughter. They were in the compound when we attacked. Unharmed, but terrified. Raoul has them under guard, awaiting your judgment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If the wife and sons have not apparently participated in the treason, they can be set free. The men, we keep them in chains for now. They followed orders yes, but also fought against the emperor. We keep them for now.

roll.outcome: Costly Success: Battle at the Gates — Notaras's guards fight. The Castilian knights break them quickly, but not without blood. Several guards dead, a handful of knights and Greek soldiers wounded. Notaras is taken alive in the chaos—dragged from a hidden cellar, trying to burn documents.

encounters.recap: The arrest of Logothetes Notaras succeeds but at a cost. His guards fought professionally, killing two Byzantine soldiers and wounding several Castilians before surrendering. Notaras was found burning documents in a hidden cellar and was captured after brief resistance, but much evidence was destroyed. The traitor and surviving guards are imprisoned while his family is released.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos finds you in the palace as the last light fades from the sky. The Strategos looks tired—he has been moving non-stop since the war council, racing from gate to gate, dock to dock, coordinating a security operation across an entire city. He bows briefly and delivers his report without preamble.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The gates are sealed, Defensor. No one has left by land since the second hour after noon. Every exit is watched, every traveler searched.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And the harbor?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The harbor is... controlled. But not sealed. Not completely. The Golden Horn alone has forty-three quays, eighteen major docks, and countless places where a small boat can put in or push off. I have perhaps two hundred men I can trust absolutely. That's enough to watch the major points. It's not enough to watch everywhere. In the first hour, before my men were fully in position, at least three small boats departed from minor quays. Fishermen, supposedly. Perhaps they were fishermen. Perhaps they weren't.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What did you catch?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Seven confirmed agents. Men I have watched for years, waiting for the authority to act. They are in chains now. Their homes have been searched, their documents seized. Letters in Ottoman Turkish. Payment records—gold from Edirne, funneled through merchant houses. Lists of contacts. Some of those contacts are... surprising. Minor officials in the customs house. A clerk in the harbor master's office. A servant in House Laskaris.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Does Laskaris know?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Not yet. The servant was arrested quietly—the family believes he fled when he heard about the security sweep. How you handle this is your decision, Defensor. The boy is committed to the restoration. His house has been loyal. But the spy was in his household for three years, and Laskaris never knew.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos continues his assessment of what escaped their net, explaining the limitations of their operation and the likelihood that Ottoman intelligence networks still operate in the city.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The visible network is broken. The agents I knew about are in custody. The obvious channels of communication are closed. But I am not a fool. I know what I could see. I do not know what I could not see. The Sultan has been watching this city for decades. His father watched it. His grandfather watched it. They have had generations to plant assets we don't know about. I caught seven fish today. Perhaps there were only seven. Perhaps there were seventy, and the other sixty-three are still swimming.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: If I were running the Ottoman network, and I saw the Defensor's forces suddenly sealing gates and sweeping the harbor, I would send one message: Something has changed. The Latin king has moved. Stand by for more. They won't know the details yet. They won't know about Notaras's arrest, about the decree, about the muster tomorrow. But they'll know something happened. The Sultan will be alert. Whatever surprise we might have had... It is diminished.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: One of the captured agents asked to speak with you. With the Defensor Romaniae. He says he has information worth trading. Information about the network we didn't catch. Information about what the Sultan already knows. He may be lying—trying to buy time, or feed us false intelligence. Or he may be genuine. I cannot tell.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Laskaris should not be held too accountable for this. It's difficult to tell a good spy from a loyal servant. The spy that wants to talk to me can tell Kantakouzenos whatever he has to say. He should trust the process. You can tell him that I have heard of him and his request and that he can trust the officials.

roll.outcome: Partial/Complicated - Mixed results and political complications. Seven agents captured but some intelligence escaped to Ottoman territory.

encounters.recap: Kantakouzenos reports on the security sweep of Constantinople following Notaras's arrest. While seven Ottoman agents were captured and the visible spy network broken, some boats escaped in the first hour, likely carrying word to the Sultan that something had changed. The operation achieved partial success but lost the element of complete surprise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find John VIII in his private study—a smaller room than the formal chambers, lined with books and icons, lit by candles that cast dancing shadows on ancient walls. He has changed from his imperial regalia into simpler robes. He looks tired, but there is something in his bearing that was not there a week ago. Purpose, perhaps. Or simply the exhaustion of a man who has finally acted after years of paralysis.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Defensor. I have heard about the arrest. Notaras fought.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: His guards fought. Twenty dead. Two of your Tagmata among them.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Their names?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not have them yet. Raoul will know.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I will know them too. They died in my service. Their families will be provided for. And Notaras himself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Alive. In chains. The trial can proceed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your question about judges brings the Emperor forward in his chair, engaged in a way he has not been since the war council.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The challenge, Defensor, is that the existing judiciary is... compromised. Not all of them, but enough. Notaras spent ten years ensuring that men who owed him favors sat in positions of judgment.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Georgios Scholarios. A scholar and theologian, trained in both civil and canon law. He studied in Italy—Padua, I believe—and knows Latin jurisprudence as well as our own traditions.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I signed your decree, Defensor. I gave you authority I did not wish to give. Grant me this much: let me have a voice in who wields that authority. Not to obstruct—to ensure that when this is over, when you sail home to your wife and your kingdoms, what remains behind is something I can live with.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: More than acceptable. I want us to have a strong working relationship and this is a good example of how it should be. Would you like to invite these men to your palace in the coming days and discuss with them their pending appointments as judges?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor is silent for a long moment. You watch something move behind his eyes—a complex emotion working its way through layers of trauma and habit. For ten years, no one asked John VIII Palaiologos what he felt comfortable with.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: When I was young, I believed I would be a great ruler. I studied the histories—Justinian, Basil the Bulgar-Slayer, the Komnenoi who restored the Empire after disaster. Then my father died. Then my brother died. Then the throne fell to me, and I discovered that the throne was a prison.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You are asking me to believe again. To act like an Emperor, not merely wear the title. Yes, I will invite them. I will speak with them. I will assess their character, their learning, their fitness for office.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: She is well emperor. Let us work together to restore the empire to glory. When Constantine founded his empire and embraced christianity, he did so while building on an existing empire and he made it great. We can do so again but this time, we embrace cooperation with latin christians and it will make us great and strong.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Constantine. You compare what we do to Constantine. Do you know what they called him? Isapostolos—Equal to the Apostles. He saw a vision in the sky and remade the world. That is the standard you invoke.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I will not promise you glory, Defensor. But I will promise you this: I will try. For the first time in ten years, I will try to be the Emperor my people need. Go to your wife, King Juan. Hold her. Rest. Tomorrow we stand before our people together—Emperor and Defensor—and show them what a new alliance looks like.

roll.outcome: Four qualified candidates identified for new imperial courts: Georgios Scholarios (scholar-theologian), Theodoros Notaras (cousin of the disgraced Megas Logothete), Demetrios Chrysoloras (legal scholar), and Alexios Philanthropenos (young patriarchal lawyer). Emperor John VIII agrees to personally interview all candidates.

encounters.recap: Juan II and Emperor John VIII discuss establishing new imperial courts with trustworthy judges to replace Notaras's corrupt system. The Emperor, showing new confidence, agrees to personally interview judicial candidates and expresses his commitment to truly ruling for the first time in ten years. Juan invokes the legacy of Constantine the Great, inspiring John VIII to embrace the possibility of imperial restoration through Latin-Greek Christian cooperation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor turns from the icon, his expression shifting to something like surprise—and then genuine interest. It has been a long time, perhaps, since anyone asked him to teach. To share what he knows.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You do not know the story of Constantine's vision?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back toward his chair, gesturing for you to sit as well. Sphrantzes quietly sets aside his notes, recognizing that this conversation has moved beyond administrative matters.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: It was the year 312 by the Latin reckoning. Constantine was not yet Emperor—not sole Emperor. The Roman world was divided between rival claimants, as it so often was in those days. Constantine marched on Rome to face Maxentius, who held the city with a larger army. The night before the battle—the Battle of the Milvian Bridge—Constantine saw a vision in the sky. A cross of light, blazing above the sun. And with it, words: En toutō níka. In Greek. 'In this sign, conquer.' That night, Christ appeared to him in a dream and commanded him to mark his soldiers' shields with the Chi-Rho—the first two letters of Christ's name in Greek. Χ and Ρ, overlaid.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor's eyes are distant, seeing something beyond the candlelit room.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Constantine obeyed. His soldiers marched into battle bearing the sign of Christ. Maxentius drowned in the Tiber when the bridge collapsed beneath his fleeing army. Constantine entered Rome as its master. Within a year, he issued the Edict of Milan—toleration for Christians throughout the Empire. Within two decades, he had refounded this city as his new capital. Constantinople. The New Rome. The Christian Rome. One vision. One battle. One act of faith. And the world was remade.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The historians debate, of course. Eusebius, who knew Constantine personally, swore the Emperor told him the story himself. Others say it was propaganda—a useful tale to legitimize Christian rule. Lactantius describes it differently, as a dream alone without the sky-sign. But whether the vision was real or crafted, the result was real. Constantine believed—or chose to act as if he believed. And that belief built an empire that has endured eleven hundred years.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You invoke Constantine's name, Defensor. You speak of new founding principles, of embracing cooperation with Latin Christians as Constantine embraced Christ. You place yourself in the tradition of men who remake the world. Do you believe God has sent you here? Do you believe you have received a vision—a calling—as Constantine did?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You know I speak and read Greek and had heard of this tale in passing, but never was it laid out before me as you just did. Do you in turn know about me and my inspiration? The full tale of how I went to Rome in the first place? Went back for my father's sword to discover a plot against me? How I felt the urge to strip down naked before the pope and pledge myself, my crown and everything to christ? I never had a vision of a sign in the sky that told me what to do. Instead, I see glimpses of heaven sometimes and I try to make it real. And when I do see it, it is incredible and I know that I can do incredible things. Nothing scares me and I am unstoppably determined. Like I know what to do and how to do it, even if it is scary. I have debated with my confessor what this is and we have determined that the theological term is 'divine inspiration'. Did you know this?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor is very still. Sphrantzes has stopped breathing, his quill frozen above his notes. The candles flicker in the silence.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I knew... pieces. Rumors reached us even here, even through Notaras's control of information. The young King of Castile who completed the Reconquista in a single campaign. The king who went to Rome and received the Pope's blessing for a great crusade. The king who arrived in Constantinople with knights and gold and asked for nothing. But stripped naked before the Pope? Pledging everything—crown, kingdom, self—to Christ? No. That tale did not reach us. Or if it did, it was dismissed as Latin exaggeration. We Byzantines are... skeptical of such stories. We have seen too many men claim divine mandate while pursuing earthly ambition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises from his chair and moves closer to you, studying your face in the candlelight as if seeing you for the first time.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Glimpses of heaven. You see glimpses of heaven, and you try to make them real. The hesychasts—our mystics—they speak of something similar. The uncreated light. Divine illumination that comes through prayer and stillness. They say that those who achieve theosis—union with God—can perceive things hidden from ordinary sight. But they seek these visions through years of contemplation. Through fasting and prayer and withdrawal from the world. You... You are no hermit on a mountain. You are a king who conquers cities and signs treaties and builds alliances.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty, the Western Church speaks of inspiratio divina—divine inspiration. The breath of God moving through a soul to accomplish His purposes. It is not the same as the hesychast path, but it is... recognized. The prophets of old were not contemplatives. They were men of action whom God seized and used.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Your confessor—this Fray Hernando I have heard mentioned. He examined this... experience of yours? These glimpses? And what did he conclude? Does he believe you are truly inspired? Or does he fear that you mistake your own will for God's voice? That you see what you wish to see and call it heaven? I ask because I need to understand who I have allied myself with, King Juan. A man who believes he sees heaven and acts upon it—such a man can move mountains. Or such a man can lead armies into disaster, convinced that God will provide victory that never comes. What does your confessor say? And what do you believe about yourself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What I hear is not the voice of God and what I see is not some vision given to me by the Lord. No. What I see is the world how it should be and what we as mortals can do to make it so. I know that I am different from most men. Not only through my title as king, but through how I see the world. Everyone always asks me why I am generous, why I am being honourable, what I want in return. I have to explain to them again and again that I act because it is what aligns most with the kingdom in heaven. Proverbially of course. That I consider doing good is it's own reward. Consider everything that I have done while we have known each other. Are those the actions of someone who thinks God blessed him and only him? That I have been granted visions by the Lord? Or am I Juan, who does everything in his power to remake the world into the image of the kingdom of heaven?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor is silent for a long moment. The candles flicker. Somewhere in the palace, a door closes. The night sounds of Constantinople drift through the windows—distant dogs, the cry of a watchman, the eternal lap of water against ancient walls.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: When I was young, I studied the heresies. Every educated Byzantine does—we must know error to recognize truth. The Messalians, who believed prayer alone could achieve salvation. The Bogomils, who saw the material world as evil. The iconoclasts, who smashed holy images in the name of purity. And always, throughout our history, men who claimed God spoke to them directly. Who believed themselves chosen vessels for divine will. Some were saints. Many more were madmen. A few were both.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He touches the frame of Constantine's icon.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I asked you if you believed yourself inspired. I expected either denial—false humility—or confirmation. The zealot's certainty that God has blessed him above other men. Instead, you give me something else. You say you see the world as it should be. That you act to make it so. That doing good is its own reward.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty, what King Juan describes... it is not prophecy. It is not mysticism. It is closer to what the ancient philosophers called eudaimonia—the flourishing life. The life lived in accordance with virtue, pursuing the good because the good is worth pursuing.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Aristotle. The Nicomachean Ethics. We Byzantines preserved those texts when the West forgot them. It seems fitting that a Western king would embody them. I have watched you, King Juan. Since you arrived in my city. I have watched you give gold without demanding return. I have watched you honor our faith when you could have insisted on Latin supremacy. I have watched you hand power to Greeks when you could have kept it for yourself. I confess I did not understand it. In my experience, men who give freely are either fools or schemers. They either do not understand the game, or they are playing it at a level I cannot perceive. But you are neither. You are a man who sees the world as it should be and bends all his strength toward making it so. Not because God commanded you. Not because you expect reward. Because that is simply... who you are.

encounters.recap: Juan asks Emperor John VIII about Constantine's vision. The Emperor recounts the Chi-Rho vision before the Battle of Milvian Bridge. Juan reveals his own spiritual experiences—glimpses of heaven that inspire him to remake the world. The Emperor initially suspects divine delusion but comes to recognize Juan's philosophy as virtuous action for its own sake, comparing it to Aristotelian ethics.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I have watched you, King Juan. Since you arrived in my city. I have watched you give gold without demanding return. I have watched you honor our faith when you could have insisted on Latin supremacy. I have watched you hand power to Greeks when you could have kept it for yourself.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I confess I did not understand it. In my experience, men who give freely are either fools or schemers. They either do not understand the game, or they are playing it at a level I cannot perceive.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: But you are neither. You are a man who sees the world as it should be and bends all his strength toward making it so. Not because God commanded you. Not because you expect reward. Because that is simply... who you are.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I have not known many such men. Perhaps I have not known any. The court I grew up in was a nest of vipers. Every kindness had a price. Every gift was a trap. I learned to see conspiracy in generosity, threat in friendship.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You are asking me to unlearn the habits of a lifetime. To believe that a man can act from pure principle, without hidden motive. To trust that what I see is what is truly there.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: It is not too late, Your Imperial Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Tell me of your confessor, this Fray Hernando. Tell me how a king comes to strip naked before a Pope. Tell me what heaven looks like, when you glimpse it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I loved my first wife Isabel fiercely and when she gave birth to Catalina was one of the most profound moments in my life. A parent's care and love for their children is one of God's greatest gift and I see God's gift everywhere. Her death in childbirth hit me hard and I shouted in anger at the lord in front of my entire court. But instead it had made me angry and even more determined to shield others from the loss that had been inflicted on me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will put a stop to Muslims because they enslave people and use child soldiers. These are acts of pain and suffering and I will rid the world of them if I can. I will always place myself, my sword and shield before a mother when someone tries to take away her son as tax for the sultan's army.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: The devshirme. You know of it, then.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Every Greek knows of it, Your Majesty. Every family in Ottoman territory fears it. The Sultan's men come to Christian villages and take the boys—the strongest, the healthiest, the most promising. They are taken to Edirne, converted to Islam, trained as soldiers.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: When you say you will rid the world of this evil or die trying—do you mean it? Truly? Not as rhetoric, not as crusade propaganda, but as a vow you intend to keep?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You are not here for glory. You are not here for empire. You are here because somewhere, right now, a mother is watching Ottoman soldiers take her son away. And you cannot bear it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am always ready to place myself between the innocent and harm, especially evil so foul as the blood tax. This does not mean that I will charge headlong into the sultan's army, such an act will serve no one. But I instead do what I have been doing. Forging alliances between kingdoms who together can stand up to the sultan.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You speak of hard-won victory. Of moving closer to God's kingdom every day. Of practical steps—alliances, coalitions, the slow accumulation of strength. This is not how I imagined salvation would come.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: But sitting here now, hearing you speak of why you do what you do... I find I am glad I signed it. Not merely resigned to necessity, but glad. Because for the first time in many years, I believe the man I have allied with is who he claims to be.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Tomorrow we stand before Constantinople together. Emperor and Defensor. Perhaps—perhaps even friends.

encounters.recap: In a late-night conversation, Emperor John VIII opens up about his lifelong distrust and recognizes Juan's genuine character. They bond over shared grief and Juan's commitment to stopping the devshirme (blood tax) that takes Christian children. The Emperor expresses gratitude and hope for their alliance, suggesting they may become true friends.

roll.outcome: Impressive Turnout — Enthusiasm Emerges. Something shifts in the Hippodrome. The Doukas patriarch gives a speech praising the Emperor's courage. The Palaiologos cadets publicly acknowledge the Basileus as rightful head of their house. Military families compete to demonstrate their value. Even the Gattilusio send a representative with forty men, carefully explaining that their Genoese arrangements remain separate from their Byzantine loyalties. Total new forces: 550-700 men. The mood is no longer cautious—it is becoming hopeful.

encounters.recap: The Great Muster at the Hippodrome assesses noble commitment to the Emperor and Defensor's coalition. With impressive turnout, major houses including the Doukas and Palaiologos cadets publicly commit forces, transforming the cautious mood into genuine enthusiasm. The coalition gains 550-700 new men as Constantinople's nobility begins to unite behind resistance rather than accommodation with the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: HEAR AND WITNESS! His Imperial Majesty John, in Christ God faithful Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, Palaiologos, and His Majesty Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, Defensor Romaniae, do hereby call this muster of the forces of Constantinople! Let all houses present their strength! Let all claims be registered! Let all oaths be witnessed!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd stills. The morning sun catches the Emperor's crown, the Castilian banners, the glitter of eight hundred lances. Theodoros turns to the dais and bows. The Emperor nods once. You mirror the gesture. The muster begins.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: House Philanthropenos steps forward first. The old patriarch cannot walk the distance, but his grandsons lead their eighty men in a formal march across the marshaling ground. The eldest grandson speaks the oath: 'House Philanthropenos pledges its swords, its gold, and its honor to the Emperor and the Defensor.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: House after house presents their strength—Raoul with their hundred swords, Kantakouzenos with forty men, Laskaris with twenty. The scribes record claims and oaths as each contingent takes their position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then—the moment everyone has been waiting for. The Doukas banner appears at the eastern gate. A ripple passes through the Hippodrome. They do not come with thirty men, hedging their bets. They come with one hundred.

exchanges.speaker: house_doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty. I am an old man. I have watched this empire shrink for five decades. I have seen emperors beg and grovel and sell pieces of our heritage for another year of survival. I told myself it was wisdom. That accommodation was the only path. I was wrong.

exchanges.speaker: house_doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Notaras told us resistance was futile. That the Latins would betray us as they always have. That our only hope was to make ourselves useful to the Sultan. And all the while, he was selling us to that same Sultan. Correspondence in his own hand. Treason dressed as pragmatism.

exchanges.speaker: house_doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty chose differently. You chose to trust a Latin king who asked for nothing but the chance to help. You chose to fight instead of kneel. You chose to be an Emperor. House Doukas stands with you. Our swords, our ships, our gold, our ancient claims in the Aegean. Whatever comes, we face it together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Doukas declaration breaks something loose. The Palaiologos cadets arrive—not one branch but three, competing to demonstrate loyalty. House after house follows: Tornikes with fifty soldiers, Metochites with thirty, Angelos with forty. Even commoners approach, asking to enlist despite having no noble names.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By midday, the marshaling ground is transformed. Over five hundred new men have joined the coalition. The total strength now approaches sixteen hundred souls. The Hippodrome buzzes with energy that was not there at dawn.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_metochites
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty. Your Majesty. The houses have presented their strength. The claims have been registered. The oaths have been witnessed. The muster is complete. Unless there is... further business?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome falls gradually quiet. Six thousand faces turn toward the dais. They are waiting.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I stand and walk to where the acoustics can best make me be heard. In my practiced and best Greek, I tell them...

roll.outcome: Impressive turnout. Doukas commitment triggers cascade of pledges. Over 500 new soldiers join coalition.

encounters.recap: The great muster transforms from cautious attendance to enthusiastic commitment when House Doukas dramatically pledges one hundred men and publicly condemns Notaras as a traitor. This triggers a cascade of noble houses joining the coalition, adding over 500 soldiers and bringing total strength to nearly 1,600. Juan prepares to address the assembled crowd.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome falls gradually quiet. Six thousand faces turn toward the dais. They are waiting.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Citizens of Byzantium. Before you stands I, Ioannes of Castille. Today, you have given me the greatest honour. You have chosen me as your defendor. An honour I shall try to repay in kind. Yesterday, the old empire was dying. Yesterday we were preparing for the inevitable day when Ottomans would break through our walls and finally take from us whatever is left of our empire. Yesterday, we feared each other. We were afraid to lose what little we had left. Today, we turn the page. Today, we decide that we shall be afraid no more! That from this day forward we shall not go quietly into the night! We shall not vanish without a fight. Today is a new dawn for the empire. No longer will we lose ground to the muslims, but we start taking it back. Long has the Byzantine empire been asking the west for aid. And for a long time, we have been wondering what that aid would even look like. Now we know. The only way forward is when Greeks and Latins work together, when we no longer fear each other and hide behind walls. We are christians and it's time we remembered that. And you have, when you named me defensor. Defensor...a name chosen carefully. I am not here to dominate, or to conquer. No. I am here to reclaim, to protect. Why do we fight? Not because of greed, no. We fight to free our brothers and sisters from the yoke of the true opressors, the sultan and his janissaries. How many times do mothers have to clutch their sons to their chests, in fear of the dreaded blood tax? How much longer do we have to face our own kin in battle who have been stripped of their identity, their culture and their faith? How cruel can one be to twist young boys so? No! I will not stand for it. We will not stand for it. I will always place myself between any mother and this evil and say 'Not today!' For I am not just a general, a soldier, a father. I am Defensor Romaniae and I will protect and defend. Today under this sun begins the Reclaiming, the Apokatastasis. Everyone fights. And if we all put our strength into it, then we will reclaim that what was lost. We will mend that was broken. We will make the lord smile as he looks down upon us and he will se his name honoured and his praises sung. An empire worth fighting for and a future worth dying for. To Victory!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The roar exceeds the Hippodrome. People in the streets outside stop and listen. The sound carries across the Golden Horn. In the markets, in the churches, in the homes of those who did not attend, heads turn toward the ancient stadium. What is happening there? The chanting does not stop—it grows, wave after wave. 'Níka! Defensor! Basileus! Níka!' When Juan finally lowers his sword, the crowd does not fall silent. They keep chanting. They do not want the moment to end.

roll.outcome: Thunderous Response — The City Hears. The roar exceeds the Hippodrome. The chanting carries across the Golden Horn. 'Níka! Defensor! Basileus! Níka!' The crowd does not want the moment to end.

encounters.recap: Juan delivers his Apokatastasis speech in fluent Greek to six thousand assembled in the Hippodrome, declaring the beginning of the Reclaiming and positioning himself as Defensor Romaniae. His passionate appeal against the blood tax and call for Greek-Latin unity creates a thunderous response that echoes throughout Constantinople, with crowds chanting victory cries long after he lowers his sword.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your voice carries across the ancient stadium. The acoustics of the Hippodrome were designed for this—for emperors to address their people, for heralds to proclaim victories, for the roar of a hundred thousand throats to shake the heavens. Today, perhaps six thousand souls fill the tiered seats. But they make the sound of sixty thousand. When you speak the first words in Greek—"Citizens of Byzantium"—a ripple passes through the crowd. Heads turn. Eyes widen. A Latin king, speaking their tongue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you speak of yesterday—of the dying empire, of fear, of preparing for the inevitable—they are silent. The silence of recognition. When you speak of today—"we shall be afraid no more"—something shifts. A murmur runs through the stands. Not disagreement. Hunger. They want to believe it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How many times do mothers have to clutch their sons to their chests, in fear of the dreaded blood tax? How much longer do we have to face our own kin in battle who have been stripped of their identity, their culture and their faith? I will always place myself between any mother and this evil and say 'Not today!' For I am not just a general, a soldier, a father. I am Defensor Romaniae and I will protect and defend.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The roar that answers you is not polite applause. It is not the calculated enthusiasm of nobles seeking favor. It is fury—fury that has been suppressed for generations, fury that finally has somewhere to go. When you speak the word—Apokatastasis—the crowd catches its breath. The restoration. The renewal. The theological promise that all things broken will be made whole.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will reclaim that what was lost. We will mend that was broken. We will make the Lord smile as he looks down upon us... This I commit before you and our Lord. Your Defensor. To Victory!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You draw your blade. The steel catches the noon sun, blazing bright. You raise it toward heaven—not threatening, not aggressive, but offering. A sword dedicated to God's service. The Hippodrome explodes. "NÍKA! NÍKA! NÍKA!" The ancient cry of the chariot factions thunders from six thousand throats, echoing off the ancient walls. The sound carries beyond the Hippodrome walls, across the Golden Horn. Constantinople is roaring.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor has risen from his throne. John VIII Palaiologos stands at the edge of the dais, gripping the railing, staring out at his people. His cheeks are wet. He makes no effort to hide it. He has not heard this sound since he was a boy—the sound of Byzantium believing in itself.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I have never heard them like this. Not once in my reign. Not once in my father's reign. What you have given them today... I do not know if we can deliver what you have promised. I do not know if the Apokatastasis is possible. But you have given them something they had lost. Something I thought was gone forever. You have given them belief.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Today we shout Nika! Today we know that everyone fights. Today our hands have found the grip of a sword again. Let's not forget this as we tell our neighbours of today and later our children. There is much to do, so let's get to work. And let's build this new empire together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You sheathe your sword and step back from the platform. The gesture is deliberate. You have said what needed to be said. You have given them fire. Now you give them something equally important: an ending. A return to the practical. A signal that the time for speeches is over and the time for action has begun.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You have heard the Defensor. Now hear your Emperor. The muster is recorded. The oaths are witnessed. The claims are registered. Let every house return to its duties. Let every soldier prepare for the work ahead. Let every citizen of Constantinople carry today's words in their hearts. And let Notaras's trial begin tomorrow. Let the traitor answer for his crimes before the people he betrayed. Go now. Tell your neighbors what you witnessed. Tell them the Empire remembers itself. Tell them their Emperor stands with them. At last.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, that was... I have served this court for twenty years. I have witnessed ceremonies and speeches and proclamations beyond counting. I have never witnessed anything like that. The scribes have recorded the commitments. The claims are documented. The total strength pledged today—including the Castilian forces—exceeds sixteen hundred men, with more volunteers still presenting themselves to the clerks.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: They want to fight. Men without noble names, without houses, without claims. They heard your words and they want to answer them. In the old days, the Empire had the tagmata—professional soldiers, yes—but also the themata. Provincial levies. Common men called to defend their homes. But these men are not asking to be paid. They are asking to serve. This is your domain, Defensor. Matters of defense. What would you have us do with men who wish to fight but have no lord to follow?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Greetings men of the city. You are prepared to fight? And are you prepared to be rewarded according to the themata?

roll.outcome: Thunderous response. The crowd explodes with enthusiasm, chanting 'Níka!' and 'Apokatastasis!' The Emperor weeps openly. The city hears the roar. Common people volunteer to serve.

encounters.recap: Juan concludes his stirring speech at the Hippodrome muster with a thunderous crowd response. Six thousand Byzantines chant 'Níka!' as he promises to end the blood tax and restore the empire. The Emperor is moved to tears, saying Juan has given the people belief. The speech concludes with practical work ahead, and common citizens volunteer to serve in a revived themata system.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You climb the ancient steps toward the upper sections of the Hippodrome, where the common people have gathered. Your guard of six knights follows, hands on hilts, eyes scanning—but the crowd parts respectfully before you. These are not men seeking to harm. They are men seeking to serve. Perhaps two hundred have lingered. Fishermen with salt-weathered faces. Craftsmen with calloused hands. Laborers whose muscles were built by hauling stone and timber. A few greybeards who carry themselves like soldiers—veterans of the walls, perhaps, men who once served and never forgot the weight of a sword.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A man steps forward from the crowd. He is perhaps forty, broad-shouldered, with a blacksmith's arms and a face marked by smallpox scars. He does not bow—commoners do not know the courtly gestures—but he inclines his head with rough respect.

exchanges.speaker: blacksmith_leader
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We heard your words. We felt them here. You spoke of mothers and sons. Of standing between evil and the innocent. We have mothers. We have sons. Some of us—had sons. Before the blood tax took them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Greetings men of the city. You are prepared to fight? And are you prepared to be rewarded according to the themata?

exchanges.speaker: blacksmith_leader
exchanges.text: We know what the themata was, Your Majesty. Our grandfathers spoke of it. Soldiers given land. Farmers who fought. Men who had something to defend because they owned something. We own nothing. We rent our homes from lords who barely know our names. We work for wages that buy bread and little else. When the Ottomans come—we will fight anyway. We will fight because Constantinople is all we have. Because our families are here. Because there is nowhere else to go.

exchanges.speaker: blacksmith_leader
exchanges.text: But you speak of themata. You speak of reward. You speak of an empire rebuilt. If you are saying what I think you are saying—if you are offering land to men who fight for it—then you will have more volunteers than you can count. Every man in this city who works with his hands and dreams of something more will come to you. But I must ask plainly, Your Majesty, because we have been lied to before: Is this real? Will common men truly receive land if we help you take it back? Or are we just swords to be used and discarded when the fighting is done?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes, do we not have one decree that states the themata and land grants already? They are enacted in force the moment the emperor signed the bull. Can you read it and tell these men how much land they will receive when they serve in the themata?

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the decree establishing your authority as Defensor Romaniae grants you the power to organize military forces and administer matters pertaining to defense. The Taktikon of Romania, signed in April, establishes the framework for territorial administration of reclaimed lands... But the specific terms of land grants for common soldiers—the revival of the themata system itself—This was discussed in principle, Your Majesty, but the precise allocations were left to be determined by the Defensor according to military necessity and the extent of territories reclaimed.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The authority exists. The framework exists. But the specific terms—how much land, what obligations, what rights of inheritance—these have not yet been proclaimed publicly. If Your Majesty wished to establish those terms now, before these witnesses, it would have the force of law. The Emperor has granted you this authority. You need only speak it, and I will record it.

exchanges.speaker: blacksmith_leader
exchanges.text: So the power is there, but the promise is not yet made. Then make it, Your Majesty. Here. Now. Before us. Tell us what a common man earns by fighting for the Apokatastasis, and we will hold you to it. Tell us what our sons inherit if we fall, and our widows will bless your name. Tell us—tell us that we matter. That we are not just bodies to fill the gaps between noble cavalry.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are mistaken Sphrantzes. Read Taktikon of Romania, articles 14 & 15. It establishes what every infantrymen shall receive and what his obligations are moving forward.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with two hundred common volunteers in the Hippodrome's upper tiers. A blacksmith spokesman questions whether land grants promised under the themata system are real or mere words. When Sphrantzes suggests the specific terms haven't been established, Juan asserts that the Taktikon of Romania already contains these provisions in articles 14 & 15.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are mistaken Sphrantzes. Read Taktikon of Romania, articles 14 & 15. It establishes what every infantrymen shall recieve and what his obligations are moving forward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The secretary freezes mid-sentence. His face flushes—a scholar caught in error, and publicly. 'The Taktikon...' He fumbles through his documents with his good hand, pulling out the thick sheaf of the military charter. 'Forgive me, Your Majesty. I was thinking of the general decree. The Taktikon is more... comprehensive than I—' He finds the relevant pages, scanning quickly. His expression shifts from embarrassment to recognition. 'Articles 14 and 15. Title IV: The Thematic System. Yes. Yes, you are correct.'

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Article 14: Establishment in Reconquered Territories. As territories are liberated from Ottoman occupation, military land grants shall be established according to the ancient thematic model, adapted to present circumstances. The purposes of the thematic system are: To populate reconquered lands with settlers capable of defending them. To create a self-sustaining military force that does not depend on treasury payments. To bind families to military service across generations. To reward those who fight for the restoration with permanent stake in its success.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Article 15: Categories of Grants. Thematic grants shall be made in three categories. Infantry Holdings—Stratiotika Ktemata: Sufficient land to support one family and equip one infantryman. Approximately thirty to fifty modioi of arable land, depending on soil quality. Obligation: One equipped infantryman when summoned, attending monthly training. Granted to: Common soldiers, militiamen who volunteer for settlement, Greek farmers already working the land who accept military obligation.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The law is already written, signed by the Defensor and ratified by His Imperial Majesty. Any man who serves in the infantry during the reconquest—who fights for the Apokatastasis—shall receive land. Not as charity. Not as reward to be revoked at a lord's whim. As right, bound by law, hereditary to his sons and his sons' sons, so long as they fulfill the obligation of service.

exchanges.speaker: konstantinos
exchanges.text: Thirty to fifty modioi. Do you understand what he just said? Thirty to fifty modioi. My grandfather worked land like that. Before the Turks took it. Before we became... this. Tenants. Laborers. Men who own nothing. And you're saying—the law is already written—any man who fights gets land? Any man, Your Majesty? Even men like us? Men without names, without houses, without lords to speak for us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Everyone fights, my man. Everyone fights. And together we reforge our empire. Yes, I would gladly have you in my army.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The scarred man stares at you for a long moment. Something is happening behind his eyes—the hard shell of a lifetime's cynicism cracking against the weight of what he has just heard. A king. Speaking Greek. Looking him in the face. Saying I would gladly have you in my army. The blacksmith's jaw works. His hands—hands that have shaped iron for twenty years—are trembling. Then he drops to one knee.

exchanges.speaker: konstantinos
exchanges.text: Then you have me, Defensor. My hammer. My arm. My life, if it comes to that. For land my sons can inherit. For an empire worth fighting for. My name is Konstantinos. I was named for the founder of this city. I never thought the name meant anything. Maybe now it will.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind Konstantinos, the dam breaks. One man kneels. Then another. Then a dozen. Then all of them—two hundred common men, fishermen and craftsmen and laborers and veterans, dropping to their knees on the ancient stones of the Hippodrome. 'Defensor!' The cry comes from somewhere in the mass of kneeling men. 'DEFENSOR!' It spreads. It builds. Two hundred voices, ragged and untrained, but fierce with something that has been sleeping in Constantinople for generations. 'DEFENSOR! DEFENSOR! DEFENSOR!'

exchanges.speaker: konstantinos
exchanges.text: What do we do, Defensor? Where do we go? How do we... We don't have weapons. We don't have armor. We don't know how to fight in formations. We're not soldiers.

encounters.recap: Juan corrects Sphrantzes and has him read the Thematic System articles, promising land grants to common soldiers who fight in the reconquest. The blacksmith Konstantinos and two hundred commoners are moved to pledge themselves to Juan's cause, kneeling and crying 'Defensor' in the Hippodrome, marking a pivotal moment of popular support for the restoration.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes has stopped writing. The secretary stands frozen, his quill dripping ink unnoticed onto his robes. The noble houses have not fully dispersed. Those who lingered—the Doukas patriarch, the Raoul brothers, Lord Bryennios, others—have turned to watch the scene in the upper tiers. Two hundred commoners kneeling before a Latin king, pledging themselves to his service. Some faces show approval. Others show uncertainty. A few show something darker—the unease of men who have built their power on the assumption that common people do not matter. Philanthropenos, still seated in his chair, catches your eye across the distance. The old patriarch is smiling—a thin, knowing smile. He raises his hand, just slightly. A gesture of acknowledgment. You understand, that gesture says. You understand what the nobles have forgotten. The strength of an empire is not in its lords. It is in its people.

exchanges.speaker: konstantinos
exchanges.text: What do we do, Defensor? Where do we go? How do we... We don't have weapons. We don't have armor. We don't know how to fight in formations. We're not soldiers. But we can learn. And we will learn. Tell us what to do, and we'll do it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes, make sure the names of these men are recorded. We will train and arm them as is appropriate. I summon Raoul. Raoul, these men have committed themselves to serve in the themata. These men must be trained and equipped. Who can we appoint to train these men?

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: It will be done, Your Majesty. We will establish a registry here, today, before these men disperse. Names, quarters, trades, ages. The rolls of the new themata will begin with these two hundred. Form a line. Each man will give his name, his trade, his quarter of residence, and his age. You will receive a token confirming your enrollment. Keep it safe—it is your proof of service and your claim to land when the territories are reclaimed.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: Two hundred men. Most have never held a spear in formation. Some have never held a spear at all. Fishermen's arms are strong for rowing, not for shield walls. Smiths know metal but not how to use it against a man trying to kill them. But they have fire. That counts for something. Fire can be shaped, if the shapers know their work. For trainers, Defensor, we have several options. First: my own Tagmata officers. Professional soldiers, Byzantine-born, Greek-speaking. They know how to train men for wall defense—that is what they do. But they are few, and they are needed for palace security. I can spare perhaps five men for training duty without compromising our position. Second: the wall garrison veterans. Kantakouzenos has men who have stood on those walls for twenty years. They know siege defense better than anyone alive. Some are too old for front-line duty but would make excellent drill instructors. The Strategos could identify a dozen such men, perhaps more. Third: the noble household guards. The committed houses—Philanthropenos, Doukas, Tornikes—they have men who know how to fight. Not all are needed for their lords' immediate service. A rotation could be arranged—each house contributing one or two experienced soldiers to the training cadre. Fourth: your Castilians. They know infantry tactics—real tactics, tested against the Moors. Your tercios broke Granada. If you could spare officers to teach formation fighting, close-quarters combat, the discipline that holds a line when men are dying around you... My recommendation is a combination. Byzantine officers for basic drill, wall defense, and discipline—they speak the language, they understand the men, they can earn trust quickly. Castilian officers for combat tactics—formation fighting, coordinated maneuvers, the things that turn a militia into an army that can take the field, not just hold walls. There is one other matter, Defensor. The Taktikon specifies forty days of basic training. These men have trades, families, obligations. Forty consecutive days away from their work means forty days without income. Some will struggle to feed their families during training. The military treasury can provide basic rations during training—the Taktikon allows for this. But if we want these men to train well, without distraction, without worry about hungry children at home... we may need to provide more. A small stipend, perhaps. Enough to replace lost wages. It is an investment, Defensor. Two hundred men now could become two thousand if word spreads that the themata treats its soldiers fairly. Or it could collapse if these first volunteers return to their quarters complaining of empty bellies and broken promises.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: The wages vary by trade, Defensor. A common laborer—a dock worker, a porter, a man who hauls stone—earns perhaps two to three hyperpyra per day. A skilled craftsman—a smith like Konstantinos there, a carpenter, a mason—earns four to six. Some of the fishermen earn more on good days, less on bad; call it three on average. Common laborers: Three hyperpyra per day, forty days—that is one hundred twenty hyperpyra. Skilled craftsmen: Five hyperpyra per day, forty days—that is two hundred hyperpyra. Average across the group: Most of these men are laborers and fishermen, not craftsmen. Call it one hundred fifty hyperpyra per man as a fair middle figure.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: In florins, Your Majesty—the exchange fluctuates, but currently one Florentine florin trades for approximately twelve to fourteen hyperpyra in Constantinople. So... One hundred fifty hyperpyra equals roughly ten to twelve florins per man. For two hundred men, at one hundred fifty hyperpyra each, the total stipend for forty days of training would be... Thirty thousand hyperpyra. Or approximately two thousand to twenty-five hundred florins. For comparison, Your Majesty—the Hippodrome races cost approximately three hundred twenty florins, including the prize. The wall repairs have consumed perhaps eight thousand florins thus far. Two thousand florins to create the foundation of a new citizen army...

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: That provides rations and wage replacement. The men train without worry. Their families do not starve. Word spreads that the Defensor keeps his promises. And if this works—if these two hundred become soldiers and return to their quarters speaking well of their treatment—the next muster may bring five hundred. Or a thousand. The investment multiplies. The noble houses spent more than that on wine and silk last month. This buys something that actually matters.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. They shall receive this compensation for their training. The crown will compensate. Let it be known. Those wanting to enter the themata will be judged for physical fitness. Those unfit to fight will contribute in another way. Raoul, get these men trained using your proposal. I then set up a meeting with me, the emperor and all representatives of the italian cities and factions in the city. They have the rights to own property in the city from now on.

encounters.recap: Juan formally establishes the thematic system by ordering the registration of 200 volunteer commoners and authorizing their training with full compensation. He allocates 2,000-2,500 florins for training stipends and orders a combined Greek-Castilian training program. He also announces that Italians will be granted property ownership rights in the city.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You send runners to the Italian quarters—both Venetian and Genoese, as well as to any Florentine, Pisan, or other Italian merchants of standing in the city. The message is simple: The Defensor Romaniae requests the presence of representatives from all Italian communities at the Blachernae Palace, two hours before sunset. Matters of mutual interest will be discussed.

exchanges.speaker: emperor_constantine_xi
exchanges.text: Property rights for Italians. My ancestors would be horrified. But my ancestors did not face extinction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the appointed hour, they have gathered in a receiving chamber of the Blachernae—a room smaller than the throne room but elegant, with faded frescoes depicting ancient commerce and alliance. The Venetians are represented by Marco Contarini, Alvise Diedo, and a notary. The Genoese delegation includes Benedetto Fregoso, Tommaso di Campofregoso, and Giovanni Adorno. The Florentines have sent Jacopo de' Bardi. Other Italian merchants from various cities cluster at the back.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Italian representatives arrange themselves carefully—Venetians on one side, Genoese on the other, with the Florentine and minor Italians forming a neutral middle. The old rivalries are visible in every glance, every careful positioning.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Imperial Majesty. We are honored by this summons. The Italian communities of Constantinople have watched recent events with... great interest. The changes in the city are remarkable. You spoke of matters of mutual interest. We are eager to hear what the Defensor proposes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room falls silent. Venetians, Genoese, Florentines—all watching, all calculating, all wondering what this Latin king who speaks Greek and arrests traitors and raises armies from common men will offer them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I let the decree be read out aloud, especially the parts concerning the rights for Latins under this new decree.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes representatives from all Italian communities in Constantinople at the Blachernae Palace. Venetians, Genoese, Florentines, and other Italian merchants gather in careful factional arrangements. After formal greetings from senior merchant Marco Contarini, Juan orders a decree read aloud granting new property rights to Latins in the city.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The secretary produces the document—the Chrysobull of the Choice, sealed with imperial purple wax, signed by both Emperor and Defensor. The Italians watch with professional wariness as he unfolds the heavy parchment.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
