exchanges.text: By request of the Defensor Romaniae, I shall read the relevant portions of the Chrysobull of the Choice, ratified by His Imperial Majesty and entered into force upon the signing of the Decree of the Defensor.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He clears his throat and begins reading the preamble: 'Whereas the Roman Empire was built by peoples of many nations united under common law and common purpose... And whereas the division between Greek and Latin has weakened Christendom... Now therefore, this Chrysobull establishes the means by which Latins residing in Constantinople may become full citizens of the Roman Empire.'

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Any Latin Christian of good standing may elect to become a citizen of the Roman Empire—a Romanos—through the process established herein. This election is voluntary; no Latin is compelled to choose, and those who do not choose retain their existing rights under the treaties of their home cities.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes continues reading the methods of election: investment of property, military service, professional contribution, marriage, or imperial grant. The Florentine banker takes notes as the rights are detailed—full property rights, legal standing, commercial rights, political voice, and religious freedom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is very quiet. The Italians are processing what they have just heard. For centuries, they have operated in Constantinople under treaties—tolerated, permitted, but never belonging. Now they are being offered something else entirely. Full citizenship. Equal rights.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Imperial Majesty. This is... unprecedented. In all the centuries that Venice has traded in Constantinople, no Emperor has offered such terms. I must ask plainly: is this genuine? Why now? What has changed?

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: And what is the price beyond what was read? There is always a price.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The price was pretty obvious in the decree. You have obligations as well. You become part of the fight for the survival and restoration of the city. Much of the city stands empty, we must make the city prosperous again. When there is much opportunity, there is not always a cost that is equal to the gain.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: The Defensor speaks plainly. I appreciate plainness. You are correct—the city stands half-empty. Constantinople was built for half a million souls. How many remain? Fifty thousand? Fewer? And you offer us the chance to fill those empty spaces. To become Romans.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: The opportunity is clear. But you must understand our position, Defensor. We are not free men who answer only to ourselves. We are Genoese. If a Genoese merchant elects Roman citizenship, what happens to his standing in Genoa? Can he still trade under Genoese protection?

exchanges.speaker: giovanni_adorno
exchanges.text: You ask us to add Roman citizenship. But can a man serve two masters?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You ask what has changed. I will tell you what has changed. I have changed. My predecessors offered you treaty rights because they feared you. I am done with fear. I am done with managing decline. The price is loyalty. The price is service. The price is deciding that Constantinople is not merely a place you do business, but a place you belong.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty speaks forcefully. But we cannot answer today. What we can do is carry this offer back to our communities. Is there a timeline, Defensor? A date by which men must choose?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is an offer and I do not expect it to close anytime soon. Maybe ever. The advantages for both the empire and the latins is simply too great. But let me perhaps clarify that becoming a roman citizen may not be such a stark crisis in identity as some of you may think.

encounters.recap: The Chrysobull of the Choice is formally read to Italian merchants, offering Latins full Roman citizenship with unprecedented rights including property ownership, legal standing, and commercial equality. The merchants express interest but concern about dual loyalties, while the Emperor emphasizes this as a test of commitment to Constantinople's future.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Is there a timeline, Defensor? A date by which men must choose? Or does the offer stand open indefinitely?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is an offer and I do not expect it to close anytime soon. Maybe ever. The advantages for both the empire and the latins is simply too great. But let me perhaps clarify that becoming a roman citizen may not be such a stark crisis in identity as some of you may think. It is simply this. Rights are offered and with rights also come certain obligations. Those owning properties in the city will be required to help under the principle of 'everyone fights'. Logical, as they will be protecting their own property together with the other citizens of the empire. But it does not require you to become Greek. To accept Orthodoxy, or to abandon being Venitian. You simply have some extra obligations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Italians process your words. The framing matters—you have moved the conversation from identity crisis to practical arrangement. Marco Contarini's posture changes subtly. The wariness recedes, replaced by something more like genuine interest.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Dual obligations. Not replacing Venetian citizenship, but... layering Roman citizenship atop it. You are correct that there is precedent. The Duke of Burgundy holds lands from both the King of France and the Holy Roman Emperor. When those sovereigns quarrel, he manages his obligations to each according to which lands are affected.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: You mention the lex mercatoria. The law merchant. This is... significant. You are saying that disputes between Latin merchants in Constantinople would be judged not by Greek law, not by Venetian or Genoese law, but by the international customs of trade?

exchanges.speaker: giovanni_adorno
exchanges.text: The lex mercatoria is neutral ground. It is the law we use in the great fairs, in the ports where many nations trade. If Constantinople's courts will apply these principles... Then a Genoese and a Venetian could settle a dispute here without either submitting to the other's law.

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: You said you will promote these principles in your own kingdoms. In Castile. Legal symmetry, you called it. So a Florentine who holds property in Constantinople under Roman law, and property in Seville under Castilian law, might find those legal systems... harmonized? Compatible? Speaking the same commercial language?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes produces the Charter of the Latin Courts—another heavy document, sealed and signed, the ink barely dry. He passes it first to Marco Contarini, who receives it with the reverence a merchant reserves for contracts worth fortunes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The emperor and I have already created the framework for this system. Not only mercantile courts but also new legal courts for civil disputes. Roman law but neutral judges. The recent conflict between the Genovese and the Venetians established this precedent. And yes, I shall promote the exact same system in my own kingdom and will encourage others to do the same.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: This is not a proposal. This is already law?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: Signed and ratified. The courts are established. We lack only judges to fill the benches—appointments that will be made in the coming days.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: No judge may hear any case in which a party shares his national origin. A Venetian judge may not hear cases involving Venetian parties. A Genoese judge may not hear cases involving Genoese parties. Do you understand what you have created, Defensor? For two hundred years, every dispute between Venetian and Genoese in this city has been a political crisis. This solves that.

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: You have created a merchant court that speaks merchant law. Not Roman law adapted awkwardly to commerce. Not canon law stretched beyond recognition. Actual lex mercatoria, applied by judges who understand trade.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You have thought this through. This is not improvisation. This is not a desperate emperor throwing concessions at foreigners hoping something will stick. This is... Architecture. Legal architecture. A structure designed to bear weight.

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: Is that your vision, Defensor? Not just Constantinople. Not just Castile. But a framework that could span Christendom?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A strong trade network makes a strong kingdom. And we need strong kingdoms in the fight to come. Yes, I will promote this same system in all the kingdoms I rule and in those I have significant influence. Portugal, Castille, Leon, Aragon, Navarre, Naples. And I will ask the Italian states to develop similar systems as well. It's all part of my effort to mobilize for eventual war against the Ottomans and take back what was taken from us.

encounters.recap: Juan presents the Charter of the Latin Courts to Italian merchants, revealing an established legal framework with neutral judges and lex mercatoria. The merchants recognize the revolutionary nature of the system and Juan reveals his broader vision to create a harmonized commercial law network across his kingdoms to strengthen Christian unity against the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: Is that your vision, Defensor? Not just Constantinople. Not just Castile. But a framework that could span Christendom?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A strong trade network makes a strong kingdom. And we need strong kingdoms in the fight to come. Yes, I will promote this same system in all the kingdoms I rule and in those I have significant influence. Portugal, Castille, Leon, Aragon, Navarre, Naples. And I will ask the Italian states to develop similar systems as well. It's all part of my effort to mobilize for eventual war against the Ottomans and take back what was taken from us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence falls over the chamber. You have just listed kingdoms like a merchant listing inventory. The Italians are merchants. They understand scale. And they are only now grasping the scale of what you intend.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_di_campofregoso
exchanges.text: You rule Castile and León personally, yes. But Aragon? Navarre? Naples? King Alfonso of Aragon is his own man. Navarre has its own dynasty. Naples is... contested. You speak of these kingdoms as if their cooperation is assured. How assured is it?

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: The Bardi bank collapsed sixty years ago. My great-grandfather's generation. They lent to Edward III of England for his French wars. When he defaulted, it destroyed us. What you describe—harmonized law, neutral courts, predictable commercial systems across multiple kingdoms—this is what we dream of, Defensor. But dreams require trust. Can you deliver what you promise?

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Let me be direct, Defensor. Venice has interests that sometimes align with what you describe, and sometimes do not. We profit from complexity. You propose to simplify what we have spent generations learning to exploit. And yet Venice is not what it was. If what you build succeeds, then Venice must be part of it or be left behind.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: Genoa has less to lose than Venice from simplification. We are already losing the competition for complexity—the Venetians outmaneuver us in every court, every negotiation. If neutral courts and harmonized law level that field, we might find ourselves better positioned than we are now.

exchanges.speaker: giovanni_adorno
exchanges.text: The Adorno family has always counseled caution. What the Defensor describes requires stability—stable kingdoms, stable laws, stable alliances. You are young, Defensor. But what you describe is the work of decades, not years. Will you still be pursuing this vision in twenty years?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Six months ago, I was a prisoner in my own palace, watching my empire die by inches, certain that nothing could change. Then this man came to my city. He brought belief. Belief that the current could be turned. I have learned not to bet against him.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: The courts you have established—you said you lack only judges. When will appointments be made? When will the system become... operational?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask the right questions. I only control the kingdoms of Castille and Leon. I can and will establish the same laws there as in this city. What more kingdoms will follow our principle is uncertain, but I have good faith that they will in time. I dont promise things I do not have, so I just tell you to wait and see. And in regards to the judges: the emperor is in the process of appointing judges for the civil courts and with his permission, I will leave the coordination of the merchant courts in his hands as well. Every faction should propose his own judges for this new system. Are the factions ready to propose their candidates so the emperor can review them?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: The Defensor honors me with his confidence. I will oversee the appointment process for both the civil courts and the commercial courts. The principle is clear: judges must be neutral, learned, and incorruptible. Each nation represented in Constantinople may propose candidates. I will not have these courts become another arena for factional warfare.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Venice will propose candidates, Your Imperial Majesty. We have men trained in the law at Padua and Bologna—scholars who have studied the lex mercatoria extensively. I can have names and credentials prepared within three days. Perhaps four.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: The Genoese community will also propose candidates. However, the Genoese community is not... unified. Would it be acceptable, Your Imperial Majesty, for each faction to propose candidates separately?

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: Florence will propose candidates as well. I would also suggest that the court system might benefit from Florentine administrative expertise. We would offer this knowledge freely—as an investment in the system's success.

encounters.recap: Juan reveals his ambitious vision for a continental network of harmonized commercial law spanning multiple kingdoms. Italian merchant factions react with a mixture of excitement and skepticism, debating whether Venice would benefit from simplified trade systems versus their current advantage in navigating complexity. The Emperor endorses the judicial appointment process, and each faction agrees to propose candidates for the new commercial courts, with arrangements made for competing Genoese factions to submit separate proposals.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pisan merchant's face transforms—anxiety giving way to something like wonder. He bows deeply, almost stumbling over himself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "Thank you, Your Majesty. Thank you. We will—Pisa will propose our best men. We have lawyers trained in the maritime courts of the Tyrrhenian. Men who have arbitrated disputes between a dozen nations. They may not carry famous names, but they know the law."

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: The Defensor clarifies an important point. This is not a council where each nation sends representatives to advance its interests. This is a court where judges must forget their nations.

exchanges.speaker: giovanni_adorno
exchanges.text: This changes how we should think about candidates. We should not propose men who are connected—men with extensive commercial ties, with debts owed and favors outstanding. Such men would be constantly recusing themselves.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Each community—Venetian, Genoese of both factions, Florentine, Pisan, Anconan, Ragusan, and any others present—may propose up to three candidates for the Commercial Chamber. Submit their names, their qualifications, their experience, and any potential conflicts of interest you are aware of.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Security. The Ottomans sit across the water. Their ships patrol the straits. Their armies have swallowed everything around this city. A merchant who elects Roman citizenship, who buys property here, who moves his family within these walls—he is betting everything on Constantinople's survival.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: As a mortal man, there are no guarantees I can offer regarding the coming conflict with the Ottomans. To do so would be a promise of hubris and pride. All I can say is that I came with my family and that I am fully committed to the success of the city.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You brought your family. Your wife. Your daughter. The Queen is with child, I am told. That is not the act of a man who plans to flee when trouble comes.

exchanges.speaker: jacopo_de_bardi
exchanges.text: You speak of early investment. Of prices rising as the city expands. Property in Constantinople today is... remarkably cheap. A man with gold could acquire holdings that would cost ten times as much in Venice or Genoa.

exchanges.speaker: benedetto_fregoso
exchanges.text: The Defensor speaks truth. I have made fortunes by moving first—buying cargoes others thought too risky, opening routes others feared to sail. The Fregoso will not wait.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: I stood in the Hippodrome this morning. I heard your speech. I saw something I have not seen in this city in all my decades here. I saw hope. Real hope. Marco Contarini will invest. I will buy property under this new law.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Constantinople welcomed you when you were refugees from the Fall of Rome. She sheltered you when barbarians overran your homelands. Now she asks you to believe in her again—to help her rise from the ashes as she once helped your ancestors rise.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: We will stand with you, Your Imperial Majesty. We will stand with the Defensor. Ten days for judicial proposals. And in those ten days, many of us will be examining properties, consulting lawyers, making decisions.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You have done something remarkable today, Defensor. The muster, the volunteers, and now this—the merchants committing their gold to our cause. A week ago I signed your decree because I had no choice. Today I am beginning to think I signed it because it was right.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the Italian merchants' concerns about judicial appointments and security guarantees. He establishes merit-based selection allowing small cities to propose candidates, and responds to fears about Ottoman threat by speaking of investment risks and personal commitment. The merchants, led by Contarini, are convinced by Juan's presence of family in the city and commit to investing in property and citizenship under the new legal system.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They gather in the war council chamber as the last light fades—the men who will hold Constantinople after you leave, and the Emperor who must lead them. Present: The Emperor John VIII sits at the head of the table, no longer the hesitant prisoner of a week ago. Sphrantzes stands at the Emperor's right hand, his injured arm still in its sling but his mind sharp as ever. The eldest Raoul represents the military. Kantakouzenos the Strategos sits across from Raoul. Lord Bryennios represents the committed noble houses. The Doukas patriarch—old, grey-bearded, leaning on his cane—has been invited as well. Captain Fernán stands near the door, representing the Castilian forces.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Defensor. You called this council. You are leaving in a few days, and we must ensure that what you have built does not crumble in your absence. Tell us what you need from us. And tell us what we can expect from you—from Rhodes, from Naples, from the broader alliance you are forging.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My main concern is the Sultan's response now that we have signed the decree and I am named defensor. The coming two years will be critical and we will be at our most vulnerable yet. What is our current arrangement with the Sultan? Are we at peace and can he break the peace at any time?

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Peace. We are at peace, Defensor. If you can call it that. The terms were established under my father, Manuel II, and renewed under my reign. Notaras negotiated the most recent renewal three years ago.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The arrangement has several components, Your Majesty. First: Tribute. Constantinople pays the Sultan twelve thousand hyperpyra annually. Second: Non-aggression. The Sultan agrees not to attack Constantinople directly, and we agree not to support his enemies or harbor his rebels. Third: Trade access. Ottoman merchants may trade in Constantinople. Fourth: Military restriction. We are forbidden from expanding our military forces beyond what is necessary for the defense of the walls. We have been violating the fourth provision since the day you arrived, Defensor. The Sultan knows it.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The peace—such as it is—exists because the Sultan permits it to exist. Murad II could break it tomorrow if he chose. He would claim provocation—the foreign knights, the expelled embassy, the arrest of Notaras who was his creature. The question is not whether he can break the peace. He can. The question is whether he will, and when.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: The Sultan is patient. His father Bayezid was not—he besieged this city and nearly took it, until Timur destroyed him at Ankara. Murad learned from his father's failure. He does not rush. He waits until the fruit is ripe, then plucks it. The decree you have signed, Defensor—this is a provocation Murad cannot ignore forever. The peace will hold until Murad decides it will not. And when he decides, he will not warn us. He will simply come.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: We should assume the peace is already dead, Defensor. The Sultan's ambassador saw everything—our knights drilling, our nobles committing, our people cheering in the Hippodrome. If Murad decides to attack in force before your alliance is ready, before your reinforcements arrive, before we have trained these volunteers into soldiers—we will lose.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: So we stand in violation of a peace that exists only at the Sultan's pleasure. A peace that he will break when it suits him, with whatever pretext serves his purpose. What is your counsel, Defensor? Do we continue to pay tribute—maintaining the fiction of peace while we prepare for war? Do we cease payment—openly declaring what everyone already knows? Or is there another path I do not see?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me think. The sultan has been building his forces up. He is cautious. I have met the Bey and have spoken Arabic with him. This... intrigued him. A cautious man will not commit into an action he cannot know or control. He will want to meet me and to get my measure. Setting up this meeting will buy us time. We will combine it with the paying of the tribute. With the emperor's permission, I will hand over the tribute myself and use the moment to discuss trade arrangements with the sultan now Latins aim to increase trade in the area. I will move 500 knights from Rhodes into the city as well. With the walls repaired and a strong crusader presence, cannons on the walls, a trained militia, we have a good and strong defence. Emperor, we should write the sultan that I would like to meet him near Tesalonika to discuss trade and the arrangements between the city and the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You propose to meet Murad. Personally. To hand him tribute and discuss... trade arrangements. It is audacious. The Sultan does not meet with foreign kings casually. But you are not me. You are not Byzantine. You are something Murad has never encountered—a Latin king who speaks Arabic, who completed the Reconquista, who arrived in Constantinople uninvited and turned everything upside down. You may be right that curiosity alone would draw him to such a meeting.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Defensor, I must counsel against this. You are the linchpin of everything we are building. If you ride to meet the Sultan and he decides to take you prisoner—or worse—the alliance collapses. Thessalonica is Ottoman territory. You would be placing yourself entirely in his power. What guarantees could possibly be sufficient?

encounters.recap: In a war council at Blachernae Palace, Juan proposes a diplomatic gambit to buy time for Constantinople's defenses. Learning that the city pays tribute to Sultan Murad II under a fragile peace agreement already violated by his arrival, Juan suggests personally delivering the tribute and requesting a meeting near Thessalonica to discuss trade arrangements. The proposal divides the council—the Emperor sees potential in Juan's unique position, while Kantakouzenos warns of the extreme risk of placing their defender in Ottoman hands.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: But you are not me. You are not Byzantine. You are something Murad has never encountered—a Latin king who speaks Arabic, who completed the Reconquista, who arrived in Constantinople uninvited and turned everything upside down. You may be right that curiosity alone would draw him to such a meeting. The Sultan collects unusual things—scholars, artists, warriors who interest him. You would certainly... interest him.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Defensor, I must counsel against this. You are the linchpin of everything we are building. If you ride to meet the Sultan and he decides to take you prisoner—or worse—the alliance collapses. The coalition falls apart. Constantinople loses its defender before the defense has even begun. Thessalonica is Ottoman territory. You would be placing yourself entirely in his power. What guarantees could possibly be sufficient? The Sultan's word? Ottoman promises have weight only when Ottoman interests align with them.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos speaks as a soldier. Let me speak as one who has watched Ottoman politics for sixty years. The Sultan does not take hostages lightly. It is... crude. Beneath him. Murad styles himself as a cultured ruler, a patron of poetry and learning, a man who honors the forms of civilization even as he conquers. If the Defensor requests a meeting under safe conduct, and Murad grants it, he will honor that conduct. Not from virtue—from pride.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: If such a meeting were to occur, Your Majesty, the arrangements would need to be precise. Safe conduct guaranteed in writing, with specific terms. The meeting location—Thessalonica is Ottoman, yes, but there are neutral grounds that might serve. A ship in the harbor, perhaps, where neither party is fully on the other's territory. The tribute would need to be prepared—twelve thousand hyperpyra, properly counted and documented.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: Five hundred knights from Rhodes. Added to the garrison we have now, plus the volunteers we're training, plus the noble levies... Perhaps eight hundred Castilian knights total in the city. Seventy Tagmata. Three hundred noble household troops. Two hundred militia volunteers—untrained yet, but bodies on the walls. It is not enough to defeat an Ottoman army in the field. But behind these walls, with cannons and crossbows? We could hold for months. You promise reinforcements if siege begins. How many? How quickly?

exchanges.speaker: bryennios
exchanges.text: The noble houses have committed based on faith in this alliance. Faith in you, Defensor. If you leave Constantinople and meet with the Sultan, there will be whispers. Some will say you are negotiating behind our backs. Others will say you are abandoning us. Make clear that you go to buy time for the city, not to sell it.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. You propose to ride into Ottoman territory with... how many men? A handful of guards? This is not like your other risks. In battle, skill and courage matter. In the Sultan's camp, you are entirely at his mercy. The Queen is with child. The Princess depends on her father. Castile needs its king.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: The Defensor has proposed a course of action. We have heard concerns and support. First: You will request a meeting with Sultan Murad near Thessalonica, under safe conduct, to deliver tribute and discuss trade arrangements. Second: You will transfer five hundred knights from Rhodes to Constantinople. Third: You will proceed to Naples after the meeting to secure that kingdom and prepare a relief force. Is this accurate? And what timeline do you envision?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Many concerns are raised. And I have promised to be cautious with my life. Too much depends on me indeed. I still want to meet him, but on neutral grounds. I will not surrender myself into his care and hospitality. Muslims have violated the flag of truce against me before and I have remembered. Even one year should be enough to at least secure us against him just taking the city. How about the other concerns of the Sultan? He has an internal conflict with his Jannisaries? And how about his enemies in Karaman?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The Janissaries—the Sultan's elite infantry, drawn from the devshirme—are a double-edged sword. They are the finest soldiers in the world. They are also increasingly... political. They expect conquest. Plunder. Glory. A Sultan who keeps them idle too long finds them restless, demanding, dangerous. The Karamanids—Ibrahim Bey rules there. He is Murad's most persistent enemy. Every time the Sultan turns his attention west, Ibrahim Bey raids his eastern borders.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: The Karamanids have fought the Ottomans for generations. Every time the Sultan marches east to crush him, Ibrahim retreats into the mountains and waits. It is an endless dance. There is one more factor the Sultan must consider. The memory of Timur. Thirty-two years ago, Timur the Lame destroyed the Ottoman army at Ankara. Captured Sultan Bayezid. Shattered the empire into civil war.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: So the Sultan faces pressure from Janissaries demanding conquest. Threat from Karaman in the east. Threat from Hungary in the north. Uncertain vassals in Serbia and Wallachia. Venetian hostility at sea. And the memory of catastrophic defeat within living memory. This is why your strategy of buying time makes sense, Defensor.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You propose to meet the Sultan, Defensor. To take his measure, as he takes yours. To buy time through diplomacy while we strengthen our defenses. But what you have just heard suggests another possibility. Not merely buying time—but building pressure. Coordinating with Karaman. Encouraging Hungary. Is that your intention? Not just to delay the storm, but to create conditions where the storm never comes?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me more about the events leading up to the taking of Tessaloniki. Why was this not a roll of the dice for him? Why was he so secure he was able to just take it?

encounters.recap: The war council debates Juan's proposal to meet Sultan Murad under safe conduct. Concerns about the king's safety are weighed against strategic advantages. The discussion reveals Ottoman vulnerabilities: Janissary pressure for conquest, threats from Karaman and Hungary, uncertain Balkan vassals, and the memory of Timur's devastating victory. Juan insists on neutral meeting grounds and asks about Ottoman strategic calculations regarding recent conquests.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Strategos's face darkens at the question. This wound is fresh—only four years old—and it still bleeds.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Thessalonica. Yes. Let me tell you how we lost the second city of the Empire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the map, his finger tracing the Aegean coast to the great city in Macedonia. The city was dying long before it fell. Ottoman territory surrounded it on all sides. Trade was strangled. The population dwindled—from perhaps a hundred thousand in its glory days to perhaps forty thousand when the end came.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: In 1423, the Despot Andronikos—His Imperial Majesty's brother—made a decision. Thessalonica could not be held. The Empire could not defend it. So he sold it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sold it?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: To Venice. For fifty thousand ducats and a promise of protection. The Republic took possession. Venetian governors, Venetian garrisons, Venetian flags on the walls. They believed they could hold what we could not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes takes over, the diplomatic dimensions his expertise.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Venice calculated that Murad would not risk war with a major naval power over a single city. They had treaties with the Sultan. They had trade agreements. They believed their fleet made them untouchable—that Murad would accept Venetian Thessalonica as he accepted Venetian Crete, Venetian Cyprus, Venetian colonies throughout the Aegean. They miscalculated.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Murad spent years preparing. Not rushing. Not gambling. Preparing. First: He secured his eastern frontier. Campaigns against Karaman, truces with other Anatolian powers. When he moved against Thessalonica, his back was protected. Second: He neutralized Hungary. Sigismund was distracted—the Hussite wars in Bohemia consumed his attention. Murad knew the Hungarians would not march south to save a Venetian city. Third: He isolated Venice diplomatically. Genoa would not help their rival. The Pope called for crusade, but no crusade came. Florence, Milan, Naples—none would risk war with the Ottomans for Venetian interests. Fourth: He built overwhelming force. When he finally moved, he brought perhaps fifty thousand men. The Venetian garrison numbered perhaps fifteen hundred. The walls were strong, but walls need defenders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Doukas patriarch speaks, his old voice heavy with memory.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: I had contacts in the city. Merchants who sent letters until the end. Let me tell you what they described. The siege began in March of 1430. Murad offered terms—surrender peacefully, and the population would be spared. The Venetian governor refused. He was waiting for relief. Relief that never came. Venice sent nothing. A few ships, a few hundred men—gestures, not reinforcements. The Senate debated while Thessalonica burned. They calculated the cost of war against the Ottoman Empire, weighed it against the value of a single city, and decided... to wait.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The city fell on the twenty-ninth of March. The walls were breached. The Ottomans poured through. What followed...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Raoul finishes for him, soldier to soldier.

exchanges.speaker: raoul
exchanges.text: What followed was what always follows when a city falls by storm. Three days of sack. The population killed or enslaved—perhaps seven thousand taken in chains. Churches converted to mosques. The city gutted. The massacre was deliberate. A message. This is what happens to cities that resist. This is what happens when you trust Latin promises of protection.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You ask why Murad was so secure, Defensor. Why taking Thessalonica was not a gamble. Because he ensured it would not be. He waited until every factor favored him. Until his enemies were distracted, divided, unwilling to act. Until Venice stood alone, and Venice's allies calculated that Thessalonica was not worth the cost of saving. That is how the Ottomans conquer. Not through reckless aggression—through patient preparation. They wait until the fruit is ripe. Until resistance seems hopeless. Until the defenders look around and realize no one is coming to help them. Constantinople has watched this pattern repeat for a century. Adrianople. Philippopolis. Sofia. Thessalonica. One by one, the cities fell—not because Ottoman armies were unstoppable, but because Christian powers would not unite to stop them.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: There is another element, Your Majesty. After Thessalonica fell, Venice sued for peace. They signed a treaty with Murad, accepting the loss, resuming trade, pretending nothing had happened. The Venetians who died defending the walls, the citizens who were enslaved, the city that burned—Venice wrote them off as acceptable losses. The trade agreements were renewed within the year. Venetian merchants were back in Ottoman ports before the ashes cooled. This is what Contarini and his colleagues remember, Defensor. This is why they hedge, why they calculate, why they speak of 'reading the currents.' They watched Venice abandon Thessalonica. They know Venice might abandon Constantinople too, if the price of loyalty becomes too high.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see. This comforts me. We only have to appear strong to him and he needs years of preparation. It is settled then. I will meet him on neutral ground. We buy time. We also send a letter to Karaman. I will handle and write the other christian monarchs myself. Anything else?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes pauses, glancing at his documents, then frowns.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Forgive me, Defensor—I misspoke earlier. Let me correct the record. The tribute established in February 1424, when the Emperor Manuel II re-established vassalage to the Ottomans after the failed rebellion—it was not twelve thousand hyperpyra. It was three hundred thousand silver coins annually. In florins, the exact amount depends on the exchange rate, which fluctuates. But roughly speaking... The Ottoman akçe trades at approximately forty to fifty per Venetian ducat. If the tribute is paid in akçe or equivalent silver, three hundred thousand coins would equal approximately six to seven thousand florins annually. However, if the Ottomans demand payment in higher-quality coinage—Venetian ducats, Florentine florins, or Byzantine gold hyperpyra at the old standard—the effective cost rises. The Sultan's treasury prefers sound money.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: In practice, we scrape together whatever we can. Gold when we have it. Silver when we don't. Sometimes we pay in goods—silks, icons, treasures from the churches. The Sultan cares only that the tribute arrives. How we bleed ourselves to gather it is our problem.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Three hundred thousand silver coins. Six or seven thousand florins. Call it what you will—it is the price of our survival. The cost of the Sultan's patience. When my father signed that treaty in 1424, we had just failed to overthrow Murad with a pretender. Our armies were broken. Thessalonica was lost. We had nothing left to bargain with except submission. That tribute has been paid every year since. Even when it meant melting church plate. Even when it meant the Emperor's own household going without. We pay, because the alternative is annihilation. You would pay our tribute, Defensor? Take on this burden that has crushed us for a decade? I should refuse, for pride's sake. This is our obligation, our humiliation. But pride is a luxury we cannot afford. If you would carry this weight, even for a time, while we rebuild... I would accept. And I would not forget.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I could indeed pay the tribute myself without blinking as you say. But I own no property in Constantinople. Hold no title. And the defensor is a great honour and obligation but yields me no income. I gladly fulfill it, that is not the issue. But the bull of the choice grants me no taxation rights. The treasuries of Byzantium and Castille are kept separate. What is it that you propose exactly?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room shifts uncomfortably. You have asked the question that everyone has been carefully avoiding—the question of who pays for all of this. The Emperor's face flushes slightly. Sphrantzes suddenly becomes very interested in his documents. Raoul and Kantakouzenos exchange glances. Even the Doukas patriarch looks away.

encounters.recap: Juan learns the devastating history of Thessalonica's fall to Murad II in 1430—how Ottoman patience and preparation succeeded against Venetian miscalculation and Christian disunity. The discussion turns to Constantinople's annual tribute of 300,000 silver coins (6-7,000 florins) to the Sultan. When Juan asks specifically who will pay for the defense preparations, the council falls into uncomfortable silence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room shifts uncomfortably. You have asked the question that everyone has been carefully avoiding—the question of who pays for all of this. The Emperor's face flushes slightly. Sphrantzes suddenly becomes very interested in his documents. Raoul and Kantakouzenos exchange glances. Even the Doukas patriarch looks away.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You are correct, Defensor. The treasuries are separate. The decree grants you authority over defense, not revenue. You hold no title that yields income from Byzantine lands. And yet you have spent—how much? Sphrantzes, what has the Defensor expended since his arrival?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The wall repairs: approximately eight thousand florins. The Hippodrome races: three hundred twenty florins. Supplies for the Castilian garrison: ongoing, perhaps two thousand florins thus far. Equipment for the new volunteers: not yet tallied, but the stipends alone for forty days of training will cost twenty-five hundred florins. In total, Your Imperial Majesty, the Defensor has spent approximately fifteen thousand florins on Constantinople's behalf since his arrival. Perhaps more.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_doukas
exchanges.text: Let us speak plainly, since the Defensor has done us the courtesy of plain speech. The Byzantine treasury is empty. Not metaphorically empty—actually empty. The tribute to the Sultan consumes what little revenue remains. We have been living on the Defensor's charity since the day he arrived. We have pretended otherwise—called it alliance, called it crusade, called it Christian duty. But the truth is simpler: we cannot afford to save ourselves. Without Castilian gold, there is no restoration. There is only slow death.

exchanges.speaker: ioannes_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: The forces we have assembled—the volunteers, the noble commitments, the defensive preparations—all of it depends on Castilian gold. If that gold stops flowing, the army dissolves. You ask what we propose. I will tell you what we need: a formal arrangement. Not charity that might end at any moment, but a structure. Revenue that the defense can rely upon.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: There are precedents, Your Majesty. Grants of revenue. The Emperor could assign specific revenues to the Defensor. Loans with security. Joint administration. Imperial title with revenue. Each option has advantages and complications. But all of them would transform the current arrangement from informal generosity into something structured. Something sustainable.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You have given us everything, Defensor. Your knights. Your gold. Your counsel. Your very presence, which has transformed this city more than any sum of money could. And we have given you... a title. Words on parchment. Authority over an empire that cannot pay its own soldiers. What do you propose, Defensor? Name your terms. Within reason, I will accept them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We could merge the treasuries, make it a joint administration for as long as I hold the title of Defensor. This also grants me the ability to reform the income streams of the city. The city requires investment of 50,000 florins annually, which I can provide from Castille. Secondly, we apply the law where everyone fights and everyone contributes. I have provided more than 900 knights. My contribution would dwarf those of anyone else. So I propose that my contributions are recognized for now, but that I make no claim on a title. We retake Thrace first and those titles should go to the Greek nobles who have pledged themselves. Later, as we take even more lands, I can take titles for myself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room absorbs your words. You have just offered fifty thousand florins annually—more than seven times the tribute paid to the Sultan—and asked for nothing immediate in return. The Emperor stares at you. Sphrantzes has stopped writing, his quill suspended in mid-air.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Fifty thousand florins. Annually. Do you understand what that sum means to us, Defensor? The entire imperial revenue amounts to perhaps twenty thousand florins, at generous exchange. You are offering to more than triple our resources. And you ask for no titles. You defer your claims so that Greek nobles can receive the lands of Thrace first. What you propose is... unprecedented.

exchanges.speaker: constantine_doukas
exchanges.text: I have lived eighty-two years, Defensor. I have served four Emperors. In all those years, I have never seen a Latin offer what you have just offered. You offer fifty thousand florins a year and ask for titles later. You defer your own claims so that Greek houses can receive Thrace first. When the nobles hear of this—when they learn that the Defensor has put their interests before his own—you will have their loyalty. House Doukas accepts this arrangement.

exchanges.speaker: philippe_raoul
exchanges.text: Fifty thousand florins funds an army. A real army. You understand that with this commitment, we could field five thousand men within two years. Ten thousand within five. Enough to not merely defend Constantinople, but to retake territory. To actually achieve the Apokatastasis.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: The proposal is accepted. Let it be recorded: the treasuries of Byzantium and Castile shall be administered jointly for matters pertaining to defense and restoration. The Defensor shall have authority to reform revenue collection. Castile commits fifty thousand florins annually to the Apokatastasis. This is more than an alliance, Defensor. This is partnership. True partnership, between equals who trust each other.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a revolutionary financial arrangement: joint treasury administration with Castile providing 50,000 florins annually, while deferring his own territorial claims so Greek nobles can receive the first Thracian titles. The Byzantine leadership, stunned by the generosity and unprecedented nature of the offer, unanimously accepts the proposal, recognizing it as the foundation for true restoration rather than mere survival.

roll.outcome: Acceptance with Conditions: Formal Safeguards. The Doukas patriarch speaks for the nobles: 'We accept. But we require certain assurances in writing.' The conditions are reasonable: formal documentation of the arrangement, clear accounting procedures, explicit commitment that Thracian titles go to Greeks first, provisions for what happens if the Defensor title ends. The Emperor adds: 'And I wish it understood that this arrangement exists because you offered it generously—not because we had no choice. Let the records show that Byzantium accepted partnership, not subjugation.' Pride preserved through careful language. Substance accepted.

encounters.recap: The Byzantine council evaluates Juan's extraordinary treasury proposal offering 50,000 florins annually and joint administration while deferring his own territorial claims. Rolling for their reaction, the council accepts with formal conditions—they want written safeguards and explicit documentation that preserves Byzantine dignity, but they embrace the substance of the partnership.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room is not silent. There is a murmur—glances exchanged between nobles, between the Emperor and Sphrantzes, between military men who understand resources and politicians who understand implications.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: We accept, Defensor. But we require certain assurances. In writing. Inscribed formally, witnessed, sealed with both imperial and Castilian authority.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: First: The joint treasury arrangement must be documented precisely. What Castile contributes. What Byzantium contributes. How expenditures are approved. How accounts are kept. I will not have future generations accuse us of selling the Empire because we failed to keep proper records.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Second: The commitment that Thracian titles go to Greek houses first—this cannot be merely spoken. It must be inscribed in a formal decree, signed by both the Emperor and the Defensor, witnessed by the noble houses present. Our children must be able to point to parchment and say this is what was promised.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: Third: Provisions for what happens if circumstances change. If the Defensor title ends. If—God forbid—you should fall in battle or succumb to illness. If Castile faces its own crises and cannot maintain the commitment. What then? We cannot build our restoration on foundations that might disappear.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: I accept your proposal, Defensor. The joint treasury. The reforms. The fifty thousand florins. The deferral of your claims. But I wish it understood—and recorded—that this arrangement exists because you offered it generously. Not because we had no choice. Not because Byzantium surrendered to necessity. But because a King of Castile extended partnership, and an Emperor of the Romans accepted it as an equal.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Let the records show that this was alliance, not subjugation. That Constantinople chose this path freely, recognizing honor when it was offered. That the Roman Empire retains its sovereignty, its dignity, its ancient rights—and adds to them the friendship of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The terms the Doukas patriarch describes are entirely reasonable, Your Majesty. They protect both parties and ensure the arrangement can survive changes in circumstance. I propose: a formal charter establishing the joint treasury arrangement, with detailed provisions for contribution, expenditure, and accounting. A separate decree confirming the priority of Greek houses for Thracian titles. And a third document—perhaps appended to the charter—addressing succession of the arrangement should the Defensor title change hands or terminate.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: If the Defensor falls, what happens to the Castilian knights? The garrison? The military commitments? I do not doubt Alfonso of Aragon's honor. But Aragon has its own wars, its own concerns. Naples is contested. Sicily requires defense. If you die, will your cousin truly send another thousand knights to Constantinople? Or will he recall what remains and focus on Iberian and Italian matters?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I want to make a few clarifications. My treasury currently has an annual surplus of around 50,000 florins, maybe more if I halt other projects. The 50,000 contribution should not be set in stone, just the treasuries should merge so that a surplus in Castile can be used to invest here. But if there is a crisis or disaster in Castile, I must maybe reduce this temporarily. So the 50,000 should not be set in stone. I will probably spend more than 50,000 the coming years as investment is needed the most.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I can make it so that Castile contributes 1000 knights to the Apokatastasis. That way, even if I die, my successors are bound by this obligation. I will sail to Alfonso soon and I will discuss these matters at length.

exchanges.speaker: sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I understand, Your Majesty. The commitment is not a fixed sum but a principle—that Castilian surplus flows to the Apokatastasis as circumstances permit. More in good years, less if crisis strikes. Flexibility rather than rigid obligation. We might inscribe it thus: The Kingdom of Castile commits to contribute its treasury surplus to the joint fund for the Apokatastasis, with the understanding that such contribution shall vary according to the resources available.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You could have promised fifty thousand in perpetuity and let your successors deal with the impossibility. Many kings would. Instead, you name the truth: that commitment must be real to be meaningful, and real commitment acknowledges uncertainty.

roll.outcome: Acceptance with conditions. The Deliberation

encounters.recap: The Byzantine council accepts Juan's treasury and military proposals but demands written documentation with specific conditions: precise treasury arrangements, formal Thracian land reservation for Greeks, and succession provisions. Juan clarifies that Castilian contributions should be flexible based on surplus rather than fixed amounts, and proposes binding Castile to provide 1000 knights regardless of leadership changes.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I understand, Your Majesty. The commitment is not a fixed sum but a principle—that Castilian surplus flows to the Apokatastasis as circumstances permit. More in good years, less if crisis strikes. Flexibility rather than rigid obligation.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: We might inscribe it thus: The Kingdom of Castile commits to contribute its treasury surplus to the joint fund for the Apokatastasis, with the understanding that such contribution shall vary according to the resources available. In years of plenty, the contribution shall be generous. In years of hardship, the contribution may be reduced as necessity demands, without breach of the arrangement.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: This is honest language. It acknowledges reality—that no kingdom can promise fixed sums regardless of circumstance. Droughts, plagues, wars—these things happen. A commitment that cannot bend will break instead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: John VIII's expression shifts—not disappointment at the flexibility, but something like respect.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You could have promised fifty thousand in perpetuity and let your successors deal with the impossibility. Many kings would. Instead, you name the truth: that commitment must be real to be meaningful, and real commitment acknowledges uncertainty.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: This is wiser than a rigid promise. I have seen treaties built on fixed obligations that became chains around the necks of those who signed them. When the obligation could not be met, the entire arrangement collapsed in acrimony and accusation. Flexibility preserved in writing is better than rigidity that breeds resentment. Document the principle. Trust the good faith.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: One thousand knights. Committed to the Apokatastasis. Binding on your successors. Defensor, do you understand what you are offering? One thousand Castilian knights is not a garrison—it is an army. It is more heavy cavalry than the Sultan can field from any single province.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: With one thousand knights as the core, supported by Byzantine infantry and the themata militia we are training... we would have perhaps three thousand effective soldiers within two years. Five thousand within five years, if recruitment continues. That is enough to not merely defend Constantinople. That is enough to campaign. To retake the Thracian fortresses.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty, one thousand knights is an enormous commitment. The cost alone—wages, equipment, horses, supplies—must be twenty thousand florins a year? More? If this obligation binds your successors, it binds Castile to Constantinople for generations. Are you certain, Defensor? Once inscribed, this cannot easily be undone.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: You said you will sail to Alfonso soon. Alfonso is King of Aragon. He is not King of Castile. These commitments you make—they bind Castile and León, your kingdoms. But until you inherit, Aragon's resources are Alfonso's to command, not yours. When you meet him, what will you ask of him? And what authority do you have to promise his cooperation before he has agreed?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: If I understand correctly, Your Majesty, the arrangement has two parts. First: commitments that bind Castile and León immediately. The merged treasury. The contribution of surplus. The thousand knights as ongoing obligation. Second: the regency provision naming Alfonso. This is a statement of Castilian succession law—that if you die before Fernando comes of age, Alfonso serves as regent. But Alfonso himself—his own kingdoms of Aragon, Sicily, Sardinia—those are not bound by this arrangement unless he chooses to bind them. Is this the correct understanding?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will go to Alfonso in a few days and will seek to include Naples and Aragon into this arrangement as well. How exactly, I shall have to discuss with him. But rest assured that I will make sure our interests are represented.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor nods, accepting your assurance.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii
exchanges.text: Then we shall await the results of your discussions with Alfonso. The framework is clear—Castile commits now, and you will seek to expand the arrangement to include Aragon and Naples.

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Draft the documents based on what we have agreed tonight. The treasury merger, with flexible contribution. The Thracian reservation for Greek houses. The succession provisions naming Alfonso as regent. The commitment of Military Order forces to the Apokatastasis.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes, can you draft the two documents right now regarding both the Thrace grants and the treasury arrangements? Or do you need more clarifications?

exchanges.speaker: george_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: For the treasury arrangement, I believe I have sufficient clarity, Your Majesty. For the Thracian grants, I have one question. You said no Latin shall receive lands in Thrace. But what of Latins who elect Roman citizenship under the Chrysobull of the Choice? Are they considered Latin or Roman for purposes of this reservation?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For the purpose of this reservations they are considered latins. The point is to give the original Byzantines lands and men again. After that, we shall divide open titles evenly and fairly. Include that after Thracian conquest, Greeks may sell titles to latins no problem. It concerns only the initial distribution that is covered.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Sphrantzes works in focused silence, drafting both documents. After nearly an hour, he presents them for review and approval.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. I sign them and ask the emperor to do the same. Now, lets look at the treasury. What revenue and expenses does the empire have right now?

encounters.recap: Juan and Emperor John VIII finalize the treasury merger agreement and Thracian land reservation. The arrangements include flexible Castilian financial contributions, commitment of 1000 military order knights to Constantinople, succession provisions naming Alfonso as regent, and exclusive Greek rights to initial Thracian land grants. Both documents are drafted and signed.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: I have attempted to capture all the elements we discussed. The flexible contribution, the reserved imperial expenditures, your authority to reform revenues, the military commitment, the succession provisions naming Alfonso as regent, and the language permitting future modification of the arrangement. Does it accord with your intentions?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Great. I sign them and ask the emperor to do the same. Now, lets look at the treasury. What revenue and expenses does the empire have right now?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You and the Emperor affix your signatures to both documents—the Decree of Thracian Reservation and the Charter of Joint Treasury Administration. Sphrantzes melts wax, applies the imperial seal, and the witnesses sign in turn. The Doukas patriarch's hand trembles slightly as he writes—age, but also emotion at what he is witnessing.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: It is done. The treasuries are joined. The restoration has a foundation.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The Byzantine finances, Your Majesty. I shall be blunt, as the situation demands honesty. Our annual revenues amount to approximately five thousand two hundred florins. Perhaps sixty thousand hyperpyra at current exchange. This comes from customs—what little the Genoese leave us—land taxes on our remaining Thracian farms, market fees, harbor dues, and miscellaneous imperial income.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: Our annual expenses—even at the reduced level we have maintained—amount to nearly twelve thousand florins. The Ottoman tribute alone consumes seven thousand. The imperial household, the Tagmata, the wall garrison, the bureaucracy, the Patriarchate—even stripped to the bone, these require another five thousand.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: We have been running a deficit of approximately six to seven thousand florins annually for years. We survive by pawning relics, selling offices, borrowing from Italian merchants at ruinous rates, and allowing everything—walls, roads, buildings—to decay.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: For comparison: the Genoese at Galata—across the Golden Horn, within sight of the imperial palace—collect sixteen thousand florins annually from customs alone. Three times our entire revenue. They control eighty-seven percent of all trade through the Bosphorus. We collect thirteen percent.

exchanges.speaker: doukas_patriarch
exchanges.text: My grandfather remembered when the kommerkion collected twenty thousand hyperpyra per day. Now we collect that much in a year.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: This is why your commitment transforms everything, Defensor. You speak of fifty thousand florins annually—sometimes more. Combined with our five thousand, this creates resources of fifty-five thousand florins or more. That is a tenfold increase in available funds. For the first time in generations, we could properly man the walls. Train soldiers. Cast cannons. Repair fortifications. Pay the Ottoman tribute without bleeding the city dry. Even begin to restore what has decayed.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think I understand your desperation even better now. Looking at these numbers makes me sad. Fernan, transfer the treasury of 60,000 florins to the combined treasury immediately. We have spent some on wall repair already and while I had intended the rest for that purpose as well, this is an emergency we must address immediately. No one has to fear that his wages will not be paid anymore. The treasury is now well-funded.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me, the latins receive many revenues. Why can they collect so much? Is it tariffs from their own trade? Can we not consolidate these revenues into the combined treasury as well? Or are these revenues property of Venice, Genoa and the other latins?

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: The Latin revenues, Your Majesty, are... complicated. The Genoese at Galata collect customs duties on goods passing through their harbor facilities. Ships dock at Galata, unload cargo at Genoese wharves, pay tariffs to Genoese customs officials. The money never touches Byzantine hands. This is not theft—not technically. It is the result of treaties.

exchanges.speaker: georgios_sphrantzes
exchanges.text: However, Defensor—the reforms you have already enacted create new possibilities. Under the new system, Latins who elect Roman citizenship become subject to Roman taxation. They pay into our treasury, not their national quarters. If we restructure our customs—lower rates for Roman citizens, efficient administration, honest officials—merchants will choose to trade through Byzantine harbors rather than Italian ones. The revenue follows the trade.

encounters.recap: The joint treasury documents are signed and sealed, formally combining Byzantine and Castilian financial resources. Juan orders an immediate transfer of 60,000 florins to address the Empire's desperate deficit. Sphrantzes reveals the stark financial reality: Byzantine revenues of 5,200 florins against expenses of 12,000 florins, while Italian merchants collect over 20,000 florins annually from Constantinople's trade. The transfer creates a tenfold increase in available resources, transforming the Empire's financial position from desperate deficit to adequate funding for the first time in generations.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You make yourself essential to both sides. The Byzantines cannot defend themselves without you. And if Murad wants his tribute delivered reliably, he must deal with you as well. My uncle Alfonso would admire this. He has spent twenty years trying to make himself essential to everyone in Italy and has mostly made himself distrusted by all.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The theological questions. You did not answer me—are they genuine?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The questions are genuine, yes. But I want to meet him personally.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Three days, then. I will be ready.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning finds you on the Theodosian Walls, where Kantakouzenos has assembled three hundred of the new politikoi stratoitai—citizen soldiers recruited from Constantinople's guilds and neighborhoods. They drill with spears and shields in the shadow of the great towers, their movements ragged but earnest.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: Six months ago, I could not have gathered sixty. Now they come because they believe there is something worth defending. Because they have seen Western knights on their walls who did not come to loot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The imperial foundries in the Mangana district have been dormant for years—bronze too expensive, craftsmen scattered, demand nonexistent. Now, with Castilian gold and the promise of ore shipments from Trebizond and Venetian traders, Master Theodoros Kataphraktis is attempting to resurrect them.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros_kataphraktis
exchanges.text: If the ore arrives as promised, Domine, we can cast two small bombards by autumn. Perhaps four by spring. We have the knowledge. What we lack is tin for proper bronze. The Venetians control the trade and their prices...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the courtyard of the old Boukoleon Palace, now serving as a mustering ground, you observe the men who have answered the call to reconstitute the themata—the ancient Byzantine military districts. The numbers are modest but real: 847 men have registered since the Chrysobull of the Choice was proclaimed.

exchanges.speaker: raoul_the_elder
exchanges.text: They are raw, Domine. But they are ours. Not mercenaries who will flee when the gold runs short. Not Latins with their own agendas. No offense intended.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the evening of May 14th, you attend vespers in the Great Church. The Hagia Sophia swallows sound and light alike, its vast dome floating impossibly overhead, golden mosaics glittering in candlelight that seems wholly inadequate to fill such immensity. Emperor John VIII stands across the nave, surrounded by his court. When it ends, the Emperor catches your eye across the crowded nave. He inclines his head—a gesture of acknowledgment, perhaps of something more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning of May 15th, you gather the commanders of the Military Order forces in the Blachernae's great hall. 915 knights under the white banner, soon to be reduced by your departure. You will take 200 with you—your personal guard and escort for the journey to Rhodes and then Naples. The remaining 715 will stay under Don Juan de Sotomayor's command.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: And if the Sultan moves before you return, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then you hold the walls until relief arrives or until there are no walls left to hold.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Tribunal Latinorum, established by your Charter of the Latin Courts, has been operating for less than a month. You find it housed in a wing of the Blachernae, three Byzantine jurists and two Castilian legal scholars working through a growing pile of documents.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we are... the work proceeds. Perhaps not as quickly as—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The claims fall into several categories: 23 Crusader Descent Claims from Western nobles, 14 Byzantine Restoration Claims from Greek noble families, 31 New Grant Petitions from knights seeking promised lands, and 8 Disputed Claims where multiple parties claim the same territory.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios_chrysoloras
exchanges.text: The law favors documented descent. But possession... possession is also a form of right, is it not?

encounters.recap: Juan conducts final preparations before departing Constantinople, reviewing the wall militia (300 citizen soldiers), inspecting foundries for cannon production, observing the reconstituted themata forces (847 registered), attending vespers at Hagia Sophia with Emperor John VIII, giving final orders to the 915 Military Order knights (715 staying, 200 departing), and examining the Court of Claims which has processed 76 territorial petitions of various types requiring adjudication.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: The law favors documented descent. But possession... possession is also a form of right, is it not?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hangs in the air. These are the decisions that will shape whatever coalition you are building—and you will not be here to make them. The sun is setting over the Golden Horn. Tomorrow morning, the fleet sails.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks a question that has vexed Byzantine jurisprudence for two centuries. The short answer is: no, we never accepted them. The long answer is considerably more complicated.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to a map pinned to the wall—a rough sketch of Greece and the Aegean.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: When the Emperor Michael VIII Palaiologos reclaimed Constantinople in 1261, he recovered the City. But the Frankish states? Many survived. Some survive still. The Byzantine legal position has always been clear: the Latin Empire was illegitimate, born of treachery and theft. Every title granted by the Latin Emperors was therefore void from inception. The lands belong to Rome—to us—by ancient right. But reality... We could not reconquer everything. For two hundred years, Latin lords have held Greek soil, married Greek wives, ruled Greek peasants. Their grandchildren speak Greek. Some have converted to Orthodoxy. Are they usurpers? Legally, yes. Practically?

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's Tribunal must decide: Do we adjudicate based on the law as Byzantium understands it—in which case most Latin claims are void? Or based on Latin legal traditions—which recognized these grants? Or based on practical reality—whoever holds the land owns it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I want to be extremely clear. 1204 was a disaster and a mistake born of greed. To restore grants gained through this reign using the apokatastasis would be heresy. So all of the latin claims on lands that have been lost to the Ottomans will not be restored to those who stole them. This means in effect that all the ancient claims of latins are rejected. But. But we welcome their contribution to the reconquest of their homeland through the normal system, based on their contribution in men and blood.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Chrysoloras stares at you for a long moment. Then, slowly, a smile spreads across his weathered face—the smile of a man who has just heard something he thought he would never hear from a Latin king.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... Forgive me. In two hundred years, no Western lord has spoken thus of 1204. Most regard it as a glorious conquest, their ancestors' rightful prize. I will record your ruling. The Tribunal's standard is now clear: contribution, not inheritance from theft.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the stack of Crusader Descent Claims, pulling them toward him with renewed purpose. He sorts the 23 petitions into three piles.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: So. Four men who fight. Seven who hedge their bets. Twelve who dream of inheritance without effort. Under Your Majesty's ruling: the four receive consideration proportional to their contribution. The seven and twelve receive nothing unless they come themselves and bleed for what they claim. The Emperor will be... relieved. He feared you would demand restoration of Latin claims as the price of your aid. Many at court whispered this was your true purpose—to rebuild the Latin Empire under Castilian domination. This ruling says otherwise. It says: the past is past. What matters is what you do now.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What about the Greeks? Are there Greeks with a lot of big claims but without the men to back it up? Even if their claims is legitimate?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Chrysoloras's expression shifts—a flicker of discomfort. He is a Greek himself, and you have just asked him to apply the same unsparing standard to his own people that you applied to the Latins. He is silent for a moment. Then he nods slowly, respecting the question.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. There are. These families have bled for Constantinople. Some have bled for generations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the second stack—the 14 Byzantine petitions—and begins sorting with the same methodical honesty.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: The same standard, Your Majesty? Contribution before restoration?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But Notaras has been arrested on account of treason. How is his trial coming along?

encounters.recap: Juan establishes a revolutionary legal principle for the Tribunal: all territorial claims based on the Fourth Crusade are void, and restoration depends on current contribution to the reconquest, not ancient inheritance. This applies equally to Latin crusader descendants and Greek noble families, fundamentally reshaping the coalition's legal framework from inheritance to merit-based participation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice carries something complicated—pride that you would ask, discomfort at what the answer reveals, and beneath it a question: How will you judge the widow, the monk, and the fisherman who have nothing to give but what they have already lost?

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Ah. Yes. The Megas Doux. I should not have included this. The family's claims are... complicated by the trial.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: Loukas Notaras stands accused of proditio—high treason. The evidence recovered from his chambers is damning: correspondence with Ottoman officials detailing our food supplies, wall conditions, the number of defenders. Negotiations for his family's survival should the city fall.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: The trial began two days ago before a tribunal of five: two imperial judges, Lord Bryennios representing the committed noble houses, a representative of the Patriarch—who insisted on Church involvement—and Strategos Kantakouzenos representing military interests.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Chrysoloras sends a clerk running to the tribunal chambers. You continue reviewing the remaining petitions—the widow, the monk, the fisherman who bears an emperor's name—but your mind is partly elsewhere. The clerk returns within the hour, breathless.

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
exchanges.text: His Imperial Majesty was asked to confirm the sentence as required by law. The court expected... deliberation. Instead, the Emperor rose immediately. He said— 'I have lived in fear of this man for three years. I watched him control my palace, my guards, my food, my letters. I could not give an order he did not approve. I could not speak to my own subjects without his permission. And all that time, he was selling us to the Turks. The sentence is confirmed. Let it be carried out before sunset tomorrow. I will not spend another night knowing he breathes the same air as my city.'

exchanges.speaker: chrysoloras
