exchanges.text: I will teach her about castles. When she's bigger.

encounters.recap: Juan introduces two-year-old Catalina to her newborn half-sister Bianca. Despite initial suspicion about the small, red baby, Catalina's protective instincts emerge when Bianca grasps her finger, and she solemnly promises to teach her sister about building castles when she grows bigger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey has progressed well thus far. The sea crossing from Naples to Valencia passed without incident, and the royal party has been traveling overland through Castile for several days. The winter air is crisp but not bitter; the roads are passable. It is Doña Beatriz who notices first.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, Catalina has developed a cough. It started this morning—I thought it was just the cold air, but it has persisted.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: It does not seem serious. She is eating well, playing normally, no fever that I can detect. But with the infant and the Queen...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the inn's common room, playing with a wooden horse one of the soldiers carved for her. She looks up at your approach, smiles, and then coughs—a small, wet sound, followed by a sniffle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, look. It's a fast horse. Like yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She seems entirely herself—bright-eyed, energetic, unbothered by the cough that punctuates her chatter. The party is perhaps five or six days from Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Catalina! Love. For a few days you will stay with papa and we play a game that we must stay away from the baby and mama. When they come close we must run away ok? Shall we play?

roll.outcome: Minor illness affects Catalina with cough and congestion, very mild severity

encounters.recap: During the journey home to Toledo, young Catalina develops a mild cough and congestion. Though not serious, Juan takes precautionary measures to keep her separated from baby Bianca and recovering Lucia by turning isolation into a playful game.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the inn's common room, playing with a wooden horse one of the soldiers carved for her. She looks up at your approach, smiles, and then coughs—a small, wet sound, followed by a sniffle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, look. It's a fast horse. Like yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She seems entirely herself—bright-eyed, energetic, unbothered by the cough that punctuates her chatter. The party is perhaps five or six days from Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Catalina! Love. For a few days you will stay with papa and we play a game that we must stay away from the baby and mama. When they come close we must run away ok? Shall we play?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A running away game? I'm good at running! But why we run from Mama and baby? Is it like hide and seek? Do they try to find us? Do we hide?

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: I can have Catalina's things moved to the adjoining chamber, Your Majesty. She can travel in the second carriage with myself and the guards. I will keep her entertained. Shall I inform the Queen? She will worry if Catalina suddenly avoids her without explanation.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Papa. Can the horse play too? He wants to run away also.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I stay with Catalina the coming days and play to be her horse. Then we walk together to Lucia and run away the moment she moves a bit closer to us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days that follow are unlike any Juan has experienced as king. He gets down on hands and knees on the cold floor of roadside inns while Catalina clambers onto his back, shrieking with delight. The King of Castile, Defensor Romaniae, conqueror of Granada—reduced to a child's steed, complete with neighing sounds that make Catalina dissolve into giggles.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Faster, horse! Faster!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Each evening, they approach Lucia's chamber. They peek around the doorframe. Lucia sits in a chair by the fire, Bianca in her arms. She looks up, sees them, and her face softens with understanding.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Oh, there you are. I've been looking for you two—

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: RUN!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They flee down the corridor, her laughter echoing off the stone walls. Juan scoops her up and gallops away, her small arms wrapped around his neck, coughing and giggling simultaneously. Behind them, he hears Lucia's voice, warm with amusement.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I'll catch you eventually!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the third evening, Lucia catches Juan's eye from across the room while Catalina is distracted with her wooden horse. She mouths silently: Thank you. She understands. The game that keeps her daughter happy is also the game that keeps Bianca safe. By the fifth day, the cough has faded to an occasional sniffle.

encounters.recap: When Catalina develops a minor cough during the journey to Toledo, Juan creates a playful quarantine game where they pretend to run away from Lucia and baby Bianca. Over five days, Juan plays horse for his daughter while maintaining distance from the others, successfully preventing the illness from spreading to the infant while keeping Catalina entertained and happy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The towers of the Alcázar rise against a pale winter sky as the royal procession approaches the city gates. Word has traveled ahead—crowds line the streets despite the cold, cheering for the king who left to save Constantinople and returns with a new queen and a new princess. But Juan's thoughts are not on the crowds.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro de Luna waits in the great courtyard, his weathered face breaking into a rare smile as Juan dismounts. Behind him stands the household staff, the guards, the officials who have kept Castile running in his absence. And there, held in the arms of a wet nurse, is Fernando. Juan's son. Fourteen months old now. Born the day Isabel died—the son Juan has seen only once, at his baptism, when the boy was barely two months old.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando has grown. He is no longer the tiny, swaddled bundle Juan remembers. He has dark hair like his mother, and her eyes—Isabel's eyes, the same eyes Catalina carries. He looks at Juan with the open curiosity of a child encountering a stranger. Because that is what Juan is to him. A stranger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia hangs back, Bianca in her arms, understanding without being told that this moment belongs to Juan and his firstborn son. Catalina tugs at Juan's hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, who is that baby?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is your brother, mija. Fernando. Do you remember? I told you about him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina studies the boy with the same suspicious scrutiny she applied to Bianca.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He's bigger than Bianca.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He is older. He has been waiting here for us to come home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan approaches the wet nurse and she curtsies, offering Fernando to him. The boy looks uncertain, glancing back at the only caregivers he has known. His lower lip trembles. Juan takes his son in his arms for only the second time. Fernando stares at him—this large stranger with the tired eyes and the travel-worn clothes. For a long moment, neither moves. Then Fernando reaches out a small hand and touches Juan's beard, fascinated by the texture.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. That's Papa. He's nice. He's a good horse.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando blinks, processing this information. His hand remains tangled in Juan's beard. Lucia steps forward now, Bianca stirring in her arms.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Fernando. I am Lucia. I am... I am going to help take care of you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She does not say mother. She will not claim that title uninvited. But her eyes are gentle as she looks at the boy who will never know the woman who died bringing him into the world. The four of them stand together in the courtyard of the Alcázar—Juan holding Fernando, Lucia holding Bianca, Catalina clinging to Juan's leg. A family. Broken and remade. Marked by loss. But together at last.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro clears his throat softly.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Welcome home. There is much to discuss, when you are ready. But it can wait. It can wait.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Alvaro. Lets have council tomorrow. We use today to get settled in and have a meal together for the first time. I make sure we have crostata.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Toledo and meets his son Fernando for only the second time. The fourteen-month-old boy is cautious with his father, whom he barely knows. Lucia gently introduces herself as Fernando's new caretaker, while Catalina helps bridge the gap between father and son. The reunited family gathers together in the Alcázar courtyard for the first time, forming a new bond despite their complex history of loss and separation.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Welcome home. There is much to discuss, when you are ready. But it can wait. It can wait.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Alvaro. Lets have council tomorrow. We use today to get settled in and have a meal together for the first time. I make sure we have crostata.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro bows, and there is something in his eyes—relief, perhaps, or simply the satisfaction of seeing his king home safe with a family intact. He withdraws, taking the business of the kingdom with him. For one evening, Castile can wait.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The private dining chamber in the Alcázar has been prepared hastily—servants scrambling to accommodate a family that did not exist when Juan left for Constantinople. A fire roars in the hearth against the January chill. Candles cast warm light across the table. The crostata arrives as requested—a proper Italian crostata di marmellata, the pastry latticed over quince jam. The cook has done his best with an unfamiliar recipe, working from hurried instructions. It is not perfect. But when it is set before Lucia, her eyes widen.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You remembered.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You complained about Neapolitan pastries for three months. I paid attention.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I complained about everything for three months. The heat. The food. The physicians. You. This is... acceptable. The cook needs practice. But acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From her, this is high praise. Catalina sits in a chair piled with cushions to bring her to table height, attacking her portion of roast chicken with more enthusiasm than technique. Fernando, in a nurse's lap nearby, watches the proceedings with wide eyes, gnawing on a piece of soft bread. Bianca sleeps in a cradle by the fire, oblivious to it all.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Catalina, use your knife, not your fingers.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But fingers are faster.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Ladies do not— I sound like my aunt. God help me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The meal is chaos. Catalina chatters endlessly about the journey, about her horse game with Papa, about the wooden horse the soldier made her. Fernando drops his bread and wails until it is retrieved. Bianca wakes and demands feeding, and Lucia excuses herself briefly to the wet nurse. It is loud and messy and utterly without the dignity befitting a royal household. Juan cannot remember the last time he felt this content.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Later, when the children have been taken to their beds and the servants have cleared the table, Juan and Lucia sit alone by the fire. She holds a cup of wine—her first since before the pregnancy—and stares into the flames.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Toledo is colder than I expected.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You will grow accustomed to it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Mm. The Alcázar is impressive. Older than anything in Ferrara. I can feel the history in the stones. I can feel Isabel in the stones, too. Her portrait hangs in the gallery. I saw it when we entered. She was beautiful. More beautiful than I expected.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Catalina has her eyes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I am not her. I will not try to be. But I will love her children as my own, and I will build something new in this place. That is what I can offer.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan raises her hand to his lips.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is enough.

encounters.recap: Juan's new family shares their first meal together in Toledo's Alcázar. The evening is chaotic but joyful, with Italian crostata, children's chatter, and domestic warmth. Later, Lucia and Juan discuss the challenge of building a new life in the shadow of his first wife Isabel, with Lucia promising to love Isabel's children as her own while creating something new.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council gathers in the great chamber of the Alcázar. Winter light streams through tall windows, illuminating the faces of the men who have governed Castile in Juan's absence. Present: Álvaro de Luna — Royal Constable, the man who has held the kingdom together through two years of Juan's travels. He looks tired but alert, a stack of documents before him. Diego de Daza — Chief administrator of the financial reforms. His ledgers are organized with meticulous precision. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza — Head of House Mendoza, founder of the Council of Great Houses. The poet-diplomat carries himself with quiet authority. Sir Thomas Beaumont — English knight, now leading the Royal Military Academy. He sits slightly apart, the foreigner among Castilians. Archbishop Juan de Cerezuela — Archbishop of Toledo, Primate of Spain, and Álvaro's half-brother. He represents the Church's interests at court. Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles — Commander of the royal guard, present for matters of security. They rise as Juan enters and remain standing until he takes his seat at the head of the table.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. It is good to have you home. The kingdom has been stable in your absence, but there is much to report—and much that requires your decision. Where would you like to begin?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets begin with the treasury. I have commanded the assembly of an army and 15000 assembled in Palermo. Using noble levies, but I suspect there have been expenses to transport them there and to supply them. King Alfonso has been generous with his supply in goods for my army but still. How was it to organize this army and can we now review the total cost of this operation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza straightens in his chair, pulling a ledger from his stack. His methodical nature is evident in the way he organizes his papers before speaking.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the Naples expedition was... unprecedented in its logistical demands. Allow me to present the accounting as we have it. The assembly itself proceeded smoothly—Don Íñigo can speak to the military aspects. But from the treasury's perspective, the costs were substantial. Fifteen thousand men required transport from Castile to Palermo. We chartered Aragonese and Genoese vessels—King Alfonso assisted with some ships, but the bulk of the cost fell to us. Ship hire, provisioning for the voyage, replacement of horses lost at sea... King Alfonso was indeed generous with supply once the army reached Sicily and Naples. But the initial provisioning—food, fodder, ammunition, medical supplies—was borne by the crown. An army of that size consumes enormously. The levies served without direct pay, as is their feudal obligation for campaign service. However, we compensated losses—horses, equipment, men-at-arms who fell. The battle at Aversa was decisive but not without cost. In total, Your Majesty, the Naples expedition cost the crown approximately... Forty-two thousand florins. This does not include the forty thousand previously sent to King Alfonso for the Sforza contract.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Eighty-two thousand florins total committed to securing Naples for Aragón.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The treasury remains healthy, Your Majesty. But it is a significant expenditure. Shall I detail the current balances?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We live in the year of our lord 1434. Were there any other one-time expenses of note in this year so far?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza flips back several pages in his ledger, his brow furrowed in concentration.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The year 1434 has been... extraordinarily active, Your Majesty. Beyond the Naples expedition, there were several significant disbursements. The sixty thousand florins pledged for the wall repairs and the joint treasury with the Byzantine Empire. This was transferred before Your Majesty departed Constantinople. Two thousand florins granted to the Knights of Saint John for the purchase of properties in Constantinople. The perpetual endowment continues to disburse annually—this year approximately three hundred florins in dowries were distributed on the third of August, as established. There may be expenses Your Majesty committed abroad that have not yet reached our records. The Military Orders, for instance—we received instructions to increase the Constantinople garrison to one thousand men and establish permanent commanderies. The Masters have written asking about crown support for this expansion.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The Royal Military Academy also continues its operations—Sir Thomas can speak to those costs if needed.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, if there are other commitments made during your travels that I should account for, I would be grateful to know them now, so the treasury records remain accurate.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The orders have their own income and revenue streams and will pay for the expansion themselves. If they need support, they can petition the emperor who has a treasury large enough to accomodate them. He will not fall short. The other expenses have already been paid no? The dote de la reina Isabel has been paid as one lump sum if I am not mistaken. The 2000 for the knights of rhodes will likewise be paid from the treasury in Constantinople. As far as I can tell, the only real one time expense we have is the campain in Naples and the journey to Constantinople. But we have ships of our own so we only would have to pay for supplies and the normal wages for the crew.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza pauses, then nods slowly, a flush of embarrassment creeping up his neck.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is correct. I apologize for the confusion. La Dote de la Reina Isabel—yes, the twenty-five thousand florins was established as a perpetual endowment. The annual disbursements come from the endowment's own returns, not from crown funds. I misspoke. And the Constantinople expenditures—the sixty thousand for the walls, the two thousand for Rhodes—these were drawn from the crusade treasury, which Your Majesty transferred to the joint administration with the Emperor. That is Byzantine-Castilian money now, not crown revenue. So, to correct myself: the true one-time burden on the Castilian crown treasury for 1434 is the Naples expedition—forty-two thousand florins in transport, supply, and compensation, plus the forty thousand sent earlier for the Sforza contract. Eighty-two thousand total for Naples. Journey costs for the royal fleet—supplies, crew wages, port fees—perhaps another three to four thousand florins over the course of the year. Approximately eighty-five to eighty-six thousand florins in extraordinary expenses, Your Majesty. The crown treasury can bear this, but it is not insignificant.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The 40000 was already spent in 1433.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes his full council to review treasury expenses from 1434. Diego de Daza presents the accounting for the Naples expedition, initially conflating different funding sources before Juan corrects him. The actual crown expenditure was 42,000 florins for the Naples campaign plus 3-4,000 florins for royal fleet operations, clarifying that other expenses were drawn from separate endowments and the Constantinople joint treasury.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty raises a fair point. The situation in Granada has changed substantially since the conquest. In the first year, eleven thousand men were necessary. The population was uncertain, pockets of resistance remained in the mountains, and the new lords had not yet established their authority. We needed overwhelming presence to prevent rebellion before it could begin. Now? The Military Orders hold their commanderies and have brought their own men. The new lords have settled their estates and raised local levies. The Moorish population that remained has largely accepted the new order—those who would not have fled to North Africa or the mountains, and the mountain bandits are a matter for local forces, not crown troops.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: Garrison duty rots soldiers, Your Majesty. Men who sit in conquered cities grow soft and resentful. The best of them would rather be training at the Academy or serving where there is purpose.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The question is not whether we need eleven thousand men in Granada. We do not. The question is how many we should retain, and what becomes of the rest. Some can be disbanded—returned to their homes. Some can be retained as a reduced garrison, perhaps two or three thousand, to maintain crown presence and respond to any local troubles. And some might be repositioned for other purposes. The Constantinople commitment, perhaps. Or held in reserve for future needs.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Eleven thousand troops at the rates we pay costs the crown nearly twenty-six thousand florins annually. Reducing to three thousand would save approximately seventeen thousand florins per year.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can the governor of Granada not handle this with his own forces? I would rather give out titles then pay men to hold a fort.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Don García López de Padilla is Master of the Order of Calatrava. He commands the Order's own forces—several hundred knights and men-at-arms. And the Order now holds substantial commanderies in Granada, as do Santiago and Alcántara. The three Military Orders together maintain perhaps fifteen hundred to two thousand men in their Granadan holdings. The new lords—those who received grants for their service in the crusade—owe feudal levies. If summoned, they could raise another two to three thousand from their estates.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's instinct is sound. The purpose of granting titles and lands is precisely this—the lord defends what is his. If we pay crown soldiers to do what the lords should do themselves, we teach them that the crown will bear their burdens. There is one consideration, Your Majesty. A small crown presence—perhaps a few hundred men, a royal banner in Granada city—reminds both the new lords and the remaining Moorish population that the king's eye is upon them. Not enough to do the lords' work for them. Enough to show that Granada remains part of Castile, not a collection of independent fiefdoms. Perhaps five hundred men?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Twelve hundred florins. Perhaps fifteen hundred with officers and maintenance.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will keep the Alhambra for crown purposes and will house 50 soldiers there along with a staff of tax assessors and a few crown marshalls. The rest of the defence of these lands will fall to the new local lords. If there is a rebellion, we will crush it. And one other matter. I have now appointed a governor but I have not given the title of duke of Granada to anyone. What will change if I give the title away? Will this affect my revenue?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, much depends on how the title is granted and what rights accompany it. There are several possibilities. The title of Duke of Granada could be granted as an honor only—prestige, precedence at court, a seat on the Council of Great Houses. But the crown retains direct administration, direct taxation, direct authority. The duke is duke in name; the king rules in fact. This costs nothing and changes little. But it is also... a thin gift. Men know the difference between a title with teeth and a title without. Alternatively, you could create a true duchy—the duke holds Granada as his domain. He collects taxes, administers justice, raises levies. He owes the crown feudal service and perhaps a fixed annual payment, but the day-to-day revenues are his.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: This is how the great duchies of France operate. The Duke of Burgundy, the Duke of Brittany—they are near-kings in their own lands.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And therein lies the danger. A Duke of Granada with full rights commands the wealthiest, most fertile territory in Castile outside the heartland. He has ports, trade, a defensible position. Give this to the wrong man, and you create a rival. Give it to the right man... And you still create someone powerful enough to be a rival to his grandchildren, if not to you.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The revenue implications would be substantial, Your Majesty. Granada's contribution to crown revenues—including Málaga customs, the alcabala from trade, agricultural taxes—is perhaps thirty to forty thousand florins annually once fully integrated. If a duke takes this, the crown loses it, save for whatever fixed payment is negotiated.

exchanges.speaker: cerezuela
exchanges.text: There is a middle path. The duke receives certain estates, certain rights, certain revenues—but not all of Granada. The crown retains the major cities, the ports, the customs. The duke holds rural lands and the obligation to defend them.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This is how Your Majesty has already distributed much of Granada—to the Military Orders, to crusade veterans. A Duke of Granada could be first among these lords, with authority to coordinate defense and settle disputes, but not sovereign over them.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: There is also the question of who, Your Majesty. The title of Duke of Granada would be the highest in the realm after the crown itself. Whoever receives it becomes the most powerful noble in Castile. This is not merely a financial decision.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will keep the current arrangement. It suits me fine. So, we have shaved off a lot of money. Looking at the income side of things, how are Diego's reforms coming along?

encounters.recap: King Juan II decides to drastically reduce the Granada garrison from 11,000 to just 50 soldiers stationed at the Alhambra, relying instead on feudal obligations from the new lords and Military Orders to defend the conquered territory. He also chooses not to create a Duke of Granada title, maintaining direct crown control over the wealthy province's revenues and administration.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will keep the current arrangement. It suits me fine. So, we have shaved off a lot of money. Looking at the income side of things, how are diego's reforms coming along?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza straightens with visible pride. This is his domain—the patient, unglamorous work of making the kingdom's finances function properly.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I am pleased to report that the reforms continue to bear fruit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He opens a separate ledger, one filled with his own meticulous notations.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Year one brought five thousand florins—modest, but we were establishing the infrastructure. Warehouses, customs officials, standardized tariffs. Year two shows significant growth. Málaga is becoming known as a reliable port. Genoese and Venetian merchants who previously sailed past now stop to trade. The Moorish merchant families who remained have proven... surprisingly cooperative. They know the trade routes; we provide stability.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: I project eight to ten thousand florins for 1434, possibly more if the winter storms do not disrupt shipping. By 1436 or 1437, we could see fifteen thousand annually if growth continues.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The Council system is working, Your Majesty. When nobles see their peers paying, when disputes are settled fairly, when cooperation brings tangible benefits... resistance fades.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The twenty-three thousand florins in improved compliance from 1433 appears to be holding. I expect similar returns this year—perhaps slightly higher as more houses recognize the new order is permanent.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The less glamorous work. But important. We have reduced corruption among collectors, standardized assessment methods, closed loopholes that allowed certain estates to underreport. The base crown revenue of one hundred seventy-nine thousand florins... I believe we can increase this by five to eight thousand annually through efficiency alone, without raising any tax rates.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: In sum, Your Majesty: the reforms are working. Slowly, steadily, without drama. The kingdom grows richer not through conquest or windfall, but through good administration.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Diego will never write songs about himself. But his ledgers have done more for Castile than many battles.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How are trade revenues coming along? These are always going to be crown revenue, not one of a noble lord.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is correct—customs, port duties, and trade tariffs are crown revenue by ancient right. No lord may levy them without explicit royal charter, and Your Majesty has granted no such charters.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The great prize. Gateway to the Atlantic, the wool trade with Flanders, trade with Portugal and England. Seville's customs generate approximately forty thousand florins annually—more than any other single source save the alcabala itself. This has been stable for years. Growth is possible if we improve harbor facilities, but Seville is already near capacity during peak trading seasons. Ships sometimes wait days to unload.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The new opportunity. As I mentioned, we began at five thousand florins in 1433. I project eight to ten thousand for 1434. But Málaga's potential is far greater. It is the natural gateway between the Mediterranean and the Castilian interior. Goods that now travel overland from Valencia or Barcelona could come through Málaga instead—if we build the roads and establish the reputation. In five years, with continued investment, Málaga could rival Seville. Twenty to thirty thousand florins annually is not impossible.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Total trade revenues across the kingdom: approximately seventy-eight to eighty thousand florins annually, Your Majesty. Of this, perhaps sixty-five thousand is stable and predictable. The remainder—particularly Málaga—is where growth lies.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And crucially, these revenues are crown revenues. They do not diminish when you grant lands to lords. A duke may collect rents from his peasants, but the customs at Málaga remain yours.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: This is why the Mediterranean commerce initiative matters so much, Your Majesty. Every florin invested in ports and trade infrastructure returns to the crown directly, without passing through noble hands.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Provide the trade income to me in a table

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza produces a fresh sheet of parchment and writes out the figures clearly for crown trade revenues across all major ports and sources.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The Málaga figure is conservative, Your Majesty. If the autumn shipping season proves strong, we may exceed ten thousand. And this is only the second year—the potential for growth remains substantial. Shall I include this breakdown in the formal 1434 accounts?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now make a list of the expenses of 1434

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza nods and begins drafting the expense ledger for 1434, incorporating the changes Juan has ordered.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the reduction of the Granada garrison alone saves the crown nearly twenty-five thousand florins. Total recurring expenses have fallen from one hundred twenty-five thousand to ninety thousand. Shall I compare this against projected revenues?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Now list the projected revenue

encounters.recap: Diego de Daza presents comprehensive progress reports on tax reforms and trade revenues. The Mediterranean commerce initiative shows growth from 5,000 to 8,000-10,000 florins, with Málaga emerging as a key port. Total crown trade revenues reach 86,000-88,000 florins annually. Military expense reductions, particularly the Granada garrison cut, save 25,000 florins, bringing recurring expenses down to 90,430 florins for 1434.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the reduction of the Granada garrison alone saves the crown nearly twenty-five thousand florins. Total recurring expenses have fallen from one hundred twenty-five thousand to ninety thousand. Shall I compare this against projected revenues?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza turns to a fresh page and begins compiling the revenue projections for 1434. He presents a comprehensive breakdown of crown revenues: base revenue of 179,094 florins, trade revenues of 87,000 florins, reform improvements of 30,000 florins, and noble taxation of 27,000 florins.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, if these projections hold, the kingdom's position is strong. A surplus of nearly one hundred eighty-seven thousand florins. Added to the treasury balance of three hundred seventy-one thousand from year-end 1433... The crown treasury would stand at approximately five hundred fifty-eight thousand florins by year-end 1434.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: A war chest, Your Majesty. Should you need it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But I also own some estates directly. And I have acquired all the estates of the infantes and have been optimizing them with Diego. Where are they included in these statements?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza freezes, his quill hovering over the parchment. A flush creeps up his neck.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... correct. I have not listed them separately.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Diego. Where are the royal estates in these accounts?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: They are... partially embedded in the base revenue figures, my lord. But Your Majesty is right to ask. The distinction matters. The traditional royal estates perhaps twelve to fifteen thousand florins annually. The Infantes' confiscated lands... these are more substantial. Perhaps thirty to forty thousand florins, now that the optimization work is showing results. Shall I prepare a complete accounting of all crown-held estates, Your Majesty? Separate from the tax revenues? It is work I should have done already.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego takes a fresh sheet and begins anew, creating a revised revenue statement that properly categorizes crown estates separately. Traditional royal estates generate 13,500 florins, while the confiscated Infantes' estates produce 35,000 florins. The revised total projected revenue for 1434 is 371,594 florins.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Over six hundred thousand florins, Your Majesty. I apologize for the earlier omission—the crown estates deserve proper tracking. With your permission, I will establish a separate ledger for estate revenues going forward.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This is a remarkable position for the kingdom. Your Majesty's father, God rest him, never saw half this sum in the treasury.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Diego, if we start a major investment program. Say 150,000 florins to improve infrastructure, ports, ships, roads, bridges or other investments, how would you go about this?

encounters.recap: Diego de Daza presents the 1434 financial review, initially projecting a treasury of 558,000 florins. When Juan points out missing estate revenues, Diego revises the accounting to properly include crown estates as a separate category, revealing a stronger position of over 606,000 florins. Juan then inquires about launching a major infrastructure investment program.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego sets down his quill, his earlier embarrassment replaced by evident satisfaction. "Over six hundred thousand florins, Your Majesty. I apologize for the earlier omission—the crown estates deserve proper tracking. With your permission, I will establish a separate ledger for estate revenues going forward."

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: This is a remarkable position for the kingdom. Your Majesty's father, God rest him, never saw half this sum in the treasury.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Diego, if we start a major investment program. Say 150,000 florins to improve infrastructure, ports ships, roads, bridges or other investments, how would you go about this?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Diego de Daza's eyes widen slightly. One hundred fifty thousand florins is an enormous sum—nearly half the annual revenue of the kingdom. But his administrator's mind is already working, and after a moment's thought, he begins to speak.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, an investment of this magnitude requires careful structure. Spent poorly, it vanishes like water into sand. Spent wisely... It transforms the kingdom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises and moves to a side table, retrieving a blank sheet of parchment. "I would approach this in four parts."

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Not all investments are equal. Some generate returns quickly; others take decades. Ports and customs infrastructure return money to the crown treasury directly. Every florin spent improving Málaga's harbor generates customs revenue for years to come. This is the highest priority.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: One hundred fifty thousand florins cannot be spent wisely in a single year. There are not enough skilled workers, not enough materials, not enough competent overseers. I would recommend a three-year program. Fifty thousand florins annually.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: This is where such programs fail, Your Majesty. Money flows from the treasury to intermediaries to contractors to workers—and at each step, it leaks. I would require independent inspectors who answer only to the crown, milestone payments released only when work is verified complete, and severe penalties for fraud.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The Military Orders have experience building fortifications. Their discipline might serve as a model—or their engineers could be borrowed for oversight.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Properly executed, Your Majesty, a one hundred fifty thousand florin investment program could add fifteen to twenty-five thousand florins in annual revenue within five years. The investment pays for itself within a decade, and then continues paying forever.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of employment, Your Majesty. Such a program puts men to work—masons, carpenters, laborers, carters. Men with wages spend money. Merchants profit. The alcabala collects its share. The benefits ripple outward.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty wishes, I can prepare a detailed proposal—specific projects, costs, timelines, expected returns. It would take me perhaps two weeks to do properly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets talk about expanding the fleet separately. I want to set up a fleet that can trade by transporting cargo and men, but can also function in a battle. Can carracks fit this role?

encounters.recap: Juan II proposes a massive 150,000 florin infrastructure investment program. Diego de Daza outlines a comprehensive strategy involving prioritized investment in ports, roads, and ships over three years with strict oversight. The discussion shifts to fleet expansion for dual trade and military purposes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets talk about expanding the fleet seperately. I want to set up a fleet that can trade by transporting cargo and men, but can also function in a battle. Can carracks fit this role?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council stirs at this shift in topic. Naval matters are not the strongest expertise at this table, but several members have relevant knowledge.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty built four carracks last year at considerable expense—fifty-eight thousand florins. They served well in transporting men to Constantinople and Naples. Captain Fernán, you sailed on them. What is your assessment?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The carracks are sturdy vessels, Your Majesty. They carried our men and horses safely through rough waters. The sailors speak well of them. But I am no naval expert. I can tell you how they feel under foot, not how they would perform in battle.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: In England, we use similar vessels—large sailing ships that carry cargo in peacetime and mount guns in war. The great ships of King Henry's fleet serve both purposes. But there are trade-offs. A ship built purely for war is faster, more maneuverable. A ship built purely for trade carries more cargo. The dual-purpose vessel does both, but excels at neither.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The Aragonese and Catalans have long experience in Mediterranean naval matters. King Alfonso maintains both galleys and round ships. Perhaps his admirals could advise...

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Each carrack cost approximately fourteen thousand florins to build, Your Majesty. They require crews of perhaps fifty to eighty men for sailing. In wartime, they would need additional soldiers—marines, gunners. The ongoing costs are substantial.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Perhaps we should hear what Your Majesty envisions. A fleet for what purpose? Trade with where? War against whom? The answers shape what vessels we need.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I need a fleet that can transport 15.000 men from Iberia to Constantinople. In one trip. If the sultan attacks we need this army to sail immediately to relieve the city. I want this fleet to be able to perform trade as well as be able to face the Ottoman navy in battle. Maybe build a fleet of mixed types?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council falls silent. The scale of what Juan proposes is staggering.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Fifteen thousand men in one voyage. Your Majesty, that is... an enormous undertaking. The largest fleet Castile has ever assembled.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: When King Henry invaded France, he required over a thousand ships to transport his army—though many were small vessels, fishing boats pressed into service. But the English Channel is narrow. Iberia to Constantinople is... weeks at sea. You need proper ocean-going vessels, not coastal craft. A large carrack can carry perhaps two hundred fifty to three hundred men in military transport conditions—crowded, uncomfortable, but feasible. For fifteen thousand men, you would need fifty to sixty carracks of good size. Plus horses. If you are transporting knights, you need horse transports. A carrack might carry thirty to forty horses, no more. Heavy cavalry requires many additional vessels.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The voyage itself is perilous. From Cádiz or Málaga to Constantinople—through the Strait of Gibraltar, along the Barbary coast, past Sicily, through waters controlled by Genoa, Venice, and the Ottomans themselves. Such a fleet would need escorts. Warships to protect the transports.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, if we assume sixty carracks at fourteen thousand florins each... that alone is eight hundred forty thousand florins. More than the entire treasury. And that is only the transports. Before escorts, before crews, before supplies.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asked about a mixed fleet. This is wise. Different vessels serve different purposes. Carracks—large, sturdy, can carry men and cargo. They mount guns and have high castles that make them difficult to board. In battle, they serve as floating fortresses. But they are slow, dependent on wind, and vulnerable to galleys in calm waters. Galleys—the weapon of Mediterranean war. Fast, maneuverable, independent of wind. The Ottomans use them extensively. But they cannot make the Atlantic voyage safely, they require enormous crews of rowers, and they carry little cargo. Galleasses—a compromise. Larger than galleys, they combine oars and sails. Venice uses them. They can fight and carry modest cargo. But they are expensive and complex. A fleet to do what Your Majesty describes would need all three types, I think. Carracks for transport and heavy combat. Galleys for battle and protecting the carracks in calm waters. Perhaps smaller vessels—caravels, pinnaces—for scouting and communication.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I have seen the Ottoman galleys from the deck of our carracks. They are fast—terrifyingly fast. If they catch a carrack becalmed, they swarm it like wolves on a wounded stag. But if the wind is with you, a carrack's guns can shatter a galley before it closes. The question is always the wind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council looks to Juan, awaiting direction. The questions hang in the air: How many ships of each type? Built where? Crewed by whom? At what cost? Over what timeframe?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is not realistic. Lets allocate 200.000 florins to naval expansion. I want to build my own ships myself using the most modern techniques and develop our own expertise in building them. But before we do so, it becomes apparent to me that me miss an important figure in this council. I need an admiral who knows what he is doing and who can lead this big investment effort. Diego, put aside 200.000 florins for naval investment. And we allocate 40.000 florins for the coming 5 years to improve infrastructure and some other improvement projects.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes an ambitious naval expansion program to transport 15,000 men to Constantinople if needed. The council discusses the technical challenges of mixed fleets, comparing carracks, galleys, and galleasses. After realizing the initial scale is unrealistic, Juan allocates 200,000 florins for naval expansion and recognizes the need for an experienced admiral to lead the effort.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is not realistic. Lets allocate 200.000 florins to naval expansion. I want to build my own ships myself using the most modern techniques and develop our own expertise in building them. But before we do so, it becomes apparent to me that me miss an important figure in this council. I need an admiral who knows what he is doing and who can lead this big investment effort. Diego, put aside 200.000 florins for naval investment. And we allocate 40.000 florins for the coming 5 years to improve infrastructure and some other improvement projects. Also, can we look at the workshops that are here in Castille? I know we produce a lot of iron. Can we build more workshops that make tools and weapons from it?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Two hundred thousand florins reserved for naval expansion, to be spent under the direction of a competent admiral. Forty thousand florins annually for infrastructure improvements over five years. That is four hundred thousand florins committed over the period—substantial, but the treasury can bear it, particularly with the surplus we are generating.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is wise to seek expertise before spending. A fleet built by landsmen is a fleet built poorly. Castile has capable ship captains—men who know the Atlantic trade, the fishing grounds, the route to Flanders. But a true admiral? One who understands fleet tactics, shipyard management, naval architecture? We have not fought a major naval war in living memory. Our expertise lies on land.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The Aragonese have such men. King Alfonso's admirals have fought in the Mediterranean for generations. Perhaps he could lend us an expert, or recommend a man willing to enter Castilian service.

exchanges.speaker: thomas_beaumont
exchanges.text: The Genoese are the finest shipbuilders in Christendom. Their admirals command fleets across the known world. A Genoese captain seeking new employment might bring both expertise and connections to shipwrights.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: There are also the Portuguese. Prince Henry—they call him the Navigator—has been building ships and training captains at Sagres for years. They explore the African coast, develop new vessel designs. A Portuguese naval man would know modern techniques. Shall I make inquiries, Your Majesty? Discreetly, to determine who might be available and suitable?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is correct that Castile produces abundant iron. The Basque country—Vizcaya, Guipúzcoa—has mines and foundries that have operated for centuries. Bilbao exports iron ingots across Europe. But Your Majesty identifies a weakness. We export raw iron and import finished goods—tools, weapons, armor, nails, fittings. The profit in transformation goes to foreign smiths. Toledo already has a reputation for fine swordsmithing—the espadas toledanas are prized throughout Christendom. But this is artisan work, small workshops producing luxury goods. What Your Majesty describes is different—large workshops producing tools and weapons in quantity.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The Military Orders maintain their own armories. Calatrava especially has skilled smiths who produce weapons and armor for the knights. Perhaps their methods could be expanded.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: If we established royal workshops—manufacturas reales—near the iron sources in the north, we could produce standardized tools, weapons, ship fittings, nails by the thousands. The iron travels a short distance to the workshop; the finished goods travel to markets across the kingdom and beyond. But this requires expertise we do not fully possess. Master smiths who understand large-scale production. Investment in water-powered hammers, proper forges, storage facilities. Perhaps we could recruit master craftsmen from abroad? Flanders, Germany, Milan—these places have developed such industries. A few skilled masters could train Castilian apprentices.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: So we need an admiral for the fleet, and master smiths for the workshops. Your Majesty builds a kingdom that requires expertise Castile does not yet possess.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will ask if Alfonso can send me an officer to serve as my admiral. I miss the expertise. We also recruit experts from abroad to set up these smithies for both naval supplies and weapons. Invite them to come before my court and I will give them a royal grant and funds to set these workshops up.

encounters.recap: Juan II commits 200,000 florins to naval expansion and 40,000 florins annually for infrastructure development. The council discusses the need for foreign expertise: an admiral from Aragon to lead the naval program, and master craftsmen from abroad to establish royal workshops for large-scale production of tools and weapons, transforming Castile from an exporter of raw iron to a producer of finished goods.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council stirs with interest. This is a question that touches on the future prosperity of the kingdom. Diego de Daza practically glows—this is precisely the kind of strategic thinking he lives for.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks the right question. A kingdom that exports raw materials and imports finished goods will always be poorer than one that transforms its own resources.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: This is our greatest untapped opportunity, Your Majesty. Castilian merino wool is the finest in Europe—Flemish and Italian weavers pay premium prices for it. But we sell them the wool, and they sell us back the cloth at three times the price.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Segovia already has some textile production. The infrastructure exists; it is the skill that is lacking.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: A royal textile manufactory in Segovia, staffed with Flemish masters training Castilian apprentices... within a decade, we could be producing cloth for domestic consumption. Within two decades, perhaps for export.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Córdoba. The cordobanes and guadamecíes—Córdoban leather—are already famous throughout Europe. This industry exists and thrives.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_cerezuela
exchanges.text: Granada. The Moors cultivated silk in Granada for centuries. Mulberry groves, silkworm farms, weaving workshops. When Your Majesty conquered the emirate, you inherited this industry.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: The crown already holds the salt monopoly. But we could do more with it. The Atlantic fisheries—cod, sardines—are enormous.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: On campaign, salted fish is worth its weight in silver. A reliable supply would strengthen any military expedition.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: So we have opportunities in textiles, leather, silk, salted fish, paper, ceramics, and shipbuilding. All require some combination of capital investment, foreign expertise, and patient development.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will develop all these industries at once. But in an organized way. I will indeed include a Junta de manufacturas and have a representative attend our Toledo council.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets reserve 6000 florins to fund these industries for now. Include a donation of 5000 each to the military orders. I have more tasks for them.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_daza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the accounts for 1434 are complete. Your Majesty, even after setting aside two hundred thousand florins for the naval expansion—money that remains in the treasury but committed to a specific purpose—we retain nearly three hundred fifty thousand florins in available funds. The kingdom has never been wealthier.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The reduction of the Granada garrison alone saves twenty-five thousand florins annually. The reforms pay for themselves many times over.

encounters.recap: Juan II establishes a comprehensive manufacturing development plan for Castile, creating a Junta de Manufacturas to oversee expansion of textile, leather, silk, salt, paper, ceramics, glass, and shipbuilding industries. The council identifies specific opportunities including Segovia textiles, Córdoba leather, Granada silk recovery, and Atlantic salted fish production. The king allocates 6,000 florins for industrial development and 5,000 florins each to military orders, while Diego de Daza presents the complete 1434 budget showing a treasury surplus of nearly 346,000 florins after expenses.
